0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19544/homepage_large.f5c2ba74.jpg|Move Way EP|31550.0|dBridge|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['R&S']|2013-08-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:34.116557|"

Drum and bass musician dBridge has been making music for some two decades-- both solo and as part of drum and bass supergroup Bad Company-- and he might as well keep going for another two or three. The man born Darren White has been at it long after the genre went through its initial early cycle: experimental beginnings
column2: urgent development
column3: mainstream crossover
column4: post-trendiness deconstruction
column5: and being re-niched back to urgent development again. That's afforded him the sort of later-career freedom that happens to be accompanied by steady quality and the occasional revelation. He's switched up styles as often as he's tweaked his alias' structure; the D-Bridge that gave the mid 90s masses hardstepping junglist tracks like ""Let That Shit Ride"" and ""Bring Da Flava"" is a fair distance away from the more R&B-tinged dark ambient of early 10s dBridge a la ""Love Hotel"" and ""So Lonely"".

column1: If that means he's got multiple audiences of varying investments to try and satisfy
column2: his EP-length releases often do a good job of showing off all his facets
column3: from the downtempo excursions to the classic drum and bass he never really abandoned. Move Way
column4: dBridge's new EP and his first for the evergreen R&S label
column5: puts a strong focus on his efforts to maintain the structural integrity and rhythmic impact of drum and bass while pushing its forms outward from the template-driven repetition he's spent his post-Bad Company career trying to counterbalance. His recent approach with the Autonomic label/podcast/dance night established a space for minimal
column6: half-step takes on the style.

column1: But Move Way isn't quite as out there
column2: at least on its first two tracks. The title cut
column3: a co-production with Exit Records roster member Skeptical
column4: pushes 170 on a driving triple-kick pattern riddled with crisp snares. Despite its sawn-off feel-- its sharp
column5: trebly drums and bright rhythmic counterpoints  feel constructed to let a dynamic range shine through
column6: rather than charging headfirst into bassbin-quaking territory--  it still hits a dancefloor mark pretty close to the intense post-jungle complexity of the late 90s. Cerebral aggression is still aggression
column7: and the recurring sample of a fired-up Peter Tosh discussing the liberation of pissed-off epithets doesn't hurt any. ""Death of a Drum Machine"" is even more of a throwback
column8: if a line-blurring one: its airy spaces and hi-hat heavy beats are just a 70s soul-jazz lick or two away from evoking the cool fusion of 97/98 era sides by LTJ Bukem or Photek
column9: but they charge ahead as hard as anything Moving Shadow put out five years previous. Any charges of retrograde pandering should be tempered by the fact that this music
column10: being in line with the genre's great innovators
column11: is still kicking against the dumbing-down of drum and bass
column12: even if on familiar terms.

column1: At the end of the EP
column2: dBridge offers a cut that scratches the itch that his more ambient recent singles might have created. ""Plain to See"" is given the same wide-open negative spaces as his other half-step tracks
column3: sculpted from click-track beats snapped into scattered form. Creeping synthesizer chords pierced with sharp
column4: stark notes add to the intricacy of what initially sounds like a simple
column5: sparse rhythm. When the beat finally builds to its full shape
column6:
it unspools into another nuanced exhibition of what he's been mastering in his drive to reinstate drum and bass' creative curiosity.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19568/homepage_large.b75bdb43.jpg|Back on the Planet|31572.0|Ras G|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brainfeeder']|2013-08-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:34.945853|"

L.A.’s avant-garde beats scene boasts a high concentration of giddy eccentricity. There are such characters as its poster boy Flying Lotus
column2: the dispensary-fueled scion of a radically progressive musical family
column3: and the bassist Thundercat
column4: who’s singlehandedly propping up the few remaining pieces of jazz funk’s credibility. And then there’s Gregory Shorter
column5: Jr.
column6: aka Ras G
column7: who might be the furthest out of all of them. The inheritor of an Afrofuturistic musical tradition passed down from Sun Ra and George Clinton
column8: Shorter is the head (and apparently sole member) of something called the Afrikan Space Program. He's seemingly on a mission to gather gather up the best elements of a half-century of revolutionary black music and launch them into a utopian sci-fi alternate dimension of his own devising.

column1: His latest salvo is called Back on the Planet
column2: but it doesn’t feel like the work of an entirely earthbound artist. The opening title track shows off both Shorter’s artistic ambition and his formidable technical skills
column3: with a convincing electronic emulation of the organic
column4: frenetic crackle of an Ornette Coleman free jazz cut that evolves into a mass of irregular drumming
column5: squealing synths
column6: and layers of noise. It sounds like someone’s packed Coleman up in a rickety Apollo module and launched him into low earth orbit.

column1: Back on the Planet spends its first few tracks focused on setting moods and generally avoiding the concerns of melody and steady rhythm. There are soothing arrangements of gently pulsing drums
column2: echo-blurred keys
column3: and the occasional sub-bass boom. Bits of roots reggae drift by
column4: along with ambient waves of analog synthesizer
column5: clips of audio lifted from movies or TV
column6: and a lot of sounds that aren’t so easy to place. The songs don’t really go anywhere
column7: but they don’t need to-- it’s the psychic tone that matters
column8: not any sort of hooks
column9: and the blissful state they produce comes from simply enjoying them in the moment.

column1: It’s not until “_G Spot Connection” that the sounds start to cohere into something resembling the rap beats that Shorter is ostensibly a producer of. Once he gets focused
column2: though
column3: he stays that way
column4: and the rest of Planet’s 16 tracks consist of the most radical beat deconstructions of his career. “OMMMMM” sounds like vintage Cali rap with all of the drum samples swapped out for assorted snippets of field recordings. “One 4 Kutmah” and “Been Cosmic” take throwback breakbeats and bury them under layers of raw synthesizer freakout. The minute and a half standout “Culture Riddim” revolves around a throbbing synthesizer and what sounds like a sample of someone filling a glass with water.

column1: As freaky as Shorter's compositions get
column2: they still knock hard like rap beats should. It’s a little hard to imagine cruising the streets blasting something like “Natural Melanin Being”
column3: where where the tempo not-so-subtly speeds up and slows down every couple bars
column4: but it would be a sufficiently trunk-rattling experience.

column1: When the L.A. beats scene first broke out with a wider audience
column2: its popularity spiked exponentially and it looked for a minute like that it might being in danger of burning out
column3:
its wild experimental edge and deep vein of genuine weirdness diluted by a legion of imitators. But Back on the Planet is proof that its vanguard is still out there-- way out there-- pushing themselves into ever wilder territory. 

"|18373.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18373-ras-g-back-on-the-planet/|7.8|Miles Raymer

Solo acts boast a few benefits: There’s less gear to tote and less ways to split whatever loot might come of a release or a tour. Scheduling band practice is easy enough
column2: and your group doesn’t break up if you decide you’re living in the wrong town. But the essential asset of starting and running your own group is that there’s no one to tell about the music-- no need to explain to anyone how the guitar tone should shift mid-song
column3: no need to annotate lyrics for someone who didn’t write them
column4: and no need to compromise when the rest of the group either doesn’t agree or simply doesn’t get it. The calls are yours alone.

column1: The previous output from the deceptively sunny-named post-punk/black metal belligerents Raspberry Bulbs-- a string of short-run cassettes and 2011’s menacing debut LP
column2: Nature Tries Again-- thrived on just such an unequivocal solo approach. Known as He Who Crushes Teeth in his corrosive black metal duo Bone Awl
column3: Marco del Rio spat distorted vitriol over identifiably one-man-band arrangements as Raspberry Bulbs. On Nature Tries Again
column4: simplistic
column5: rubbery bass lines bounced between basic rock rhythms
column6: bashing out time beneath blown-out guitar blisters. The draw was del Rio’s voice
column7: a nasty
column8: weaponized thing that seemed frustrated enough to put the whole world on notice. It was bleak
column9: bothered
column10: and strangely appealing
column11: the kind of thing you wanted to turn up until it hurt. Del Rio’s words were generally indecipherable
column12: a product not only of his unrepentant screams but also of the crude
column13: lo-fi production. But his lyrics
column14: or at least his intentions with them
column15: felt immediately clear. They were stark transmissions from a veteran black metal dude
column16: offering his serrated invective over an atavistic punk plod.

column1: Deformed Worship is
column2: by name
column3: the second album from Raspberry Bulbs
column4: but it’s the first one to feature a five-member lineup. A two-guitar quartet surrounds del Rio now
column5: and the band’s good enough that the former multi-tasker can concentrate only on his murderous bark. The new outfit alters the way that Raspberry Bulbs both structure songs and present them: Only one of nine tracks on Nature Tries Again
column6: for instance
column7: broke the three-minute mark
column8: while less than half of Deformed Worship’s nine numbers don’t. “By the Root” stops just shy of six minutes. “Lusty Climbing” keys on a legitimate
column9: compelling bridge. And this is now a group interacting with one another in a room in real-time
column10: meaning that the bass finds the groove and that the guitars are able to trace more than the basic pattern of a riff
column11: with harmonies and counters and stop-time pauses. Toward the end of audacious opener “Cracked Flesh
column12: ” there’s even a shift in tone
column13: making it clear that these are more than malevolent
column14: monochromatic tirades-- they’re
column15: like
column16: legitimate songs played by a well-prepared quintet.

column1: Perhaps that sounds problematic. Raspberry Bulbs
column2: after all
column3: are engulfed with a feeling
column4: and shifting from a one-person outfit to a full band is an evolution historically fraught with peril-- the new people simply don’t get the project’s essence in the same way as the person who has fostered it from the start. But this band
column5: featuring ex-members of Rorschach and Italian Horn
column6: does. Though the expanded lineup has affected Raspberry Bulbs’ delivery
column7: it has not changed their spirit. “When a Lie Becomes the Truth” flirts with the thought of suicide as a safe harbor from unfaithfulness
column8: and the band sounds as resolutely anxious and irascible as del Rio. It’s as if they studied the script of Deformed Worship
column9: familiarized themselves with its misery and
column10: like method actors
column11: prepared themselves to wallow in it
column12: too. “Wild Inside” is a teenage tantrum writ large
column13: with del Rio churning childlike turmoil into a seemingly endless vortex; the band responds by keeping it simple
column14: dumb
column15: and angry
column16: joining his pout until they collectively snap out of it. What’s best
column17: all of the new moving parts and increased dynamics give del Rio more space to broadcast his burdens
column18: letting the inchoate frontman shade his screams with a little subtlety. Those first-impact feelings are still there; you don’t need to follow along to intuit that the half-hardcore sprint of “Lusty Climbing” is about rejection in the midst of abject despair. That much is clear in the sound of his voice alone. But his howls take narrative shape now
column19: adding gravity to what was before only a quick if painful punch to the gut.

column1: Though their were indeed melodies pancaked beneath the din
column2: it’d have been a stretch to call much of anything by Raspberry Bulbs two years ago “catchy.” But on Deformed Worship
column3: both “Standing in Line” and “Groping the Angel’s Face” push toward poppy
column4: with guitar lines as sharp as talons and production that allows the vocals to function as more than a misanthropic haze. This is one of those rarified full-band transitions
column5: then
column6: where nothing seems to suffer. Rather than losing any of their earlier power through translation
column7: Raspberry Bulbs have instead found a way to broadcast the same brood for a bigger return. Turn it up again
column8: and this time
column9: sing along to the sulk
column10:
rather than simply soak in it.

Steve Arrington is one of the great underheralded figures in funk
column3: a drummer/vocalist who transitioned from lounge acts to gigs with the Escovedos before joining the Dayton funk band Slave for a five-year stretch of hitmaking. After a successful solo career stretching through most of the 80s
column4: he left the business at the turn of the 90s for the ministry
column5: about the same time as g-funk was starting to mine his catalog for inspiration and a kid from Pasadena named Damon Riddick was traversing over that same turf for his own early demos. The lineage is so clear and traceable that pairing up Dâm-Funk with the recently unretired Arrington seems like an intersection of a no-brainer homage and a dream come true. Anyone who's heard classics like “Just a Touch of Love
column6: ” “Weak at the Knees”
column7: or “Dancin' in the Key of Life” can probably picture how natural and comfortable it'd sound for Arrington to jam over the spaced-out
column8: smooth-gliding bounce of the style that made Toeachizown so immersive. Played straight and aiming right for the retro-funk bullseye would probably result in one of the most effortlessly crowdpleasing throwback records of the year.

column1: That's not quite what they did. Higher is messier than that
column2: and weirder
column3: and ultimately more ambitious. Instead of a straightforward selection of boogie jams that effortlessly recall 1982 and leave it at that
column4: Arrington and Riddick put together something spontaneous
column5: potentially polarizing
column6: and joyously strange. Arrington's lost none of his range or power over the years
column7: and he sounds instantly recognizable as the same man who laid a rubbery
column8: often unearthly voice over tracks three decades ago. But he willfully goes off on odd tangents and improvised-sounding flights
column9: spends a bit of time dodging a traditional on-the-one delivery for a more off-beat performance
column10: and overall treats Dâm-Funk's backing track more like a suggestion to be elaborated on than an authoritative
column11: meter-driving pulse. This is that rare record where the singer beats all the critics in the race to call a sound “angular”-- “that angular approach that's so funky and new
column12: ” to be specific
column13: as he points out on “Tap That.” It's a phrase that touches on all the quirks and brow-furrowing curveballs that come with that territory.

column1: Granted
column2: it's not that out of character for Dâm-Funk
column3: though it does seem less experimental than he's been of late. Keeping in mind some of his more daring post-Toeachizown work
column4: from his amped-up yet faithful cover of Human League's “Things That Dreams Are Made Of” to last year's New Wave-via-Minneapolis jam “I Don't Wanna Be a Star
column5: ” this feels a bit more like a reversion to still-funky
column6: but less eclectic
column7: turf. That means a lot of similar tempos
column8: boom-clap drum machine patterns
column9: and flowing chords-- sounds that barely stray from the Toeachizown palette-- and the musical simplicity threatens to fall into a droning sort of repetition
column10: albeit a pleasant one. On the bright side
column11: it never actually drags
column12: and the production's still a good complement: it feels like Dâm-Funk decided to cede the spotlight to Arrington
column13: leaving his work to buoy Arrington's voice
column14: give him a springboard to riff off
column15: and leaving the more eccentric touches to the singer himself.

column1: And this is where Higher really shines: this is a genuinely sincere
column2: silly
column3: joyous record that seems difficult to actually look down at. What it sometimes lacks in heavy groove and get-down raunch it makes up for in sheer enthusiasm and unpredictability; “the beats tend to sound the same” is less of a concern when they're all glimmering and elated to such effective ends. This album has been in the works for something like three years
column4: but it sounds like it was thrown together off-the-cuff over a weekend by two musicians with a lot of good
column5: pent-up ideas. That's to its benefit
column6: and it makes the giddiness feel extra-human. Arrington has a short monologue in the middle of “I Love This Music” where he mentions how how people tell him how his style keeps changing after all this time. “Yeah
column7: ” he explains
column8: “I think like a jazz musician.” Then he lets out this non-verbal string of rapidfire rhythmic scatting that sounds too internalized to be just a mess-around joke
column9: even if he caps it off with a rimshot.

column1: There's a real spiritual vibe that Arrington brings to the table
column2: too
column3: albeit laid out in secular terms
column4: and he seems more like he's ruminating or meditating than singing sometimes. The ceaseless positivity of the lucid memory-banking “Good Feeling” (“I remember Little League baseball
column5: yo/ How the bases were pure white
column6: and the grass was electric green”)
column7: the brightly refracting refrains of love-song “Magnificent""
column8:
“I Be Goin' Hard' and its “stuck on stooo-pid” defiance filtered through deliberately cartoonish runs that toy with his virtuoso range-- it's somewhere between being church and being #based.

Ask Edward Sharpe
column2: and he'll tell you: all you need is love
column3: and-- you got it-- love is all you need. Roughly half the songs on Edward Sharpe & the Magnetic Zeros-- the economy sized L.A. troupe's self-titled third LP-- find Sharpe and company singing about love; not just romance
column4: but a bigger kind of love
column5: a force for good in this mean old world of ours. Radiating positivity from every pore
column6: Sharpe's looking to melt cynicism
column7: to stick a daisy in your gunbarrel
column8: to turn that frown upside down. The onetime Imarobot frontman's transformation from dance-punker Alex Ebert to vibe-peddler Edward Sharpe has taken him well past the point of no return. Where the group's 2009 debut
column9: Up From Below
column10: sounds like a tentative first step toward guru status
column11: everything since that shaky debut suggests Sharpe plans to don those flowing robes for the duration.

column1: Melodically
column2: the Zeros keep things on the up-and-up; the arrangements are spacious
column3: often downright sprightly
column4: and by the time the second chorus rolls around
column5: you'll have the whole thing down cold. And though the generously applied harmonies still sound straight outta 1967 California
column6: everything else seems to be gunning for a kind of Beatlesy universality: were it not for names like ""Let's Get High"" or lyrics about jackin' it to Miriam Makeba (no
column7: really)
column8: you could teach these songs to a class of kindergarteners. But you know how they always let Ringo sing the easy ones? The ones that they actually do teach to kindergarteners? The Zeros' third LP feels like an album made up almost entirely entirely of Ringo songs: bouncy
column9: spirited
column10: and knock-you-over-the-head obvious
column11: a Raffi for the Bonnaroo set.

column1: But it's not the music that sinks Edward Sharpe & the Magnetic Zeros
column2: it's those lyrics: well-intentioned
column3: certainly
column4: but as deep as the bowl on a one-hitter. Love is all around
column5: and you can hear it everywhere: on ""Let's Get High"" (""…on love
column6: ba-dum-ching)
column7: on ""Two!"" (""if we sing together
column8: love will sing along"")
column9: again on ""Please!"" (""hear me love
column10: see me love""). No matter the song
column11: the message never seems to change: love good
column12: hate bad. Even the best song here
column13: a bluesy solo turn from the underutilized
column14: whiskey-and-ginger-voiced Jade Castrinos called ""Remember to Remember""
column15: can't go by without throwing out a little ""praise to love."" I can't help but think of David Byrne here: say something once
column16: why say it again? On LP3
column17: Sharpe and the Zeros take their message of positivity uber alles and run it so far into the ground
column18: it's positively wearying.

column1: Not that Sharpe fares a whole lot better with a subject change. Opener ""Better Days"" finds him railing against ""some cliché shit"" that makes him ""wanna cry""; a bit rich
column2: when you've got a chorus like ""try to remember that you can't forget."" ""Ain't we all just Japanese when we're high"" is either baffling nonsense or offensive. And turning the late
column3: great Miriam Makeba into some object of lust oozes something that sure ain't charm. ""War is the ego of man's repressed libido
column4: Sharpe sings on ""Please!"" Bet you didn't know your libido even had an ego.

column1: LP3 centerpiece ""Life Is Hard"" finds Sharpe taking up the existential longview: ""you will not be called a weakling or a fraud
column2: he sings
column3: ""for feeling the pain of the whole wide world."" But moments like these-- when Sharpe swaps out the moony-eyed mantras for what feels like genuine reflection-- aren't easy to come by amidst the record's gloopy sloganeering. It's not enough that he keeps trying to hammer the same point home (""be good to yourselves
column4: and each other
column5: more or less); he's gotta yowl it into your ear until you've got no other choice but to submit. And ""ain't love grand"" isn't exactly a new idea
column6: and ""we don't have to talk
column7: let's dance"" isn't much of a worldview. I'm sure Sharpe's heart is in the right place-- he won't stop saying it is
column8: anyway-- but my heart needs relatin'
column9:
not platitudes.

Consider the following: Arcade Fire
column2: Broken Social Scene
column3: Feist
column4: Grizzly Bear. I don’t think it’s much of a stretch to assume you either like these bands or at least are willing to acknowledge them as the ruling class of no-qualifiers indie rock. Now
column5: what if you saw that list on someone’s dating profile? Would you have a positive impression of this person? Conversely
column6: what if a band used that list to point out their primary influences? Would you have a negative impression of this band? Would you consider them frontrunners or unambitious or lacking curiosity? They should at least be able to play the game and acknowledge Berlin-era Bowie or mid-90s Mariah Carey
column7: right? The Belle Game aren’t trying to fool anyone: those are the influences slapped on their Facebook page and Ritual Tradition Habit proudly manifests the effect those bands had on the Vancouver quintet. But while Belle Game have taken a lot of cues from the sound of those bands
column8: more importantly
column9: they aspire to the ideal of being a critical and popular darling without sounding cool-- Ritual is unerringly tuneful and tasteful
column10: with confident vocals
column11: meticulous craftsmanship and no fear of being seen as middlebrow. In short
column12: it could’ve come out any time in the past decade and sound just as good as it does in 2013.

column1: The irony is that Ritual is something of a grower as a result of being so familiar. You might think you have “River” and “Wait Up For You” pegged within their first minute. Free of context
column2: the choruses broad pleas based on their titles
column3: “I’ve been your river since we were kids
column4: ” “I’ll wait up for you.” “River” begins with a waltz-timed flurry of chalkdust guitars that have to be from a Walkmen song you can’t quite recall; the intro of “Wait Up For You” is so reminiscent of Fleet Foxes’ “Ragged Wood” that you might just sing the “whoooooooa!” harmonies out of habit.

column1: Any skepticism or accusations of theft are done away with pretty quickly
column2: as singer Andrea Lo is the opposite of a “secret weapon
column3: more of a demonstration of just how rare a commanding
column4: powerful vocal presence is in this realm. It isn’t long before “River” and “Wait Up For You” generate enough velocity for liftoff
column5: and the choruses don’t explode so much as slowly levitate and expand with Lo’s vocals guiding the way. No amount of artfully scuffed filters or small-screen production touches can hide that Lo’s a performer through and through
column6: someone who could just as easily have been an R&B powerhouse or at least doing some off Broadway material.

column1: For all the sonic immediacy
column2: it doesn’t take much digging to get to Ritual’s dark roots. The chorus of “River” uses its titular metaphor in a disturbing way-- Lo empathizes with a place where bodies and secrets are dumped. “Wait Up For You” might sound like breathless infatuation
column3: but the narrator appears to be at the mercy of a drunk lover or an absentee father
column4: where the waiting is futile and endless. Lo’s lyrics are in such plainspoken language and the music so instantly accessible that you can easily miss Ritual dealing entirely in the wages of sin: prostitution
column5: abuse
column6: heartbreak
column7: the list goes on. It’s hardly alone in its occasional Fleetwood Mac worship
column8: but more than most bands
column9: Belle Game zeroes in on the codependency and desperation in the lyrics.

column1: Still
column2: nearly everything here gives you a brief glimpse of who they could possibly open for in the upcoming months. As with “River” and “Wait Up For You”
column3: many songs here could pass for a populist indie version of what the Field did on From Here We Go Sublime
column4: in reverse; the “reveal” of the source material happens at the beginning rather than the end. You’ll catch the clacking rhythms and broad harmonies of early Local Natives (“Wasted Light”
column5: “Blame Fiction”)
column6: skeletal guitar figures cloaked in reverb a la the xx and airy vocal runs taken from various Beach House songs. They gamely cover their tracks by making good on their “dark-pop” descriptor: “In Secrets” incorporates an intense orchestral swell more reminiscent of Montreal’s late-90s post-rock than its mid-00s indie
column7: while “Salt + Water” is caked with oxidized distortion. Less convicing are the three interludes which intend to give the record some conceptual framework (“Ritual”
column8: “Tradition”
column9: “Habit”)
column10: but end up stunting its momentum instead.

column1: Ritual ultimately brings to mind some phrase whose source I can't recall
column2: it could've been a famous musician or just someone at a party: “it’s really easy for a band to be unpopular.” It’s a variant on poptimism
column3: an acknowledgment that screaming over guitar ran through five effects pedals isn’t necessarily easier than writing a three-chord jingle. Belle Game shouldn’t be commended just because they’re not trying to be an improvisational noise band or what have you. But there is something weirdly daring about Ritual-- there’s no narrative
column4: no currency
column5: just an arguably naïve trust that they can draw you in with familiarity and let the strength of the musicianship and the depth of the lyrics win the day. It’s especially charming as the O.C. celebrates its 10th anniversary and causes many of us to look back with both warm nostalgia and a twinge of embarrassment at a time when polite
column6: melodic and sync-able indie rock was indie rock. And for the most part it works; the fact that Ritual would sound good had it come out in 2004
column7:
2008 or 2010 means it’s going to sound good in 2014 and beyond.

Like its kissing cousins garage rock and punk
column2: power pop was once synonymous with the sound
column3: spirit
column4: and uproarious stink of youth. Then something happened. Those who made it got older. Those who listened to it got older. What once sounded hormonally ephemeral became swept up in the stately ebb and flow of nostalgia. To his credit
column5: New Orleans’ King Louie Bankston has always represented the most timeless aspects of this cyclical renewal-- In his numerous bands over the past 20 years he’s played garage rock
column6: and he’s played punk
column7: and he’s played power-pop. It’s power-pop
column8: however
column9: that he’s landed back at. Although his best-known group in the 90s
column10: the Royal Pendletons
column11: exuded paint-peeling garage gunk
column12: they were once produced by power-pop royalty Alex Chilton. His one-off project Bad Times was snarling
column13: spit-flecked punk rock
column14: but it also gave an up-and-coming power-pop master
column15: the late Jay Reatard
column16: some extra momentum. Then
column17:
as a member of the Exploding Hearts-- which Bankston just before the band’s deadly accident in 2003-- he helped reconstitute power-pop for future hook-slingers and jangle-mongers.

With the Exploding Hearts’ tragedy still looming in his rearview-- he told the Times-Picayune in 2011
column18: “It took a long time for me to go back to doing that kind of music after that”-- Bankston’s current power-pop outfit Missing Monuments released its debut Painted White. Like its predecessor
column19: the self-titled sophomore album evokes Stiff Records’ late-70s power-pop classicists Nick Lowe and particularly Wreckless Eric
column20: whose wide-eyed
column21: stripped-to-the-bone romanticism oozes from the Missing Monuments ballads “Super Hero” and “Tru Luv"". If only the whole album retained that kind of consistency. Granted
column22: there’s plenty of room for eclecticism under the power-pop umbrella-- but tracks such as “I Don’t Share” lean closer toward Something Fierce’s recent mix of catchy 70s punk and arty proto-wave
column23:
to the point where Bankston’s solo-happy guitarist Julien Fried does his prickly best to pay tribute to Voidoids-era Robert Quine.

The influences continue to fly
column24: up to and including Bankston’s credible Stiv Bators impersonation-- gluey yelps and all-- on “Grizzly Star"". But the songs are also torn in another direction: the recent wave of twangy Southern power-pop led by Gentlemen Jesse and His Men
column25: a band partially inspired by Bankston’s past work in the first place. For someone as versatile as Bankston
column26: it’s an admirable effort to shove as much stuff he loves onto a single full-length. But his gruff vocals
column27: besides veering in style from track to track
column28: don’t always hit the melody they’re reaching for. “Another Girl” is among Missing Monuments’ stronger showings
column29: a singsong jingle about exactly what it advertises
column30: complete with ripping leads and carbonated bassline. It’s also
column32: one of the few songs on the album that even attempt to embody the perpetual pimple-squeezing of power-pop. (Then again
column33: it’s sung by drummer Aaron Hill
column34: not Bankston.) Now in his forties
column35: the wizened and world-weary frontman doesn’t try to fake the trapped-in-amber adolescence of his latest chosen genre-- He owns every inch of his age. It makes Missing Monuments a more soulful expression of power-pop timelessness
column36:
if not always an even one.

If the title of The Nextwave Sessions isn’t doing a whole lot for you
column3: that’s completely understandable. It’s the kind of literal
column4: placeholder name usually stamped upon a stopgap release
column5: “fans only
column6: move along.” But let’s get a little Dan Brown with this and crack the code: Sessions. Wave. Next. These words suggest regularly scheduled studio gatherings
column7: impetus
column8: a future. How are we supposed to interpret this when Bloc Party just finished off the biggest tour of their career with the announcement of an indefinite and possibly infinite hiatus? Is the urgency and quick turnaround of The Nextwave Sessions an indication that we should keep the faith
column9: that Bloc Party is in a refractory period following a triumphant and prolific past two years? Or are they taking advantage of a surplus of inspiration and momentum to go out on a high note?

column1: Amongst other things
column2: Nextwave shares that jumbled sense of purpose with its predecessor. On Four
column3: Bloc Party returned after a contentious four-year break with conflicting agendas: it was a record that went to great lengths to prove it was effortless
column4: an attempt to convey vigor by rehashing their old sound. By default
column5: Nextwave is less scattered and more consistent: It’s only five songs. But “Ratchet” indicates that Bloc Party could’ve gone way further off the grid if they gave themselves enough time.

column1: There’s a perverse thrill in hearing what is almost certainly the worst song Bloc Party could write and still be proud enough to include on a commercially available recording. It’s easy to see how “Ratchet” appeals to Bloc Party-- honed throughout their Four tour as a future fan favorite
column2: you can imagine how leading an arena in a chant of “we go ratchet!” could be cathartic or at least a nice change of pace for a band with a deadly serious reputation. Of course
column3: you might also be of the perfectly reasonable belief that it’s a fool’s errand for any rock band
column4: let alone Bloc Party
column5: to employ “ratchet” in its adjective form in 2013 without embarrassing themselves. If so
column6: you’ll hear it no differently than the times when a rock band does a straight hip-hop cover with the best intentions and the worst execution even if Okereke's ill bars about sour diesel and keepin' it one hundred are his own.<span style=""font-family: Georgia
column7: serif;"">

column1: “Obscene” is the other track Bloc Party recorded with producer Dan Carey and it forgoes the uplift mofo party plan of “Ratchet” to apply the slinky
column2: synth-pop sheen he lent to Bat For Lashes and Chairlift last year. Since A Weekend In The City
column3: Bloc Party’s best songs have been ballads. This can seem counterintuitive-- Okereke’s voice isn’t particularly supple or suited to melody and restricting their lively rhythm section to electronics can feel like a misallocation of resources. But Okereke’s voice lends itself well to vulnerability
column4: of trying to sing “pretty” when he doesn’t really have the physical capabilities for it. Likewise
column5: there are only so many barbed riffs and jagged rhythms in Bloc Party’s repertory as a standard rock band
column6: so experimenting with the production and textural qualities of R&B and hip-hop rather than the slang has proven wise.

column1: All Bloc Party albums have at least two softbatch keepers
column2: and the nice thing about Nextwave is that they’re easier to find. In addition to ""Obscene
column3: “Montreal” sounds like the comprehensive Bloc Party
column4: tying in the storytelling lyricism of A Weekend In The City with the electronic
column5: club-minded aesthetic of Intimacy and their remix albums
column6: while guitarist Russell Lissack edges beyond his typical Edge atmospherics and post-punk downstrokes into chorused Police riffs. Elsewhere
column7: “French Exit” is the same ol’ angular Bloc Party growing soft around the edges while the messianic streak in “Children of the Future” has a clumsy charm but not much else.

column1: It does serve as a curious closer since Bloc Party introduced themselves as a band with a savior complex and has evolved into a more humane
column2: fan-focused and knowable act
column3: a cult affair on a mass level. Silent Alarm dealt in absolutes and theoreticals-- the songs were either burners or ballads
column4: Okereke in Code Red or a deep blue. Nextwave Sessions continues in the vein of Intimacy and Four in being the work of band that will make tracks using hip-hop vernacular if they feel like it
column5: admit to being exhausted and test out hot producers without committing to an entire album
column6: to make good on Okereke’s wish from “I Still Remember” to make more mistakes. All the same
column7: praising Nextwave Sessions for being “interesting” feels like a cop out-- Silent Alarm and even A Weekend In The City gave the listener as much to enjoy as it did to consider
column8:
but Bloc Party’s output since then has made it feel like those two qualities are mutually exclusive.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19545/homepage_large.e8759390.jpg|Vehicle|774.0|The Clean|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Flying Nun'

The Clean’s debut full-length came after they’d already been legends for almost a decade
column3: ever since their 1981 single “Tally-Ho!” put both them and the Flying Nun label on the charts in their home country of New Zealand. The trio of Robert Scott on bass and brothers David and Hamish Kilgour on guitar and drums
column4: respectively
column5: continues on to this day with irregular tours and albums and Vehicle
column6: newly reissued on vinyl by Captured Tracks
column7: remains just as engaging and immediate as it was 20 years back.

column1: Given the group's decades of work
column2: including rarities collections and a career-spanning overview that contained a number of its songs
column3: Vehicle might initially seem just another signpost along the way. But the original context was very different. Geoff Davies of Rough Trade offered to release new songs by the Clean after catching them on a reunion tour in 1989 (yes
column4: they were already on a reunion tour) and the recording came together in just a few short days in London. It’s quietly astonishing to realize that the year of Vehicle’s release
column5: Robert Scott was already two albums in leading the Bats while Hamish Kilgour founded his own long running act the Mad Scene; the following year David Kilgour began his own solo career with Here Come the Cars. With such an embarrassment of riches in their side projects
column6: it would have almost made sense if Vehicle had been just an easygoing slapdash ramble.

column1: But the songs on Vehicle hold their own. Instead of the rough and ready four-track recordings that marked their early singles and EPs
column2: Vehicle sounds very much like a studio creation
column3: though the fuller sound didn’t harm the performances. Part of the pleasure lies in hearing how each of the band members is so distinct
column4: creating the type of collaboration where the individual parts’ strength meshes rather than trying to outstrip another. The singing from all three is a core part of the Clean's appeal
column5: the back-and-forth between Scott’s affable but never cloying voice and the Kilgours’ slightly gentler but no less engaging approach. Leads are almost always matched by harmonies
column6: and the feeling throughout Vehicle is one of continuity. Scott’s vocal turns on “Big Soft Punch” and “The Dunes” are beautiful contrasts against the giddy arrangements-- especially on “The Dunes”
column7: where he almost seems to easily sashay through both verse and chorus
column8: riding the choppy
column9: always focused shimmer of the arrangement like it was the steadiest thing ever recorded. On songs like “Getting to You” and “Bye Bye”
column10: the distinctive and immediate organ sound that defined them from the start remains
column11: exchanging spikiness and hear-the-keys-being-pressed feeling for an energetic warmth.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: “Some One” has the kind of guitar part from David Kilgour that feels like a big explosion of power without being some wanky mess
column3: while Hamish Kilgour’s drumming is crucial
column4: drawing from the focused flow and power of German art-rock of the 1970s to help show a path to a rhythm-obsessed underground in the 1990s. On songs like “Dunes
column5: ” “The Blue”
column6: and “Big Soft Punch”
column7: he ensures that the arrangements have all the propulsion one could want without being overbearing. (The bonus In-A-Live EP included with the reissue
column8: taken from the 1989 tour
column9: shows his quality even more
column10: especially on a run through “Fish” and a monstrous “Point That Thing Somewhere Else”.)

column1: Vehicle offers an interesting case study of of how perceptions of a release can come around. The album clocks in at under a half an hour; it's filled with short
column2: melody-on-top-of-melody songs first heard when full CD lengths were starting to become a little more of a norm. Only a couple of songs break three minutes and a good number don’t even make it past two. In a time of vinyl and cassette fetishism in independant music
column3:
the fact that this release fit on even one side of a C60 feels perfectly appropriate. But that brevity never feels forced or surprising. Every song really is as long as it needs to be and the album as a whole is a dense concentration of pleasures.

Over the past few years the chorus calling for a return to “real” hip-hop that’s been going steadily since the 90s has only gotten louder and angrier as the genre’s entered an era of unprecedented experimentation that’s left older fans and artists bewildered. Most of the arguments seem to come from rap musicians who’ve fallen out of style and knee-jerk reactionary hip-hop heads who can’t deal with rappers wearing kilts. Few of them make a convincing case.

column1: Pete Rock
column2: whose production work helped define the 90s “golden age” is a rare exception. 80 Blocks from Tiffany's Part II
column3: his second full-length collaboration with the Bronx duo Camp Lo
column4: offers proof that amidst the expeditions rap music’s launching into new sonic territories like EDM
column5: noisy psychedelia
column6: and quasi-industrial music
column7: the classic boom-bap stuff still has a place.

column1: Rock’s one of the few musicians who made his name in the aggressively unflashy 90s East Coast sound who’s managed to stay continually relevant without capitulating to changing tastes. A Pete Rock beat from 2013 works on the same basic level as a Pete Rock beat from 1993
column2: but it doesn’t sound dated. Unlike some of his contemporaries who’ve been happy to go through their careers chopping up the same old breaks they’ve been playing with for years
column3: he’s been constantly evolving his sounds while his method of putting them together has remained fundamentally unchanged.

column1: “No Uniform""
column2: a collaboration here with Brooklyn bruisers M.O.P. is a prime example of Rock’s ability to make old school techniques sound new again. The drum pattern is classic boom-bap
column3: and M.O.P. still flows about the same as they did when they broke through in 2000 with “Ante Up"". But the instrumentation replaces the crackling grittiness that typified the roughneck beats of their prime years with richer
column4: darker tones that smartly fill up the sonic spectrum with a minimum of moving parts. And the fuzzed-out guitar sample looping on top of everything is placed over the drums in a peculiar
column5: precarious way that adds a new flavor of tension to the song.

column1: “Megan Good""
column2: which features a verse by the increasingly respectable Mac Miller
column3: takes the new-old dichotomy even further. The snappy
column4: dirty drums and one-note hollowbody bass riff that form the song’s bare-bones foundation would have been familiar to crate diggers back at the dawn of hip-hop
column5: but if Rock had arranged them into a snappy
column6: hip-shaking retro-soul-pop confection a decade ago the way he does here
column7: he probably would have incited a riot amongst pop-averse hardcore rap fans.

column1: Like the individual tracks that make it up
column2: 80 Blocks II finds new life in well-worn ideas. Its structure predates the modern definition of a mixtape as essentially just an album without a label. It’s more like what DJs and producers put together when they were still dubbing the results onto actual tape-- a freewheeling collage of songs
column3: extended samples lifted from movies and TV
column4: brief instrumental sketches
column5: and spoken word interludes (delivered here by Rock
column6: with his voice pitch-shifted up to helium-balloon squeakiness) outlining the collection’s purpose and its contributors’ bonafides.

column1: And like a lot of those old school mixtapes
column2: 80 Blocks II runs too long by almost a third. But in smaller doses it’s easily equal to some of the best and boldest rap music being made right now. There’s something incredibly admirable about the way that hip-hop’s been charging full-speed ahead into the future
column3:
but Rock’s music is a good reminder that occasionally looking back over your shoulder can be a very good thing.

"|18353.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18353-pete-rock-camp-lo-80-blocks-from-tiffanys-pt-ii/|6.8|Miles Raymer

In the past
column2: whether or not you’ve enjoyed the music of Queens rapper Homeboy Sandman has had a lot to do with the way in which you digest rap verses. His delivery is halted
column3: stuttering-- not really a flow so much as a series of strategically layered blocks of wordplay. If you like cerebral rap music
column4: Sand has been your man for some time now
column5: but if you just wanted to turn your brain off
column6: the dissonance of his bars and the aggro-quality of some of his beats might not keep your interest.

column1: But Sandman’s newest project All That I Hold Dear proves to be an enjoyable album both for folks who really listen to music and for those who just skim through it. Listeners who don’t want to have to hear to a song half a dozen times before they can understand and enjoy it should be taken with the project’s sparkling soul beats and verses from Homeboy Sandman that are slightly more modulated than his usual darts of staccato.
The release was produced entirely by M Slago
column2: a Dallas beatmaker reminiscent of 9th Wonder. As with the North Carolina producer
column3: Slago’s beats are hardy and stuffed with plenty of soul. But for some strange reason
column4: he can’t really get his drums to hit and those too-soft snare snaps can dull the music's impact.

column1: Sand here is as incisive as ever
column2: stream-of-consciousness rhymes shading in the complexities of any given theme. “Musician” may have some worried that they're about to receive another in the endless cycle of lectures about the distinction between rap and hip-hop
column3: but they've got a surprise coming. The track is a deft complaint about being perceived as a rapper rather than as a musician and forms a defense of rap as an essentially musical profession. ""Like there could never be a logical answer other than the music we make
column4: Sand raps
column5: in response to questions about what differentiates him from his rapping peers.

column1: Another standout
column2: ""Relapse""
column3: details the kind of pseudo break up where the parties involved continue to circle warily
column4: wondering whether or not they've made a mistake and are meant to be together. And while uncle-rap won’t be burning up the airwaves anytime soon
column5: “Runts” is a touching tribute to Sand’s nephew and niece
column6: which makes up for its triteness with well-observed details about the trials and tribulations of dealing with kids.

column1: All That I Hold Dear is the second Sandman release on which the production is handled by a single producer (the first was Kool Herc: Fertile Crescent
column2: produced by EL RTNC)
column3: a smart idea that provides a cohesive platform for the rapper to zero in on his talking points. The project won’t attract many new fans
column4: but even those who haven’t been following Sand should enjoy this pleasant
column5:
low-key brain food.

"|18354.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18354-homeboy-sandman-all-that-i-hold-dear/|7.2|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19551/homepage_large.cd8e2cd7.jpg|Hammer of Night|31556.0|Yellow Eyes|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sibir']|2013-08-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:42.987110|"

Remember back when “Brooklyn black metal” was a slur
column2: serving as a snide dismissal of any number of the Big Apple’s rotten exports? That niggling image of smug gentrifiers with combo amps and spanking new Burzum shirts captured the collective metal imagination several years back
column3: buoyed by the success of bands like Liturgy and Krallice and viciously maligned by anyone who fancied themselves an elitist. The elitism remains
column4: for sure
column5: but Krallice (who were lumped in unfairly in the first place) have evolved
column6: and erstwhile poster boys Liturgy have disbanded
column7: returning to the Upper West Side coke dust from whence they came. Brooklyn black metal is less of a theory than a fact. The borough now lays claim to a host of hungry young (and not so young) bands that are doing well for themselves. Even as some of their members split their time between East and West coasts or points in between
column8: the NYC-based representatives of Mutilation Rites
column9: Ruin Lust
column10: Villains
column11: Raspberry Bulbs
column12: Ash Pool
column13: and Woe redefine what “black metal” means without abandoning its core ideals or pissing on their roots. Even occult favorites Negative Plane live just around the corner. With their intoxicating new album
column14: Hammer of Night
column15: Yellow Eyes have joined the upper crust of Brooklyn’s blackest.

column1: The album opens with “Light Has Fallen”
column2: ushered in by gentle sound of rain. Yellow Eyes come from a place of rust and decay instead of a pristine Northwestern forest
column3: though
column4: so the quiet only lasts for a moment. Punctuated by pained howls scraped from an unwilling throat
column5: the surprisingly melodic riffing echoes the clear
column6: clean sound that is so often found glinting up from modern black metal’s murky depths and coiled around shoegaze’s darker moments. It’s a sound that’s uniquely American in conception
column7: but European in execution. Manic tremolo picking and intricate
column8: studied compositions intertwine and evolve together
column9: creating something that is indisputably black fucking metal
column10: but still a little strange.

column1: That melodic edge is a crucial part of Yellow Eyes’ sound
column2: not an affectation
column3: and is something that the band strives to perfect and manipulate in turn. The rawness remains. A brief acoustic interlude ends the grim-faced “In This Stillness” and segues right into the icy chords of “Many Long Fingers Bent In Pain”
column4: with its hoarse cries and more straightforward approach that stops on a dime halfway through
column5: just long enough for a sweet little punk rock fill to pop out.

column1: Yellow Eyes keep up the intensity with an almost hardcore zeal. The frenzied quality of moments like “Ice Knell’s middle passage sound on the verge of collapse
column2: but then quickly hunker down into a solid swath of tremolo hellnoise like it’s nothing. Hammer of Night’s title track pulls out the acoustic once again
column3: plucking away at a simple stretch of moody neofolk before the hammer itself comes crashing down and the ride cymbal dictates the proceedings. The same formula worked well earlier on and appears one last time halfway through “Cabin Filled With Smoke And Flies”
column4: though this time perverted with unsettling drones. The album fades out acoustically
column5: petering off into silence.

column1: Yellow Eyes' earlier output showed promise
column2: but the amount of care that was taken in the creation of these six songs is obvious. USBM’s got a new dark horse
column3:
and Hammer of Night is one of 2013’s strongest black metal releases. Not bad for a couple of kids from Brooklyn.

"|18358.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18358-yellow-eyes-hammer-of-night/|7.6|Kim Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19584/homepage_large.413f137a.jpg|Stop Pretending EP|31594.0|Default Genders|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-08-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:44.335918|"

A week ago this past Monday
column2: bedroom electronic musician James Brooks
column3: who first gained some notice with Elite Gymnastics
column4: put out a four-song EP on Bandcamp under the name Dead Girlfriends (another band with this name exists
column5: so he re-titled this project Default Genders). A torrent of discussion ensued
column6: much of it centered around the song ""On Fraternity""
column7: whose lyrics offer brief snapshots of situations that point to the fear of sexual assault and the lack of support for victims of violence. Brooks writes eloquently and often on his Tumblr about feminism
column8: power structures
column9: and the patriarchy
column10: among other topics. With ""On Fraternity"" he found himself accused by some of “mansplaining” the dynamics of rape to women who presumably knew more about it than he did. The record turned out to be an unlikely flashpoint for a cluster of ideas bubbling up in culture: What is the role of men in feminist discourse? How should art draw from personal experience and how much can we know about the artist’s relationship to that experience? How should we account for the context created by an artist’s social media presence?

column1: There were more questions
column2: many of them interesting and important. But using this four-song
column3: Bandcamp-released EP by a bedroom electronic musician as a pivot for them was
column4: perhaps
column5: more than the actual musical content warranted. Stop Pretending
column6: as a collection of electronic pop songs
column7: wasn’t sturdy enough to bear the weight of it all and was quickly crushed under the dialog. We’ll get to those ideas in a second. But first
column8: pulling the EP back out from the pile-up and listening again
column9: we find four songs that extend the sound of Elite Gymnastics but in a smaller
column10: closer
column11: more intimate way. Brooks isn’t much of a singer
column12: so he half-speaks and Auto-Tunes his lyrics
column13: creating vocal melodies that are reasonably memorable. He offsets his pedestrian vocals with tics that try and make the music more expressive and conversational-- little breaths and sighs
column14: words twisted into the sing-song exasperated cadence of a teenager. One of the last things we heard from Elite Gymnastics was a song called “Andreja 4-Ever”
column15: a tribute to feminist theorist Andrea Dworkin that was Brooks’ brightly-colored yet modest stab at an anthem. Stop Pretending never tries for that sense of scale.

column1: As with Elite Gymnastics
column2: the most immediate musical references are from the 1990s and early 2000s-- Her Space Holiday
column3: Pacific Northwest indie pop like Land of the Loops
column4: the Postal Service. The title track is a dense confection that includes a sample that sounds like it could have come from the soundtrack to Riverdance along with the “Funky Drummer” loop
column5: a sample so obvious it was obviously chosen by Brooks as a kind of shorthand
column6: pointing back to the music of a specific era. “Omertà”
column7: is a delicate
column8: affecting instrumental with slowly-shifting drones and simple and spare piano notes. And then “On Fraternity” is the point on the album where the music takes a darker turn
column9: as the metallic screech of noise music surges and retreats (Brooks is a fan of extreme artists like Whitehouse) leaving behind spaces filled with tension. On a purely musical level
column10: there’s a Tumblr-like quality to Brooks work
column11: as he pulls sounds and samples from all over and combines them in a personal way that doesn’t hide its dependence on existing sources. If Stop Pretending lacks some of the grandeur of Elite Gymnastics
column12: it’s also a worthy attempt to create small-scale music that feels as intimate as a gchat conversation.

column1: And then there are the themes
column2: which mix the small and personal with the broad and universal. A certain amount of friction was inevitable. When you write lyrics like “Tell me again about how heavy the crown is/ About the weight of the burden of being white and male” and you are white and male
column3: people are going to question your motives. A songwriter like Randy Newman
column4: who would leave the listener searching for a satirical wrinkle to explain the on-the-nose phrasing
column5: could get away with it. But once you’ve read interviews with Brooks and spent some time with his writing

column8: ” such as it may be
column9: is irresistible.

column1: As for “On Fraternity”
column2: while some have heard Brooks’ comments as trying to speak for women in general
column3: he’s pointed out on his Tumblr that the gender of the characters is never stated. Both men and women are assaulted
column4: and we have no idea what Brooks’ own experiences in this realm might be

column6: about people being afraid to talk

column11: as we see a thoughtful person not quite knowing how to get his ideas across. In trying to communicate thoughts about the issues important to him

column14:
is filled with “you” and “they” when a few more uses of “I” might have helped.

Never leave Prodigy for dead. People tried that in the mid 2000s
column2: and Return of the Mac came out to blindside them: Alchemist shined behind the boards
column3: providing a timelessly grimy soul-break soundtrack
column4: while the Mobb Deep vet refocused and returned to his malevolent street-noir wheelhouse after years of questionable crossover bids. What was originally intended as a promo vehicle for Prodigy's 2008 LP H.N.I.C. Part 2-- a strong album in its own right-- became one of the MC's defining late-career albums
column5: and set a new precedent for him to live up to in his solo work. Now here we go again: skeptics figured P needed to find some way to regain his footing after his prison bid
column6: his social media beef-not-beef with Havoc
column7: and the rusty compromise of his first post-incarceration albums. And whether Prodigy agreed with them or not
column8: his return to a teamup with Alchemist actually came across like it really meant something
column9: a definitive attempt at reminding everyone just what got him to the point where it matters if he lets people down.

column1: The funny thing about Albert Einstein is that the six-year stretch between Prodigy/Alchemist collaborations means very different things for both parties' art. Prodigy's proven to be best when he finds some new ways to describe his old habits
column2: an endless reserve of sharp threats and cool menace fueling his dark-punchline verses. But Alchemist's switched up his game significantly since the 70s-jukebox R&B/funk break approach he deployed with brutal efficiency on Return of the Mac: he's been on his psych-prog thing for a while now
column3: leaning effectively on pitched-up
column4: complex guitar noodling and lo-fi loops where Hammonds and Moogs hit as hard as kick drums. Hearing one of the giants of NYC hardcore hip-hop spill classic knuckle-to-the-eyesocket rhymes over the same dopamine-jolting hashbar beats that made Russian Roulette
column5: Covert Coup and Gangrene albums so blown-out and grainy? Why the hell not?

column1: In that sense
column2: Albert Einstein is so casually visceral and immediately gettable that it feels like a recent high point for both of them. Lyrically
column3: Prodigy's delivery is enough to make the constant pile-on of relentless violence blur into something more lifelike and experience-driven than empty threats. He's a cinematographer
column4: letting the scene speak for itself
column5: and even when he gets cute with a punchline-- “I peddle dope longer than Lance Armstrong” (“Curb Ya Dog”) or “Can't come around no more
column6: your mouth runnin'/ Sprints through New York like that marathon Puff did” (“Bear Meat”)-- it all ties in with the bigger picture of a callous
column7: calculating scrapper with a grim wise-ass streak. “Bible Paper”'s first verse invokes Breaking Bad body-removal tactics and reduces an adversary to a “gooey mess” and “special sauce.” And the insomnia-fueled ""Confessions” relays an insomnia-fueled hit on a hotboxing couple with the kind of detail that haunts (“I saw his radio lights through the rear tint”; “Now there's weed smoke pouring out the bullet hole glass”). The appearance of similar-minded guest MCs pays off
column8: too; he stands up well paired with excellent verses by Roc Marciano (“Death Sentence”) and Action Bronson (“The One”)
column9: but in ways that feel more complementary than competitive
column10: like old friends and respected peers shooting the shit.

column1: As strongly as his best lyrics can stand on their own
column2: and as good as he's capable of sounding on even the most familiar breaks
column3: Prodigy's vision really gets pulled into vivid life when the beats are especially tense. And while Alchemist's productions have their own foreboding inner life
column4: an MC who can credibly double-up that haunted-house mood makes that production just that much filthier. Practically nothing on the album feels strained
column5: and even less seems compromised. When subject matter and production click the most graphically-- the weathered resilience of the grown-man badass on the daggers-of-sleet piano trudge “Stay Dope”; a remorseless Class of 95 reunion where Havoc and Raekwon cut through with molasses-bassline dread and nail-biting disco/funk chase-sequence breaks on “R.I.P.”; metal-caliber threats of Old Testament bodily harm set to the tune of downpitched
column6: shapeshifting Eastern Bloc space rock on “Bible Paper”-- there's a real tactile feeling to it. It's like if the uniquely weathered
column7: evocatively musty sensations of long-shelved
column8: resin-stained gatefold LPs and dusty
column9:
cracked-spine pulp crime paperbacks were fused and synthesized into music.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19501/homepage_large.ea477d3c.jpg|Somerset Avenue Tracks (1992-1995)|4402.0|µ-Ziq|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2013-08-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:45.584898|"

The 1990s experimental electronic scene that came to be known as ""intelligent dance music"" was simultaneously home to both the most anhedonic snobs to be found on the avant garde fringe (hence the genre's insufferably pretentious and sneak-dissing name) and its most genuinely entertaining eccentrics. Mike Paradinas
column2: aka µ-Ziq
column3: was of the latter type
column4: and the music he was making at the time managed the improbable task of pushing the boundaries of aesthetics and techniques while also showing a genuine appreciation for less ""intelligent"" dance music styles
column5: producing music you could actually dance to rather than simply appreciate on an intellectual level.

column1: Somerset Avenue Tracks (1992-1995)
column2: the 300th release on his Planet Mu label
column3: collects 24 previously unreleased recordings from the very beginnings of Paradinas’ solo career. Split between a disc compiled by his wife (and bandmate in the group Heterotic) Lara Rix-Martin and one of assorted odds and ends from his DAT archive
column4: the set offers an in-depth look at the lead-up to to the material that would lead up to the albums Paradinas made his name off of
column5: and a portrait of a young artist who displayed formidable talents from the very start.

column1: Paradinas was only 22 years old at the beginning of the Somerset Avenue era
column2: and although he’d already been playing for years in New Wave-influenced bands
column3: he was something of a beginner in the field of programmed
column4: beat-centric music. It seems like he was a natural
column5: though-- the material here is impressively subtle
column6: especially compared with the relentlessly smiley-faced happy hardcore that had come to define the UK rave scene by the time µ-Ziq launched.

column1: “Johnson’s Q-Fab""
column2: from the first disc
column3: is built around what initially seems like a simple combination of a tom-heavy techno drum beat and bits of airy synth pads
column4: but over its seven minute running time introduces an increasing number of complications to the sequence that add a level of complexity. It makes the track far more compelling than the basic chillout-room ambient tracks of the time. Elsewhere
column5: Paradinas dabbles in complexly broken beats
column6: expertly tweaked analog synths
column7: and fine-grained production techniques-- including some stroboscopic hi-hats that sound eerily prescient of EDM’s current trap music phase-- that are hard to believe he accomplished prior to the introduction of easy-to-use
column8: graphics-based digital recording software.

column1: One of the defining aspects of Paradinas’ body of work is a willingness to mess with genre conventions
column2: often even as those conventions were in the process of being decided. Some of Somerset Avenue’s most gratifying moments come from experiments with au courant styles. “Boistron” takes the squelching 303 synths popularized by the acid house movement and sets them loose over a jacking beat that’s more spacious than the norm
column3: and adds in strokes of semi-ambient keys that offer a unique twist of the paranoid edge that the form’s known for. “Poc” offers a throbbing
column4: acidified take on the breakbeat style that around the time it must have been recorded was already well into the process of evolving into drum & bass.

column1: Since the time he recorded the material that would end up on Somerset Avenue Tracks
column2: Paradinas has gone further out
column3: dabbling in jazz funk and other more cerebral-leaning forms
column4: but he’s retained the same admirable focus on making music that’s both challenging and pleasurable to listen to. (An aspect of his personality that extends to Planet Mu’s support for intriguingly next-level styles like Chicago footwork.) Compared with the rest of his catalog
column5: Somerset Avenue Tracks is as raw as you’d expect from an artist just starting to find himself
column6:
but it's strong enough to stand with the best work that he’s done.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19554/homepage_large.436d471e.jpg|Hobo Rocket|30264.0|Pond|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modular']|2013-08-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:46.072788|"

Any band currently making ol’ fashioned psychedelic pop-rock will be measured against Tame Impala’s modern masterpiece Lonerism and Pond has it especially tough: the Australian group shares two members with Tame Impala and is likely to be considered a side project even though Hobo Rocket is their fifth album. In fact
column2: when Pond frontman Nick Allbrook left Tame Impala to focus on his various projects
column3: he was replaced by another current member of Pond. So while there isn’t a competition between the two
column4: there is an implict sibling rivalry; while the two bands share DNA
column5: one is the genial
column6: goofy ne'er do well counterpart to their more accomplished brother.

column1: That said
column2: genial and goofy are almost always positive attributes in this realm. Allbrook opens Hobo Rocket asking
column3: “Whatever Happened to the Million Head Collide?"" which…yeah. And while you ponder that mystery over a loosey-goosey Bo Diddley beat
column4: all of a sudden it breaks into a Zeppelin stomp of maxed drums and burly blues riffs. The van's a-rockin'. I’m sure the origin story behind the bombastic glam-stomp “Xanman” is a hoot
column5: even if it’s just a result of Allbrook coming across ""Zan With That Lean"" and “The Nightman Cometh” in the same YouTube spree. No band that takes itself too seriously could write “Xanman”
column6: and it’s a good example of why Pond can serve a purpose against the more refined likes of Dungen or Tame Impala.

column1: You also have to grapple with the fact that it’s a five-minute song based on the lyric ""Xanman! Won't you understand you're not crying for your xan
column2: man!"" It gets to the core question of just how much ambition and expression you can expect from a record called Hobo Rocket that clocks in at just over a half hour in seven tracks. You can be a witness to Pond’s good time
column3: but can you be an active participant in it? ""Whatever Happened to the Million Head Collide?"" and “Xanman” at least have hooks and something close to coherence. Otherwise
column4: Hobo Rocket quickly becomes a collation of the kind of wigged-out studio tricks that Lonerism was notable for avoiding or at least minimizing
column5: an idea of what Tame Impala would be without Kevin Parker’s consummate songwriting and meticulous editing.

column1: There are no shortage of abrupt tangents and fades
column2: whooshing stereo panning and phaser effects and obscene fuzz tones throughout Hobo Rocket. They’re often more extreme than anything on Lonerism or the loopier Innerspeaker. Blast it at a keg party in an open field or ingest the headphone candy by yourself
column3: it holds up either way. But the trickiness becomes a distraction. “O Dharma” and ""Midnight Mass (At the Market Station)"" replicate replicas of Beatles replicas
column4: the same old flanged vocals over strummed acoustics and weepy Mellotron
column5: with little melody to get in the way. “Aloneaflameafloewe"" runs its banshee wails and plodding rhythms through an impenetrable haze of effects
column6: evoking a half-remembered Wolfmother festival set. The title track only exists for its vocal EQ’ing; it gives the effect of a radio DJ too drunk to realize his mic’s still on and that he’s been talking over Bad Company for the past four minutes.

column1: Pond mean well and it’s hard to stay mad at Hobo Rocket for very long; it’s quite to easy to take it at face value as stoner rock in a pure form. Then again
column2: that term tends to be misunderstood or misapplied: is it meant to describe the consumers of the music or the creators? Not to cast aspersions on how Pond spend their free time
column3: but when you look at bands ranging from Sleep to Tame Impala that get the same tag
column4: there’s still a precision
column5: studiousness and clarity to their music regardless of the production tricks or narcotized tempos. Hobo Rocket draws out the indulgence
column6:
more than happy to engage in dumb fun without bringing much to the party.

The front cover of Pop. 1280’s new album features a shot of the Manhattan skyline at night and
column2: thanks to the wonders of Photoshop
column3: some multi-headed mutant monster rising from the waters before it. The scene is apropos on many levels: in both sound and intent
column4: Pop. 1280 very much seem like the product of the notoriously seedy New York City that was eventually washed away by the dual forces of Giuliani and gentrification. Their future-shocked art-punk brutalism hearkens back to the time when Sonic Youth namedropping Philip K. Dick rather than Marc Jacobs
column5: and when Richard Kern’s muse was Lydia Lunch instead of Sasha Grey. And yet more so than any specific aesthetic reference points from that era
column6: what Pop. 1280 most vividly evoke is a bygone 1980s when an after-hours stroll through the Lower East Side could prove more dangerous anything you see on ""Fear Factor."" But after burrowing toward new depths of depravity on last year’s still-startling The Horror
column7: even these miscreants need to come up for air. And like vampires stepping into the sun
column8: Pop. 1280’s tentative crawl toward the light can be a little unflattering.

column1: That’s not to say Imps of Pervision constitutes a major cosmetic change
column2: or that Pop. 1280’s music now sounds anything like the first half of their name; as far as clean-up jobs go
column3: this one was administered with a crumbling piece of wet toilet paper rather than a hydraulic hose. But compared to the apocalyptic clamor of The Horror
column4: there’s a greater crispness and clarity here that
column5: at times
column6: works against the band’s attempts to dredge up the dread. On Horror highlights like “Bodies in the Dunes” and “New Electronix""
column7: Pop. 1280 pillaged forth in unison with a creeping intensity
column8: like a street gang encircling its victim in a swarm attack; by contrast
column9: the clearer separation of Ivan Lip’s spidery guitar lines and Zach Ziemann’s shifting rhythms on Imps’ “Lights Out” and “The Control Freak” defuses their imposing mystique
column10: leaving frontman Chris Bug oddly overexposed-- all the bark without enough bite to back it up. (Furthermore
column11: the latter song’s attempt at examining the more mundane sort of monstrous beings we encounter on a daily basis doesn’t pack the same absurdist panache as their cubicle-bound peers in Pissed Jeans.)

column1: It’s not that Pop. 1280 necessarily need scuzzed-out production to feel convincingly caustic; the corrosively vocoderized “Population Control” is the most aggressively lo-fi song here
column2: but also the most unformed and ineffectual
column3: too. Pop. 1280’s potency is really a function of proper pacing
column4: of allowing sufficient time for the players’ competing parts to cohere into a punishing squall and for Bug to undergo a gradual transformation from simmering unease to strait-jacketed psychosis. And to that end
column5: Imps of Pervision peaks with its torrid middle stretch. “Nailhouse” pounds the deviant groove of The Stooges’ “Little Doll” into submission
column6: with Bug’s increasingly violent fantasias eerily evocative of the current vogue for homemade pressure-cooker bombs; “Human Probe II” and “Do the Anglerfish” are exceptional showcases of Lip’s six-string savagery
column7: unleashing a deep arsenal of caterwauling tones that can drill holes through skulls. Pop. 1280 sustain just enough of that gonzo energy to elevate the more conventionally rendered mid-tempo rockers that make up the album’s back half
column8: however
column9: the morosely monotone closing ballad “Riding Shotgun” suggests they have the aspirations-- if not yet the artistry-- to rise above their sewage-smeared station. Given all the blood
column10: jism
column11: and other bodily secretions the dot Bug’s lyric sheet here
column12: Pop. 1280 are still very much the sort of band that demand a post-listen shower-- this time
column13: though
column14:
you just won't need as much soap.
