Nigel Godrich epitomized the sound of the late 90s alt-rock-- that combination of space-age expanse and dystopian dread that thrust Radiohead super nova
column2: made a low-key Beck album sound epic
column3: and invested a band as unassuming as Pavement with a little sci-fi swoosh. But while Thom Yorke remains his most loyal client-cum-collaborator
column4: Godrich’s production aesthetic has greatly evolved with the times
column5: his current interest in complex electronic patterns and nervy West African-inspired rhythms emblematic of both 21st-century global connectivity and technological dependency. His similarly styled concurrent projects with drummer Joey Waronker-- the electro-pop trio Ultraísta and the more high-profile
column6: Yorke-fronted supergroup Atoms for Peace-- evince the infinite possibilities of the digital age and the claustrophic constrictions of being tied to your machines. Accordingly
column7: both bands have the tendency to feel untamed and caged-in at the same time.

column1: Atoms for Peace
column2: of course
column3: boast an awesome
column4: globe-trotting live show that overpowers the contained quality of their recordings. Ultraísta
column5: however
column6: tour on a much more limited scale
column7: so we have this alternative version of their 2012 debut-- as reassembled by an eclectic
column8: star-studded cast of beatmakers
column9: and at least one legendary director-- to proffer a second opinion. Remixes
column10: however
column11: is a bit of a misnomer. Given Godrich’s densely packed productions
column12: the process at play here is more like an unraveling
column13: an opportunity to peel back the high-beam synths that smother so many Ultraísta tracks and expose the darker undercurrents and sense of unrest bubbling underneath. Presenting radical reconstructions-- and
column14: in some cases
column15: marked improvements-- of each song from the original record in a resequenced order
column16: Remixes makes encouraging strides in addressing the source material’s chief shortcoming: specifically
column17: that every song followed the same formula
column18: to the point of making singer Laura Bettinson sound automated
column19: pre-set. When you have everyone from Four Tet to David Lynch on board
column20: uniformity is no longer going to be an issue.

column1: As if to reinforce the notion that Remixes is meant to be heard as a complete
column2: alternate-universe version of the original album rather than a random collection
column3: the new record uses Ultraísta’s closing track
column4: “You’re Out
column5: ” as its jumping-off point
column6: with Prefuse 73 retaining its broken-beat cadence but gradually opening up greater fissures in the rhythm bed that hint at the more dramatic deconstructions to come. Not every track recovers from surgery: Zero 7’s slow-motion Italo-disco disassembly of “Our Song” plods on for far too long only to set up a standard-issue chillout-house groove
column7: while FaltyDL’s smoothed-over “Gold Dayzz” nudges Ultraísta further into café-compilation territory. (A bonus vinyl-only EP offers three additional takes on the latter
column8: highlighted by an exemplary psychedelic tabla-funk transformation by Boom Bip.)

column1: The most succesful remixes here-- from Four Tet’s garage-clattered “Smalltalk” to Canon Blue’s Mezzanine-level “Party Line”-- retain the originals’ melodic integrity but wisely opt to showcase Bettinson’s voice in isolation
column2: lending her a more ghostly presence. Books guitarist Nick Zammuto’s bone-dry take on “Easier” is especially revelatory
column3: pitting the main vocal line against an anxiously panting backing track and spartan drum beats
column4: drawing out an eeriness and menace barely perceptible on the original. Or
column5: in other cases
column6: they subject Bettinson to sonic abuse: Herbert’s “Static Light” filters her voice through distorted sax squwaks
column7: whereas gloomy Brooklyn post-punk outfit Eraas takes the title of “Wash It Over” literally
column8: submerging the track in a murky techno that slowly drowns the original to death. But the most spectacular revision here is the simplest
column9: and it comes from the unlikeliest participant: Lynch
column10: who reduces “Strange Formula” to a dirty
column11:
PJ Harvey-worthy blues with a tick-tock beat that summons an intensifying apocalyptic drone to swallow the song whole. Ultraísta’s synth-pop odysseys always sounded like they were begging for a more widescreen treatment-- who better to provide it than one of our greatest filmmakers?

It's strange to think that the malformed noise made by Black Dice was once released through EMI
column3: albeit as part of a deal signed by their former label
column4: DFA. That moment didn't last long
column5: although the relationship has been somewhat rekindled here
column6: as Eric Copeland returns to DFA for the first time since his other band released Broken Ear Record in 2005. The label's gone through vast changes in that time-- the dramatic curtain call of LCD Soundsystem
column7: an acrimonious split with label co-founder Tim Goldsworthy-- but for Copeland things remain pretty much the same. In fact
column8: it's possible that he's become even less proficient in the intervening years
column9: choosing to un-learn as he goes. Joke in the Hole is his latest raggedy solo venture
column10: essentially a series of samples and beats patched together so it manages to feel like both the best and worst drug experiences of your life all tied together in one woozy package.

column1: Copeland has maintained a strong punk aesthetic over the years
column2: choosing instinct over skill
column3: divining thrills from crude
column4: base forms. Even the cover art for Joke in the Hole looks like a copy of the Pet Shop Boys' Introspective that's been tossed into a 70s porn emporium. There's a lighter touch here than on most Black Dice records
column5: with a fondness for pop forms weaved into the confusion. That's become a strain threaded through much of Copeland's solo work
column6: coupled with a skill for combining humor and z-grade sleaze that positions him close to the feel of John Waters' earliest films. Still
column7: this is a subdivision of the world he creates in his other band
column8: just one that has a little more logic to its rhythms. If Black Dice records often resemble a group of people furiously tossing around garbage
column9: Copeland's solo work is the sound of him arranging the trash into pretty shapes.

column1: Pitchfork's Marc Masters commented on how each release by Copeland has gotten ""more viscerally enjoyable"" in his review of 2012's Limbo
column2: and that continues here. ""Grapes"" is about as funky as he'll ever get
column3: driven by a loop that resembles a flattened-out Nile Rodgers guitar line that hilariously falls apart when extended to the point of disintegration. Copeland never exactly plays it straight
column4: but there are moments on ""Bobby Strong"" and ""Cheap Treat"" where the obsession with degrading his source material lightens
column5: closing in on the ultra-hectic rhythms of big beat. It's better when he's trying to assimilate the feel of a gut full of beer wobbling around on an impossibly hot day
column6: which he does to wonderfully vomitous effect on ""Babes in the Woods"". If Copeland is interested in the conventions of clubland
column7: it's at the point where someone’s puking on their shoes outside the venue
column8: a distant throb of bass beating into their brain through the brickwork.

column1: Copeland has always had a taste for the puerile-- Black Dice signed off from major labeldom last time out by constructing a cover collage that featured (among other things) the initials of the band scrawled over a naked
column2: bent-over ass. Here
column3: he dresses up his songs with titles like ""A Little Tit"" and ""New Leather Boogie"". DFA is even releasing an accompanying 12-inch to Joke in the Hole titled Masterbater. It might seem juvenile
column4: or even wearying that he's still ploughing that seam after releasing records for so long. But it continues to fit perfectly well with what he's doing
column5: which is essentially creating filthy
column6: funny
column7: non-dance music
column8: all somewhat akin to filtering samples through the frivolous approach of an oompah band. Mostly it's like coming across a public-access channel late at night
column9: where it never feels like the people on screen are fully in control. It works because Copeland isn't too rigidly stuck to his aesthetic
column10:
instead setting up his stall and letting the chaos pour in.

The three guys in Brooklyn’s Dawn of Midi play a grand piano
column2: an upright contrabass
column3: and a drum kit-- the same instrumentation used in traditional jazz piano trios. But it’s tricky to say where Dawn of Midi's new album Dysnomia fits within the jazz pantheon
column4: if it even fits in there at all. Unlike their minimalist free jazz debut First
column5: Dawn of Midi meticulously scripted and scored Dysnomia. For 46 continuous minutes
column6: the trio inverts free jazz into bound jazz
column7: torturing their instruments by playing as few notes as humanly possible. They write barely-there melodies that chase their own tails. They establish mercurial rhythms that are confusingly simple -- three humans dovetailing instrumental loops into thousands of subtly different permutations. It sounds close to an acoustic Beak> session playing a Steve Reich composition
column8: though even closer to something totally unprecedented.

column1: There’s been plenty of jazz groups that tried to reach out to the rock kids in recent years-- The Bad Plus and Brad Mehldau (both trios
column2: incidentally) have shown up on the radar with covers of indie rock songs
column3: though the covers feel more like like a bait and switch operations to get a wayward rockist into their more straight-ahead jazz charts. Unlike those groups
column4: Dawn of Midi aren’t interested in coddling the uninitiated into the world of trading fours and Dmaj11 chords. On Dysnomia
column5: they more interested in
column6: or rather wholly focused on
column7: rhythm. It's a new bridge out of traditional jazz to the rest of the world
column8: and it's built with obsessive precision.

column1: The pilgrimage begins with Aakaash Israni suggesting a tempo with two-note bass line. Then Amino Belyamani counters with one or two notes played with one hand while the other mutes the strings inside the body of the piano
column2: making the piano melodies on Dysnomia sound more often like a thwack on a cymbal stand or some Eastern banjo. The polyrhythms of the bass and piano lap each other until Qasim Naqvi connects all the pulses on on the kit and
column3: for a sustained moment
column4: trio is in sync. And when they coalesce like this it’s so rewarding in that kind of pseudo-spiritual way
column5: like when the tempo of the windshield wipers match up with the music in your car. But they all soon disengage and the three scatter off into new orbits at new speeds and prepare to align again.

column1: This rubric that Dawn of Midi uses-- the lost and found
column2: the tension and release-- has its closest cousins the digital world of Orbital
column3: DJ Shadow
column4: or Aphex Twin. The very real instruments on Dysnomia start to transform into breakbeats
column5: ambient textures
column6: a house hi-hat on “Nix”
column7: all with gradual builds with a few “drops” here and there. With a sleek mix by Rusty Santos
column8: who engineered Animal Collective’s Sung Tongs and mixed Owen Pallett’s Heartland
column9: it also shares more with these avant indie albums that used looped acoustic instruments to create free-form dance music-- the ""j-word"" has little to do with it.

column1: The ultimate irony of Dysnomia is that by playing with musical restraint
column2: they discover whole new avenues of sound that's focused on rhythm
column3: dismantling jazz with the tools that built it. And while it may be closest in spirit to ambient electronica or American minimalism
column4: it retains the tenor of a human
column5: organic quest for something spiritual and transformative. Who knew a grand piano
column6: a contrabass
column7: and a drum kit could actually get people nodding their heads the same way a DJ could? Dawn of Midi’s first triumph isn’t just a sleeker Can
column8: or a more narcotic Battles
column9: or a catnip for Radiohead fans who enjoy arguing whether or not “Pyramid Song” is in 4/4. It’s not just a piano trio that’s subverting the tenets of jazz
column10: either. It’s a missing link for two camps that have been diametrically opposed for years
column11:
speaking different musical languages and mostly failing to communicate. Guess no one ever thought to try to get the kids dancing.

Light in the Attic’s new compilation of tracks by Honey Ltd. opens with the female vocal quartet singing a curiously harmonized and lushly orchestrated song called “The Warrior.” It’s from 1968
column2: so you know they’re talking about Vietnam
column3: even if they never name that country. A lover readies himself for war
column4: then dies in a battlefield
column5: then is lowered into his grave a hero; the chorus goes
column6: “And it’s good
column7: it’s good… everybody knows it’s good.” Honey Ltd. play it so close to the chest that’s it’s hard to know just how to read the song nearly a half-century later. Is it a pro-war bromide
column8: a corrective to the kneejerk pacifism of the late 1960s? Is the song counter-counterculture? That could be an intriguing perspective-- and certainly not an unusual one for the time.

column1: The liner notes for The Complete LHI Recordings insist “The Warrior” is a “dark
column2: angry
column3: and wonderfully eloquent anti-war anthem.” In other words
column4: the song
column5: written by the group’s own Laura Polkinghome
column6: is meant to be a wake-up call to a war-ready America
column7: with air quotes around every “it’s good.” Intention
column8: however
column9: does not determine outcome
column10: and Honey Ltd. don’t really have the interpretive skills to make “The Warrior” sound angry or accusatory or bitterly ironic. They make it sound too sincere and too sensual
column11: which turn out to be their default settings. The four women fare better on less topical songs about romance gone sour
column12: which are less ambitious yet more straightforward. The Complete LHI Recordings collects every song Honey Ltd. recorded for Lee Hazlewood’s imprint
column13: which means it collects every songs they ever made. Even then it only adds up to 13 tracks
column14: two of which are instrumentals. In other words
column15: theirs is a story of a group only just getting started but never going anywhere.

column1: Honey Ltd. formed in the mid 1960s in Detroit: four Wayne State co-eds who harmonized in the cafeteria and eventually dubbed themselves the Mama Cats. After gigging with Glenn Frey (later of the Eagles) and Bob Seger
column2: they departed Motown for sunnier Los Angeles. You can hear that westward progression in their music
column3: which mixes the polite sounds of Motown vocal groups with the much less formal folk-pop of the West Coast. This is what the Crystals might have sounded like if they’d grown up in Laurel Canyon instead of Brooklyn. Or what the Mamas & the Papas might have sounded like if there’d been no Papas.

column1: After signing the group
column2: Hazlewood changed their name to Honey Ltd. and shooed them into the studio
column3: where he produced these 13 tracks over the course of a few months. As a result
column4: there is a uniformity of sound here that belies the comp’s catchall nature
column5: but Honey Ltd. are no Nancy Sinatra-- at least not at this early stage of their career. They can’t quite muster the romantic one-upmanship of “I’ve Got Your Man” and “No
column6: You Are”
column7: but they fare surprisingly well on the more psychedelic “For Your Mind” and “Silk 'n Honey”
column8: with its acrobatic high notes. And then there’s the cover of “Louie Louie”
column9: which Jack Nitzsche arranged at a slower tempo with an awkward
column10: protracted coda. It’s faintly ridiculous
column11: especially when Honey Ltd. get around to singing “me gotta go
column12: ” but those flashy horn blasts-- which sound 10 stories tall-- match the quartet's vocals much more astutely and naturally than all the acoustic and electric guitar that Hazlewood added to their production. It’s bold enough to make you wish they’d reteamed with Nitzsche again.

column1: It turns out
column2: however
column3: that the group truly was anti-war. In 1968 they did a USO tour with Bob Hope
column4: and their experience cemented their opposition to U.S. military presence in Vietnam. LHI did not share their outrage and persuaded the four singers to back off their stance. Once they bent to pressure
column5: they broke. Alexandra Sliwin married JD Souther and left the group
column6: and the remaining trio eventually disbanded. All that remains is a handful of songs and little in the way of a legacy. With so little of their promise realized
column7: The Complete LHI Recordings works less as a piece of revelatory music than as a historical artifact: a curio from a different era of politics and pop culture. The truncated quality of their career gives this compilation a tragic sheen
column8: though: Honey Ltd. obviously had ambitions to match their talents
column9:
but we can only wonder what they might have accomplished even with another 13 songs.

It's not clear what type of dream Chicago drone-rock outfit Implodes were referring to in the title of their recent LP Recurring Dream
column2: but it's a safe bet that it wasn't anything pleasant. The darkness engulfing that band can be unnerving at times
column3: but at least one of its members has found a way out. Ken Camden spends his time away from Implodes working on a solo career that demonstrates a fondness for sparse
column4: repeating figures
column5: all wrapped up in tracks described by his label as ""guitar/not guitar"" pieces. This is Camden's second solo album
column6: following the similarly minded Lethargy & Repercussion from 2010. The main difference on Space Mirror is a softer hew to the sound
column7: which is laid out in a cottony expanse that largely replaces the sharper edges of his prior record. Mostly he's concerned with a form of balmy future gazing that falls in line with the kind of work Emeralds once produced.

column1: There's a strong air of nostalgia to Camden's music here
column2: a hark back to the time when a kid could stare up at the night sky and dream of traveling to exotic purple planets. Camden chooses to let his imagination lead him through tracks that bring to mind towering ice palaces and blooming methane clouds. It's a thoughtful work
column3: expertly put together
column4: riddled with repetition but never to the point of boredom or distraction. He's as concerned with night terrors as he is with utopian dreams
column5: setting ""Moon"" on a gradual course to destruction but letting ""Spectacle"" just stand there shimmering. Camden works best when there's a lack of motion
column6: allowing tiny treated sounds to swell and fade
column7: favoring a form of evolution that barely exists at all.

column1: At times the playing is reminiscent of the point where Spacemen 3 collapsed inward circa Playing with Fire
column2: often recalling the scant
column3: echoing guitar lines in the front end of ""How Does It Feel?"". That's some impressive company to keep
column4: although Camden doesn't pull off the same affecting build of that song when he attempts something similar on ""Antares"". When he does favor journey over suspension he occasionally appears lacking in direction
column5: heading off in his own peculiar orbit without appearing to have a clear idea of where he's going. Space Mirror mostly succeeds when Camden is out there marvelling at the enormity of it all
column6: just taking in the view
column7: lost in his own head. As such it's an appropriate soundtrack to the stalled space race
column8: with human voyage perpetually spinning in place
column9: left in the hands of astronauts who simply shuttle back and forth across a miniscule expanse of the universe.

column1: Of course there's not much glamour in the thought of space travel being routine
column2: unadventurous
column3: and a rather unenlightening experience. That's certainly not what Space Mirror is about
column4: even if its great circling motions now have more in common with the crushing workaday nature of space travel than they do with astronauts padding around the centrifuge of Discovery One in 2001: A Space Odyssey. Camden's dreams are tilted in a more optimistic direction than the current state of things
column5: albeit ones that are butting up hard against reality. It might explain the sadness dripping out of ""Dominic Sunset""
column6: where the dream of a better world comes crashing down in a slow
column7: agonizing fashion. At least he sometimes reaches a point of hope on Space Mirror. In a sense it does feel like he's that kid with a crumpled star chart in hand
column8: picturing impossibly exotic worlds
column9:
fighting off the threat of disillusion with every turn he takes.

The sprawling instrumental rock of Explosions in the Sky has so often been called ""cinematic"" that it's easy to forget they've done little actual soundtrack work. One reason may be that their music
column2: where intricate layers of effects-laden guitar build to cathartic crescendos
column3: threatens to overshadow any but the hardiest onscreen action. It's all well and good for the colliding shoulder pads of Friday Night Lights
column4: but harder to imagine as fodder for the subdued character beats of a David Gordon Green film. Nevertheless
column5: Explosions in the Sky have teamed up with fellow Austinite David Wingo
column6: leader of indie rock band Ola Podrida and musical contributor to Green films such as All the Real Girls
column7: to score Prince Avalanche
column8: where two men repaint a wildfire-ravaged highway-- hardly a natural fit for starry guitar pyrotechnics.

column1: But Explosions in the Sky have been hunkered down in the extreme loud/soft dynamics of post-rock for almost 15 years now
column2: and the consistency of their maximalist glare
column3: which can only be done so many ways
column4: makes it easy to overlook the area where they have shown real growth: the nuance of their softer side. Over the course of their discography
column5: you can hear the band's interest shifting away from soaring peaks and toward the more finely textured valleys between them. On the Prince Avalanche OST
column6: they get to delve into more microscopic composition without tacking on perfunctory climaxes. The result is a collection of emotive
column7: melodious themes that makes for excellent around-the-house mood music. The band's diaphanous electric guitars are discerningly shaped in collaboration with Wingo
column8: who understands how movie music sounds and also knows his way around a line of melodic counterpoint
column9: as proven on Ola Podrida's excellent Ghosts Go Blind earlier this year.

column1: On Prince Avalanche
column2: the enormous
column3: trembling tremolo chords that usually hang like supernovas in Explosions' sky diffuse into a variety of subtler constellations
column4: mostly made of acoustic guitar and piano in counterpoint with electric shimmers and hums. There are taut
column5: crackling ambient pieces (""Fires""
column6: ""Wading""). There are haunting e-bowed meditations
column7: like the melody for saturated overtones on ""Theme from Prince Avalanche"" or the plaintive theme on ""Passing Time""
column8: which recurs on later tracks to give the record its elegiac emotional center. There is a waltz (""Dear Madison"")
column9: an eloquently slow and sad flamenco-like tune (""Hello
column10: Is This Your House?"")
column11: a misty piano interlude that wouldn't sound out of place on an Eluvium record. There are also a handful of more driving tracks
column12: especially deep cuts ""Join Me on My Avalanche"" and ""Send Off""
column13: where a subdued skyward gallop pays deference to the fans who have supported Explosions for so long. It's still questionable how this pretty
column14: solemn music will work in the quirky context of Green's film
column15:
but it makes for a nice little album on its own.

If you go to the YouTube channel for Richard X’s label Pleasure Masters and look up Annie’s first single
column3: “Anthonio
column4: ” the video-of-sorts will seem pretty standard at first: muted-strobe neon to match X’s take on Italo
column5: Star Wars lyrics scroll as blurry and blue-flecked as her memory of her fling
column6: everything executed according to promo protocol. Except lyrics videos generally don’t include lyrics that aren’t actually in the song. At the end
column7: the Pleasure Masters crew sneaks in a pair of parentheticals: ""(The End.) (For Now.)"" It makes sense in context

column9: and at the time a sneaky bit of meta-commentary: Pleasure Masters put the video up just as Annie was trying to free her sophomore album Don’t Stop from enough Island Records red tape to entangle it forever. (She left Island a few months prior and eventually got it released later in 2009.) And four years later
column10: after the Don’t Stop cycle came to its own end (for then)

column1: A&R
column2: Annie’s comeback EP
column3: stands for Annie and Richard X (and
column4: if you want to stretch the abbreviation

This isn’t necessarily a big aesthetic decision so much as Annie running out of viable ex-collaborators-- Don’t Stop‘s Paul Epworth’s subsequent work for a certain British upstart named Adele has likely knocked him permanently into a different orbit
column6: one where no matter when you read this he’s probably being asked for another “Rolling in the Deep”

column1: But it sounds like a big aesthetic choice. X and Robinson have been responsible for her best and best-known work-- “Chewing Gum”
column2: “Songs Remind Me of You”
column3: “I Know UR Girlfriend Hates Me”-- and more than that
column4: Richard X’s become synonymous during his career with the sort of lush
column5: nostalgic
column6: house-tinged productions that make his core fanbase swoon. Which is the other half of the pun; the five tracks on A&R match Annie to just the sort of repertoire the public’s demanding: danceable
column7: but subtle enough to be positioned as a counterpoint to stadium EDM; nostalgic for the same strains of 90s pop house (X has cited Telstar’s Deep Heat compilations as an inspiration) that Disclosure and others have taken to the charts. She’s always done that-- Anniemal predicted what’s becoming a decade of slightly skewed blog-pop
column8: and extragenre excursions like “Anthonio” have fit the revivals as well. And while there’s a cynical edge to a lot of this
column9: Annie’s always made it come off like this is just what euphoria happens to sound like to her.

column1: Or
column2: as one might say
column3: “you can lose yourself in the sound like it’s yesterday.” That’s the conceit of “Back Together”
column4: as intoxicating a rush of meta-nostalgia as any that’s been set to music. Co-written by Victoria Hesketh of Little Boots
column5: it’s such a dizzy trek through the best parts of Nocturnes that it’s shocking she didn’t keep it for herself. Unlike on the somewhat scattershot Don’t Stop
column6: the collaborators and tangents on A&R blend in seamlessly with the aesthetic: Robinson’s sparkling “Hold On”
column7: which is like RAZE’s sampled “Break 4 Love” in a flurry of confectionery sugar
column8: or closer “Mixed Emotions
column9: ” which works equally well as the crystalline bit of heartbreak on the dance floor that it is or the big-name remix you could assemble from the percussion breakdown and staccato synths underneath.

column1: All of this could come off overly studied in the wrong hands
column2: but A&R fortunately preserves Annie’s most compelling aspect of all: her wink. “Invisible”
column3: a sneaky grower of a rave-up
column4: introduces another name to the credits: “Mannie”
column5: Annie’s pitch-shifted impression of the loutish dude who wouldn’t call. It’s like a battle of the sexes performed by a woman and her club-mirror reflection
column6: and it adds to the track’s po-faced regret something else: levity
column7: frisson
column8: maybe even empowerment. “Ralph Macchio”
column9: meanwhile
column10: really is what you suspect it is
column11: which is a chirpy confession of love to the Karate Kid guy whose Google results have a Funny or Die hit in the first three results. (In the chorus: “Kiss me once and keep me forever
column12: Ralph Macchio!” Not in the chorus: irony.) It’s by far the goofiest of Annie’s nostalgia plays (her other crush-that-was was Joey McIntyre from New Kids On The Block.) But it works
column13: because the production’s as earnestly ebullient as anything else on the record and because Annie’s a past master at taking goofy subjects and turning them into utterly believable pop: a suitor in a terrible garage-rock band (“I Don’t Like Your Band”)
column14: an agony aunt letter about a summer hookup (“Anthonio” again)
column15:
the sentence “what do you want for breakfast?” deployed as a come-on (“The Breakfast Song”). It’s easy enough to pastiche up a house period piece; 15 people probably just finished one in Ableton. What’s harder to come by is a winning personality.

A month after Sean Kilfoyle's debut LP as Minks-- By the Hedge-- earned comparisons to shoegaze staples like early Creation Records releases
column3: the Brooklyn-based musician was already expressing a desire to move away from his ""wall of sound"" toward something more direct. Two years later
column4: Kilfoyle enlisted producer Mark Verbos
column5: an ex-pat of the Berlin electronic and techno scene
column6: to flesh out songs Kilfoyle sketched at the East End of Long Island
column7: where he had relocated to break a writer's block. The resulting Tides End follows a trajectory similar to Captured Tracks label mate Wild Nothing's Empty Estate EP
column8: trading vaporous guitars and indiscernible words for the bright
column9: perky lines of new synthesizers and more defined song structures.

column1: Despite Verbos' attempts to exorcise Kilfoyle's influences by making him listen to only Enigma and Chicago house during the recording process
column2: the old Minks that listened to Felt and recorded their first full-length in a basement studio still crop up occasionally on Tides End. ""Hold Me Now"" simmers with Disintegration-era synth tones (Kilfoyle claims the Cure are just a distant influence
column3: but it's impossible not to notice consistent similarities between the two) and a muffled
column4: insistent kick drum
column5: tranquil guitar tones settling like gauze over the quieter spaces between the lyrics. Other moments that seem like a natural progression from By the Hedge-- the brooding bass and dream-pop phrasings of ""Playboys of the Western World
column6: the heavy reverb that haunts ""Everything's Fine""-- are more subtle. For better or worse
column7: Verbos mostly accomplished what he set out to do.

column2: either. Much of Tides End might have been made as a reaction to the term ""lo-fi
column3: a descriptor Minks has often been pegged with. ""It's funny when people describe Minks as lo-fi. To me
column4: it's not very lo-fi at all
column5: he said in one interview
column6: and in another
column7: ""Bedroom pop this is not."" Regardless of whether it is or it isn't
column8: gone now are By the Hedge's meandering six-string textures; now every sound is clearly demarcated
column9: including Kilfoyle's voice
column10: which is actually quite affecting once you can hear it. (It's also more noticeable in the absence of former Minks co-vocalist Amalie Bruun
column11: who added to their debut's layered quality). That's probably the most redeeming part of Tides End
column12: which overall suffers from the loss of Bruun and the ""wall of sound"" Kilfoyle so desperately wanted to leave behind.

column1: Minks' vision goes awry from the beginning. Opener ""Romans"" is electro-pop at its most juvenile
column2: topping a mewling synth line with a bouncy beat and the lyrics ""Happy birthday to the worst friend in the world."" ""Margot"" is a close second
column3: galloping along at a double-time that's especially aggravating in light of Minks' earlier material
column4: songs that did just fine as they took the time and space to arrive at their lovely
column5: hazy conclusions. The rest of the tracks on Tides End aren't as bad as those two-- they aim for and
column6: more often than not
column7: hit a combination of Smithsian post-punk and the frothier parts of <i>Power
column8: Corruption and Lies-- but they're also not as good as they could be. While looking for something more immediate than By the Hedge
column9: Kilfoyle seems to have forgotten that Minks' original
column10: diaphanous guitar-driven melodies worked precisely because they were a little indefinable: they explored territory too subtle for a traditional pop song. Now that the veil has been lifted
column11:
there’s not much on Tides End worth the price of progress.

Sarah Lee Guthrie and her husband Johnny Irion have been singing together for 13 years and recording for eight. In that time
column2: they’ve released three studio albums that have been generally lumped in with the Americana set
column3: thanks primarily to their folksy harmonies and acoustic-based sound. Yet they’ve often bristled against the strictures of the roots scene
column4: and the duo have indulged their taste for unabashedly pop hooks and moody soundscapes. In other words
column5: they ought to be a perfect match for producer Jeff Tweedy: As frontman for Wilco
column6: he certainly knows a thing or two about screwing around with folk-rock conventions
column7: and as a helmer for Low and Mavis Staples
column8: he has devised a recognizable sound that is playful yet artful
column9: ambitious yet restrained. Furthermore
column10: he has a long history with the Guthrie family
column11: starting back in 1998 when he worked with Nora Guthrie to put music to some of her father Woody’s unrecorded lyrics. That incredibly fruitful project produced three LPs’ worth of strong material and launched a cottage industry of sorts. Sarah Lee is Nora’s niece and Woody’s granddaughter
column12: which makes her the third generation of Guthries
column13: living or dead
column14: to work with Tweedy in some capacity.

column1: With Wilco’s Patrick Sansone he co-produced Guthrie and Irion’s new record
column2: Wassaic Way
column3: but any expectations that artists and producers are well matched are immediately dispelled on the very first song
column4: which is called “Chairman Meow”. Seriously. It’s a slice of tooth-decay meme-pop about a girl with a crib in Koreatown
column5: a movie in production
column6: and a cat with a clever name. Never mind that it’s impossible to determine if the song is parody or paean: it just sounds bad. Tweedy and Sansone turn the treble all the way up and the bass all the way down
column7: which renders everything tinny and shrill. The drums plod along
column8: the fuzz guitar fizzes like a child’s toy
column9: the voices take on a pre-adolescent pitch. It all sounds juvenile.

column1: Wassaic Way could be a sequel to Guthrie's 2009 children's album
column2: Go Waggaloo. While there's nothing wrong with targeting the pre-K set (check out Tweedy's version of Woody's ""Hoodoo Voodoo"" for proof)
column3: there is something alienating about treating adult listeners like children. Whether attempting upbeat power pop or nestling into a saccharine ballad
column4: these songs are persistently coy and cloying
column5: with lyrics about butterflies and trick-or-treat that habitually mistake platitudes for insights. ""How are we here? What are we made of?"" Guthrie asks on ""Circle of Souls. ""Now the dream is clear
column6: so what are we afraid of?"" It sounds lofty and portentous
column7: but ultimately sacrifices meaning for rhyme.

column1: Despite-- or
column2: perhaps
column3: due to-- Guthrie and Irion’s long history as bandmates and spouses
column4: their voices go together all too well. One is cake
column5: the other icing: both are uniformly sugary
column6: but they do the same thing
column7: set the same tone
column8: and convey the same emotions in exactly the same way. There’s no contrast between them
column9: therefore no tension or conflicts in these songs. Surprisingly
column10: they sound better when they sing solo
column11: as on “Circle of Souls” or “Not Probably Gone”. Even more surprisingly
column12: they sound best at their most conservative

column14:
like “Still Dreaming” or the harmonica-drenched title track. It's pleasant enough-- not exactly memorable but also not actively off-putting to a grown-up listener.

There's an immense sense of satisfaction that comes with watching a band progress. It’s exhilarating to see talented
column2: hardworking people take those first steps out of the practice room and into the world armed with only a handful of riffs and ambition. Sometimes it takes awhile
column3: and sometimes the rewards come fast. The excellent Oakland death doom quartet Lycus have taken the latter path. Their first release
column4: 2011’s Demo MMXI
column5: made the rounds quietly
column6: catching underground attention with three gutted paeans simmering beneath a stark
column7: skeletal Bryan Proteau cover. It felt raw and honest
column8: and captured the imagination in a way that’s rarely seen from metal’s extreme outliers. On Tempest
column9: their first proper album
column10: and first for 20 Buck Spin
column11: the rough edges have been sanded down
column12: and the light shines through.

column1: Often used interchangeably with ""death doom
column2: funeral doom is more accessible than the most perverse
column3: impenetrable corners of black metal
column4: death
column5: and grind
column6: but don’t be fooled-- the punishing lengths
column7: torturously slow tempos
column8: and disquieting emotional heft it offers still inflict plenty of damage. Those who enter into the darkest depths of this suicidal subsect are asked to abandon all hope
column9: and given little choice in the matter. Lycus approach the void carefully. Though they’ve had the funeral doom tag lobbed at them already
column10: it’s not entirely accurate: 11 minute songs do not a funeral doom band make
column11: and Lycus show no interest in following genre conventions. They refrain from histrionic
column12: death-worshipping self-hatred and instead embrace a more cosmic
column13: organic take on sorrow. Given their Bay Area lineage
column14: it’s not hard to connect the dots and see that their proximity to like-minded acts Asunder
column15: Graves At Sea
column16: and Noothgrush has made an impact.

column1: Their approach eschews the classic European emphasis on keyboards and overly flowery gothic influence
column2: focusing instead on the sludgier
column3: more straightforward sound that American bands often gravitate towards. Think Samothrace
column4: not Skepticism. Opening dirge “Coma Burn” sets the tone down low
column5: with rumbling vocals and ominous chords. Their penchant for tremolo (as heard on the effortlessly
column6: engagingly dynamic “Engravings”) speaks of a faint black metal influence
column7: one that intensifies into mania during the epic closing track.  After the listener is taken through peaks and valleys of howling black metal
column8: slavering sludge
column9: and contemplative doom
column10: “Tempest” lets us down gently
column11: fading out in a gentle blur of noise. Punctuated by mournful violins
column12: each of the album’s three compositions flows beautifully into the next
column13: allowing for a force of movement seldom seen within the style. Melancholia reigns
column14: yet there is no gnashing of teeth or soot-smeared wails permeating the monolithic riffs. They are better than that. Lycus have entered the next stage of mourning with this release
column15:
and their early stages of grief have matured into dignified resignation and graceful acceptance.

In 1995
column2: the the Chicago-based band Red Red Meat and the Brooklyn-based band Rex concluded a tour and decided to record together. Red Red Meat was on the road behind their minor masterpiece Bunny Gets Paid
column3: while Rex
column4: a slowcore band that included drummer Doug Scharin
column5: also of Codeine
column6: was promoting their self-titled debut on Southern Records. The bands had some things in common: both could be very subtle and focused on details
column7: letting space do a lot of work
column8: and both were steeped in the history of American music and ready to bend the textures and songs of the past to their own
column9: more postmodern
column10: ends. The joint record was recorded by Chicago mainstay Bundy K. Brown and Red Red Meat sonic mastermind Brian Deck and the sessions were described as loose and improvisatory. The resulting record
column11: Loftus
column12: wouldn’t be released until 2000
column13: by which time both original bands were no longer. To say that initial issue of the album didn’t get around would be an understatement. I know many serious fans of Red Red Meat and Califone (the Tim Rutili-led band band RRM transitioned into) who have never heard of it. It seemed somehow appropriate that this artifact
column14: which sounded like something that been pulled out from underneath a rotting log
column15: would fade away. But now it returns with this carefully assembled vinyl/digital reissue.

column1: Though I listened to Rex a bit at the time
column2: I’ve always considered Loftus firmly as a Red Red Meat side project
column3: in part because this record sound so clearly like a step in their steady evolution from a blues-obsessed grunge band to a noisy avant-folk group exploring the concept of studio-as-instrument. There was a glorious tension in their work during the 1990s
column4: as they followed their muse in what seems like opposite directions but found a way to make them meet in the middle. On the one hand
column5: they were exploring deep blues and rustic folk from the dawn of recorded history
column6: finding inspiration in the old
column7: weird America and used as a springboard for the acoustic experimentation in music a few years later (every generation
column8: it seems
column9: hears something new in the Anthology of American Folk Music). But they were also keeping abreast of rapidly changing technology
column10: using sequencers
column11: computers
column12: and loops to give their music a mechanized clang that
column13: in the most distant way
column14: owed something to industrial-leaning dance music. So you had ancient song structures and modern technology working in tandem to create music that sounded remarkably new.

column1: The Loftus record found these experiments happening at the hazier end of the spectrum. The album alternates proper songs with instrumental interludes that feel more like sketches but somehow
column2: the patchy nature of the album as a whole works to its advantage. So a track like the banjo-led instrumental “Theme From Loftus Nine”
column3: which sets a simple chord projection over wafts of organ and feedback
column4: accumulates its power in the context of the whole. On one side of it you have “King Carp in a Dan Ryan Ditch”
column5: which consists of looped fragments of delicate sound that are eventually obliterated by crashing drums that sound like a hammer beating on the side of an empty boxcar
column6: and on the other side you have “Nervous”
column7: a taut
column8: bass-driven instrumental filled with creeping menace. These abstract tracks wash over like a half-remembered dream and contribute to the sense of the album as a place
column9: something you sink into for 40 minutes.

column1: But there are some fantastic songs mixed in with the drones and creaks
column2: and the juxtaposition of the two is what really makes the record. “Haywine” begins with one of the eeriest blues riffs I’ve heard
column3: as single notes of palpable texture are bent into a gorgeously expressive shape
column4: and the song that emerges from the fog
column5: the voice processed to a half-dead gurgle
column6: expresses a rare sense of downcast weariness. “Stolen From a Rifle Clean Brothel” is a bracingly simple upbeat blues
column7: just acoustic guitar
column8: a bass
column9: and a bit of cheesy organ
column10: and has the dank tossed off-brilliance as the third side of Exile on Main Street
column11: the sort of thing Royal Trux was also nailing around this time.

column1: The cover of Loftus shows an image of a jawbone on a tan background
column2: which
column3: on both the CD issue and (big respect for going this extra mile) the LP reissue
column4: is made of sandpaper. When it sits on the shelf
column5: if you don’t keep it in a plastic sleeve
column6: the abrasion of this sleeve will slowly and steadily wear on the record next to it
column7: scuffing it leaving its mark. Loftus itself is a slowly burning thing
column8: a record that both evokes the march of time and
column9: here and there
column10: seems to stop it. Late in the album comes “Penguin Boy's Love Story”
column11: quite possibly the most beautiful song Tim Rutili has written
column12: an achingly sad slow dance that is like a half-speed Santo & Johnny’s “Sleepwalk” mixed with harmonized voices sung by a quartet of ghosts. “This is where we’ll come for water
column13: ” goes the refrain
column14:
expressing the elemental feel of record that deserves another chance to be heard.

Kyary Pamyu Pamyu is the most popular J-pop performer in the Western Hemisphere
column2: which makes sense because she’s the most Western J-pop performer in Japan. It’s a quality that’s embedded right in her name: “Kyary” is the closest Japanese-language approximation of the Western name “Carrie
column3: ” which her high school classmates teased her with when they thought she was dressed in a too typically “American” style. (She added the “Pamyu Pamyu” part just because she thought it sounded good.)

column1: Her fashion sense isn’t the only element that makes Kyary such a Western-oriented artist
column2: but it explains some of it. Before she began her musical career two years ago she was a hardcore harajuku girl who managed to flip her sartorial instincts into a career as a fashion blogger and model
column3: and even released her own signature line of fake eyelashes. It’s a far more independent
column4: entrepreneurial backstory than most J-pop artists
column5: who tend to be plucked out of obscurity by managers who mold them with factory precision to a prespecified blueprint before they’re introduced to their audience.

column1: The video for her 2011 debut single
column2: “PonPonPon”
column3: introduced viewers to a Kyary Pamyu Pamyu aesthetic that was already fully formed
column4: a hyperkinetic pileup of lysergically vivid Japanese design sensibilities and American pop culture detritus-- a literal pile of garishly colored
column5: mostly plastic stuff including a giant box of Kraft mac & cheese
column6: creepy stuffed animals
column7: and a Green Bay Packers “cheesehead” hat. It also established Kyary as a multimedia artist along the lines of Björk and Lady Gaga
column8: whose aesthetic instincts are strong enough that she’s allowed to scribble way outside of the lines most pop stars have to operate within. Along with the kawaii props and posing there’s a dancing woman in a full-face stocking mask (who seems to be a man in drag) and at one point the video’s star farts a beam of strobing abstract computer graphics.

column1: Nanda Collection
column2: her second LP and first to be officially released in the U.S.
column3: continues in the direction that “Ponponpon” established
column4: which is to say it feels like a face-first dive into a Takashi Murakami painting. Its unrelenting Day-Glo anime psychedelia isn’t for everyone
column5: and the level of constant overstimulation it maintains throughout its running time on could probably trigger a panic attack in more sensitive listeners.

column1: If you can handle the barrage of synthesizer marching bands
column2: PS1-era video game noises
column3: and Kyary’s overwhelming kawaii-ness
column4: Nanda Collection is a fascinating listen. It’s very much a J-pop record
column5: with the requisite synth-pop and smooth disco numbers that entails
column6: along with a jazzy piano flourish here and there
column7: but it frequently breaks from the form’s conventions. Its first single
column8: “Invader Invader”
column9: is essentially a Rapture-style dance punk track rendered in candy-colored electronics
column10: at least until the part where it turns into a synth emulation of a metalcore breakdown mixed with a dubstep drop. Halfway through the straightforward-seeming “Fashion Monster”
column11: the song’s high speed bubblegum melts down into a psychedelic drone for a minute before swerving back.

column1: Like Murakami
column2: Kyary’s take on kawaii has a weird
column3: sinister edge to it
column4: and she seems to enjoy keeping her audience slightly unsettled. For instance she’s fond of painting over her real mouth with oversized
column5: distorted mouths that are cartoony but also freakish-- a grotesque mutation to put a strange spin on her overwhelmingly cute image. She does something similar musically
column6: and at times Nanda Collection feels almost like a twisted parody of J-pop
column7: with overclocked tempos that are just a little too fast
column8: and the usual cheery mood amplified to a discomfiting level. “Kurakura” feels downright malevolent
column9: alternating between lurching oompah-band circus music and Kyary’s multi-tracked voice chanting “kura kura” over and over while a glockenspiel repeats a maddeningly dissonant figure
column10: and overall it sounds like Danny Elfman at his most intentionally nightmarish.

column1: Despite years of predictions that J-pop’s big American break is just around the corner
column2: it still seems supremely unlikely to happen. The style’s earnestly upbeat mood isn’t edgy enough for American tastes
column3: and for the most part we aren’t interested in foreign pop culture. The odds of Kyary finding a mass audience here seem slim
column4: but not exactly zero. She’s already found an audience outside the usual Japanophile consumers
column5: specifically a cultish following of Tumblr users who look up to her twisted interpretation of kawaii
column6:
and it’s not unimaginable that she could find some fans in the mainstream. She’s already breaking most of J-pop’s rules and traditions. What’s one more?

Patricia Hall and Ian Hicks of the Los Angeles-based synth act Soft Metals approach their music with the loose conceptual framework of avant-garde sound artists rather than musicians. The duo
column3: who started dating right around their band's formation
column4: refer to Soft Metals albums as “works being commissioned” and stand apart from their boy-girl synth contemporaries like Kisses and Glass Candy
column5: simply because their electronic compositions are several shades darker
column6: stalking around ominously on the back of churning keyboards and drum machines
column7: often without any discernable hook or cathartic crescendo. Their self-titled 2011 debut album had flashes of poppier aspirations amidst the busy distorted breakbeats and murky bedroom production
column8: but those moments were almost always subverted by Hall’s ethereal
column9: distant vocals and unnervingly detached lyrical persona.

column1: For their latest album Lenses
column2: Hall and Hicks relocated from Portland to Echo Park
column3: setting up a home studio after failed attempts to write and record in a professional space. Like their self-titled debut
column4: they worked through the new material by participating in extended improvised jam sessions
column5: shaping and editing the new batch of songs from long dirges of chugging krautrock rhythms set to the Teutonic tick of an 808 drum machine. But Lenses dives deeper into the hallucinogenic soundscapes from their previous work via subtraction; instead of pushing toward more pop inflected compositions and building off the moments of melody from their previous album
column6: they've pared down their work
column7: focusing on the hypnotic depths of the repetitive synthesizer movements and brittle keyboards of Kraftwerk and John Carpenter’s classic movies scores. The production allows most of the tracks’ spartan compositions to reverberate in cavernous expanses of space
column8: while Hall’s ghostly voice waxes dreamy poetics about the doors of perception and altered states of consciousness.

column1: Hall’s heady lyrical abstractions were inspired
column2: in part
column3: by a moment of clarity she reached during a mushroom and ecstasy fueled dance party. “<span>We'd be there for 10 hours dancing and then I start seeing cave paintings on the wall
column4: ” Hall told me when I interviewed her for Paper. “It made me think of how this couldn't be very different from what prehistoric people were doing. They were gathering
column5: and dancing around a fire
column6: listening to this primitive music and having these really incredible experiences connecting with one another.” But while Hall and Hicks’ aspiration to explore weighty philosophical ruminations through their impressionistic songwriting is an interesting goal
column7: the results are more admirable than listenable.

column1: This is pretty evident on Lenses’ title track
column2: which attempts to create an abstract patchwork of synth arpeggios
column3: but never quite congeals into a coherent enough piece to merit attention. That
column4: and Hall’s vocal work here is marred by an unflattering harmony and cringe-worthy
column5: sophomore philosophy major's lyrics: “Breaking through my perception of you/ Breaking through my concept of life/ Breaking through what the mirror reflects/ Breaking through the way that I move.” “Tell Me” does a much better job working out the rhythmic dimensions that Hall and Hicks seem to be striving for
column6: pulsing from a spiraling synthesizer riff and four-on-the-floor beat as Hall sings breathy lyrics that are alluring in their sensual crypticism (“Tell me/ Has this come true?”)
column7: while staying much closer to the central melody than she did to worse effect on “Lenses”. On the occasions Soft Metals inch nearer to pop songcraft
column8: like they do with the bass-heavy R&B light show of “On a Cloud” or the arty melodrama of “No Turning Back”
column9: the results are surprisingly effective
column10: especially considering the ways in which the duo’s penchant for breakneck cyclical synth patterns augment their prettiest harmonies with a paranoid sense of unease.

column1: In the end
column2: Lenses comes off like a proggy
column3: synth pop album that wants to get treated like sound sculpture
column4: but Soft Metals don't fully commit to either endeavor in spite of the record's handful of successes. Regardless
column5: they've admirably carved out their own corner of the electro world; Hall and Hicks are determined to make challenging
column6:
cerebral EDM and have more on their minds than the placement of the next drop.

The gap between awful and awesome can be small and unpredictable. Consider Forestelevision
column2: the third album by Seattle quartet Lesbian. Across one 44-minute track
column3: the band manages to move without pause from aching funeral doom to arching classic thrash
column4: from acid-washed electric jazz to acrobatic prog-rock
column5: from ambling stoner rumble to assailant death metal. And that’s merely a sample. Forestelevision is the shortest Lesbian album to date
column6: respectively clocking in at 20 and 30 minutes less than 2007’s Power Hor and 2010’s Stratospheria Cubensis. But its series of suites
column7: starts
column8: stops
column9: misdirections
column10: and redirections makes for their most audacious and zealous LP. It feels wide-eyed and enthusiastic
column11: too
column12: as if played by kid prodigies out in the garage
column13: recreating every new heavy sound they hear. That is the awesome part.

column1: But Forestelevision stumbles toward awful when its music moves beyond the theoretical-- you know
column2: when you actually listen to the thing. Lesbian pilfer genres that tend to deliver all-consuming experiences
column3: whether that’s the steady Sunn O)))-style quakes that open Forestelevision or the warped krautrock fantasies that soon follow. But Lesbian is too distracted and too focused on showing us that they can swivel between all these styles for this single song to ever whisk away its audience. Just past the halfway mark
column4: for instance
column5: they enter a particularly technical passage that flips between iron-fisted math metal and brief psych-rock washouts
column6: with onyx
column7: hoarse vocals inlaid through it all. Listening to the section by itself
column8: it’s easy to hear how good Lesbian is as a band. Listening to it as part of Forestelevision’s 44 minutes
column9: however
column10: it simply recalls the part of a Girl Talk album where it just becomes too much
column11: where the obsession with an inundation of so many parts gets stupid and masturbatory. This is a very long song
column12: sure
column13: but you almost want Lesbian to take it slower
column14: or at least to take less of it. They can’t sit still
column15: meaning the listener can’t settle in.

column1: None of this is to say that Forestelevision is a complete waste. In lieu of offering a sample track from the album
column2: as it consists of only one track
column3: Lesbian doled out edits of their 44-minute monster in the weeks leading up to its release. Those digestible samples worked better than the full course
column4: turns out
column5: showcasing the range of the group without overwhelming by virtue of it. The merry-go-round ballet between piercing guitars and calliope keyboards is exhilarating in 10-minute bursts
column6: as is the NWOBHM supremacy that lords over the album’s end. But continuously listening from one Forestelevision highlights to another is a task best left to the masochistic. What’s more
column7: for all its stylistic gumption
column8: Forestelevision is generally clumsy and awkward with jarring fusions and fumbled handoffs. Lesbian’s ideas are bigger than their ability to arrange them
column9: only exacerbating the feeling of unease.

column1: The future seems precarious for Lesbian after making a record like Forestelevision. This album is a grand idea that they’re just not yet good enough to pull off. Sure
column2: they more than pass muster technically
column3: even when Dorando Peter Hodous’ chameleonic vocals get swallowed by the sounds that surround him. But the net effect of the record is that of joyless sex or sports practice-- something that’s trudged through because it’s always suggestive of a better
column4: more fulfilling version of itself. That doesn’t mean Lesbian can’t make something like this compelling. With some heavy edits and rewritten transitions
column5: and with production that allows for space between these sardine-packed parts
column6: Forestelevision or its successors might actually work. So what’s next: Do they try such a stunt again
column7: committing themselves as composers charged with making each subsequent symphony a bit better than the one before it? But is that limiting and redundant? Or do they retreat toward previous iterations and make an album that bites off a bit less with each track? And does that qualify as defeat? Maybe
column8: but then again
column9:
so does an album that so adamantly wants to be awesome it actually becomes awful.

"|18093.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18093-lesbian-forestelevision/|5.0|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19458/homepage_large.96369147.jpg|You've Always Meant So Much to Me|31484.0|Wrekmeister Harmonies|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2013-08-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:57.087176|"

Who will lay claim to You’ve Always Meant So Much to Me
column2: the second proper album from Chicago sound art project Wrekmeister Harmonies? During its sole
column3: 38-minute track
column4: the dozen-member ensemble led by J.R. Robinson builds from asymptotic silence into space-age electroacoustic drone
column5: and from browbeating doom metal into
column6: ultimately
column7: a circular
column8: harp-flecked denouement. Within Robinson’s magnetic musical current
column9: the distance from beer-soaked rock club to incense-scented yoga studio is but one quick fadeout.

column1: That notion is backed up by the varied personnel he recruited for this massive instrumental beauty: Jef Whitehead-- better known as Wrest
column2: of U.S. black metal belligerents Leviathan-- adds drums
column3: while seasoned studio musician and distinguished improviser Fred Lonberg-Holm plays cello; there’s viola from Julie Pomerleau
column4: a musician with a wealth of indie rock experience
column5: and electronics from high-tone harsh noise priest Mark Solotroff. It’s an unlikely crew
column6: the sort of experts-in-their-field assembly that you expect to be financed by a major label. Instead
column7: it was simply fostered by the musical diversity of Chicago. But You’ve Always Meant So Much to Me doesn’t fit conveniently into any of its makers’ scenes-- noise or post-rock
column8: metal or classical-- because it falls too far into other scenes into which it doesn’t completely fit
column9: either. Doom or drone
column10: new age or space rock? That barely matters: You’ve Always Meant So Much to Me is a terrific monument of simultaneous stylistic acceptance and avoidance.

column1: Robinson constructed this music as the score for a film of the same name
column2: shot from a rooftop in Long Island City
column3: in the desert of Joshua Tree
column4: and in the urban ruins of Detroit. “It’s a classic example of structural filmmaking
column5: where the camera does all of the work for you
column6: ” he recently explained. “There were long
column7: static shots... Nature doing its thing to nature
column8: and nature doing its thing to man.” Such a sense of vulnerability and predictability define this piece
column9: in part because its direction and structure are at once obvious and enthralling-- that is
column10: nearly as soon as it starts
column11: you know exactly where it’s going
column12: but hearing the process itself develop is still captivating.

column1: Here
column2: Wrekmeister Harmonies feels like a stateside
column3: kid-friendly answer to Australia’s the Necks. A gentle bell peal opens You’ve Always Meant So Much to Me
column4: serving as an invocation for the electronic hum and patchwork of phrases and patterns that follow. Upright bass skips along in deep zigs and zags
column5: while shouts and hisses shoot through the space like errant asteroids. A harp traipses. A harmonium howls. A viola weeps. All these sounds grow together for the first 22 minutes or so
column6: gathering eventually into the same great post-rock swell that you might’ve predicted at the track’s beginning. And then it all crashes down
column7: with Whitehead hammering the drums in mid-tempo wrath
column8: evacuating the air beneath distorted guitars and tidal strings and saturating electronics. With the dependability of the setting sun
column9: the beating stops eight minutes later
column10: giving way to an extended trickle back toward silence. Again
column11: the end result
column12: like the middle
column13: is predictable
column14: but the path toward it is both engrossing and wonderful all the same. Wrekmeister Harmonies use familiar elements from Neu! and Neurosis
column15: free jazz and Swans to offer a compass within a sometimes disorienting patchwork of sound. To further facilitate that navigation
column16: Robinson employees a traditional format-- quiet
column17: louder
column18: loudest
column19: quieter-- to let you know where you’re going
column20: just not how you’ll get there.

column1: There’s a temptation to talk about records such as You’ve Always Meant So Much to Me as proof that heavy metal is itself going places
column2: getting smarter and becoming more adventurous. Wrekmeister Harmonies
column3: one could suggest
column4: stands in the midst of some advancing experimental frontier. And
column5: sure
column6: fans of the liminal heaviness of Sunn O)))
column7: Earth
column8: Locrian or those that have used volume and riffs to push outside of metal’s confines will likely want to slip inside of Robinson’s protracted rise and fall here. But Robinson’s work feels too personal to be part of any movement
column9: too centered on the intricacies of its own action to be concerned with anyone else’s activities. Its intentionality feels entirely internal
column10:
like a deep and calming breath that just happens to be exhaled in the same direction in which the wind is blowing.

Berlin has a well-deserved reputation for producing aggressively tasteful minimal techno but it also has a warmer
column3: more human side that doesn’t often attract the same level of attention. At the forefront of that scene are Apparat (aka Sascha Ring) and Modeselektor (the duo of Gernot Bronsert and Sebastian Szary)
column4: and their 2009 album as Moderat was a massive
column5: supergroup-level event for a very
column6: very particular kind of electronic music fan.

column1: After several productive years apart
column2: the trio has reconvened for a second full-length. Four years is a long time in the fast-moving dance music world (more than enough time for whole genres to bloom
column3: wither
column4: and die)
column5: but Ring
column6: Bronsert
column7: and Szary have picked up pretty much exactly where they left off. The major differences between II and their self-titled debut is that their sonic sensibilities have grown more refined and compelling
column8: and that the world has just about caught up to them.

column1: Luckily the album’s weakest moment comes early on
column2: and is therefore quickly dealt with. “Bad Kingdom”
column3: II’s first song after a brief intro
column4: has a wicked instrumental bed with a sparse breakbeat drum part and growling sawtooth synths-- if it had been released a few months earlier
column5: Kanye might have sampled it on Yeezus somewhere. But it’s topped by a vocal that’s afflicted with the kind of generic Euro-soul inflection that American ears have a hard time dealing with
column6: and the juxtaposition between the aggressive synths and airy pop vocals weakens the former rather than creating an interesting contrast.

column1: Things pick up after that. The trio seem intent on exploring (and blurring) the line some electronic music fans draw between “dancefloor listening” and “headphone listening.” They favor unhurried tempos
column2: and tend to emphasize texture over melody
column3: but it’s not simply chill-out music either. “Let in the Light” runs at considerably lower BPM than the average peak-hour banger
column4: but the echo-laden-yet-punchy drums
column5: swelling synth chords
column6: and a far stronger vocal melody than the one on “Bad Kingdom” make it easy to imagine how it could provide an amped-up crowd going off to it if the right DJ was daring enough to drop it in a mix.

column1: The album peaks right around its midpoint with the track “Milk”
column2: which over 10 minutes evolves from the barest rhythmic sketch embellished with a few ambient sounds into an swarm of pulsing synths drifting in clouds of white noise
column3: the whole time repeating one brief melodic line that somehow gets more compelling the more it repeats. It lacks the hard edges and aggressive drive that most big-room rave anthems are built from
column4: but it’s still precisely engineered to produce the same kind of world-shaking late night epiphany.

column1: Moderat was a peculiar sounding album at the time. Outside of dubstep and a burgeoning drum & bass revival
column2: breakbeats weren’t really in fashion
column3: and some of the songs were structured like pop songs and boasted pop vocal parts but were still sonically rooted in the sounds of the electronic fringe. Since then a two-step renaissance has bubbled up out of the remnants of the underground dubstep scene and spread throughout dance music
column4: and as pop radio moves increasingly EDM-ward listeners have made weird synthesized sounds de rigueur in the mainstream. So II is just about perfectly synchronized with the zeitgeist
column5: and if it’s not a flawlessly executed record
column6:
it still seems capable of making the most out of its moment.

Boston quartet Morne has
column3: to date

column8: only to emerge into recalcitrant
column9: noisy rumbles gilded by strings and electronics.

column1: If the first four years in the Morne workshop were about building something ornate
column2: however

column6: a flood of sound emptying into a void. The motion eventually rises into a half-time charge of seesaw melodies and sandpaper screams
column7: a black mass of stepwise accretion. Indeed

column9: anchored by a militaristic drum tromp. But the song’s midsection browbeats with sluggish thrash
column10: a heavyweight attempting to summon a featherweight’s agility. “New Dawn” first feels like an attempt to crush with sheer sonics

column12: however

Raffertie is the latest in a line of dance music producers to move to subtle and grown-up R&B-ish music. It feels strange in the London artist's case
column2: however
column3: because at the beginning of Benjamin Stefanski's career he was behind some of the zaniest dubstep of the genre's late-2000s boom. Tunes like ""7th Dimension"" made colourful pyrotechnics out of dubstep's skank
column4: and even as he moved to house his penchant for larger-than-life sound design stuck around. But after founding his own Super label and then signing to Ninja Tune in 2011 (not to mention graduating from a conservatory)
column5: every new missive showed him gradually quieting his weirder impulses. And then
column6: a few months ago
column7: it peaked-- Raffertie dropped ""Build Me Up""
column8: a quivering crooner
column9: appearing on the single's sleeve all dolled up and proper. His long-awaited debut album
column10: Sleep of Reason
column11: strolls down the same path

column1: Unlike so many other former dance artists
column2: songcraft isn't a hurdle for Stefanski. He's always had an ear for melody; he discovered AlunaGeorge
column3: after all. His vocal tunes are blessed with simple
column4: hooky phrases

column1: Elsewhere on the album
column2: Stefanski duels with his own atmosphere: the conflicting impulse at the heart of his musical development. ""Build Me Up"" competes with its instrumental
column3: and elsewhere Raffertie's delicate melodies are trampled underfoot by the remnants of his over-the-top musical persona. It's when he aims for for something bolder than quiet storm R&B that he most succeeds. On ""Principle Action""
column4: his voice gets swallowed by a buzzing wall of sound
column5: but it's meant to
column6: and it's breathtaking. ""Gagging Order""
column7: on the other hand
column8: has a catchy theme buried somewhere beneath its array of fidgety sounds
column9: but I'd be hard-pressed to recover it.

column1: Carrying over some tracks from past Ninja Tune EPs
column2: Sleep of Reason isn't a straight pop album; its best moments pulse with the nuclear energy of those early Planet Mu EPs. ""One Track Mind"" is the highlight
column3: violently exploding arpeggios and all
column4: and Raffertie's evolution into an expert arranger means he's always calm and in control. Skippy garage makes a welcome appearance propping up tender ballad ""Touching""
column5: and quieter moments like ""Undertow"" are fascinating vignettes of intricate digital build-up and decay. But in his consummately cautious approach
column6: he loses some of his personality; moments like ""Last Train Home"" and the maudlin duet ""Trust"" feel like they could have been made by anyone.

column1: Sleep of Reason ends in a flurry of emotion with the closing couplet ""Black Rainbow"" and ""Back of The Line""
column2: where Raffertie controls waves of distortion and searing climax as if he were parting the sea. ""Back of The Line"" is especially affecting
column3: where he warbles the choked voice of a man stuck behind his machines
column4: constantly trying not to be dwarfed by their immensity. That's what most of Sleep of Reason sounds like-- it's an uneven but captivating album that sounds like an artist still looking for his stride and trying to balance between two extremes. He does it better than some of his peers
column5:
but he still has a while to go yet.

Ka's voice isn't overexcited. It's not larger-than-life
column2: not a caricature

column1: Last year's Grief Pedigree showed a DIY auteur with one of the more unique and underreported stories in hip-hop. Despite the exposure that comes with his professional working partnership with Roc Marciano and a base in the ironclad diehard world of 1990s-steeped NYC hardcore hip-hop

His outlook on that recent groundswell of support has the levelheaded perspective of someone hitting his stride in his forties: “Of course this isn't over night sensation music...it's the music of the sensations you get over the course of the night”

Emmett Kelly's the deliberate type
column2: not usually one to rush things. It took Kelly's Cairo Gang some seven years to follow their fine 2006 debut with a proper full-length

column4: solemn The Corner Man. In the meantime

column7: characteristically stark Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy records. Kelly's exacting nature comes through in much of his recent work: he rarely uses two notes when one will do.

column1: Tiny Rebels

column3: finds Kelly throwing much of that caution to the wind. Rebels came together in a fit of inspiration: recorded in a week
column4: with both the same musicians and the same instruments on every track
column5: the reverb-thick
column6: unabashedly Byrdsy Rebels is driven by a spontaneous streak even Kelly seems a little surprised he had in him. Not that Rebels is some slapdash affair; Kelly and company committed every sound on Rebels to quarter-inch tape

column9: just as psychedelia started creeping its way toward folk-rock. But
column10: amidst Rebels' taut harmonies and stately chord shuffles-- and despite the backward glance of its sonics-- there's an undeniable urgency at work here
column11: a sense that this stuff all but burst forth from Kelly
column12:
fully-formed.

Still

column15: offering it nowhere to hide among the barren accompaniment. Kelly sang the words with grave austerity but their plainspoken nature left little question as to what Kelly hoped to get across. On Tiny Rebels

column1: And the lyrics peeking through the clouds just feel a bit imprecise

column3: after putting it all out there not so many months ago
column4: Kelly's a bit reticent to share that much again. Halfway through ""Shake Off
column5: when Kelly confesses ""I don't fucking feel much"" and quickly starts to rail against ""all the retarded bullshit I must be able to shake off
column6: it's a shock: for just a fleeting second or two
column7: you can actually make out a real person-- and not just a slice of received wisdom or a paisley-tinted caricature-- in Kelly's vaseline-spackled lens. Tiny Rebels certainly proves the slow-going Kelly and company can make a great-sounding little record in seven days' time. But
column8: with that frustrating distance between Tiny Rebels' finely tuned sonics and Kelly's uncharacteristically indistinct lyrics
column9:
it's hard not to wonder what another week might've done.

This spring Drake picked up the first signee for his newly minted OVO Sound imprint in Toronto-based singer and producer PARTYNEXTDOOR. Like The Weeknd
column2: who produced sporadic sessions as the Noise before a name change and a dollop of mystery sent his career into the stratosphere
