column5: Ultra
column6: PARTYNEXTDOOR had been making cheery EDM-infused R&B under his real name Jahron Brathwaite before starting with a clean slate. Brathwaite’s OVO acquisition was announced with an unassuming track drop on Drake’s October’s Very Own blog. The song
column7: “Make a Mil”
column8: found PARTYNEXTDOOR running through fleet verses of self-assured melodic rap with greater ease and range as a singer than his benefactor. His eponymous self-titled mixtape trades the doe-eyed sensitivity of the Jahron B. material for something closer in spirit to the villainous player chronicles of Ty Dolla $ign and the Weeknd.

column1: The album’s chock full of strippers and drugs
column2: and our narrator navigates a succession of dimly lit clubs and private afterparties with devilish gusto
column3: informing the exotic dancing love interest of “Relax with Me” that
column4: “Girl yo ass is so instrumental” and noting elsewhere that “Shawty silhouette look like a dollar sign”. All of this is carried out in a vocal delivery that fuses an R&B singer’s melodic finesse with the percussive wordplay of a rapper. In his lower register he’s a dead ringer for his boss; “Wus Good/Curious” invokes So Far Gone makeout cuts like “Houstatlantavegas”. When he draws his voice up into a high register word flurry on “Right Now” he essentially affects Meek Mill’s puppy dog yawp. If you close your eyes you might mistake “Tbh” and its oscillation between Brathwaite’s baritone and high tenor ranges for a lost Drake/Weeknd collaboration. Brathwaite’s a talented singer
column5: but sometimes you get the impression he’s better at twisting and recapitulating sounds than inventing them. The inarguable triumph of PARTYNEXTDOOR is actually his production.

column1: PARTYNEXTDOOR abounds with homespun beats that turn radio rap tropes inside out. “Make a Mil” and closer “Ballin’” both call in the foreboding 808s and the cricket chirp hi-hats of trap
column2: but the former does it in service to a central melody played on what sounds like a Pan flute while the latter undercuts its cavernous low end with breathy flute notes that soak up all the menace. Mid-album highlight “Right Now” revolves around a breakneck synth figure
column3: while “Break from Toronto” bastes otherwise unremarkable drum programming in a choice chop of Miguel’s “Girl with the Tattoo”. Throughout the album PARTYNEXTDOOR’s flair for off-the-wall musical flourishes (the clinking glasses and noirish sax on “Wild Bitches”
column4: the drillbit synth sound that piledrives the kick hits home on “Wus Good/Curious”
column5: the brashly synthetic horn section on the chorus of “Make a Mil”) and propensity to stash melodic elements in unexpected corners (see: the marimba melody of “Over Here” and the album’s tendency to pair hollow kick thuds with deep bass hits to give the effect of trunk-rattling drums) collude to buoy these songs through fitful moments of mimicry.

column1: Jahron Brathwaite’s decision to ditch the mealy mouthed
column2: saccharine dance pop to transmogrify into PARTYNEXTDOOR has been a shot in the arm. He’s got the ear of Drake at a time when the Toronto MC’s presence has solidified into dominance
column3: and his versatility as a producer and songwriter means he could be put to great use in the OVO pop machine. PARTYNEXTDOOR occasionally works better as an audition for future work with Drake than an expression of Brathwaite’s own aspirations as an artist. But it’s also clear from the bedroom intimacy of the production and the demo-like quality of some of the one- and two-minute sketches that pepper the album between the more fully realized songs that PARTYNEXTDOOR is maybe just a sampler. It spends much of its brief running time wandering around Take Care’s wheelhouse churning out deft approximations of Drake and Noah “40” Shebib’s pet sounds
column4:
but some of it is used to strip their signature brand of confessional hip-hop/R&B fusion for parts to restructure it into something new.

but mostly this is a band searching for hope amid shattered dreams.

As the legacy of Hüsker Dü has shown
column2: equal songwriting partnerships do not necessary translate to equal statures. Throughout the St. Paul noise-pop pioneers’ 1980-87 tenure
column3: Bob Mould and Grant Hart exhibited a Lennon/McCartney-esque division of songwriting labor (and the festering internal tensions that inevitably result)
column4: but in terms of post-breakup public profile
column5: Hart may as well be Pete Best. While Mould has remained in the spotlight through myriad ventures-- by selling hundreds of thousands of records with Sugar
column6: becoming Jon Stewart’s jingle-writer
column7: penning scripts for the WCW<b>
column8: and guesting on Foo Fighters albums-- Hart has recorded only sporadically
column9: taking several years and sometimes entire decades between releases. And whether he’s been serving up power-pop pleasures (1999’s Good News for Modern Man) or frazzled lo-fi psychedelia with the assistance of various Godspeed You! Black Emperor members (2009’s Hot Wax)
column10: his albums have suffered the same unceremonious fate
column11: issued by obscure micro-indie labels and mostly ignored.

column1: Recent times have been especially trying: Hart lost both his mother and father in the past two years (the latter’s death prompting an investigation into embezzlement by a nursing-home employee)
column2: while his long-time St. Paul house-- which had been in his family for nearly a hundred years-- was destroyed in a fire. Rubbing salt in the wounds was the fact that Hart’s greatest visibility in the past few years came via Mould’s tell-all autobiography
column3: See a Little Light
column4: which paints a damning portrait of his former foil. Hart
column5: fortunately
column6: has responded to this strife in true better-to-burn-out-than-fade-away fashion: by producing a 20-song
column7: 74-minute concept album based one of the most totemic works of poetry of all time-- John Milton’s Paradise Lost-- as interpreted through an unfinished literary/stage adaptation by none other than William S. Burroughs.

column1: This isn’t exactly uncharted territory for Hart: Hüsker Dü
column2: of course
column3: set the template for the punk rock song cycle. Hart’s post-Hüsker Dü outfit Nova Mob explored overarching narrative frameworks on 1991’s The Last Days of Pompeii
column4: and his longtime friendship with Burroughs presents a direct personal connection to the endeavor. (The late author’s unpublished treatment of the Milton poem was bestowed to Hart by Burroughs’ long-time executor
column5: James Grauerholz.) But the complexity of this mission pushes Hart well beyond his usual distorto-pop terrain: The Argument demands more theatrical
column6: melodramatic performances than we’re used to hearing from Hart
column7: and his musical palette here expands exponentially to include everything from operatic glam-rock (“Awake
column8: Arise!”) and militaristic marches (“If We Have the Will”) to stormy psychedelic soundscapes (“War in Heaven”) and old-timey mandolin-plucked folk (“Underneath the Apple Tree”). But the real triumph of The Argument isn’t its ambitious scope or narrative heft
column9: but the fact that you don’t need a degree in English Lit to enjoy it. And for all its stylistic variance and densely packed lyricism
column10: Hart’s melodic gifts are unmistakable throughout.

column1: It helps that Paradise Lost is rooted in eternal themes-- good vs. evil
column2: order vs. chaos
column3: temptation vs. guilt-- that carry universal resonance
column4: meaning most of these songs can stand alone independent of their conceptual context: the Guided By Voices-styled garage-pop shot “It Isn’t Love” works as both a warning of the devil’s manipulative ways
column5: and a portrait of a womanizing lothario; “So Far From Heaven” is a paean to fallen angels condemned to hell
column6: yet it boasts the same celestial language and congenial form as a classic 50s doo-wop song. But the songs take on added dimensions of poignancy when shot through the lens of Hart’s own hardscrabble life: If anyone’s earned the right to sing a wistful ballad about getting exiled from heaven called “I Will Never See My Home""
column7: it’s a guy who recently watched his go up in flames
column8: while the dazed-and-confused elegy “Is the Sky the Limit?” presents the sort of question asked only by those who’ve hit rock bottom and have nothing left to lose.

column1: Inevitably with an album of this scale
column2: there are moments where Hart’s attempts at role-play supersede the songcraft (like the one-note 60s-psych stomp of “I Am Death
column3: ” or the wind-chimed haze of the overlong title track). But for all its sprawl
column4: The Argument maintains a brisk pace
column5: with a White Album-inspired sense of irreverence that ensures Hart never gets stuck in place for long. No doubt
column6: the album’s wandering spirit and baroque sensibility present a challenge to old-school fans who wish Hart and Mould would just bury the hatchet once and for all and unseat the Replacements as this year’s unlikeliest Minnesotan indie-rock-vets reunion tour. But the great thing about The Argument is that
column7: not only does it make a Hüsker Dü reformation seem like an evermore remote possibility
column8:
it makes the whole prospect that much more undesirable and unnecessary.

The Love Language's self-titled 2009 debut was endearingly frayed collection of alt-country pop
column2: 1960s garage-rock swagger
column3: and Spector-esque swells of melodrama
column4: all recorded by leader Stuart McLamb
column5: alone on his four-track. McLamb scrounged together seven-piece band to tour the record
column6: and the adaptation of the rough-hewn debut album to a live setting was a revelation
column7: as the motley lineup made each of McLamb’s songs pop in high-contrast technicolor. But McLamb's 2010 Merge debut
column8: Libraries
column9: found him continuing to record solo
column10: crafting nuggets of Burt Bacharach inspired baroque pop if never quite moving beyond mid-tempo indie rock competency. McLamb’ took two years to record his third LP as the Love Language
column11: <i>Ruby Red
column12: this time with the help over over 20 musicians across a handful of timezones. This album’s recording process was the complete antithesis of McLamb’s previous efforts
column13: and the collaborative spirit has led to a record of relaxed confidence.

column1: The production details and influences that produced the most interesting moments from the previous albums-- Spector’s orchestral swathes
column2: Bacharach’s deceptively simple pop compositions
column3: a steely garage rock nerve
column4: the twangy alt-country stomp-- have coalesced and hardened into a full-bodied dynamic sound that bristles with excitement and pleasure. Ruby Red is a willfully effervescent record that wears its pop music heart on its sleeve; string and horn sections are used liberally to crest and smash with the motion of McLamb’s melodies
column5: while anthemic guitar figures and radio-ready hooks whistle through each song like they were designed to pour out of a set of car speakers.

column1: The lingering mopiness that permeated Libraries’ is swapped for the unabashed enthusiasm in songs like track one “Calm Down”
column2: a bass-chugging thrasher that erupts into a piano/tambourine driven chorus. ""Calm Down""
column3: along with the family-friendly garage rock of “Kids”
column4: along with the loungey
column5: sunkissed harmonies of “Hi Life” and the classical crooning vibe of “Golden Age”
column6: make for a solid tour through McLamb’s M.O. on Ruby Red
column7: as he filters a handful of faithfully rendered canonical styles from pop music’s history through his indie rock sensibilities. Even the weaker ballad “Knots”--which is marred by a shaky vocal performance early on-- slowly transforms into a heart-melting
column8: jaunty
column9: string-laden sing-along. This is the album that should have followed McLamb’s quaintly lo-fi debut and ensuing tours
column10: as the small army of collaborators brings his pop music vision to life. McLamb seems to be relishing the chance to get outside of his head
column11:
making music that is gorgeous and unashamedly fun.

Reading metal reviews would be a lot more entertaining if we'd occasionally pause and allow our imaginations to run wild through some of the album titles and band names. Monikers like Palace of Worms and Lake of Blood capture the mind’s eye
column2: while Ride for Revenge
column3: Pig Destroyer
column4: and diSEMBOWLMENT send chills down the spine. While a Skeletal Spectre haunts your dreams and a Front Beast with One Tail
column5: One Head lurks in the shadows behind your bedroom door
column6: a Mammoth Grinder sounds like a fearsome contraption in a scene from some wintry Neolithic Fargo
column7: a sputtering metallic beast cranking out ropes of dark
column8: bloody flesh and orchestrating a chorus of deafening clangs
column9: frenzied roars
column10: and whirring blades as the show turns crimson beneath it.

column1: You could describe the Austin band Mammoth Grinder's latest album in much the same way. It's been four years since the release of Extinction of Humanity
column2: but Mammoth Grinder’s third full-length Underworlds maintains that forward momentum-- it's a savage collection that sees the four-piece (who were a trio the last time we heard from them) heading straight for the jugular from the first note and tearing through the title track in under two minutes. It’s the kind of entrance that catches you off guard
column3: and the intensity doesn’t let up. When they go slow
column4: it’s all sludgy
column5: bludgeoning breakdowns and Stockholm grooves; when they speed up
column6: it’s a torrential storm of gutter thrash and hardcore punk that aims to fuck things up faster than a Sharknado. The band have long incorporated death metal elements into their songwriting
column7: and the 2011 split with a grind-heavy Hatred Surge (with whom they share key members) may have dropped some major hints
column8: but on Underworlds
column9: Mammoth Grinder have fully come into their own as genre-bashing geniuses.

column1: “Wraparound Eyes” stomps in with a big fat groove and dips in and out of the same
column2: padding out the rest with Disfear-driven d-beats and Entombed riffs
column3: while “Revenge” sounds like Bolt Thrower’s “... For Victory” sped up to 45 RPM with a few lines of yayo laid out on top. “Roperide” has the album’s best moshpit anthem-- you can almost see the bodies fly. Three-minute burner “Cog in the Machine” is an epic by Mammoth Grinder’s standards
column4: and they use those extra thirty seconds to hammer their message home (hint: it’s not a very nice one). “Born in a Bag” is pure Swedish death down to the guitar tone and whiplash guitar solo
column5: and album closer “Moral Crux” drags it all back down
column6: a stoned stomp towards oblivion. (You can’t go wrong with a good “bleah!” grunt.) When not indulging his inner Matt Harvey
column7: vocalist Chris Ulsh’s hoarse throat erupts again and again as a gravelly warning or enraged bellow; you can hear the spittle flying out and feel his white knuckle deathgrip on the mic.

column1: The album is peppered with the kind of wild-eyed
column2: squealing guitar licks that’d make Jeff Hanneman proud
column3: and a big
column4: hollow drum sound acts as a powerful backup generator for when the guitar and basslines need a bar or two to breathe. Brevity is the soul of wit
column5: after all
column6: and much like a particularly cutting Oscar Wilde diss
column7: the short lengths of the songs come off as calculated and clever. Nothing feels hasty or rushed. Mammoth Grinder know exactly how to get in
column8: cause a ruckus
column9: and get out in three minutes or less
column10:
and aren’t interested in belaboring their point. They've earned the right to keep it tight.

Whirr’s new EP Around is not an assertive work: the songs move with the forward momentum of a tortoise dosed with Benadryl
column2: Kristina Esfandiari and Loren Rivera's vocals are nearly see-through
column3: and the melodies a mere suggestion. Nonetheless
column4: the Bay Area sextet engages the listener with classic
column5: deal-closing salesmanship in the process: they tell you what they’re gonna say
column6: they say it
column7: and then they tell you what they just said. Start with their name
column8: which was changed from the original “Whirl.” Recall their 2011 EP Distressor and 2012 debut LP Pipe Dreams
column9: which were compared to basically every 90s shoegaze band you still listen to. And consider song titles like “Swoon""
column10: “Drain” and “Keep”
column11: all one-syllable verbs that evoke the slowest movements or a complete standstill. It’s clear they favor the swirling
column12: deliberate iterations of their chosen genre and on Around’s four sweeping tracks
column13: Whirr deliver on their sales pitch. The problem is that they fulfill a need for a certain audience
column14: but they don't create demand amongst those outside of it.

column1: Forgoing the relatively tight strictures of Pipe Dreams
column2: Whirr position themselves within the realm of NorCal bands that have been using intimidation tactics to coax beauty out of their guitars. As with the Deftones/ISIS collaborative Palms
column3: Whirr’s song lengths are in place seemingly as self-fulfilling prophecy-- played at twice the speed
column4: you might be able to hear nine-minute opener “Drain” as a pop song with elegant melodic motion and a fairly standard structure
column5: but that’s not the point of Around. The point is to push “Drain” to an extreme of tempo and volume
column6: to see how loud and slow it can get while still maintaining its figure. Though they lack the Brooklyn transplanted Weekend’s propulsion (or at least have no interest in it)
column7: Whirr similarly layer shrieking fuzz guitars to the point where they become meditative and mesmeric. Guitarist Nick Bassett used to play in Deafheaven
column8: and at its best
column9: Around momentarily touches Sunbather’s all-encompassing fire/water
column10: agony/ecstasy rapture.

column1: Whirr just happens to go about it the same way over Around’s half hour and
column2: as a result
column3: the record focuses more on juxtaposition and texture than impression. They work with fairly commonplace dualities: babymaking music under the threat of apocalypse
column4: fluttering vocals against flagrant guitars. Most of all
column5: Whirr use brittle material to create an impenetrable
column6: impervious wall of sound. All of this stuff inevitably traces back to My Bloody Valentine and with the distorted guitars and cooing vocals so distended they sound a bit modal
column7: you can imagine m b v in a metal mood. With enough scrutiny
column8: the four tracks here distinguish themselves: “Keep” stands out on account of moving with a swinging gait rather than a plod
column9: evoking a monstrous cover of Cocteau Twins ca. Treasure. It also contains the clearest and most idiosyncratic lyric-- Esfandiari breathes “insecurities make me shy
column10: ” punctuated by a startling thrust of pulverized guitar. That’s how all the immediately striking moments occur here-- there’s a small break before the low end hits and the distortion surges even further into the red
column11: the loud/soft dynamics of grunge given shoegaze exaggeration in terms of both volume and tempo.

column1: The tidal pull and deep blue-black disposition of Around creates an ambience that makes for an easy selling point-- Pure Moods music for people who dream about the kind of vacations where they sit alone on a freezing beach at night. Is it pretty? Of course it is. But how much of Around’s beauty is attributable to Whirr and how much of it's predetermined due to natural forces? Without an insatiable need for shoegaze that can get doomy without edging into metal
column2: it’s tough for the listener to ascertain what exactly is at stake on Around. You’re not here for the lyrics
column3: though it is worth noting that while the central refrain of “Drain” (“drain me”) may not have been used verbatim in any My Bloody Valentine or Slowdive song
column4: it’s the basic sentiment that’s driven the genre since the beginning-- the listener submits to the artist’s pummeling sound in exchange for cleansing and catharsis. But
column5: on Around
column6: Whirr don’t elevate themselves beyond the level of a listener; instead
column7:
they remain supplicant to their influences.

Music fandom often follows a slow boomerang trajectory: listen to top-40 radio through your tween and early teen years
column4: reject those impulses in favor of more cerebral
column5: left-of-center music as you're growing up
column6: lean back toward pop as you settle into adulthood. The last couple of years have found a crop of young independent artists boldly attempting to reconcile those stages of their own listening life cycles
column7: walking a tightrope of poptimism and experimentalism to create confectionary
column8: homespun electronic music that’s sometimes described as future-pop. Grimes gushes about Mariah Carey and Aphex Twin in the same breath; Canadian duo Purity Ring have listed “Justin Timberlake
column9: Clams Casino
column10: and Holy Other” as inspirational forces behind their prismatic fairy tales; Glaswegian electro trio Chvrches have spoken about loving Fugazi and the Cure in interviews before divulging plans to cover Whitney Houston’s “It’s Not Right
column11: But It’s Okay” in live shows. These omnivorous tendencies-- along with the breakdown of genre boundaries and advancement of affordable home recording technology-- have created inviting territory for the cleverest and most enterprising young musicians to explore.

column1: Another intriguing act within the growing corral of future-pop artists is AlunaGeorge
column2: a UK duo comprised of vocalist Aluna Francis and producer George Reid. When the two began giving interviews last year
column3: they mentioned their love of old Timbaland and Neptunes-produced hits along with affinities for Radiohead
column4: the Knife
column5: and Joanna Newsom. Together the pair have adeptly synthesized those tastes and perfected a futuristic sound that blends wonky
column6: wobbly beats drawn from 2-step and glitch with the irresistible hooks of “TRL”-era pop and the 90s R&B it was heavily indebted to. A decade ago
column7: Aluna Francis might have been a long-lost member of Dream
column8: the all-girl group behind the sleeper hit “He Loves U Not”
column9: or a contestant on Diddy’s ill-fated “Making the Band”. The pair’s lyrics can even feel as though they were written for young teens of an era before smartphones and social media platforms mediated pubescent growing pains. “I usually wait for you to call/ But it’s getting closer between me and you
column10: ” Francis laments on the balladesque new song “Friends to Lovers”. “How do you make the change from friends to lovers/ When you risk looking like a fool?”

column1: Following last year’s EP on Brooklyn label Tri Angle
column2: their debut album Body Music arrives on a major (Island in the UK
column3: the indie Vagrant in the U.S.); about half of its songs are new. The collection is a remarkably seamless extension of their early songs
column4: an expert execution of a concept and aesthetic that felt perfectly crystallized even before anyone knew who the duo were. While there’s nothing on Body Music that hits quite as hard as their breakout hit
column5: the crystalline R&B song “You Know You Like It”
column6: there’s hardly a weak track to be found (save a misguided bonus cover of Montell Jordan’s “This Is How We Do It”). They tinker with a bit of balladry (“Friends to Lovers”)
column7: niche dance genres (“Lost & Found”)
column8: and lite disco-funk (“Kaleidescope Love”)
column9: but everything retains a uniformly slick veneer
column10: propelled by Francis’ slightly warped
column11: nasal vocals and ice-princess posture. There’s an enticing liquidity that carries over from the earlier material-- beyond lyrics like “I want to be a diver into the sea” and “I've been treading water for your love”
column12: the songs can sound like water hitting hard
column13: shiny surfaces
column14: or like ice chips being shot though narrow chrome tubes. The entire album is sexy and strange and sugary all at once. That these songs were recorded over the course of a couple years (straddling a major-label deal) and still maintain total fluidity throughout speaks to the strength and maturity of the duo’s initial formula.

column1: But there
column2: in the word formula
column3: lies the catch. There's not much wrong with Body Music
column4: but its constellation of contemporary electro-pop elements can sometimes feel too slick for its own good. Francis and Reid almost do themselves a disservice by being so competent
column5: by executing a single
column6: well-defined sound so consistently and so tidily that the record can begin to create a lull. That’s been the fate of some of AlunaGeorge’s peers as well: Purity Ring’s 2012 debut possessed the same paradoxically frustrating one-note perfection; Chvrches’ sound is crisp and singular enough that they could face a similar challenge. It’s also possible that the sheer number of artists springing up and inhabiting this sphere slackens the future angle in all this future-pop. For Francis and Reid
column7: one possible escape from their shiny little box might be to further experiment with blossoming dance music trends-- something they successfully tried their hand at on a recent collaboration with Disclosure
column8: another UK duo doing exciting
column9: retro-futuristic things with newly malleable genre boundaries. But for now
column10:
it's hard to complain about AlunaGeorge being a little bit too focused. 

"|18298.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18298-alunageorge-body-music/|7.6|Carrie Battan

Clap Your Hands Say Yeah are essentially starting over
column2: a situation more daunting than starting out. Their underrated sophomore LP Some Loud Thunder absorbed the inevitable backlash
column3: but whatever momentum CYHSY could generate from critical reappraisal was squandered by a four-year hiatus
column4: 2011’s tepid Hysterical
column5: and the subsequent departure of two band members. As a result
column6: though their debut’s origin story would be commonplace in 2013
column7: to even say the name “Clap Your Hands Say Yeah” suggests an intent to evoke “man
column8: 2005” anachronism. But you can also see how an artist as publicity-averse and creatively fitful as Alec Ounsworth could use this situation to his advantage-- he always came off like a sincere guy who just wanted to release music without all the attendant bullshit and Little Moments is a quickie EP that lowers the stakes and allows his band to follow a whim. Unfortunately
column9: it’s a more confused work than a confident reinvention
column10: Clap Your Hands Say Yeah making a complete left turn just to half step.

column1: You can say this much-- at least superficially
column2: it doesn’t recall anything CYHSY has done in the past
column3: with the possible exception of their debut’s infamous opener “Clap Your Hands!” Little Moments likewise features no guitars and Ounsworth’s vocals are most often mixed in a way that’s seemingly meant to drive out all but the most forgiving listeners. In short
column4: CYHSY have gone full-on electro-pop for about 20 minutes. But even in this guise
column5: it’s hard to mistake this for the work of anyone else especially since “Once” could pass for “The Skin of My Yellow Country Teeth” done up Electronic Anthology Project-style. Even Hysterical had a few keepers and Ounsworth hasn’t lost his knack for writing sticky melodies expressed in long strides
column6: staggered sibilating
column7: or outright ululation; his voice impresses upon you whether you like it or not. More crucially
column8: these are pop songs
column9: not electronic songs-- they still rely on verse-chorus structure rather than groove. After all
column10: this is the guy who equated dancing with damnation on Some Loud Thunder’s “Satan Said Dance”.

column1: The problem is that the sound of Little Moments is inexcusably amateur or that of a guitar band learning how to write electronic music on the fly. Combined with the slapdash “Photoshop font + .jpg” cover art
column2: if there wasn’t a price tag attached to these songs
column3: I’d just as quickly assume they were Ounsworth’s home demos. Though it bears no resemblance to the overly mannered indie rock of <i>Hysterical
column4: Little Moments similarly gives you little reason to continue calling CYHSY ""quirky."" The four songs here are composed of the most basic synth-pop presets-- octave-jumping riffs
column5: basslines that pulse on every upbeat
column6: sickly synthesized strings
column7: an occasional non sequitur of a sample. None of it retains the pleasing precision and concision of the best stuff. The mix is thin and unbalanced
column8: putting too much emphasis on Ounsworth’s most grating affectations even when he's obscured by aluminum filters. The addition of live percussion at least indicates that it isn’t Ounsworth fucking around on Fruity Loops
column9: but it’s also a reminder of how a voice with that many sharp edges is best situated within equally prickly indie rock and jittery disco beats. Over the slicked-up textures of “Heaven”
column10: Ounsworth never finds steady footing
column11: his enunciation is so unctuous
column12: he may as well be ad-libbing.

column1: Still
column2: it’s somewhat encouraging that CYHSY can put out something in 2013 capable of triggering stronger reactions than the soft disappointment inspired by Hysterical. According to their Bandcamp
column3: an untitled fourth album is already in the works at the turn of the calendar year and it’s hard not to root for them at this point; there were a number of things embarrassing about Clap Your Hands Say Yeah and the vague construct of “blog-rock” from 2005-2007-- the name
column4: the earliest live shows
column5: the idea that it could somehow completely alter the music industry-- but Clap Your Hands Say Yeah and Some Loud Thunder were definitely not among them. There’s no conceivable rebranding that will make Clap Your Hands Say Yeah overhyped rather than underdogs again and if they’re going to move forward as simply a good band
column6:
Little Moments is hopefully a purge of misguided ideas or a transition into something more committal.

Whether listeners should hold artists to a standard of constant innovation is a knotty problem-- If a musician wants to express their urge to break free from their previous constraints by going back to their roots and influences
column2: there's more than enough precedent to make that move something less than shocking. But if their early work was driven by a distinct disinterest in rules and predictability
column3: especially in the middle of a wider movement's healthy bouts of iconoclasm
column4: is it worth getting disappointed when that classic-homage sound rises up to take its place-- especially when the end result is fairly enjoyable on the surface?

column1: That's a paradox that pops up in frustrating ways on Ikonika's new album Aerotropolis
column2: a stated tribute to the old-school freestyle house and synthpop jams that soundtracked Sara Abdel-Hamid's 80s youth. And while the short answer to what would happen if Ikonika was old enough to make music at the time is ""a pretty good record
column3: that puzzling Mobius strip of inspiration and expression leans so heavily on the idea of pop as a historical waypoint that something feels a bit detached. Not on its own context-free musical level
column4: granted
column5: but in the larger scope of the reputation Ikonika's made for herself as one of late-period dubstep's more melodically subversive and off-kilter composers.

column1: If that means the album's biggest flaw is that it nails a certain aesthetic too faithfully
column2: that's not a very harmful problem to have. Early album cut ""Beach Mode (Keep It Simple)""
column3: which recruits up-and-coming singer Jessy Lanza
column4: is Ikonika's first-ever vocal track
column5: and the coolly haunted tone it sets is immediately resonant as something deeply affectionate for a clearly remembered (and reassembled) past. It's a feel that runs a line through the whole album-- the burbling fusion of synthpop and boogie funk ""Mr Cake""
column6: the Madchester throb of ""Eternal Mode"" and ""Lights Are Forever""
column7: Class of 1987 house tribute ""Manchego""
column8: and the upended cathedral chords of Optimum teamup ""Mega Church"". It's far from a cold and emotionless recitation of last generation's digital pop heritage; if those aforementioned tracks don't race pulses
column9: ""Cryo"" and its foreboding minor-key stormcloud formations should call up shivers.

column1: So why is there this nagging feeling that something's missing? Ikonika's transition to vintage sounds and signifiers
column2: whether through old-school synths or uncluttered 4/4 patterns
column3: is reverent enough to parallel their sources instead of update or subvert them. And even when she pulls back the curtain to nudge the listener over how much of a stylistic transition this album might be-- one of the shorter
column4: more skeletal exercises in gaining her throwback footing with Hacienda-ready 808s and keyboards is called ""Practice Beats""-- it sounds more like a history lesson than history in the making. Her 2010 LP <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14131-contact-love-want-have/"" target=""_blank""><i>Contact
column5: Love
column6: Want
column7: Have was a thrill because it had the self-admitted playfulness of an artist learning as she went
column8: leaving a trail of brightly smart-assed tweaks to formula-- she fit right in with that year's trailblazing class of gloom-defying bass artists like Rustie and Joker.

column1: Even as last year's I Make Lists EP darkened her style a bit
column2: it still had a similar unpredictable intrigue and sense of left-field jitteriness that was too lighthearted to be alienating. Aerotropolis' 180 pop move-- as comfortable and assured in its own niche as it is-- is so abrupt that it almost feels like an innovative rulebreaker hitting the reset button and starting a completely new
column3:
much more familiar persona from scratch. Where things go from here hinges on what happens if or when she finds a way to upend that end result in the same way she crashed the scene to start. No doubt it'll sound good-- but fingers crossed it'll also sound strange.

"|18304.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18304-ikonika-aerotropolis/|6.5|Nate Patrin

The digital era has fed the desire for slick
column2: minimalist apps and beautiful
column3: easily applied filters that try to make functional objects feel like art. Washed out colors and stripped-down fonts (or
column4: in music
column5: lightly distorted guitars and reverb-tinged vocals) offer a sort of distressed beauty that suggests depth and implies seriousness. Art
column6: these images and sounds suggest
column7: may be hard to define
column8: but you know it when you reblog it.

column1: LA.-based singer Nylo supported herself for a while as a graphic designer and session musician
column2: so she has a feel for cool
column3: crafted product. She released a debut EP last year in what has become an archetypal model for hip R&B acts
column4: dropping a fully-formed project with almost no supporting information other than a monochromatic cover. That collection
column5: Memories Speak
column6: landed perfectly on trend
column7: mimicking the careening production and lacerating self-doubt of the Weeknd and echoing the smooth pop vocal confidence of Keri Hilson or Ciara. Nylo was doing the right things to suggest she had a vision worth paying attention to
column8: and attention quickly followed. Mac Miller and Nas tweeted excited endorsements
column9: and Nylo landed a major label deal with Epic.

column1: The follow-up mixtape
column2: Indigo Summer
column3: continues in the same vein
column4: hinting at meaning through abstraction. Nylo’s phenomenal voice and savvy ear for production are still front and center
column5: but the record shows its hand a little more. While Memories Speak suggested an artist with strong pop instincts
column6: Indigo Summer often seems more like the work of someone with substantial musical talent and an eye for aesthetic details who doesn't have much to say. Nylo is drawn to signifiers -- Audrey Hepburn
column7: the movie Donnie Darko -- that are such familiar tropes of cool that they have been smoothed out to near meaninglessness. Her musical approach is also surface-level
column8: approximating the airy formlessness of neo soul in a secondhand way
column9: leading to wispy R&B that sounds pretty but feels indecisive. A joyless cover of Robin Thicke’s summer smash “Blurred Lines” demonstrates the shortcomings of this style most clearly
column10: abandoning the original’s crisp
column11: carefree funk in favor of tepid
column12: drawn-out vocal meandering and a contrived
column13: theatrical tension.

column1: While Nylo may be very much part of a trend rather than dictating it
column2: she still is delivering more realized music than many of her blog-friendly peers due to both her airy voice and an instinct for hooks. Smoldering first single “Fool Me Once” ambitiously layers in chiming synthesizers and a propulsive drumbeat
column3: but its most sublime moments are the simple “woo-oo-oos” that highlight her vocal clarity. The similarly regretful “Take It Back” concludes with elaborate backing vocal flourishes over a martial drumbeat as the Destiny’s Child-like chorus ostensibly remains the focus of the song. Then there's “Breakfast at Tiffany’s”
column4: which flips its movie-title conceit into a rather wonderful image of lost-love obsession
column5: as Nylo reaches a pinnacle of vocal potential on the straining chorus of “lately I’ve been thinking about you.” It’s deeply satisfying to hear her hit these high notes
column6: which constitute the album’s purest moment of emotion.

column1: Nylo’s at her most effective when she trusts her emotional ideas instead of leaning on concept
column2: a point driven home by the lackluster collaborations with the album’s two big producer names
column3: Tricky Stewart and Fisticuffs. The latter's “Cocaine Hearts” delivers its warning about addiction by making living fast and dying young sound grating and incredibly boring. At these moments
column4: Indigo Summer’s on-the-nose approach exposes its lack of substance and distracts from the way in which it’s best enjoyed: as an aesthetically pleasing feat of design
column5:
the work of a talented person with good taste still figuring out how to translate those things into something more.

Through the 1970s
column2: Chance Martin had the sort of connections in Nashville that most aspiring rhinestone cowboys would kill for. He was Johnny Cash’s most trusted stagehand
column3: a drinking buddy of Tanya Tucker
column4: and he served as a sound engineer for director Robert Altman’s Oscar-nominated Music City masterpiece. And when
column5: toward the end of the decade
column6: Chance decided to make the leap from being an assistant to the stars to becoming one himself
column7: he had no less a Nashville legend than “Cowboy” Jack Clement behind the boards. There was just one thing holding Chance back from certain country-music celebrity: The music he made sounded like absolutely nothing else coming out of Nashville at the time
column8: or anywhere else in America for that matter.

column1: Even by the standards of lost cult classics
column2: Chance’s 1981 debut album
column3: In Search
column4: was so overlooked when it was released that it may as well have never existed. (And
column5: according to Wikipedia
column6: it still doesn't). Recorded piecemeal over a span of five years in a kitted-out home studio-cum-clubhouse located above Martins’ parents’ garage
column7: the album was initially issued through a private-press run that barely cracked triple digits. But In Search defies the romantic
column8: outsider-art associations that so often get attached to amateur DIY recording projects
column9: whether it’s that of unassuming innocents naively chasing pop-star aspirations (see: The Shaggs)
column10: or day-jobbers living out their rock ‘n’ roll fantasies on a blue-collar budget (see: Guided by Voices). In Search
column11: by contrast
column12: is a master-class in the art of Going For It
column13: proffering a high-concept
column14: cinematically scaled hodgepodge of loverman soul
column15: outlaw country
column16: blaxpoitation funk
column17: arena-rock pyrotechnics
column18: and Zappa-esque meta-prog that sounds just as confounding and bizarre today as it no doubt did to the few who got to hear it 32 years ago.

column1: On first approach
column2: you could be forgiven for thinking this was all a big elaborate ruse
column3: like some salvaged mid-90s Ween album released under a pseudonym.
column4: serif;"">(Indeed
column5: Chocolate and Cheese chestnuts like ""Take Me Away"" and ""Voodoo Lady"" would sound right at home here.) As a singer
column6: Chance makes for a good auctioneer
column7: with a lower-register sing-speak that frequently degenerates into the sort of improvised
column8: self-aggrandizing spiel Jon Spencer would no doubt appreciate; when hitched to the rolling and tumbling rhythms of “High Test” and the “Peter Gunn” pastiche “Sunn of Gunn""
column9: Chance comes off less as bandleader than the booze-blitzed conductor of a runaway train that’s perilously close to careening off the rails. And even when Chance cedes lead vocals to some guest female singers
column10: his peculiar presence is still felt: the smooth
column11: knickers-shedding soul ballad “Love by Chance” works as both a heartfelt ode to serendipitous romance
column12: and a cheeky jingle for his own imaginary brand of aphrodisiac perfume.

column1: But while Chance is fond of joking
column2: this album is no joke. As In Search plays out
column3: it becomes increasingly clear that the record’s scatterbrained eclecticism and frantic energy is less a product of eccentricity-for-eccentricity’s sake than a manifestation of the very real anxieties fuelling this endeavor. For all the musical bravado on display here (the climactic guitar solos on “Angel” and “Drema” are practically “Comfortably Numb”-worthy)
column4: Chance’s lyrics continually suggest his failure is certain (“everyone tells me I’m a loser”; “I’m on the outside looking in”; “the buzzards flying high over me”)
column5: and that this record amounts to a knowing act of career suicide
column6: if not the prelude to a real one. (In this light
column7: the “give you all the love that I can” hook of “Mr. Freedom Man” seems less the command of a horny superhero than the delusional fantasy of an insecure Clark Kent.)

column1: In Search hits its delirious peak with “Dead Medley
column2: ” a shot of southern-rock funk that ruminates on the deaths of Jimi Hendrix
column3: Buddy Holly
column4: and Hank Williams while extrapolating liberal quotes from The Doors’ “When the Music’s Over” to emphasize the do-or-die stakes at play here; in Chance’s hands
column5: Jim Morrison’s “cancel my subscription to the resurrection” becomes “cancel my subscription to the Rolling Stone
column6: ” as if he were already resigned to his wholesale rejection by the rock establishment. In Search’s swift slip into oblivion didn’t exactly ruin Chance-- he continues to record today under the alias of Alamo Jones and
column7: for the past eight years
column8: he and Clement have hosted a popular country-music radio show on Sirius XM. But now that his most painstaking
column9: singular musical achievement has been rescued from history’s dustbin
column10:
Chance is in a much better position to answer a question he asks himself deep into In Search: “Have you ever felt like a loser until you win”?

Louisiana rapper Kevin Gates’ The Luca Brasi Story matched the brutality of coke rap to earnest sentimentality and melodicism with such a finesse that it obscured the record's essential weirdness. Songs outlining the perils of trafficking narcotics were heard next to those inspired by romance novelist Nicholas Sparks’ The Notebook and the Twilight series. In street rap
column2: a fixation on romance is often seen as a mark against the artist’s perceived toughness
column3: as if the one gives the lie to the other. But the weathered rasp of Gates' voice lent a measure of grit to the love songs even as it made the deterministic criminality elsewhere in the tape feel lived-in. He's has since inked a deal with Atlantic Records (who summarily squished the 22-song tape into a digital EP) and released the low-stakes digital album Stranger Than Fiction. Where The Luca Brasi Story’s itinerant sprawl and plentiful guest appearances played like a game of show and prove
column4: Stranger Than Fiction whittles things down to a series of pithy two- to three-minute nuggets that lurch toward resolution
column5: often finding it within a verse or two.

column1: The accomplished tunefulness of Luca Brasi highlights “Paper Chasers” and “Neon Lights” is pushed to the margins here. Save for the hooky despondency of late-album gem “Don’t Know What to Call It”
column2: Stranger Than Fiction’s Kevin Gates is world-weary in all the spots where he was starry-eyed and reflective the last time around. Whether the tense shift in his songwriting is a conscious attempt to put some distance between himself and his trap house hook-men contemporaries or a function of him stockpiling melodies for a future mainstream push
column3: his knack for detailed
column4: despairing storytelling cogently picks up the slack.

column1: Stranger Than Fiction draws much of its gravitas from Gates’ own colorful back story: he cuts through the airy synths and open spaces of “4:30AM” with a travelogue of betrayal for which he’s as much a culprit as a victim
column2: and on “4 Legs and a Biscuit”
column3: a viewing of the gangster flick King of New York trips off a broadside about the constant strain of legal woes. “Tiger” elaborates on the period when he quit dealing drugs to pursue a career in rap
column4: only to fall prey to a series of janky promoters and label executives whose shifty machinations made him the vic instead of the villain. Stranger Than Fiction is a litany of near-misses with police and armed foes interspersed with emotionally guarded examinations of the trust issues they leave as collateral damage. But where Gates has pulled back from the emotional heft that made Luca Brasi such a compelling character composite
column5: he’s poured his energy into the mechanics of rhyming with such fervor that what’s being said in these songs is often trumped for intrigue by the way he says it.

column1: While Gates’ stories suggest a battle-damaged cynic
column2: his restless wordplay gives voice to the excitable language nerd beneath the gruff exterior. “Die About It” effortlessly switches up cadences mid-flow
column3: shifting from a laconic swing to a sparse
column4: staccato yelp and back. On “Careful”
column5: he goofily adopts three different Southern accents in two verses
column6: only one of which is his own. “MYB” reduces his voice to a guttural whisper
column7: rendering the song’s callous dress-down of a lesser criminal all the more diabolical in the process. Gates sells all of these experiments with the same verve
column8: and the album scarcely misses a mark until Wiz Khalifa hits the buzzerbeater on the album closing remix of Gates’ 2012 single “Satellites” with a wastepaper-basket-deep verse delivered in a bratty yawp grossly ill-suited to the rest of the song.

column1: The success of Stranger Than Fiction is as much a result of keen lyricism and inventive vocal tricks as good editing. Its 14 tracks are over and done in just a little more than 40 minutes. The brevity and the relatively monochromatic production
column2: a glut of foreboding minor key trap beats
column3: collude to force the spotlight on Gates’ versatile rapping. From the achy old gunshot wound that flares up after Gates gets stabbed and the glass of Sprite that’s purple instead of pink because he overdid it on the promethazine on “4:30AM” to the Popeyes dinner that lends the title to “4 Legs and a Biscuit” to the punch in the face that doesn’t hurt on “MYB” and the succession cars he laments not being able to drive on “Don’t Know What to Call It”
column4:
the record's uncompromising hard luck street narratives are dispensed with a preternaturally sharp eye for detail that dabs Gates’ economic writing with a shock of much-needed color.

Stephin Merritt is a master ironist

column3: an exercise in Tin Pan Alley-style craft and artifice that could generate real emotions. That effort's subsequent ""no synths"" trilogy tweaked misconceptions about the author's voice (2004's entirely Merritt-sung i)
column4: Jesus and Mary Chain-level fuzz (2008's Distortion)
column5: and organic folksiness (2010's Realism). Last year's Love at the Bottom of the Sea was a return to synths and longtime label home Merge
column6: but not quite to form.

column1: With Merritt's main gig in a relative slump
column2: it's reasonable to wonder if he's currently subverting assumptions by saving his best material for less-famous projects. In fact
column3: 2011's odds-and-ends collection Obscurities

column6: Partygoing

column1: Wrong

Although the Future Bible Heroes' first outing since 2002's uneven Eternal Youth does offer up slightly more catchy melodies and deadpan quotables than Love at the Bottom of the Sea (outside of brilliantly funny ""Andrew in Drag"" or tenderly furious ""Quick!""). The Future Bible Heroes have always combined Merritt's tunes and lyrics with the 80s-minded electronic arrangements of Chris Ewen
column3: a Boston DJ and former keyboardist for Seymour Stein signees Figures on a Beach; Magnetic Fields member Claudia Gonson also adds drolly conversational vocals. The technology was more immediate this time

column5: Merritt told WNYC's Soundcheck-- but the results are largely the same: Partygoing is an oddball record full of moments that ought to make Merritt devotees knowingly nudge their neighbors
column6: but its pleasures are too esoteric and too kitschy to recommend to any poor souls who still haven't heard 1994's wonderful Holiday or The Charm of the Highway Strip.

column3: ""Dude
column4: they have to use computers just to sing

column6: one of a few songs here that touch on aging
column7: yearns gracefully from the perspective of someone in a room filled hoarder-style with books
column8: records
column9: and dolls: ""Crazy for you
column10: darling
column11: you come to suspect
column12: is right.

column4: which ingeniously notes how the bubbly stuff ""makes life shorter than drinking water"" and will help you ""never say no to love

column11: elf-free ""Digging My Own Grave"" (""What money I shall save!""). At 13 tracks

The Chicago quartet Twin Peaks deserve a better
column2: more imaginative name

column4: Replacements-inspired rock-- where ""pretty good"" is an easy bar to clear and anything above that formidably harder. Power pop and bar rock bands work from a sort of creative commons of riffs and bass lines: There's the ""Shake Some Action""

column11: happy headlock.

column1: Sunken is less than twenty minutes long

""Out of Commission"" occupies a minute and 25 seconds of precious running time but it still finds a moment to burn a joyfully squalled miniature Thin Lizzy guitar solo onto the song's surface. column8: wintergreen riff and another squiggled lead

column6: and breaks more joyfully
column7: than Casablancas's

column10: fey
column11: high register

Copenhagen's Nick Eriksen makes electronic music that's as playfully elaborate as his moniker

column3: Eriksen signed to Kompakt for his more distinctive first LP

column7: high-contrast timbres and granulated rhythms swarming around house beats both implied and explicit. The Kompakt contract presumably goes on

Henry Steinway is a modern day Jekyll and Hyde when it comes to his electronic dance potions. His day-glo personality is called Clockwork; a 22-year-old with big-room
column2: mega-club house bangers like his jacked remix of Avicii’s “Levels” that hat-tips the fusion dance genre of moombahton while shoveling in heaps of electro to sidestep along the way. As Clockwork
column3: Steinway has pulled production aesthetics from and played alongside house staples (like Avicii or Afrojack) while mining through indie-hip EDM scenes fostered by A-Trak’s Fool’s Gold and Steve Aoki’s Dim Mak imprint. He embraces trancy synth build-ups and uses chainsaw revs and electro-burping tech-house that’s fistpump ready even if it’s made with mosh-pits in mind. RL Grime
column4: however
column5: is a totally different animal.

column1: It’s easiest to present RL Grime as Steinway’s grittier
column2: more ominous alter-ego. One with trap prowess
column3: catering more to stomps than pumps. And RL Grime really is all about that life; he fiddles with the bass and messes with tightly-wound beats
column4: pulling away from the explosive
column5: emotionally manipulative pandering of his EDM counterpart. But the mega-club mentality hasn’t completely escaped him. With his remix of Benny Benassi’s chart-topping hit “Satisfaction” last year
column6: the producer wound down the shrill
column7: whining melody to use as fodder for frantic bass blips and sexily sauntering snares. The idea of mimicking overbearing pop melodies with syncopated horns and strategically placed beats flips the song on its head. It also represents one of the producer’s greatest talents: his ability to restructure songs entirely without losing the drama of soaring dance melodies.

column1: And so High Beams’ strongest points showcase the ease in which Steinway can use this technique crossover to straight rap production. Last year’s “Mercy” remix with Salva immediately comes to mind upon hearing “CliqCliq”
column2: the duo’s collaboration for this EP. Like “Mercy”
column3: the hit-sampled track is catchy
column4: clappy
column5: and sinister. Pitchy synths wail over staticy beats and a loopy
column6: buzzing drone that could easily drive a person insane was it not complemented with the menacing
column7: echoing thuds of static that push the song forward. “Secondary” features Compton based rapper Problem for what turns out to be the most complete
column8: radio-ready track on the EP; a testament of where RL Grime could head if he was so inclined.

column1: Elements from Clockwork remain as well. “Pockets
column2: ” the album’s intro
column3: tempers his hip-hop instrumentation with lush laser-like synths that pan over ping-pong drum-rim rhythms and bouncing MPC beats. “Shells” gives in a little more to the tropes
column4: becoming a moonbounce of elastic synths that wind up
column5: scream out
column6: and boomerang around the song.  As with Baauer-- a recent tour-mate and fellow Fool’s Gold/Mad Decent affiliate-- this balance of rap’s bump-n-grind groove and EDM’s flashiness helps prevent an artist from getting swallowed by the glut of the recent trap craze. But where Baauer is putting in work to show that he can also do house (by stripping down Disclosure’s “You & Me”) and ravey festival show-stoppers (his collab with Just Blaze for the Jay Z sampled “Higher”)
column7:
Steinway has no need. In turn the producer’s High Beams EP serves not only as RL Grime’s debut EP on Fool's Gold but as a window into where RL Grime and Clockwork meet.

When you release a record like Sports

column5: shadowy post-punk

column8: but captivating
column9: malleable

column11: recording only a five-song EP
column12: Red
column13: in the three years since. Some of the material on Red reflected the image of a band whose ears might need a break; though it still sounded like the work of the guys who gave us Sports
column14: it hinted at a cleaner
column15: glossier update of their sound.

column1: On their second LP
column2: Jinx

column4: Jinx has a reflective
column5: acrylic gloss to it. Expanding from a trio to a four-piece after hiring bassist Nick Ray
column6: frontman Shaun Durkan moved his band to Brooklyn in the wake of a family death that found him seeking therapy. Still bleak
column7: but surprisingly spirited and indebted to new wave
column8: this newfound clarity and change of scenery has had an impact on the band: Weekend have put together a record that's begging to be played to more ears in bigger spaces. Like their arena-goth forebearers the Cure and Depeche Mode

column10: pop-conscious moves
column11: focusing on melody and cleaner sonics to contrast the doubt
column12: melancholy
column13: and occasional tenderness already present.

column1: During Jinx's hook-minded first half
column2: Weekend nearly pull off the transformation. With its buoyant low-end and surprisingly straightforward guitar work
column3: opener and first single ""Mirror"" is an obvious indication of Weekend's commitment to reshaping their sound. While the torrents of noise are missed
column4: Durkan and company prove that they have the songwriting chops to make up for it. ""July"" is a step further in the right direction
column5: managing to capture the balmy freedom of summer's favorite month without alienating what could be the track's core constituency. It only takes a few listens for choruses to open up
column6: with ""Oubielete"" pulling off a rare trick in that it sounds like a lost 1980s college radio staple that
column7: despite not having been heard in years
column8: feels like it never went away. (You could say the same for the big-beat anchored ""Celebration
column9: FL""
column10: but it's more likely thanks to the fact that it just sounds like a really bummed-out cover of ""Just Can't Get Enough"".)

column1: But as good as some of these songs are
column2: you can't help but shake the feeling that they could be better. Production-wise
column3: Jinx needs more oomph; merely cleaning up your sound doesn't maximize your songs' inherent potential. And
column4: while these songs are often memorable
column5: some fine-tuning could have pushed them over the top. No one's saying the band has Killers-sized aspirations
column6: but if they want these songs to play in the rafters the same way they play right up against the monitors
column7: they'll need to make basic
column8: proper adjustments. It's commendable Durkan's un-fuzzed his voice and made strides to spend ""a lot more time on the lyrics this time around"" (though stuff like ""I feel sick
column9: sick
column10: sick
column11: sick
column12: sick/ In my heart"" and ""I want to save you from the world"" may suggest that more work is needed)
column13: but he doesn't inflect enough gusto in his vocals to make the promise of big
column14: truly riveting choruses a reality.

column1: One of the problems with Red was how quickly Weekend were willing to pull back from that early intensity-- for every ""Hazel""
column2: there was something like ""Your Own Nothing"". Unfortunately
column3: the back half of Jinx feels like even more of a retreat. Moving away from the more varied songcraft that speckled the record's earlier tracks
column4: Jinx eventually resigns itself to a pillowy darkness that
column5: while not unpleasant
column6: feels safe and flat. ""Sirens"" is the kind of shoegaze track that finds itself staring into the wall instead of the floor
column7: and before you notice
column8: you too have been peering blankly into oblivion for three minutes. There are little takeaways that help steady things
column9: with ""It's Alright"" blowing fairy dust all over the Soft Moon's post-industrial vibes

column11:
you just feel in need of a stretch.

After four albums (including one post-apocalyptic surf movie soundtrack) mining the proggy bass chugging wizardry of Yes
column2: the black hole guitar-driven R&B of Blue Cheer
column3: the dankest parts of Led Zeppelin’s mountain mystic folk rock
column4: and some Velvet Underground proto-punk
column5: the Vancouver-based sludge psych band Black Mountain is a known quantity among classic rock revivalists. But the way their aesthetic trickles down to its members' side projects provides an interesting angle on their approach. Lead singer/guitarist Stephen McBean’s debut album with Grim Tower is the most recent example
column6: combining strains of bluegrass with pitch black psychedelic textures to create a “new acoustic death folk” ensemble with former Yeah Yeah Yeah’s guitarist Imaad Wasif. Lightning Dust
column7: comprised of Black Mountain vocalist Amber Webber and drummer Joshua Wells
column8: is probably the most accomplished BM satellite.

column1: Lightning Dust cues from their parent band in some ways-- maintaining a wistful veil of doomy
column2: occasionally inscrutable
column3: psychedelia-- but without the bombast. They've also calibrated their songwriting to include electronic flourishes in the vein of minimalist electronic legends Suicide
column4: and shades of 1970s FM soft rock like Fleetwood Mac
column5: with Webber’s gorgeous voice providing an eerie parallel to Stevie Nicks’ howl. On Fantasy
column6: Lightning Dust’s third studio album
column7: Webber and Wells have polished and foregrounded the once-peripheral synths and drum machines. So while the duo’s 70s pop influences remain relatively intact
column8: the small scale prog rock oddities that permeated 2008's Infinite Light are discarded for chilly
column9: art-disco sheen.

column1: But the album's glossy production proves to be an awkward fit for Webber’s elegantly weird harmonies and impressionistic lyricism. Where the band once drew energy from the friction created by her cryptic vocals butting up against the rigid grid of driving synths
column2: there are too many instances on Fantasy where the electronics dominate
column3: throwing the sound out of balance. “Mirror” in particular is beautifully sung song trapped inside shiny
column4: bland production
column5: with cheap sounding skittering 808’s and percolating percussion. And “In the City Tonight” squanders another ethereal Webber performance with listless keyboards and a-rhythmic drum machines pattering pointlessly in the background.

column1: Sometimes the duo’s newly developed sound clicks into place
column2: like when the brittle electronic beats link up with Webber’s lyrics on the industrial-tinged “Loaded Gun”
column3: but even then we lose the most distinctive parts of Webber’s croon. Her voice is unique
column4: to the point that it needs only a haunting keyboard line or acoustic riff to complete a song. The album's inconsistency can be attributed to Lightning Dust's desire to add additional wrinkles to their well-worn psych rock/ 70s pop mix. And while it's hard to fault a band for branching out beyond their established template
column5:
the tidy electronic textures of Fantasy don't begin to match the mysterious depths of Lightning Dust's best work.

Love Your Dum and Mad begins with this insistent clanging; it's guitarist Simon McCabe hammering away on a zither

column1: Much of Shah's press attention's referenced some fantasy patrilineage

But Shah's actual lineage sheds more light on her sound: growing up Shah's Pakistani father sang Urdu ghazals around the house

column1: The album's second single

column8: a looping 3/4 of vibes and music box melody

column11: until Shah lets loose-- the jagged vibrato at the top of her range recalling Diamanda Galás at points-- as her voice comes to full power. ""Darling
column12: I'm leaving
column13: she howls
column14: all emotion but still in total control of her voice

column1: On ""To Be a Young Man""
column2: she sings as a man with his youth and all it's privilege and ease far behind him. ""Oh to be a young man again
column3: she sings drawing the ""o"" long in her Northern accent
column4: moaning distress until it almost sounds a little obscene. ""There were hopes and dreams that we locked up and hid
column5: she intones. Her voice is rapturous
column6: the desperation in her voice allowing her inhabit characters completely-- whether she's playing the venomous housewife of the nearly perfect ""Runaway"" or the pliant lover on ""All I Want""
column7: boasting ""I'm all that you want.""

column6: sounds double back
column7: pile up
column8: and refuse to fade. The arrangements are simple
column9: usually just piano
column10: bass
column11: guitar
column12: drums
column13: and some bits of feedback or guitar scuzz saturating the mix for emphasis. It's all baroqueness and black clouds
column14: and Shah low voice
column15: purring
column16: like she is trying to beg the moon down from the sky. For all of Dum and Mad's unebbing intensity-- it never gets overbearing
column17:
it retains a dynamism through Shah's magnetic voice-- she makes you want to stay in the darkness with her.

Elvin Estela has to be aware of all the jokes that come with operating under the alias of Nobody-- it'd be pretty unsurprising if it turned out that's one of the main reasons he chose it. As a producer
column2: his output has ridden more on the personalities of collaborators and scene compatriots than any specific character statement of his own. And the irony is that his music often feels like it comes from somewhere rather than someone. For better or worse
column3: there's an enigmatic bubbling-up and reconfiguration of half-recalled instrumental hip-hop and beat music ideas about that feels like it can fit in a movement
column4: but less as a driving force than a mysterious insinuation.

column1: If that means immediacy and instant cheap thrills are sacrificed
column2: that's a risky cost
column3: but there's something to be said for blurry background music that comes into deep focus when you least expect it. Vivid Green is the latest Nobody album to explore the pleasures of subtlety and long-soak immersion
column4: a breezy but not inconsequential recliner-beat suite with a warm-weather glow to it. There's an inert
column5: vague sort of beauty that you have to meet halfway here
column6: a naggingly familiar yet unplaceable assemblage that often feels like it has to be completed by the pre-existing experiences a deep listener might already have.

column1: The album's emphasis on low-key ambience doesn't keep things from knocking here and there. Airy melodies and weighty drum breaks mix well on a handful of early album tracks
column2: like the liquid flutter of ""Third Charm""
column3: the faucet-drip on a drumhead rumble of ""Pentwater""
column4: or ""Flat Black"" and its subterranean cavern echo. Few of his instrumentals really come alive with an emotional heft that rises above calm head-nod reverie
column5: the slowly cresting
column6: invigorating triumph of the title track being a welcome exception. But like a mild narcotic or a one-pint buzz
column7: it does feel attuned to the potential of just slightly amplifying the mellow-high qualities of an already pleasant surrounding. It's a precarious balance
column8: and going too far in either direction between preciousness and aggression jostles things off the track a bit. The twee synth-baroque ""Rhombus"" sounds like the soundtrack to one of the more boring plot-advancement cutscenes in a mid-90s Playstation RPG
column9: and when the record's subtle nods to trap get a bit too unsubtle on the horn-blat bombast of ""Rex""
column10: it's hard not to hear it as an out-of-place caricature. But those mood-breaking moments are more outliers than dealbreakers
column11: weird diversions on an otherwise consistently bucolic record.

column1: Bucolic doesn't always make for exciting
column2: though
column3: which is why it's a good thing Nobody's tapped into his collaborative impulses and recruited a few vocalists to bolster the ranks and ink in the lines that the music too often simply sketches out. Mars Volta frontman Cedric Bixler-Zavala provides his voice to ""Our Last Dance""
column4: which isn't exactly the prog-crossover move that one might expect -- it's a woozily soulful
column5: borderline mournful downtempo psychedelic synthpop dirge that hints at either a breakup or a death but might as well be about both. Teri Gender Bender (of Bosnian Rainbows) and Anna Wise (of Sonnymoon and the hook to Kendrick Lamar's ""Real"") let their enigmatic
column6: melody-distorting qualities pierce the half-awake goth-soul of ""Sleeping Alone"" and the disassociated Stephen Hawking namechecking g-dub of ""Spliff!"" And even if its oceanside summer vibe couldn't fit anywhere but the album's high-note end
column7: the Baths-coproduced ""Beaches"" is a choice moment
column8:
featuring a turn from Project Blowed battle-rap vet Nocando that flips convincingly between downpitched reefer-smoke zone-out and straight-up lovestruck devotion. Let it all sink in -- it'll come to you soon enough.

If you’ve heard of Valient Thorr
column2: the hirsute and heroic rock’n’roll five-piece stretched between Raleigh
column3: N.C.
column4: and Richmond
column5: Va.
column6: you’ve probably heard their creation myth
column7: too: Decades ago
column8: the band members were on a spaceship dispatched from their hometown of Burlatia
column9: Venus
column10: when a crash-landing temporarily stranded them in the college town wilderness of Eastern North Carolina. Try as they might
column11: the spacemen have yet to fix the ship. Instead
column12: they’ve passed the time with a rock group that tours incessantly
column13: spreading warnings about the endless greed and impending catastrophe they’ve encountered on Earth with a great Pentecostal fervor. In front of swiveling riffs lovingly borrowed from Thin Lizzy
column14: Rainbow and the like
column15: leader Valient Himself has preached revolution and suspicion with an Iggy Pop-styled urgency
column16: an alien trying to save himself and everyone around him from seemingly inescapable predators.

column1: Of course
column2: the problem with such origin tales is that they can sometimes overrun the actual work of the band behind them. For the last decade
column3: Valient Thorr’s shout-out-loud anthems and frenetic live shows have often been the sidecar to their story
column4: as it provides a ready diversion for an industry generally overloaded with narratives of four friends who met in college or found one another on Craigslist. The stranded Venusians offer intrigue. Sometimes
column5: though
column6: that anecdotal allure has prevented the band from being taken seriously; despite their pristine two-guitar attack and one of the most riveting frontmen around
column7: they have been perceived as a gimmick
column8: jokesters too taken with fantasy to commit to the reality of the world around them.

column1: But as its title suggests
column2: Our Own Masters-- the band’s sixth LP and first in three years-- finds Valient Thorr largely forgetting the spaceship and forgoing their skyward return for a more immediate and local redemption. Though all of Valient Thorr’s records have been
column3: to some degree
column4: about the problems of this world
column5: Our Own Masters feels of our problems
column6: too-- not only ready to proclaim them but also to claim them as the band’s own
column7: issues to be stared down and solved and not simply yammered about. Our Own Masters is the first Valient Thorr album to feel less like a sermon than a spirited conversation.

column1: They haven’t given up on the pronouncements of disgust and disappointment; “Master Collider” is a fortified hardcore sprint about apocalypse
column2: reinvention
column3: and salvation
column4: a bell-tolling cry to beat back corruption with “the power to be free.” Valient Thorr even leads with an indictment on “Immaculate Consumption”
column5: a smartly written and exuberantly delivered critique of American overspending that now seems so multigenerational and habitual that it’s hereditary. Importantly
column6: Himself implicates himself
column7: lambasting his own needs over any compulsion to help those around him. “Kick me in my grave
column8: ” he screams. “I feel like I’m fixin’ to die.” That moment of frustrated mortality suggests that Valient Thorr’s come a long way from a band that
column9: in interviews
column10: still embraces its interplanetary heritage.

column1: Indeed
column2: across most of Our Own Masters
column3: Valient Thorr thrives upon a relatively fresh honesty and vulnerability. The incandescent “No Strings Attached”
column4: for instance
column5: offers a new benchmark for the group
column6: finally turning “stormy weather” and “bills that we cannot pay” into launching points for solidarity and triumph. Valient Thorr’s built a worldwide network of tattooed and denim-clad “Thorriors” during their seemingly endless tours
column7: and “No Strings Attached” finally capitalizes on that sort of fostered goodwill; it’s a love song to a world that these aliens still worry about but now belong to
column8: and it’s one of the most winning songs they’ve ever written. The bruising “Good News Bad News”
column9: meanwhile
column10: finds Himself invoking Bad Brains and “counteract[ing] those who spread fear
column11: ” the thick riffs and relentless rhythm serving as the locomotive that pulls him through the awakening. He confesses that difficulties are just around the next hook
column12: but that he’s got to take charge in dealing with them-- that is
column13: the alien has come home to roost with his terrestrial burden
column14: not to pass it along on someone else.

column1: What’s most gratifying about this attitude shift is that it doesn’t mitigate Valient Thorr’s musical brawn; if anything
column2: it’s only galvanized it. The 27-second sizzle of “Life Hands You Demons” and the outsized glory of “Call Off the Dogs” stand among Valient Thorr’s most riveting songs to date without standing apart from them. Self-absolved from their roles as alien emissaries and newly loaded with personal responsibility
column3: they seem entirely recharged now
column4:
a veteran outfit bailing on one mission to start a better and more approachable one.

Syd Barrett is the perfect hero figure for music fans of a certain age: he’s brilliant
column2: mysterious
column3: romantically tragic
column4: and eternally young and beautiful. (Also: drugs.) But Jackson Scott’s interest in the troubled Pink Floyd founder goes beyond surfaces. On his debut
column5: Melbourne
column6: the North Carolina-based singer-songwriter attempts to locate his inner Barrett
column7: aspiring to the dark whimsy and fractured melodies of Pink Floyd’s Piper at the Gates of Dawn and the solo albums The Madcap Laughs and Barrett. It’s an admirable attempt at achieving a difficult goal-- for all their woozy tempos and “weird” affectations
column8: Scott’s songs never quite reach the singularly unsettling depths of Barrett’s best music. He is
column9: for better or worse
column10: a different kind of artist.

column1: That’s not to say that Jackson doesn’t have talent
column2: or that Melbourne isn’t a winning introduction. Because he does
column3: and the album most definitely is. Scott might not be the next Syd Barrett
column4: but he could be a budding Rivers Cuomo. In an interview with Pitchfork back in April
column5: Scott copped to his love of early Weezer and alt-rock in general. (While Scott’s music bears some superficial similarities with fellow southern psych-rock tunesmiths like Bradford Cox and Jeff Mangum
column6: to whom he’s often been compared
column7: he wasn’t weaned on Elephant 6 bands or indie-rock at all.) Sure enough
column8: if you listen closely to <i>Melbourne
column9: what initially sounds like oddball 1960s pop gradually reveals itself to be something else. Though Scott lathers his songs in tape hiss and disembodied noise
column10: but the songs themselves are straight-forward and hooky guitar jams.

column1: Cuomo’s influence on Scott is apparent in the number of songs named women on Melbourne. “Evie” is one of the album’s prettiest songs
column2: with Scott’s murmuring
column3: wandering vocal anchored by a sturdy acoustic strum and lifted by a jangly electric lead. Also lovely is “Sandy”-- which refers to the Sandy Hook shootings-- which offsets the disturbing lyrics (“Little kids/ Sitting all around/ Wishing they were sound asleep again”) with a light shuffle and sighing backing vocals. “Sandy” is the closest that Scott gets to full-on lysergic creepiness on Melbourne; he’s most at home with sprawling
column4: slow-burn rockers that climax with stunning six-string pyrotechnics. “That Awful Sound” stomps with surprising swagger after the tweeness of Melbourne’s opening tracks
column5: with Scott’s smoldering guitar finally bubbling over for a searing mid-song solo. The Pixies-like “Together Forever” is a mini epic-- at 3:42
column6: it’s the longest song on this fleet 12-track and 29-minute record-- that builds to a chorus of guitar feedback in the final minute.

column1: While the melodies jump out of Melbourne and immediately assert themselves-- “Any Way” is the giddiest two-minute rock song you’ll hear this year-- Scott disguises his voice by pitch-shifting the vocals into various distorted shapes. It’s an intermittently successful approach
column2: equal parts creepy and annoying
column3: but the gimmickry adds little to the songs
column4: which are strong enough to benefit from greater clarity and a more confident delivery. Scott already has his songwriting tools in place; once he finds his voice
column5:
look out.

To date
column2: one of Seth Bogart's great defining works is the 2010 Hunx and His Punx compilation Gay Singles. With its cover emblazoned with the visage of his greasy crotch sheathed in a zebra-print Speedo
column3: the comp featured songs that were heavily indebted to girl groups. Bogart

column1: Last year
column2: Nobunny continued his streak of power pop gems with ""La La La La Love You""
column3: but shortly after that single came out
column4: he made a sudden turn for a much more pointedly aggro sound. And now
column5: it seems that Seth Bogart has made a similar transition. After releasing last year's ballad-lined solo effort Hairdresser Blues and the girl group joy of Too Young to Be in Love
column6: Bogart has reminded us why he calls them His Punx. Street Punk exhibits the same kind of shrugged off sneering
column7: swearing
column8: and intimidation as Nobunny's latest punk onslaught. Take ""Everyone's a Pussy (Fuck You Dude)""-- a song that's exactly 30 seconds long-- a hard-hitting cut that has an all-intimidation bass riff on the low end and features exactly six angrily screamed words. That song is proof enough that Hunx and Nobunny are still on similar wavelengths
column9: except now
column10: the two men owe more to G.G. Allin than Phil Spector.

column1: But while the Punx may have shifted into a tougher mentality
column2: these tracks can still be genuinely funny. ""Bad Skin"" escalates things pretty quickly by threatening to ""kill you with a knife"". Why? Because they have bad skin. Perhaps the most sly track of the bunch is ""You Think You're Tough""
column3: where the narrator makes a gradual transition from irrational anger (""I think you're gross"") to the moment when they realize their disdain may actually be affection (""Oh no
column4: what have I become? Am I in love?""). And like a lot of Hunx's romantic material
