column10: serif;"">

column1: Which is promising in a sense; at least you know Palms isn’t entirely redundant. But it’s more so than you might think. Glistening opener “Future Warrior” isn’t all that far off from Deftones’ more sensitive and balmy recent work-- think “Entombed” from Koi No Yokan

column1: It’s the sort of work most would call “exploratory

column3: slicked with delay and reverb
column4: pinging around the stereo field. But once you’ve heard him do it once on “Future Warrior""

column5: floating a couple of longing

column1: These moments of catharsis or even contrast never arrive

column1: Still

column5: Blut aus Nord
column6:
Deafheaven or even Sigur Rós’ Kveikur are establishing ways for metal to double as makeout music without skimping on the heavy petting.

column8: repetitive wallop of Swans

And “Eternal Return” takes shape around bitterly shouted imprecations and swells of background noise so strong they sometimes threaten to push the ascension off track. Return to Annihilation forever demands that you decide for yourself-- or

an essential Locrian idea.

All Hail West Texas is a lonely album
column2: a product of idle time and summer boredom recorded alone
column3: quickly
column4: in an empty house. John Darnielle wrote most of the lyrics in the margins of the stapled
column5: mimeographed handouts given to him in the orientation sessions at his new health-care job in Ames
column6: Iowa. It was 1999. Every day he’d come home at three to an empty house
column7: dishes crowding the sink (his wife was away at hockey camp) and pass the solitary evenings leafing through his handouts and editing the day’s work. When a melody came to him
column8: he’d grab his guitar
column9: mute the TV and hit the red button on a dying
column10: decade-old boombox that had documented hundreds of similarly fractured
column11: bleating folk songs since he began recording as the Mountain Goats in 1991.

column1: There were obstacles to recording this way-- sometimes the tape ran out mid-song
column2: very occasionally the phone rang-- and once they were resolved
column3: the composition in question had sometimes already fallen out of Darnielle’s favor. “In those days
column4: a song got exactly one day in which to either resolve its issues or be cast forth from the company of its brethren
column5: ” he writes in the reissue’s liner notes. The lucky survivors
column6: though
column7: have a palpable immediacy. Most of the takes you hear on All Hail West Texas were recorded within hours (or
column8: when the juices were really flowing
column9: minutes) of being written.

column1: There’s a common misconception that all Mountain Goats records were recorded this way
column2: but that’s not exactly true. Up until All Hail West Texas’s release in 2002
column3: they were more like compilations-- collage-like assortments of bedroom recordings
column4: live shows
column5: occasional duets
column6: radio broadcasts and four-tracked one-offs. The subject matter was sometimes bleak (especially the many songs that charted in stinging detail the doomed relationship of the fictional Alpha couple) but these variedly textured means of recording lent the albums a feeling of motion: Darnielle seemed more like an eccentric
column7: town-to-town troubadour than an elusive bedroom-folk hermit. But not so on All Hail West Texas. Recording in suburban solitary confinement and exclusively on the boombox gives All Hail West Texas a cohesion and an echoing sense of isolation-- the perfect atmosphere for 14 songs about crushed dreams (“The Best Ever Death Metal Band in Denton”)
column8: long-distance longing (“Source Decay”)
column9: and occasional moments of piercing joy (“Jenny”).

column1: While recording All Hail
column2: Darnielle did have a companion of sorts: his Panasonic RX-FT500
column3: a temperamental machine so crucial to the album’s overall vibe that he credits it as a “second performer” in the liner notes. It had been out of commission for about two years (listening to the RX-FT500’s contributions to the Mountain Goats’ discography chronologically is kind of like listening to an alt-folk Disintegration Loops: you can practically chart its slow
column4: gradual decay)
column5: but that fateful summer
column6: it came back from the brink of death for an encore performance. “What you have with you now
column7: ” Darnielle writes on the inside sleeve
column8: “[Is] the sound of a long-broken machine deciding
column9: on its own and without the interference of repairmen or excessive prayer vigils
column10: to function again.” And perhaps more than any other Mountain Goats record
column11: you get a sense of this feeling in his voice
column12: too: urgency
column13: finality
column14: and a twinge of superstition-- as though he’s not sure the “record” button will still be working by the next take.

column1: The first people we meet are Jeff and Cyrus
column2: a pair of pentagram-doodling teenage metalheads with big dreams for their still-unnamed two-man band (though they’ve been arguing over a few possibilities: Satan’s Fingers
column3: the Killers
column4: the Hospital Bombers). They’re the stars of album opener “The Best Ever Death Metal Band in Denton” a song that
column5: if not the definitive Mountain Goats song
column6: at least deserves an undisputed mention in the top 5. This isn’t a statement you throw around lightly about a band this prolific
column7: but “Denton” feels like a dizzyingly succinct crash course in everything that makes the Mountain Goats great. In just two-and-a-half minutes
column8: Darnielle pulls off three whiplashing tonal shifts. It starts off seeming like a light
column9: funny song about a couple of high school goofballs
column10: but then-- with a simple
column11: unexpected pivot in the chord progression—things turn suddenly poignant: the band and the boys’ friendship is abruptly interrupted when Cyrus gets sent to a boarding school-- or
column12: as the now-ominous “Hospital Bombers” suggests
column13: could it be a psychiatric facility?-- “where they told him he’d never be famous.” In its closing moments
column14: though
column15: it becomes defiant
column16: triumphant battlecry: “When you punish a person for dreaming his dream/ Don’t expect him to thank or forgive you/ The best ever death metal band out of Denton/ Will in time both outpace and outlive you.” It’s brilliantly structured and smartly crafted
column17: but it wouldn’t be half as stirring if it were recorded with more polish. “Denton” is an imperfectly sung ode to all the songs that don’t get sung because of the people who put into the singers’ heads that the only songs worth singing are the perfect ones.

column1: As advertised on its otherwise blank cover
column2: All Hail West Texas is comprised of “fourteen songs about seven people
column3: two houses
column4: a motorcycle
column5: and a locked treatment facility for adolescent boys.” The specificity of the narrative here is something of a joke: this was Darnielle’s first attempt at a concept album and-- somewhat paradoxically-- it succeeds mostly because of how loose the concept is. None of the other recurring characters get the first-name introductions that Jeff and Cyrus do
column6: and it’s hard to follow which songs are about which of the seven people
column7: or where one person ends and the other begins.

column1: But that’s the point-- and even the brilliance-- of All Hail West Texas. Darnielle finds the common humanity in the people he’s singing about
column2: whether it’s the injured high school football star who accidentally sells acid to an undercover cop (“Fall of the High School Running Back”)
column3: the blissfully happy couple in “Jenny” or the thoroughly miserable one in “Fault Lines”. There’s no shortage of contenders for “most devastating moment on All Hail West Texas”
column4: but my vote goes to the half-second beat between tracks 8 and 9
column5: the tender “Riches and Wonders” (“We are strong
column6: we are faithful
column7: we are guardians of a rare thing…/ And we dance like drunken sailors
column8: lost at sea
column9: out of our minds”) and the searing pre-break-up travelogue “The Mess Inside” (“We went down to New Orleans one weekend in the spring/ Looked hard for what we’d lost/ It was painful to admit it
column10: but we couldn’t find a thing”). Are these two songs about the same couple? The suggestion that they could be-- that the potent feeling captured in “Riches” is too often something fleeting-- stings worse than knowing for sure.

column1: As the Panasonic RX-FT500’s swansong
column2: All Hail West Texas (which finally came out
column3: first on cassette
column4: in 2002) does mark the end of something fleeting
column5: too. Later in 2002
column6: Darnielle released the excellent Tallahassee-- not only the first “hi-fi” Mountain Goats record
column7: but also the first in a series of concept albums that stick to much clearer narratives. But in the retrospective ruminations prompted by Merge’s new CD/LP reissue of this album
column8: it feels less like a turning point in Darnielle’s career than an undeniable sweet spot. Mountain Goats fans are generally divided between the lo-fi diehards who champion the unpolished virtues of the early stuff and the people who prefer the more finely crafted later records. But All Hail West Texas (as well as the highlights of the previously unreleased material included with the reissue
column9: like “Answering the Phone” and the proto-Tallahassee sketch “Indonesia”) is the best of both worlds: a snapshot of the moment when Darnielle had honed his lyrical and melodic sensibilities well enough to write songs as good as “Jenny” and “The Best Ever Death Metal Band in Denton”
column10: but also perhaps before he actually realized how good and enduring these songs actually were.

column1: Revisiting All Hail West Texas over two decades into the Mountain Goats’ existence makes a central irony in their story all too clear: it’s not a lonely record anymore. A handful of these songs remain the most iconic in the Mountain Goats catalog
column2: which-- thanks to Darnielle’s cult fanbase that seems to be steadily
column3: improbably increasing with each year-- means that some of the lines that echoed off the empty walls that summer in Ames
column4: Iowa have now been screamed by thousands and thousands of different people. When Darnielle put most of these songs to tape in 1999
column5: even to his fans he seemed like someone who’d end up a committed but obscure lifer on the indie cassette circuit; it was hard to imagine there’d ever be a wide audience for the kind of eccentric
column6: homespun music he was making. But remember: people underestimated Jeff and Cyrus
column7:
too.

While they had very vocal fans in the likes of Johnny Lydon and Mark E. Smith

column6: all of it tethered to drummer Jaki Liebezeit’s relentless rhythms

column8: Radiohead
column9: Tortoise
column10: and Stereolab remain deeply in their debt; same goes for massively influential producers like Carl Craig

column1: Even after the band dissolved

column1: Some nineteen different players are credited on Retrospection

column4: Olek Gelba

column9: Retrospection cherrypicks from the group’s 80’s output
column10: a four album run starting with 1983’s Colours and Soul and ending with 1989’s Songs for Everyone.

column1: First song “This is How You Came” features tropical sound effects
column2: some baby talk
column3: and a lush polyrhythmic groove with extra hand percussion
column4: while the next song
column5: “Q” detours into the strangely lush world of Ryiuchi Sakamoto-styled gloss and early 80s sax
column6: a strain of smooth jazz made all the stranger by Suzuki’s brand of pillow talk. On the 13-minute sprawl of “Retrospection""
column7: the groove is decidedly more AOR rock-based
column8: with Suzuki’s deeper vocals grappling with Wolfgang Schubert’s saxophone. If you ever wondered what it might sound like if the horn from “Baker Street” wandered onto Ege Bamyasi
column9: here is the closest approximation of that trainwreck.

column1: But as odd a fit as such rock moves can sound
column2: it’s when grotesque-seeming genres like “Teutonic reggae” and “Kosmische-fusion” appear that the set intrigues. “Keine Python” has the skip and bounce of turn-of-decade reggae (think of Sly & Robbie’s Taxi productions) with vocalist Coco Claus yipping like Ari Up as Berliner. “Network” finds the group mimic Weather Report via Schubert’s processed horn and Krachten’s shuffling drum patterns while Suzuki scats amid the slick fusion.

column1: The highlight of the vinyl set for me occurs on the second 12”. It opens with “Trailer II""
column2: coupling a martial beat of “Sunday Bloody Sunday” with a bass throb like something emanating from Metal Box. With Suzuki’s inexplicable muttering on top
column3: it makes for a sinuous and intoxicating dark disco track. The taut and vivacious “Bleib Nicht So Lang Im Schatten Stehn” shows that Dunkelziffer could also make boisterous femme-fronted new wave with Claus
column4: too. Uneven at times
column5: its sleekness sometimes to the point of sounding oily
column6: Retrospection will still reward and satisfy Can fans
column7:
showing how their DNA continued to mutate the music of their homeland even after they had disbanded.

figuring out a new set of altered states to explore next time.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19345/homepage_large.0638e143.jpg|Rebellion Hymns|31359.0|Man's Gin|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2013-07-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:26.472529|"

Never question Erik Wunder’s gumption: The design scheme of the second album from Man’s Gin
column2: the folk-rock project of Cobalt drummer and multi-instrumentalist
column3: mimics the layout of a classic Swans title. The band’s name
column4: written in large white capital letters
column5: stretches across the top of the record’s cover within a thick black bar; below
column6: the album’s name
column7: <i>Rebellion Hymns
column8: squeezes across the bottom
column9: caps-lock again surrounded by black. The disc’s spine even co-opts the familiar Young God Records layout
column10: with Profound Lore’s coat of arms and the album’s catalog number both offset in separate white boxes. Indeed
column11: Michael Gira’s work
column12: particularly as it bled in the late 90s from Swans into Angels of Light
column13: offers a clear stylistic guide for Wunder’s own reflections on morality and morbidity. Like Gira
column14: Wunder’s swollen
column15: resonant bellow lifts lines about desperation
column16: resignation
column17: and perseverance above electrically charged acoustic music-- a bleak mirror image of typecast heaviness.

column1: Such a conspicuous reference to one of music’s great cult acts cuts both ways
column2: of course. It situates Rebellion Hymns within a clear aesthetic framework
column3: but it also sets a particularly heavy onus of expectation squarely at the feet of Man’s Gin. But by and large
column4: Wunder proves to be a compelling songwriter and arranger
column5: overhauling structures in ways that make it clear that Man’s Gin is neither mere obsequy or a vacuous side-project from a musician better-known for his role in Cobalt. Most often
column6: Rebellion Hymns gathers itself into grand waves
column7: with what might sound like folk or country tunes rising deliberately into dramatic crescendos. During album opener “Inspiration”
column8: for instance
column9: Wunder delivers a series of motivational credos (“Take a leaf off a tree and make it worth something”) over a steady rise in volume; by song’s end
column10: he’s yelling his mantras
column11: his voice straining and cracking over accordion
column12: drums
column13: and piano. The terrific “Deer Head & the Rain” pushes from a similarly polite mien to
column14: four minutes later
column15: a truly Swans-styled meanness
column16: as Wunder shouts over cascading drums and guitars that surge through a thin scrim of dissonance.

column1: Such a songwriting script is a holdover from Smiling Dogs
column2: Wunder’s previous and much more monotonous LP as Man’s Gin. On Rebellion Hymns
column3: for better and worse
column4: he strikes out in several new directions at once
column5: aided again by the versatile backing band of Joshua Lozano and Scott Edward and contributions from a number of guests
column6: including former Swan Jarboe and Cobalt’s other half
column7: Phil McSorley. “Old House (Bark at the Moonwalk)” slyly approximates the shape of black metal with piano
column8: its keys flickering quickly while the drums crack open behind it; a series of rhythmic switchbacks and momentum swings
column9: “Old House” eventually peaks in a full sprint
column10: with Wunder yelling over chaotic guitar and still-pounding piano. “Never Do the Neon Lights” pushes decidedly toward pop-rock
column11: swiveling on a hook that’s perfectly sharp and strangely reassuring. Closer “Hibernation Time” is Wunder’s attempt to construct an acoustic doom epic
column12: with the baritone saxophone of Yakuza’s Bruce Lamont smoldering beneath forlorn vocals and a curtain of neon noise.

column1: These are indeed intriguing moments
column2: but as an hour-long
column3: 12-track album
column4: Rebellion Hymns fails to weave together the various and variably provocative threads that Wunder offers. The band flips from the plaintive acoustic croon of “Varicose” to the awkward gypsy folk growl of “Off The Coast of Sicily”
column5: from the strangely bustling and winning grunge of “Never Do the Neon Lights” to the demented acoustic plod of “Deer Head & the Rain”. The band scatters four instrumental interludes through the disc
column6: too-- three are untitled
column7: though the last and best is a candlelit piano dirge called “Cellar Door”. The scraped piano strings and aleatory percussion of the first and third such pieces and the asphyxiated guitar of the middle number are rather rote lifts of 20th century composition. More important
column8: though
column9: is that none of these wordless bits do anything to enhance the album as an experience or to help the tunes themselves make more sense as neighbors. Rather
column10: they only sit in their places
column11: unarticulated thoughts that never fell quite to the cutting-room floor.

column1: Wunder’s voice doesn’t do him any favors here
column2: either. He’s a terrific singer
column3: with a deep tone that seems to bubble up from a pool of experience. But he wanders uncomfortably inside of it
column4: alternately taking on the characters of Eddie Vedder
column5: Mike Patton
column6: Scott Kelly
column7: Layne Staley
column8: and
column9: at certain points along the way
column10: himself. Man’s Gin remains
column11: then
column12: the quintessential other band
column13: functioning more as a reservoir for outlying ideas and accessorized themes than an outfit with a direct focus or aim. But even though Rebellion Hymns is less cohesive than Smiling Dogs
column14: that’s because it’s more imaginative
column15: suggesting that Wunder is slowly acclimating to his role as Man’s Gin singer
column16:
songwriter and-- most important-- bandleader.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19429/homepage_large.885ba6f2.jpg|Ghil|19488.0|Okkyung Lee|['Jazz'
column3: Okkyung Lee’s Ghil sounds about as solo as it gets. It’s just her and a cello
column4: improvising without overdubs or effects. The production is raw and immediate
column5: putting you so close to her instrument you can practically see the divots in its strings. And the music is so impulsive and untamed that at times it feels like you’re hearing her nervous system. Lee has made intimate solo music before-- 2008’s I Saw the Ghost of an Unknown Soul and It Said… is a highlight of her diverse discography-- but nothing so far has had the direct impact of Ghil.

column1: It turns out
column2: though
column3: that Ghil is actually a collaboration. Lee played all the sounds on the album
column4: but they were recorded by Norwegian noise musician Lasse Marhaug
column5: whose ideas guided the project. Marhaug took Lee to numerous locations in Oslo and documented her improvisations with a cheap mic and a vintage 1976 tape deck. Lee calls Marhaug’s technique “expressionistic…the way he recorded was the closest way to how I 'feel’ when I play rather than how it 'sounds.’” The pair laid down nearly three hours of music this way
column6: and Lee trusted Marhaug so much that she let him edit and sequence the results without hearing the full source material herself.

column1: That was a wise decision
column2: because Marhaug did a masterful job of choosing and arranging Lee’s music. He maintains the sessions’ in-the-moment feel while crafting a progression that approaches narrative. Ghil is also remarkably varied for an album with such a consistent emotional tone. Though Lee always sounds like she’s playing on the edge of her seat
column3: some of the music is hypnotic
column4: with repetitions that encourage meditation; other sections dart around so quickly it’s like she's putting out fires in the corners of her mind. Tracks like the trebly “Meolly Ganeun” sound like a pedal-pushing noise band
column5: while the cavernous “Hollow Water” and the growling “Two Perfectly Shaped Stones” build drones that seem beyond the capacity of a single instrument.

column1: If you’re unfamiliar with Lee’s work or improv in general
column2: a good reference point for Ghil might be the saxophone workouts of Colin Stetson. Both he and Lee put physical effort into their music that in turn has a visceral effect on the listener. But where Stetson can drift toward calmer tones
column3: Lee here is all about brute force-- sometimes at a frightening level. Take the ear-busting “Two to Your Right
column4: Five to Your Left
column5: ” which evokes string sections from horror movie soundtracks shattered against each other.

column1: That thrill-ride aspect of Ghil is intoxicating
column2: but its main strength is how it sounds both tactile and emotional-- both like natural phenomena and purposeful music. I often find myself fascinated by Lee’s textures and how she created them
column3: but I never feel like I’m listening to field recordings or abstract art. That’s due to Lee’s pedigree as a composer and player-- she has a degree in music from Berklee
column4: has accompanied Laurie Anderson and Vijay Iyer
column5: and made two albums of precisely-arranged music for John Zorn’s Tzadik label.

column1: But when Marhaug asked her to record
column2: Lee had reached a stage where she was thinking less about structure
column3: preferring to “start totally blank and wait for something to tell me where to go.” The result is an album that somehow embraces music while it’s abandoning it. And whichever end of her spectrum Lee swings toward-- the harshly noisy or the hypnotically meditative-- her sound always commands attention
column4:
making Ghil the biggest surprise in a career already full of them.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19453/homepage_large.40b75ced.jpg|The Aeroplane Flies High|3838.0|The Smashing Pumpkins|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Virgin'
column2:
'Universal']|2013-07-19 00:00:00|1996|2016-06-11 16:55:28.014048|"

Let’s can the mock suspense and acknowledge the absurdity of this rerelease as a starting point rather than a conclusion. The Aeroplane Flies High is not a beloved obscurity
column3: nor is it a canonical album celebrating a milestone anniversary. It’s not even an album: it’s a widely available
column4: 16-year old collection of B-sides from a double album. Granted
column5: the Smashing Pumpkins' Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness was more judiciously edited than the title would lead you to believe. It was a 28-song double album all the same
column6: and now Aeroplane nearly quadruples in size with 90 additional tracks on top of its original 33
column7: with a bonus DVD to boot. But while the numbers make The Aeroplane Flies High the most difficult Smashing Pumpkins reissue to endure
column8: it’s actually the easiest to revisit. For most listeners
column9: Siamese Dream and Mellon Collie are inseparable from the memories of living with those records at a certain age; it’s tough to rehear “Disarm” or “X.Y.U.” without recalling the specific sensory triggers of your parents' house or the details of a particularly shitty day in 10th grade when [INSERT NAME HERE] didn’t reciprocate your crush on them. Aeroplane simply reminds the listener of what it was like to be a Smashing Pumpkins fan when people were expected to pay money for music.

column1: It was equally exhilarating and exhausting during the band’s prime. If you caught the videos on MTV and chose to take your Pumpkins fanship to the next level by exploring the deep cuts
column2: the bootlegs
column3: the formative guitar tablature sites
column4: and so forth
column5: you realized that Billy Corgan was every bit as excited about the music of Smashing Pumpkins as his audience. In fact
column6: that probably strikes at the root of everything you’ve come to loathe about Corgan as well: he’s the biggest Smashing Pumpkins fan on earth.

column1: So while Aeroplane was always meant as a collector’s item
column2: Corgan made it worth your while. Even if you bought it out of obligation and never even listened to the thing
column3: it was one of the 90s’ most handsome and unique physical packages: five CD singles with their own art design
column4: delivered in a hypno-swirled carrying case. It was a keepsake and a conversation piece
column5: a vinyl era throwback for kids who assumed the CD era would last forever. So even if the songs themselves were dashed off (Corgan claimed “Pennies” took literally minutes to write) or slapped together (the very literal 23-minute guitar collage “Pastichio Medley”)
column6: there was nothing half-assed about the actual product.

column1: Separating the B-sides onto five separate CDs ensured that the collection was no mere data dump in terms of quality and presentation. If you let your ears go slack a little
column2: every EP retains some important characteristic of its linchpin Mellon Collie single. It’s not an exact fit; with the exception of the country and western curio “Said Sadly”
column3: Bullet With Butterfly Wings is the “covers” EP and the selections brought the new wave genealogy of that song to the fore. The keeper of the bunch is their take on Blondie’s “Dreaming”; not only does it feature a rare lead vocal from bassist D’arcy
column4: but the requisitely light
column5: billowy arrangement distinguishes it from their competent Cars and Alice Cooper karaoke and a fumbled cover of the Cure’s “A Night Like This” where James Iha can’t decide if he wants to perform it as a country
column6: slowcore
column7: or shoegaze song.

column1: Tonight
column2: Tonight is technically the “ballad” single-- it is the one with the strings and all. Yet
column3: its sumptuous studio arrangement bares no similarity to its attendant outtakes which are mostly solo
column4: acoustic performances from Corgan. Even compared to the spare and wistful lullabies from their previous odds-and-ends collection Pisces Iscariot such as “Whir” and “Obscured”
column5: the songs here sound incomplete rather than realized minimalism. If you’re trying to fashion a four-star Smashing Pumpkins album out of the original B-sides-- and really
column6: that seems like the entire point-- you can skip those two EPs altogether.

column1: On the other side
column2: everything on the 1979 single warrants inclusion. The most-beloved Smashing Pumpkins single gives these songs a certain halo effect
column3: of course. Beyond that
column4: the lightly carbonated college rock of “The Boy” is easily the best thing James Iha has ever written
column5: while the whispered restraint lent to the could-be power ballad “Believe” puts it as the runner up. More intriguing is how in 20 minutes
column6: the fluorescent and fizzy 1979 lays out an intriguing “what if?” for the Smashing Pumpkins. While Adore is known as their synth album and a sonic outlier amidst Corgan’s ambitions for Sistine Chapel art-rock
column7: it’s still a 70-minute opus draped in black and smeared with kohl eyeliner. “Ugly” and “Set the Ray to Jerry” are two sides of a coin and together they present a fascinating alternative to Adore: the former a self-hate song driven by palm-muted
column8: bristling guitar and the latter a love song of swirling
column9: phased ambience. Is it possible they could’ve made a minimalist
column10: melody-driven new wave album following in that vein? I have my doubts-- for all his generosity in the realm of B-sides and miscellany
column11: albums are a huge event for Corgan and we’ll never know if “Set the Ray” would’ve included triple-guitar harmonies or if Jimmy Chamberlin’s barnstorming drum rolls would’ve found a way onto “Cherry”.

column1: If you want those aspects of Smashing Pumpkins
column2: you can head straight to the Zero EP
column3: which
column4: like the titular single
column5: is the most immediately satisfying of the bunch and the quickest to lose its appeal. “God” rages with such Neanderthal impulses
column6: it’s actually fun; it’s basically “Bullet With Butterfly Wings” if you fast forward straight to the avalanche of its coda. The relatively raw glam-grunge of “Mouths of Babes” and “Marquis in Spades” has an underdog appeal if you somehow thought Mellon Collie was hindered by its concept album ambitions or ever mistook Smashing Pumpkins as being a punk or indie band at some point; but as far as riffs or melodies or dynamics go
column7: they’re all second-tier Corgan compositions.

column1: That leaves us with Thirty-Three
column2: the oft-forgotten single from Mellon Collie and the least typical of the lot. The rest of the EP follows suit
column3: as it bears the collection’s most risky and disparate offerings; you  get the prettiest cover (“My Blue Heaven”) and the sludgiest
column4: slowest guitar workout (“The Aeroplane Flies High (Turns Left Looks Right)”). The electro-spazz of “Transformer” segues into Iha’s ornate
column5: porcelain art-pop offering “The Bells”. And it’s all preceded by the showstopping closer on your hypothetical Aeroplane single-CD; containing one of Corgan’s most sweet and yearning vocal performances as well as guitar solo from his father
column6: “The Last Song” feels too crucial to be ignored and too personal to make it onto an album with Mellon Collie’s overt commercial ambitions.

column1: And those are all things you can surmise from buying the original version of Aeroplane Flies High; the tracks have been remastered here
column2: though liars and professional audio engineers are the only people who will claim to notice the effect. Like every Pumpkins reissue
column3: Aeroplane is stocked with extras; the difference here is that they’re jammed onto each single seemingly at random
column4: rather than separated into bonus discs. As a result
column5: the tasteful and accessible arrangement of the original is compromised
column6: negating one of its best qualities. For example
column7: why are 15 tracks of instrumental jamming slapped onto Bullet With Butterfly Wings? And these aren’t snippets either
column8: some go on for five minutes
column9: and mostly prove that while Smashing Pumpkins songs are pantheon material
column10: Smashing Pumpkins riffs are fairly easy to come by. As works in progress
column11: they’re nothing particularly special; it’d be more interesting if Corgan granted a Creative Commons License as part of the purchase price and allowed fans to use his scraps to come up with their best Smashing Pumpkins imitation.

column1: Otherwise
column2: do we need the Smashing Pumpkins’ July 1995 performance at Chicago’s Double Door and their rehearsal? The DD rehearsal is spirited and ragged
column3: notable for Corgan cracking up during “By Starlight” of all things and reconfiguring the lyrics of “God”. As far as the actual performance
column4: you almost wish Corgan would get all Patton Oswalt on the dude who’s yelling in the middle of “Stumbleine”. Forget all of those-- head straight to “Special Winner’s Song”
column5: which is five minutes of interactive crowd participation and an improvised rap by James Iha who is presumably drunk as shit. Hearing him yell
column6: “D’arcy Wretzky on the motherfucking bass!” makes the whole endeavor somehow worth it because it’s one of the few times you might imagine the Smashing Pumpkins being four people who enjoyed each other’s company.

column1: With all that said
column2: Aeroplane gives you insight to what a tremendous strain it must’ve been to be a member of the Smashing Pumpkins-- if listening to everything on Aeroplane Flies High seems taxing
column3: imagine playing it. And imagine that what ended up on this still somehow isn’t the sum total of their recorded output at the time. On a basic level
column4: the supersizing of Aeroplane magnifies what it was back in 1996
column5: a point where Corgan’s giving nature felt more like neediness
column6: where the generosity started to lose its altruism and became an oppressive act. The deluxe reissuing of Smashing Pumpkins’ heyday has resulted in upwards of 200 bonus tracks and the ones on Aeroplane are almost entirely inessential. You learn from the eight-track demo of “Zero” that it needs vocals and it needs Jimmy Chamberlain. You learn from the live version that it doesn’t need 50% more whammy pedal soloing. If it’s easy to revisit Aeroplane without getting emotionally attached
column7: it’s harder to talk about for the same reason. But it gets us one step closer to reevaluating <i>Adore
column8: the first Pumpkins record that underperformed commercially and critically
column9:
whose legacy is still somewhat in flux. And that’s a worthy cause even if Aeroplane couldn’t possibly justify its price tag.

"|18259.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18259-the-smashing-pumpkins-the-aeroplane-flies-high/|7.0|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19445/homepage_large.2344cb4e.jpg|Dear Mark J Mulcahy I Love You|27999.0|Mark Mulcahy|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fire']|2013-07-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:28.609385|"

Considering the death of his wife in 2008 and his subsequent focus on his family in favor of public work
column2: it would be understandable if Mark Mulcahy’s first full album in close to a decade was a somber one. Any album that ends with “Where’s the Indifference Now”
column3: portraying a suicide
column4: unanswered questions and grieving survivors
column5: would seem to fit that bill. But then
column6: part of what makes Dear Mark J. Mulcahy I Love You so distinct in an already dinstinctive career that stretches back to Mulcahy fronting Miracle Legion in the 1980s
column7: is its bright
column8: easygoing
column9: and often upbeat feel.

column1: Dear Mark J. Mulcahy makes no bones about where it sits musically. Early on
column2: the basic scope is set: Imagine an early 70s never-never world of incipient glam rock and folky pop
column3: UK style. Think of David Bowie if his glam peak was actually Hunky Dory (“He’s a Magnet” manages the neat trick of suggesting Bowie’s Velvet Underground tribute “Queen Bitch” without actually sounding like it) or
column4: even more particularly given Mulcahy’s singing style
column5: if T. Rex’s high point was the self-titled album instead of Electric Warrior. Mulcahy’s knowledge of history shows through in the details: many younger musicians miss these particular artists’ smaller moments in favor of the well-worn higher profile ones.

column1: But while you get a sense of his hard-earned knowledge
column2: Mulcahy doesn't come off as world weary. The previously mentioned “Where’s the Indifference Now” may have a serious subject
column3: but the arrangement is engaging
column4: down to a concluding electric guitar solo
column5: Mulcahy’s singing an energetic rumination that matches the thoughtful lyrics. Similarly
column6: “Poison Candy Heart” may be about a failed relationship
column7: but lines like “I saw you kissing the paperboy” are backed by music that moves sweetly along-- the descending keyboard melody that appears with the first chorus is pure delight
column8: as is a chorused whistling break that mirrors a brief solo introduction to the song. These are representative of Dear Mark J. Mulcahy in general: What drives this record throughout is gentle playfulness.

column1: On a lyrical level
column2: Mulcahy offers quick
column3: vivid portraits of people and situations. Early on
column4: the rumbling stomp of “Everybody Hustles Leo” gives a sense of what surprises Mulcahy is capable of: the verses seem to suggest straightforward (if not simply straight) talk about a woman ""who can get milk from a crowbar
column5: among other metaphors. But then the chorus makes it seem like it’s a song about a man
column6: or perhaps someone gay
column7: or a trans individual
column8: maybe something else entirely. And it’s all over and done in two and a half minutes
column9: followed by a slower
column10: steadier groove with another intriguing title “She Makes the World Turn Backwards
column11: ” featuring a call and response starting with a hoary medical chestnut: “Where does it hurt?” “Everywhere!”

column1: That so much on Dear Mark J. Mulcahy should be playful without being straight-up comedy songs or heavy-handed ""jokes"" is one of its best gifts; it’s pretty easy to find yourself starting to lock into turns of phrase rather than letting them pass by in the flow. To pick out three at random: from “Everybody Hustles Leo”: “Who cares
column2: as long as it’s white and you can snort it”;  “He’s a Magnet”: “Lady what’s that book you’re reading/ Oh
column3: the Bible/ That’s so interesting/ They’ve got a word for everything in there”; “Bailing Out on Everything Again”: “Now I smell trouble/ You had better roll down the window.”

column1: But if it were all jokes this would be stand-up or spoken-word. That “Let The Fireflies Fly Away” should start with the music settling in while Mulcahy delivers another well-worn joke setup “Waiter
column2: there’s a frog in my...” is one thing. But it’s another when he repeats the phrase only to have a backing chorus add in a “Waiter!” of its own
column3: all with the feeling of one-take ease. (Paul Q. Kolderie’s mixing ear throughout is top notch
column4: everything fitting in just the right place.)

column1: The songs on Dear Mark J Mulcahy often have codas that are honest-to-god codas-- different keys
column2: lyrics that tie up or tie together a song
column3: new instruments introduced-- while there are enough notable moments of instrumental bliss
column4: such as the blended guitar parts on “The Rabbit” or the numerous differing drum fills on “My Rose Colored Friend”
column5: that need no explanation when the pleasure one gets from listening to them is so immediate. From start to finish
column6: Dear Mark J. Mulcahy is a treat. In fact
column7:
it may be his best yet.

"|18251.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18251-mark-mulcahy-dear-mark-j-mulcahy-i-love-you/|7.7|Ned Raggett

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19400/homepage_large.a4f1b37d.jpg|Tonight You Look Like a Spider|6491.0|David Yow|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Joyful Noise']|2013-07-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:29.088513|"

Releasing an album that comes with a concrete monolith is one way to grab peoples' attention. But for David Yow
column3: on solo duties for the first time after years spent baiting audiences as the frontman of Scratch Acid and the Jesus Lizard
column4: it's a minor footnote to a wildly unpredictable record. To say it's uncompromising would be correct
column5: although somewhat redundant
column6: as he hasn't ever dealt in half measures. But this is not the sound of a sweat-soaked Yow plunging into a crowd and rubbing his blubbery belly all over the faces in the front row; Instead
column7: it's a studio creation
column8: cut somewhere between the art-fun antics of the Residents
column9: old horror movie soundtracks
column10: classical leanings
column11: a streak of digital noise
column12: a burst of Spanish guitar
column13: text messages translated by computer software
column14: and a recording of Yow squeezing a cat.

column1: Tonight You Look Like a Spider is an album that has been 15 years in the making
column2: once destined to be released by Mike Patton's Ipecac
column3: but ultimately coming out on the Joyful Noise label. Naturally
column4: Yow's new home have heralded its release with a photo of him with jeans around his ankles
column5: posed in front of a toilet. The picture hovers over a blurb that offers insights such as: ""I named it Tonight You Look Like a Spider after a spider I saw one night."" Don't look to Yow for any easy explanations for this stuff
column6: but it's better that way
column7: just left hanging out there for people to determine their own interpretation. It's mostly instrumental
column8: alternately brilliant and terrible
column9: sometimes focused
column10: at other times hopelessly rambling. Yow would probably admit as much himself. ""The record is kind of retarded in a lot of ways
column11: he said in a recent podcast by Vish Khanna.

column1: On cursory listens there might not appear to be much that ties this work to Yow's former persona as a drooling
column2: babbling rock beast
column3: but it's pulled from a similar sensibility. He admits to having no formal musical training or even knowing how chords work-- essentially
column4: this is an album that's as psychotic as his live shows with the Jesus Lizard
column5: both of which hinge on the premise that the less you know
column6: the more demented you can get. Part of Yow's success as a vocalist and performer was because there was really no one like him; similarly
column7: this album works best when he's fully committed to making a creation without peer. Its failings come when he edges toward the familiar
column8: at times resembling a dollar store Scott Walker
column9: stuck with MIDI presets in a rotting basement instead of large orchestras in an expansive studio.

column1: For someone who worked so well with concision in his other bands
column2: it's a surprise to find out that Yow works best over great lengths of time in his solo guise. The two 10-minute-plus tracks are the best pieces here
column3: one heading off on a million tangents (""Opening Suite"")
column4: the other closeted in a gradually unfurling drone that resembles a slowed-down air raid siren (""Visualize This""). The rest feels like a mixture of Yow amusing himself
column5: sometimes hitting on a strain of inspiration
column6: but just as often tailing off into inconsequential meanderings when the ideas run dry. At its most playful it feels like an army of ringing alarm clocks pounding on your head (""Uncle"")
column7: or mirrors the kind of pithy spoken word rants Ann Magnuson would undertake in Bongwater (""Senator Robinson's Speech""). Of course
column8: the track that comes closest to beauty
column9: full of dark piano stabs spun through a spooky ambient fog
column10: is called ""Lawrence of a Labia"".

column1: Albums recorded over ample stretches of time often don't hold together well
column2: and Tonight is no exception. Sometimes the sounds are horribly dated-- synth-induced slap bass sounds that border on the ""Seinfeld""-ian
column3: even a hint of Al Jourgensen's industrial emptiness in ""Bleth My Thoul"" (presumably some unspecified private joke Yow is inflicting on his audience). Although one of the strengths of this album is that it's clearly coming straight out of a void
column4: oblivious to anything else around it
column5: there's also a childlike wonder coupled with a decent understanding of the gruesome side of life. Yow's vocal work had that
column6: too. In the times when he wasn't jumping into the audience at Jesus Lizard shows there was something decidedly creepy about him
column7: a feeling of the paunchy uncle with whisky on his breath
column8: cornering you and asking uncomfortable questions. Still
column9: he doesn't quite see it that way. When asked about it on Khanna's podcast
column10:
Yow simply responded: ""Am I scary? I’m just ugly.""

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19427/homepage_large.507d382b.jpg|Celestial Soul Portrait|31452.0|Iasos|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2013-07-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:29.661346|"

When it comes to soothing tones and ethereal zone-outs
column2: ambient and new age music often overlap. They are not the same game
column3: though. If you read the back cover of Brian Eno’s 1975 album
column4: Discreet Music
column5: you’ll find a set of diagrams and instructions meant to explain the processes that the producer/composer/guru employed in creating the music. The record
column6: which is often cited as one of the formative works of the ambient genre
column7: contains a series of slowly evolving compositions that rely on slight variations (measure length
column8: echo
column9: equalization) of simple repeating melodic phrases to create a sense of movement amid static components.

column1: That same year also saw the debut release by the San Francisco
column2: California-based composer Iasos
column3: who would become heavily identified with the then emerging new age genre. Though his compositions are shorter and draw heavy inspiration from spiritual jazz
column4: there are plenty of similarities to Eno’s ambient music
column5: particularly in the gauzy tones and glacial pace. The LP did not come with a score and even if Iasos had wanted to include one
column6: the process might have been tough to explain to an outsider. According to the composer
column7: his music was not written
column8: but communicated to him by a trans-dimensional being called Vista.

column1: The purpose of Discreet Music is to fade into the background
column2: to become aural wallpaper that teeters at the edge of comprehension
column3: hence the title. Iasos’ record
column4: Interdimensional Music
column5: requires direct attention. The sounds are not meant to drift on the edge of perception
column6: but expand consciousness-- to transcend Earthly anxiety and envelop the listener in bliss. Like many new age musicians
column7: Iasos was not shy about embracing hokey imagery-- rainbows
column8: crystals
column9: crystalline rainbows-- to get his point accross
column10: and not every track that he cut can transcend the goofiness of his genre. Celestial Soul Portrait
column11: a new compilation assembled by Numero Group
column12: functions as a highlight reel
column13: grabbing some of the sturdiest swatches from the composer’s 30-year-plus career.

column1: Born in Greece and raised in upstate New York
column2: by the late 1960s Iasos had moved to California to devote himself to music
column3: eventually settling in Marin County
column4: near San Francisco. He tried playing in a number of rock bands but found his peers a little too Earth-bound in their tastes. After purchasing a four-track recorder
column5: he started experimenting with tape effects
column6: treated sounds and
column7: eventually
column8: synthesizers
column9: which helped him hone the celestial sound he had been reaching for. On “Rainbow Canyon”
column10: which was taken from Interdimensional Music
column11: Iasos improvises on a lap steel guitar
column12: using an echo unit to smear his notes across the stereo field. Were you to dry it out from the effects
column13: his riffing might just sound like a series of Eastern-tinged goofs
column14: but the constantly sliding tones and delay trails give the music an unearthly quality-- soothing
column15: but also seasick. “Cloud Prayer” congeals from a series of drones that the guitarist created using guitar feedback and a wah-wah pedal. It’s an ominous piece
column16: building tension with the muted buzz of low tones.

column1: The root of Iasos’ music is in late 1960s composers like Terry Riley
column2: who came from a more formal university background
column3: but who also temporarily embraced the current psychedelic moment
column4: experimenting with drones
column5: tape loops
column6: and the structures of Indian music. The compositions on Celestial Soul Portrait carried those ideas forward
column7: but from a folkier
column8: less academic perspective. Still
column9: the stakes were high for Iasos and his inter-dimensional writing partner. “Imagine creating symphonies by tuning up planets [to] create beautiful chords that echo through the galaxy
column10:
” explains Iasos in the compilation's liner notes. “That’s the game Vista is playing.”

For a band so clearly invested in tales of invasion
column3: war
column4: and conquest
column5: Sweden’s Amon Amarth is a strangely lead-footed target
column6: so listless and uninterested in change that they’d make for an easy capture on a Norse battlefield of old. During the last two decades
column7: they’ve released nine albums of headstrong Viking metal
column8: built almost entirely around tales of shared Scandinavian heritage and tunes that either charged like a massive military’s frontline or sailed skyward like a hard-earned victory chant. The best of those records (by mere example
column9: see with Oden on Our Side and Versus the World) have felt both urgent and addictive
column10: combining death metal heft and modern rock-ready hooks to build and brandish verifiable anthems. Indeed
column11: to see Amon Amarth live is to see almost all of an audience throw hands or horns at once
column12: chanting along to stories of wins in war and glory in the afterlife. They are a sort of turbocharged Cliff’s Notes to The Poetic Edda and The Prose Edda
column13: a modern metal band revivifying ancient history with unwavering conviction.

column1: There’s little reason to suspect
column2: then
column3: that Amon Amarth will soon run out of stories to sing; their potential pool of subjects is
column4: in essence
column5: a culture’s complete heritage
column6: and they’ve got tales of Oden and Loke to share yet. And there’s always the option of fan-fiction
column7: or creating imagined sagas of pugnacity and defeat from the lore itself. Of late
column8: though
column9: Amon Amarth has started to run out of
column10: if not songs
column11: then novel ways to make their stories really stick within those songs. After an incredible streak of righteous albums
column12: 2011’s Surtur Rising sometimes felt overly stiff and deliberate
column13: as if Amon Amarth were trying to bully past the limits of their own Viking brand. But the new Deceiver of the Gods feels formulaic and tired
column14: as if the long-running quintet has now settled into the complacency and comfort of their reputation-- bad news
column15: of course
column16: for warriors who end songs with shouts of “Now we attack! Ride into fate!” At last
column17: Amon Amarth has made a record that is every bit as rote
column18: uninspired and matter-of-fact as a set of Cliff’s Notes. In the past
column19: they’ve sounded strangely uplifting; this time around
column20: they simply sound persistent.

column1: The symptoms start as early as the opening title track
column2: a thrashing sprint that flatlines in the chorus and rebounds a bit in a chant-along bridge but ultimately stumbles into a solo so tepid and predictable that it nearly necessitates skipping right along to the next track
column3: “As Loke Falls”. Amon Amarth at least displays some vivacity there
column4: volleying a riff between drums blasts like a game of pinball. Frontman Johan Hegg sounds convincing here
column5: too
column6: delivering the tale of Ragnarök’s end less like a storyteller than a witness. In fact
column7: Hegg is compelling throughout most of Deceiver of the Gods
column8: and he’s got good material to offer. His account of a brutal murder technique called Blood Eagle makes for fine pulp fiction
column9: while “Shape Shifter” uses the life of the god Loke to discuss betrayal and a necessary balance of light and dark. In fact
column10: reading Deceiver of the Gods is arguably more engaging than listening to most of it. The band behind Hegg seems exhausted or
column11: at the very least
column12: over it. They push ahead with the same up-tempo roil so much that any break at all-- be they the sampled sounds of murder at the start of the gruesome “Blood Eagle” or the psychedelic guitar spirals that introduce closer “Warriors of the North”-- are welcome
column13: overdue diversions. Candlemass’ Messiah Marcolin guests on “Hel”
column14: but Amon Amarth is so unyielding that the best they can do is let him moan in the background like Marianne Faithful.

column1: It’s not that anyone’s now hoping for Amon Amarth to be metal’s great hybridizers or innovators. Nine albums into a career
column2: no-one expects them to suddenly lace their battle hymns with electronics or noise or to write brilliant black metal bursts or dramatic post-rock crescendos into their records. But Amon Amarth boasts a lot of their own skill
column3: bravery and brilliance within their songs; they are a small army of “endless wrath” and “the walker on the wind” and “fast in thought
column4: quicker tongue.” Here
column5: though
column6: those are only hollow words
column7: self-righteousness from a band bloated on their own lofty reputation and sales history. On Deceiver of the Gods
column8: they are satisfied with plugging 10 new anecdotes into 10 songs they’ve made before and
column9: unfortunately
column10:
will most likely make again.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19476/homepage_large.b8e7cec4.jpg|Nocturnes|302.0|William Basinski|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['2062']|2013-07-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:30.648068|"

Definitive work can cast a long shadow. It's to William Basinski's credit that he hasn't let the weight of his most lauded piece
column2: The Disintegration Loops
column3: overwhelm him. He still appears proud of that album
column4: releasing an expanded box-set edition last year
column5: bolstering its reputation instead of shirking from it. It's essentially become a living
column6: breathing thing. Letting The Disintegration Loops take a back seat never felt like much of an option for Basinski anyway. A large part of that album's narrative was spun out of his real-world struggles with his art
column7: triggered by the financial woes he was undergoing prior to its release. The rush of people toward it must have provoked a strong sense of freedom and validation-- not easy emotions to forget
column8: and ones that were presumably not taken for granted by someone in Basinski's circumstance.

column1: His return to The Disintegration Loops also tied into Basinski's ever evolving relationship with his own past
column2: as witnessed by the frequent reworkings of his older material. Nocturnes is his first new solo recording in four years
column3: but the 40-minute-long title track is a return to a tape and prepared piano piece recorded in his San Francisco period circa 1979-80. The second of the two tracks dates back to 2009
column4: parts of which featured in Robert Wilson's opera
column5: The Life and Death of Marina Abramović. Things don't get left behind in Basinski's world
column6: they carry on mutating as the years pass
column7: provoking questions about where things begin and end. ""I have a weird way of living in time
column8: he said in an Update interview in 2012. ""I just try to stay in the eternal present.""

column1: Both Nocturnes tracks are wrinkle-free. Immaculate
column2: even. There's nothing that suggests an era in which they might have been recorded. No trace of a dusty old reel-to-reel tape machine
column3: no dated recording techniques. Basinski's relationship to time is key
column4: especially on ""Nocturnes""
column5: where it's easy to lose track of how long its slow-moving loops have been gently rotating around one another. Somehow
column6: Basinski has mastered how to keep material like this interesting
column7: slowly fading in changes
column8: just doing enough to make it immersive. This isn't exactly the ""eternal present"" he refers to-- instead
column9: it feels more like an attempt to manipulate time
column10: to see how malleable its boundaries can be. Seconds pass like weeks
column11: minutes turn into seconds. Often it's hard to tell whether you're at the end or in the middle. Ultimately
column12: those distinctions don't really matter.

column1: The only part of the overall work that takes you out of the moment is in the transition from one track to the other. Initially
column2: the switch is jarring
column3: resembling an alarm clock sounding at a particular inopportune moment in a dream. ""Nocturnes"" is all muddy
column4: languid movement; ""The Trail of Tears"" has a coarser
column5: more agile feel. The latter is a lesser work
column6: making an awkward fit in an album that may have benefitted from containing just one track. ""Nocturnes"" siphons its beauty from the slow-release journey that Basinski instills in it. By contrast
column7: ""The Trail of Tears"" starts by resembling a paint-cracked old rocking chair creaking into infinity
column8: only to drift into a wash of ambient mush. It tilts toward total escapism
column9: taking on a dream-like state. But Basinski's best work isn’t positioned there; he's better when fusing the otherworldly with the real. On ""Nocturnes""
column10: abstract thoughts become one with the music
column11:
forming a place so tangible you can almost reach out and touch it.

If you really want to get where Mayer Hawthorne's coming from
column2: it's not enough to just check out his first two studio albums
column3: A Strange Arrangement and How Do You Do. Those records got retro-soul revivalist tags stapled on to them
column4: thanks to a hip-hop fiend's sense of vintage soul that drew heavily off Stax/Motown goodwill vibes. But the real scope of his musical influences jump out on the 2011 covers EP
column5: Impressions
column6: where his classic R&B leanings ran the gamut from the well-loved Isleys to the obscure Festivals. He also made a point of taking on some of his blue-eyed soul contemporaries-- artists like Chromeo and Jon Brion
column7: who work adjacent to R&B and funk without necessarily binding themselves to it. If integrating those attributes meant Hawthorne took on multiple pop lineages at once in order to establish a unique identity of his own
column8: it's served him well so far.

column1: As he keeps moving forward and adds on new dimensions to his repertoire
column2: Hawthorne's new album
column3: Where Does This Door Go
column4: gives him a lot of self-imposed leeway. Here he cedes his usual production duties to an all-star cast. There's Cee-Lo collaborator and Plantlife funkateer Jack Splash
column5: Oak of pop-rap/R&B production superteam Pop & Oak
column6: producer-to-the-stars Greg Wells and-- most prominent of all-- Pharrell Williams
column7: who shares Hawthorne's eccentric depth and enthusiasm for modernized
column8: chronology-twisting sounds. That Hawthorne's wrangled this crew into a consistently engaged sound is to his credit
column9: where his impact is tangible enough that the committee effect takes a backseat.

column1: Hawthorne deliberately shaking his throwback rep is probably the best thing you could expect from Where Does This Door Go: the songs sound clean and of the now
column2: aided by people who successfully mine the last couple generations' best pop ideas. That this music sounds sly without actually feeling like a joke is impressive-- there's too much practiced musicianship in songs like the breezy quiet storm-via-Private Eyes “Backseat Lover” or the N.E.R.D.-does-Aja bounce of “Reach Out Richard"". This wouldn't be the first review comparing Hawthorne's sensibility to '77 Steely Dan or '81 Hall & Oates
column3: but those admittedly fitting touchstones mean that even through production proxies
column4: he's springboarding off of artists who were already looking at the horizon and the rearview at the same time. Retro isn't the same thing as timeless
column5: and this album trades up in taking that second route.

column1: It helps that Hawthorne's improved noticeably as a singer. Once a tolerably flat if charismatic vocalist
column2: he's expanded his range and his confidence. His falsetto's finally started to resonate as charmingly vulnerable instead of just withdrawn
column3: he's gotten better at sounding eccentric without forcing it (dig the way he casually rolls off the oddball pronunciation of “Chris-ti-an-Di-or” on “Wine Glass Woman”)
column4: and his penchant for interjecting f-bombs in otherwise sweetly sung lyrics comes across more frankly sincere than gratuitously snotty. Those lyrics are more straightforward than ever: Like a lot of the music he's called back to over the years
column5: it's stuff that lives and dies on its delivery. He can fit in some neat turns of phrase; “She walks into a room and all the lights flicker violently” is a vivid way to start “The Innocent”. But just as many songs attempt to build a lot out of a little
column6: like the yearbook-quote simplicity of teenage weekend bender anthem “The Stars Are Ours” (“Well we're breakin' all the rules/ 'cause they're getting in the way/ And we'll never be as young as we are today”) or the bad-sex-as-tired-machinery conceit of “Robot Love"". Still
column7: it never gets cringingly obvious enough to feel like the performance can't redeem the ordinary-at-worst lyrics.

column1: Where Does This Door Go is a record that's equally focused on delivering mildly self-effacing party jams and empathetic moments of connection. Women are both predatory seductresses to be avoided (“The Innocent”) and sympathetic done-wrong figures to identify with (the Jessie Ware-featuring “Her Favorite Song”). Moments of post-hedonistic defensiveness (“Crime
column2: ” which Kendrick Lamar reliably owns) are followed by an apologetic yet reassuring monologue to his father (“Reach Out Richard”). Inconsistency or complexity? Depends on how much you believe in this music as sincere self-expression versus its status as smartly crafted
column3: artist-as-listener-proxy pop. Three albums in to a late-blooming career
column4: it's getting easier and easier to picture Hawthorne
column5: a DJ-turned-singer and fan-turned-musician
column6:
pulling off both.

"|18257.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18257-mayer-hawthorne-where-does-this-door-go/|7.1|Nate Patrin

Los Angeles singer and producer Ty Dolla $ign scored a left-field local hit last year with “My Cabana”
column2: a lightweight ode to women-- and the drugs they love-- that goofily pondered how many he could fit into his titular cabana. “My Cabana” and the accompanying mixtape Beach House made up for what they lacked in lyrical depth with dense
column3: immersive production
column4: which slowed EDM’s chunky synths and drops and the sinewy
column5: hyperactive sonics of L.A.’s ratchet music scene down to screw music’s promethazine crawl
column6: and that voice: a syrupy tenor that can contract into taut staccato sing-rap or spread out into drippy vocal runs at a moment’s notice. Ty Dolla $ign’s talents recently landed him a deal with Atlantic Records via Wiz Khalifa’s Taylor Gang imprint
column7: and he celebrated the occasion this month with the release of Beach House 2. The sequel follows on the lead of the original
column8: but where Beach House presented a summation of the artist’s varying talents
column9: Beach House 2 feels like a dry run for the majors
column10: weighted down by a glut of largely ineffectual guest raps
column11: songs recycled from other artists’ mixtapes and remixes of songs that didn’t really need fixing.

column1: Dolla $ign’s arrangements are lush and intriguing on songs like “I Bet”
column2: which matches oceanic synths to subterranean bass in the verses before a wash of keys overtake the mix at every chorus. All of the outside producers he calls on follow his lead by striking a precarious balance between house music and Southern hip-hop
column3: mostly to dazzling results. But his impish lyricism wages a continual warfare with the sweetness of the music
column4: and it occasionally makes for rough listening. You can snicker at darts like “I took his main bitch away like King Koopa” on “Creez”
column5: but you have to sneak past a minefield of “These hoes be playing games for nothing” and “These bitches ain’t shit” to get there. It gets ugly on “Bitches Ain’t Shit”
column6: where Ty$ graces a spectral
column7: druggy production with a yarn about stealing a guy’s girlfriend containing a bridge where he tells the girl “Your nigga laid up in the hospital
column8: and you still think of me/ Man
column9: I swear to God I’d kill your fucking ass if you did that shit to me”. It illuminates the extent to which the mawkish depravity of Ty’s songs feels like an end in itself. R&B knows no shortage of dirtbag auteurs
column10: but where R. Kelly bedded paramours with searching lines like “It seems like you’re ready”
column11: and the Weeknd’s creep tendencies are points of consternation for him
column12: Ty Dolla $ign treats these situations like bloodless coups
column13: full of boyfriends ripe for the beating and women who are play things rather than companions
column14: whose fealty & attraction to him are a foregone conclusion.

column1: Beach House 2’s problems with writing aren’t confined to Ty$; its guests spots are a mixed bag. The contributions from Dolla $ign’s Cali rap cohorts rank among the best. Heart Break Gang’s Iamsu! turns in a capable performance on “Float” (off his own Kilt II)
column2: and YG and DJ Mustard inject much-needed levity into “Dolla $ign”
column3: which cleverly flips the “All I see is dollar signs” from Rihanna’s “Pour It Up”. Joe Moses
column4: co-star of Ty’s 2012 mixtape Whoop!
column5: delivers the mixtape’s best verse on “Paranoid” (off DJ Mustard’s underrated Ketchup tape). By and large
column6: though
column7: the tracklist here is a rogue’s gallery of Atlantic Records signees
column8: and many of them seem to appear out of label affiliation rather than genuine chemistry. Juicy J’s creepy uncle act meshes perfectly with “Ratchet in My Benz”
column9: and Kevin Gates shines on “These Hoes” when you can hear him over the beat. But Wiz Khalifa and Drake mimic Kirko Bangz faceplant on two separate songs apiece
column10: and Taylor Gang associate Chevy Woods is sluggish and forgettable on “Bitches Ain’t Shit”. Ty snagging Jeezy for the massive “My Cabana” remix only to have him flop by singing his verse is emblematic of Beach House 2’s frustrating misuse of star power.

column1: Beach House 2 is peppered with skeezy dirtbag narratives and cringeworthy guest raps that bring it down
column2: but Ty Dolla $ign’s melodies and production are almost strong enough to wash them out of earshot. If you’re not picking over this thing for lyrics you might not catch some of this stuff for all the interlocking hooks and deft vocal runs
column3: and there isn’t anything here more shocking than the offbeat sexual politics of Yeezus. What’s most off-putting about Beach House 2 is how ill-suited the dead-eyed resignation of Ty Dolla $ign’s approach is to the warmth of his voice. “I got another nigga bitch in my bed right now/ She got her legs all up in the air... right now”. Yawn. “These hoes ain’t shit
column4: but I’ma fuck this bitch”. Stretch. Beach House 2 is gratingly drunk on its own bedroom swashbuckling
column5: like an hour-long teenage locker room sex story set to painstakingly pretty music. <span>Given the opportunity to tell a fascinating story
column6:
he instead opts to fixate on how cunning and virile he is to have gotten there in the first place. There’s satisfaction in the telling but not as much in the listening.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19459/homepage_large.ea4d8ff9.jpg|About Farewell|6327.0|Alela Diane|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rusted Blue']|2013-07-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:33.898096|"

The “stripped-down break-up record” is one of the most well-worn tropes in singer-songwriterdom. But on About Farewell
column2: her fourth record
column3: Alela Diane comes by her romantic devastation honestly. The Portland-based folkie was last heard on 2011’s excellent Alela Diane & Wild Divine
column4: where she was backed by a crack band equally conversant in soul
column5: country
column6: and 1970s SoCal soft-rock. Diane’s musical co-pilot was guitarist Tom Bevitori
column7: also her husband at the time. Sadly
column8: the marriage ended between Alela Diane & Wild Divine and About Farewell
column9: prompting a return to the stark guitar-and-voice arrangements of Diane’s early work on a collection of songs that ache with the specificity of poetic reportage on the last flickers of a doomed relationship.

column1: About Farewell is a backward-looking record for Diane
column2: musically and lyrically
column3: but it’s also a reboot of sorts. Superficially it resembles her stunning 2004 debut
column4: The Pirate’s Gospel
column5: except it sounds more grown-up. The understated sumptuousness of Alela Diane & Wild Divine is mostly gone (and keenly missed)
column6: though Diane finds way to work that record’s expansiveness into the cozier confines of About Farewell. On the foreboding “The Way We Fall”
column7: which sketches an evocative setting-- it’s Indian summer
column8: there are wildfires burning
column9: and a whiskey bottle is being passed around-- that feels like a bittersweet memory
column10: muted horns and a muffled drum track soften the barbed-wire tentacles of Diane’s skeletal guitar and ghostly backing vocals. On “Nothing I Can Do”
column11: the frustration expressed so beautifully in the chorus (“Honey there is nothing I can do/ to save you from yourself”) turns playful with the introduction of gently pirouetting piano ringlets.

column1: The star of the show
column2: as always on Alela Diane records
column3: is Diane’s voice. Nimble and graceful like a jazz singer
column4: sad and knowing like a blues crooner
column5: but always restrained like a bedroom-pop auteur speaking softly into a four-track
column6: Diane delivers her detached observations on the end of her marriage with stinging intimacy. “Before the Leaving” is a melancholic travelogue from the perspective of two traveling musicians who are slowly drifting apart. “Side by side we pass through towns/ that we’ll never see/ and it’s here I will wait out the storm
column7: ” she sings
column8: drawing out that last part a few extra painful beats. The album’s saddest track-- the competition on About Farewell  is fierce for the distinction-- is “Hazel Street”
column9: where Diane suggests that the coupling was troubled from the beginning. (“I woke up drunk on that basement floor/and then you asked how I would read the score/ If you asked me to marry you.”) Diane is similarly fatalistic on the lilting “I Thought I Knew”
column10: when she sighs
column11: “I’d only just arrived/ when I foresaw the end.”

column1: A record seemingly composed over the course of many sleepless nights and hungover mornings
column2: About Farewell is yet another addition to the canon of brokenhearted sadsack singer-songwriter records. Surely there will be another artist attempting to make their own Blood on the Tracks or Blue very soon. Alela Diane hasn’t upended the form
column3: but that probably wasn’t her intent. What she needed was a port in a storm
column4:
and About Farewell is a very sturdy bulwark.

"|18265.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18265-alela-diane-about-farewell/|7.3|Steven Hyden

The Austin/Houston hardcore band Hatred Surge started out in 2004 as a powerviolence quartet built around the male/female vocal dynamic of Alex Hughes
column2: who also plays bass
column3: and lead vocalist Faiza Kracheni
column4: currently of Mindless. Under this lineup
column5: they released a series of splits and one full-length
column6: 2009's Deconstruct. They've since abandoned the dualing genders angle; Kracheni was replaced by Rahi Geramifar
column7: currently of Houston's War Master and formerly of grindcore insurgents Insect Warfare. Geramifar also guested on Deconstruct
column8: credited as “Gargling Urine”; his guttural vocals live to that moniker in his other bands
column9: but they were somewhat redundant placed alongside Hughes.

column1: Now
column2: almost a decade after forming
column3: Hatred Surge are a trio
column4: rounded out by long-standing members Chris Ulsh (also of Power Trip
column5: Mammoth Grinder
column6: and the Impalers) on guitar and drummer Mike Sharp (who's played in the Impalers as well
column7: in addition to Sungod and a former stint in Trap Them)
column8: with Hughes taking over all vocal duties. Human Overdose
column9: released during the recent Chaos in Tejas festival in Austin
column10: is their first record as a three-piece
column11: and it's their burliest
column12: most focused yet.

column1: Ulsh's guitar work in Mammoth Grinder
column2: which combines death metal
column3: Discharge
column4: and the “power groove” sound pioneered by Pantera
column5: creep into Overdose
column6: especially in the longer songs. Those seeds were sown when the Hatred Surge did a split with Mammoth Grinder-- Hughes and Ulsh essentially doing a split with themselves-- in 2011
column7: and now they've sprouted fatally poisonous berries. Nowhere is this more apparent than in “Psychonaut”
column8: which could easily be a Mammoth Grinder song if it weren't for Hughes' deep growl. A galloping intro breaks way into a Swedeath catharsis. The intro riff on “God Complex” brings to mind a more fluid
column9: less mechanical Prong
column10: and “Delta Nine” jerky swings are among the most “power groovy” riffs on the record. In fact
column11: the swifter songs on this album are like Pantera's “Slaughtered” raised on punk
column12: right down to the lyrics
column13: exploring the link between social corruption and the breakdown of one's inner will.

column1: Travis Bonner's production lends Overdose a stronger death metal feel than their previous work
column2: emphasizing downtuned crunch and smearing it just enough without turning the album into incoherent “bestial” beige. With the album's focus on concise
column3: concentrated explosions
column4: the ambient intro “Figurehead” feels like a blockade (not endless
column5: thankfully) to the emotional release of “Psychonaut”. Those electronics appear again at the very end of the title track
column6: also the record's closing number
column7: in a shorter
column8: more fitting fashion. Overdose's consistent quality renders this less of a gaping flesh wound and more of an annoying scab
column9: really.

column1: Hatred Surge could be the spiritual successor of Iron Age
column2: another Austin band Hughes took part in. Iron Age started as another hardcore band with some metal influences
column3: but by 2009's <i>The Sleeping Eye
column4: they morphed into a beast with crossover's ferocity and Manilla Road's sense of grandeur. It's useless to ask “what could have been
column5: ” especially in a genre with vocal contingents of fans who inquire about Cliff Burton and Lars Ulrich switching spots on the bus
column6: but Iron Age were definitely onto something a lot of their revivalist peers were not
column7: save for Power Trip. Hatred Surge
column8: likewise
column9: by incorporating more metal into their sound
column10:
have both matured and grown even heavier than before.
