column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19450/homepage_large.a953e43d.jpg|Andy and His Grandmother|31474.0|Andy Kaufman|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City'
column3: Andy Kaufman-- and his act-- changed. In '77
column4: the comedian (or
column5: as he preferred
column6: ""song-and-dance man"") was 28 years old
column7: and his bits were marked by wide-eyed innocence. At that point
column8: it often seemed like his characters were pre-pubescent or eerily unaware of the adult world; in fact
column9: much of his material at the time was culled from previous stints entertaining childrens' birthday parties as a teenager or hosting a kids' show
column10: ""Uncle Andy's Funhouse
column11: in college. For Kaufman
column12: retaining this child-like perspective was essential-- he even took up Transcendental Meditation in an attempt to hold onto this aura as he entered his twenties-- and it helped to inspire a similar feeling in his audience
column13: to make them think back to a time before bills and heartbreak and death. A TV special he taped in the summer of 1977 epitomized this era as it featured his hopelessly naive Foreign Man character
column14: a sincere interview with Kaufman's childhood idol Howdy Doody
column15: and a step-by-step tutorial on how to make chocolate milk. The showcase ended with a sing-along to a song called ""This Friendly World"".

column1: Due to its unabashedly offbeat nature (is he kidding? is he serious? what is he?) that special was shelved and would not air until two years later
column2: after Kaufman had gained more fame with his role on ""Taxi"". But by then
column3: in the summer of '79
column4: the performer had
column5: as one TV critic put it
column6: ""turned."" He had started wrestling women onstage because he loved wrestling and its ridiculous theater. He also found the activity quite arousing and
column7: according to Bill Zehme's definitive biography Lost in the Funhouse
column8: it was a good way for Kaufman to break the ice with girls he wanted to have sex with after the show. Not very innocent. He also invented a new character
column9: Tony Clifton
column10: who was the exact opposite of his lovable Foreign Man-- a Vegas-style lout in a bad toupee
column11: tumbling gut
column12: and hideous moustache. Clifton was pure id
column13: a reaction against Kaufman's kid-friendly former self. Looking back
column14: that period between '77 and '79 was especially pivotal for Kaufman-- it's also the timeframe when he taped 82 hours of audio from his everyday life onto his newly purchased microcassette recorder. A keenly edited version of those tapes make up the 48 minutes of Andy and His Grandmother
column15: a comedy album that is
column16: fittingly
column17: unlike any other.

column1: The inspiration behind Kaufman's home recordings may be a man that his confidant and co-conspirator Bob Zmuda calls Mr. X (due to fear of retribution) in his book Andy Kaufman Revealed!. Zmuda worked for this apparently psychotic Hollywood screenwriter who would get himself into dangerous or outlandish real-life situations-- like insulting a mob boss' mother at her birthday dinner-- record them on audiotape
column2: and then use those recordings as catalysts for his writing. Such mixing of fact and fiction was catnip for Kaufman
column3: whose life often seemed like a series of pranks and put-ons. So Andy and His Grandmother-- compiled by veteran comedy writer/producer Vernon Chatman (""Louie""
column4: ""South Park""
column5: ""The Chris Rock Show"") and documentarian Rodney Ascher (the Shining-obsessed Room 237)-- isn't merely a recording of Kaufman's stand-up performances
column6: but rather recordings of real-life conversations that would plant creative seeds in his eccentric mind. Considering that many of the record's most memorable moments document wildly heated phone calls
column7: it can seem like Andy and His Grandmother is more similar to a Jerky Boys album than comedy classics by Steve Martin or Bill Cosby.

column1: Because
column2: by-and-large
column3: this is a record of provocation. It's also probably one of the most clear-eyed accounts of the ""real"" Andy Kaufman in existence
column4: a serious feat considering his notoriously slippery relationship with what most of us call reality. The candidness here can be startling
column5: even by 2013 standards. A track called ""Slice of Life"" has Kaufman talking to one of the many women he bedded while on tour in the late 70s. ""We just screwed and here's the afterward conversation
column6: he announces
column7: before continuing: ""It didn't look to me like you were enjoying it that much."" But this isn't laugh-out-loud funny. It's unflinching. He asks her
column8: ""What happens if you got a baby?"" to which the unnamed woman responds
column9: ""I'll hop a plane to Toronto and get a little abortion."" Naturally
column10: she asks for him to turn off the tape (there's an entire track here devoted to the voices of people requesting-- often in an incensed tone-- for Kaufman to ""shut that off"") but he's adamant: ""Why is it that nobody understands that the kind of conversations that nobody wants me to tape are the kind of conversations that should be taped?"" It's the sort of philosophy that runs through the work of many great comedians
column11: from Woody Allen to Louis C.K.
column12: laid perfectly bare
column13: without the filter of a camera lens
column14: script
column15: or stand-up routine.

column1: Later on
column2: a series of phone calls show up in which Kaufman diabolically riles up a woman who doesn't appreciate her feelings being used as some sort of meta comedy exercise. ""You are fucked up!"" she screams. ""I WANT THOSE FUCKING TAPES!"" The call is followed by Zmuda and Kaufman plotting how they could release the contentious conversations with this one tremendously angry woman as an album. ""The concept would be funny because it's real
column3: but it would be dramatic at the same time
column4: Kaufman says
column5: before excitedly suggesting to Zmuda
column6: ""Wouldn't it be great if she killed me and you have the tapes?"" It's uncomfortable comedy
column7: the kind that Kaufman would perfect with Tony Clifton and his inter-gender wrestling career. And these talks with various women accentuate the more problematic sides of his personality
column8: the parts that were addicted to prostitutes and womanizing. ""He hated that he needed to be with women
column9: says friend Wendy Polland in Lost in the Funhouse
column10: ""because he didn't like the mind games they played with him. Which I guess was sort of ironic
column11: wasn't it?"" Andy and His Grandmother shows him fighting back against these women
column12: and it can sound as compelling as a car crash.

column1: But it's not all unusually cringe-worthy. There are moments when Kaufman's more lighthearted
column2: '77-era persona shows up
column3: like when he takes his grandmother out for a car ride and tries to convince her that a radar is guiding the vehicle (though that track cannily jump-cuts to a confrontation with a traffic cop who threatens to ""knock the shit"" out of a belligerent Kaufman). And all that phone yelling toward the end of the album is foreshadowed by another phone bit
column4: ""Andy Can Talk to Animals""
column5: where Kaufman gets into a shouting match with what sounds like a squealing pig: ""Yeah
column6: whaddya want? Say it fast."" [pig squeal] ""I had to change my fucking clothes so I can go out and have a good time and you just made me miss my appointment
column7: so fuck you!"" It's funnier than the real arguments-- likely due to the absurdity and lack of actual consequence-- but as Kaufman progressed through the late 70s
column8: coaxing laughs from his audience became less and less of an imperative.

column1: At one point during the album
column2: a wronged woman lashes out at Kaufman in a particularly discombobulated-- but not inaccurate-- manner: ""You think that I really don't know when you goof on me
column3: and you think that I really don't know
column4: and really I know
column5: and you know that I really know
column6: but you say I don't know."" These are the mental hoops this one-of-a-kind performance artist would force people to go through on a regular basis
column7: whether onstage or in front of his tiny personal recorder. It's why he still resonates and fascinates in our world of meta-this and post-that
column8: why anyone would care about a collection of cobbled together personal recordings from an enigma who's been dead for nearly three decades. Based on <i>Andy and His Grandmother
column9: Kaufman comes off like an asshole
column10: a hopelessly naive loser
column11: a crazy person
column12: a hothead
column13: a hopelessly sweet grandma's boy
column14: a sexually confused teenager
column15: and a manipulative monster. In other words
column16:
he comes off like Andy Kaufman.

Though Detroit's Slum Village has suffered many hardships
column2: their music
column3: for the most part
column4: has been consistent: 2002’s <i>Trinity: Past
column5: Present and Future had a few positively soupy J Dilla productions as strong as anything he did for the previous material
column6: while 2004’s Detroit Deli had star power
column7: including a contribution from Kanye West. But fast-forward to 2013 and things look almost entirely different: Baatin and Dilla having passed on in the past half-decade
column8: the core unit carrying on the legacy is T3 (the only founding member remaining)
column9: Illa J
column10: and Young RJ.

column1: With just a single original member
column2: it seems wrong call this project Slum Village. Young RJ handled all the production here but none of his beats bring to mind this outfit’s classic material
column3: though a few channel imitation-worthy rap songs from years past: “Scared Money” is heavily percussive like Clipse’s “Grindin’”
column4: “Summer Breeze” is like a modest take on Nas’ “Summer on Smash”
column5: and “The Line” channels Big Boi’s booming bro-down “Follow Us”. But when RJ tries to do something new and inventive behind the boards
column6: he doesn't follow through and winds up with something like the minute-long scratch solo that closes “Rock Rock”. Still
column7: RJ produced most of Villa Manifesto
column8: a solid outing for Slum Village in every respect
column9: so it’s unclear why these beats fall so flat compared to the ones he was making just a few years ago.

column1: The current Slum Village lineup has a lot of Black Star in it. That’s not to say SV are trying to define the underground-rap of today like Mos Def and Talib Kweli did 15 years ago
column2: but the lineage can be heard in these MCs’ interplay
column3: which is one of the few things that they do well together. Unfortunately
column4: with the absence of former Villager Elzhi
column5: who with his 2011 Illmatic tribute proved himself to be the most talented writer ever to hold a full-time position in this group
column6: Slum Village has little to say lyrically. They most often rap about rapping
column7: but when they switch things up
column8: as on the testosterone-infused “Summer Breeze”
column9: the results can be disastrous: “Chest 36C
column10: hips 42/ Can’t blame me for the freaky things I’ll do to you/ Your body’s my Viagara.”

column1: At least that line is delivered with some excitement. Too much else feels like coasting. There’s an unfortunately telling declaration on track eight
column2: “Hustle”: “We don’t talk much
column3: we let our history define us.” Such a policy of terseness was the basis of at least one hit rap song in 2012; here
column4: it’s ironic given that these three
column5: as a unit
column6:
still have plenty to prove.

Though it was released less than two years ago
column3: Gauntlet Hair’s self-debut album already feels like a time capsule. It’s a snapshot of a moment when seemingly every emergent indie act was trying to elbow their way into Animal Collective's campfire circle by reverbing their voices into oblivion
column4: duct-taping their guitar pedals down to achieve infinite delay
column5: and locking their rhythms into an epileptic stutter. But as prevalent as that messthetic was
column6: it’s one that has served as a springboard into myriad directions: Doldrums’ recent Lesser Evil pumped it up to super-club size; Braids’ upcoming Flourish // Perish chisels it into minimalist electro-prog. Gauntet Hair sees another
column7: possibly more lucrative way forward. Their sophomore effort
column8: Stills
column9: feels less inspired by AnCo's Merriweather Post Pavilion than the actual Merriweather Post Pavilion: By amplifying the darker undercurrents of their sound and switching on the strobe lights
column10: the Denver-via-Chicago duo sound eager to follow in the footsteps of those 80s goth acts that streamlined their sound and graduated to the summer-amphitheater circuit.

column1: Gauntlet Hair’s sound was always big
column2: it’s just that Andy Rauworth and Craig Nice’s vocals were the smallest things within it
column3: as the duo were content to treat their melodies as ephemeral layers in the miasmic monsoon. Stills immediately issues a corrective: the instantly inviting opener “Human Nature” is a dream retro-dance-night mash-up of INXS’ “The Devil Inside” and the Jesus and Mary Chain’s “Head On”
column4: building up a minimal bass pulse into a heart-racing
column5: clap-clattered rush-- a gradual
column6: ecstatic ascent that mirrors the stirring desire Rauworth openly expresses within. (When he repeats
column7: ad infinitum
column8: “They tell me I make you smile/ one time a week
column9: ” it’s with the cool confidence of a guy who presumes that
column10: even with an 86% strike-out rate
column11: he’s still got a crack at the courtship.)

column1: If Gauntlet Hair’s debut sounded like it was recorded at the bottom of a well
column2: “Human Nature” is the geyser that shoots Still above-ground into the great wide open. And
column3: more often than not
column4: Gauntlet Hair successfully answer the challenge of pushing themselves to both more populist and aggressive extremes: “Heave” and “Waste Your Art” are batcave-rockin’ fist-pumpers packed with massive
column5: larynx-shredding choruses that imagine Kurt Cobain dressed up in PVC; “Falling Out” is a robo-rockabilly rave-up that feels like a 21st-century answer to Love & Rockets’ “Yin and Yang The Flowerpot Man.” The duo excel at moodier
column6: downtempo material
column7: too: the insidious “Bad Apple” is a smooth mid-80s MOR ballad by way of Wax Trax
column8: and the dubbed-out “G.I.D.” boasts the album’s most sublime sonic flourish
column9: when the song’s elating chorus hook is reprised as a mutant
column10: slowed-down synth line that sounds like a symphony melting into the floor.

column1: It's too bad the duo can’t sustain that sort of boldness over Stills’ entirety
column2: even with a total runtime of just 31 minutes. This is ultimately a transitory record
column3: its gate-crashing momentum tempered by songs that feel like holdovers from Gauntlet Hair’s more whimsical debut. With Stills’ crisper production cleaning up the band’s formative psych-pop splatter
column4: the album’s more sanguine tracks
column5: like the bass-slapping tropical-funk of “Simple” and Panda Bear-hugging “New To It”
column6: come off as plodding and nondescript; what at first seems like an audacious
column7:
game-changing record for the band ends up feeling patchy and indecisive. Stills’ most bracing moments show that Rauworth and Nice have their eyes on the prize-- and the stadium back rows-- but their grand visions occassionally get obscured here by navel-gazing regressions. They’ve laid down the gauntlet; they just have to keep trimming the hair.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19486/homepage_large.e0328cbc.jpg|Unreal|31308.0|Hebronix|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATP']|2013-07-17 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:36.657336|"

When Daniel Blumberg yelped “I can’t get away!” on Yuck’s self-titled album
column2: it felt like a prime example of their period-specific craftsmanship: the buzzy
column3: hooky guitars and explosive alt-rock dynamics signify a sort of overwhelming
column4: ill-defined angst and here was a perfect
column5: all-purpose phrase giving it a voice. Now that Yuck is carrying on without its primary frontman
column6: the vagueness of that lyric allows us to reverse engineer Blumberg’s personal life into it. First there was Cajun Dance Party
column7: then there was Yuck
column8: then there was Oupa
column9: and now here’s Hebronix-- in the past five years
column10: Blumberg's released widely available records with four different
column11: awkwardly named bands. That takes a lot of commitment and an utter lack of it as well. But while the rambling and roomy songs on Unreal offer Blumberg all the space he wants
column12: it often turns out to be far more than he needs.

column1: In addition to the opening track on Yuck
column2: Unreal recasts that album’s closer
column3: “Rubber”
column4: in a new light; a seven-minute slowcore dirge
column5: “Rubber” smoldered with the speed and intensity of a tire fire. It was an outlier on Yuck and a template here. There are six songs on Unreal and “Rubber” would be the fifth-longest. The initial problem is how this framework can make Blumberg sound more stubborn than ambitious. Opener “Unliving” has some intriguing passages: it begins as a downer solo performance that immediately posits Unreal as a confessional
column6: eventually evolving into a slowly levitating chorus of “ahs.” But they’re splayed about haphazardly and separated by extended subdivisions of laggard drumming and aimless guitar interplay-- it feels like Blumberg started with the goal of making a daunting
column7: 10-minute opener and just worked towards that end. This quality is also shared by its uncompromising and uneventful bookend
column8: “The Plan” which personifies the insularity of its hook (“I’ve got some things to do/ Some private things to do”). In addition to the title of that track
column9: Blumberg’s tastes in frazzled
column10: fuzz-flecked guitar tones will allow comparisons to Built to Spill
column11: another band that’s never shied away from Crazy Horse soloing and marathon track lengths. But where even Doug Martsch’s most labyrinthine studio constructions have a plan
column12: Hebronix can sound fueled by the belief that an eight minute song necessarily grants you twice the ragged glory of one that’s four minutes.

column1: As with most indie artists in the lineage of Neil Young
column2: Blumberg’s proclivity for jangly acoustic/electric jamming can ultimately reveal itself as charming rather than curmudgeonly. Unreal hits a stride during its midsection where “Wild Whim” and the title track strike the right balance of being unforced but not too effortless. They’re every bit as shambling as “Unliving” or “The Plan”
column3: but aren’t meant to convey the idea of Blumberg as a “challenging” artist. “Wild Whim” details a “wild day of sin” but also a solitary one (“There you are on top of him/ Creating situations I’ve never been in”) over an endlessly repeating chord progression
column4: while “Unreal” simply intones “I feel unreal” over and over again until this insouciant state becomes some kind of a stoned reality
column5: a day without clocks where you wake up and just keep going until you shut down. Unreal is a pretty explicit hangover/breakup record
column6: yet “Wild Whim” in particular feels like it’s mining the positive side of those situations
column7: a freedom you get from a sudden a lack of obligation
column8: where you counter the hardships of the previous day by taking back the power and wasting the current one.

column1: It’s easy to draw that conclusion based on the fissuring of Yuck as well as the ramshackle production of Royal Trux’s Neil Hagerty. A benefit of working with Hagerty is that you appear a little seedier by association and Unreal does come off as decidedly less wholesome than any of Blumberg’s previous work. There was a sweetness and naivety to the heartbreak detailed on Yuck’s “Shook Down” and “Sunday”
column2: whereas here
column3: “Viral” and “Wild Whim” both underline his loneliness with lyrics that make big assumptions about the sex his ex is having elsewhere. Likewise
column4: the rare rhythmic foible or piped-in electronic noise is meant to sound queasy rather than quirky. But you mostly sense Blumberg’s decidedly depressive state in the manner in which Unreal takes its sweet time doing everything. After two minutes of whooshing cello
column5: feedback
column6: and electric piano
column7: “Viral” blooms into Unreal’s most immediately fetching chorus. In fact
column8: it might be the only one. Listening to the sweet co-ed harmonies
column9: the concise and utilitarian lyrics
column10: it stands to reason that Blumberg might feel a little guilty about “Viral”; despite all of his attempts to contort and distend “Viral” during its relatively brief five minutes
column11: you can’t shake how reminiscent it is of Yuck.

column1: It’s an encapsulation of the messy separations that define Unreal. The lyrics talk about disintegrated relationships in the past tense
column2: while the music suggests that while Blumberg has left Yuck
column3: he hasn’t quite quit his last and most successful guise. Blumberg is a capable
column4: if not particularly distinguished guitarist. He is also a songwriter with an unusual gift for sticky
column5: familiar hooks and the issue here is that Unreal puts far more emphasis on the former. On Unreal
column6: Blumberg still can’t get away from himself
column7:
he’s just figuring out ways to accept it.

As made abundantly clear by Enjoy the Experience
column2: the recent book exploring the world of privately pressed records
column3: there tithings to be had by churches pressing records to sell to their own congregation. Be it in Alabama or Ohio
column4: the covers for these releases were usually interchangeable: the sun setting over a landscape
column5: waves breaking against the rocks
column6: and-- most fitting for the implicit metaphor of New Testament enlightenment conquering darkness-- sunbeams lancing through a cloud.

column1: In the opening notes for Numero Group’s third compilation of gospel music
column2: subtitled Aprocryphal Hymns
column3: they explain that such pastoral landscapes were interchangeable when it came to ordering your very own record sleeves
column4: citing the Century Records Custom Recording Service of Saugus
column5: Calif.
column6: in the 1960s and 70s. Gospel acts ranging from the Sensational Friendly Four of Selma
column7: Ala.
column8: to the Supreme Jubilees chose their sleeve art dependent on what image seemed most inspirational. Per the Jubilees’ Leonard Sanders: ""When I saw that photo of the sun setting into the ocean
column9: it seemed to express everything we were trying to say.” The Traveling Souls
column10: Song Birds of the South
column11: and Flying Eagle Gospel Singers thought it spoke for them
column12: too.

column1: From such visual clichés come the most intimate of expressions
column2: though
column3: as Aprocryphal Hymns makes clear. Covering the 1960s through the late 70s
column4: Aprocryphal Hymns documents a time of flux for gospel music. Whereas the previous generation caned “Amazing Grace”
column5: soon pop music such as Curtis Mayfield’s “People Get Ready” began to be refigured as praiseworthy fare. Harmonies here draw as much from Philly Soul as they do from Claude Jeter. And with the rise of home studios
column6: what this set compiles is a more personal relationship with God established via magnetic tape.

column1: The hi-hats distort on Robert Vanderbilt & the Foundation of Souls’ “A Message Especially From God”
column2: but its message comes through from syrup-slow flanged guitar and honeyed harmonies. Another deliriously unhurried guitar solo and some fine falsetto praise from the Spiritual Harmonizers puts “God’s Love” somewhere between Mayfield and the Congos. Who knew God was such a 'head for psychedelic music? Elsewhere on this 20-track compilation
column3: the run from Shelton Kilby’s “Poor Wayfaring Stranger” through Jonah Thompson’s wistful “Get Involved” onto the Supreme Jubilees’ “It’ll All Be Over”
column4: is simply sublime. On the latter
column5: end days are rendered into R&B as bittersweet as David Toop’s Sugar & Poison set.

column1: There are more than a few attempts at the Delfonics’ “La-La (Means I Love You)” beat

column3: but for the most part

column5: one from a retrofitted Hammond B-3

the pulse here acts as a beacon through the haze.

Big Star weren't perfect. The word gets thrown around a lot
column2: especially regarding to their debut
column3: #1 Record
column4: as if perfection were their triumph. They were a band of few
column5: if any triumphs; theirs was a losers' history upgraded by the passage of time and the success of those they influenced. Big Star were marked by their lack of triumph. Big Star were roiling and volatile
column6: a freak collision between a couple of college kids and an idle teen idol
column7: who in every regard but artistic
column8: failed their way through a career that barely qualified as such. How far Big Star fell into that wide chasm between what they wanted to be and what they were
column9: that is what made them great.

column1: Nothing Can Hurt Me is the soundtrack for the new Big Star documentary of the same name. It contains unheard
column2: alternate mixes from #1 Record
column3: rough mixes from Sister Lovers
column4: and other special mixes created for the movie
column5: all bracketed by studio banter. They don't shine like the original album versions
column6: but still
column7: ""When My Baby's Beside Me"" is just as compelling even if this mix has more pish in the cymbals. You would have to be at least a six-out-of-10 on the Big Star nerd scale to hear specific differences without cuing up a Big Star album proper to check.

column1: During the time of these recordings
column2: Alex Chilton was only a few years past ""The Letter""
column3: the single that made him a teenage star with the Box Tops. The single had sold four million copies and nabbed them a Grammy nomination alongside the Beatles. (That they both lost to 5th Dimension explains the dimensions of entire pop cosmos at the time). Over the next few years he saw enough of success to know he didn't want it on its terms; he dropped from the limelight
column4: bailed on his life in Memphis with his teenage bride and newborn son
column5: hung heavy with the Beach Boys in L.A. before he expatriated to the Village at 19 to fashion himself into a folkie. Embarrassed by the Box Tops
column6: he was aiming to do something earnest. Two years later he returned to Memphis with a couple of songs and essentially stumbled into Chris Bell's laborious studio project with bassist Andy Hummel and drummer Jody Stephens. With the addition of Chilton
column7: they became Big Star.

column1: If nothing else
column2: Nothing Can Hurt Me functions as a will-do-in-a-pinch Big Star Best Of. You get a sort of thumbnail genesis
column3: but without the movie to provide context
column4: it's jarring to go from Chilton's ode to the purity of the teenage love
column5: ""Thirteen""
column6: with its fragile harmonies and ""tickets for the dance
column7: to a markedly less lucid Chilton droning
column8: ""Nothing can hurt me... I can't feel a thing"" five songs later. On ""Thirteen""
column9: and the songs that precede it
column10: they sounded like what they were: American kids who grew up on the Beatles. Once you get to the brittle distance of ""Kanga Roo"" and its peals of feedback
column11: there is a sad
column12: reedy quality to Chilton's voice. It's clearly the same repentant boy of ""Give Me Another Chance""
column13: but on ""Kangaroo""
column14: his wavering
column15: narcotized tone makes it seem like he's melting; his promise that ""I'm gonna be alright now
column16: ringing hollow as he sounds anything but.

column1: Chris Bell
column2: as the saying goes
column3: was perhaps just not made for his times. Born into affluence
column4: he was private and volatile--during Big Star's era he secluded himself in the back house behind his parents home
column5: where he immersed himself in making art and music and taking drugs in an attempt to salve his depression and blunt his sexuality (in the film
column6: his brother says Bell confessed as much-- in the American South in the early 70s
column7: even amid the youth culture fringe
column8: being queer was not really spoken of. Even in the documentary
column9: some of Bell's friends speak of it euphemistically as ""experimentation"". Many of the doc's tearjerking moments are for Bell). You can hear Bell's Beatlesmania in his voice here on ""My Life Is Right""
column10: in his crisply un-American o's of the ""lonely road"" he sings of. There's a quiver in his voice on ""Feel""
column11: a squeaky stretch as he forces his high notes; along with the surly bravado he summons on ""Don't Lie to Me
column12: --""I told my dad/ And now I'm telling you/ Don't push me 'round
column13: he yalps--you hear the proximity to boyhood. That for all their finesse
column14: for all of these gorgeously arranged songs and year of Bell-helmed sessions at Ardent-- they were still amateurs getting it right; kids in a good time band.

column1: What the sad documentary and its accompanying soundtrack of barely alternate-mixes reinforce is that there is no justice in pop music; the ones that ""deserve"" to make it rarely do
column2: dreams die on the vine.  Big Star's fame
column3: during their initial three-album run
column4: was directly inverse to their talent. Rock'n'roll is cruel like that; it's all winners histories and idiot luck. Music might have been a different place if #1 Record had been just that and bumped Jethro Tull's Thick as a Brick off the charts in June of 1972
column5: but maybe not. There are plenty of bands that mapped inspired paths to greatness
column6: but Big Star's story
column7: as seen on film and heard on these songs
column8:
is a potent reminder of just how beautiful failure can be.

The rigors of touring resulted in Andrew Cedermark amicably parting ways with Titus Andronicus
column2: his second solo LP was recorded in a number of former and current domiciles
column3: and it contains songs with titles such as “Tiller of Lawn” and “Heap of Trash”. But why would you want a document of a 27-year old settling into a domesticated existence-- it’s the literal sound of a chore
column4: no? Fortunately
column5: Cedermark plays up the existential and philosophical issues that make “home” one of the most powerful and commonplace concepts in pop music. Even the quaint abode on its cover allows you to project your fears and ambitions onto it. If you’re thinking about starting a family one day
column6: do you see conformity or comfort? If you’re an apartment dweller in a crowded metro area
column7: do you see isolation or privacy?

column1: There’s enough space to consider all of the above on Home Life
column2: though Cedermark leans towards the latter of both those binaries. If there was ever an album that sounds like it was made to be listened to on the Saturdays when you’re in your boxers
column3: easing out of your hangover with a noon beer

column5: helping frame Home Life as relatable and grounded-- typically
column6: an honest day’s work causes the people here to head out to bars and the next day’s work is the reason they have to call for their tab and a cab.

column1: At the risk of projecting
column2: both Cedermark and I resided in Charlottesville
column3: Va.
column4: during our early 20s and though most of Home Life was recorded in upstate New York and New Jersey
column5: it sounds like it’s fueled by memories of the Southern college town that Dave Matthews
column6: Stephen Malkmus
column7: and David Berman also once called home. There’s a shuffling
column8: country pace to these songs and Cedermark’s droopy
column9: drawled vocals evince a boozy bonhomie that you don’t hear too often north of the Mason-Dixon. The sound of Home Life is pure indie rock
column10: though
column11: produced by Kevin McMahon (The Monitor
column12: Real Estate’s Days) with holistic intimacy; compared to the sizzling fuzz of Cedermark’s 2010 debut Moon Deluxe
column13: this is a warm recording
column14: capturing a couple of musicians in one room with limited pruning and letting the instruments bleed into each other. Stinging
column15: lyrical guitar leads and Cedemark’s vocals weave together throughout
column16: which can be something of a drawback. Though Cedermark made the lyrics available on his Blogspot
column17: they can easily fade towards the background and give you the false impression that Home Life is meant to be a bashful work.

column1: On the contrary
column2: Cedermark’s lyrics on Home Life are well worth considering. Without getting too specific about geography or personal detail
column3: its perspective is one of post-collegiate anxiety
column4: a point where Cedermark is either worrying about the future
column5: stuck on the past and
column6: as a result
column7: not really living in the moment as much as he could. A lot of Home Life is viewed from passing trains
column8: most pointedly “Train Window Man”
column9: where he tries to think of a way to describe the trees and piled-up beer cans he sees during his commute. He can’t come up with anything besides “sad
column10: ” which becomes its own form of sadness.

column1: Most often
column2: Home Life theorizes on how old friendships can endure and new ones can start when people are no longer in close quarters and bar nights become fewer and further between.  “Canis Major” scans as a love song
column3: albeit one concerned with how to get over yourself enough to love someone else
column4: either romantically or platonically. He sighs
column5: “My girl/ Chest heaves as she dreams/ Oh how I love her with my cicada-shell heart/ Sometimes I need you/ but I don’t know how to get there
column6: ” and it’s a deadpan moment of ridiculousness. He’s aware of his need for companionship
column7: yet can’t communicate them to the person who is right there in his bed. On the subsequent “Canis Minor”
column8: love is viewed with trippy logic as part divine intervention and cosmic joke
column9: no less random than connecting two stars in the shape of a dog.

column1: But while Cedermark is an ace guitarist and affecting lyricist
column2: his songwriting isn’t quite as rigorous or sharp. The preworn familiarity of “On Me” makes it the standout by default
column3: and it’s also the most memorable song by a fair margin. Though his former bandmate Patrick Stickles is an equally wordy lyricist
column4: he typically writes melodies that are sturdy enough to handle the cramped verbiage. Conversely
column5: Cedermark’s tend to follow the ambling path of his plainspoken prose. There are exceptions; the up-tempo surge of “At Home” is a welcome eye-opener while “Come Back” provides contrast with a solo performance that lets Cedermark air his doubts about his artistic process. It’s a self-aware moment on a self-aware record
column6: though he’d be served well going a little further to connect with those who aren’t in the specific vibe that Home Life nails. Cedermark laments in “On Me” that “I've got a beer and nobody to lean on
column7: ” and if you’re a little nostalgic
column8: a little tipsy and feeling pretty OK with all of that
column9:
Home Life is there when you need a hand.

Portland composer and vocalist Natasha Kmeto is a multitasker. Half her time's spent on careful precision production; the other half
column2: the straightforward melodies and plainspoken lyrics you’d find in more outward-facing dance or R&B. As such
column3: she makes two types of songs: meticulous vocalises that seem hookier than their short length would allow
column4: and more fully-formed songs with melodies and subject matter that wouldn’t be out of place on a 90s R&B crossover-- maybe it was done by Timbaland at his pre-Shock Value loopiest. (For an example
column5: see Kmeto’s tense cover of Brandy’s “I Wanna Be Down.”) Kmeto has company in this
column6: especially lately
column7: and she’s often brought up alongside vocalist-producers like Maya Jane Coles
column8: Grimes
column9: and Jessie Ware
column10: sometimes on dubious gender grounds. Arguably
column11: she has equal affinity with James Blake or How to Dress Well
column12: artists who share similar ideas about space and moodiness
column13: or Disclosure
column14: who’ve fielded the same questions about composing for vocals. Crisis
column15: her proper full-length debut

column1: For one

column3: the sequencer octaves and skittery percussion
column4: the piano chasing glassy voice down the scale
column5: the chorus that kicks up about three times the storm of anything else surrounding
column6: but it’s authoritative in a way that’s new for her. There’s another
column7: too. “Last Time” presses against a synth slab long enough to highlight how little motion the track’s got-- an apt analogue to the sorta-on
column8: sorta-off relationship described. The quieter cuts have their charms
column9: too. “Morning Sex” is far more unmoored and resigned than the blunt title suggests; it provides its own soft focus. “Vodka Diet” is like a callback to The Ache’s “Detox Saturday”
column10: another hungover hallucination with synth claps
column11: vague trap rhythms
column12: and half-distorted vocals submerged in the fog. The album closes with a three-track suite that sheds progressively more production frippery (thrilling as it is) to great effect
column13: until closer “Prideless” is almost a cappella over snaps and a simple riff. It’s like an early Ashanti track submerged underwater
column14: and just because that’s right off the alt-R&B pantheon of ideals doesn’t make it any less delicately compelling.

column1: Though “delicate” may not be the best word for Crisis. Kmeto’s said that Crisis is her “straightforward
column2: cathartic” album
column3: and while that’s often interview-speak for “album with broader ambitions than the old stuff
column4: ” there’s something to it. Just look at the song titles-- the middle stretch in particular comes off like a drugged-out portion of a Laurie Weeks book-- or what they’re saying. “Idiot Proof” is one big protest-- “it’s been a while
column5: I need peace from all the things I’m supposed to be”; the weighty synths punctuating the words as much as Kmeto’s voice
column6: torchy all of a sudden. It’s a little strange at first that such millennialisms are as poppy a prospect as the crashing rhythm
column7: but it’s 2013 and here we are. If “Last Time” is like something out of a mumblecore sitcom
column8: come-on “Take Out” is the party episode: beginning brash
column9: as if Kmeto’s strutting in front of a mirror
column10: it bursts with extra vocal tracks and laser zaps and synths like confetti. Moments like these are
column11: at times
column12: more effective hooks into the album than the actual hooks
column13: or Kmeto’s 90s vocals
column14: for all their perfectly timed retromania. Anyone can get all Aaliyah over Ableton. Where Kmeto shines as a songwriter/producer isn’t simply mashing together trends and skillsets
column15:
but finding that emotional entry point.

Once a novelty
column2: the guitar-and-drums duo has became so commonplace
column3: you can actually parcel these bands into subgenres. It’s easy to see the appeal
column4: as the inherent limitations of this setup can inspire bands to push themselves in ways that power trios might not-- in the case of Japandroids
column5: stripping to the barest instrumentation allows the most direct connection to the audience
column6: whereas No Age attempt to uncover the maximum textural possibilities within their boundaries. A band like Dodos focuses on the rhythmic qualities of acoustic instruments
column7: while the Black Keys and White Stripes subvert roots music with their respective idiosyncrasies. Manchester duo Ghost Outfit do a number of those things for brief periods of time on their debut I Want You to Destroy Me. But they're also a reminder that playing as a duo can simplify things beyond an economic and touring perspective; having only one other guy to bounce ideas off can result in taking the artistic path of least resistance as well.

column1: It’s no slight to say Ghost Outfit come off as energetic performers more than adroit craftsmen at this point. Opener “Too Soon” is played like they have two minutes tops to hold your attention
column2: a 6/8 churn of pounding toms
column3: guitars fuzzed beyond recognition
column4: and Jack Hardman's yelped vocals. It’s the sound of a band that’s struggled through basement shows and crap PAs in order to be heard; Ghost Outfit is the opening act that actually moved you when you were just expecting to kill time before the headliner. Throughout
column5: Ghost Outfit sound like they’d be a blast live
column6: especially with the visual element implied by Michael Benson's prodding drumwork and Hardman's neck-straining.

column1: But at the risk of stating the obvious
column2: you’re not in the same room as Ghost Outfit during I Want You to Destroy Me. The downside of this formalist
column3: reverential sound is that Ghost Outfit trigger just as many memories of specific bands rather than bespoke emotions without giving much sense of why you’d gravitate to Ghost Outfit in particular. When the tempos and vocals calm down during the mid-album valley of “Sleep” and “Words”
column4: they become yawning Echo and the Mary Chain narco-pop that will get jumbled with the last Crocodiles or Stagnant Pools song you heard. While “Lexicon” stands out in context for its pitch-shifted guitars and erratic
column5: phonetic vocals
column6: it’s ground that Gauntlet Hair have covered more comprehensively. Interludes of droning guitar try to create a sense of continuity to I Want You to Destroy Me
column7: but it all seems perfunctory; you wonder if Deerhunter's enduring contribution to indie rock will be the idea that one-minute interstitials are a requirement for any up-and-coming noise-pop band.

column1: I Want You to Destroy Me is solid as far as debuts go
column2: though it offers the all-too-common letdown of hearing music that’s superficially loud and aggressive
column3: yet feels like it’s doing so little to actually stand out. Ghost Outfit occasionally find ways to do so-- as opposed to most vocalists working within endless tides of sustained
column4: distorted guitars
column5: Hardman's excitable presence lends a welcome burst of reckless energy. It finally perks up for the promising closer
column6: “Kids”
column7: an unabashed crowd pleaser with count-off vocals and start-stop dynamics
column8: tricks that have sustained energetic
column9: if not overly distinct debuts for time immemorial. But for Ghost Outfit
column10:
it’s important because it’s the first time where it finally feels like more than two people are in the room on I Want You to Destroy Me.

column2: Culture
column3:
and Identity in the Caribbean 1920-72|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Soul Jazz']|2013-07-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:41.410416|"

Soul Jazz has established itself as much as a historical and cultural record as a record label. They’ve released compilations that showcase particular styles from acid house to country soul alongside an increasing number of books on music-related topics from Haiti’s Kanaval to New York’s ball culture to the rise of electronic dancehall in Jamaica. As it stands
column4: much of what Soul Jazz has done is chart narratives and tell stories as much as they showcase music. Mirror to the Soul brings together music
column5: film
column6: and writing to provide a perspective on the Caribbean-- particularly the postcolonial era.

column1: The compilation is part of the package and acts as soundtrack to a two-hour documentary film made up entirely of clips from the archive of British Pathé-- the company that produced newsreels for cinema-goers in the UK from 1920 to 1970. It’s tough to visit the Pathé website and not end up pleasantly trapped in an abyss of newsreel goodness. Label head Stuart Baker meandered through the Caribbean clips and with the eyes and ears of a DJ-- the film moves back and forth between places and times-- and painted a portrait of mid-20th-century West Indian life as seen through the eyes of the empire. An uncomfortable
column2: insightful and surprising
column3: as well as eye opening film
column4: the accompanying compilation provides another element of the place that is the Caribbean. And this is a place that is not normally considered all together.

column1: Especially where music is concerned
column2: the Caribbean is rarely viewed as a region. The archipelago that stretches from Belize across to Cuba-- the so-called “greater” Antilles-- down to Guyana are “seeds of islands dispersed by the winds” as Nobel-winning St Lucian Derek Walcott would say. And though the promotion of all-inclusive resort travel may have narrowed the definition of these disparate places to a series of warm and relaxing beach destinations
column3: the range of culture and identity is
column4: in actuality
column5: incredibly wide. Sure
column6: the world listens to reggae
column7: but beyond that
column8: though Guadeloupans might listen to Haitian konpa
column9: it’s more than tough to find
column10: say
column11: a dancehall in Jamaica that would be rocking reggaeton. Language tends to divide West Indian music into sections-- calypso
column12: soca
column13: reggae and dancehall; konpa
column14: zouk and soukous; cha cha
column15: salsa and merengue
column16: to name but a few. Though one might assume that any linguistic disconnect might be lessened by the interconnectedness made possible by the internet
column17: listening to the radio in the region demonstrates that lines are indeed drawn.

column1: With Mirror to the Soul
column2: listeners are provided with a view on the Caribbean that encourages cultural links and connections
column3: reaching back to the 1960s and 70s. Listening to the compilation from beginning to end
column4: there’s certainly a regional obsession with creating tunes that do well on a dancefloor. It also demonstrates the perspective of this area of the world during the era of independence for many of these islands. Through culture
column5: immigration
column6: and communication
column7: the Caribbean integrated numerous musical influences. It’s perhaps why the music works so well together. To call the accompanying booklet ""liner notes"" is a bit of an understatement. Seventy-five pages not only describe the tunes
column8: but tell the history of the period.

column1: The set kicks off with Andre Toussaint’s “Nassau Cha Cha”
column2: a recording that seems to do a good job of setting the tone for this collection-- a two-minute mash up of jazz and cha cha
column3: sang by a scatting Haitian with a band featuring a flautist trained at Jamaica’s world-famous Alpha Boys School. The connection between the English
column4: Spanish and French Caribbean is represented in this track-- a connection that isn’t often made.

column1: There are some highlights here-- like Trinidadian Edmondo Ros “London Is the Place for Me”
column2: which sounds like a soundtrack to Sam Selvon’s classic book about West Indian experience in the UK
column3: Lonely Londoners. It also demonstrates the Caribbean connection to the UK through the generation of immigrants that travelled on the Empire Windrush to find their fortunes on the challenging and often discriminatory shores of the mother country. Russ Henderson’s jazzy “West Indian Drums”
column4: recorded in England in the late 1950s
column5: is another example of a piece that reaches from the West Indies across the ocean.

column1: The Cuban selections are particularly good
column2: with examples from before and after the revolution. “Mambo Caliente” by Bebo Valdes and his Havana Allstars is a peek into Havana’s famous Tropicana nightclub in the early 1950s. Reaching forward to 1976
column3: Grupo de Experimentación Sonora del Icaic’s odd “Repentino” is a standout. But this isn't really about picking out the best tracks-- in fact
column4: fans of Soul Jazz releases will probably recognize quite a few of the bits and pieces gathered together here. This is more about curation than it is about crate digging. Moving from the groove of “Calypso Invasion” of the Trinidadian Duke of Iron to the infectious “Baila Mi Shingaling” by Puerto Rico’s El Gran Combo to the gorgeous
column5: shimmering rocksteady of Slim Smith’s classic “My Conversation” is hearing different musics from different places talk to each other. As Smith puts it
column6: “all I need from you is a good conversation
column7: because it gives me sweet inspiration.”

column1: Providing further context is a bonus CD of 15 roots music tracks. Reaching back over the past couple of decades that Soul Jazz has spent recording Afro-Caribbean music
column2: this selection features some new bits and some previously released gems. There’s Haitian rara-- carnival marching music complete with horns
column3: drums and shouts
column4: Gwada (Guadeloupan) gwo-ka drumming
column5: a range of Garifuna music from Belize
column6: and further roots styles from Cuba. Listening to this CD alongside the music from the mid-century Caribbean draws further rhythmic connections between islands and cultures.

column1: This is not a comprehensive collection
column2: and aficionados of some of the styles and genres will not find a trove of undiscovered treasure. But that’s really not the point. Much like the accompanying documentary
column3: with it’s non-linear presentation of the Pathé clips
column4: listening to Mirror to the Soul is about a particular period and set of places. It’s about listening to music as a means of encapsulating an experience
column5: about framing the Caribbean in a different way
column6:
and for that reason it’s a worthwhile project. 

"|18291.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18291-mirror-to-the-soul-in-the-caribbean-1920-72/|7.0|Erin MacLeod

column2: 'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sunday Best'
column4: David Lynch began writing a weekly syndicated comic called The Angriest Dog in the World. The artwork for each installment was the same: an image of a monstrous rage-filled creature who only looked a little bit like a dog
column5: tied in a yard outside and open window. Dialog bubbles from inside the house would offer a punning exchange or some philosophical point that was twisted into a single goofy joke (this one was typical: “Pete has a police record”/ “What does he have a police record for?”/ “I guess he likes Sting and their music.”) If you were tuned into Lynch’s surreal sense of humor
column6: there was something compelling about this relentless devotion to a single idea. Angriest Dog ran for nine years.

column1: For Lynch
column2: revisiting obsessions over and over is part of the deal. His second solo album
column3: The Big Dream
column4: which follows on 2011’s Crazy Clown Time
column5: is another example. It feels very much like a continuation of its predecessor
column6: with the same weaknesses and strengths. Once again
column7: Lynch takes musical elements from his youth-- the sock-hop ballads of Bobby Vinton
column8: the gnarled guitar instruments of Link Wray
column9: both of which are common in his films-- and gives them a modern but still homemade sheen
column10: topping the reverb-heavy dreaminess of the music with half-sung lyrics in Lynch’s distinctively nasally register. The imagery is archetypical: cold winds blow
column11: it’s last call
column12: there’s a wishing well. It is
column13: in other words
column14: another album of Lynch shuffling his iconic imagery and rendering it in another form of media
column15: in this case an album.

column1: The strengths? Lynch has a deep understanding of song and mood. Though he’s not a musician
column2: exactly
column3: he’s been working in a studio with composer Angelo Badalamenti
column4: sound designer Alan Splet
column5: and others for going on 40 years. He knows how sound works and the kinds of emotional responses it can generate. So the fat low-end and ringing twang of “Star Dream Girl” put you into a very specific headspace within about five seconds
column6: and the vaporous guitar tone and slow-dance sway of “Cold Wind Blowin’” generate a palpable ache
column7: even if the song itself doesn’t necessarily stand up to heavy scrutiny. You get a sense that
column8: given Lynch’s interests and the tools available to him
column9: The Big Dream is probably a well-rendered version of what he might have had in his head
column10: the album that he wanted to make.

column1: The main weakness is the same one found on Crazy Clown Time: the songs. As songs
column2: they don’t do much or say much. There are no new wrinkles
column3: no moments of surprise or recognition. It hints at fear and creepiness and dreaminess without ever embodying them. The main appeal of the record is that it’s “an album by David Lynch”. It’s hard to hear the album without thinking first “I’m listening to a David Lynch album” rather than “I’m listening to music” or “I’m listening to a song.” In other words
column4: without intimate knowledge of Lynch’s aesthetic
column5: place in culture
column6: and oeuvre
column7: the album doesn’t have much to offer. (The big exception once again is a song sung by someone else-- Lykke Li’s lead vocal turn on the “digital bonus track” “I'm Waiting Here”; hearing it
column8: it’s hard not to wish very badly that Lynch would have gotten others to sing the rest of the album). As such
column9: it’s difficult to imagine returning to this album months or even weeks from now
column10: once the initial charge of “I’m listening to a David Lynch album” has worn off.

column1: That might sound like a harsh criticism
column2: but it really isn’t. Lynch as an artist and an icon has earned some latitude
column3: and following along with his projects has proven to be an enjoyable activity in its own right as we wait for him to catch another big fish and make another film. But when we look back at his great body of work years hence
column4: I suspect that this pair of albums-- unlike
column5: say
column6: the Eraserhead soundtrack or the Julee Cruise album Floating Into the Night-- will be considered minor diversions
column7: something more on the level of The Angriest Dog in the World
column8:
a collection of Lynch-isms stretched to a point where they are of interest to only his most committed fans.

As the utopian dream of the 1960s came to an end
column2: Ohioan undergraduate art students Mark Mothersbaugh and Gerald Casale witnessed a traumatic sight on their college campus
column3: one that resonated far beyond the quad. On May 4
column5: a student demonstration protesting President Nixon’s recently announced expansion of the Vietnam War (deemed the Cambodian Campaign) at Kent State University turned deadly
column6: the National Guard opening fire on unarmed students
column7: killing four
column8: wounding nine others
column9: and permanently paralyzing another. It was an ugly moment in U.S. history and a profound one for Casale. “I saw exit wounds from M1 rifles out of the backs of two of the four people who were killed
column10: Jeffrey Miller and Allison Krause
column11: [who] were my friends
column12: ” he told one interviewer. “Until then I was a hippie. I thought that the world is essentially good... [That day] I saw the depths of the horrors and lies and the evil. I stopped being a hippie and started to develop the idea of devolution.”

column1: That violent tragedy ultimately led Casale and Mothersbaugh to recruit their younger brothers and drummer Alan Myers to form Devo
column2: the deconstructed
column3: devolved art punks that arose with Cleveland acts like Pere Ubu and the Dead Boys in the late 70s. Their 1978 Brian Eno-produced debut Q: Are We Not Men? A: We Are Devo is regarded as one of the finer albums of punk and new wave (placing at #89 in our Top Albums of the 1970s)
column4: and the band reached the Top 20 in the 80s on the strength of an anxious motorik song that could either be about masturbation
column5: nitrous oxide
column6: sadomasochism
column7: working class values
column8: or President Jimmy Carter
column9: as delivered by guys twitching in Energy Dome hats and sleeveless turtleneck outfits. But in 1990
column10: long after they had sunken into irrelevance (culminating with a flaccid album called Smooth Noodle Maps)
column11: Devo released two compilations that predated their signing to a major label
column12: revealing a secret history of the group.

column1: Perversely out of print for over twenty years
column2: Hardcore Devo now gets a CD and LP reissue. (Lamentably
column3: the vinyl reissues arrived in shops the same week that news came down that Myers
column4: deemed ""the human metronome"" by bandmates during his decade-long tenure in the group
column5: had lost his battle to cancer.) Recorded to four-track at their basement space from 1974-1977
column6: the forty demos presented here reveal Devo to be abrasive
column7: twisted
column8: paranoid
column9: primal
column10: and sexually frustrated
column11: robotic in a way far more disconcerting than Kraftwerk could ever manage. It revealed a band more demented and trenchant than had ever been glimpsed on MTV. On one sleeve
column12: they are beaver-watchers wrapped in rubber
column13: stacked as corpses. In another
column14: they are adorned with rubber tits. Only “Mongoloid” and “Jocko Homo” made it to those Eno sessions at Conny Plank’s recording studio in Germany
column15: as well as covers of the Stones and Allen Toussaint’s “Working in a Coal Mine”.

column1: While scrubbed from all later versions of Devo’s doctrine
column2: “de-evolution” also meant regressing from adulthood back to pre-pubescence
column3: far from political correctness or polite company
column4: to considering women only as alien apparatuses. They’re tomatoes
column5: holes
column6: a biological urge
column7: a commodity for rich business men who want “but one taste of [their] toilet water
column8: ” something to tie a rope around like a horse. There’s commentary on marriage to be had in “The Rope Song”
column9: but amid the queasy Moog
column10: there’s still that ring-modulated voice saying: “She runs away but not very far/ Push a button
column11: retractable cord/ I pull her back when I get bored.” Less creative: “I need a bitch to suck my dick.” Some lines vie for Yeezus-level trolling: “A slant-eyed catfish that tasted better than Mom
column12: ” on post-Vietnam War “Bamboo Bimbo”
column13: and pining for “buttered beauties of the negroid” just after an era of civil rights marches.

column1: Most acutely felt on the far weirder id- and Moog-blats of Vol. 2
column2: the aforementioned lyrical themes border on something like a psychiatrist’s notes on a frequent teen masturbator. They don’t get a free pass
column3: but considering how many times incest also crops up (see the disco moves of “Midget”)
column4: it feels like an unfiltered spleening of sexual anger and frustration. There are also odes to being a mongoloid
column5: to the cognitively impaired
column6: to pinheads. But amid such idiocy and infantilism
column7: the band was also honing their peculiar lyrical purview: culled from ad copy
column8: nursery rhymes
column9: obscure pamphleture
column10: and crackpot theories. “Can You Take It?” talks cartoons
column11: then mortality: “Yosemite Sam blows up his head/ You and me wind up dead.” There then follows sex with a toaster.

column1: Hardcore comprises a heap of songs too crude
column2: toothed
column3: and cringeworthy for crossover success
column4: so it makes sense so many were composted. But embarrassing as these discarded songs can now be seen in hindsight
column5: the band itself is a glorious thing. They try on disco
column6: garage rock
column7: instrumentals
column8: New Orleans pop
column9: lounge
column10: and lo-fi weirdness
column11: full of modular synth space junk and minimal wave electronic drums
column12: with melodies that veer from radio jingle to white noise to muzak to alien transmissions. And it proves the band to be an outsider art project at its heart
column13: kin to the likes of Bruce Conner (who shot an early video for the group)
column14: Destroy All Monsters and LAFMS. Devo became an act that somehow infiltrated and infested mainstream radio like some mutant progeny of Sun Ra
column15: Captain Beefheart
column16: and the Residents. A formidable feat
column17: considering how Mothersbaugh now works on movie soundtracks
column18: video games
column19:
and kids' TV show ""Yo Gabba Gabba"". Hardcore Devo re-asserts the band as the angry punks they once were.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19475/homepage_large.7e2ca9ea.jpg|Music for Objects EP|9780.0|CFCF|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paper Bag']|2013-07-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:43.280965|"

For Mike Silver
column2: the Montreal producer who records as CFCF
column3: inspiration comes from simple sources. First garnering attention with his balmy take on beat-driven electronics on 2009's still great Continent
column4: Silver's pushed himself out of his comfort zone with nearly every subsequent release
column5: and in the process reshaping what his music is capable of doing. Just as Continent was influenced by Silver's interest in film
column6: his 2010 EP The River provided a patient
column7: yet somewhat warmed-over alternate universe soundtrack to Werner Herzog's Fitzcarraldo. But with last year's Exercises EP
column8: Silver hit a stride that now continues with Music for Objects
column9: a companion to the exploratory
column10: piano-anchored pieces found on Exercises.

column1: The last EP was inspired by the music of Philip Glass and Yellow Magic Orchestra's Ryuichi Sakamoto
column2: and more amorphously
column3: from the brutalist architecture of the 1960s. Music for Objects
column4: as the Eno-esque title would suggest
column5: subscribes to a similar kind of intellectual curiosity that informed the previous release (this record aims to depict normal
column6: unimpressive things Silver encounters every day)
column7: but it isn't a purely eggheaded endeavor. Instead
column8: Silver is able to evoke wide arrays of emotion with mere keystrokes. And while Music for Objects doesn't strictly adhere to ""sounding"" like the objects examined here-- ""Keys""
column9: ""Lamp""
column10: ""Bowl""-- he brings things to life in ways that wouldn't feel unfamiliar to OCD sufferers quick to anthropomorphize objects lying around the apartment. But with CFCF
column11: the less literal the better
column12: as the real payoff is experiencing these things from Silver's point of view
column13: with surprisingly moving results.

column1: Despite recently taking cues from tangible items
column2: CFCF's music has always seemed informed by the seasons
column3: like the bone-cold late winter feel of Exercises
column4: which in some ways gives way to the new growth of springtime that Music for Objects inhabits. From the dewy serenity of ""Bowl""
column5: with its pan flutes and sparse keys
column6: to the shyly sexy saxophone and drain spout plunks of ""Camera""
column7: to ""Glass""'s nimbleness and shimmer
column8: all of it suggests something of a rebirth. The same could be said for Silver
column9: who has found new but sure footing with these complimentary EPs. Just as with Exercises
column10: Music for Objects finds CFCF becoming less of a producer and more of a composer
column11: using more traditional instruments (sax
column12: piano
column13: marimba) to delicately layer and build with. These works are far less busy than the neon-streaked
column14: movement-minded tracks that described his earlier work
column15: but are just as capable of soundtracking some pretty impressive eyelid movies.

column1: Music for Objects came to life after Silver watched 1989's Notebook on Cities and Clothes
column2: a documentary by Wim Wenders on fashion designer Yohji Yamamoto. Silver was particularly struck by the challenge faced by Laurent Petitgand
column3: the film's composer
column4: regarding having to construct a piece of music that expressed something about a piece of clothing. Following in Petitgand's footsteps
column5: Silver has uncovered a good deal more than a project of this nature might reveal
column6: as viewing Music for Objects as merely a functional piece of work is to ignore how emotionally impacting it truly is
column7: no matter what is being depicted. In reinterpreting Petitgand's task
column8: Silver is often able to get a decent amount of mileage out of more concrete depictions of his objects.

column1: It's hard not to hear the romance in something like ""Perfume"" or ""Ring""
column2: the closing piano suite that feels eternal in its simplicity. ""Turnstile"" is even more effective
column3: with its bright pastels and bell tones suggesting a time-lapse video of a Tokyo street during rush hour. The rest of these tracks require a little more effort to unpack-- it's not hard to conjure images of light being refracted off of ""Glass""
column4: or feel the rounded edges of ""Bowl""
column5: but they don't come as quickly or easily. But Music for Objects is
column6: above all else
column7: a record about perspective
column8: one that requires you to look at the familiar from a different angle
column9: and in doing so do the most impressive illuminations take place. The playful tug of war on display on ""Lamp"" doesn't trace a common shape
column10: but sharing a corner of Silver's headspace for a little while is more than half the fun.

column1: But the finest moment on Music for Objects has to be ""Keys""
column2: which is strange because it's probably the least indicative of the EP as a whole. Carrying the saxophone over from ""Camera""
column3: it's a humid
column4: almost danceable track that jams in classic house-y pianos
column5: chirping cicadas
column6: and a dizzying little free jazz coda. It ends up sounding like Bruce Hornsby melting into a swamp. But while ""Keys"" may not be the clearest statement of purpose here
column7: it says something larger about CFCF
column8: offering a condensation of the best bits of Silver's personality
column9: a measured mix of the old and the new all wrapped up into one beatific little four minute segment. It also hints at even greater potential: While it's obvious that Silver isn't the least bit interested in following any set of prescribed rules
column10: the vision of a more complete
column11: multi-faceted CFCF becomes easier to make out. But it's obvious that these smaller steps have all been necessary ones
column12: and wherever he takes his music in the future
column13: there will be plenty to be excited about. But on the subject of Music for Objects alone
column14: it's another excellent chapter in CFCF's story
column15: a strong case for how much unexpected magic can be found in the ordinary and
column16: more importantly
column17:
in CFCF's ever-mutating discography.
