column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19473/homepage_large.fa4b7f1c.jpg|Humble Hustle 2|31497.0|Young Moe|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-07-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:43.809557|"

You can spot Alexandria
column2: Va.
column3: rapper Young Moe hanging uncomfortably in the background of D.C. rapper Fat Trel's ""Respect With the Teck"" video; he's the one with the boyish
column4: fresh face and gray hoodie
column5: bopping his head and struggling slightly to appear menacing. Moe is only 19 years old
column6: and he looks even younger than that
column7: but his hoarse
column8: cracked voice
column9: infused with preternatural weariness and reminiscent of the Game or Yo Gotti
column10: makes him sound decades older. Moe raps with a panicked urgency
column11: hurrying through his wordy
column12: packed verses like he's stopping a loved one from walking away from him.

column1: His writing is similarly blunt and direct: The first Humble Hustle
column2: released when Moe was 17
column3: included a disarmingly direct version of the older-then-the-hills gangsta-rap trope
column4: the ""letter to my mother
column5: and Humble Hustle 2 starts out with an even sweeter and unaffected message to his son. ""I used to drive for hours just to see you for 30 minutes
column6: he says on ""Letter 2 Amarie""
column7: reflecting on his own absentee father and concluding thoughtfully: ""I'm guessing I love you more than he loved me."" It's a powerful
column8: sad insight
column9: and Moe has the intuition not to underline it. It's just there
column10: along with the rest of his life.

column1: Humble Hustle 2 glows with this understated honesty; at 19 tracks
column2: it is a generous and sometimes daunting platter of heartfelt
column3: serious
column4: and finely observed struggle-rap. What it isn't
column5: really
column6: is flashy or stylish or that much fun
column7: which makes Moe's loyal fanbase in local middle schools-- cultivated
column8: Chief Keef-style
column9: by handing out mixtapes to kids-- somewhat surprising. Keef
column10: who is a vocal fan of Moe's
column11: turns up once on Humble Hustle 2
column12: for the intense
column13: blaring ""Round Em Up""
column14: a song that seems to be built from two non-compatible beats playing over each other
column15: but Moe is not the dead-eyed presence that Keef is. Moe traffics in the human-sized blue-collar weariness of Chicago's Tree
column16: or Nashville's Starlito and Memphis' Don Trip. Maybe kids see Moe as a sage older brother figure; maybe they crave a sound moral compass as much as they enjoy violent escape. Maybe they just like Moe.

column1: Either way
column2: Humble Hustle 2 boasts some of the year's wisest and most soulful grown-man music
column3: delivered by a relative kid. His soulful openness seems to open up others around him; Freeway appears on ""Dreamin"" with his best-written verse in a few years
column4: a recollection of his grandfather's struggles with alcoholism. Fat Trel also shows up twice
column5: unfolding rich crime-story details on ""Million Dollar Dreams"" and delivering lip-licking
column6: snaggle-toothed sex talk on ""Gettin It All"". It's to Moe's credit as a rapper that he remains the most vivid presence on his mixtape
column7: even with his colorful guests.

column1: Moe raps like a pugilist
column2: his voice plowing doggedly into each beat and his rhyme schemes piling like pack crates on a pallet. On the story-rap ""T.I.N.O.""
column3: his forceful raps are dotted with writerly grace notes: ""Rang six times and he picked up on the last""; ""So he told him the sour and the powder was on the counter."" At the song's climax
column4: he demands
column5: ""What you do when you momma need her medicine
column6: the devil at the door and he beggin' you to let him in?"" It's an old gangsta-rap question-- the oldest-- but he rattles you with it. On the ""Outro""
column7: he tells us
column8: charmingly
column9: that he feels like ""the principal over the intercom"" and then delivers an entire verse alternating between English and Arabic (the ""Moe"" is short for ""Mohammed""
column10: and the rapper is Egyptian-born).

column1: There are some audible marks of the project's budget-- the tempo switch between the chorus and verses on ""No Love For Ya"" jars very each time
column2: and at one point
column3: the volume on the song increases inexplicably. But otherwise
column4: the production is
column5: grimy
column6: melodic
column7: and diverse
column8: and Moe works as well over the melted downtempo keys of ""My Life"" as he does the weepy chipmunk-soul melodrama of ""Find My Way"" and ""T.I.N.O."". Moe reportedly burned through about 30 tracks for this project
column9: the mark of a hungry young talent
column10: and he fills up every inch of Humble Hustle 2
column11:
as if he's already unsure how he'll find enough time to tell us everything that's on his mind.

"|18279.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18279-young-moe-humble-hustle-2/|7.4|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19446/homepage_large.e0fe2af4.jpg|Tarot|31473.0|Alex Burkat|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['100% Silk']|2013-07-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:44.385722|"

Sometimes it doesn't take much to pry open a door into the music world. Even a brief flash of inspiration can get you there. Take Alex Burkat
column2: a Brooklyn-based electronic musician
column3: now part of Amanda Brown's house-y Not Not Fun offshoot
column4: 100% Silk. The story goes that Burkat was out dancing at a Mister Saturday Night party
column5: where he was so inspired that he sent the organizers his ""Shower Scene"" track. It became as his first single on the Mister Saturday Night label
column6: with ""Tarot"" providing a quick follow up. With ""Tarot""
column7: there were already signs of progress since ""Shower Scene""
column8: signs of dialing down of the epic tendencies of that track
column9: a sense of getting comfortable working on a smaller patch of turf. The difference in the two records is like seeing a career in miniature
column10: with a more robust vision in place after barely any time has passed.

column1: Burkat is still that guy caught up in the jubilation of clubland
column2: but the tracks that make up Tarot hint at how those experiences stimulate reflection as well as hands-in-the-air euphoria. It's on the experimental end of downtempo house
column3: although it never gets too far out there
column4: instead settling into solid grooves that sometimes mirror the mood of Pantha du Prince's benchmark Black Noise. There are three tracks here plus ""Tarot (Global Warming Mix)”
column5: which adds a decent amount of steel to its framework. The varieties in mood are all tied up in a form of future dreaming
column6: with Burkat constructing work that increasingly trepidates as it progresses. It's softer than something like Kuedo's Severant
column7: but takes its mood from similar sources
column8: interlacing a strand of Ballardian doom as its central aesthetic.

column1: It's an EP that steadily plummets into sci-fi fears as it progresses
column2: suggesting Burkat was mindful of spinning a mini-narrative through these works-- ""Tarot"" is comparatively bubbly when stacked up against the knuckle-dragging bass welts of ""Four Seasons"". Still
column3: there's a feeling that Burkat hasn't figured out exactly where he's going yet
column4: especially when viewing the wildly gimmicky video for ""Tarot"". Patched together from iPhone photos
column5: some altered through Instagram filters
column6: the clip feels more suited to cheap seaside punk nostalgists than the Brave New World thinking conjured up by the track itself. The Global Warming mix returns a layer of mystery
column7: adding a loop of digital glitch that mostly removes ""Tarot"" from the joyous territory the original skirts around
column8: instead depositing it into a space that fits with the moodier other tracks.

column1: These are still early days for Burkat and it's likely that he's still figuring out where he wants to go; certainly the change in style from the wide-open ""Shower Scene"" to the techno-mope of ""Last Cigarette"" is vast. But there's enough on this EP to suggest he'd be wise to stick around down there
column2: making the kind of dance music that alternates between staring-at-your-shoes miserablism and trancey floor fillers. On ""Last Cigarette""
column3: he gets the switch from one to the other exactly right
column4: spending half the track lost in anticipation
column5: the midway point's payoff hitting a perfectly transportative note. Now Burkat just needs to figure out where he wants to take his audience all the time
column6: because with cheesy cut-and-paste videos at one end and immersive future gazing at the other
column7:
it's clear that his vision needs a little tightening.

"|18252.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18252-alex-burkat-tarot/|6.6|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19439/homepage_large.6d3a86cc.jpg|Major Arcana|31267.0|Speedy Ortiz|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Carpark']|2013-07-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:45.144532|"

God bless middle school bullies: without the torment they’ve reliably inflicted on generation after generation of brooding
column2: musically-inclined creative types
column3: would there even be indie rock? At the very least there wouldn’t be “No Below”
column4: one of the most striking songs on Northampton
column5: Mass.
column6: noise-pop quartet Speedy Ortiz’s proper debut Major Arcana. “I didn’t know you when I broke my knee
column7: ” frontwoman Sadie Dupuis murmurs during the song’s wounded
column8: palm-muted intro
column9: “Spent the summer on crutches
column10: and everybody teased.” Gnarled yet stingingly heartfelt
column11: “No Below” blooms into a portrait of the artist as a friendless tween: death-obsessed
column12: ditched by the one person at school who gets her
column13: and left “freezing alone with [her] thoughts.” You know
column14: the kind of early-onset trauma from which great
column15: off-kilter bedroom-pop eventually springs.

column1: The first album to bear Speedy Ortiz’s name (which itself is a nod to a doomed character in the beloved alt-comic Love and Rockets) was a solo affair. Dupuis’ self-recorded 2011 release The Death of Speedy Ortiz was a patchy
column2: sardonic (sample titles: “Hexxy Sadie”
column3: “Kinda Blew”) lo-fi gem in the tradition of early Sebadoh or Liz Phair’s legendary Girlysound tapes. But like the heroine of “No Below” (who later finds a companion to compare scars with: “Everything fucked up we both felt before/ I’m glad for it all if it got us where we are”)
column4: Dupuis eventually found strength in numbers. By the time Speedy Ortiz’s promising Sports EP came out last year
column5: she’d brought in some new recruits-- bassist Darl Ferm
column6: guitarist Matt Robidoux
column7: and drummer Mike Falcone-- to kick the firepower up a notch. It worked wonders: A Speedy Ortiz song used to sound like a personally gummed
column8: exactingly aimed spitball
column9: but the best ones on the explosive
column10: earthquaking Major Arcana land like grenades.

column1: Still
column2: even as their songs have grown louder
column3: gnarlier
column4: and more compositionally ambitious
column5: Speedy Ortiz have managed to preserve the intimacy and idiosyncrasy that made Dupuis’ early home recordings so compelling. Which is a testament not just to producer Justin Pizzoferrato (Dinosaur Jr.
column6: Chelsea Light Moving) but also to how receptively and thoughtfully all four members play off each other: Ferm and Falcone keep Major Arcana’s rhythms feeling fluid and adventurous but never sloppy
column7: while the ongoing conversation between Dupuis’s vocals and Robidoux’s trebly
column8: agile riffs is particularly essential to Speedy’s charm. As it does on “No Below”’s caustic
column9: catchy chorus (“And though I once said/ I was better off just being dead”)
column10: Robidoux’s guitar usually mirrors or embroiders Dupuis’ vocal melody
column11: underscoring her words rather than drowning them out.

column1: And thank goodness-- because Major Arcana finds Speedy Ortiz joining a depressingly small club of young indie rock bands (maybe the first new members since Parquet Courts’ Light Up Gold) writing lyrics that are actually worth poring over. “My mouth is a factory for every toxic part of speech I spew
column2: ” Dupuis quivers on the Mascis-indebted sludgefest “Tiger Tank”
column3: and the rest of the record makes good on that promise. Like her hero Stephen Malkmus (she was once the frontwoman of an all-female Pavement cover band called-- wait for it-- Babement) Dupuis sings like someone palpably fascinated with the way words sound. Check
column4: for one example
column5: the way she scales the line
column6: “criminally twisted puny little villain” in the opening moments of “Fun”
column7: delighting in the texture of every vowel. Her lines strike a tricky balance between feeling loose and meticulously crafted-- another trick she must have learned from memorizing Malkmus quotables. On highlights like “Pioneer Spine” or the hellraising “Cash Cab”
column8: Dupuis has a knack for turning seemingly dribbled-out mouthfuls into catchy hooks; in a lot of cases you won’t stop to marvel at the ingenuity of her lines until you’re already singing along.

column1: Speedy Ortiz wear their love of the 1990s on their torn
column2: flannel sleeves
column3: which makes this particular round of Spot the Influence about as challenging as a game of teeball: there’s the squalling
column4: guitar-on-guitar carnage of Archers of Loaf
column5: the grungy mysticism of Helium (Dupuis lifted the title Major Arcana from a book she was reading on black magic)
column6: and of course the deadpan wit of vintage Phair (“I was never the witch that you made me to be
column7: ” Dupuis tells a burnt-out old flame on “Plough”
column8: “Still you picked a virgin over me”). But don’t let any of that lead you to think that Speedy Ortiz are your garden variety nostalgists. Even at its most distortion-caked
column9: there’s a melodic confidence and a gimlet-eyed clarity about Major Arcana that’s a rare find in a debut. They’ve got reverence for their forebears
column10: sure
column11: but unlike a lot of recent bands exhuming the ghosts of indie rock past
column12: Speedy Ortiz also have faith in the peculiar personality traits that set them apart from their heroes. With its quaking rhythms
column13: twisted riffage
column14: and jet-black wit
column15:
Major Arcana is a redemptive ode to the broken bones that grew back together a little crooked-- the ones that taught Dupuis how to walk in her own weird way.

"|18245.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18245-speedy-ortiz-major-arcana/|8.4|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19470/homepage_large.6105a18d.jpg|Summer Knights|30517.0|Joey Bada$$|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cinematic']|2013-07-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:45.669961|"

One of the most surprising mixtapes of 2012 was made by a Flatbush teenager named Jo-Vaughn Scott a.k.a. Joey Bada$$
column2: an Edward R. Murrow High School student who channeled Native Tongues-style rap music with a deceptively sharp edge while heading up the intriguing Pro Era collective. Simply put
column3: the kid could rap. No matter how much his flows echoed the work of his chosen style’s well-entrenched pioneers (Mos Def
column4: Common
column5: Q-Tip
column6: Doom)
column7: his skills were such that 1999 was a fresh
column8: welcome spin on well-worn subject matter.

column1: Since that initial excitement
column2: a lot has happened. In December
column3: one of Joey’s best friends
column4: Pro Era’s Capital STEEZ
column5: tragically took his own life amid a storm of strange rumors
column6: tweeting “The end” the night he committed suicide. Around the same time as STEEZ’s death
column7: Joey turned down an offer to sign with Jay-Z’s Roc Nation imprint
column8: later saying it would take a $3 million dollar advance to sign him (A$AP Rocky
column9: who rose to prominence at roughly the same age
column10: reportedly got that figure from RCA). All the drama pulls down Summer Knights
column11: a record that mines the same bank of 90s rap influences but does so with a more negative
column12: fuck-the-world mentality. The enthusiastic momentum that buoyed 1999 is missing
column13: and Summer Knights is much cloudier proposition.

column1: Even imbued with a darker tint than his debut mixtape
column2: the touchpoints often feel clumsy. It starts with the lyrics: “Somehow the rap game reminds me of the trap game/ In fact is the exact same
column3: and these tracks is my crack ‘caine
column4: ” raps Joey on “Sweet Dreams”. Knotty lines like “Fulfill your needs with similes non similar/ Spit that unfamiliar
column5: put that on familia” (“Hillary $wank”) amount to nicely rapped nonsense. There’s much talk of “similes and verbs”
column6: “metaphysics”
column7: and there are direct homages: “Sorry Bonita” chops up A Tribe Called Quest’s spacey classic “Bonita Applebum”
column8: and there’s a song called “Word Is Bond”. It’s one thing to bat around references
column9: ping-ponging them in a way that riffs on the established themes and vocabulary of rap music. But the approach feels off. Take “Death of YOLO”
column10: a song built off a promising
column11: darkly funny concept-- the protagonist of the song is dead
column12: having taken YOLO too far. Why deliver it with a straight face?

column1: All that said
column2: Summer Knights features strong production. If I had to pick a Native Tongues record to compare it to
column3: it'd be the back half of A Tribe Called Quest’s relatively downcast Beats Rhymes & Life
column4: where keys
column5: hi-hats
column6: snares
column7: and low basslines mingle to create a warm bed of texture to get loose over. Joey can still rap
column8: but the producers on Summer Knights-- Pro Era affiliates Chuck Strangers
column9: Kirk Knight and Lee Bannon with single tracks produced by DOOM
column10: Statik Selektah and Oddissee respectively-- are the real highlights here. While something like “#LongLiveSTEELO” is an affecting
column11: heartfelt cut from Joey-- it’s basically Joey’s version of “I’ll Be Missing You”
column12: complete with Faith Evans-like backup-- you’re 16 tracks deep into a listless affair.

column1: Instead of embracing the styles of more contemporary-minded peers and bending those sounds into his own shapes-- seemingly a must in today's rap climate
column2: if you want to work with a major and get played on the radio-- Summer Knights moves in the other direction
column3: retreating to well-made templates without adding anything to them. Joey deals with heavier shit
column4: but feels weighed down by it. The clunky lyrics wouldn't be a big of a deal if lyricism in the mode of his heroes wasn't one of the aspects he was deliberately playing up. But the deeper problem is one of tone. Joey too often comes out looking like someone who’s already grown weary of the system
column5: an 18-year-old curmudgeon
column6:
a sharp contrast with the energy that 1999 promised.

"|18276.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18276-joey-bada-summer-knights/|6.8|Corban Goble

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19420/homepage_large.9477364e.jpg|Bass Drum of Death|28772.0|Bass Drum of Death|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Innovative Leisure']|2013-07-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:46.315630|"

In the time since Bass Drum of Death played Dinosaur Jr. to MellowHype's Del the Funky Homosapien for a live version of ""64""
column2: the Odd Future boys have forged a more palpable partnership with hardcore heroes Trash Talk. It's just as well-- Trash Talk are now very much aesthetically linked with Odd Future
column3: which isn't a fate BDoD needed after their 2011 debut GB City. That album had some killer hooks
column4: but a couple of unremarkable tracks kept it from being a truly powerful opening statement. This band didn't need any distractions
column5: Odd Future-based or otherwise. John Barrett had to focus on hammering out an even better Bass Drum of Death album
column6: and maybe more importantly
column7: finding a distinctive aesthetic. (Barrett is the sole creative force behind Bass Drum of Death
column8: having written and recorded the entire thing by himself.) The Mississippi native is
column9: after all
column10: releasing an album the same year we've gotten solid new ones from FIDLAR and Wavves
column11: to name two.

column1: So does their new self-titled album capitalize on the immediacy of ""Get Found""
column2: differentiate itself from the rest of rock's oversaturated market
column3: and pack in better songs? No. It doesn't do any of those things. Barrett delivers some solid melodies
column4: but they're usually cheapened by his tendency to draw out one good idea for far too long. Every song on this album could stand to be tightened. Most could lose a verse or two
column5: and a lot of them would sound much better if they were played faster. Seriously
column6: this thing could dominate if it had the pacing of an OFF! record. But that's not the case. ""Shattered Me"" is the easy single
column7: with its earworm melody and run-time of two minutes
column8: and even that feels like it goes on for too long. There are tracks with good energy and solid hooks that are unfortunately long (""Bad Reputation"") and some that are flat-out boring (""White Fright""). And it's easy to understand the impulse to make a paced jam with a sludgy low-end like they do with ""No Demons""
column9: but the last thing this album needs is another track that feels slow.

column1: In many ways
column2: this album offers a natural extension of the work Barrett did on GB City
column3: from his power chord drive to the smoke billowing out of his mouth on the cover. Like that album
column4: this one hosts some undeniable bangers
column5: like album opener ""I Wanna Be Forgotten"". It's exactly the right length
column6: it's got the right drive for the melody
column7: and with a spitfire delivery
column8: Barrett knows exactly how to blurt a line like ""buy a car
column9: get fucked
column10: be dead."" Just like ""Get Found"" before it
column11: it's the sort of song that could serve as a mantra of sorts for BDoD. It's a dirty
column12: concise
column13: satisfying summation of what they're capable of
column14: sort of like what ""Hunchback"" did for Kurt Vile's Childish Prodigy. Barrett even delivers a solid psych track on ""Such a Bore"". The vocals and guitars on that track and the smoldering jam ""Faces of the Wind"" are smothered with psych reverb. As it turns out
column15: Barrett wears Nuggets really well.

column1: The other thing that quietly works against Bass Drum of Death is its easy comparison. Of GB City
column2: David Bevan wrote that the band were at their best ""when whipping up an evil frenzy much like those of Ty Segall
column3: though for all that album's garage rock immediacy
column4: Segall was undeniably the more consistent songwriter. That was two years ago
column5: and once again
column6: Segall feels like an inescapable point of reference. It's probably not intentional
column7: but there are several moments where Barrett implements these vocal nuances that sound just like Ty's. And when that Segall drawl pops up in these overlong Bass Drum of Death songs
column8: it's an unfortunate reminder that these guys don't come close to their peers' seemingly effortless way with writing tight
column9:
exciting rock songs.

"|18229.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18229-bass-drum-of-death-bass-drum-of-death/|5.9|Evan Minsker

Over the last decade
column2: a spate of pastiche-fiends have been mining previously dormant genres for inspiration-- and as a result
column3: dudes like Bruce Hornsby and Nile Rodgers are now serving unexpected
column4: late-career stints as alt-touchstones. “Jam bands
column5: ” though-- long the presumed terrain of white people in dreadlocks and homemade pants-- stay largely unsung; maybe there’s something too dopey about the contemporary scene
column6: or something too ambitious about the virtuosity high-caliber jams require. The Grateful Dead remain the grand exception
column7: a band that’s somehow both an embodiment of and an outlier within their field. The Dead’s best live jams are emotional
column8: melodically dizzying romps
column9: rightly treasured for their ability to insulate a listener from whatever shitty things might be transpiring elsewhere. There’s safety in those songs. Getting close to it can feel euphoric.

column1: Steve Gunn
column2: a sometime-guitarist in Kurt Vile’s Violators and one half of the Gunn-Truscinski Duo
column3: is offering the same kind of shelter on Time Off
column4: a collection of six loose
column5: spiraling guitar songs that give more than they ask: These are generous compositions
column6: gently presented. Gunn’s a descendent of the Dead
column7: but also of J.J. Cale and La Monte Young and Bert Jansch and Frank Hutchinson
column8: and his guitar playing has a mesmeric quality
column9: a tender circling that feels almost like being swaddled. Which is not to belittle their potency
column10: or Gunn’s craft: he’s a nimble
column11: expressive guitarist and a pleasantly lackadaisical vocalist
column12: singing
column13: as he does
column14: about his Brooklyn neighborhood
column15: or water bumping a waterwheel into motion
column16: or taking a certain path through a field. There’s an unrefined
column17: organic quality to Gunn’s work that occasionally recalls Chicago stalwarts Califone or early Red Red Meat-- a reinterpretation of “Americana” that allows for plenty of ingenuity (and requires no costuming).

column1: Gunn’s voice is rambling and soft
column2: but he’s a welcome guide wherever and whenever he shows up-- like a third of the way into “Street Keeper”
column3: when his vocals hitch onto a sweet guitar refrain
column4: or on “Water Wheel”
column5: where he sounds
column6: momentarily
column7: like the late Shannon Hoon
column8: mewing placidly about a river. There are bits here that feel improvised-- or at least slack enough to suggest improvisation-- but Gunn’s songs still rely on patterns and interactions that were clearly composed with care. It helps that his backers (John Truscinski on drums and Justin Tripp on bass) are as comfortable with a groove (see “New Decline”
column9: especially) as they are with hoisting up Gunn’s guitar.

column1: Like all acoustic guitarists with extensive record collections
column2: Gunn has endured plenty of comparisons to John Fahey
column3: but the association feels almost too facile to perpetuate: While Gunn’s produced some more explicitly cerebral work (for a time
column4: he was into manipulating tapes of field recordings)
column5: Time Off’s biggest asset is its ease. There’s a real sense
column6: listening to these tracks
column7: that everything could be a little simpler if we all stopped trying so hard. It is deeply mellow in a way that the famously cantankerous Fahey would have likely found confounding.

column1: It’s also a record that happens to make tremendous sense right now
column2: on the precipice of summer
column3: when we’re all anxious to uncurl a little. On “Lurker”
column4: Gunn sings repeatedly about finding “a spot to kill time and look around
column5: ” and while it’s ostensibly an innocent observation of a neighborhood drifter
column6: it ends up feeling more like a directive-- advice to heed. Find a spot
column7:
kill some time. Look around. 

"|18176.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18176-steve-gunn-time-off/|7.9|Amanda Petrusich

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19281/homepage_large.9ba94473.jpg|Old Mornings Dawn|31331.0|Summoning|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Napalm']|2013-07-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:47.410021|"

Everyone’s favorite dragon porn series has succeeded where so many others before it have failed. Against all odds
column2: ""Game of Thrones"" has managed to make fantasy novels sexy: burly
column3: hirsute tribesmen and corset-busting maidens populate an intrigue-infested feudal world
column4: slicing and dicing their way towards Valhalla beneath a hypothetical soundtrack comprised of Motörhead standbys and Amon Amarth deep cuts. It sounds like The Silmarillion Mach 7
column5: and has proven to be popular with everyone from the bumbling professor next door to your grandma’s hairdresser
column6: but what about the old school fantasy fans? What about the nerds?

column1: Fear not
column2: fellow geeks. Summoning’s got your back. It’s undeniable that these Austrian keyboard enthusiasts are dyed-in-the-wool Tolkien obsessives
column3: swiveling the epic scope of ""Lord of the Rings"" square onto the soaring highs and rumbling lows of Bathory’s Viking odes. There’s a lot more to them than that
column4: of course
column5: even in simply musical terms. Their latest album
column6: Old Mornings Dawn
column7: marks their seventh foray into Middle Earth (not counting a handful of demos and EPs) and will feel like a homecoming to longtime fans. Its lineage can be traced straight back to their 1995 classic Minas Morgul
column8: but these old dogs have picked up a trick or two along the way as their stellar recent output will attest. Their last full-length
column9: Oath Bound
column10: came out back in 2006
column11: and showed a marked progression from its predecessor; Old Mornings Dawn follows the same path especially when the guitar lines are concerned
column12: but spends plenty of time looking backwards towards past triumphs
column13: as well.

column1: The core Summoning sound has barely changed since before the original Nordic black metal’s Second Wave entered its death throes
column2: and Burzum and Emperor’s obvious impact on their sound is proof enough that its roots within that circle are still firm. Protector and Silenius adhere to a strict formula of hypnotic black metal riffs
column3: grandiose keyboard melodies
column4: and vocals that range from harsh
column5: throaty croaks to rumbling spoken word
column6: topped off with a heady swig of pagan folk metal’s chants and choruses. The title track features a rousing choir of Vikings in full voice
column7: and more traditional male/female choirs add color to the majority of the album as well. There’s a sweeping cinematic feel to the proceedings; if any of you guys know Peter Jackson’s sound guy
column8: now might be the time to give him a call. The keyboards often take center stage
column9: piling on the cheese and
column10: at times
column11: stifling the guitar work. Summoning’s approach is an acquired taste
column12: to be sure
column13: but sports acres more heft than is offered by similarly key-heavy “epic” metal bands like Rhapsody of Fire or Blind Guardian. There’s a darkness to it.

column1: That’s nothing compared to the rhythm section
column2: though. Long a thorn in purists’ sides
column3: Summoning’s now legendary programmed drums are unapologetically inorganic
column4: an essential afterthought that come across as almost militaristic in their simplicity. They even skitter into bongo-driven territory on tracks like “Flammifer”
column5: “Earthshine
column6: ” and “Of Pale White Morn”
column7: the latter of which sounds like an outtake from Disney’s Tarzan soundtrack until the guitars... and Orc sounds kick in.

column1: Yep. Summoning is so slavishly devoted to their cause that they’ll toss in Orc samples when the moment feels right. You’d almost wonder if these guys are serious
column2: but the diverse and beautifully orchestrated songwriting on this album speaks for itself. Old Mornings Dawn is a more than worthy addition to their canon
column3:
and a wholly satisfying treat for fans who’ve been waiting nearly a decade for the next adventure.

"|18092.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18092-summoning-old-mornings-dawn/|6.9|Kim Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19474/homepage_large.328c3ead.jpg|Ciara|5068.0|Ciara|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2013-07-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:48.052424|"

Ciara’s 2004 debut Goodies arrived at the tail-end of the last R&B boom. Its best moments used the churn and snap of “crunk’n’b” as a vehicle to re-imagine and repackage the frothy
column2: light-hearted dancefloor charm of early Janet Jackson or Lisa Lisa and the Cult Jam
column3: only replacing girlish energy with insouciance and reserve. She wanted you to drip the sweat she never perspires. And while this mix of qualities made Ciara seem more distinctive and unique than a more solidly traditional R&B diva might
column4: it’s always seemed like Ciara gets R&B at its core
column5: that she’s invested in exploring all the ways the music can move you. Perhaps consequently
column6: the mixed qualitative and commercial fortunes of her career since have mirrored the fortunes of the genre itself. It’s easy to think that if Ciara could put out an album that consistently captured the best of her talents
column7: that record alone might be enough to help R&B reassume the throne of commercial dominance.

column1: I suspect Ciara is not that album
column2: but it roughly matches the quality of 2010’s Basic Instinct
column3: probably her most consistent album up to that point. Which should be good enough to keep the dream alive a little longer. Ciara also touches on just about every facet of her style to date
column4: and while she’s a more versatile
column5: accomplished singer than when she started
column6: her appeal remains essentially unchanged. At her best
column7: Ciara comes on less as a full-blooded personality or even an object of desire and more as a glamorous big sister
column8: the one you want to be when you grow up
column9: who knows all the right moves on the dancefloor and in life. Complexity and personal drama ain’t in it: Ciara holds out the dazzling promise of somehow transcending all of that.

column1: So it’s not surprising that Ciara feels slightly (though only slightly) weaker when she swims against the current of her own charm and tries for “raw.” “I’ve just been through a break up” she announces flatly on the blaring
column2: Nicki Minaj-assisted opener “I’m Out”
column3: and while she’s probably aiming for some mixture of bold personal statement and casual don’t-give-a-fuck swag
column4: all you can hear is the deliberateness. Rihanna
column5: a more limited singer than Ciara
column6: can sound convincingly dead on tunes like “Pour It Up”
column7: but Ciara’s stabs at a similar vibe can have a dress-ups quality
column8: like she’s practicing her enervated monotone recitals in front of the mirror
column9: singing into her lipstick. Ciara has done “hard” plenty of times
column10: but on past tunes like “Oh” or “Ride” she effectively floated above the fray
column11: untouched by the violence even as she endorsed it. “I’m Out” and Ciara’s Nicki-aping rap on (the otherwise excellent) “Super Turnt Up” are enough to confirm aggression is not her strong suit.

column1: Conversely
column2: the delectable
column3: “My Boo”-referencing slow jam single “Body Party” finds the singer in top form
column4: its billowing Mike Will Made It synth chords and crashing snares the perfect setting for Ciara’s light as a feather performance. The key line is “I’m having so much fun with you”
column5: delivered with startled exuberance: even sex
column6: in Ciara’s world
column7: resembles the more innocent sensual pleasure of dancing. Likewise the double entendre-filled cunnilingus ode “Read My Lips”
column8: perky electro-pop delivered with such frothy
column9: wide-eyed innocence that it’s hard even to notice the subject matter. This same sense of uncomplicated exhilaration raises the straightforward
column10: 2013 carbon dated club-pop of “Livin’ It Up” and “Overdose” from throwaway to highlight status
column11: their obviousness transformed into a virtue through the singer’s palpable enjoyment.

column1: The marvelous closing remix of “Body Party” (with features from Future and B.o.B.) underscores this (and the “My Boo” resemblance) by adding a popping bass beat
column2: further submerging Ciara’s come-ons within easy dancefloor camaraderie. It’s a bewitching vision of life without any room for doubts or sadness-- except
column3: perhaps
column4:
for the bittersweet realization that contemporary pop doesn’t sound just like this nearly enough.

"|18280.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18280-ciara-ciara/|7.3|Tim Finney

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19356/homepage_large.2f8aea26.jpg|Late Night Tales|3611.0|Röyksopp|['Pop/R&B'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Late Night Tales']|2013-07-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:49.323393|"

In its second decade of existence
column3: Late Night Tales is an institution. The compilation series asks artists to create their ultimate ""late night"" mix and has featured a variety of acts
column4: from MGMT to Belle & Sebastian to Four Tet
column5: Jamiroquai
column6: and Lindstrøm. The line-up's been so diverse
column7: it's interesting it took until now to ask Röyksopp to curate an entry: the group's always showcased a smart design sense as well as an open acknowledgement of other music's influence on their work. Unsurpisingly then
column8: on their 19-track collection
column9: the veteran Norwegian dance duo's instincts on curation and sequencing are top-notch
column10: offering a feeling that's sweetly compelling but gently guarded.

column1: “Daddy’s Groove”
column2: the duo's sole original contribution to Late Night Tales
column3: is the opener. In light of Daft Punk’s retro doings this year
column4: the title
column5: the treated vocals
column6: and the easy pulsing pace of the song feel shaped by larger trends. Röyksopp also offer a studio recording of early Depeche Mode B-side “Ice Machine”. Their version features fellow Norwegian performer Susanne Sundfør on lead vocals and a generally faithful take in the main arrangement with a slow
column7: dramatic start to give it its own flavor. Sundfør’s lead vocals contrast nicely with a brief midsong break from the duo.

column1: Röyksopp's selections generally live somewhere in a late-1970s/early-80s setting. The most compelling include Tuxedomoon’s “In a Manner of Speaking”
column2: a showcase for part-time member Winston Tong’s portrayal of romantic miscommunication over a stark arrangement of nervous guitar and distant swirls
column3: Vangelis’ “Blade Runner Blues”
column4: a pure synthesizer realization of the late-night and disconnected melancholy of Blade Runner that steers clear of the pounding doom of its end theme
column5: and F. R. David’s remarkable synth ballad “Music”
column6: which sounds like a Eurovision winner with all heart and inspiraiton and no irony
column7: even 30 years after it was originally written.

column1: There are also choices that merrily trash received ideas of coolness. Like “Stranger on the Shore”
column2: Acker Bilk’s clarinet-lined Easy Listening smash from the early 60s
column3: which is a kind of outlier from the midcentury that nails both big band jazz and romantic film music. Ready to be reclaimed by the cassette/chillwave generation
column4: Andreas Vollenweider's 1981 track “Hands and Clouds” is a brief bit of swirling delicacy that sounds like a lost track from the high point of West Coast radio stations like the Wave. Meanwhile
column5: the neo-classical impulses of acts like Johann Johannsson
column6: whose composition of strings and deep electronic bass plus voice of “Odi Et Amo” features here
column7: showcase a further connection at work.

column1: Part of this Late Night Tales' joy lies in the atypicality of the choices from bands that might not seem to fit at first. “The Somnambulist” is an XTC B-side recorded in 1980
column2: when the group was peeling out energetic brawlers like “Generals and Majors” and “Life Begins at the Hop
column3: ” but the song consists solely of Andy Partridge’s voice in a calmly sung undertone over a moody keyboard/drum machine riff. Thomas Dolby’s similarly chirpier side is exchanged for a slower grooving funk punch on “Budapest by Blimp”
column4: itself acting as a callback to earlier numbers on the disc like Vangelis and Rare Bird’s 1977 effort “Passing Through”
column5: while still standing out in its own right
column6: concluding choir vocals and all. This Mortal Coil's showcased not through something overfamiliar like “Song to the Siren”
column7: but via their live-in-a-room sounding cover of Emmy Lou Harris’s “Till I Can Gain Control Again”.

column1: There's a sweetly consistent mood throughout; it’s something you can put on and treat as ambient sound
column2: but there’s also a clever subtlety in their process. Rare Bird’s entry leads into the similarly paced and feeling “Light of Day” by the Little River Band from three years later
column3: but the latter’s lusher harmonies-- not to mention string accompaniment-- feel like a wider development of the easy
column4: understated swing already introduced by the former song. Following the steady
column5: descending feeling of “Music” with Prelude’s reverb-heavy a capella 1974 cover of Neil Young’s “After the Goldrush” is breathtaking. Immediately continuing with the literal wave crashes and bossa nova lounge lizardry of Richard Schneider Jr.’s 1977 cut “Hello Beach Girls” maintains and reworks that mood
column6: Schneider’s occasional laughs and smooth smarm a remarkable contrast to Prelude’s steady
column7: angelic approach.

column1: The collection ends with English actor Benedict Cumberbatch continuing his spoken word story from last fall's Friendly Fires entry in the series. The tale of a night out and house party is not quite of a piece with the rest
column2: but it is a literal late night tale-- and
column3: hey
column4: why not stick with a theme? In any event
column5: ending on a note that's both ruminative and engaging works well with Röyksopp’s intent
column6:
fitting into the overall series with a yacht-rock-for-fjords feeling that's all its own.

"|18168.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18168-royksopp-late-night-tales/|7.4|Ned Raggett

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19460/homepage_large.c638fc34.jpg|Embracism|30536.0|Kirin J Callinan|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['XL'
column2: 'Siberia'
column3:
'Terrible']|2013-07-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:50.104411|"

Kirin J Callinan has some pretty conventional ways of establishing himself as an unconventional
column4: provocative artist. The Australian native sings and more often howls in a louche
column5: heavily accented brogue that rarely has much use for cadence or strict melody-- a confrontational pose that startles the listener into attention. He also performs solo
column6: looping his guitar and vocals through a battery of effects and headsets
column7: relieving you of the temptation to focus your eyes elsewhere. During a recent show in Los Angeles
column8: he wore Stars and Stripes boxers and asked the crowd if it would be a federal crime to shit his pants. He then performed the last two songs in nothing but his underwear. Typical stuff
column9: but nonetheless
column10: Callinan manages to distinguish himself on a basic songwriting level with his debut album. While most of his peers deal with matters of the heart and head
column11: Embracism is a physical record
column12: one of grabbing hands
column13: gnashing teeth
column14: and thrusting groins. It holds a mirror up to the human body and reveals something alternately beautiful
column15: hairy
column16: awkward
column17: scarred and imperfect
column18: but rarely less than fascinating.

column1: While Embracism is a treatise
column2: it’s not some sort of high-minded dissertation. On the title track
column3: one of the year’s most riveting singles
column4: Callinan snarls the only question that seems to matter to him: “Do you measure up? Or do you still got work to do?” Contrary to the assumption that man has become a sedentary and domesticated animal in 2013
column5: “Embracism” lays out his waking life as a constant struggle to prove one’s mettle
column6: on the schoolyard
column7: in the boardroom
column8: in the bedroom
column9: or “on the internet
column10: RIGHT NOW!” The only difference between any of these competitive arenas is the skew of the “passive-aggressive” ratio; it’s all the same combat to satisfy primal urges for sex and the upper hand. It's best expressed on non-album track “MSBT & Wait”
column11: a scorched earth screed on platonic relationships where Callinan doesn't want to hear he's just a friend: ""I feel used... He would fuck you/ He masturbates/ And you share my secrets with him.""

column1: Callinan particularly relishes playing the wounded alpha male
column2: and whether it’s a nasty breakup or death
column3: loss hangs over Embracism. It’s always rendered in tactile ways and between the erratic shrapnel of percussion
column4: jagged guitar
column5: and Callinan’s serrated vocals
column6: you’re going to feel Embracism. “Chardonnay Sean” plays out more like a graveside confession than a song
column7: as Callinan expresses guilt at what appears to be a fatal drunk driving incident
column8: picking through the shards of a windshield and wine glass. Conversely
column9: “Scraps” deals with a much different kind of automotive disaster
column10: a remorseless revenge fantasy where the offending party rests “compacted with the scraps of my Nissan.""

column1: So clearly
column2: Callinan’s got issues to sort out
column3: as does Embracism. That whole Hampton bit in Kanye West's “New Slaves” proved that the obvious double entendre promised by “Come on USA” can still be virile
column4: but the phallic shock and awe here lies limp when you can't discern whether lines like “the land of the free/ Is not what it claims to be"" and ""I cry when I listen to Springsteen"" are commenting on cliche or just cliche themselves. And while “Scraps” and “Chardonnay Sean” are intriguing narratives
column5: they're stuck in ponderous musical arrangements; the effect of sequencing them consecutively puts Embracism in a serious mid-album lull.

column1: But you get the sense of an artist whose songwriting potential hasn’t been maximized
column2: as Callinan’s got the vocal chops to keep Embracism interesting throughout. The industrial grind of “Halo” introduces Callinan as some instinct-driven
column3: proto-human being
column4: skulking out of primordial ooze
column5: and “Landslide” casts him every bit as effective as a balladeer when he works within a tight structure. Thanks to the production and mixing of Kim Moyes (the Presets) and Grizzly Bear’s Chris Taylor
column6: Embracism remains fidgety and unbalanced in service of its narrator-- even the imperial pomp-rock of “Victoria M” can’t play it quite straight.

column1: It’s one of the instances that suggest Callinan isn’t a cynic so much as a disillusioned romantic. You can hear aerobic electro rock workouts “Stretch It Out” and “Way II War” as self-help mantras
column2: where you can physically work your way into right thinking. And on the closing “Love Delay”
column3: you understand why Bruce Springsteen gets Callinan all teary-eyed. He lasciviously stares down a disrobed lover and communes with fire over nothing more than severely pitch-shifted guitars
column4: a naked performance that renders the title literal. And then
column5: no more delay-- Embracism hurtles towards a finish in a manner that’s more shocking than what preceded it
column6: largely because it’s such a conventional crowd-pleasing rush of distorted bass
column7: rafter-reaching yells
column8: and the first appearance of a traditional drum kit. If Callinan continues on this tack
column9: he just may end up singing it in arenas
column10: but for the time being
column11: “Love Delay” is an apt closer for his initial phase. After all
column12:
“Love Delay” underlines what the title track suggests as an answer to every misunderstanding in our overly talkative society: let’s hug it out.

"|18266.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18266-kirin-j-callinan-embracism/|7.4|Ian Cohen

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19477/homepage_large.eaef4ef1.jpg|Southeastern|5343.0|Jason Isbell|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thirty Tigers'
column2:
'Southeastern']|2013-07-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:50.723897|"

In recent interviews with the New York Times Magazine and the Wall Street Journal
column3: Jason Isbell has been admirably forthcoming about his alcoholism
column4: admitting that he can’t remember much of the time he spent with the Drive-By Truckers
column5: who decided to move on without him after several attempts at rehabilation. Isbell's solo albums
column6: especially his 2009 self-titled LP and 2011’s Here We Rest
column7: ended up sounding cursory
column8: as though he was trying too hard and not hard enough; there were too many go-nowhere genre excursions and not enough focused storytelling. It didn’t help that the music sounded too polished
column9: too polite
column10: too professional
column11: with too little grit and personality.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Isbell’s story appears to have a happy third act. His friends confronted him about his drinking and checked him into rehab
column3: and he emerged sober
column4: determined
column5: and newly focused. He got married (to the fiddler/songwriter Amanda Shires
column6: who spearheaded his intervention)
column7: stayed clean
column8: and recorded a new album<i>
column9: Southeastern. To his considerable credit
column10: Isbell has very little interest in recounting his long fall or his darkest moments. This album doesn’t wallow in alcoholic squalor; its real subject is not what it means to hit rock bottom
column11: but what happens after you pick yourself up. How do you allow yourself any kind of contentment or security when you’ve done such bad things? How do you live with that dark half lurking just offstage?

column1: Isbell the storyteller knows this is rich subject matter
column2: as the day-to-day conflict of not taking that next drink or not falling back into old ways proves much more compelling and humanizing than the non-conflict of simply bottoming out. That approach makes Southeastern his most gripping and his most personal album to date. “Live Oak”
column3: the dark heart of the album
column4: opens with Isbell singing a cappella: “There’s a man who walks besides me
column5: he is who I used to be / I wonder if she sees him and confuses him with me.” It’s a deeply revealing line
column6: but “Live Oak” isn’t a direct confession from Isbell. Instead
column7: it’s a piece of fiction about a murderer wandering Pre-Civil War America who finds tentative redemption with a forgiving woman. It does not have a happy ending.

column1: Isbell inhabits similar men throughout Southeastern
column2: and there’s a new clarity in these characters to match the new vigor in his voice. To an extent they become proxies to recount Isbell’s own recent transformation
column3: which prevents the album from becoming too hermetically introverted. As a storyteller
column4: he has a generous empathy toward the people inhabiting his songs
column5: most of whom display a hard-won humanity despite the extremes of their situations.

column1: On “Elephant”
column2: a barfly tries to comfort a friend dying of cancer
column3: unsure what to do but finally understanding that just being there and raising a toast is enough to ensure she doesn’t die alone. It’s an epic rebuke of those hideous cancer ballads that infected mainstream country music for so many years; when Rascal Flatts hear a line like
column4: “There’s one thing that’s real clear to me: No one dies with dignity
column5: ” they ought to just pack in their Ed Hardy shirts and head home. An emotional kneecapping
column6: “Elephant” is a standout on Southeastern
column7: but for once it’s not one of two or three. Rather
column8: it’s a crucial part of a statement album
column9: one that draws as much from literary influences-- Peter Matthiessen
column10: Shelby Foote
column11: Colum McCann-- as from musical ones.

column1: Southeastern is easily Isbell’s best solo album-- his most richly conceived and generously written. If it’s not quite the album that lives up to his considerable talents
column2: it’s mostly the music that’s to blame. The production
column3: courtesy of Dave Cobb
column4: tends to buff away the rough edges of Isbell’s songs
column5: which can rob his stories of impact and nuance. It’s not the 400 Unit backing him this time
column6: but this group of musicians can’t sell the rocker “Super 8” or give it the boisterous urgency it demands. It threatens to become make-do country rock
column7: lacking the specificity and idiosyncrasy of Isbell’s songwriting. Perhaps it’s fitting that the one instrument that stands out is Shires’ fiddle
column8:
which eddies and shimmies throughout “Traveling Alone” before adding a solo as eloquently understated as Isbell’s chorus. Of course they have chemistry.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19166/homepage_large.42c2fc5a.jpg|Spiritoso|650.0|Calexico|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-'

'City Slang']|2013-07-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:51.214881|"

The songs “Trigger” and “Frontera” first appeared on Calexico’s 1998 album
column3: The Black Light
column4: when the duo were still as minimalist as they were minimal. The former is a tense story-song whose impact derives from its restraint; Joey Burns delivers the tale of tragedy in a conspiratorial whisper
column5: as though passing along gossip at a highway cantina
column6: and John Convertino-- even then one of the most inventive drummers around-- punctuates the violence with hard hits of his splash cymbal. “Frontera”
column7: by contrast
column8: sounds like the opening credits for some forgotten spaghetti western
column9: with a shuffling beat
column10: a barbed-wire tangle of guitar
column11: and horns that announce the director of photography with appropriate grandeur. The scope on both songs is small
column12: personal
column13: and intimate
column14: with ambitions that transcend the low budget.

column1: In the 15 years since the release of The Black Light
column2: those two songs have evolved dramatically from their original arrangements
column3: gradually merging into one song that pops up from time to time on Calexico’s setlist. “Frontera/Trigger” is the opener and highlight of the band’s new live album
column4: <i>Spiritoso
column5: and the differences between this version and the song’s previous incarnations underscore just how far Burns and Convertino have come in a decade
column6: not to mention all that has been lost and gained along the way. Featuring the Vienna Radio Symphony Orchestra
column7: the song rumbles with thundering tympani
column8: baroque strings
column9: great blasts of brass
column10: and what sounds like a klezmer band being heaved into Monument Valley. Together
column11: the two songs become a widescreen
column12: Technicolor epic of John Ford proportions
column13: announcing that Calexico’s original ambitions have finally been matched with the means to realize them.

column1: Originally a Record Store Day exclusive
column2: Spiritoso documents a series of shows Calexico performed in Germany with the Vienna Radio Symphony Orchestra and the Deutsches Filmorchester Babelsberg. Much like last year’s vinyl box set Road Atlas
column3: this live album has a casual retrospective feel
column4: culling songs from throughout the band’s career but with no real attempt to be definitive. And much like the separate tour-only albums that comprised <i>Road Atlas
column5: it will most likely sound better as a complement to other live albums-- like 2009’s Live in Nuremberg or the upcoming Ancienne Belgique Vol. 2-- than it does as a stand-alone release.

column1: Given the increasing scale of Calexico’s records
column2: which have outgrown the minimalism of their first releases
column3: an orchestral live album seems inevitable in retrospect. Once considered a sign of a rock artist’s delusional self-regard
column4: this kind of collaboration no longer carries the stigma it might have in the past. To their credit
column5: Calexico aren’t interested in using these orchestras to prove the importance of their own music. Rather than reinvent the songs
column6: they accentuate and amplify the non-rock aspects that Calexico have long ago mastered: the soundtrack flourishes
column7: the mariachi horn riffs
column8: the jazzbo rhythms. “The News About William” bounces on its spry woodwind triplets
column9: which mimic the rhythms of Convertino’s drums. “Black Heart” swells and fades ominously
column10: like John Barry conveying intrigue and foreboding. It sounds like the greatest James Bond theme never used.

column1: In other words
column2: very little on Spiritoso sounds too far removed from its original incarnation
column3: and nothing is nearly as transformative as “Frontera/Trigger”
column4: which is the only song that truly shows off the possibilities of Calexico + orchestra. “Minas de Cobre”
column5: another Black Light tune
column6: is revved up and tricked out but maintains its original shape
column7: while “Crystal Frontier” opens with a slow epilogue-- Burns setting the stage for his tale of the ancient among the modern-- before launching into its familiar fast tempo. Despite the strong performances and some inspired choices in arrangement
column8: the album has the pall of a missed opportunity: not bad at all
column9:
but certainly not the major statement it could have been.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19442/homepage_large.1a940b8e.jpg|Me Moan|30241.0|Daughn Gibson|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2013-07-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:51.890136|"

Having a voice like Daughn Gibson’s must be kind of a burden. It’s such a deep
column2: sonorous
column3: chesty thing that carrying it around must weigh on him
column4: and every lyric feels like a bench press. It’s a physical gift that doubles as a restriction. When you’ve got the ability to conjure Johnny Cash or any other basso profundo like Gibson
column5: your artistic direction is laid out for you-- you’re probably not gonna make punk or R&B. That was quite all right on last year’s All Hell
column6: an intriguing confluence of sampling and songwriting. It was something like Odelay if Beck's record was culled entirely from episodes of ""Cops"" and the kind of country cassettes available at truckstops. Otherwise
column7: it sounded like nothing else. On Me Moan
column8: his Sub Pop debut<i>
column9: Gibson wisely attempts to maintain the immediate draw of his authoritative vocals and perspective without making an exact replica of his first album. It’s an uneven record that lacks the spark of its predecessor
column10: but a more diverse and accessible follow-up from an artist who’s laudably willing to take risks.

column1: Compared to All Hell
column2: Me Moan is more an album of various “songs” than a unified sound. And now
column3: Gibson is coaxing music out of human beings (including members of Baroness and Brokeback) rather than samplers. He’s still treating it all like a rummage sale
column4: even if the budget has emboldened his taste for chintz and levity. Gibson’s voice will undoubtedly draw more comparisons to golden country greats
column5: though the closest Me Moan gets to any sort of “roots” music might be the cocaine cowboy balladry of “Won’t You Climb”. Otherwise
column6: the songs here are pieced together with bagpipes
column7: melodica
column8: drum machines
column9: and warped samples
column10: adding rhinestone to Gibson’s trucker flannels. Even the one thing that sounds like it could be plucked out under the Mississippi moonlight (“All My Days Off”) has a riff that could easily segue into David Banner’s “Cadillac On 22’s”.

column1: But there’s the burden of his voice: like the terribly uncoordinated klutz who got put on the basketball team because he’s the tallest guy in school or the diffident offensive lineman with the thyroid condition
column2: Gibson can seem pressed into action out of some kind of physical obligation. You just can’t hide with that baritone and so Gibson figures he might as well stand out as much as possible. The choruses of “Phantom Rider” and “Mad Ocean” teeter on kitsch based solely on their lyrics and Gibson delivers them with extra “we’re gonna move that convoy” gusto.

column1: This approach works on Me Moan’s more campy material
column2: but when he tries to convey menace over Alabama 3-style beats on “You Don’t Fade”
column3: he sounds retrograde instead of classicist; all that's missing is a video of Gibson chomping a cigar on the New Jersey Turnpike. Gibson’s hampered on the emotionally bare songs as well. “Franco” is Me Moan’s most immediately striking number
column4: with chalky guitar harmonics and sobering reverb evoking a slippery-when-wet power ballad that shifts the focus from the docks of New Jersey to a trailer park somewhere. The ache in the chorus is palpable
column5: as Gibson yearns to a tired lover
column6: “I wish we had a kid that never wanted to die.” It’s a situation that begs for an earnest performance
column7: but Gibson leans hard on the vowels in “campfire” and ""hour"" to the point where they sound like they’re curdling in his mouth (""camp-foyer"" and ""orrrrrrr
column8: respectively). “Franco” is meant to be a tearjerker
column9: but sometimes it feels like it’s poking you in the eye.

column1: Otherwise
column2: there’s a glaring disjunction between the detail of the music and the lack thereof in Gibson’s lyrics. Me Moan leaves a little too much to the imagination
column3: and you might think that a year as a touring musician didn’t give Gibson as much raw material as his time in the cabin of an 18-wheeler. His more suggestive form of storytelling works on “The Sound of Law”: Gibson’s born on the roadside to an outlaw
column4: more specifically
column5: a beast of a man who doesn’t just kill
column6: he “blows that fucker off to hell.” Though specifics are scarce
column7: the music lets you fill in the blanks
column8: as the charging drum rolls and girded guitar riffs generate the momentum of a moving train
column9: plotting a perfect visual for a family that has to up and leave town at the faintest whine of a police siren.

column1: But elsewhere
column2: while the tone of Gibson’s vocals convey truth and wisdom
column3: the songs rarely feel populated with fully drawn characters or narratives. Places like Lynn Falls and Pisgee Nest and the Rio Bar and Grill sound like where a character in a Daughn Gibson song might hang out
column4: even if they’re not necessarily real. Over the span of <i>Me Moan
column5: this lack of geography starts to wear. Both “The Pisgee Nest” and “Kissin on the Blacktop” have evocative lines in their choruses that makes you want to lean in closer; yet they’re incomplete
column6: memories or images of a state trooper’s daughter or a devious middle school friend that he couldn’t quite bring to life just yet. The result doesn’t take Gibson’s music off the open road
column7: it just replaces mystery with mundanity: while All Hell felt imbued with danger and intrigue
column8: on Me Moan
column9:
the people pulled off to highway shoulder are never in any real distress upon closer inspection. They just stepped out to check a map.

"|18248.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18248-daughn-gibson-me-moan/|6.3|Ian Cohen

Freddie Gibbs has said that his new project ESGN is ""the definitive Freddie Gibbs album
column2: an uncompromising
column3: unvarnished collection of the blacktop-hard gangster rap that vaulted him to a higher profile in the summer of 2009. Gibbs' desire to return to his most authentic sound springs from a less-than-amicable split from Young Jeezy’s CTE label in 2012
column4: and he isn't necessarily mistaken. ESGN is more of the dark
column5: violent
column6: exceedingly skillful rap for which the rapper has become one of the last reliable sources.

column1: But ESGN is ultimately a step back for a rapper who had worked to increase the variety of his sound and the depth of his subject matter in recent years. In the fashion of the 1990s gangster rap albums Gibbs came up with
column2: ESGN has 20 tracks. That’s over an hour of unyielding
column3: uncompromising music which displays plenty of ability but very little imagination. Gibbs had managed to widen his appeal with tapes like Cold Day in Hell and Baby Face Killa
column4: but now he's back working in an incredibly specific space
column5: one that will win him accolades from heads but which can’t help but to be exhausting for anyone who likes a little variety in their rap diet.

column1: Many of the songs on ESGN can be seen as direct repudiation of industry rap
column2: marked as they are by violence
column3: pain
column4: regret and religiosity
column5: all of which are heavily out of fashion at the moment. He refers to the “pussy boys” in the music industry on “Came Up” and then later expands
column6: rapping that he “won’t be a monkey for them crackers like I’m LL” and taking direct shots at Young Jeezy. The sniping comes off both as honest and defensive
column7: Gibbs' simmering resentment at his former label
column8: which he's given voice to in multiple interviews
column9: finally finding a musical outlet.

column1: Gibbs is at his absolute technical best on ESGN
column2: and it’s worthwhile to take a closer look at what he does so well. “Eastside Moonwalker”
column3: the title a reference to the most famous Gary native of all time
column4: is a perfect example of the form
column5: Gibbs switching bars and lanes
column6: zooming in to capture specific moments in time and then out again to shit-talk. ""Freddie Soprano"" is a showcase for quickhitting cleverness
column7: with a pop-culture savvy that lends dark comedy to its gangsterisms. Both songs are examples of perfectly regimented rapping
column8: with the shifts in cadence and perfect breath-control of hip-hop formalism inspired by the greats.

column1: Gibbs’ resemblance to his idol Tupac is becoming ever more obvious and the rapper seems to be using his intonation to make the comparisons stick. “I Seen a Man Die” could pass for an extra from the Don Killuminati sessions with its yearning West Coast production and another track
column2: “F.A.M.E.”
column3: includes a spot from the Tha Dogg Pound legend Daz Dillinger. (The track also features Spice 1
column4: the two guests representing a kind of bifurcation of Gibbs’ production sound
column5: which tends to split the difference between Southern and West Coast rap.)

column1: Too often though
column2: Gibbs uses his technical ability and knowledge of rap classics to disguise a lack of substance. Songs like “Lay it Down” contribute nothing but more time to the record: as well-delivered as the lyrics are
column3: the song comes across as dull and unoriginal. The chorus of “9mm” is as tired as the song’s concept
column4: and Gibbs’ insistence on including contributions from anonymous crew members like Hit “Skrewface
column5: ” Big Kill
column6: and G-Wiz further implicates Gibbs in his unwillingness to stretch. When all of his cohorts are spitting boilerplate gangster shit
column7: the thinness of subject matter here becomes ever more obvious.

column1: There are slight deviations in sound
column2: all of which are welcome. “Dope in My Styrofoam"" is a breezy
column3: Southern style riding anthem complete with a loop of sampled chorus girls. “Lose Control” features singing from BJ the Chicago Kid that momentarily lightens the mood. There's also plenty of of sterling rap music here that Gibbs fans won't have any issue with: “Hundred Thousand”
column4: “I Seen a Man Die”
column5: ""Have U Seen Her""
column6: “Eastside Moonwalker”
column7: and “Freddie Soprano” are some of Gibbs’ best songs to date
column8: overwhelming displays of rap virtuosity that
column9: had they been released a decade ago
column10: we'd consider classics today. To damn them for being of a kind is to miss the point.

column1: On “Hundred Thousand""
column2: Gibbs supplies a perfect-- and
column3: true to form
column4: concise-- review of ESGN himself. “Ain’t trying to be the man
column5: just trying to maintain.” Callin an album ""more of the same"" sounds dismissive but its something that fans are often happy to receive and there are those for whom 20 tracks of Gibbs rapping nearly perfectly will be enough. But for everyone else
column6: ESGN comes as an unwelcome reversion to the mean. It’s the sound of a rapper more than happy to maintain his narrow lane after being burned by the industry
column7: one who's lost the ambition to leave his comfort zone
column8:
at least for the time being.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19455/homepage_large.d773c181.jpg|Swisher|28242.0|Blondes|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2013-07-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:53.105292|"

Techno’s narrative of robot soul is music-mythologising at its most seductive and I suspect Brooklyn duo Blondes think about this myth. Last year’s self-titled collection of singles offered up tech-house (with the emphasis on the “house”) at its most unabashedly pretty
column2: all glittering chime loops and warm basslines
column3: and sometimes even the gentle nourishment of a piano vamp. Blondes ploughed this furrow so intently that it felt like a cohesive statement
column4: and one that it was difficult to imagine the duo adjusting it-- let alone surpassing it-- any time soon.

column1: Follow-up Swisher doesn’t abandon the beauty of the duo’s earlier work (“Andrew” and “Rei” could easily be lifted from last year’s album) but it uses it more judiciously. This shift makes Swisher less immediately captivating but somehow more involving than its predecessor
column2: establishing the ultimate core of the duo’s aesthetic somewhere deeper and altogether more mysterious. How to reconcile the gentle machine-clanking of opener “Aeon”-- like a lost treasure from Aphex Twin’s Selected Ambient Works 85-92-- with the frozen expanses of the appropriately-titled “Poland”
column3: or that with the urgent stop-start stalk of “Clasp”
column4: which harkens back to Dettinger at his most ambitious? These tunes are less distant from one another in strict stylistic terms than in function and intention: The underlying dynamic feels slippery and difficult to pin down
column5: but united in its sense of purpose. This shift in tone coincides so closely with the move away from house and towards techno proper that it’s probably pointless to detangle them.

column1: What carries over from the debut to these undeniably colder
column2: more shadowed arrangements is the naturalism of Blondes’ production
column3: pointillist in precision but still organic in feel. At its most steely and forbidding
column4: Swisher aspires to the kind of warmth-in-coldness of Basic Channel
column5: the percussion like tiny blades gently scraping at the surface of your ears
column6: and urgent low drones like locust clouds hovering below eyeshot. “Bora Bora” builds to a torrent of feedback before relaxing into an outro of unexpectedly Latin-infused percussion
column7: and it’s a mark of just how good Blondes are that they can execute transmutations like this so effortlessly and near-imperceptibly. Similarly
column8: the title track creates an entire gas-planet ecosystem of scratching snare patterns
column9: sighing new age synth rushes
column10: and disorienting
column11: bubbling churns
column12: through which a restless Carl Craig arpeggio coalesces like a nascent life form attempting to will itself into existence.

column1: Rounding out Swisher is “Elise”
column2: which threatens to overshadow all that has preceded in its singularity and directness. The kind of winsome
column3: heart-in-mouth epic for which Jürgen Paape or Superpitcher were once beloved
column4: its nagging chime melody
column5: swishing house percussion
column6: and hesitantly flirty bass pulses evoke the human where elsewhere there is only the sentient. If it wasn’t so lovely
column7: it would seem like a cop-out. Instead
column8: it’s a gift
column9: and a reminder of how the familiar emerges out of the foreign
column10: interpersonal meaning out of seemingly meaningless biological process. As myth-making goes
column11:

Sometimes confined spaces offer as much possibility as wide-open plains. American composer Keith Fullerton Whitman deliberately streamlined his process for this split EP with Belgian electronic artist Floris Vanhoof. ""I've been liking the idea more recently of putting out these recordings that are just single ideas
column3: he said in a recent interview. So here we get subtle variations on a theme
column4: spread over four tracks culled from the same modular synth patch. It's tightly controlled work by Whitman's standards
column5: with the first three tracks all barely making it over the three-minute mark. Vanhoof works with similar tools-- essentially a modular set-up he created himself-- but ventures further into the stratosphere
column6: creating a single 19-minute piece full of bleeps and drones. His work is notably softer than Whitman's
column7: providing the balm to his storm.

column1: Music composed within tight parameters
column2: using few chords and a limited sonic palette
column3: often feels meditative or hypnotic (or both). Holger Czukay's bass in Can's imposing ""Yoo Doo Right"" almost has the same pacifying qualities as a children's lullaby in the quieter portions of the song. Whitman doesn't take that route here
column4: instead choosing to see how many sharp corners he can bump into with the tools at his disposal. His first three tracks are wrapped up in a form of deterioration
column5: driven by rhythms that barely follow logical patterns
column6: manic analog synthesis
column7: and blocky electronic forms that sputter into malformed life. At times it feels like he's antagonizing his equipment to the point of pain
column8: looking for that peculiar spot where machines appear to make very human responses.

column1: Despite tendencies toward decay
column2: there's nothing here as overtly confrontational as
column3: say
column4: ""Occlusion (Rue de Bitche)"" from Whitman's 2012 record
column5: Occlusions. Instead
column6: much of this material reaches for a warmer
column7: brighter space
column8: typified by the lightly criss-crossing patterns of ""Automatic Drums With Melody"". It makes for a neat outward juxtaposition to Vanhoof's single contribution
column9: which plunges far deeper into introspection. Whitman says the two met when Vanhoof toured with the ultra-tranquil Dolphins into the Future
column10: whose undersea take on New Age tropes is in a vaguely similar orbit. His ""De Karekiet van Karakas"" is all deeply pulsing oscillations pitched against light trickles of machine noise
column11: forming a track so abyssal it creates an abstract world all of its own
column12: where the music speaks its own strange language.

column1: So the bond between Whitman and Vanhoof's work stretches far beyond their similar interest in primitive electronics. Both reach a point where aspects of the physical world seep into their sound. For Vanhoof
column2: elements are pulled from the animal kingdom
column3: sometimes overtly in the form of noises that resemble sea life
column4: but more interestingly when the shapes he creates resemble a peculiar type of life of their own. Tiny figures loop and flourish then fade
column5: like amoebas fluttering momentarily into life. Whitman appears concerned with making the equipment itself bleed out
column6: poking and prodding at it until the response is somewhere more personal than the standard man-machine interface. There’s overlap here for sure
column7:
but both artists find singular moments of beauty from each vantage point.
