column3: ideas become cornerstones
column4: cornerstones become rules
column5: rules become clichés
column6: clichés become memes-- and memes are made to be subverted. AraabMuzik is one of the unlikeliest crossover stars to jump from hip-hop production to festival-scale electronic bass music
column7: and it's largely because he treats that latter genre in the context of the former. Albums like Electronic Dream and For Professional Use Only took an approach to beat-extending
column8: break-isolating mixing that goes back four decades
column9: and drew out some of the moodier
column10: wilder elements of his source material using the oldest trick in the hip-hop book: repossessing the entire intent of a song by isolating one specific stretch of it.

column1: So much of the material that AraabMuzik's been dealing with over the past few years
column2: from arena dubstep to pop-chart trance
column3: rides on peaks-and-valleys successions of build-ups to bombastic peaks. AraabMuzik's mutation of that dynamic into a steady
column4: prolonged all-peaks churn is the key: who says you have to wait for the drop? In that sense
column5: The Remixes Vol. 1 isn't significantly different than his previous records' approaches. There's more of a feel of “official” business to it; much of the source material comes from the Ultra Music label and skews closer to the Electric Daisy Carnival aesthetic than anything AraabMuzik's worked with to date. But that's the closest there is to a unifying background to The Remixes
column6: which really does make his own choppily momentous
column7: joyously abrasive
column8: and widely sourced sense of rhythm the biggest common denominator.

column1: Mt. Eden's “Sierra Leone” is a sort of mission statement. In its original form
column2: it's as steadily composed and fluid as wobbly bass anthems get
column3: a balanced split between hard bombast and billowy emotion that might sound like a maximalist Clams Casino if you stripped out all the wubs. Which is just what AraabMuzik does at the outset
column4: juicing it up with orchestra hits and rearranging the beat so it's more distinctly hip-hop-friendly. And once the wobble-bass does get dropped in
column5: it's more of a rumbling shudder than the hyperactive hiccups in the original. Further elements of AraabMuzik's style show up in more transformative moments
column6: like the nearly from-scratch rebuild of Wolfgang Gartner's Omarion-featuring “Still My Baby”. That cut revamps its tweaky electro house chords into a more spread-out melody that stalks like a 1980s slasher-flick villain over a more traditional house 4/4
column7: then unexpectedly disintegrates into a puddle of rattling snares that make a point of proving why the best trap comes from a miles-deep hip-hop grounding.

column1: Not that The Remixes Vol. 1 pins him to any genre constraints. Style trumps niche every time here
column2: and in its efficiently compact sub-hour runtime there's plenty of opportunity to let that style run through all kind of territory. His take on Skrillex's omnipresent remix of Benny Benassi's “Cinema” cuts to the chase
column3: as AraabMuzik lets that hyperventilating gatling-laser drop loop for long enough to make its overamped malfunctioning slot-machine spasm feel as simple and immediate as the “Ante Up” horns. Steve Aoki's Kid Cudi/Travis Barker collab “Cudi the Kid” is saved from its flabby trance-n-bass excess with a slick minor-key pitch shift and a regrouping around a martial
column4: mid-tempo slice of breakbeat. It's ambitious recontextualization
column5: even if it gets away from him a little: another Gartner cut
column6: “Cognitive Dissonance”
column7: lives up to the title with some abrupt borderline-trainwreck swings from electro to boom-bap that would work together as individual pieces. And his soulful remix of Taana Gardner's 81 b-boy disco staple “Heartbeat” sticks out amidst all this top-dollar superclub material like a banana-seat Schwinn Sting-Ray at the Tour de France
column8: though it's no big dealbreaker when the worst thing you can say about a mix selection is that it makes you wish he'd do an old-school all-West End Records set.

column2: characteristically enough

column4: and that's what continues to keep his material compelling. It's easy to hear the excitement and flashiness in his beats

column6: ditching crescendos for churn

column11: while a pretty straightforward money-flinging door-kicker with the MC on it
column12: shows up earlier as an instrumental that reveals some tense
column13: icy arpeggios driving those chattering snares. The other one's a sparse number featuring bleary
column14:
slowly floating chords and near-subliminal mournful choir vocals. The title? “Darkside”. Just so you know where he's coming from.

“Prolific” has long been the dominant adjective to describe Robert Pollard
column3: and even then it sounds like an understatement. Deep into his fifties
column4: he hasn’t lost a beat or slowed down a bit
column5: but instead churns out album after album after EP after one-off solo thing after album. Already in 2013 he has released a new Guided by Voices album
column6: a full-length under his Teenage Guitar pseudonym
column7: a singles box set
column8: and a 12”
column9: with who knows what all else planned for the next six months. It’s been this way for decades now
column10: such that Pollard’s chief trait as an artist is the frequency of his output. Consequently
column11: it’s all too easy to forget that he’s not just a prolific songwriter
column12: but a good songwriter
column13: too. Indie rock’s own Joyce Carol Oates possesses an insanely deep vocabulary of classic-rock tropes
column14: a facility with killer hooks
column15: and an idiosyncratic lyrical style that has matured to reveal new depths of wisdom
column16: humor
column17: and harrumphing crotchetiness.

column1: It should surprise exactly no-one that Honey Locust Honky Tonk is a good record: Even at his most unedited and undigested
column2: Pollard’s music still displays a joy in its own resourcefulness
column3: a contentment in its own faith in the power of rock and roll to define a life. In other words
column4: every release is worth spinning at least once. But it should surprise everyone that Honey Locust Honky Tonk is a very good record
column5: his best and most focused in quite some time. One byproduct of his prolific nature is a constant flattening out of his catalog
column6: so that everything
column7: especially at this end of his career
column8: begins to blur together; the highs never seem quite so exciting anymore
column9: the lows no longer quite so embarrassing
column10: and very little stands out as essential. That any particular release stands out at all is by now a small miracle.

column1: Pollard’s dedication to the form has always been impressive
column2: and he has remained largely untouched-- or unperturbed
column3: or uncompelled-- by outside forces or trends in rock and roll. Instead
column4: he has burrowed deeper and deeper into his beloved classic rock and has somehow managed to find new modes of expression in this tiny realm of music. “Circus Green Machine” builds on great bursts of acoustic guitar power chords that sound like Pete Townshend is about to spin a yarn
column5: while “Strange and Pretty Day”
column6: the album’s lowest-fi recording
column7: nods to Skip Spence or maybe Roky Erickson with its insistent one-note piano theme. By this point
column8: Pollard has even become his own reference point: Scuff up the sound a bit and “Airs” or “Igloo Hearts” wouldn’t be out of place on Bee Thousand or Alien Lanes.

column1: Even if it’s not hard to imagine a 30-something Pollard penning these new tunes
column2: Honey Locust Honky Tonk nevertheless sounds like the work of a man with some years and experience behind him. There’s some polish on the melodies
column3: a new forthrightness in the lyrics. And by forthright
column4: I mean how he repeats the pretzel-logic line
column5: “We may never not know
column6: ” ad infinitum on “It Disappears in the Least Likely Hands (We May Never Not Know)” and still makes it sound somehow poignant. There’s always been an odd melancholy to Pollard’s music
column7: but there’s a peculiar gravity to the psych-rockin’ “Her Eyes Play Tricks on the Camera” and the country-rockin’ “I Killed a Man Who Looks Like You”. A desperate gregariousness pervades the 44-second toast “I Have to Drink” and surely informs the camp-choir sing-along that ends “Real Fun Is No One’s Monopoly”.

column1: The guitars on Honey Locust Honky Tonk can be sluggish at times
column2: especially during the more cumbersome anthems
column3: and the tracklist could stand some pruning. But these are perennial complaints
column4: excusable for being bound up among his many eccentricities
column5: and Pollard compensates with what seems like a greater sense of mission. Mortality looms over <i>Honey Locust Honky Tonk
column6: explicitly defining songs like “Who Buries the Undertaker” while implicitly informing fragments like “Shielding Whatever Needs You”. Rather than dour
column7: however

column9: perhaps even worried

column11:
who sounds like a man who has said so much already but still has so much left to say.

Opening Without Your Love with a cameo from Butterclock
column3: a Berlin-based collaborator who whips cotton-candy love-trips out of sleepy melancholy

column5: Dexter’s music always sounded best when love was involved and there was someone there to help drive that stake through his heart. His earlier solo work was easily lumped in with the subgenre he refused to associate with
column6: but with the help of vocalists (and compelling vocal samples)
column7: oOoOO has always sounded like something bigger than a fad.

column1: With his debut full-length
column2: Dexter’s ear for dramatics is stronger than ever. He hasn’t strayed from the dimly lit brooding that took over oOoOO and Our Love Is Hurting Us
column3: but in the years since his style has moved out of the spotlight
column4: the musician has figured out what he wants to do with it: go pop. He’s mentioned a local train outside of his apartment window as inspiration while working on the album
column5: saying that the clattering on the tracks stopped him from dozing off. That dynamic is key here: Much of this album is a haze that sucks you in only to push back out when the listener comes too close to being enveloped in its cloudiness.

column1: Where Dexter's catalog has a tendency to quicksand around drone-like samples
column2: the production on Without Your Love is more focused than it’s ever been. On “Misunderstood”
column3: one of Without Your Love’s strongest tracks

column5: you’ll be doomed to listen to the song on repeat. But it’s here where Dexter's R&B flair comes through; when his vocal manipulations are as strong as his production technique. “Stay Here” harkens back to Our Love Is Hurting Us’ “Break Yr Heartt”
column6: and “Without Your Love” is practically cheery.

column1: There’s no way to avoid the gloom though
column2: and with it
column3: the witchy
column4: goth tropes to which oOoOO has invited assocation. With the album being released on Dexter’s own Night Feelings
column5: he’s undoubtedly trying to break out of that mold. But the dark
column6: gut-flipping menace pulls through despite the cleaner production. “Crossed Wires” is a staticky call from some sort of haunted monastery
column7: warped chanting and all. “Mouchette” floats airy croons and waves of synths over a fantastic hammering of industrial reverb. “The South” takes another route
column8: blending stuttering beats and flying wails into a trap instrumental that could easily host a rapper or two.

column1: It’s unclear if oOoOO has larger pop aspirations
column2: or if he’s making tracks with vocalists to play with the idea of straight R&B or rap production. If nothing else
column3: songs like “Across the Sea”
column4: with its sauntering groove
column5: melodic keys

column7: the ideas on Without Your Love are a little too disparate to indicate what he’s getting at. The sequencing helps

column9: overall

it’s still difficult to tell what direction he’s trying to lead us in. Without Your Love ends up becoming a loose survey of Dexter's work instead the Nihjgt Feelings statement he intended it to be.

One of the most impressive aspects of Oneida's post-Preteen Weaponry career is how lost to the world they sound. It's become hard to pin them down them at this point. They don't appear to have many peers
column2: or even particularly care about anything going on around them. It's easy to imagine them locked away in their Ocropolis studio in Brooklyn
column3: falling ever further into the cycles of repetition that gather around them like an impenetrable force whenever they play. People of the North is a side project from Oneida's Kid Millions and Bobby Matador
column4: a duo now onto their third album together
column5: and their first for Thrill Jockey. Sub Contra picks up where they left off on last year’s Steep Formations
column6: even bringing in the same guests
column7: Shahin Motia and Barry London. It's a short set of instrumental jams with a purposeful looseness in the playing
column8: often underpinned by a sense of gloom that loosely ties it to the last couple of Oneida records.

column1: The Ocropolis appears key in the making of this album and much of Millions and Matador's other works. Unshackled from the burden of recording against the clock and with no need to keep an eye on per-hour rates
column2: it feels like they dug far deeper into the music. It's difficult to picture Sub Contra coming out the way it has if they hadn't unlocked those freedoms. That liberation has brought them to a curious spot here
column3: one that's somewhere between fully formed ideas and first-thought improvisation. Millions is one of the tightest drummers in the business when he wants to be
column4: but on People of the North records he prefers a more scattershot approach
column5: sometimes appearing completely absorbed in his own world. For the twin ""Sub Contra 1"" and ""Sub Contra 2"" he skews into jazzy fills
column6: lightly playing around the exhaust-fume drones that char away at the center of the suite.

column1: What's most interesting about Sub Contra is the interplay between the two players and the guests they bring in. Sometimes it's tight
column2: focused
column3: locked into the same vision. At other times they wander off on individual tangents
column4: only to slowly drag each other back to the same point. ""Coal Baron"" is easily the highlight of the former work
column5: with its glassy ambient textures mirroring the more reflective work of krautrock bands such as Tangerine Dream
column6: Popol Vuh
column7: and Cluster. Krautrock has long been a touchstone for Oneida
column8: but mostly the driving
column9: fiercely hypnotic side of the genre. ""Coal Baron"" is People of the North getting in touch with gentler patterns
column10: subtly tracing out its rhythms through tiny organ figures and trance-y loops. In contrast
column11: the closing 14-minute ""Osage Orange"" demonstrates their wayward side
column12: with Millions coming perilously close to performing a drum solo before nailing it down into a harmonious place at its close.

column1: The shifts in style from Sub Contra further enforce the sense of near limitless flexibility and detachment that surrounds the guys in Oneida. Sometimes this feels like a glimpse into their studio process
column2: resembling a 40-minute snippet of tape cut from a few lengthy workouts that no doubt stretched long into the night. But there's a passion here that gives it more value than that
column3: a feeling that this is something they're compelled to do regardless of how accepting the outside world is to it. Sub Contra is a limited edition of just 500 vinyl copies

column5: it's quite the opposite. People of the North is a project that’s all about openness
column6: about laying processes bare
column7:
about welcoming people in to what would otherwise be a very private moment.

column1: <div dir=""ltr"">
<div dir=""ltr"">
<div dir=""ltr"">
Since 2007
column2: the members of West Coast post-punk trio Grass Widow have exuded a group dynamic so seamless their otherworldly three-part harmonies and disjointed melodies sound effortless. But such grace doesn’t come easily. In line with the kind of radical politics pushed around their hometown of San Francisco
column3: Grass Widow proudly self-identify as a leaderless band with a democratic songwriting process. When that type of consensus decision-making works
column4: it’s beautiful. But consensus is never an easy process: individuals often end up making compromises to accommodate the shared values of the group as a whole. With her solo project Ruby Pins
column5: Grass Widow drummer/singer Lillian Maring has stepped away from those limitations to spend time inside her own head and embrace her darker creative impulses. The result
column6: written over three years and self-recorded with a laptop and one microphone
column7: is a haunting collection of cryptic pop songs.

column1: Maring’s autonomous vision shines through its abstractions; through its way of shaping spooked moods with heavy
column2: cyclical drumbeats
column3: shadowy surf riffs
column4: and enigmatic wordless vocal hooks. Like in Grass Widow
column5: the vocals on Ruby Pins are consistently low in the mix
column6: veiled by home-recording hiss
column7: making space for Maring’s psychedelic guitars and spiraling keys to sing the stories just as much as her voice does. Sometimes
column8: Maring self-harmonizes for double-tracked parts
column9: deadpanning like a girl-gang of one (“Gagging on the Obvious”) while at other points she sings woozy pop melodies (“Lost Art”). The words are rarely audible
column10: but it always sounds like she’s trying to tell us something.

column1: The album starts with the dim and distant chugging riffs of “Chariot”
column2: an opener that sounds like a moving vehicle racing away. “My Friends Are Insane” could be a sketch pulled from Maring’s diary; her words are urgently plainspoken over echoes of murky instrumentals. “Girl Store” is similarly arcane and downcast
column3: a collage of what sounds like recorded conversations pieced together. A recurring high-pitched voice sounds like a little girl lost in a toy store: “ha ha ha
column4: ” she hums over shuffling circus-like percussion. “Begotten” contains barely any lyrics
column5: but is one of the most entrancing tracks on side B; a nightmarish four-minute jam that starts out with a mess of indecipherable words drowned out by a meandering minor-chord guitar line and speeding percussion. It'd make a good soundtrack for a haunted fun house.

column1: In a recent interview with East Bay Express surrounding the release of Ruby Pins
column2: Maring slowly unveiled some of the heavy baggage she was dragging around while writing lines like
column3: “No day is the right day to die/ No day is the right day to die” on ""Chameleon"". In 2010
column4: she lost her boyfriend to cancer
column5: and writing Ruby Pins was one way of grieving. While it's hard to forget such a tragic story
column6: it’s also not entirely necessary to know in order to sense the surreal
column7: ever-present gloom of Ruby Pins. In fact
column8: the obscured lyrics (the record doesn’t come with a lyric sheet) almost prevent Maring's personal life from driving the narrative of her debut. It further proves
column9: though
column10: that the most intrinsically human records are ones an artist makes entirely for herself.

Jay-Z and Kanye West's Watch the Throne was introduced by Frank Ocean parsing the respective qualities of gods and kings. Two years later
column3: both rappers have new solo albums that expound on the distinction. Kanye infamously proclaimed “I Am a God” on Yeezus; you could either gape in awe or call it heresy
column4: but you couldn’t doubt his conviction. And just as the brutal and blasphemous Yeezus is true to its title
column5: Magna Carta…Holy Grail offers a jumbled juxtaposition of the regal and divine-- hear Jay-Z gasp “You in the presence of a king/ Scratch that
column6: you in the presence of a god” on “Crown”. It's one of the few lines here that scans as wishful thinking. The album is a celebration of unlimited financial privilege and power that even used its literally game-changing release as a Samsung Galaxy app to separate Jay-Z’s fans into haves and have-nots. Only a small subset could acquire Magna Carta Holy Grail on its release date
column7: and it seems safe to say that fewer still will relate to it in a meaningful way.

column1: Which is problematic
column2: since here the “voice of the young people” seems bent on addressing the public. “I ball so hard on ESPN/ See my name come across CNN/ About six minutes you gonna see it again
column3: ” he later claims on “Crown”. Between his newborn daughter
column4: budding sports agency
column5: political controversies
column6: and his equally famous wife
column7: Magna Carta has the most personal material to work with since The Black Album. But the songs rarely go deep. On “Picasso Baby”
column8: Jay boasts “House like the Louvre or the Tate Modern/ Because I be goin’ ape at the auction.” I doubt he meant it to be “Poppin’ Tags” for the Sotheby’s set-- a vulgar display of net worth that puts him in the tax bracket of shipping magnates and NBA owners-- but it comes across as a context and appraisal-free recitation of famous names
column9: a Winner’s History of Modern Art.

column1: The same can be said of the collaborators. Like The 20/20 Experience
column2: the latest album from his Legends of the Summer tourmate Justin Timberlake
column3: Magna is a hedge-betting
column4: black-tie/Black Card affair that’s not just an account of luxury
column5: but an accessory to it. Marquee names Timbaland
column6: Swizz Beatz
column7: Pharrell
column8: Timberlake
column9: Beyoncé
column10: and Nas all lend their talents-- and all appear on “BBC”. The money isn't totally wasted
column11: as these are some of the stranger beats Jay’s rapped over in some time. Witness the contorted
column12: metallic pings of “Tom Ford”
column13: “Somewhereinamerica”’s drunken ragtime horns
column14: or the codeine-laced
column15: dubby “Crown”. Jay is at least trying to interact with a hip-hop mainstream that has evolved a great deal since his last true solo album
column16: though relegating the production of reigning MVP Mike Will Made It to a one-minute interlude (""Beach Is Better"") smacks of unintended elitism.

column1: At its best
column2: Magna is a record that only a 43-year-old Jay-Z could make. “Heaven” is the most thought-provoking spiritual meditation he’s written
column3: and the willful misreading of “Losing My Religion” is used to powerful effect. “Jay-Z Blue” ruminates on the responsibilities and cyclical pathologies of fatherhood with warmth and self-doubt rather than the bitterness that marked what had previously been his most family-minded LP
column4: The Dynasty: Roc La Familia. But Jay also manifests a worst case scenario for “dad-rap.” Twelve albums in
column5: he’s still Muhammad Ali
column6: he’s Michael Jackson
column7: he’s Michael Jordan
column8: he’s Frank Sinatra-- the latter is the most deflating comparison
column9: if only because Jay-Z is using him as a prop for yet another lyric about how he did it “my way.” As tedious as these hoary references can be
column10: it's worse when Magna Carta dabbles in contemporary name-drops and Jay-Z becomes Jay Leno-- mentions of Homeland
column11: Instagram
column12: Scott Boras
column13: and Miley Cyrus’ twerkin’ incident bomb like failed monologue jokes between idle chatter.

column1: Unlike Watch the Throne
column2: Jay-Z lacks a foil to bring out an emotional or sociological underpinning
column3: someone to help Magna Carta resonate beyond “look at my shit.” Timberlake is in “my name is Bob and I work at my job” mode during the laughably overblown “Holy Grail""
column4: cycling through every tortured artist cliché short of a crucifixion metaphor. And as bad as the “Smells Like Teen Spirit” interpolation reads on paper
column5: once you hear JT and Jay-Z duet on “and we all just entertainers/ And we’re stupid and contagious
column6: ” the Nirvana song becomes just another forgettable status symbol. And where Kurt Cobain felt compromised by his fame
column7: Jay and Timberlake are doing everything in their power not to offend the money people-- whether it’s Samsung
column8: Target
column9: or someone dropping $250 to see them at the Rose Bowl.

column1: Jay-Z rapping about the incomprehensible awesomeness of his life is nothing new
column2: and the corporate synergy is hardly a novelty: The Black Album doubled as a retirement party
column3: Kingdom Come was launched by a Budweiser commercial
column4: American Gangster coincided with a Hollywood blockbuster of the same name
column5: and
column6: in hindsight
column7: Blueprint 3 was made with full knowledge that Jay-Z would be Coachella’s first hip-hop headliner. He’s a businessman and a business
column8: man. After all
column9: while Samsung shelled out seven figures for exclusive access to the Jay-Z brand
column10:
Shawn Carter was the guy signing the contract and cashing the check. But the best of those joint ventures seemed determined to reach a new audience and create a connection. The weirdly distant and safe Magna Carta Holy Grail abides by the tried and true business principle that the customer is always right: you just have to remember who the customer is here.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19440/homepage_large.2443dde8.jpg|Live at Bestival 2012|3031.0|New Order|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sunday Best']|2013-07-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:55:59.358942|"

It's easy to take a band with a storied history and try to impose thoughts and feelings about where they should be heading instead of taking them at face value. This recording of a headline show by New Order at 2012's Bestival on the Isle of Wight offers plenty of moments that don't necessarily sit well-- Bernard Sumner bellowing ""come on!"" in the middle of a stadium-ized version of ""Love Will Tear Us Apart""
column2: the inclusion of non-classic era songs ""Krafty"" and ""Here to Stay""
column3: the absence of Peter Hook on bass. But if you trace their history it's clear that the stoic image they partly cultivated has gradually loosened and fallen away as the years have passed
column4: sometimes becoming distinctly at odds with the impeccable Peter Saville sleeves and Factory marketing acumen of yore. This is
column5: after all
column6: a group that chose to perform on the Baywatch set when invited to play ""Regret"" on Top of the Pops in 1993.

column1: What's remarkable about New Order circa 2013 is the amount of good will that continues to flow toward them despite their obvious flaws. Hook is gone
column2: Sumner has often seemed disinterested in the band
column3: it's arguably been 20 years since they penned anything like a good song
column4: and this is their third go-around following a 2011 reunion with an altered lineup. Yet
column5: listen to the version of ""Blue Monday"" here and you can hear the (no doubt huge) crowd faithfully singing along at times
column6: turning it into an unlikely festival anthem. They sound comfortable in this space
column7: and so they should. Their notable festival appearances are legion at this time
column8: arguably beginning with a headline slot at the 1989 Reading Festival
column9: which played a big part in transforming that event from a parade of has-beens into something approaching vitality (Starship of ""Nothing's Gonna Stop Us Now"" fame topped the bill the previous year).

column1: The question of whether Hook is missed is somewhat moot. His basslines are played impeccably by Tom Chapman
column2: for the most part. But Hook's presence was always a key part of their makeup
column3: a flash of dirt and menace to counteract Sumner’s boyish exterior. It's possible that Hook’s leather trouser act no longer befits someone of his years
column4: but still it's probably better that this is being released as an audio document as opposed to a visual one. We're also spared the sight of Sumner's erratic performance
column5: with his voice sometimes comically strained (horribly so in ""True Faith"") or sounding like he's out of breath (""Bizarre Love Triangle""). But New Order were rarely ever a slick machine live
column6: and mostly Live at Bestival highlights the shortcomings of documenting them in such a light; what once might have been drunk
column7: celebratory fun sounds distinctly less so in the cold
column8: sober light of day.

column1: This is a charity album
column2: released to aid the Isle of Wight Youth Trust
column3: and as such it's a commendable venture. Still
column4: its placing in the New Order discography is hardly likely to be significant
column5: especially as the Live at the London Troxy album from 2011 already documented this incarnation of the group in a live setting (and with a similar tracklisting). There's a certain joy to be found in them tearing through ""Regret""-- a song that always seemed designed for such cavernous surroundings-- or hearing them stretch out a 10-minute-plus version of ""Temptation"". It's when they turn to smaller moments that things backfire
column6: such as the decidedly unsure steps taken through the opening ""Elegia""
column7: reduced here to a runtime of less than three minutes
column8: which feels especially puny following the release of the 17-and-a-half minute version on the Retro box set.

column1: Live at Bestival won't tear anyone away from the riveting Taras Shevchenko live video from 1981
column2: but it's still hard not to crack a smile at how corny Bernard Sumner can be on occasion. His between-song banter is the sound of someone utterly comfortable with what his group have become
column3: a veteran festival headline act happy to work through the hits. It's about as far away as you can get from the multiple shades of black that cloaked the original Joy Division songs liberally sprinkled throughout the setlist
column4: but there's a strong sense of vindication in the robust vigor of ""Transmission""
column5: a feeling that this music was always destined to connect to an audience far beyond those who first claimed it. Sumner's almost certainly having far too much fun to care either way. ""Cheers
column6: thank you Bestival
column7:
he says at the close of the set. ""What a great festival. It's the best... festival.""

"|18246.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18246-new-order-live-at-bestival-2012/|6.4|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19286/homepage_large.615ea2bd.jpg|Masterpiece|851.0|Carl Craig|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ministry of Sound']|2013-07-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:00.021373|"

Dance music fans are notorious for their capricious tastes
column2: but Detroit techno has never fallen out of fashion. Maybe it’s because along with the first few waves of Chicago house it formed the basis for the entire form
column3: and because it’s never been overexposed via car ads or rock musicians briefly reinventing themselves as “electronica” artists. But there’s also something simply aesthetically perfect about the style: minimalist and dark and
column4: when it’s executed well
column5: really hard to imagine as improvable in any way. It’s like the sonic equivalent of the black band t-shirt.

column1: Carl Craig has come closer than any other artist to locating the style’s aesthetic ideal
column2: the sweet spot between Kraftwerk’s organically icy machine music and Funkadelic’s deeply human funk exploration that remain its two most essential influences. His entry in the Ministry of Sound’s Masterpiece series of mixes by ground-laying dance music pioneers is not only a great trilogy of three CD-length sets
column3: but something like a self-portrait or an autobiography in sound
column4: and an intriguing look into the mind of a master musician.

column1: Disc one
column2: titled “Aspiration”
column3: is meant to be a 70-minute sample of what he’s up to these days as a DJ. It leads off with “Zug Island”
column4: a 2012 single by Detroit natives Kyle Hall & Kero
column5: and named after a blighted
column6: heavily industrialized man-made island in the most polluted part of the city. In true Detroit minimalist fashion it consists of little more than a pattern of noisy drums
column7: an ambiently beeping bell-tone synthesizer
column8: and another synth repeating a three-note bassline. It’s a ridiculously simple arrangement
column9: but fascinating to hear as the sounds begin to evolve
column10: with delays dropping in and out and the bassline mutating from a gentle throb to an acid-house freakout. The sounds are modern
column11: but it’s also a perfect representation of the aesthetic philosophy on which techno was founded.

column1: For the remainder of “Aspiration”
column2: Craig shifts seamlessly back and forth between stark minimalism and more lushly elaborate (by comparison) sounds. Many of the contributions come from newer artists working in the Detroit style
column3: but there are also excursions into house-ier stuff
column4: and a brief glimpse at one of Craig’s influences through the inclusion of Egyptian Lover’s 1984 world-shaker “Egypt Egypt”.

column1: The second mix
column2: “Inspiration”
column3: is a more thorough exploration of the music Craig’s been affected by. Some it’s the kind of stuff you might expect him to cite: fellow techno artists of the old school like Derrick May
column4: e-Dancer
column5: and Moritz von Oswald. Other inclusions are more eye-opening. There’s experimental reggae from African Head Charge and digital dancehall originator King Jammy. There’s R&B from DeBarge and Erykah Badu. There’s a track from David Lynch’s 2011 album Crazy Clown Time
column6: Freeway’s “All My Life
column7: ” and a bossa nova-influenced track from Melody Gardot. Muddy Waters’ “Mannish Boy”
column8: the Temptations’ psychedelic-era “Cloud Nine”
column9: and the organ-heavy proto-hard rock cut “In the Jungle” by the Motown-signed group the Messengers represent a fuzzed-out
column10: loose-limbed approach to making music that’s difficult to see reflected in Craig’s own work.

column1: If “Aspiration” and “Inspiration” are Craig surveying his present and past
column2: the final disc finds him looking forward
column3: staking out new stylistic territory and proving that after almost 25 years of recording he’s still evolving as an artist. “Meditation” is a suite of six new
column4: original compositions for modular synthesizer that explore a much different side to Carl Craig than we’re used to seeing. As the title indicates
column5: they’re the result of directing his talents for bare-bones arrangement and selecting fascinatingly dark sonic palettes to ends that are far more suited to contemplation than dancing.

column1: The sounds of his modular synthesizer setup invite comparisons to synth wizards of the past like Vangelis
column2: Tangerine Dream
column3: and John Carpenter
column4: but the way he uses it is bracingly original and often daring. The individual tracks
column5: most of them coming in around the 10-minute mark
column6: drift between downtempo but danceable songs that hint at techno and Italo disco on one hand
column7: and on the other pure
column8: trance-inducing ambience. The former kind are rewarding
column9: and offer the unique sort of pleasure that comes from hearing an accomplished artist working with a different set of tools to normal
column10: but the ambient stuff is even more fascinating.

column1: It makes sense that one of the modern masters of minimalist composition would be able to apply his talents successfully to a style that’s historically compatible with bare-bones arrangements
column2: and the end results exceed expectations. They’re richly textured despite their sonic sparsity
column3: and full of the energy that separates ambient music that engages the listener’s mind from the kind that just puts them to sleep. It’s so engaging
column4: in fact
column5: that at one point Craig pulls down everything in the mix until there’s only a deep
column6: throbbing bass tone that you can only hear on headphones or a halfway decent set of speakers. The really tricky part of it is that you might very well find yourself pulled so far into it that you don’t even notice the missing instruments until they come back in minutes later. It’s a master-level maneuver that underlines the essential theme of the three-disc set
column7: which is that after a quarter century of pushing music into the future
column8:
Carl Craig’s still not done.

"|18097.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18097-carl-craig-masterpiece/|7.3|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19301/homepage_large.11c759be.jpg|Blaze Colour Burn|31340.0|Jan St. Werner|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2013-07-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:00.735926|"

It's tough to categorize Mouse on Mars much beyond the ""electronic duo"" tag
column2: mainly because their various albums and side projects have splintered off in so many directions. Even the ""electronic"" tag doesn't entirely fit at times-- core members Andi Toma and Jan St. Werner's respective backgrounds are as a guitarist and a drummer
column3: and their live shows often feature the charismatic Dodo NKishi behind the trap set. St. Werner has made solo recordings under various guises before
column4: but here he steps out under his own name for the first time
column5: again blurring perceptions and stretching at definitions of his working method. This is the inaugural release in the Fiepblatter series for Thrill Jockey
column6: which will focus on field recordings
column7: improvisational works
column8: and other elements drawn from the margins of sound.

column1: Blaze Colour Burn is a suitably amorphous statement of intent for this proposed set of releases
column2: principally because it's a series of fractured recordings that are as much about what's happening around the sounds as the sounds themselves. The two-part ""Spiazzacorale"" has been edited down from an eight-hour live performance in Italy
column3: and is frequently punctured by audience movement
column4: a low-lying conversational murmur
column5: and other crowd noise. At one point it appears to collapse altogether
column6: only for St. Werner to bring it back in a burst of brilliant color via the sound of a traditional Umbrian band. It's far from the studied work of Mouse on Mars
column7: replacing that band's strictures with a looseness that feels freeing. The non-live material works that way too-- ""Sipian Organ"" acts like an industrialized take on Brian Eno's ambient works
column8: oscillating between quiet background drones and sharp
column9: metallic foreground noise.

column1: The amount of space in the recording is key
column2: sometimes causing it to resemble a performance happening far off in the distance
column3: at other times situating everything front and center. It makes listening to Blaze Colour Burn a distinctly physical experience. In quieter moments you might strain to hear what's going on; similarly
column4: when the extraneous crowd bustle is foregrounded
column5: it feels like your brain needs to do some filtering to get to what's important. As such
column6: it also poses questions about what the important elements are when listening to music
column7: especially when non-musical forms take on a strange rhythm of their own. There are no echelons of significance here-- an audience member coughing adds just as much as the ripples of vibraphone that light up ""Spiazzacorale""
column8: mainly because of the sense of place they bring.

column1: It's surprising how much movement there is in these ruptured
column2: abstract pieces
column3: with St. Werner casting each track as a tiny journey to undertake. Part of its stated intent is for the listener to question their position in relation to the music
column4: to figure out where they are situated in the listening process. It works along those lines to a certain extent
column5: but there's also a flipside to it that has more in common with St. Werner's work in Mouse on Mars
column6: where you get slung adrift
column7: wandering around in gigantic structures like the 13-minute ""Cloud Diachroma"". Blaze Colour Burn lands somewhere in between music that makes you hyper-aware of your place in relation to it and something that removes you from thinking about yourself altogether. That split creates a subtle tension at the heart of the record
column8:
positioning it as a maze-like structure where getting lost and found become equally gratifying.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19438/homepage_large.e2a066d4.jpg|Corps Exquis|31471.0|Daniel Wohl|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['New Amsterdam']|2013-07-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:01.695753|"

To listen to Corps Exquis
column2: an album of compositions by the Paris-born composer Daniel Wohl
column3: is to be mowed over by a tiny army's worth of interesting sounds. It's hard to tell
column4: sometimes
column5: if those noises represent the crackle of cell phone interference or the creaky floor of an old house: The opening piece
column6: ""Neighborhood""
column7: churns together little bits of composer and performer Aaron Roche's processed voice with furious scribbles of tremolo'd string
column8: a waveform that Wohl snags with his software and distends
column9: so that we no longer picture human arms generating the sound. There are an abundance of other noises here
column10: too
column11: all of them of hazy origin-- some percussive clicks
column12: some radiant
column13: soft-edged keyboard arpeggios
column14: a shimmer effect that resembles locusts or a lawn sprinkler. There is some groaning
column15: burping electronic noise in the music's low end that could be a groaning double bass or electronics. This zone of confusion
column16: between the digital glitch and bow-on-string screech
column17: is where Wohl lives
column18: and Corps Exquis gets more interesting the more confused you get.

column1: The album
column2: recorded by the modern classical guitarist and composer Andrew McKenna Lee
column3: is beautiful and maze-like
column4: with sounds emanating from all directions in your listening space. It is performed by the excellent five-piece ensemble Transit (percussion
column5: clarinet and bass clarinet
column6: violin
column7: cello
column8: and piano)
column9: which Wohl co-founded. The album is a kind of all-star affair
column10: at least as far as the tight-knit world of NYC contemporary classical is concerned: So Percussion show up on ""Neighborhood""; Julia Holter drops by on ""Corpus"". They render Wohl's music as a world overrun with small scrapes and fidgets
column11: constantly scurrying across the floorboards while larger
column12: more patient sounds operate above. ""Insext"" opens on a digital storm of white noise
column13: overlaid with wisps of bowed string harmonics. A little string melody eventually rises out of the din
column14: like someone whispering some half-remembered Copland
column15: but it's promptly buffeted by waves of digital percussion. This push and pull
column16: this sense that the music Transit plays is being sucked into the void and spit out transformed
column17: like the tennis-ball scene in Poltergeist
column18: is part of what makes Wohl such an original voice.

column1: His voice is not manic
column2: however
column3: and his canvas is not seething: Even as it's surrounded by a clattering of pots and pans
column4: the center of ""323"" is a radiant
column5: booming nimbus of major chords
column6: moving slowly. ""Cantus"" meanwhile
column7: opens on a gently piling snowdrift of strings
column8: all bowing in different pattern to create a gorgeously featureless expanse similar to Arvo Pärt's Fratres For Eight Cellos. Slowly
column9: other noises creep into the frame-- a sharp
column10: stabbing cello sound
column11: some hollow rattles
column12: like bottles being racked up at a bar counter. The piece dissolves
column13: near the end
column14: into a distressed racket of competing cries from all players
column15: but Wohl leaves us with a contemplatively cool sound in its last seconds
column16: a small sigh. In each piece
column17: clamor briefly overwhelms serenity
column18: but each time
column19: clamor loses.

column1: Most pieces operate on both planes at once: ""Ouverture"" generates a hushed
column2: expectant mood that recalls George Crumb's ""Star-Child"". That piece builds its most fearsome roar from an old-fashioned pedaled piano
column3: then fans out into a soothing hum of manipulated string textures. Whatever Wohl's vision is
column4: about the noise of digital lives
column5: and how they affect the mind
column6: it isn't binary: Solace
column7: these pieces seem to argue
column8:
can come from anywhere we look for it.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19372/homepage_large.c53fcaeb.jpg|The Inheritors|15555.0|James Holden|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Border Community']|2013-07-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:02.527355|"

Around the release of his 2006 debut LP
column2: The Idiots Are Winning
column3: UK producer James Holden was asked by production magazine Future Music to list his top 10 pieces of gear. He's a space cadet in the interview
column4: turning idly in a messy room. By my count he names eight items
column5: three of which are stuffed animals
column6: with a fourth being a shelf of children's action figures overlooking his computer. It's a performance by an artist who at the time was still trying to shake his reputation as a barely legal trance wunderkind/Britney Spears remixer: Holden had burst onto the scene in the late 90s with the kind of progressive tracks that fans still upload to YouTube accompanied by pictures of beaches and sunsets.

column1: He probably wouldn't admit it
column2: but Holden learned something from those early trance hits: go big or go home. It's an impulse he's honed even as he's backpedaled from his early recordings: see his skyscraping remix of Nathan Fake's ""The Sky Was Pink"". Holden's second album
column3: The Inheritors
column4: is a raging bonfire of electro-acoustic composition. His kindling is the open-field psychedelia of groups like Cluster and Popol Vuh
column5: with a healthy amount of Boards of Canada's dusty gaze. Broken into 15 tracks but playing like a long
column6: evolving piece
column7: The Inheritors oscillates between buzzy pastoral beauty and harsh rhythmic duress. It's the sound of an artist uniquely in tune with his instrument
column8: as Holden coaxes all manner of beastly noise out of his mighty modular synthesizer
column9: trying to keep that sound organized and only sometimes succeeding.

column1: Holden takes advantage of that instrument-- essentially a bespoke synthesis engine adapted for each track
column2: aided by software Holden writes himself-- by embracing its imprecision. He recorded his curdling circuitry live
column3: capturing plenty of pots and divots in the process
column4: which gives The Inheritors a savage and craggy feel. If Boards of Canada evoke the beauty and majesty of the rolling countryside
column5: Holden is puts you in direct contact with it
column6: forcing you to engage its uneven terrain and irregular placements. This comes through on tracks like ""The Illuminations""
column7: on which pretty
column8: circular patterns are interrupted by haphazard distortion and chords are held to the speaker's breaking point.

column1: In most electronic music
column2: the core elements-- drums
column3: bassline
column4: lead-- play well-defined roles and inhabit familiar sonic spaces. The Inheritors doesn't work like that. The rhythms and melodies come from odd places
column5: sometimes switching roles during the course of a song. The title track
column6: for example
column7: is a hurricane of sound
column8: sharp percussive hits fighting back a massive
column9: distorted midrange assault. When Holden does break out traditional drum sounds-- during the climax of lead single ""Renata"" or ""Delabole""
column10: for example-- they amplify the intensity
column11: offering the gargled synth patterns something to spring from. The Inheritors comes to a head with ""Gone Feral"" and the title track
column12: a sequence during which Holden unleashes his circuity and records the carnage. The hissing
column13: buckling oscillations during this stretch wipe clean the careful pacing of tracks like ""Inter-City 125"" and ""Rannoch Dawn"". When he dials it down afterwards he has a sense of humor about it: ""Some Respite"".

column1: It's difficult to describe the sound of The Inheritors without coming off like an analog apologist. But turn a track like ""Blackpool Late Eightes""-- the penultimate and longest track
column2: which acts as something of a victory lap-- up on a good system and you can feel its humming warmth
column3: the air it browbeats around the room. You can imagine a shamanic Holden working amidst his machines

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19457/homepage_large.e1486f51.jpg|Y.R.N. (Young Rich Niggas)|31455.0|Migos|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-07-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:03.310696|"

The guest list for Young Rich Niggas
column2: the new mixtape from emerging Atlanta trap trio Migos
column3: is short but telling: in 19 tracks
column4: there are guest spots from Gucci Mane
column5: trap scene evergreen and early supporter of breakout stars like Waka Flocka and Future whose revolving door Brick Squad collective currently counts Chief Keef and Young Thug as members; Soulja Boy
column6: spirit guide and occasional symbiote for weird rap mainstays like Lil B and Young L of the Pack; and Trinidad James and Riff Raff
column7: whose left-of-center theatrics have brought their authenticity as well as their worth as lyricists into constant review. Migos are both natural descendents of Atlanta's florid coke rap cottage industry and purveyors of something defiantly stranger. On the surface
column8: Young Rich Niggas appears to traffic in slight
column9: hooky pop rap
column10: but the abundance of aesthetic and lyrical quirks here also genuflect to rap’s frayed outskirts.

column1: Young Rich Niggas’ lyric sheet is a vast expanse of trap house platitudes
column2: but Quavo
column3: Offset
column4: and Takeoff’s absurdist humor sets these songs apart from the pack. “China Town” juggles plentiful references to Asian culture-- Honda
column5: Mortal Kombat
column6: Manny Pacquiao-- hilariously failing to hit on anything legitimitely Chinese. Mixtape highlight “Hannah Montana” is a flurry of bald-faced boasts about proficiency at dealing drugs
column7: but the codenames for the product are all culled from white female TV
column8: movie
column9: and pop stars. It’s the song’s chorus that illuminates Migos’ incontrovertible weirdness
column10: though. At the end of each verse Quavo bludgeons the mix shouting “Hannah Montana! Hannah Montana! Hannah Montana! Hannah Montana!” until he’s driven home the principal silliness of the word combo. Migos' choruses work like that a lot of the time: the badgering
column11: hypnotic repetition of “Trapped out the bando” on “Bando” and the comically insistent “Versace/ Versace Versace/ Versace Versace” refrain of “Versace” warp each phrase in your mind until they hit the ear like something other than English
column12: hammering hooks home with the manic urgency of toy commercials.

column1: If that seems like a shaky foundation for an hour-long mixtape
column2: know that Migos’ bag of rhyme schemes is more varied and adventurous than simple catchphrase repetition: Young Rich Niggas houses capable double-time speed trials like “Cook It Up”
column3: brawlers like “Hannah Montana” and “China Town”
column4: the half-baked self-satisfied stunting of “Bando”
column5: dalliances with sung hooks on “Adios” and Auto-Tune experimentation on “Finesser” and “Pronto”. And for all its smart alecky veneer
column6: Y.R.N. is shot through with a palpable darkness that comes to a head at the end of the tape: there's the one-two punch of “R.I.P.”
column7: an ode to Future’s recently deceased Freeband Gang associate OG Double D
column8: and “Thank You God (Outro)”
column9: a rags-to-riches yarn that charts Migos’ progression from childhood adversity (“Daddy was a hospital patient/ Next thing you know he ain’t make it”) to financial comfort that’s couched in the self-flagellating remorse of Offset’s proclamation that he “sinned every day just to get this success.”

column1: Migos’ deceptively simple lyricism favors production that follows suit. Trap’s booming 808s and ticking hi-hats are still present
column2: but where the production of
column3: say
column4: a Rick Ross song is designed to blurt out of speakers like a battering ram pushed it through
column5: Y.R.N. shoots for pared down productions that highlight the strengths of the songwriting. The staccato synth blips on Zaytoven’s “Versace” beat race against the lyrics laid over them. The plodding piano line on “Adios” walks in lock step with its sung hook. Dun Deal fades the foreboding bells and guitars of “Hannah Montana” after each verse
column6: punching up Quavo’s frantic chorus for maximum effect. Guest MCs similarly fold into the songs where they’re featured. Gucci Mane goes along with the gummy Auto-Tune shtick of “Dennis Rodman”
column7: and Trinidad James and Riff Raff’s contributions to “Out Da Gym” are surprisingly reserved. (Drake jumped on a remix of “Versace” last week and coopted the Migos cadence with childlike zeal.)  The willingness of Migos’ collaborators to follow their lead feels like a vote of confidence in their sound
column8: a rarity in a time of rap game Frankenstein’s monsters like A$AP Rocky’s “Fuckin’ Problems” and Kanye West’s remix of Chief Keef’s “Don’t Like”
column9: releases that played like pic-stitches of the artists’ famous friends.

column1: Young Rich Niggas finds Migos perfecting their sound even as they bristle at it
column2: and the tape rarely delivers anything resembling a failure. The subject matter can be suffocating in its cavalier depravity
column3: especially on tracks like “FEMA”
column4: which employs a heavy-handed metaphor comparing one’s speed at whipping up crack to the movements of Hurricane Katrina
column5: and Migos’ kingpin fantasies also hit a few sour notes racially speaking. (See: Y.R.N.’s bottomless stream of Latin names for cocaine connects and “China Town”
column6: whose adventures in drug smuggling are periodically punctuated by gross “ching chong” ad libs.) Y.R.N.’s indiscretions are usually
column7: mercifully scant
column8: however
column9: and the group never approaches this material with anything less than an affable
column10: good-natured goofiness. With Young Rich Niggas
column11: Migos have peeled the gruff exterior off of trap and revealed the giddy
column12:
catchy party music underfoot.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19401/homepage_large.775bb972.jpg|Contact|30213.0|The-Drum|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Audraglint']|2013-07-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:03.952407|"

When Chicago electronic musicians Jeremiah Chrome and Brandon Boom began making music together as the-Drum towards the end of 2010
column2: it was with the express purpose of emulating the eccentric R&B super-producer Terius “The-Dream” Nash: from their spare
column3: syncopated beats all the way down to the hyphen in the project’s name. When they released Sense Net last year
column4: Nash’s presence still loomed large
column5: even amidst the influence of vintage avant-electronic acts and industrial bands. Since then
column6: however
column7: the pair have struck out on a far more idiosyncratic course. Contact
column8: their first full-length
column9: abandons Sense Net’s gently psychedelic R&B bump
column10: along with anything resembling traditional pop song structure. Maybe those things are still there somewhere
column11: just radically mutated
column12: rapidly evolved into unrecognizable new shapes.

column1: Contact opens with a short sound effects vignette where someone enters a high tech enclosure and connects to a data network using a computer that offers roughly digital voice prompts. Having successfully logged in
column2: we encounter reverb-rich pads
column3: synthesized nonsense vocal sounds
column4: and finger snaps that lead in a beat that skitters and booms and refuses to settle into one steady pattern. Instead
column5: it flickers between drum & bass
column6: Chicago footwork
column7: two-step
column8: and
column9: during a couple of moments
column10: the kind of R&B the pair were doing back on Sense Net.

column1: The rest of the songs operate in a similar fashion
column2: with the pair establishing a sonic premise
column3: then giving it a gentle push and following where it rolls. “Narco” begins with metallic-toned synth arpeggios
column4: a minimal but vaguely menacing kick drum part
column5: and a sprinkling of aquatic-sounding digital blips. Over the next eight minutes
column6: it touches on everything from turn of the millennium radio rap to VHS-era action movie soundtracks
column7: and includes a frantic digital slap bass solo and tones that sound like they could have been sampled from a vintage PC operating system.

column1: Many of the songs float off into full-on ambience at some point in their journey. “Arcadia” actually begins there
column2: with long
column3: leisurely stretches of blissed-out synth pads decorated with little scraps of sound-- a heavily manipulated vocal sample or a brief keyboard figure-- that float leisurely by. Every once in a while a little bit of structure creeps in and the song drifts almost to the point of something that could pass for R&B
column4: but only briefly
column5: and then it drifts gently back.

column1: It’s an intensely dreamy record
column2: and a very futuristic one too. It’s a slightly dated brand of futurism though
column3: full of sounds lifted from primitive early samplers
column4: organic percussion sounds that suggest a particularly 90s “tribal” aesthetic
column5: and low-resolution computer voices that say things like “data connection” and “systems online.” It’s the sound of 2013
column6: but more specifically of 2013 as it looked in the early days of Wired magazine
column7: when digital culture was first starting to emerge. Contact seems like the type of thing the fringier characters from a William Gibson cyberpunk novel would put on when they want to kick back and smoke a spliff.

column1: It’s kind of a bummer to see two producers who were so good at making a particular kind of music essentially leave it behind with barely any finished recordings to show for it (although they still dabble in R&B with the Chicago vocal trio JODY)
column2: but that’s really the only disappointing thing about Contact. It may not offer pre-existing the-Drum fans what they may have thought they wanted from the group’s first album
column3: but what it delivers is powerful stuff. The pair only recently started performing outside of Chicago
column4: and last week I saw them play one of their first shows in New York City. No one was dancing
column5: which is usually a huge problem for a concert of what’s ostensibly dance music
column6: but the two didn’t seem concerned in the least bit as they built up
column7: warped
column8: and tore down one richly textured sonic structure after another. And they shouldn’t have been. No one was dancing
column9:
but everyone was mesmerized.

"|18210.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18210-the-drum-contact/|7.5|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19128/homepage_large.6c9117b4.jpg|Drillary Clinton|30545.0|Katie Got Bandz|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lawless']|2013-07-02 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:04.421244|"

One of the quietly beloved figures of Chicago’s drill scene has been 19-year-old Kiara Johnson
column2: better known in rap as Katie Got Bandz. She appeared last spring in a handful of videos that embodied drill’s most enticing qualities: youthful DIY energy
column3: a cohesive aesthetic
column4: and simple
column5: brutally menacing hooks. Her one-off tracks and her first mixtape
column6: Bandz and Hittaz
column7: were spun around infectiously loud chants delivered in a raspy bark
column8: underscoring Waka Flocka Flame’s role as the godfather of drill. She’s also become something of a rap-lover’s folk-hero
column9: largely because she’s a master of slang and catch phrases-- ""Katieeeee!""-- and because her online persona is brashly funny. “ROMENY SAID MARTIN LUTHER KING DAY IS IRRELEVANT FUCK HIM
column10: ” she wrote on Twitter during the Presidential Election as part of her ongoing personal campaign against Mitt Romney. ""THE BEST PART ABOUT NOT GIVING A FUCK IS REALLY NOT GIVING A FUCK
column11: she once wrote. Her jubilant confidence has often been thrilling.

column1: But when Katie took the stage at this year's South by Southwest for her show at the Fader Fort-- which you could stream live online-- she froze up
column2: timidly shouting over a backing track like someone who'd lost a bet at a crowded karaoke bar. Gone was the ebullient swagger and take-no-prisoners attitude that got her noticed over the last year. Her long-promised new mixtape
column3: the delightfully titled Drillary Clinton
column4: transmits that trepidation and inexperience. What could’ve been an event tape is instead a minor release that will likely lurk in the shadows of Katie’s outsized persona.

column1: Higher stakes seem to have an adverse affect on Katie’s brute-force approach to rapping. Excepting “Y U Mad”-- a sneaky hit in its own right-- and the King Louie collaboration “Pop Out”
column2: there’s a hesitant
column3: unnatural air to Drillary Clinton that finds Katie dragging through some of her verses
column4: sounding timid or lethargic rather than purposefully measured or unhurried. “Fuck fighting/ We shooting/ Catch up!/Y’all losing/ Keep it on us/ No snoozing!”
column5: she shouts on the cumbersome “Finessin’” (like many of Drillary Clinton’s tracks
column6: this one was produced by drill mainstay BlockOnDaTrakk). Occasionally the apprehension or clumsiness is endearing: the Auto-Tuned “Foreign” has an ugly-beautiful sound not unlike Chief Keef’s “Citgo”; her imitations of other rappers’ adlibs-- “skirrrr!”
column7: “nawwhh”
column8: “bow-bow”-- expose her as someone who just plain loves rap music.

column1: Still
column2: she recedes from the foreground too often-- something that doesn’t work
column3: given her style's emphasis of presence over lyrical dexterity. This becomes especially clear when she's heard alongside guests like Dreezy
column4: who offers an explosive verse on “Knock a Hoe”. Dreezy's another young woman from the Chicago's drill scene-- paradoxically
column5: the hyper-aggressive sound has tended to neutralize gender
column6: breeding a disproportionately large crop of new female rappers. Inside it all
column7: Katie sits quietly
column8:
reminding us that she still has plenty of room to grow into the authoritative spirit she baited us with at the onset.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19410/homepage_large.e231dd24.jpg|Run the Jewels|31319.0|Run the Jewels|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|"[""Fool's Gold""]"|2013-07-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:05.801049|"

Even for those of us who go all the way back to “8 Steps to Perfection” and “The Whole World”
column2: it's starting to feel like El-P and Killer Mike have always been talked about in the same breath. The connection makes a kind of retroactive sense going back to their early 2000s solo debuts
column3: Fantastic Damage and Monster. Both albums seethed with the anxious funk of retrofuture 808s-and-synths production that rattled trunks and cages with unrestrained intensity. And both portrayed the artists as out-of-control forces trying their damnedest to stay true to friends
column4: family
column5: and hip-hop while confronting disenfranchisement
column6: abuse
column7: and cynicism. That their creators would gravitate towards collaboration makes even more sense now than it does with hindsight in mind
column8: as the 1-2 hooks to the head of Cancer for Cure and R.A.P. Music shared not just a producer and a timeframe
column9: but the kind of catharsis-fueled defiance that career no-sellout vets live and breathe.

column1: Thankfully
column2: El-P and Killer Mike made a point to keep working together
column3: and by all accounts their two-MCs/one-producer teamup Run the Jewels was meant to be some kind of “cool-down” record-- just something they could brainstorm up and record as a sort of fun
column4: no-stress victory lap in celebration of a triumphant 2012. But if that kind of session reads as a low-stakes slack-off
column5: especially in the form of a free 33-minute download
column6: keep in mind just what constitutes “fun” for these guys. At the top of the list
column7: it's the process-- workshopping ideas
column8: putting things together
column9: delivering them with conviction
column10: and bringing it out to a rampant fanbase prone to drawing irreverent fan-art and ordering special-edition herb grinders. No excuse to relax here.

column1: The only significant sign that El-P and Killer Mike are taking things “easier” on this album is the focus on shit-talk: aside from the confessional coming-of-age self-pep talk of closer “A Christmas Fucking Miracle”
column2: there's little-to-no high-concept storytelling and a minimum of “Reagan”/”Drones Over Bklyn”-style political science. They haven't gotten complacent-- that latter song gets fleetingly referenced in a Mike line on “DDFH”
column3: one of the few verses that catches the same police-state anger that R.A.P. Music did. And El still raps like somebody who's not sure if he's the last sane man or the craziest man on earth
column4: carrying his refined maniacal diatribes over from Cancer for Cure. But the majority of Run the Jewels is a succession of throw-shit-out-a-window anthems which take the early-LL knuckles-first bragging that inspired the name
column5: running their own psilocybin-tinged mean streak through it.

column1: The deepest messages of Run the Jewels are the ones dedicated to figuring out just how many ways there are to threaten bodily trauma in the most over-the-top language possible while not actually coming across like some screwfaced shock-value manchild. It feels as though the options of either catching a bad one or riding with them are easier to decide between because the latter sounds like it'd be a hell of a time anyways. And there's this sense of friendly
column2: unspoken one-upsmanship between the two MCs that keeps upping the stakes. Mike on the title track: “I'll pull this pistol
column3: put it on your poodle or your fuckin' baby.” El on “Sea Legs”: “Try to pet my fuckin' head again and I'm'a put a tooth through the flesh of the palm that you jack with.” Mike on “Get It”: “stupid goofy stoolie
column4: the gooch in Gucci will slap you/ and that go for the cop-kissing cats that's in the back of you.” El on “Twin Hype Back”: “Me and Mike'll go Twin Hype and do a dance on your windpipe/ put your fuckin' jazz hands back in your pants or get them shits sliced.” It's a game of the dozens where the barbs are aimed outwards and funny-looking moms are swapped for an all-encompassing People Who Fuck With Us category.

column1: In the process
column2: both MCs have both started to meet each other halfway personality-wise
column3: though that wasn't a long trip to begin with. El's panic-attack rasp has grown into this fluid delivery that's become as immersive as his older hitched-timing flow was
column4: spitting slick bars and doubletimes that make the acidic comedy roll out like his own take on vintage Ludacris. And Mike maintains his wrecking-ball mode
column5: but twists it into moments of psychedelic delirium and over-the-top throat tearing
column6: a man incapable of sounding nonchalant about anything getting the chance to turn that elbow-throwing flow into the narrator for a story about getting a lapdance on mushrooms (“No Come Down”) or turning it up to the breaking point on the grimy Tyson-isms of “Job Well Done”. When they get into verse-swapping back-and-forths on “Twin Hype Back”
column7: “Get It”
column8: and “Banana Clipper” (where an otherwise excellent Big Boi verse bizarrely feels like an afterthought in comparison)
column9: or throw around conversational line-finishing asides elsewhere
column10: the rapport's enough to raise questions as to why this teamup was supposed to be unusual in the first place.

column1: This is hardhead music
column2: but it's also supposed to be a good time-- shit
column3: they even brought in Prince Paul to do his oily weirdo pick-up artist Chest Rockwell routine on “Twin Hype Back”. (“I got your glass of Beefeater
column4: I got a brand new deck of Uno cards... how 'bout I come over tonight and pick you up in my brand new Segway?”) So El-P pulls out the stops in making the abrasive
column5: heavy aspects of his production sound boombox-ready. If this stuff's “dystopian
column6: ” you might as well book a party bus to Airstrip One: growling synthesized basslines do the heavy lifting as percussion skitters beneath like warped distortions of the 84
column8: and 02 versions of analog hip-hop
column9: a cohesive sound that serves as a reminder that Georgia and New York are both technically East Coast. El's signature production touches-- minor-key chord drones
column10: ligament-snapping guitar squalls
column11: highwire arpeggios
column12: twitchy drum patterns that are as restless as a rock-solid beat can get-- are put to pretty straightforward use this time around.

column1: The beats fit the blueprint of R.A.P. Music's tendency to let the voices supply most of the brute force; it still bumps like a bastard
column2: but not in the kind of way that had Yeezus casualties scrambling for punk rock namedrops. It's just a distilled take on everything that made last year's albums such an event
column3: with all the chrome ripped off and upholstery pulled out so it'll run faster
column4: louder
column5: nastier. Yeah
column6: it's a fun album
column7:
and it's probably the most affable thing they've done so far together. But don't take that for a weakness. They don't yank chains-- they snatch them.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19350/homepage_large.f19435a3.jpg|For Years|30303.0|Airhead|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['R&S']|2013-07-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:06.532643|"

Rob McAndrews
column2: a.k.a. Airhead
column3: is best known for collaborating with James Blake
column4: which will do as much to foster an audience for his own albums as it will threaten to overshadow them. Like Blake (and his associates in Mount Kimbie)
column5: McAndrews makes low-key electronic music that never lets you forget the human presence behind it. In Blake's case
column6: it's his ghostly pillow talk; in McAndrews'
column7: it's delicately plucked guitars
column8: grainy field recordings
column9: and a naturalistic sense of drift more akin to ambient music than techno. Portions of his debut
column10: For Years
column11: sound like crosstalk coming in from an open window; others appear to be happening under a pile of leaves.

column1: The album is rooted in the hip-hop mosaics of producers like J Dilla and a subdued take on post-rock. At first it might be hard to figure out what the two styles have to do with each other
column2: and if nothing else For Years connects them as dots in a constellation of instrumental music that favors abstract forms while clinging to an almost classical sense of beauty and grandeur. (The same qualities make duly clear its popularity among stoners.)

column1: Aside from the mid-album exclamation point ""Pyramid Lake""
column2: For Years doesn't beg for attention. It is downtempo music
column3: subtle but paradoxically best heard at a distance. Its highlights are tracks that become memorable after multiple listens but are just as easily tuned out: the Karen O-sampling ""Wait""
column4: ""Autumn""
column5: and Blake collaboration ""Knives""
column6: whose contorted gospel keyboard progressions are mixed under so much atmosphere they're practically subliminal.

column1: In a recent Pitchfork interview
column2: McAdams said that he spent a lot of time growing up listening to music while sitting in front of a computer
column3: ""which I'm sure [the music] wasn't intended for"". Consciously or not
column4: it's a relationship to sound that has seeped completely into For Years
column5: which has an even-keel
column6: almost analgesic quality when played in the background of otherwise uneventful moments.

column1: It takes skill to make music this way-- to exist without disturbing
column2: to engage without interrupting
column3: and to please without sounding like you're going out of your way to do it. But there are tracks on For Years that feel like 30-second ideas stretched to four minutes
column4: or where the music becomes so airy and loose I wonder if even McAdams is convinced it absolutely needs to exist. Ironically
column5: what drew me to For Years on first listen is what held me back on the tenth: Despite its clever syntheses
column6: there are times when it's not much more than pretty.

column1: But the good is not only good
column2: it's promising. Some of For Years was recorded as early as 2009
column3: and McAndrews expressed no interest in changing how he makes music in order to keep so-called pace with his peers. That's noble. His earliest singles-- ""Paper Street"" and the Blake collaborations ""Pembroke"" and ""Lock in the Lion""-- still have an isolated
column4: thrillingly idiosyncratic sound
column5:
like blueprints for buildings that nobody ever got around to. Think of For Years as a brick.

"|18164.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18164-airhead-for-years/|7.0|Mike Powell

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19349/homepage_large.a55979c2.jpg|Planta|4821.0|CSS|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['SQE']|2013-07-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:07.211553|"

Cansei de Ser Sexy famously took their name from a Beyoncé interview in which the world's favorite diva declared that she was ""tired of being sexy."" The Brazilian band have consistently used cool
column3: yelpy electro-punk to take a stand against something or other; shouting out rebuttals to female stereotypes while being coy about it
column4: too. With Planta
column5: they lose their only male member
column6: Adriano Cintra. Unfortunately
column7: that means losing part of CSS' appeal along with him.

column1: Last year
column2: <a href=""http://sendmetojail.blogspot.com/2012/03/how-this-cookie-crumbled.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">in a ranty
column3: long-winded blogpost
column4: Cintra at least explained why he had to quit
column5: citing artistic priorities
column6: fame-stunting
column7: shady managers
column8: money-swindling
column9: and calling out his bandmates for pretending they were friends when they were anything but. Which really strikes a blow when dealing with a group who are trying to sell we-don’t-give-a-fuck club kid romps. Planta suffers from the same one-trick sameness that plagued Donkey and La Liberación
column10: two albums that went relatively unnoticed considering their hit debut. Here “Hangover” comes closest to the image that CSS has projected; a song co-written by Rancid’s Tim Armstrong that sweetly declares “I’ve never had a hangover til you
column11: ” over a slowly plodding and sunny reggaeton beat. Front-woman Lovefoxxx adopts a drawl that feels hat-tipped to the M.I.A. that was dating Diplo when he brought CSS to the U.S. spotlight way back in 2006.

column1: It's worth noting that TV on the Radio’s David Sitek stepped in to executive produce Planta. His flair is something you hear on “Honey”
column2: an open love-letter that burns along to flying
column3: cinematic synth melodies worthy of Santigold or TVOTR-- morse-code blurts of bass
column4: and vintage roller-rink strobe lights. Instrumentally it’s an electro pop stan’s dream
column5: gloriously cheesy in all the right places. “Sweet” and “Teenage Tiger Cat” fare similarly; expansive cinematics with casually provocative snares that break into relentless bass and bop-along electric guitar. The problem with both tracks
column6: however
column7: remains the total lack of vocal prowess. Sure there are growls on “Teenage Tiger Cat”
column8: but what’s meant to sound like ‘tude or luring temptation mostly comes off as a starlet attempting to seduce a fan who has forgotten she exists.

column1: Sentimental ballads show up frequently on Planta
column2: earnestly declaring love and unearthing secret admiration. “Faith In Love” is the least trying because it’s different
column3: a drone of organs and haze-clearing tambourine fades the album out. But its sleepiness is where we’re continuously lost; the singer’s vocals get swallowed by her surroundings
column4: making something that could have been heart-tugging and lovelorn into a song that sounds bored with itself. “Dynamite”-- the best track on the album next to “Hangover”-- shows some signs of life
column5: though
column6: as we’re sucked into a destructive mosh-pit while Foxxx eggs us on (“Burn baby
column7: burn”) to get high on the night and all the things we like. And that's exactly what we want from CSS; for them to shout at us and demand that we seize the day. Unfortunately
column8: on Planta
column9:
they only seem half-awake.
