column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19426/homepage_large.7ca85d70.jpg|Anthology|31445.0|Knx|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2013-07-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:08.093425|"

Glen Boothe
column2: an instrumental beatmaker drowning in samples and a neo-hippy vibe who goes by both Knx. and Knxledge
column3: is a near-perfect merging of the identities of L.A. labels Stones Throw and Leaving Records. Earlier this year
column4: the former began distributing releases from the latter
column5: a partnership that produced Anthology. It was curated from the 40+ tapes that Boothe's released on his Bandcamp page in the past four years (including at least seven from 2013)
column6: clearly assembled by someone familiar with the best of Knx.’s catalogue. While it eschews the pop remixes that might entice listeners in favor of deeper cuts
column7: its 53 short pieces (most falling between one and two minutes) provide a fine introduction to an enormous
column8: if capricious
column9: talent.

column1: Knx. rejects the free release schedule that so many in the hip-hop community have embraced
column2: which is likely the reason he remains relatively obscure-- his bandcamp mixes
column3: at $5 a pop
column4: are out of your standard internet-comber’s price range. But while post-Dilla beatmaking fervor has reached its highest point
column5: there’s certainly room to be made for a producer steeped in the history of black music and still with it enough to put out remixes of Drake
column6: Miguel
column7: and Danny Brown.

column1: The tracks on Anthology don't make it as easy for sample-spotters as on some of Knxledge's past releases. For every Jadakiss ad-lib
column2: every Illmatic skit
column3: there’s an unrecognizable treatment of Camp Lo’s “Luchini AK (This Is It)” or a magical horn salvo like the one on “Pho”. Creating collages from the unfamiliar helps to show the fallacy in thinking of this kind of music as unoriginal
column4: while also adding to Knx.’s legend as a prodigious crate-digger-- a snippet from an episode of ""What’s Happening"" on “Rude” is a perfect find for the track’s dreamy mix. Just as attractive is the beatmaker’s lack of snobbery: one of the best tracks here “[Lets]TalkAbtit” samples liberally from Tori Kelly
column5: an amateur artist best known from <i>America’s Most Talented Kids
column6: and later on
column7: “TooKlose[latensi]” is a remix of Next’s famous warning.

column1: Comparisons between Madlib and Knx. are inevitable as both artists are reclusive and prolific
column2: with more interest in churning out beat after jazzy beat than classifying their music. But there are some key differences. Madlib
column3: as befits Stones Throw's flagship artist
column4: is more polished
column5: his music more holistic
column6: with a better eye for tracks that make sense together. He’s also more exploratory
column7: constantly ranging to different countries and genres
column8: and ocasionally to different personalities
column9: in search of new inspiration. By contrast Knxledge doesn’t seem as interested in albums (he’s more taken with EPs) and his tracks often have little in common from one to the next. He’s firmly ensconced within the world of black American music
column10: and has more interest in sampling and remixing contemporary sounds than Madlib does.

column1: None of which is to say that fans of the former will have anything against the latter. Both are shining examples of an artistic type that seems increasingly rare. (Though
column2: admittedly it can be difficult to get a tally of artistic shut-ins.) A recent article in the New York Times highlighted another of their kin
column3: a Brooklyn artist named Rafael Leonardo Black
column4:
who has been steadily making art for three decades in near total seclusion. Black was quoted as saying that “people who become what are called artists don’t stop.” Anthology demonstrates about as well as any of his other releases that Knx. is a consummate artist.

"|18237.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18237-knx-anthology/|7.6|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19409/homepage_large.0a1fd495.jpg|Ecstasy & Release|31440.0|TNT Subhead|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Groovement']|2013-07-01 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:08.590989|"

Right before a Caribbean vacation in 2009
column2: I got turned on to a slow-moving yet sunkissed slice of Balearica perfect for laying on the beach. Produced by an unknown Portuguese duo named Mendes & Alçada
column3: they had but that lone single to their credit. A bit of digging revealed that one half of that duo
column4: Tiago Miranda
column5: was quite a busy producer in his own right. Soon after
column6: his tracks turned up on labels ranging from Italians Do It Better to Japan’s Ene
column7: from Prins Thomas’ Internasjonal Spesial to DFA
column8: while his band Gala Drop was beginning to garner some notice as well (though Miranda has since left that group). While the labels may have been varied
column9: Tiago's adept nature for crafting tracks that could be leftfield disco
column10: acid
column11: or psychedelic dub house connected them all.

column1: Ecstasy & Release-- released under the name TNT Subhead-- marks Miranda's first full-length effort. But his name appears nowhere on the album sleeve or on the record labels; there are no credits whatsoever. And judging by the cover art
column2: it looks more like a lost agitprop 80s post-punk record than something suited for dancing. It seems destined to be mis-filed
column3: which may be what Miranda wants.

column1: The music itself seems unwilling to be beholden to any one genre. Opener “Story of the Eye” namechecks the sexually-kinked novella by Georges Bataille
column2: but favors the smooth minimal pulses of something like Steve Reich's Music for 18 Musicians
column3: bolstered with chimes
column4: rattles
column5: and some live drums. The textures are enthralling although the track builds only to drain away slowly. The incessant
column6: anxious hi-hats on “Can’t Relax” fall somewhere between “Vote for Miles” and “Someone Great” and make the song feel overly caffeinated and on-edge.

column1: It leads into the album’s squelching standout track
column2: “Icelberg”
column3: which thrills even though it never quite settles into being electro or acid
column4: its icy arpeggios meeting a heavily-reverbed guitar line that warms it ever so slightly. The title track repeats “We all need love” ad infinitum
column5: giving it the feel of an early Chicago house track
column6: though the rock guitar nudges it beyond simple pastiche.

column1: The second half of the album brightens its tone ever so slightly. “Think of Sex But Not of You” uses a bowed cello and a stand-up bass line to erect a sleek and spacy house track out
column2: soon building up enough steam to sound like one of Larry Heard’s more jazz-tinged productions. A more primitive drum machine pushes “The Book of Yes” along
column3: adding analog synth gurgles
column4: bloops
column5: and a touch of acid along the way.

column1: It sounds like Miranda repurposed the acid line he deployed on his excellent leftfield 2010 single “Motorcycles” (a track that James Murphy played out often at that time) for penultimate track
column2: “Arp K Found”. Yanking out the live drums and churning guitar line of the original and layering more synth washes across it instead
column3: it doesn’t work quite as well. Ecstasy & Release makes me pine for a compilation that might truly bring all of Miranda's myriad productions in one handy package. But as a debut
column4: it's an encouraging sign
column5:
no matter what genre he decides to go into next.

"|18218.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18218-tnt-subhead-ecstasy-release/|7.3|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19437/homepage_large.40d9931c.jpg|Random Access Memories Memories|31465.0|Daftside|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-06-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:09.160734|"

For all the discussion around the backward-looking facade of Daft Punk's Random Access Memories
column2: there was one aspect most people could agree on: it felt expensive. There were echoes of a once-thriving industry in there
column3: harking back to a time of money being endlessly funneled into lavish studio complexes
column4: sometimes in aid of wild vanity projects. RAM added a whole other level of expenditure in service of the concept of retro. You can buy all the vintage amps and instruments you want
column5: loot endless thrift stores to get just the right period ruffle on your shirt. But can you hire the guy who played drums on Michael Jackson's Off the Wall? In a sense it's a grand folly
column6: an ill-fitting match for the way music is mostly consumed at this point in time. You're not likely to hear the nuances of Bob Ludwig's mastering job through tinny laptop speakers
column7: crappy earbuds
column8: low bitrate MP3s
column9: and streaming YouTube clips.

column1: Of course the sheer ambition of RAM is a large part of its appeal
column2: a big group purposefully acting big to flesh out the music as they imagine it in their heads. Nicolas Jaar's Darkside project
column3: here renamed Daftside
column4: take all that aspiration and siphon out every drop of it from the original source. This album
column5: really just a series of clips uploaded to Soundcloud
column6: remixes RAM in full
column7: deconstructing it to resemble a thin
column8: hollowed-out version of its original self. It's an internet-redux model of Daft Punk's work
column9: a scratchy counterpart that sees virtue in the kind of ultra-low production values and consumption models that RAM veers away from. The first half of Daftside's ""Give Life Back to Music"" is positively emaciated
column10: its drums falling flat
column11: its cymbal splashes resembling old Casio presets caked in cheap distortion. It's the kind of thing John ""J.R."" Robinson
column12: Daft Punk’s ludicrously accomplished drummer on the original track
column13: must have nightmares about.

column1: It's difficult to judge exactly how long Jaar and his musical partner
column2: Dave Harrington
column3: spent on this work (probably not much
column4: considering how quickly they turned it around). So the tweaking is minimal at times
column5: with pitches shifted resolutely down and that crackly flimsiness recurring as a theme. There was already something of a sad-robot motif to some of RAM
column6: and the downturned atmosphere here emphasizes it further. ""Get Lucky"" sounds positively bluesy at times
column7: with Pharrell's vocal reduced to a drunken slur
column8: making its central refrain sound more like a lost hope than a promise of good times ahead. It's indicative of this project's inclination for taking big moments and making them small
column9: pushing them inward. Even RAM's centerpiece
column10: the Paul Williams-fronted ""Touch""
column11: is pulled out of its its wide open space
column12: given a minimal techno makeover
column13: then shunted to the penultimate slot in the running order.

column1: Daftside's ability to find something else in this music doesn't just stretch to them reducing the mood to a set of internal post-club jams. At times they're looking for the direct inverse in mood
column2: turning the gloomy ""Game of Love"" up in pace so it resembles a shuffling disco tune. For ""Contact"" they open with a gnarled take on the noise bursts at its close
column3: placing it at the start of the tracklisting in a move that mirrors Oneohtrix Point Never's positioning of the similarly bracing wake-up call ""Nil Admirari"" on Returnal. Surprisingly
column4: the material that seems more in Jaar's orbit-- the slow-build electronics of ""Motherboard""
column5: the pulsing ""Giorgio by Moroder""-- produce less satisfying results
column6: with the former a mess of runaway electronics and the latter a tangle of empty loops. ""Doin' It Right"" is better
column7: taking Panda Bear's escalating vocal and turning it into a wonderfully ugly set of belches.

column1: Amusingly
column2: for something that often deliberately drags so hard
column3: Daftside simply brush over one of the RAM tracks that taps into that mood
column4: turning the indifferent ""Lose Yourself to Dance"" into a two-second vocal passage then moving on. That sense of play
column5: resembling Jaar and Harrington poking Daft Punk with a stick then gleefully running away
column6: is partly what makes this a far greater work than standard remix albums. At times they're looking for nuances in the original
column7: small threads they can pick up and take somewhere else. Elsewhere they're just having fun
column8: acting on instincts
column9: never over-awed by the material. Certainly there's an overall feel of taking all of Daft Punk's expansion and turning in a low-rent version of it
column10: an Off-Off-Broadway version constructed in a cardboard pyramid patched together with tape and glue. Jaar's Space is Only Noise worked from a similar mix of nuttiness and constraint. Somehow
column11:
he found a way back there through a most unlikely route.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19397/homepage_large.2efb5d3f.jpg|BE|29539.0|Beady Eye|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2013-06-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:09.914470|"

How long can the Gallagher brothers engage in this tiresome game of side-project chicken? Technically
column3: Liam’s band Beady Eye and Noel’s High Flying Birds aren’t side projects-- we're supposed to believe that these indifferently received endeavors are decisive steps away from their busted-up partnership in Oasis
column4: which was still one of the world’s more reliable arena-filling rock bands at the time of its dissolution in 2009. But Liam and Noel can’t help sounding like incomplete halves in search of a lost whole when apart. On Beady Eye’s 2011 debut <i>Different Gear Still Speeding
column5: Liam had the attitude but not the songs; Noel’s High Flying Birds had the songs but not the attitude. Two years later
column6: it’s safe to assume that anyone who still cares about either one of these guys would rather hear them together than on their own
column7: trying in vain to compensate for the other brother’s absence.

column1: But the Gallaghers are nothing if not stubborn
column2: which means the world will have to wait at least one more album/tour cycle before the inevitable reunion cash-in. With Beady Eye’s new BE
column3: Liam gamely goes through the motions of progressing beyond the rudimentary Oasisisms of Different Gear by employing TV on the Radio’s Dave Sitek as producer. The results are about what you’d expect: BE is somewhat more adventurous than Different Gear
column4: and certainly more dynamic. The horns laid over the menacing introduction of “Flick of the Finger” provide a touch of spice to Beady Eye’s meat-and-potatoes stew
column5: and the ambient noise that pads out psych-tinged rockers like “Soul Love” ostensibly improves on the straight-forward lumbering that distinguishes long stretches of the first Beady Eye record. On paper
column6: it’s a “better” album. So why is BE less enjoyable than Different Gear? Could it be that hiring a “smart” producer like Sitek was exactly the opposite of what this pleasurably dumb band requires?

column1: For all of the finesse that Sitek brings to BE
column2: he might’ve been better off just making sure that the guitars were turned up loud enough. “I’m Just Saying” boasts the record’s most magnetic riff
column3: clanking out of a burst of feedback and arrogantly barreling forward on supercharged power chords. It’s exactly the sort of song that should kill on a Beady Eye record
column4: and yet on BE it’s a little too clean
column5: even antiseptic. This is a band that needs to sound a little blurry and blown-out; Beady Eye’s broad strokes and bombastic flourishes are more satisfying when you can’t make out the specifics. Sitek’s pristine production only highlights how half-baked many of these songs are
column6: especially lyrically. “Second Bite of the Apple” is a potentially fun snotball of classic Liam Gallagher insouciance
column7: but lines like
column8: “Shake my tree/ Where’s the apple for me/ Tickle my feet with the enemy” (or possibly
column9: the NME)  are better when vaguely heard than comprehended.

column1: “Second Bite of the Apple” was written by Gem Archer
column2: one-third of Beady Eye’s songwriting triumvirate that also includes Gallagher and Andy Bell. It’s a mild surprise that Gallagher’s songs are the best on BE in a walk-- it’s downright shocking how much he sounds like his brother on the pretty album closer “Start Anew”
column3: a budget-minded “Champagne Supernova” with killer echo-y drum sounds lifted from John Lennon’s Phil Spector-produced solo records. If Liam seems hamstrung as a rocker on <i>BE
column4: at least he’s showing more promise as a balladeer. If that’s another ploy to convince Noel that he can be replaced
column5: and therefore should cancel this solo career silliness and revive Oasis
column6:
BE might serve a purpose after all.

Iamsu! is Sudan Williams
column2: a producer and rapper from Richmond
column3: Cal.
column4: who has condensed his birth name
column5: comic-book-lettering style
column6: for maximal impact and congeniality. His music has a similarly blinding elevator pitch quality: In just a few short years
column7: the 23-year-old has assembled a formidable catalog of colorful
column8: catchy
column9: and impressive mixtapes. His latest
column10: Kilt 2
column11: doubles down on all of his strongest and most likeable qualities: Largely self-produced
column12: high-energy
column13: and creative
column14: it shows Iamsu! continuing to transform from a promising
column15: agreeable Bay Area rap figure into a burgeoning star.

column1: On Kilt 2
column2: Su positions himself as an enterprising
column3: funny young trend synthesizer
column4: working hard to summarize the rowdy sprawl of his city's rap music riches and prep them for cross-country consumption. There are pieces of nearly every current Bay Area rap style floating through Kilt; DJ Mustard's infectiously bright and simple ratchet sound; hyphy
column5: as the sound has come to be defined by E-40 over the past decade (""On Citas
column6: which brings Mistah F.A.B. and gravel-voiced Keak Da Sneak for good measure); the mournful
column7: soul-inflected mob music of Husalah
column8: Joe Blow
column9: the Jacka and others in the Livewire/AR/Mob Figaz axis. ""The Science""
column10: which overflows with wooly saxophone
column11: talkbox
column12: jazz flute
column13: and grand piano
column14: is a rich DJ Quik homage. It sounds like an Easter Egg hunt meant only for Bay Area rap nerd-aficionados
column15: but Su neatly corrals all of this context
column16: shuffles it
column17: and spits it out
column18: stamped with earnest
column19: clever
column20: likeable raps.

column1: You could call it Su's College Dropout impulse; he probably wouldn't mind. ""Found bravery in my bravado/ Trying to live up to that rapper from Chicago
column2: he raps on ""The Science"". On ""Best Thing Yet""
column3: he spells it out even more clearly: ""Bumpin The College Dropout
column4: tryin' to rhyme like him
column5: he says. Su has a few Westian qualities-- his ability
column6: for one to treat the story of his rap career as an epic hero's journey
column7: with or without the autobiographical nitty-gritty to sell it. ""I recognize the uncertainty of a career in music
column8: but I still handle it perfectly
column9: "" Su says on ""Citas""
column10: and boasts on ""Father God"" that ""I could go my whole lifetime without your cosign."" The quality he shares most with West
column11: though
column12: is his burning
column13: evident desire to reach all demographics; on the feather-light ""Hipster Girls""
column14: Su raps about Instagram likes and Tumblr posts
column15: somehow without losing everyone in the room. ""Float"" and ""Let Go"" are pillowy
column16: dazed love jams that gently bump pool rafts with Wiz Khalifa.

column1: The production
column2: when not handled directly by Su
column3: comes from other members of his Invasion crew
column4: a rotating cast of producers that have distinct specialties: P-Lo sources the spare
column5: darker beats; the pinwheeling
column6: airy numbers come from Kuya Beats. Iamsu!'s own production
column7: however
column8: is the most ambitious and musical-- his beat for ""On Citas"" melts
column9: halfway through
column10: into a second section of breathy female vocals and diaphanous keys. Even when it's dark and menacing
column11: like ""Father God""
column12: there is a nimble snap to Su's music. His reedy
column13: modest voice makes him sound like a cousin to Khalifa
column14: but his rapping is deceptively complicated
column15: stepping nimbly in and out of double and triple time and running light
column16: high-stepping circles around the beat. He's not quite charismatic enough yet to match his outsized ambitions
column17:
but Kilt 2 is another solid step up his ladder.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19088/homepage_large.348b2926.jpg|Manifest Decimation|31190.0|Power Trip|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Southern Lord']|2013-06-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:11.011142|"

Before Manifest Decimation
column2: Power Trip were one of those groups people said you needed to see live to understand. This isn't to take away from the EPs and singles they released before this LP
column3: because they contained good songs. It's just that they were still eclipsed by frontman Riley Gale and company's whirling dervish stage presence. There's a reason they've toured plenty with their west coast pals
column4: Trash Talk: they play bridge shows
column5: they make liberal use of gang vocals
column6: their fans are very into circle pits
column7: and
column8: hell
column9: they shout out straightedge hardcore bands on their Facebook page. But this debut eight-song collection
column10: their first release for Southern Lord
column11: is such a strong record that you could never see Power Trip live and still understand what makes them special.

column1: The Dallas
column2: TX
column3: quintet play crossover
column4: i.e. thrash that draws from hardcore punk. The guitars
column5: placed up front
column6: are clean
column7: dexterous
column8: and fast; the vocals and drums
column9: in the back
column10: are draped in sludge and reverb. Those elements will
column11: at times
column12: remind you of the darker side of the old-school thrash spectrum (Slayer)
column13: but the spirit of this stuff pulls more from the hardcore scene
column14: like their Astoria forebears Leeway or
column15: on the burlier side
column16: Cro-Mags. Unlike other contemporary thrash bands
column17: Power Trip create a legitimately violent atmosphere
column18: and don't go around wearing sleeveless jean jackets with the front of their baseball caps turned up. They sound less like they're here to party
column19: and more like they want to kick your ass.

column1: You could safely say Power Trip are a punk band. Their whiplash fight song
column2: ""Power Trip""
column3: includes the lines ""We ride as one/ We’re ruled by none
column4: and you believe them. Manifest closer
column5: ""The Hammer of Doubt""
column6: was originally out
column7: in different form
column8: on a 2010 compilation called America's Hardcore. They've covered Prong. They could easily cover Black Flag. They remind me of my early days in high school when I was coming out of a steady diet of hardcore and getting into bands like Metallica
column9: D.R.I
column10: Suicidal Tendencies
column11: and Anthrax.

column1: The music on Manifest Decimation is bleak
column2: dirty
column3: heavy. It's also very catchy. At any given moment
column4: Gale can sound like Lemmy fronting Cro-Mags
column5: Discharge
column6: or Exodus. At other times
column7: he locates a grizzlier tone that evokes guys wearing corpsepaint. There are samples about death and Texas from movies like Robocop 2 and Blood Simple. The Italian artist Paolo ""Madman"" Girardi offers detailed old school apocalyptic metal cover art. The lyrics deal with government and religious suppression like so: ""Histories trapped in illusion
column8: who sees through who?/ For every mindless vision of who owns the truth/ For every one who spoke out
column9: thousands were slain/ Torture and bloodshed in the sake of some holy name."" That's the classic side of things
column10: but while Manifest Decimation does sounds vintage (the chug-chug-chug
column11: the whammy-bar abusing solos)
column12: these guys aren't stuck in 1986.

column1: What helps makes this album great
column2: outside of the excellent riffs and choruses
column3: is the way Power Trip mix in flourishes that place Manifest Decimation firmly in the present. (In that sense
column4: you'll also think about another Texas band
column5: the now defunct Iron Age.) There's nothing obvious; it's little touches
column6: like the weirdo echo effect on Gale's voice throughout. The album opens with a blast of swirling feedback and ominous synth tones
column7: something threaded throughout the album via brief
column8: almost industrial snippets. The feeling's picked up in some of those headier vocal effects
column9: too-- the phased pan on ""Conditioned to Death"" (which features some great early Metallica riffing)
column10: the disembodied backing vocals on the frantic ""Murderer's Row"" (complete with some Slayer-like soloing). It adds to the urgency and intensity
column11: and also sets them apart. That said
column12: none of it would matter if they weren't writing songs like the swarming title track or the Motörhead-banging ""Heretic's Fork"".

column1: Recently
column2: people who take metal seriously have spent some time talking about whether or not thrash is dead
column3: or if we're actually in the midst of a thrash revival. Power Trip have found a way to create something new by pulling from the past. In that way
column4:
it feels like they exist on both sides of the argument without giving a shit either way.

"|17893.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17893-power-trip-manifest-decimation/|8.0|Brandon Stosuy

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19348/homepage_large.0304dd3e.jpg|Hailu Mergia and His Classical Instrument|31413.0|Hailu Mergia|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Awesome Tapes From Africa']|2013-06-28 00:00:00|1985|2016-06-11 16:56:11.512855|"

In 1977
column2: Walias Band recorded a darkly bobbing funk instrumental with an ominous horn theme called “Muziqawi Silt”. It was a couple years after the overthrow of Haile Selassie by Mengistu Haile Mariam
column3: and Mengistu’s Derg government had applied the brakes to Addis Ababa’s nightlife
column4: making it much harder for a working band to make a living. Music was still being made in abundance
column5: though
column6: and cassettes ultimately made it a lot easier to duplicate and distribute it. “Muziqawi Silt” surfaced in collector circles in the U.S. and Europe in the 90s and was canonized by a 2003 Ethiopiques volume
column7: and it’s since become one of the tiny handful of songs that non-Ethiopians use as a gateway into the country’s music. Antibalas even covered it.

column1: Hailu Mergia was the keyboardist for Walias Band. His organ playing is one of the only things a lot of people know about Ethiopian music. Walias Band was more important than just that one track
column2: though. When the band arrived on the scene
column3: the typical arrangement was for the venue-- usually a hotel-- to provide a band with instruments. Walias broke that mold by buying their own and working out contracts with the venues they played. In the early 80s
column4: during a tour of the United States
column5: Mergia and a few other members decided not to return home. That was the end of the band
column6: but they’d made their mark back home.

column1: A few years after moving to the U.S.
column2: Mergia decided to record an album that merged the sounds of his youth with modern technology. Working alone
column3: he assembled a drum machine
column4: a Rhodes piano
column5: a Yamaha DX7
column6: and his accordion
column7: and got to work arranging old Ethiopian songs for this mostly modern palette. The results are striking and unusual. If Cluster had been from Ethiopia instead of Germany
column8: this is probably about what they would have sounded like. Mergia uses the Yamaha to make his buzzy bass lines
column9: fills in chords and texture with the Rhodes
column10: and then solos over the top
column11: alternately on the accordion or the Yamaha DX7
column12: in an inimitably Ethiopian style. The sound is spare and unaffected
column13: the drum programming never deviating during any song
column14: though he sometimes augments the rhythmic push with vocals halfway between beatboxing and chanting.

column1: In addition to the fluttering modal melodies
column2: there are other distinctly Ethiopian signatures running through the music
column3: particularly in the triple meters and three-against-four rhythms of the songs. “Belew Beduby” stomps along on a swaying polyrhythm on a par with anything you’ll hear from early 70s Addis
column4: while “Hebo Lale” modifies that beat a bit for more of a boogie feel
column5: aided by a faster tempo. At the other end of the spectrum
column6: “Sewnetuwa” drifts along on an almost eight-bit-sounding bass line
column7: with Yamaha DX7 and accordion dueling on top.

column1: The overall effect of the album is difficult to describe. The music is simple and straightforward
column2: accomplished but not showy. It feels at once rural
column3: nostalgic
column4: and futuristic. Replace the drum machine with people clapping
column5: and you’d be a hair’s breadth from an ethnographic recording. Drum machines and synthesizers are common ingredients of Ethiopian pop music today
column6: but not in the same way they’re used here. Perhaps one of the things that sets this apart from other Ethiopian pop music is the fact that it was made in solitude
column7:
and specifically out of longing for a vanished past. It’s introverted in a way very little other music from the country is. It’s also not quite like anything else you’ve ever heard.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19406/homepage_large.73a52d2d.jpg|The Gifted|10147.0|Wale|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic'
column2:
'Maybach']|2013-06-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:12.118840|"

Wale’s third official album
column3: The Gifted
column4: had the bad luck to come out a week after Kanye’s Yeezus. It’s terrible timing for any pop album; for the former backpack rapper who found unexpected mainstream pop success who went into the studio to attempt a singular
column5: definitive artistic statement
column6: it's bound to set up some unfair comparisons. There’s also a vaguely beefy line in “Heaven’s Afternoon” about how Wale wears Givenchy but doesn’t wear kilts that doesn’t help the situation.

column1: That said
column2: the fact that Wale’s decided to release such a left-field pop rap record at this point in his career is respectably daring. In fact
column3: it’s probably the most daring thing about The Gifted. For all its differences from Wale's closest chart competitors
column4: the music here (at least on the first half of the record) follows a path that was cleared as far back as the 90s: using the warm and lushly organic sound of peak-era Marvin Gaye and Stevie Wonder to reconnect hip-hop with a soulful revolutionary legacy that it turned away from when MCs started going in over 808 beats. It's not original
column5: but it's a good path to follow. (Chicago rapper Tree recently used a similar approach on his mixtape
column6: Sunday School II: When Church Lets Out
column7: probably one of the best rap records that’ll be released this year.)

column1: The music on The Gifted sounds fantastic
column2: with intricately arranged keys and strings
column3: stacks of soul and gospel-inspired backup vocals
column4: and deep
column5: rubbery bass lines. The problem is that Wale and his team made a really decent soul rap album without a rapper soulful enough to carry it. He’s a capable
column6: sometimes personable MC
column7: but he’s not an especially compelling one. His approach to the album’s more explicitly soul-oriented tracks is to intersperse his library of 2013 rap cliches about his personal struggle to success with the occasional line about social injustice. The combination is a jumbled
column8: awkward mess
column9: capped by a wasted guest appearance by Jerry Seinfeld on an excruciatingly unfunny dialogue with Wale on The Gifted's outro. He’s attempting to tap into the magic that Marvin and Stevie created back then
column10: but his understanding of what they did is bafflingly shallow. Wale seems to think that those records succeeded by their string arrangements and keyboard tones
column11: and with accurate enough reproductions of those at his fingertips
column12: he breezes past the part about writing lyrics that resonate with an audience enough to rattle their whole worldview. After days of listening to The Gifted on nearly constant rotation I can’t remember a single line from it.

column1: In the cruelest of ironies
column2: the album only really starts to come together when Wale abandons the high concept conscious stuff and goes straight for the pop jugular. “Clappers”
column3: the strongest track here
column4: is a big
column5: club-shaking bass anthem about girls with big butts. It’s absolutely ignorant as fuck
column6: but at least it’s fun and
column7: more vital
column8: straight to the point. Wale may not be a great thinker
column9: but he’s an accomplished entertainer who seems to have inherited some of the unabashed “anything to please the crowd” attitude from go-go groups in his hometown of Washington
column10: D.C. When he hits his stride here you can almost see him on stage
column11: gleefully controlling a packed audience.

column1: What seems to be the main purpose of the record is to elevate Wale beyond the level of Rick Ross’ reliable second-stringer
column2: a guy who’s capable of dropping the occasional strip club anthem in between a steady string of unremarkable features on pop songs. “Clappers” proves that when he embraces that job he’s actually really good at it. But if he wants to be taken as a serious artist like the ones he spends most of the record emulating
column3: he’s going to have to start taking some real chances and get real far out of the box
column4:
out to place where people are known to wear kilts.

"|18215.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18215-wale-the-gifted/|5.1|Miles Raymer

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19405/homepage_large.41e162e4.jpg|Enormous Door|31438.0|The Ex & Brass Unbound|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ex']|2013-06-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:12.585633|"

The list of punk bands that are significantly more awesome 33 years into their career than two years into it is very
column2: very short. So is the list of bands that can get away with replacing everybody except one (non-singing) member. Fortunately for remarkable Dutch band the Ex
column3: they're much more interested in expanding the horizons of their music than they are in repeating their past: they've generally discarded their entire old repertoire whenever their line-up has changed. And Enormous Door is an acrobatic
column4: ferocious record
column5: a welcome burst of electric noise and squealing horns from a group whose power and flexibility keep growing with time.

column1: The only remaining member of the Ex's original 1979 lineup is guitarist Terrie Hessels; vocalist G.W. Sok left in 2009
column2: and was replaced by the band's longtime associate Arnold de Boer. (De Boer's sly
column3: mutterering croon isn't quite as commanding as Sok's martial two-note bark
column4: although his piercing guitar tone is an excellent addition to the band. He also gets points for writing lyrics about recent research in embodied cognition.) But the trio of Hessels
column5: guitarist Andy Moor
column6: and drummer Katherina Bornefeld has been the core of the Ex since they hit their stride around 1990. They're a hellaciously tight
column7: tough rhythm section-- they haven't had a bass guitarist since the mid-2000s
column8: but both Moor and Hessels have started playing baritone guitar-- and most of their songs are built on Bornefeld's floor-rattling grooves.

column1: What the Ex have learned over the past few decades is that they thrive on collaboration
column2: especially with melodists from musical traditions that don't have much to do with their punk rock roots
column3: and that they've got a serious taste for certain kinds of African music. A lot of their best records have been made with guests
column4: from their two albums with the late avant-garde cellist Tom Cora to their recent recordings with septuagenarian Ethiopian jazz saxophonist Getatchew Mekuria. Since 2010
column5: they've occasionally performed with a shifting quartet of horn players under the name Brass Unbound-- here
column6: it's Ken Vandermark
column7: Mats Gustafsson
column8: Wolter Wierbos
column9: and Roy Paci
column10: all of whom have formidable reputations in the jazz world.

column1: Enormous Door is essentially a document of their live act from the Brass Unbound shows: a series of big
column2: rolling rhythms that let the horn section switch off between tightly arranged charts and headlong free-jazz battles
column3: or let one style mutate into the other. De Boer sings on most of them; his English-language lyrics touch on consumer culture and unadventurous vacations
column4: but they're mostly vehicles for his voice to be another rhythm instrument. (Bornefeld gets a turn at the mic too: a revved-up cover of Mahmoud Ahmed's mid-70s Ethiopian love song ""Belomi Benna"" with enthusiastically rolled Rs and near-hardcore double time on the choruses.) The one song reprised here from their first album with de Boer
column5: 2010's Catch My Shoe
column6: is ""Bicycle Illusion""
column7: which is distinctly improved both by having spent a couple of years in their repertoire and by letting Brass Unbound augment the noise attack of its final few minutes.

column1: And
column2: at the end of the album
column3: the Ex finally give us a glimpse of their past. ""Theme from Konono No. 2"" is the second song they've written around the Congolese band Konono No. 1's signature Morse-code riff; the first was on 2004's Turn
column4: and a staple of their live shows around that time
column5: so this is a real trip down memory lane for them. That ""Theme from Konono"" was an exercise in constantly building
column6: monomaniacal intensity
column7: but from the moment Brass Unbound stroll into ""No. 2""
column8: it becomes a different kind of song: not a demonstration of sweaty power
column9: but a raucous celebration of how much this band has changed
column10:
and what its alliances have given it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19412/homepage_large.e9f989fe.jpg|The Visitor|251.0|Matias Aguayo|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cómeme']|2013-06-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:14.112623|"

Matias Aguayo has always been a goof
column2: the type of jump-on-the-table artist who's having way more fun than you. He depends on this persona for his scatterbrained takes on house and electro; it takes more than a little charm and panache to get someone up on that table with you. So it's problematic that it feels like Aguayo's laboring for long stretches of his third album
column3: The Visitor. Aguayo has
column4: in the past
column5: mixed in noisier
column6: less friendly tracks
column7: but on The Visitor these tracks are more prominent
column8: busier
column9: and messier.

column1: The Visitor deepens Aguayo's dependence on his voice as he steers away from merely assisting dance tracks to carrying song structures. For an inveterate weirdo
column2: Aguayo has been involved in a surprising number of smashes: the catchy-despite-itself ""Rollerskate""
column3: his vocal turn on Battles' ""Ice Cream""
column4: his DJ Koze-remixed ""Minimal"" and its spiritual companion
column5: ""Walter Neff"". On his best tracks
column6: the rhythms act as a centrifugal force
column7: an axis around which his voice and melodic detritus can spin. Too many songs on The Visitor fail to establish this center
column8: and the result is an album of oddball psychedelia with its wacky creator foregrounded.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: we've reached the point of diminishing returns on Aguayo's imagination
column3: as The Visitor veers from style to style recklessly; The Visitor was recorded with a host of South American artists
column4: many of them residents of the Cómeme label. ""Dear Inspector""
column5: for example
column6: is a long
column7: gently tumbling pop song that sounds like someone in the Elephant Six collective bought an MPC sampler. After dragging ""Dear Inspector"" out for nearly eight minutes
column8: Aguayo abruptly switches modes on ""By the Graveyard""
column9: a reverb-heavy storm that sounds like Can's more aggressive moments
column10: a style he revisits on the album's clanging
column11: industrial closer
column12: ""A Certain Spirit"". These tracks have plenty of rhythm
column13: but Aguayo can't seem to find it. He shrouds himself in effects and shouts the songs' titles
column14: retaining none of his casual tunefulness.

column1: Aguayo has trouble balancing his whimsical impulses with his aggressive ones throughout The Visitor
column2: like he can't decide if he wants to flirt or brood. The chant-heavy ""Llegó El Don"" is domineering
column3: its thwacking rhythms pointed right at the listener. ""Levantate Diegors"" busies itself with noise
column4: unleashing dozens of small rhythmic flourishes around its bossy
column5: bass-y vocals. It's not just that these tracks are less fun
column6: it's that they're not compellingly deviant either. The big
column7: evil synth line that anchors the creeping ""Las Cruces"" feels like a better mix of Aguayo's new style and troublemaking instincts.

column1: Aguayo is better
column2: too
column3: when his tracks are less cluttered. He captures a little of his old magic on ""Una Fiesta Diferente""
column4: a vocal-heavy stew where he and some background singers spin an easy tune out of bilingual lyrics. ""El Sucu Tucu"" is frantic but focused
column5: with Aguayo's staccato vocals matching the song's eager snares. ""Rrrrr"" opens the album with a stupid
column6: inviting bassline
column7: and the chorus's purring
column8: rolling ""r""'s are vintage Aguayo. Aguayo's music is brave and increasingly complex
column9: but it's worth wondering how well these impulses are serving his tracks. There's potential in The Visitor's mix of electro
column10: new wave
column11: and pop
column12: but it's obscuring or distorting Aguayo's personality
column13:
which is the engine that has driven his songs for so long.

Spectrals' charming
column4: straightforward 2011 debut Bad Penny was largely a family affair: Louis Jones wrote
column5: sang
column6: and played almost every instrument on the album
column7: and brother Will provided the drums. The Jones brothers still make up the core of Spectrals
column8: but new record Sob Story features a much more prominent name behind the boards: J.R. White
column9: the bassist/producer who formerly made up one half of Girls. The band flew from their Yorkshire home base to White's own San Francisco for much of the recording of Sob Story
column10: and dipped into White's Rolodex
column11: too: Sob Story features session musicians on guitar
column12: pedal steel
column13: and bass. With capable playing
column14: veteran production
column15: and refined
column16: confident songwriting and vocals from Jones
column17: Sob Story's best cuts sparkle with easy
column18: compact melodicism
column19: a pop rock accomplishment reminiscent of early Girls singles like ""Lust for Life"".

column1: Jones' vocal improvement is one of the most obvious differences between Bad Penny and Sob Story
column2: noticeable from the record's first seconds; a voice that was serviceable and nondescript two years ago has bloomed into a wonderfully textured
column3: indelible croon
column4: rich and distinct. It has a fair bit of range too
column5: comfortable carrying the scruffy strut of ""A Heartbeat Behind"" and the expansive
column6: cutting ""Milky Way"" in equal measure. On standout ""Karaoke""
column7: backed by a pinwheeling guitar line
column8: kinetic percussion
column9: and sighing backing harmonies
column10: Jones admits
column11: ""I don't think I was really cut out for this/ Who is?"" It's delivered like a conversation with a close friend at a crowded pub
column12: and it's remarkably effective
column13: a testament to the newfound strength of Jones' voice and his knack for shrugging
column14: affable tunes.

column1: Sob Story's other highlights are similarly effective. The album is at its best when Jones delivers brisk
column2: bright rock with endearing hooks
column3: whether it's through the simple stomp and sliding minor-key harmonies of opener ""Let Me Cave In"" or Big Star-like power-pop love songs like ""Limousine"". A solid sense of humor shines through the melodies
column4: too: on ""Something to Cry About""
column5: he's imploring a lover to make him upset as fodder for new material
column6: and on ""Blue Whatever"" he laments that a long-distance relationship might as well be taking place across galaxies rather than cities.

column1: Things begin to lag when Jones drops the tempo and tries his hand at balladry. The transition from the sweet
column2: rollicking guitar pop of ""Karaoke"" into the slow
column3: pedal steel-laden title track is like riding your bike on a gorgeous
column4: sunny day
column5: only to steer into a thick mud patch; eerie
column6: croaked closer ""In a Bad Way"" ends the album on an unfortunate
column7: ponderous note. ""Friend Zone"" is just what you'd expect from a song with that title
column8: a concept that requires pinpoint execution
column9: and Jones' well-meaning effort falls short. It's too bad
column10: because the components making up these slower cuts-- heavy pedal steel lines
column11: emotive vocals-- are mostly gorgeous in their own right
column12: but they falter as part of dragging wholes. But even in Sob Story's weaker moments
column13: it's hard not to root for the Jones brothers. They've managed to cultivate a real sense of personality over their first two records on the backs of good-intentioned charm
column14: lyrical wit and relatability
column15: and Louis' evolving
column16:
idiosyncratic vocals. That likable and unassuming identity encourages fond glances toward any minor missteps in the meantime.

As much fun as the goofball aspect of thrash metal's personality can be
column2: it does require a dark side in order to keep its balance
column3: a Slayer to offset its Anthrax and make sure that for every thrash fan in a flipped brim cap there’s one who looks like they have legitimately practiced Satanic blood rituals. As long as we have Noisem
column4: that darker balance will be struck.

column1: Formerly known as Necropsy
column2: Noisem is a quintet of teenagers from Baltimore who are casually making their older contemporaries look bad by comparison. Their debut album
column3: Agony Defined (released by the consistently good Baltimore micro-indie A389) takes a basic thrash template
column4: adds a generous measure of death metal
column5: forges the alloy into something the size and shape of a railroad spike
column6: and then spends 26 minutes hammering it between your eyes.

column1: It’s a remarkably lean album
column2: even by thrash’s typically minimalist standards. Overdubs are rare
column3: although producer Kevin Bernsten makes sure that the barest moments hit with the same slab-like
column4: bass-heavy density as the louder ones. Noisem’s songwriting is just as uncomplicated
column5: generally consisting of a riff for the verses
column6: a slight variation for the chorus
column7: and maybe a couple-bar breakdown. The only parts that verge on ostentation are the frequent guitar solos
column8: whammy bar-abusing divebombs that are technically virtuosic and
column9: more importantly
column10: evil enough to justify their existence as something more than simple flash. It's a familiar formula
column11: especially from the first couple of Slayer records
column12: which came closest to perfecting the style.

column1: It's by no means inaccurate to compare Agony Defined to Slayer-- they scratch a similar itch-- but the band Noisem resembles most might be Iceage. Both groups consist of young musicians who despite-- or perhaps because of-- their youth are able to drill down to the core of a genre that’s been accumulating stylistic cruft for the past couple decades
column2: rediscovering its most basic appeal. Noisem comes close to locating the ideal of a death-tinged thrash band the same way that Iceage does with the concept of a hardcore band. Like Iceage
column3: Noisem's vocalist
column4: Tyler Carnes
column5: has an approach a little bit weirder and more individual than the style’s used to
column6: often sounding like a melodic death rattle.

column1: There’s some footage from Noisem’s set at the most recent Maryland Death Fest that proves beyond doubt that Agony Defined is no fluke. From the video evidence they’re as scarilyy good live as they are on record. The thrash scene is still a niche
column2: and Noisem’s altogether a little more purely metal than the type of band that gets much traction outside of a specialist audience. But if there’s one metal band worth paying attention to right now
column3: this is it. I know it’s a greedy thought to have when I’m still nowhere near tired of their first record
column4:
but I can’t wait to see what they do next.

Olympia has been tipped as Austra's ""dance album
column4: though the Toronto band's debut
column5: Feel It Break
column6: contained enough club-worthy material: the arpeggiating likes of ""Beat and the Pulse""
column7: and B-sides ""Energy"" and ""Young and Gay"" much more so. Its remixes came off less like mandatory singles life extensions than a glimpse into what these gothy tracks got up to after the witching hour. On Olympia
column8: the main change from Feel It Break isn't adding beats but adding more in general: the core trio doubled to a six-piece
column9: bringing more layers to Katie Stelmanis' songwriting
column10: and pushing it in a more house-inspired synth-pop direction.

column1: It's an obvious-seeming move these days
column2: but Austra was close enough to this sound previously that it's not too jarring a development. Plus
column3: they push in that direction with an unusual sonic palette: sparkly harp solos
column4: deadpan early-Knife riffs
column5: vocals that sound druidic
column6: even guttural
column7: including New Age-evoking morose choral drones. Much continues to be made of Stelmanis's opera training
column8: but opera's just about the only sound that isn't represented here. It takes a while to get familiar with these sounds
column9: which seems deliberate. ""You'll never know me
column10: I'll never know you
column11: as Stelmanis sings on ""Sleep""
column12: outright repudiating the notion of instant dancefloor connection.

column1: Stelmanis' solo work would turn single lines-- ""be your own company
column2: ""join us""-- into manifestos
column3: a tendency for studies on a single riff that carried through into Feel It Break. Olympia sounds far more expansive and a little less removed-- ""We Become"" even grooves. Though opener ""What We Done?"" has the bass throb and synth counterpoint of a late-night dance hit
column4: it doesn't do much else
column5: and vocalist Katie Stelmanis sings her melody as if what she's hearing is a requiem. ""Annie (Oh Muse
column6: You)""
column7: the noisiest
column8: synth-clappingest track here
column9: mutters where there might have been melodies. Lead single ""Home"" is built on a house piano riff any of today's revivalists would envy
column10: but it takes its sweet time getting there.

column1: Stelmanis has said she listened to a lot of early Cat Power while recording Olympia
column2: and while nothing here sounds anywhere near as stark
column3: the lyrics often do
column4: and lead appropriately tense
column5: nervy sounding songs. There are still hints of Feel It Break's aesthetic-heavy mysticism
column6: but in general
column7: Olympia is an album where a title like ""You Changed My Life"" is the sort to be delivered over sincere piano. (Over a low-end-heavy chug
column8: but still.) ""Forgive Me""
column9: a plea to an estranged lover or friend
column10: is blunt both lyrically (""What do I have to do to make you forgive me?"") and musically: obsessive
column11: pinprick-tense
column12: desperate for closure. ""Home"" has a similar centerpiece-- ""you know that it hurts me when you don't come home at night""-- and the arrangement sounds like the feverish
column13: sleepless worry that accompanies.

column1: Much of Olympia is disarmingly personal
column2: and some
column3: as usual with Austra
column4: is political-- but not the stuff of Stelmanis and drummer Maya Postepski's previous riot grrl band Galaxy
column5: nor the cinemascope revolution of Shaking the Habitual (another cited inspiration) but something subtler. Throughout Olympia
column6: love is a radical act and heartbreak-- in greater supply here-- a failure of community; but the album doesn’t speak in those abstractions. “Painful Like” addresses bigotry
column7: specifically anti-gay (“We don’t have to marry…. In this town we’ll bury all the minds that clench too tight”)
column8: but makes its point through quick flashes of detail (“bruised skin on top of mine”)
column9: a startling
column10: candid sort of intimacy Olympia’s remaining tracks grasp for.

column1: Later on comes the album's centerpiece ""I Don't Care (I'm a Man)""
column2: the most fuck-off title Austra's ever written
column3: but the track has no dramatics
column4: just a coolly dispassionate gaze. Stelmanis plays something between a satisfied troll and a coroner surveying the third crime scene of the day
column5: monotone while detailing ""the whimper in her sigh
column6: the softer brutalizing-- but I don't care
column7: I'm a man."" It barely lasts a minute
column8: as if about to break into something more bracing; but the group's going not for shock but shrug value
column9: the sort that gets disturbing once you process what you've just heard. This
column10: it turns out
column11:
might be Austra's greatest strength.
