The opening track on Mavis Staples’ One True Vine
column2: her second record with Jeff Tweedy
column3: may sound familiar. The song is called “Holy Ghost”
column4: and it’s a lonely monologue featuring her full
column5: beautifully controlled vocals backed by a whispery acoustic guitar strum and a judiciously unobtrusive backing choir. Written by Alan Sparhawk
column6: it appeared on Low’s recent full-length
column7: The Invisible Way
column8: which Tweedy also produced. It’s a curious bit of synergy
column9: and the Wilco frontman might be guilty of shameless product-placement had Staples’ version not turned out so well. Essentially a cappella
column10: it’s a fine showcase for the vocalist
column11: even if it she obliterates all the ambiguity in the original: This is not about “some holy ghost
column12: ” but the Holy Ghost.

column1: What rankles
column2: however
column3: isn’t the song choice but its placement. On The Invisible Way “Holy Ghost” comes late on the first side
column4: sounding like a mournful bit of spiritual questioning. As an album opener here
column5: it’s so wistful and downcast that it sounds like we’ve intruded on Staples’ private prayer. This is not introduction but a benediction. One True Vine takes a while to get going
column6: burdened by curious sequencing that emphasizes the songs’ low-key production and lurching pace. After “Holy Ghost” comes the Tweedy-penned “Every Step”
column7: whose guitar feedback and punctuating stomps sound cheaply ominous. That’s followed by the sluggish Funkadelic cover “Can You Get to That”
column8: which features a fine bass vocal from Donny Gerrard but never quite gets to that.

column1: You Are Not Alone
column2: Staples’ first collaboration with Tweedy from 2010
column3: highlighted the septuagenarian’s still-commanding voice-- which has become all the more powerful with age and experience-- and proved the Wilco frontman could work in styles and genres well beyond indie Americana. Its tone was celebratory
column4: as he showed a light touch in the control room and never burdened Staples’ performances with too much sound or too many studio tricks. You Are Not Alone sounded like a celebration: of a God who had blessed Staples with a long and influential musical career but also of a partnership that seemed to bring out the best in both artists.

column1: That’s an almost impossible act to follow
column2: and by contrast One True Vine sounds subdued
column3: hesitant
column4: downtempo
column5: downcast-- its sentiments more reflective than rousing. It’s not until the fourth track
column6: “Jesus Wept”
column7: that the album really picks up. The song begins with Staples' voice: “My throat quits when I try to say how I long for the day
column8: ” she intones. “How I wish there was a way I could see you again.” Staples invests those lines with so much fear and yearning that the sense of loss becomes palpable. It’s an arresting moment
column9: and in the album’s best bit of sequencing
column10: it’s followed by “Far Celestial Shore”
column11: written by Nick Lowe. An upbeat tune with a sharply strummed guitar propelling its quirky melody
column12: it provides a contented punctuation to “Jesus Wept” by promising a reward in the afterlife for the trials of this life.

column1: As Staples ponders the connections between the earthly and heavenly realms on “What Are They Doing in Heaven Today” and “Sow Good Seeds”
column2: One True Vine shakes off the dust of the first half and rights itself mightily. An old Staples Singers tune
column3: “I Like the Things About Me”
column4: achieves a light
column5: mobile funk
column6: as though set in motion by some great epiphany
column7: and “Woke Up This Morning (With My Mind on Jesus)” establishes a buoyant country-gospel groove punctuated by Staples’ ecstatic hallelujahs.

column1: With its quick pace and infectious hook
column2: “Woke Up This Morning” would make an effective and ebullient album opener
column3: but it works well enough as the impassioned climax before the denouement of the title track. The album intends to trace the believer’s trajectory from doubt (“Holy Ghost”) to certainty (“One True Vine”)
column4: which lends the album an introspective quality and invests those final numbers with even more power. Still
column5:
One True Vine tarries too long in doubt before finally breaking that dour spell and inviting the listener in on the celebration.

"|18220.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18220-mavis-staples-one-true-vine/|7.4|Stephen M. Deusner

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19228/homepage_large.c53d425a.jpg|The End of Silence|1931.0|Matthew Herbert|['Jazz'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Accidental']|2013-06-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:17.863405|"

Matthew Herbert just took the meticulously reductionist values of his One trilogy and further narrowed his focus. This time around
column3: he zeroes in on a brief moment in time in order to explore his feelings about a single act of terror. The End of Silence uses one 5-second sample as its sole building block
column4: which is contorted and manipulated by Herbert and a three-piece band he put together for this recording. That sample is a recording of a pro-Gaddafi plane flying over Libya and dropping its deadly payload
column5: prefigured by a whistle and a cry that hastily warn of the event. In a 2011 interview Herbert talked of how we now have ""the capacity to listen to the world in a different way."" This is his way of slowing the world down to make sense of it
column6: in the process creating something that shares the weight of a blood-spattered historical snapshot that provokes an uncomfortably lingering gaze.

column1: There are just three tracks here
column2: the first of which is almost 25-minutes long
column3: while the shortest is just over 10 minutes. Herbert's stated intent is to ""freeze history
column4: press pause
column5: wander around inside the sound."" The music works in direct inverse to the event itself
column6: providing acres of time to stop and think and ponder the consequences. Herbert exploits the silence as much as the act itself
column7: stretching out the sense of anxiety that leads up to the terrifying point of impact. The first part is often mixed so sounds are barely perceptible
column8: forcing you to crank the volume. It's a trick that serves to emphasize the bomb drop when it comes
column9: ripping and tearing through the sound
column10: sometimes bolstered by a thick layer of distortion. The use of silence is transportative
column11: triggering an evaluation of the actions of the people on the ground
column12: posing impossible questions about the thoughts rushing through their heads.

column1: What's striking about this work is how it's set up as the antithesis of 24-hour rolling news culture
column2: where bombs sailing out of the sky are presented with a rote facade
column3: then passed over for the next space-filler on the agenda. It's almost old-fashioned in a way
column4: bringing a layer of meaning back to a singular event
column5: pointing out how we're glazing over atrocities that may have caught the world's attention had they taken place in less media-saturated times. The processing through which Herbert and his band force the sample often make it unrecognizable
column6: but they're careful to imbue their tinkering with feelings of fear
column7: dread
column8: and suffering. It's not exactly music as reportage
column9: but when the pace picks up in the second part it often has the same sense of urgency as someone frantically typing up a report
column10: sending an important dispatch outlining how a small part of the world just changed forever.

column1: Distance plays an important part here
column2: too
column3: with Herbert working in sounds of the natural world
column4: all captured on mics set up outside the barn in Wales where these tracks were recorded. It's a valuable reminder of how far outside the original sound he is
column5: of how alien the whole process of exploring a bomb drop is to the average person. This is an approximation of terror
column6: an artificial rendering of distress constructed in a relatively safe space
column7: where shrapnel becomes a percussion instrument and human cries become neatly layered loops. It adds an air of surreality to the album
column8: at times drawing on that sense of being anesthetized to events like this
column9: where you feel so far removed that it's tough to find meaning amid the blizzard of information. The End of Silence is Herbert effectively tussling with what ""significance"" means at this particular moment in time
column10:
in a record that's as much a part of the gathering noise of the 21st century as it is a comment on the constant numbing we've wreaked upon ourselves.

"|18039.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18039-matthew-herbert-the-end-of-silence/|7.1|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19386/homepage_large.8fb3019b.jpg|Heart of Nowhere|9601.0|Noah and the Whale|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mercury']|2013-06-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:18.432150|"

Noah and the Whale’s debut album Peaceful
column2: the World Lays Me Down was chock full of charmless whimsy and derivative Wes Anderson-straddling imagery (their name was inspired by the Noah Baumbach-directed
column3: Anderson-produced The Squid and the Whale) but it certainly arrived at the right time. In 2008
column4: cutesy indie folk was the bomb-- thanks
column5: Juno-- so the group’s use of the entire twee pop toolkit
column6: banjo
column7: ukulele
column8: glockenspiel et al
column9: gave them instant appeal.

column1: Five years and a couple of stylistic rebirths later
column2: Noah and the Whale remain a big draw on the European festival circuit. But in a new era of blockbuster folk rock spearheaded by the likes of Mumford and Sons and the Lumineers
column3: Noah's quaint leanings risk getting lost in the crush. Heart of Nowhere attempts to address this imbalance
column4: building on the mild Tom Petty-isms of their previous effort
column5: Last Night on Earth
column6: and taking a couple of steps closer to stadium-ready territory.

column1: Heart of Nowhere is primarily a collection of coming-of-age tales peppered with sensible advice for tormented youths. (It's accompanied by an accompanying 30-minute film of the same name directed by frontman Charlie Fink.) Fink
column2: who moped so candidly after the disintegration of his relationship with former band member Laura Marling on The First Days of Spring
column3: has taken to counselling kids
column4: offering trite support: “It’s okay to not always be sure exactly where you wanna go” (“Silver and Gold”); “If you can
column5: try and get to know your parents well” (“Now is Exactly the Times”). On “Lifetime”
column6: he hamfistedly pleads with a friend to consider the finality of marriage before taking the plunge. “Are you ready to make that call? It’s gonna be a lifetime
column7: ” he splutters
column8: bluntly.

column1: The band shed the brittle electronic flourishes of their previous album for Springsteen-inspired drive-time with big choruses
column2: chugging guitar lines
column3: and thumping drums giving them more widescreen scope than ever before. But Fink is no Bruce. His foppish voice suited their sweet early recordings
column4: but there’s real strain in his singing as he attempts to compete with the fuller orchestration. Slight redemption comes with “Still After All These Years”
column5: whose 1980s sitcom theme-worthy cheese marks a return to the band’s goofier days. But the contrived feel of the whole thing renders the album stiff; their search for large-scale anthems and keenness to replicate a formula that doesn’t come naturally to them leaves them sounding boxed in
column6:
and imbuing Heart of Nowhere with all the grace and flexibility of four concrete pillars.

"|18196.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18196-noah-and-the-whale-heart-of-nowhere/|5.0|Dean Van Nguyen

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19289/homepage_large.a340de5f.jpg|Suicide Black Snake|31337.0|Integrity|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Magic Bullet']|2013-06-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:18.996590|"

Dwid Hellion is an almost comically dark personality. For the last 25 years
column2: Hellion has served as the head yawper and sole constant member of Integrity
column3: an act that helped pioneer metalcore by stripmining punk rock’s firmament and flooding it with the influence of doom
column4: thrash
column5: and psychedelic rock. Their sound has been inestimably influential
column6: helping to fork the path that bands such as Converge
column7: Hatebreed
column8: and a million others have since traveled.

column1: Musical import aside
column2: though
column3: Hellion’s often-discomfiting view of the world has fueled not only Integrity’s longevity but also
column4: to an extent
column5: listeners’ interest in the band. To follow Integrity is
column6: in some sense
column7: to wait for Hellion to say something generally disagreeable
column8: to appreciate the screaming troll at the end of the microphone. To wit
column9: Hellion is a fan of Charles Manson
column10: having released his music on his own label
column11: incorporated him prominently in the band’s art
column12: and publicly called him an American folk hero. Once asked to comment on the human condition
column13: Hellion simply replied
column14: “Humankind is a diseased animal.” And his mantra of sorts is “Love is the only weapon.” That might sound like a Bob Marley bumper sticker
column15: but Hellion goes further
column16: saying that love is a great reset button for all those bodies “incarcerated within rotting flesh. Through love
column17: we wish to destroy these confines.” Get the grunter a Hallmark contract.

column1: Suicide Black Snake
column2: Integrity’s fitful new LP on excellent Baltimore imprint A389
column3: reaffirms both of Integrity’s key qualities-- that scathing attitude and cross-stitched aesthetic-- in 10 decidedly strange songs. Granted
column4: the bulk of Suicide Black Snake might sound at first like clinical and belligerent hardcore. That’s mostly a symptom of Hellion’s voice
column5: which has stiffened into a coarse bark as he’s aged
column6: even since 2010’s more obviously warped The Blackest Curse.

column1: But beneath the surface
column2: these songs reveal complicated arrangements played entirely by multi-instrumentalist Robert Orr
column3: essentially the one-man musical puppeteer behind Integrity. During “There Is a Sign”
column4: for instance
column5: a rudimentary blast of black metal drums pushes behind a slow riff that’s dense and distorted enough to fit within an Eyehategod album; Hellion
column6: meanwhile
column7: spews over the top of it all
column8: his unapologetic hardcore growl giving the moment its surprising third dimension. The song soon accelerates into a punk rupture before pivoting
column9: unexpectedly
column10: into a spiraling guitar solo. “I Know Where Everyone Lives” opens with a classic rock
column11: crying-guitar prelude that suggests Cream; in less than a minute
column12: though
column13: it’s pogoed into a ferocious circle pit
column14: with Hellion roaring inside his self-made lane of commanding comfort. Orr returns to that 70s excess for closer “Lucifer Before the Day Doth Go”
column15: a blacklight-on
column16: lighters-out rock’n’roll anthem if only Hellion did more than scream over it.

column1: By way of easy comparison
column2: Hellion’s voice in Integrity makes the way that Damian Abraham leads Fucked Up sound delicate and considered. Especially on Suicide Black Snake
column3: Hellion overruns everything
column4: his vocal opprobrium working as the oblivious bull laying waste to the proverbial china shop. Always an acquired taste
column5: it’s occasionally a bit too much and too little here. Hellion can’t match Orr’s nimble approach on the failed hall of mirrors “Into the Night”; when the music disappears behind him at the end of “There Is a Sign”
column6: his voice feels at once like a marvel and an unnecessary overcompensation
column7: as though all these years of rotating band members have made him defensive of his dominant role in Integrity. At least he completely owns the more straightforward hardcore blasts such as “+Orrchida” and “Beasts as Gods”. Still
column8: a quarter century into a project
column9: shouldn’t mastery of the fundamentals be a foregone conclusion?

column1: Perhaps it’s time for Hellion to give his customarily martial role a rest. After all
column2: the most remarkable track here and the reason for returning again and again to Suicide Black Snake doesn’t even use it. “There Ain’t No Living in Life” is a doomy blues tune that suggests Neurosis playing Mountain Jam; Hellion speaks slow and low over Slint-like guitars
column3: adding harmonica just before the weight of the drums come crashing in. The darkness is still there-- “There is no light in this tunnel
column4: and there is only one escape
column5: ” he intones. But it’s more visceral
column6: relatable
column7: and desperate
column8:
the sound of the blues given a shot of steel. This slow-burn is likely just an Integrity album anomaly-- because there’s generally at least one-- and not a new direction. Maybe it should be.

"|18100.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18100-integrity-suicide-black-snake/|6.7|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19339/homepage_large.0c91ddd3.jpg|Blowout Comb|29141.0|Digable Planets|['Rap']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Light in the Attic']|2013-06-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:19.469136|"

Around the turn of the 1990s
column2: hip-hop had a brief and fruitful collision with jazz. “You could find the Abstract listening to hip-hop/ My pops used to say
column3: it reminded him of bebop
column4: ” said Q-Tip on 1991‘s The Low End Theory
column5: an album that included contributions from legendary second-Miles Davis Quintet bassist Ron Carter and featured a song called “Jazz (We’ve Got)”. A year earlier
column6: Spike Lee had followed his landmark Do the Right Thing
column7: a film closely connected in spirit to the hip-hop street
column8: with Mo Better Blues
column9: a film whose main characters were sharply dressed jazz musicians trying to figure out how their work fit into the modern world. Guru of Gang Starr started a side project called Jazzmatazz
column10: which found jazz legends playing alongside MCs; Us3 looped Herbie Hancock to create a global smash. Hip-hop jazz was now a thing
column11: and one of the small
column12: brilliantly burning sparks to emerge from this tiny explosion was the Brooklyn-based trio Digable Planets.

column1: To understand the music of Digable Planets
column2: it helps to remember the cultural landscape of the early 1990s. The crack epidemic was in full swing and violence was at an all-time high. (We’re rightly horrified at the 506 murders in Chicago last year
column3: but in 1992
column4: there were 943.) Coming off of 12 years of Republicans in the White House
column5: Ronald Reagan and his successor
column6: George H.W. Bush
column7: had turned the country rightward
column8: and each had scored political points by exploiting racial prejudice. The youthful energy of the civil rights generation was fading; young people who might have seen Martin Luther King
column9: Jr. or Malcolm X speak in person were well into middle age. Hip-hop was well established and rapidly growing in popularity
column10: but it wasn’t yet a global cultural force.

column1: So what did “jazz” mean in this hip-hop moment? It went beyond just sampling grooves and instrumental accents from the Roy Ayers catalog or the groove-based hard bop of the 50s/60s Blue Note catalog (though there was a lot of that too). Part of it can be found in that Q-Tip lyric: This is my music
column2: and my father hears his music in it. It was a way to connect a thread of African-American culture to the earlier generations
column3: to affirm a sense of shared experience and tradition. “My father always told me jazz is the black person’s classical music
column4: ” Digable Planets MC Ishmael “Butterfly” Butler told writer Ann Powers in the May 1993 issue of SPIN. So jazz as an idea in hip-hop was a story of tradition and shared knowledge
column5: of connecting a younger cohort to the radical art of their parents’ generation. And in the tense era of the 80s and 90s
column6: there was comfort to be found in that continuum
column7: of positioning this new music in the context of an earlier sound that had changed the world.

column1: If Digable Planets were the product of a specific time
column2: they also came together in a specific place. Blowout Comb
column3: their second and final album
column4: which was first released in 1994 and now returns in the form of this gorgeous and beautiful-sounding vinyl reissue from Light in the Attic
column5: is practically a love letter to the Brooklyn neighborhood of Fort Greene. It’s a part of the borough with a long history (Walt Whitman lived here)
column6: and not all of it was rosy (in the 1970s and 80s
column7: crime in the area was endemic). It’s also a neighborhood of African-American families
column8: and it has been known as an incubator of creativity. Spike Lee’s 40 Acres and a Mule office is based here; jazz musicians young (Branford Marsalis) and old (Cecil Taylor) called the area home. As described in Brooklyn Boheme
column9: a film by Fort Greene resident and writer Nelson George
column10: during the late 1980s and 90s Fort Greene was a nexus of African-American cultural activity
column11: to the extent that George calls it the late-century Brooklyn version of the Harlem Renaissance. It was a good place for Digable Planets
column12: none of whom were native Brooklynites
column13: to set up shop.

column1: The group’s debut album
column2: 1993’s Reachin' (A New Refutation of Time and Space)
column3: is very good
column4: but all the promise of the project was realized with its follow-up. Blowout Comb is an album of forces pulling in different directions
column5: exerting tension and stretching into new forms. On a purely sonic level
column6: the music
column7: produced by the group
column8: is beautiful and goes down so easily it’s almost disconcerting. The mixture of soul and jazz samples and live instrumentation paints an eminently listenable late-night atmosphere: there are clouds of vibraphone
column9: drum loops firmly in the pocket
column10: creaky Fender Rhodes lines
column11: tasteful horn accents
column12: all of it anchored by warm
column13: snug
column14: and instantly memorable basslines. The general sonic approach became more prominent as the 90s wore on
column15: as these kinds of crate-digging
column16: rare-groove types continued to mine old soul and jazz records for samples
column17: eventually transforming into a kind of supper-club trip-hop (Kruder & Dorfmeister
column18: Thievery Corporation). But Digable made the approach feel completely organic and integrated with their broader musical goal of expanding rap’s reach and deepening its connection to music history.

column1: Digable also found an approach to rapping that fit perfectly with their musical ideas. The three MCs-- Butterfly
column2: Craig “Doodlebug” Irving
column3: and Mary Ann “Ladybug Mecca” Vieira-- rap with confidence
column4: skill
column5: and force but they also sound relaxed
column6: unhurried
column7: close to the microphone
column8: and intimate. “No stars
column9: just bars
column10: ” Doodlebug raps on “The May 4th Movement”
column11: and his words serve as a good explanation for what’s going on here. Because the vocalists take a similar angle on rapping
column12: they feel like a true unit
column13: individuals who are comfortable giving over a certain amount of their personality to the project as a whole. Ladybug often takes the first verse on a given track
column14: and since the three MCs truly feel like equals and there’s not much in the way of macho posturing
column15: lines between masculine and feminine also seem porous.

column1: But if the sound and vocals are decidedly chill
column2: the lyrics are alternately celebratory
column3: searching
column4: and anxious. There is a strong thread of black nationalist consciousness (Butler's father is a professor of African-American history) but it’s often presented impressionistically. “Black Ego” opens with a spoken exchange that finds Butterfly being arrested and shaking off a racial slur with a “here we go again
column5: ” and later finds him transcending the situation with a mix of affirmations and escapist Afro-futurist imagery (“My shit's
column6: a natural high
column7: the man can’t put no thing on me/ Now catch me when my mind stretch out
column8: it's astro black/ Time reaching into end
column9: nappy Afro-blue”). “Dog It” has references to out-jazz genius Eric Dolphy
column10: Marvin Gaye
column11: bell hooks
column12: and raised fists; elsewhere we find Five-Percent National imagery and mythology (see Ladybug’s “68 inches above sea level/ 93 million miles above these devils” on “9th Wonder (Blackitolism)”. Mixed in with the political observations and mysticism are joyful observations of everyday life
column13: of soaking in the texture of the streets and feeling happy to be young and motivated and creative. Anyone who has felt even the slightest romantic pull of bohemian living can recognize the youthful assuredness mixed with wide-eyed wonder that pervades the record.

column1: So Blowout Comb is a modest hip-hop classic that thrives on contrast. It’s both dated and timeless
column2: angry and laid-back
column3: smooth and prickly. It’s one of the easier albums in pop history to put on and enjoy and vibe out to
column4: but it has a rich undercurrent of history and thought. It’s also something of a cul de sac. Though Butler did pick up some of these threads and combine them with more abrasive and abstract music as Shabazz Palaces
column5: Digable Planets as a project did not endure. Culture moved on and rap moved on with it. But Blowout Comb
column6: a richly rendered world with so much to explore
column7: is still there and is accepting visitors
column8:
and it has a lot to teach us on whatever level we choose to listen. 

"|18154.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18154-digable-planets-blowout-comb/|9.2|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19402/homepage_large.00e08bf5.jpg|Spitting Fire Live Vol. 1 & 2|1943.0|High on Fire|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Entertainment One']|2013-06-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:19.997151|"

Simple fact: You should see High on Fire live. Since guitarist
column2: vocalist
column3: and leader Matt Pike got sober
column4: the Oakland trio's sounded especially alive and committed to the spirit of metal. People often use descriptors like “crushing mountains” and “moving planets” to describe High on Fire
column5: and while they don't do that literally-- metal might be dangerous again if they had such powers-- their lust for volume will take care of any internal struggles. You come in to a High on Fire show complaining about your dead-end job
column6: you come out thinking you can die peacefully.

column1: Despite this
column2: Spitting Fire Live Vol. 1 and Vol. 2
column3: recorded at New York City's Bowery Ballroom and Brooklyn's Music Hall of Williamsburg during their most recent US tour
column4: feels inessential like most live records released before or since KISS' Alive!. Concert albums never sound like the concerts they're supposed to capture
column5: and with a band whose presence can stifle trite conversation like High on Fire's
column6: it's a disservice. There are a number of technical details one could get into
column7: but the point is simple enough: you're not there. You're not seeing Pike pluck strings like his life depended on it. His facial expressions when he's soloing-- missing out on that
column8: too. You're not really getting the most low end you can from Jeff Matz. Des Kensel's bass drum isn't hitting your heart in the ways that it should. And you're not smelling the weed Pike can't smoke
column9: or the beer he can't drink. It's just not the goddamn same.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: the discs pull from material from across their career
column3: which highlights the transition from Pike
column4: “The Guy Who Used To Be In Sleep” to Pike
column5: “For Whose Riffs We Tremble.” His association with Sleep garnered High on Fire the “stoner metal” tag early on
column6: despite Pike showing more ambition than his dopethroned brethren. High on Fire is a Metal band as Judas Priest
column7: Black Sabbath
column8: and Iron Maiden are Metal bands-- nothing before Metal
column9: nothing after. This tour was not just in support of their most recent studio album
column10: 2012's De Vermis Mysteriis
column11: but also the Southern Lord reissue of their debut The Art of Self Defense. High on Fire included “Last”
column13: 000 Years”
column14: and fan favorite “Blood From Zion” from Defense on the setlist
column15: and their smoldering fires don't burn as bright or as hot as the infernos of their later material. “Zion” holds up the best
column16: but it's no “Snakes for the Divine” or “Fury Whip.” Even if you only listen to both editions of Spitting Fire once-- and it's likely you will-- seeing how much High on Fire improved from album to album is of some merit.

column1: The double live set might satisfy the curiosity of some who wonder what songs from the 2010 Greg Fidelman-produced Snakes For the Divine sound like “dirtied up.” While it's far from a Boston-slick Devin Townsend album
column2: Fidelman's production on Divine is cleaner than the albums produced by Steve Albini (Blessed Black Wings
column3: High on Fire's 2005 breakthrough)
column4: Jack Endino (Death is this Communion)
column5: and Kurt Ballou (Vermis). While Divine received plenty of praise
column6: there was also a contingent who thought it represented a sterilization of Pike's inner animal. (If those folks have trouble with Pike standing on top of K2 busting out the intro to Divine's title track
column7: though
column8: their imagination needs some greasing.)

column1: But
column2: all said
column3: it's hard figuring out why Spitting Fire Live is being released in the first place. It's basically just another product clogging up record store shelves
column4:
and would work better as a (preferably free) download. Actually going out to a High on Fire will imbue memories of headbanging to the rhythm of Pike's beer gut. The end result of Spitting Fire Live? Probably nothing more than ripped CD files languishing in a terabyte external drive.

"|18211.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18211-high-on-fire-spitting-fire-live-vol-1-2/|5.9|Andy O'Connor

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19358/homepage_large.d1b33295.jpg|FOUR (Acts of Love)|1895.0|Mick Harvey|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute']|2013-06-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:20.503491|"

Pinpointing Mick Harvey’s identity as a musician has always required a little triangulation. Of his three main points of reference
column2: the closest is Nick Cave
column3: whom Harvey played with in their fledgling band Boys Next Door
column4: then the Birthday Party
column5: and on to the Bad Seeds-- whose primal menace and eerie tenderness Harvey added to immeasurably. Harvey also spent years in Simon Bonney’s collective Crime and the City Solution; by the 90s he’d added a third coordinate
column6: French pop legend Serge Gainsbourg
column7: the source of material for his first two solo albums
column8: 1995’s Intoxicated Man and 1997’s Pink Elephants
column9: the latter of which dared to offer a single Harvey composition. When Harvey left the Bad Seeds in 2009
column10: it was as a superb multi-instrumentalist who had aided
column11: abetted
column12: or interpreted many great singer-songwriters
column13: but who had contributed shockingly little to the world as a singer-songwriter himself.

column1: Harvey’s 2011 solo album Sketches From the Book of the Dead was his first since leaving the Bad Seeds
column2: and it was also his first disc of all original material. While solid
column3: its jazz-folk melodrama suffered from sounding like the average of his three big touchstones. With Sketches’ follow-up
column4: <i>Four (Acts of Love)
column5: he’s returned to a more comfortable ratio of originals to covers. It’s a harmonious alchemy. None of the artists Harvey has chosen to cover is surprising; among them are Roy Orbison
column6: Van Morrison
column7: Exuma
column8: the Saints (whom Harvey has covered before)
column9: and PJ Harvey (whom he’s covered
column10: produced
column11: and played with).

column1: Four (Acts of Love) oozes curdled lust
column2: broken obsession
column3: and morbid romanticism. It’s a self-described song cycle-- and it’s actually structured as a cycle rather than an arc
column4: bookended by the tracks “Praise the Earth (Wheels of Amber and Gold)” and “Praise the Earth (An Ephemeral Play)”. The two click together to form a tarnished ring
column5: one that describes the act of love as an epic boom-and-bust. Better yet
column6: the songs shed the shadows of Harvey’s bosses and prior influences-- and own the fact that Harvey is no longer a mere sidekick
column7: but rather a contemporary of Michael Gira or Bill Callahan with just as singular and stentorian a voice
column8: if less assured of its power. Through a fluttering filter of reverb and weaves of languid jangle
column9: Harvey sings sweetly and huskily of oblivion
column10: pining for the hereafter like it’s the girl that got away.

column1: “Glorious” is Harvey’s duet with PJ Harvey
column2: although she wisely plays a supporting role as Mick drones on laconically about debilitating love; if she raised her voice any higher
column3: it wouldn’t be a Mick track anymore. The most potent droning
column4: though
column5: is saved for the  Morrison cover
column6: a take on the darkly jaunty Astral Weeks classic “The Way Young Lovers Do” that bobs along on an ambient ebb. That subtlety informs most of the album
column7: only letting up on its semi-acoustic cover of the Saints’ “The Story of Love
column8: ” which taps into the song’s punk roots for its clunky second half. Four (Acts of Love) is made up mostly of such slivers and fragments
column9: and that adds to its strength; Harvey is trying out new things
column10: wrestling with universals
column11: and grasping at a new way to tell stories through song-- for him
column12: at least. And even if it’s stretched thin and unsatisfying in spots
column13:
Four is our most distinct glimpse of Harvey yet.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19306/homepage_large.d82e8707.jpg|Kenny Dennis LP|29808.0|Serengeti|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anticon']|2013-06-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:21.191054|"

Going off last year's Kenny Dennis EP
column2: it was easy enough to explain Serengeti's alter ego: a simultaneous parody of/homage to the 1990s hardcore rap also-ran now at middle-age
column3: a grizzled blue-collar Chicago guy who's dealing with a workaday existence but hasn't really given up rapping. It was an appealing concept-- a fictional persona who's actually less badass or supernatural than the MC who came up with him. It was also memorably funny
column4: gaining due props from rap nerds and sports superfans alike for the Steve Bartman-exonerating Cubs lament ""Don't Blame Steve"" and the simmering grudge of the Shaq dis track ""Shazam"". The lyrics were reference-heavy
column5: but rendered in uncomplicated language
column6: delivered through a barking rasp so percussive and hectoring every line seemed to demand four exclamation points. The Kenny Dennis EP transcended its comedy to work as pure music
column7: even if that comedy was largely inseparable from what made it so damned fun.

column1: But the further you stretch a comedy character-- which Serengeti's done on four albums now (including this one)
column2: along with that EP-- the more chance there is that the joke will get stale. There's also the chance that the artist becomes so invested in the character that his backstory gets fleshed out until he's no longer entirely a comedic character. In taking the latter route
column3: Serengeti's instilled Kenny Dennis with some additional pathos
column4: some extended range in subject matter
column5: and a background that turns out to be a little more human-- and sad-- than previous records entirely let on. There's a framing device that runs through the album on a series of skit-like monologues from Kenny's old friend ""Ders"" (""Workaholics""' Anders Holm)
column6: frequently undercut by interjections from Kenny that sound like snippets of flashbacks or memories
column7: culminating in a disillusioned Los Angeles reunion for a special 50th birthday celebration. Turns out
column8: the Zubaz-wearing Brian Dennehy fanboy works as something besides just a broad yet evocative caricature.

column1: The depth creeps in through the margins
column2: and if it seems like an odd fit when it emerges
column3: it still adheres well to the character. A guy like Kenny seems like the type to ruminate on the sins of no-good dirtbags
column4: and ""Punks"" has him quietly
column5: almost introspectively fuming about targets ranging from local criminals he hears about on police scanners to wrestling heels he fumes at on TV. His home life's strained
column6: not constantly
column7: but enough to leave him ""stupid stressed""; ""Kenny and Jueles"" swings masterfully from his frustration at what seems to be his wife's distance from him to a reconciliation and a return to give-and-take commitment (albeit one based upon her pride at Kenny clowning Nitro on American Gladiators). And closer ""Flows"" sees Kenny in mentor mode
column8: engaging with ""mi casa es su casa""-style community and tearing Rahm Emanuel a new one for letting inner-city Chicago schools crumble. Odd Nosdam
column9: who's built a long production career out of rusted melancholy that knocks
column10: has put together a slate of beats that leans heavier on the dissonant and unsettled side of the equation
column11: and it does a lot to emphasize the mood
column12: with the best juxtaposition-- the ghostly strings and uptempo breaks of ""West of Western""-- giving a California Split type of existential weight to Serengeti's chaos-in-Reno tour ramblings.

column1: The Kenny Dennis LP isn't a huge bummer of a departure
column2: though-- it's actually a good companion piece to the goofier
column3: more lighthearted EP
column4: right down to the cover art. Opening cut ""Bang Em"" is still as hooky and stoopid-clever as precedent demands
column5: from its class of 93 table-pounding hook (""You like 'em
column6: you bang 'em/ You like 'em
column7: you bang 'em/ Sometimes you don't like/ But you still bang 'em"") to its choppy
column8: stream-of-consciousness syntax that jumps from Miles Davis namedrops to the vision-improving properties of carrots in the span of a couple of bars. ""Directions"" starts off with a diatribe threatening to make a lost
column9: inquisitive passer-by ""extreme-a-ly late for your appoint-a-ment
column10: shifts into bragging about his Skokie-to-Evanston jogging regimen
column11: and hypnotically degenerates into an extended
column12: jumbled ""you go left/right/up/down"" navigation scheme that sounds like the Contra Code gone haywire. And even if the last story from Ders is a bummer
column13: it wouldn't resonate as much without the story of how a seven-year-old Ders met a generous Kenny at Sharper Image on ""Lazer Tag""
column14: or Kenny using his local-celeb bonafides to introduce Ders to none other than Bo Jackson's wife in ""GT Show '93"". Kenny Dennis is definitely a type
column15: but he's a type that feels real enough to want to hang out with
column16:
even during his downer moments.

Roomrunner doesn't always sound like Nirvana
column3: but considering the promo sticker on the front of the band's debut LP Ideal Cities reads
column4: <a href=""http://roomrunner.tumblr.com/image/51076720834"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"" title=""This external link will open in a new window"">“Yes
column5: we’ve heard Nirvana. Try harder
column6: ” it's a comment they must field often. There's some Bleach here
column7: some ""Lithium"" there
column8: but in the spirit of trying harder
column9: Roomrunner's true orbit revolves around their hometown of Baltimore and their fellow noise-punk bands. Charm City was nowhere near the genesis for their favorite 90s grunge and post-hardcore sounds like Seattle or Chicago. While Nirvana recorded Bleach for Sub Pop and the Jesus Lizard recorded the Pure EP for Touch & Go
column10: the most famous song to come out of Baltimore in 1989 was the cheeseball anthem and ""Centerfield"" knock-off
column11: “Why Not?”
column12: written for the suddenly and surprisingly good Baltimore Orioles
column13: who finally had the chance to go all the way. Did they? Of course not. They too had to try harder.

column1: Over last 20 years the city’s plucky DIY music community has grown in size and in spirit thanks in large part to national publicity gained by Dan Deacon and the Wham City Collective. Warehouse spaces like the Copy Cat Building became industrial salons for the city's moshing art-core noise out of which Roomrunner was born. More specifically
column2: the band rose from the ashes of Baltimore punk mainstays Double Dagger. DD drummer and now RR guitarist/singer Denny Bowen hooked up with all-star Baltimore engineer Dan Frome in 2011 for a self-titled cassette EP
column3: and again in 2012 for four uncontrollable grunge jams on the Super Vague EP. Frome returns for Ideal Cities on Fan Death Records
column4: and leads the band outside of the lived-in brambles of noise that defined their first two releases.

column1: Ideal Cities tightens all the screws on Roomrunner’s noise rock-- it’s their Nevermind if you really want to rib them. The outer frequencies are trimmed
column2: leaving much more meat to chew on
column3: and sharper focus is put Bowen’s sardonic vocals. “Wojtek” is the band’s furthest leap into pop territory to date. The guitars and drums work in unison to give the song some breath
column4: but the feedback that leaks out sounds like they’re trying to choke the ever-loving life out of a Strokes song.

column1: Beyond “Wojtek”
column2: Roomrunner decline to offer a helping hand into their atonal
column3: arrhythmic salvos. “Bait Car” bounces around in 7/4 in several obtuse key signatures. The tumbling power chords that support “Bowlth” seem random at best
column4: with Bowen’s nasal voice forging melody lines that complement the dissonant mess beneath it. The bulk of Ideal Cities flies in the face of “hooks
column5: ” instead leaving Bowen’s voice behind fat stacks of distorted bass and guitar. It might be jazz with different instrumentation
column6: it would be math rock if they cared a bit more
column7: but Roomrunner follow a long line of proud Baltimore bands who have so long been overlooked in the mainstream. They wear their weird
column8: local colors proud.

column1: <div class=""im"">
The testosterone rage of Baltimore’s Dope Body sneaks out at the end of the brutish “Weird”
column2: and the stripped-down melodicism of Baltimore’s Weekends show up at the close of “Snac Error”
column3: a song named after cryptic error message one gets on AIM/ICQ. This local debt Roomrunner pays on Ideal Cities makes it a prickly and cagey listen
column4: one that doesn’t fully reveal itself until after several go-arounds
column5: especially if you're not that familiar with the city's sound. Even if you come in with your palate trained on post-hardcore and Local H’s guitar feedback tricks
column6: the angular approach that makes the band so powerful live makes the recorded version bleed together.

column1: At about 30 minutes in length
column2: Ideal Cities never overstays its welcome. It absolutely scans as sharing an aesthetic with Nirvana or the Jesus Lizard: ripped-jeans and ratty t-shirts
column3: cans of Natty Boh and Western Fries
column4: as cynical as it is passionate. But on “Apse”
column5: Bowen lays out the band’s own us vs. them stance: “They’ve got a question/ Make up an answer.” That nonchalance in the face of authority seemed like a product of gen X in the 90s
column6: but for Roomrunner today
column7: it’s just the Baltimore ethos: we’ll do it the way we want to do it. Why not?

column1: "|18147.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18147-roomrunner-ideal-cities/|7.4|Jeremy D. Larson

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19393/homepage_large.54ef9b60.jpg|Watching Movies With the Sound Off|30111.0|Mac Miller|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rostrum']|2013-06-24 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:23.506845|"

Mac Miller skated into rap with all the bottomless happy-go-lucky charm of a best friend’s insouciant little brother. The documents of his early career are the works of a kid very much in love with hip-hop but frustratingly ill-equipped to translate his verve into compelling music. His songs didn’t feel lived in; their observations were as slight as their lyrics were clunky. Even so
column2: Miller proved a hit on the underaged weekend warrior circuit
column3: and despite a withering critical reception
column4: his 2011 debut album Blue Slide Park became the first independent hip-hop album to top the Billboard charts in nearly twenty years.

column1: Things got knotty for Mac just as quickly as he took off
column2: though. Beset by detractors and disillusioned with his career path (and the ever-present “frat-rap” association)
column3: he turned to promethazine to cope during 2012’s rigorous Macadelic tour. Miller also ran into threats of litigation from hip-hop producer Lord Finesse
column4: who says his production was used without permission on a popular mixtape cut
column5: and Donald Trump
column6: who came calling after a 2011 single named after him racked up millions of views on YouTube. Miller kicked the promethazine habit
column7: settled with Finesse out of court (although Trump still taunts him)
column8: and then summarily ditched his native Pittsburgh for Los Angeles
column9: where he’s been palling around with members of Odd Future and Kendrick Lamar’s Top Dawg Entertainment collective ever since. Watching Movies with the Sound Off is steeped in the pathos of Mac’s bad year and the musical influence
column10: both direct and indirect
column11: of his new rap friends. It’s the wide-eyed kid brother of Blue Slide Park home from college extolling the virtues of meditation and salvia.

column1: Watching Movies with the Sound Off reintroduces Mac Miller as a druggy philosopher on the mic and a left field talent behind the boards. Gone are the undercooked shaggy dog stories of Blue Slide Park and mixtapes like Best Day Ever. In their place we get a batch of songs that break the surface with snarling
column2: self-deprecating wit (“I don’t act hard/ Still read Babar” from opener “The Star Room”) and musings on mortality (“Probably be dead soon inhaling cigarette fumes” on “Avian”) and drugs (“That fetanyl
column3: it numbs me/ ...Turns you into a junkie” on “Someone Like You”). There’s still a lemon here and there (“I spit the shit that leave a diaper brown” on the otherwise promising lead single “S.D.S.” and “Gees”
column4: with its chorus of “Suck my dick before I slap you with it”)
column5: but the Mac Miller of Watching Movies
column6: who feels comfortable trading verses with rap nerd favorites like Jay Electronica and Action Bronson
column7: largely succeeds in distancing himself from the guy peddling kiddie-pool deep rhymes about drinking 40s in front of the police just two years prior.

column1: Miller’s Doom-esque witticisms are dispensed here over production that matches Wiz Khalifa’s 2012 cloud rap gambit O.N.I.F.C. for sheer druggy majesty. Miller handles a good portion of it himself
column2: turning in loping circus music on “Avian” and eerie descending mellotron melodies on the absurdly titled “Suplexes Inside of Complexes and Duplexes”. “Aquarium” stir fries tUnE-yArDs' “Powa”
column3: churning out a slow-building and hypnotic barn-burner replete with massive drums and tasteful strings. The rest of Watching Movies’ production is farmed out to blunted Cali hip-hop luminaries like Flying Lotus and Alchemist as well as emerging production talents like Clams Casino and Odd Future’s Earl Sweatshirt. Lengthy passages of stately
column4: ephemeral soundscapes give Watching Movies the feel of a quixotic vision quest with Miller playing the role of the wizened sherpa.

column1: The hazy sprawl of Watching Movies also gives Mac a chance to dart outside the boundaries of hip-hop a little. He ditches rapping on a few cuts
column2: exposing a singing voice in line with the Mark Everett school of coarse-throated
column3: disembodied vocalisms on the oceanic Clams Casino assisted “Youforia” and Pharrell’s gossamer “Objects in the Mirror”. Both are lightweight love songs that make up for what they occasionally lack in lyrical profundity with an open armed earnestness. He one-ups both with “REMember”
column4: a letter to a fallen friend full of heartsick what-if scenarios (“You had a girl
column5: I kinda wish you knocked her up/ So I could meet your son and talk you up”) and frank talk about the therapeutic power of crying. All three are instances of Miller imparting stories that dig deeper than the bedroom boasts and quests for weed that made up the bulk of his songwriting up to this point.

column1: Watching Movies with the Sound Off is a quantum leap in artistry
column2: but it’s not without faults; the album’s about three songs too long
column3: and a couple of the tracks in the back end just plain run together. Also
column4: while all of the guest spots here are welcome deviations from Miller’s adroit Stones’ Throw homage
column5: they routinely punctuate how much room he’s got left to grow as a writer. It’s highlighted most poignantly on “Suplexes Inside of Complexes and Duplexes”
column6: where Jay Electronica shows up unannounced to kick a nonsensical verse
column7: his first in years
column8: and blows the whole album sky high just recounting the story of The Wizard of Oz
column9: and also in the spoken word interlude after “Red Dot Music”
column10: which features breakout battle rap star Loaded Lux lampooning “Easy Mac with the cheesy raps”
column11: ruthlessly snarling “Who the fuck is Mac Miller?” Watching Movies with the Sound Off begins to broach the subject
column12:
but the question still stands.

"|18202.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18202-mac-miller-watching-movies-with-the-sound-off/|7.0|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19390/homepage_large.2b7fd50b.jpg|First Issue|23514.0|Public Image Ltd.|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Light in the Attic']|2013-06-24 00:00:00|1978|2016-06-11 16:56:24.041263|"

With the Sex Pistols
column2: Johnny “Rotten” Lydon helped define the everlasting image of punk: the spiky hair
column3: the safety-pinned clothes
column4: the wanton disregard for monarchy and the defaced Queen Elizabeth portraits to match. But in doing so
column5: the Pistols also created a caricature
column6: one that could be readily trotted out by sleazy TV talk-show hosts for cheap shock value and easily aped by sketch-comedy troupes. And for all the media outrage and label politicking that surrounded the release of Never Mind the Bollocks
column7: it was ultimately a slickly produced
column8: highly accessible set
column9: its anti-establishment invectives latched onto shout-along hooks crafted by the world’s most ridiculed Beatles fan. Really
column10: the Pistols were just a rock‘n’roll band fronted by a singer who happened to hate rock‘n’roll. And his next move was to show everyone just how much
column11: by redefining punk not as a sound or costume
column12: but as an idea
column13: a liberation philosophy of pan-cultural musical cross-polination and strident non-conformism.

column1: Formed in 1978
column2: mere months after the Pistols’ infamous implosion in San Francisco
column3: Public Image Ltd. were not so much post-punk as meta-punk. Though he’d detest the comparison
column4: PiL initially served precisely the same function for Lydon as the Plastic Ono Band did for another famous John L.
column5: a vehicle through which he could exorcise and excoriate the albatross of his former band. Not only was the new group’s very moniker a pointed comment on Malcolm McLaren’s shrewd attempts to commoditize the Pistols as punk-rock puppets (and Lydon's former bandmates’ complicity in the gambit)
column6: their self-titled debut single scans as a particularly bitter break-up letter; spiked with barbs like “You never listened to a word that I said/ You only see me for the clothes that I wear
column7: ” “Public Image” is essentially a “How Do You Sleep?” you can dance to.

column1: Musically speaking
column2: “Public Image” presented a logical bridge between Lydon’s old and new ventures
column3: retaining the punk-rock drive and agitated vocals
column4: but with a greater sonic expanse highlighting Jah Wobble’s subterranean basslines and Keith Levene’s metallic (in the materiality sense) guitar grind
column5: and hinting at the dub reggae and Krautrock influences that would inform the early PiL's sound. But the album on which it appears
column6: First Issue
column7: presents no convenient gateway
column8: tucking the single onto Side 2 while greeting rubberneckers with “Theme”
column9: a grueling nine-minute dirge-- on which Lydon repeatedly screams “I wish I could diiiieeee” with varying degrees of anguish-- that serves as a litmus test to instantly ward off Pistols fans looking for another excuse to pogo.

column1: Sure
column2: the Sex Pistols could be nasty
column3: but the primordial Public Image was unrepentantly brutal-- punk stripped of its fashion and tabloid-baiting sensationalism and reduced to its noisy
column4: nihilistic essence. Where the Pistols engaged in broad-stroke critiques of British institutions
column5: First Issue’s strikes on the Catholic Church are more like close-range stabbings that gruesomely twist the blade; through the two-part spoken-word churn of “Religion” (a song reportedly rejected by the Pistols) and the relentlessly harrowing “Annalisa” (based on a true story of an exorcism gone horribly wrong)
column6: Lydon’s voice is transformed from a mere instrument of provocation to the pure embodiment of sheer terror. (Not surprisingly
column7: Warner Bros. deemed First Issue too uncommercial to release in the U.S.; this Light in the Attic reissue marks the first time the album has been officially available stateside.)

column1: A word-association game with Public Image Ltd. inevitably yields the phrase “death disco
column2: ” however
column3: that sound (and the single that coined it) wouldn’t fully flourish until 1980’s Second Edition; rather than proffer a bastardized take on dance music
column4: First Issue works the other way
column5: applying disco production principles-- by boosting Wobble’s bottom end and foregrounding Levene’s tin-foiled guitar refrains-- to its deconstructionist rock attack. But what’s most striking today is the in-the-room immediacy and towering presence of the sound-- Canadian-born drummer Jim Walker may have only stuck around for this one record
column6: but his Bonham-scaled boom leaves behind a career’s worth of craters. While future PiL records would provide easily photocopied blueprints to post-punk progeny like the Rapture
column7: LCD Soundsystem
column8: and Liars
column9: First Issue’s industrial-strength stompers anticipate the scabrous art-punk of the Jesus Lizard and Slint
column10: while Levene’s guitar curlicues on “Public Image” are the stuff Daydream Nations are made of.

column1: Not all of First Issue casts such an imposing shadow-- after completing the album’s first side at Townhouse and Manor Studios
column2: the band had blown its budget
column3: and finished off the album’s closing trifecta in a more affordable
column4: lo-fi studio that specialized in reggae tracks. But the downsized dimensions encouraged the band’s experimental tendencies. “Low Life” and “Attack” succesively follow the “Public Image” single’s tunefully dissonant template but gradually debase it into echo-drenched disorientation
column5: and though the dub-disco doodle “Fodderstompf” essentially amounts to a one-note joke stretched to seven minutes
column6: it’s a significant one
column7: presenting both a test run for the grotty grooves mastered on Second Edition
column8: while paving the way for everything from Ween’s early bong-sucking pranksterism to James Murphy’s self-reflexive irreverence.

column1: Rather than lard up the tracklist with endless outtakes and alternate versions
column2: the First Issue reissue offers but two bonus incentives: beserker
column3: Bonanza-inspired B-side “The Cowboy Song” and
column4: far more intriguingly
column5: a complete unedited 56-minute BBC interview with Lydon (conducted before the album’s release) that is well worth the price of re-admission for those who've already worn out their original vinyl import.. While Lydon has since cultivated a media personality as the consummate crank who gleefully hangs up on journalists
column6: here he seems less surly than cagey and defensive
column7: still stinging from the Pistols’ break-up and the perpetual flogging that band received from the press. It initially results in some painful moments of silence between Lydon and the intensely meek interviewer
column8: but to her credit
column9: she gradually gets him to loosen up and sound off on everything from the Rolling Stones (“they rip off everybody else’s ideas”) and Siouxsie and the Banshees (“I find their record appalling”) to the superiority of dance music over rock‘n’roll
column10: which he’d already declared dead 35 years prior. And just as the album it accompanies set the discordant tone for next three-plus decades of indie rock
column11: the interview yields its own uncanny prophecies-- Lydon stops just short of outing late BBC host Jimmy Saville as a pedophile
column12: an insinuation that wouldn’t go public until an ITV documentary brought the sexual abuse claims to light last year. He may have gotten famous screaming “no future
column13: ” but as this reissue makes clear
column14:
Lydon’s greatest gift was a known future. 

"|18200.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18200-public-image-ltd-first-issue/|9.0|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19395/homepage_large.203494bd.jpg|Ceres & Calypso in the Deep Time Forever|28343.0|Candy Claws|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Twosyllable']|2013-06-24 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:24.638035|"

If you want to call Candy Claws a bunch of hippies
column2: they don’t have much of a defense-- they live in Fort Collins
column3: Col.
column4: a college town in a state that legalized recreational marijuana
column5: and about 98% of their Twitter account is dedicated to documenting the boundless beauty of Mother Earth. On their last album
column6: 2010's Hidden Lands
column7: the music refracted early Animal Collective and late Mercury Rev through a reverbed cloudbank and they generated lyrics by refracting the words of Richard M. Ketchum's The Secret Life of the Forest through a translation program. Their new LP is not only granted the title Ceres & Calypso in the Deep Time
column8: it’s also ""the story of Ceres
column9: a seal-like beast
column10: and Calypso
column11: her human partner
column12: as they travel through the Mesozoic Era."" Oh
column13: and each of the band's three members plays a different character
column14: with leader Ryan Hover as ""The Deep Time."" When they give a rare interview
column15: Hover might say something like
column16: “We just say [we're] Dream Pop because I’m a dinosaur from the Cretaceous Period dreaming I’m a human in a band in 2013.” Trippy.

column1: But they are an actual dream-pop band on Ceres
column2: as the most notable additions Candy Claws have made since Hidden Lands are definition and structure; while maintaining the same wondrous perspective and amorphous textures
column3: these are more likely to be considered “songs” than soundscapes. And it turns out Candy Claws have a knack for pop construct
column4: as “Transitional Bird (Clever Girl)” and “White Seal (Shell & Shine)” boast swelling
column5: immediate psych rock hooks that bloom from their earthy verses
column6: countering the unwieldiness of their titles. It allows them a proper showcase for their unusual
column7: intuitive melodic sense-- their chord progressions are deliberate and surefooted
column8: but each turn tends to take a step or two beyond what’s expected. It’s either the result of super-advanced knowledge of music theory or none at all; considering Candy Claws made it a point to create Hidden Lands on instruments with which they had no formal training whatsoever
column9: it must be the latter.

column1: Whereas Hidden Lands defied definition and either drew you in from the beginning or not at all
column2: Candy Claws’ disparate interests are allowed to exist as individual tracks here
column3: creating numerous re-entry points and strange innovations: spaghetti western with a 90% chance of rain
column4: the tropical psych adventures of Os Mutantes relocated to the bedroom of a landlocked teen. Often
column5: Ceres sounds like the first legitimately happy shoegaze record. “Birth of the Flower (Seagreen)” is something like My Bloody Valentine performing “To Here Knows When” at an island resort.

column1: Yet the same fanciful approach to the actual
column2: physical recording of the music doesn’t do Ceres justice. It’s an immersive listening experience
column3: but also a claustrophobic one. There’s flow
column4: though a curious lack of dynamics as so much of it is taken up by midrange. The layers upon layers of whispering vocals and airy synths turns Ceres into a surprisingly loud and brittle listen
column5: a brickwall covered in gauze. Perhaps it’s wishful thinking to imagine Dave Fridmann or Ben H. Allen taking a flier on these guys and rounding out the low end
column6: after helping Flaming Lips
column7: MGMT
column8: Youth Lagoon and Washed Out fuse nature-boy naivety with studio nerd fervor into something festival-ready. But on the other hand
column9: Ceres could’ve just easily benefited from a more holistic production along the lines of Animal Collective ca. Sung Tongs
column10: stripping away the reverb and countermelodies to let things breathe.

column1: Ceres & Calypso is certainly one of 2013’s more unique records
column2: which is even more impressive considering how many of its precedents and peers are some of indie rock’s more populist acts. It’s a strange situation where you wish they treated their passions more like a career-- the leap in songwriting promises an advance
column3: but the decision to record it in the same way as the billowing
column4: freeform Hidden Lands makes it feel like a missed opportunity. It all leads to Ceres & Calypso feeling like concrete evidence of their hippie cred
column5:
chock full of fantastic ideas and lacking just enough follow through.

From lo-fi synth noodling to skewed dance forms: as underground music narratives go
column2: it’s a pretty cliched one these days. But Christelle Gualdi is by no means a slavish follower of trends: The French producer was self-releasing CD-Rs of kosmische-inspired
column3: new age-y synth improv for some time before interest in the style began to grow in the late 2000s. By then she had found kindred spirits in the U.S. underground
column4: including the likes of Oneohtrix Point Never and James Ferraro. Her engagement with that scene culminated in a very fine album for Olde English Spelling Bee as Stellar Om Source
column5: 2010’s Trilogy Select.

column1: Gualdi’s incorporation of dance forms into her music came after her deportation from the U.S.
column2: and a subsequent period of musical isolation in Belgium
column3: where she is now based. The first recorded evidence of this shift was 2011 single ""Clarity""
column4: followed by last year’s Image Over Image EP for Rush Hour imprint No Label. Gualdi’s new sound retained the shimmering
column5: highly synthetic chord work of her previous output
column6: but re-housed it in a crisp rhythmic chassis-- one which owed a clear debt to Detroit techno and electro pioneers like Underground Resistance and Drexciya.

column1: Joy One Mile is the most comprehensive document yet of Gualdi’s new sound
column2: and her most substantial release in some years. Each of these hardware-based compositions was road-tested live before being refined and recorded in a handful of takes. Fittingly
column3: then-- and in contrast to the solipsistic repose of her earlier records-- their complex percussive patterns and glistening synth motifs fizz with barely restrained kinetic energy. The album was mixed by cult German house figure Kassem Mosse
column4: who reportedly brought “clarity” to Gualdi’s original compositions. (Mosse’s impressionistic remix of ""Elite Excel"" is also included here; while excellent
column5: it feels a little extraneous given the extreme stylistic coherence across the rest of the record.) But these tracks are still remarkably dense
column6: eschewing the linearity of much techno in favour of dizzying
column7: polyvalent structures that seem to hint at several narrative arcs at once.

column1: Take opener ""Polarity"". In its first two minutes
column2: murky bass stabs and a higher counterpart seem to be implying two different root notes
column3: before a third tone falls semitonally between the two. The result is deeply ambiguous
column4: as if we could lurch in any direction at any time-- an effect aided by Gualdi’s restless stop-start structuring. After two minutes
column5: though
column6: rich
column7: creamy pads enter and bundle the whole thing into shape. That trick-- of finding or maintaining coherence in the most seemingly adverse of circumstances-- is often the fascinating strength of these compositions. ""Trackers"" is bound together by a single dextrous synth sequence
column8: pirouetting ceaselessly through a whirlwind of texturing before giving way to 303 acrobatics at the close. ""The Range""
column9: with its brash kicks and claps
column10: is perhaps the only moment when the sheer density of the mix becomes fatiguing-- though all is forgiven when those strange
column11: tart chords descend from on high in the closing 30 seconds.

column1: This is techno
column2: certainly
column3: but the only suggestion of classicist homage comes in ""Par Amour""
column4: where Gualdi deploys Lovie’s ""Motions of Love"" a capella more or less in its entirety. Rather than softening her alien atmosphere in deference to its earthly guest
column5: though
column6: Gualdi’s scintillating synth figures and de-centred rhythms remain as rich and strange as ever. In interview the producer has put vintage Detroit techno’s appeal down to it being “very genuine
column7: very heartfelt
column8: with such strong beliefs.” Her real achievement here-- just as with her new age-inspired recordings of a few years ago-- is that she doesn’t ironize or fetishize this now-lost utopianism
column9: but embraces it fully
column10:
all the better to turn it to her own captivating ends.

Richard Morales Jr.
column2: aka Gunplay
column3: is widely known in the rap world for a number of reasons that have nothing to do with his talents as a rapper
column4: including his class-clown personality (which has inspired at least one classic viral video)
column5: a prodigious (and recently kicked
column6: he claims) cocaine habit (another viral video)
column7: and his prolonged house arrest while under investigation for an armed assault on his tax accountant’s office. The latter is the primary reason why the Def Jam-signed MC’s debut official album has yet to drop
column8: despite its endorsement from Rick Ross
column9: who recruited Morales for his Maybach Music Group years ago.

column1: As much as he likes to present himself as a recklessly id-driven madman
column2: and as entertaining as that aspect of his personality may be
column3: it tends to stop at the door to the vocal booth. Those who know Morales only as a person balls-out crazy enough to snort coke in front of a Colombian policeman might expect his recordings to land somewhere between Waka Flocka and ODB
column4: full of manic
column5: scream-along club rippers. They might be disappointed to find out that his mixtapes in general
column6: and this most recent one in particular
column7: are emotionally complex
column8: and more likely to find him grappling with the effects of his wild lifestyle than celebrating it.

column1: Morales’s lawyers successfully got his house arrest lifted back in January
column2: and the following month the case was dismissed despite the fact that there was surveillance video of him and his partner committing the crime. (His accountant refused to cooperate with prosecutors.) The aptly-named Acquitted is very much part of the tradition of the post-trial rap record
column3: but unlike the form’s best-known examples (Jay-Z’s The Blueprint
column4: for instance) it’s short on unalloyed triumph.

column1: After a brief intro
column2: consisting of audio from a local news report on Morales’s acquittal laid over an operatic string arrangement
column3: Acquitted begins in earnest with “Salute Me”. Lyrically it’s just like you’d expect the opening track on a mixtape from a rapper fresh off of house arrest and dropped felony charges to sound like: wildly boastful
column4: with the strong suggestion that the ability to elude a conviction is only part of his street prowess. But the music itself is far from celebratory
column5: and much closer to funereal
column6: with bleakly minimal verses from Gunplay and elegiac choruses delivered by Peryon J. Kee in a melodic
column7: Nate Dogg-ish flow that’s downright mournful. If Morales is happy to be back on the streets he certainly doesn’t sound like it.

column1: Other tracks serve up that conflicted sensation in subtler ways. “D.O.P.E.” has an uptempo beat with stuttering snares that add a Latin flair to the trap formula
column2: but while the lyrics comprise a list of Morales’s dope-pushing credentials there’s something strangely resigned about his perspective
column3: and the line “Dope gon’ get me way more money than this fucking song” inverts the usual corner-boy-to-superstar storyline into something sad and inescapable. And there’s something relentlessly self-destructive about a rapper fresh off a court case boasting about “pulling drive-by shootings with some mobbed-up hoodlums
column4: ” the way he does on the malevolently gleeful ode to gun violence “Drop Da Tint”
column5: as if he was just begging prosecutors to open another case on him
column6: which they probably would have anyhow.

column1: Morales isn’t all internal struggles and felony crimes
column2: though. Two of the brightest spots on Acquitted come when he lets his more uncomplicatedly manic side take the wheel. “Been Did It” is all noisy rave synths and quarter-note handclaps that highlights Southern rap’s transition from MDMA obsession to a straight-up infatuation with EDM. And the chorus to “Cocaina (Que Linda)”
column3: which consists of the title (in English
column4: “Cocaine (How Beautiful)”) delivered in a beyond-catchy way
column5: could easily become the most out-of-control club chant-along of the year.

column1: Despite many of these songs’ addictive qualities
column2: Morales and his team are promoting Acquitted’s final cut
column3: “Bible on tha Dash”
column4: as its lead single
column5: and it’s easy to understand why. It’s the most appealing fusion of his psyche’s various facets
column6: strangely uplifting even with a vein of self-doubt running through it
column7: and with a little polish it could easily fit in on the Hot 100. It also suggests how interesting it would be to see Gunplay as a pop artist
column8: but that will almost certainly involve him finally getting his official debut out
column9:
something that his behavior and self-portraiture makes out to be far from a sure thing. Let’s hope he doesn’t succeed in fucking it all up before then.

Born Sinner
column2: the heavily referential second LP for Roc Nation signee Jermaine Cole
column3: borrows its title from the Notorious B.I.G.’s ""Juicy"". By the time you’ve reached the record's end
column4: you’ll have seen him try on a number of familiar hats. He repurposes OutKast's “Da Art of Storytellin Pt. 1” (“Land of the Snakes”) and fashions it into an anti-L.A. tirade. He duets with the remaining members of TLC (“Crooked Smile”) on a song that can be read either as a breezy style mash-up or as sacrilege. He co-opts a snippet of a Mike Epps comedy routine and he flips Cults’ “Bad Things” on a song about cheating
column5: a track that also doubles down with Dirty Projectors’ Amber Coffman showing up to coo on the (long
column6: guitar-heavy) outro. “Forbidden Fruit” finds Cole swimming in A Tribe Called Quest's “Electric Relaxation”
column7: a track that also features a barely audible Kendrick Lamar. And toward the end
column8: there’s a song-length love letter to Nas-- “Used to print out Nas raps and tape 'em up on my wall/ My niggas thought they was words
column9: but it was pictures I saw.”

column1: Who is the person at the center of all this outward projection? We still don't really know. Cole's second
column2: attention-grabbing mixtape
column3: 2009's <i>The Warm Up
column4: positioned him as an upstart unmoored from traditional conventions
column5: an artist who could switch up flows
column6: rap furiously and build his own hooks; Born Sinner finds himself standing in about the same place he was on Cole World: The Sideline Story
column7: but the green room here is a little nicer. Listening to Born Sinner
column8: you can't help but think of the gold standards of the modern era
column9: among them Kanye West's first two albums as well as Kendrick Lamar's 2012 opus good kid
column10: m.A.A.d. City (""Let Nas Down"" can certainly be viewed as Cole's answer to West's ""Big Brother""
column11: which Cole references on the hook). Part of the reason you can't help but think of them is because Cole keeps bringing them up-- when you constantly point to the work of others
column12: comparisons with them are inevitable. But while the production (mostly by Cole himself) favors the soulful
column13: laid-back vibe of College Dropout and the string swoops of Late Registration
column14: there's very little to make it distinct
column15: something more than a nod to the past.

column1: Once in a while he can create something catchy-- the Miguel-featuring ""Power Trip"" almost seems like it was designed in a lab for radio rotation but the album as a whole splices together musical eras and reference without much purpose. Which is too bad
column2: because some sonic innovation might direct folks away from some of Born Sinner's more grievous lyrical howlers: “My verbal AK slay faggots/ And I don't mean no disrespect whenever I say faggot
column3: okay faggot?” Later
column4: a starry eyed Cole gets philosophical: ""Niggas say turn up
column5: hoes say turn up/ Only bad thing about a star is they burn up."" He finds something that rhymes with Kanye-- Wanyá
column6: as in Boyz II Men's Wanyá Morris-- and races to build a line about growing up
column7: a boy to a man
column8: you see. On ""Miss America"": ""I'mma fuck your daughters
column9: I'mma burn your flag."" It goes on like this.

column1: At its best
column2: Born Sinner
column3: showcases J. Cole's overall musicality
column4: pairing his ability as a lyricist with a more broadly developed production palette. In a heat
column5: he can rattle off some fierce rejoinders (See: ""Niggaz Know""). But several releases deep into Cole's growing catalogue
column6: we haven't been delivered the savior that Jay-Z's ""A Star is Born"" seemed to anoint. (The latter's current indifference to Cole has become so pronounced that Cole has to keep squashing beef rumors.) Though much has been made of Cole's decision to bump up Born Sinner's release to the same day as Kanye's Yeezus
column7: Cole is popular to a degree that suggests his sales will be competitive with Kanye's divisive-by-design Yeezus. That popularity
column8: which has grown through a handful of big singles
column9: is a testament to the fans who've been with him since his come up
column10:
fans rewarded with a recent string of $1 ""Dollar and a Dream"" performances taking place this week. But Born Sinner didn't turn out to be a reward in itself.
