When Empire of the Sun emerged in 2008
column3: they were fascinating
column4: even at a glance: Wearing costumes that evoked community-theater Flash Gordon
column5: or perhaps the leaping wing-people from the NES version of Contra
column6: they made cheery
column7: brightly pumping synth music that suggested similar pop-culture carbon dating. ""Walking on a Dream""
column8: their big hit
column9: was so beguiling that Jay-Z flew them in from Perth to record for The Blueprint 3-- the most unlikely
column10: out-of-context guest spot on a Jay-Z album since Lenny Kravitz on The Blueprint 2. Empire's Walking on a Dream was pop made by people fully intending to be famous
column11: but part of its appeal was how endearingly homemade it felt. The big anthems were set off by odd grace notes like the ambient Eno-like ""The World""
column12: the dark ""Swordfish Hotkiss Night""
column13: or the George Michael/Prince mindmeld ""Breakdown"". EOTS were theatrical weirdos
column14: for sure
column15: but it seemed conceivable you might be able to walk up to them at a party and ask them
column16: ""What's with the hat?"".

column1: Their first album did its job
column2: and now they are legitimately famous: They've have been touring internationally more or less nonstop since its release. (Party music that translates to outdoor festival audiences worldwide is a demanding beast.) Ice On The Dune
column3: their five-years-in-the-making follow up
column4: was written and recorded while running this endless arena-date treadmill
column5: and you can instantly hear that music's homemade quirks have burned off like cellulite. With their baby fat gone
column6: Empire of the Sun are both more impressive and less distinctive; they've made the confusing half-leap from indie-gone-mainstream (Luke Steele
column7: Empire of the Sun's lead singer
column8: started out in the indie-rock band Sleepy Jackson) to not-quite pop stars
column9: and Ice On the Dune feels middling as a result.

column1: It is certainly bigger
column2: and more purposefully stadium-scaled
column3: than its predecessor
column4: from the hilariously portentous Danny Elfman flourish of orchestral opener ""Lux"" onward.  The best of the Big Moments are exhilarating: ""Alive""
column5: always a good song title and pop-song sentiment
column6: arcs up into a shouted chorus that jabs you in the chest with every repeated ""alive!"" You will dance to this
column7: especially when its surrounded by the synths' popping carnival lights and spun sugar. ""Awakening"" pairs a humid Donna Summer thump with a creamy falsetto vocal straight from Toto. The midtempo ""I'll Be Around"" is probably the highlight
column8: and underlines how deftly Empire flit between eras: The same materials reworked slightly would also make an excellent Pains of Being Pure At Heart song.

column1: There are half-hearted fillips of weirdness here and there still: On ""Surround Sound""
column2: Steele sings ""Let's push through four dimensions/ Till our brains turn to jelly
column3: which feels more indebted to Ween than the Bee Gees. But the mind wanders during the album's middle third
column4: subbing in other
column5: more effective party music in the same vein to keep it occupied. The same year that Daft Punk released Random Access Memories
column6: an album that brilliantly evoked the exuberantly ripe languor of late 70s/early 80s pop
column7: is not an ideal moment for the return of EOTS. The comparison might seem unfair-- Daft Punk had a kingly
column8: late-70s budget to burn through-- but these are EOTS's competitors now
column9: and their voice isn't strong enough
column10: their imprint on their diaphanous grooves not unique enough
column11: to make them stick. Their stuff floats off
column12:
and the synths carry the whiff not of a beach breeze but of a department-store escalator.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19416/homepage_large.e9d15a77.jpg|Howlin'|31037.0|Jagwar Ma|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Marathon Artists']|2013-06-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:27.760491|"

Let’s take account of Madchester’s enduring images: a heavy-lidded Ian Brown moaning “I wanna be adored” but not sounding like he wants to be awake. Bez freaky-dancin' his way through the Happy Mondays' prime and not even being the most loutish guy in the group. The rumors that Shaun Ryder ditched a meeting with EMI to score heroin
column2: which was referred to as ""KFC"" by the band. And the sweaters. Point being that while the clash of ecstasy
column3: acid house
column4: and rock'n'roll resulted in a brief period of brilliant
column5: forward-thinking music
column6: the leading lights of the scene were never all that bright. That hindsight puts an interesting perspective on Australian duo Jagwar Ma’s gleeful debut Howlin’; their early singles cast them as the purest Madchester revivalists in some time and the full-length delivers on that promise. The music is a heady swirl of baggy beats and unabashed Beach Boys melodies
column7: while the lyrics are wholly uninterested in anything intellectual. It’s silly enough to cause skepticism and charming enough to make you wonder what kind of scrutiny Screamadelica or Thrills
column8: Pills & Bellyaches would meet if they were released in 2013.

column1: The album gets its title from a line on the shambling “Uncertainty”: “When you’re gloomy/ Howlin’ looks so good to me.” The characters within Howlin’ are gloomy
column2: they’re certainly not depressed; nothing that a little howlin’ couldn’t fix. They howl because they’re confused by loneliness
column3: and unlike fellow Australian psych pop space cadets Tame Impala
column4: solitude isn’t bliss; it can be externalized and rendered as a goofy Austin Powers-pop trifle on “That Loneliness”. They howl because it’s women
column5: not drugs
column6: that offer transcendence and Jagwar Ma needs the hook up; fluid breakbeats and classic psychedelic effects (backwards guitar
column7: naturally) drive “Man I Need” and “Come Save Me”
column8: tart and hooky songs too bashful to be overbearing. This is festival stuff
column9: the movements coming off a bit drunk and a little wearied by the sun. The beat-driven tracks
column10: “What Love” and “Four”
column11: aren’t actually dance music
column12: per se-- they lack the precision and rigor of proper electronic music. When Gabriel Winterfield yells “exercise your chemistry!” it's meaningless
column13: but at least lets you know this isn’t rocket science.

column1: In that sense
column2: Jagwar Ma’s guilelessness works in their favor; they’re hardly the first guys who’ve banged the drums on Madchester's behalf
column3: but they avoid the shamanistic mock profundity that resulted in a similarly positioned band named the Music making a song called “The People”. Ewan Pearson’s mixing is sweet
column4: slick
column5: and colorful as Skittles shells
column6: meaning Jagwar Ma avoid the leathery cock-rocking that marred the Big Pink; the latter boasted “these girls fall like dominos
column7: ” whereas when Winterfield yelps “let me show me you babe just all the man I can be!” he sounds ready to pull a bouquet of flowers from behind his back. Only on the last two tracks do Jagwar Ma aspire to “serious” artistic ambitions
column8: and the result is a preview of Howlin’s “darker
column9: ” “introspective” and duller sequel. Let's hope it doesn't come to that.

column1: It’s possible to be incredibly ambitious and disarming at the same time
column2: and in that way
column3: Howlin’ isn't that different in approach to Daft Punk’s Random Access Memories-- a backwards looking record about loving the present moment
column4: a big-tent affair that can be misunderstood as a reactionary record. (It's no less reactionary than Noel Gallagher claiming Howlin' to be more important than an Oasis reunion.) From the moment “What Love” fades in with its loose-limbed
column5: floppy rhythm
column6: Howlin’ ensures everybody will be dancing
column7: few will be doin' it right
column8:
but they'll all be feelin’ alright regardless.

"|18225.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18225-jagwar-ma-howlin/|7.7|Ian Cohen

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19424/homepage_large.324bbad0.jpg|Jackleg Devotional to the Heart|31451.0|The Baptist Generals|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2013-06-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:28.414133|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".25eyq22d43k.1.6:0.1.0.$18235/=1$18235.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div><span style=""font-family: Georgia
column2: serif;"">Distinguished by a sort of homespun musical ingenuity and front-porch experimentation
column3: the Baptist Generals’ new album
column4: Jackleg Devotional to the Heart
column5: sounds like it’s built out of beer bottles
column6: tin cans
column7: lengths of rusted chain
column8: assorted junkyard scraps
column9: and unidentifiable whatchamabobs.  Opener “Machine en Prolepsis” rigs a squelchy synth and a percussive acoustic strum into a whirligig rhythm that spins on pure gumption. “Oblivion” turns what sounds like incidental music from a home movie into a gyroscopic finale
column10: ending in a rousing finale when the guitars and keyboards spin faster and faster. The song sounds like it might just overheat and explode
column11: but the Generals manage to keep a lid on everything. Barely.

column1: <div>
It’s the Denton
column2: Texas-based outfit’s first album in a full decade
column3: which suggests a get-to-it-when-I-get-to-it attitude toward the creative process and a dismissive attitude toward the music business. In fact
column4: they trashed at least one attempt at a follow-up
column5: and the album they finally thought well enough of to release is so different from No Silver / No Gold that it might as well be a fresh debut. It’s all too easy to romanticize this sort of art-for-art’s-sake mentality
column6: especially when it comes from deep in the heart of Texas. However
column7: lacking both the demonstrative lo-fi sprawl of its predecessor and the hermetic perfectionism that often marks long-gestating albums
column8: Jackleg really does sound like the Baptist Generals made it first and foremost for themselves.

column1: If that means it’s occasionally self-indulgent
column2: fine. They sound like they take no small pleasure in fashioning the pinwheel rhythms on “Dog That Bit You”
column3: setting them against Chris Flemmons’ scratchy vocal melodies
column4: and creating something distinctive and unusual. As a result
column5: Jackleg succeeds even when its musical resourcefulness is undermined by Flemmons’ overwrought lyrics. His reliance on antiquated language and poetic phrasing suggests a self-consciously old weird America rather than inhabiting the new weird one. Exactly as ridiculous as its title
column6: “Clitorpus Christi” is a story-song without much of a story: The narrator talks about hiring a prostitute and not taking showers
column7: but never gets around to having a point. It might be less of a sore spot if Jackleg Devotional took up that point of view again or if the Baptist Generals could find a way to couch it in a larger narrative.

column1: Fighting against the song’s inconsequentiality is the singer’s adenoidal rasp
column2: which recalls that of fellow Dentonite Will Johnson. Flemmons doesn’t quite have the Centro-Matic frontman’s expressive range
column3: but to his credit he gives himself over fully to his characters. Arguably his best moment on Jackleg Devotional comes toward the end of “Snow on the FM”
column4: when Flemmons elects to sing a string of la la la’s against a steady acoustic guitar theme. By delivering sound instead of words
column5:
his voice becomes purely instrumental-- one cog in a fascinating contraption of sound.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19298/homepage_large.b65c0cd4.jpg|Antenna to the Afterworld|28676.0|Sonny and the Sunsets|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2013-06-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:28.945364|"

The title Antenna to the Afterworld seems like an intentional bit of ambiguity from Sonny and the Sunsets. On one hand
column2: the album plays up an extensive narrative about outer space and alien life
column3: which is reinforced by the band's frequent use of synthesizers.  In ""Green Blood""
column4: Sonny Smith professes his love for an alien android
column5: and maybe the antenna in question is pointing us to a distant planet. But then there's ""afterworld."" When he made this album
column6: Smith had death on his mind-- a close friend of his had been murdered. Then
column7: Smith visited a psychic
column8: who gave him a message from another recently deceased friend named Nancy. ""Through the psychic
column9: Nancy told me not to get too comfortable with loneliness
column10: as she had done
column11: to go out and live
column12: he said. ""This could be what many psychics say
column13: I have no idea
column14: and I don’t care really."" He began to think about ""the afterworld"" quite a bit
column15: and on the album
column16: he cuts straight to the point when he folds that encounter into one of his lyrics: ""I had a visit from a dead friend/ She told me not to wallow in this loneliness."" And where does space come into play? Well
column17: that song is called ""Path of Orbit"".

column1: As it turns out
column2: the album's title is an umbrella that covers most things spiritual and cosmic-- all the reasons why we stare upward and wonder what's out there or what's next. Smith doesn't get hung up on the specifics-- he accepts every possibility. ""I believe in everything
column3: he said. ""I always have. Ghosts
column4: afterlife
column5: reincarnation
column6: ESP
column7: telekinesis
column8: clairvoyance
column9: mystics
column10: shamans
column11: psychics
column12: miracles
column13: the force
column14: aliens. I believe it all."" That all-encompassing belief system is the heart and soul of Antenna to the Afterworld. Smith's acceptance of the fantastical is implied in his nonchalant lyrical approach. (On ""Primitive"": ""I love the moon/ I don't know why."") Really
column15: though the paranormal and supernatural make several appearances in the LP's 11 tracks
column16: they're never the center of attention in Smith's songs about love and the banal. His inherent belief in palmistry
column17: for example
column18: makes it so the titular ""Palmreader"" plays second fiddle to Sonny's scab- and glue-covered hands.

column1: In the past two years
column2: Smith and the band have been genre-jumping shapeshifters. Smith's 100 Records series had him going from reggae to R&B to folk to garage. Last year
column3: on Longtime Companion
column4: Smith took the band country. This time
column5: they've made something that's very much its own creature. When the synthesizers come in
column6: they understatedly float over some soft
column7: warm guitar pop. On ""Natural Acts""
column8: the country influence has carried over in their guitars
column9: though they're layered alongside synthesizers and the occasional acid-soaked psychedelic vocal stab. Later
column10: on ""Void""
column11: Smith and the gang have some garage rock fun. Smith whoops like an ape
column12: claps his hands to match his vocals
column13: and then a delighted Tahlia Harbour playfully sings along with the instrumental outro. Both musically and lyrically
column14: the album presents some of the Sunsets' best work yet.

column1: Though Antenna will probably be viewed as Sonny's ""space and synthesizers album
column2: it's also full of doe-eyed and fragile moments. Over the jangling melody of ""Girl on the Street""
column3: he pines over someone he's never spoken to
column4: but who he stares at from a distance. In ""Mutilator""
column5: he sings an awed love song about a sword swallower. (She's also the girl attached to the knife thrower's spinning wheel.) But as surreal ballads go
column6: nothing beats ""Green Blood"". His android lover is shot by her scorned cyborg husband
column7: but that isn't the end of the story. She lives
column8: and they try to make it work. So the song gets the same kind of quietly sad ending from most breakup stories-- they just drift away. When Harbour asks if she went back to her cyborg husband
column9: Sonny's reply is dejected and unsure. ""I don't even know. But I miss her
column10: you know? I really miss her."" Antenna to the Afterworld may have all the dressings of science fiction and fantasy
column11: but like many great works in those genres
column12: it's a strong
column13: emotive character study. He might've replaced the cowboy hat with a spaceman's helmet
column14:
but Sonny Smith still writes like a country balladeer.

"|18109.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18109-sonny-the-sunsets-antenna-to-the-afterworld/|7.7|Evan Minsker

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19374/homepage_large.3565b3fb.jpg|Saaab Stories|29708.0|Action Bronson|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vice']|2013-06-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:29.485998|"

Before you even press play on Saaab Stories
column2: you're confronted by the unsettling dichotomy within Action Bronson: The Flushing rapper has a tremendous ear for beats
column3: but he’s also tone deaf. Following full-length collaborations with Statik Selektah
column4: Party Supplies
column5: and Alchemist
column6: Saaab Stories matches Bronson with Harry Fraud
column7: a guy who can play both sides of the underground/Hot 97 divide with beats as rugged and plush as a sheepskin shearling. But at a time when Rick Ross’ verse on “U.O.E.N.O.”
column8: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"" target=""_blank"">Tyler
column9: the Creator’s anti-feminist rant in Australia and certain lyrics on Yeezus have resulted in real backlash throughout a wide swath of hip-hop and an opportunity to ask tough questions about the genre's pervasive attitudes towards women
column10: Bronson chooses that artwork. Repellant as it is
column11: it’s also not the least bit surprising: If you’ve heard more than five minutes of Action Bronson’s music
column12: you'll be aware of his attitude towards women
column13: and Asian prostitutes in particular. So while his prodigious talents as a rapper ensure you might enjoy Saaab Stories on a purely musical level
column14: it’s unlikely you’ll feel better when it’s over.

column1: While Saaab stories is Bronson’s shortest official release
column2: it’s his most diverse and sonically interesting. Fraud finds middle ground between the weeded-out YouTube scour of Blue Chips and the more traditional crate-digging on Rare Chandeliers-- classic boom-bap on “Strictly 4 My Jeeps” and “No Time”
column3: regal cloud-rap on “The Rockers”
column4: simmered soul on “Triple Backflip”. Attending to the realities of Bronson’s ascendant career brings Saaab to a dead halt; “feat. Wiz Khalifa” is a passport stamp for an up-and-comer and an invitation for the listener to hit fast forward (“The Rockers”). Meanwhile
column5: Prodigy is every bit as incapable of delivering a coherent rap these days
column6: though it’s not for lack of trying.

column1: The title of Saaab Stories is actually misleading for both parts of its double entendre. On prior highlights such as “Hookers at the Point” or “Bag of Money”
column2: Bronson was a storyteller
column3: whereas Saaab has a loose
column4: performative aspect more along the lines of raunchy comedy; you can picture him leaned against a stool at a stand-up gig
column5: or bragging over a brown bag lunch. If his appetites are base
column6: his words make those dirtbag pursuits sound opulent as hell (“Amethyst on the knuckle/ On the arm
column7: something Spanish with a bubble”). There’s an anti-clever cleverness to similes like “gold watch like I just retired” that hearken back to prime-era DOOM in terms of finding the most obvious likenesses that somehow never got used.

column1: But the sheer percentage of lyrics purposefully written to degrade women is about the only thing that might leave a lasting impression. The narrowing of Bronson’s subject matter has resulted in an increasingly less satisfying artistic experience. Dr. Lecter and Blue Chips weren’t particularly relatable records
column2: but even the smallest amount of emotional and personal scope worked towards distinguishing Bronson from his vocal doppelgänger Ghostface
column3: creating a tangible persona that couldn’t be culled from the jaw-dropping lines about gourmet food and old school sneakers.

column1: Gone is any counterbalance of self-deprecation (like Dr. Lecter’s fat-kid reminiscence “Ronnie Coleman”) or narrative to put the constant putdowns in context (“Thug Love Story 2012”); a line like “If I’m sick she’ll even clean me if I shit in my pants/ So I’m taking her to France with me” from “No Time” qualifies as chivalrous by comparison. And while getting two punchlines out of “Mutombo finger” in the same verse is pretty funny
column2: the repurposing of old lyrics for the hooks on “Triple Bakckflip” and “The Rockers” gives the sense that Bronson might be running out of ideas.

column1: Which makes his means of filling the void even sadder; more than ever
column2: Bronson takes particular pleasure in biting down on a harshly pronounced bitch ad-lib or using a hook to reduce a woman to the sum of her orifices. You can generously read some of the actions of Tyler
column3: the Creator or Kanye’s lyrics on Yeezus as purposeful trolling
column4: or at least an incredibly awkward means of trying to start a conversation. Yet
column5: Action Bronson only seeks to provoke indignation at Action Bronson
column6: as if he harnesses the strength of conviction from vindicating those who find his off-record persona every bit as abhorrent. It was barely a year ago when Bronson was predicating his career on something other than being as unlikeable as possible
column7: so there’s hope he isn’t too far gone. But on the grim
column8: vulgar Saaab Stories
column9:
what you see is what you get.

"|18186.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18186-action-bronson-saaab-stories/|6.1|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19277/homepage_large.15573416.jpg|Scott: The Collection 1967-1970|4636.0|Scott Walker|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Universal']|2013-06-20 00:00:00|1967|2016-06-11 16:56:30.886730|"

The story of the singer Scott Walker is typically split into three parts. The first is of his brief career with the melancholy orchestral-pop group the Walker Brothers
column2: who for a couple of years in the mid-1960s were famous enough to be a front-cover concern on Tiger Beat magazine and have their car overturned by fans while they were still sitting in it. Walker quickly became uncomfortable with this
column3: and in 1967 went solo with four theatrical and increasingly dark albums
column4: all called Scott. ""GOING SOLO IN A MONASTERY!"" a headline in Melody Maker read-- a monastery Walker had to leave because fans started banging on the door looking for him.

column1: The Scott albums-- now remastered and collected into a box set with 1970's 'Til The Band Comes In-- are the fulcrum of Walker's career: You can hear where he'd been
column2: and in retrospect
column3: where he was going; his third act was emerging after 20 years of almost total silence with Tilt
column4: The Drift
column5: and Bish Bosch
column6: released between 1997 and 2012. Walker's latter-day albums are fearless and violent
column7: featuring wailing donkeys
column8: moans
column9: scrapes
column10: and famously
column11: the sound of someone punching meat. They seem to have been written in another language entirely.

column1: The Scott albums
column2: however
column3: remain part of a tradition of highly arranged
column4: rock-free music that valued old songs over new sounds and professionalism over innovation. ""I don't wanna see my fans walking around like drugged zombies
column5: Walker told a journalist around the time Scott came out in 1967
column6: a rejection of the psychedelic culture prevalent at the time. Instead
column7: he embraced conventionally gorgeous
column8: string-heavy music targeted at housewives and elderly people. At the same time
column9: he fell headlong into existentialist literature and European art-house cinema. He appeared on variety shows
column10: and remained either at or near the top of the charts. He also developed a pitch-black sense of humor
column11: and in his rich
column12: mocking baritone explored songs about Soviet dictators and the spiritual poverty of men who only feel human in the company of whores.

column1: ""Jackie""
column2: the single released in advance of Scott 2
column3: was banned by the BBC. When the album came out
column4: it went to Number 1. It remains the first recorded instance of the hyphenated adjective ""stupid-ass"" that I can think of. By 1969 Walker was writing epics about Ingmar Bergman movies featuring dissonant choir arrangements and trumpets blowing through canyons of reverb. Around this time he was also given his own television show
column5: where he performed all your toe-tapping and heart-rending favorites in black sunglasses
column6: without smiling.

column1: This is the Scott Walker of the late 1960s: As passionately invested in covers of Tony Bennett and Frank Sinatra hits as in singing the word ""gonorrhea""; voted ""Mr. Valentine"" by Disc & Music Echo the same year he released a song about a young man routinely raped by military officers. His best performances convey the deep tragedy of their subjects while managing to laugh at them with a cruelty and indifference available to only the most total of douchebags.

The essential contrast in his late-60s albums is between easy-listening music and forbiddingly difficult subject matter. It's a dichotomy that has always made Walker seem more like an outsider artist than a mainstream one. It's also fodder for a case that Walker was ""subversive
column2: an accolade for alternative-music fans who
column3: especially now
column4: can recast him as some kind of mole inside the machine
column5: exposing the innocent people of Britain to material that would make their middle-class spines shiver. This isn't untrue. But it also smoothes over the fact that the Scott albums are different pieces of music that leave different impressions. Any attempt to lump them together is more a matter of laziness or historical convenience than anything else. If you look at the credits from Scott onward
column6: what you see
column7: essentially
column8: is Walker taking over the show: on Scott
column9: he wrote three songs among its 12
column10: the rest covers; by Scott 4
column11: he wrote them all.

column1: Walker's choice of covers essentially falls into two camps: Easygoing heartbreak music and songs by the Belgian writer Jacques Brel. The latter's impact on Walker can't be understated: Walker covered him nine times on his first three albums
column2: and some of the most elegant expressions of Walker's romantic but poisoned worldview are his. Take ""The Girls and the Dogs""
column3: from Scott 2
column4: a psychopathically chipper song about how men are longing
column5: women are fickle
column6: and dogs are lucky to not care either way. ""The dogs
column7: well you know the dogs
column8: they lift up a leg as they see it end/ The dogs
column9: well you know the dogs
column10: and maybe that's why they're man's best friend
column11: goes the refrain. ""And yet
column12: Walker sings toward the end
column13: ""it's because of the girls
column14: when they've knocked us about and our tears want to shout/ That we kick the dogs out."" Over the course of about 10 seconds
column15: his voice hardens from drippy sympathy to resolute meanness
column16: and as the song fades out
column17: he defers to a choir of trombones that sound like they wandered out of a burlesque show. In essence: The world is a monochromatically cruel place
column18: so ha ha ha
column19: fuck it.

column1: Walker's own songs are more ambiguous. From Scott 2
column2: ""The Amorous Humphrey Plugg"" tells the story of a deflated husband who finds his peace of mind wandering thorugh the red-light district at night. ""Leave it all behind me
column3: he sings
column4: sailing away on a tide of violins. ""Screaming kids on my knee and the telly swallowing me/ And the neighbors shouting next door/ And the subway trembling the rollerskate floor."" Like good satire
column5: Jacques Brel's songs cue you to laugh then startle you with reality. Walker puts you in the uncomfortable position of wondering whether to laugh in the first place
column6: or to just lean back and allow these characters a glory that eludes them in their own lives.

column1: Then there are songs like the simple
column2: country-influenced ""Duchess""
column3: from Scott 4. The same singer who rejected psychedelia started writing the kind of impressionistic lyrics whose nonsense is more penetrating than anything more literal could be. ""It's your shiftless flesh and your old-girl's grace
column4: he sighs. ""It's your young girl's face that I'm breathing."" In both sound and lyric
column5: Walker's music became more and more evocative
column6: leaving behind the easy gratification of his earlier albums for broad
column7: cinematic arrangements and stories that end not on punch lines
column8: but question marks.

column1: There are defenders of 1970's 'Til The Band Comes In. I am not one of them
column2: and for what it's worth
column3: neither was Walker. Reportedly puzzled by the fact that his audience wasn't interested in dense songs about hookers and child abuse
column4: he made the humble mistake of trying to will himself back to popularity. It has redeeming moments-- like the eulogistic ""Joe""-- but not many. Its worst songs are embarrassing: In an irony Walker could probably appreciate in time
column5: he'd become one of the gloriously desperate people he'd sung about only a year or two earlier.

column1: For anyone who hasn't heard Scott Walker before
column2: the prospect of buying a five-album box set like The Collection is ridiculous. For fans that already own these albums
column3: it's absurd. The recordings are
column4: of course
column5: ""remastered
column6: which I can discern only in fleeting moments. And unlike the now out-of-print In Five Easy Pieces
column7: whose discs were organized by theme
column8: The Collection goes for a straightforward archival treatment
column9: with a nice selection of period interviews and a beautifully synthesized essay by Rob Young
column10: an editor at British experimental-music magazine The Wire.

column1: It is ultimately yet another example of a record company attempting to re-brand material still available to consumers. Walker is a cult artist
column2: more obscure than he ever was in the late 1960s but also more intensely beloved. You can almost hear the saliva of marketing teams hitting conference-room desks at the prospect of issuing 180-gram gatefold vinyl. Still
column3: there are worse artists to focus the effort on. In a 2008 interview with the Guardian
column4: Walker blamed some of his ugly output in the 1970s on label pressures to ""stay in the game""-- a convenient story coming from an artist
column5: but if there's any truth to it
column6:
The Collection is a simple but elegant way of repaying some of the debt.

"|18088.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18088-scott-walker-scott-walker-the-collection-1967-1970/|8.7|Mike Powell

column1: This is the Scott Walker of the late 1960s: As passionately invested in covers of Tony Bennett and Frank Sinatra hits as in singing the word ""gonorrhea""; voted ""Mr. Valentine"" by Disc & Music Echo the same year he released a song about a young man routinely raped by military officers. His best performances convey the deep tragedy of their subjects while managing to laugh at them with a cruelty and indifference available to only the most total of douchebags.

The essential contrast in his late-60s albums is between easy-listening music and forbiddingly difficult subject matter. It's a dichotomy that has always made Walker seem more like an outsider artist than a mainstream one. It's also fodder for a case that Walker was ""subversive
column2: an accolade for alternative-music fans who

column5: exposing the innocent people of Britain to material that would make their middle-class spines shiver. This isn't untrue. column1: Walker's own songs are more ambiguous. From Scott 2
column2: ""The Amorous Humphrey Plugg"" tells the story of a deflated husband who finds his peace of mind wandering thorugh the red-light district at night. ""Leave it all behind me
column3: he sings
column4: sailing away on a tide of violins. ""Screaming kids on my knee and the telly swallowing me/ And the neighbors shouting next door/ And the subway trembling the rollerskate floor."" Like good satire
column5: Jacques Brel's songs cue you to laugh then startle you with reality. Walker puts you in the uncomfortable position of wondering whether to laugh in the first place
column6: or to just lean back and allow these characters a glory that eludes them in their own lives.

column1: Then there are songs like the simple
column2: country-influenced ""Duchess""
column3: from Scott 4. The same singer who rejected psychedelia started writing the kind of impressionistic lyrics whose nonsense is more penetrating than anything more literal could be. ""It's your shiftless flesh and your old-girl's grace
column4: he sighs. ""It's your young girl's face that I'm breathing."" In both sound and lyric
column5: Walker's music became more and more evocative
column6: leaving behind the easy gratification of his earlier albums for broad
column7: cinematic arrangements and stories that end not on punch lines
column8: but question marks.

column1: There are defenders of 1970's 'Til The Band Comes In. I am not one of them
column2: and for what it's worth
column3: neither was Walker. Reportedly puzzled by the fact that his audience wasn't interested in dense songs about hookers and child abuse
column4: he made the humble mistake of trying to will himself back to popularity. It has redeeming moments-- like the eulogistic ""Joe""-- but not many. Its worst songs are embarrassing: In an irony Walker could probably appreciate in time
column5: he'd become one of the gloriously desperate people he'd sung about only a year or two earlier.

column1: For anyone who hasn't heard Scott Walker before
column2: the prospect of buying a five-album box set like The Collection is ridiculous. For fans that already own these albums
column3: it's absurd. The recordings are
column4: of course
column5: ""remastered
column6: which I can discern only in fleeting moments. And unlike the now out-of-print In Five Easy Pieces
column7: whose discs were organized by theme
column8: The Collection goes for a straightforward archival treatment
column9: with a nice selection of period interviews and a beautifully synthesized essay by Rob Young
column10: an editor at British experimental-music magazine The Wire.

column1: It is ultimately yet another example of a record company attempting to re-brand material still available to consumers. Walker is a cult artist
column2: more obscure than he ever was in the late 1960s but also more intensely beloved. You can almost hear the saliva of marketing teams hitting conference-room desks at the prospect of issuing 180-gram gatefold vinyl. Still
column3: there are worse artists to focus the effort on. In a 2008 interview with the Guardian
column4: Walker blamed some of his ugly output in the 1970s on label pressures to ""stay in the game""-- a convenient story coming from an artist
column5: but if there's any truth to it
column6:
The Collection is a simple but elegant way of repaying some of the debt.

"|18088.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18088-scott-walker-scott-walker-the-collection-1967-1970/|6.2|Mike Powell

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19369/homepage_large.9cd0de58.jpg|American Love|31418.0|Bad Rabbits|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-06-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:31.557957|"

Boston area funk mob Bad Rabbits seemed to arrive with their 2009 EP Stick Up Kids
column2: a pop smart bomb that rearranged the big beat heft of new jack swing and Morris Day style funk into plush
column3: full-band R&B. That record rocketed the band into a series of unlikely tours with everyone from rap legend Slick Rick-- who once enlisted them as his backing band-- to the punk and metal upstarts on the Vans Warped Tour. Bad Rabbits’ audience steadily grew
column4: but their repertoire of songs remained puzzlingly static. In 2011
column5: with no new release in sight
column6: they launched a quick stopgap cover series: a lumbering
column7: crunchy rendition of Michael Jackson’s “Human Nature”
column8: a taut
column9: synth-heavy trek through Smashing Pumpkins’ “1979” and straight reads of songs by The-Dream and Deftones. The cover series might’ve aimed for homage
column10: but it also revealed a startling versatility. Bad Rabbits were bigger than the freewheeling funk revivalism of Stick Up Kids let on.

column1: Bad Rabbits have finally released a full length in American Love
column2: which was produced by Bay area instrumental hip-hop whiz B. Lewis. (They’re also said to be putting the finishing touches on another project with the help of new jack swing forbear Teddy Riley and Deftones leader Chino Moreno.) American Love finds the band eager to show off the moves they’ve learned since Stick Up Kids. Singer Dua Boakye twists limber vocal melodies into meaty harmonies throughout
column3: especially on “Dirty”
column4: where a chorus of backing vocals flank his pleading lead with flatly sung scales approximating Gregorian chant. “Doin’ It” and “Dance Moves” find the rest of the band dallying with Latin music behind him
column5: the former pitting samba rhythms against funk ones and the latter pairing a freestyle-informed bass riff with salsa horns that comes off like a modern day Miami Sound Machine. “We Can Roll” and “Sayonara” both skate in on crunchy
column6: psychedelic breakdowns
column7: a musculature of rhythm that might be attributable to drummer Sheel Davé
column8: who also plays in the Massachusetts math metal band Irepress. It’s a power that makes methodical rock numbers like “Fall in Love” oddly heavy one minute and gives “Sayonara” a buoyant swing the next.

column1: The band’s newfound musical breadth meets a perfect shaman in B. Lewis
column2: whose own cosmic boom bap favors a dense maximalism not unlike Flying Lotus at full tilt. Lewis’ ace sonic architecture leaves American Love brimming with interlocking instrumental tracks and vocal melodies neatly stacked in unexpected corners. Every guitar lick and squiggly synth figure is given fair breathing room
column3: and underheard hooks and submerged melodies constantly reveal themselves on repeat listens. It makes the band’s earlier work seem lean and maybe even claustrophobic by comparison. There’s also the sense that some of the album’s hazier passages
column4: like the intro of opener “We Can Roll”
column5: which teases a spartan rock workout out of a spectral
column6: ambient mist
column7: and the burbling synth underpinning of “Get Up and Go”
column8: might be the result of Lewis’ influence. While American Love finds both band and producer working with an expanded sonic palette
column9: the fundamental mechanics of Bad Rabbits’ songwriting still remain relatively unchanged.

column1: Bad Rabbits still espouse a sex-positive randiness that puts them in the direct lineage of lustful R&B maestros like Bobby Brown
column2: and Dua’s lyrics explore the same axis between new love and unfettered lust. Bad Rabbits’ greatest trick is still the way the music genuflects to bygone forms of R&B music without getting too mired in period-specific production quirks and hero worship that might date the music. The growth spurt between Stick Up Kids and American Love resembles the moment in the mid-90s where another soul band
column3: Raphael Saadiq’s Tony! Toni! Toné!
column4: cashed out on their new jack swing contemporaries and set a course for the music of their parents
column5: a direction that ended up inadvertently kicking off the neo-soul movement. Bad Rabbits have a few kinks to work out still
column6: but with a crack band
column7: a nimble vocalist
column8: and the tutelage of Teddy Riley
column9:
they’re certainly headed in the right direction.

"|18181.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18181-bad-rabbits-american-love/|7.5|Craig Jenkins

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19304/homepage_large.db986eab.jpg|Long Enough to Leave|28513.0|The Mantles|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland']|2013-06-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:32.262040|"

“This isn't me
column2: ” sings Michael Olivares. “This is happening to someone else.” That line comes in the middle of the Mantles’ second full-length album
column3: Long Enough to Leave
column4: but the sense of detachment resonates throughout the record. It’s right there in the title
column5: taken from another lyric: “You’re home/ Long enough to leave/ Always coming back to see / How far off you’ve gone.” The feeling of absence is constant-- everyone in these songs seems to disappear.

column1: That effect gives Long Enough to Leave an intriguing tension
column2: because musically it’s nowhere near distant or detached. It’s an open
column3: outward-looking set of tunes
column4: especially compared to the Mantles’ previous full-length
column5: their 2009 self-titled debut. That record had a hermetic feel that was a big part of its charm. The blurry chords and closeted sound-- a kind of rawer
column6: denser take on the Byrds and their Paisley Underground descendents the Dream Syndicate and the Rain Parade-- were a lot of fun to get lost in.

column1: Here
column2: by contrast
column3: we get a wider variety of melodies
column4: an airier sonic space
column5: and a broader array of reference points. The familiar ones persist: opener “Marbled Birds” starts with a wiry hook that sounds exactly like marbled Byrds. But the acoustic-heavy title track evokes the melancholy pop of the Clean’s David Kilgour; the jangly “Don’t Cross Town” and winding “More That I Pay” approximate lo-fi R.E.M.; and the wistful chords of “Raspberry Thighs” conjure Real Estate’s sun-baked lilt. None of these tunes are clones; all are distinguished by Olivares’ deceptively-rough singing and the interplay of swirling guitars. But together all the echoes-- I’m also hearing the Kinks
column6: Television
column7: and the Feelies-- show the Mantles have expanded their palette.

column1: The result is catchy
column2: consistent material that’s welcoming sonically but mysterious thematically. Take “Hello”
column3: a bouncy jam which is ostensibly pretty communicative; it’s about making a phone call
column4: after all. But eventually you realize the caller-- who wants someone to “help me get out of here... help me disappear”-- never quite gets through. Even better is the enthralling “Reason’s Run”
column5: whose coiled hooks become barbed wire when paired with distancing admonishments like
column6: “When you saw me ahead
column7: you should’ve crossed the street… you must be more careful about who you meet.""

column1: All this poetic exploration of distance and disconnect can also just be seen as cake-icing. The Mantles could mumble through these tunes and the infectious force of their woven melodies would remain intact. But the extra thematic layer gives the music a depth that bodes well for this band’s future (and justifies their rate of output
column2: which is glacial compared to their super-prolific garage peers in San Francisco). Because they take their time
column3: what exactly that future holds is
column4: like the best parts of Long Enough to Leave
column5:
compellingly elusive.

"|18115.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18115-the-mantles-long-enough-to-leave/|7.5|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19343/homepage_large.510ca2a8.jpg|The Dusted Sessions|31290.0|Date Palms|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2013-06-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:32.760271|"

The vast desert of the southwestern U.S. has been an inspiration for musicians in all sorts of traditions. Increasingly it creeps into metal and psych
column2: with late period Earth being a particularly strong example of rock that incorporates Western-style melodies and languid strokes meant to evoke the expanse. There’s something exotic but familiar about it
column3: a beguiling quality that Oakland
column4: CA's Date Palms nail to a tee. Riding a foundation of doom metal
column5: psych rock
column6: and mournful country
column7: the group (now a quintet) led by Gregg Kowalsky and Marielle Jakobsons builds soundscapes with keyboards
column8: mournful slide guitar
column9: sitar
column10: flute and a powerful electric bass. Their second album
column11: The Dusted Sessions
column12: ties together modern explorations of the Wild West with more traditional forms
column13: infused with Americana but not giving into its clichés.

column1: What separates Date Palms from troves of drifting psych rock bands is their distinct sense of composition. These aren’t lengthy jams but painstakingly considered pieces that ebb and flow. The Dusted Sessions centers around a suite inspired by the Yuba River in California
column2: once central to the Gold Rush and home to a vast Native American tribe that was all but wiped out. There’s a careful reverence to the three-part “Yuba Source”
column3: with its central melody that winds wide like the broad curves of the river itself. As the quintet work their way through the track
column4: they’re propped up by monstrous basslines that provide important momentum without ruffling feathers
column5: and a constant sitar that shimmers like a pool of clear fresh water.

column1: The teasing melody of “Yuba Source”-- a simple three note blues phrase-- appears throughout the record
column2: on “Yuba”'s second part and reprise. The group repeat these ideas like mantras
column3: gently echoing so that an idea passes through each instrument as if it were being purified. Jakobsons’ violin
column4: which emerges as the star of the record
column5: takes these melodies and unwinds them out into long
column6: soft strokes while the slide guitar dovetails gracefully beneath.

column1: Each track is defined by a different instrument
column2: however. As tight of a unit as they are
column3: Date Palms are also pretty versatile. On “Dusted Down”
column4: a searing electric guitar rises above the dusty tumult
column5: and on “Exodus Due West” Jakobsons’ reverbed flute haunts the landscape. Kowalsky’s keyboards play an almost equally important role
column6: especially in creating a wall-of-sound effect
column7: as on centerpiece “Night Riding the Skyland”. Especially breathtaking on the latter
column8: the viola merges with the synth before it’s all broken up by the thrust of Noah Philips’ electric guitar
column9: diving head-first into a blues jam that recalls early-70s Pink Floyd and other psychedelic cornerstones.

column1: That they can do all this on a single album is a testament to Date Palms’ ability and control as an ensemble. Even with 11-minute tracks
column2: there’s not a moment that feels wasted; with so many different sounds and ideas invoked over The Dusted Sessions’ 44 minutes
column3: there’s a clear idea at work even if it’s hard to quantify exactly what it is
column4: which is where their brilliance lies. If the idea of Wild West-style slabs of desert rock doesn’t appeal to you
column5: Kowalsky and Jakobsons will pull you in with their teasing melodies and weeping instruments anyway
column6:
their sound rough and immense like a sandpaper sky. On The Dusted Sessions they both deconstruct and reinforce the tenets of Americana and make something transcendent in the process. 

"|18158.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18158-date-palms-the-dusted-sessions/|7.9|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19371/homepage_large.a82d272e.jpg|With Love|22489.0|Zomby|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2013-06-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:33.199455|"

Zomby burst onto the scene in 2008 with a series of inventive singles and a mixtape/album that sampled Gucci Mane and Aaliyah into earworm rave. He seemed at the time capable of expanding the borders of bass music
column2: a maverick in a scene where progress is still regarded as hugely important. Things haven't quite turned out that way. As peers like Burial
column3: Rustie
column4: and Pearson Sound have added their styles to an impressive history of U.K. electronic music (referred to as the ""hardcore continuum"" by journalist Simon Reynolds) Zomby has retreated into the canon
column5: dragging up the bits-- grime's arcane melodic sense
column6: U.K. Garage's shifty rhythms
column7: dubstep's disorientation-- that best promote a perverse
column8: personal history. Put more simply
column9: Zomby likes to play progressive
column10: but he's a synthesist at heart.

column1: Never has this been more apparent than on Zomby's third album (and second for 4AD)
column2: With Love. A two-disc set of short
column3: nimble tracks loosely divided by attitude (""tough"" on disc one
column4: ""contemplative"" on disc two)
column5: With Love is an abundance
column6: an unabashed display of affection for that continuum. The execution is still very much Zomby: With Love veers sharply from rhythmic duress to stoned calm. For an immersion experience
column7: it's reckless and inattentive.

column1: Complicating matters
column2: the album offers few signposts. Zomby still works with vocals
column3: but they're less intrusive than on past albums. Even the requisite 90s R&B sample-- this from Brandy & Monica's 1998 hit
column4: ""The Boy Is Mine""-- is played with more subtlety than in the past. On ""The Things You Do"" and ""If I Will""
column5: mangled vocal snippets are masterfully woven into the track's tapestry. There's no Panda Bear collaboration or Gucci Mane remix to peg
column6: and the result is a long
column7: even run of tracks that allows Zomby to hide beautiful
column8: idiosyncratic moments in his thickets of rhythm. ""Isis""' gentle
column9: walking bassline and ""I Saw Golden Light""'s brassy malevolence pass quickly and without pretense
column10: offering their wares and then bowing to the next track.

column1: Zomby continues to show no interest in fleshing out his ideas
column2: but there's a pleasing efficiency to the way With Love's tracks move in and out of melodic phrases. His particular combination of dulcet synth tones and creeping leads tattoo these tracks
column3: and his sense of rhythm stirs those ideas into hypnotic vignettes. With Love is less expansive than Zomby's early work; he's traded invention for the opportunity to explore every nook and cranny of his humid rhythm mazes. Like simple puzzles
column4: the process and order of With Love transfix long after novelty has worn off.

column1: Just as Where Were U in '92 played like a more vibrant and modern version of early 90s rave and hardcore
column2: With Love offers a necessary sonic update on its inspirations. Drum & bass plays an increased role (Zomby also wonders where you were in 95)
column3: allowing Zomby to run stormy drum attacks like ""It's Time"" full-stop into creeping symphonic pieces. The album snaps on a good system
column4: its depth charge bass anchoring hopscotch leads and tittering hi-hats. Considering that so much of what Zomby draws on was made on cheap computers with limited software
column5: the comparative sonic richness of With Love's music is key. At times the album plays like an extended attempt to upgrade the haphazard majesty of white label grime tracks like DJ XTC's ""Functions on the Low"". Replacing a bleating
column6: synthesized horn with a more harmonically complex tone separates Zomby from his source material
column7: spiritually-- those shitty sounds were part of the appeal-- but also offers a crucial twist. With Love is reverent displacement: U.K. street music re-imagined as luxury.

column1: With Love's short
column2: baroque tracks balance its overall largesse
column3: leaving a purpled
column4: blunted ambience. Zomby's sense of melody and tone is distinct enough that
column5: intentional or not
column6: it feels like motifs and phrases are repeated and expanded upon throughout. Zomby accomplishes this despite his abrasive sequencing
column7: cramming discordant pieces next to one another. With Love is like a pocket book of poetry
column8: a series of short thoughts only tangentially related. Zomby is the elegant menace
column9: capable of beauty and great affect but too stoned or disinterested to fully commit. The tension between Zomby's adoration for his heroes and his aberrant creativity fuels With Love
column10:
less a homage to the past than an intensification of it.

"|18183.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18183-zomby-with-love/|7.9|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19391/homepage_large.0fa2d38f.jpg|Dagger Beach|4452.0|John Vanderslice|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tiny Telephone']|2013-06-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:33.833706|"

As the story goes
column2: John Vanderslice returned home to San Francisco after a lengthy tour supporting 2011’s White Wilderness only for his wife of six years to swiftly announce that she’d be leaving him. He went out into the woods of Northern California and hiked around by himself
column3: all the while pretty much losing his mind. He decided he needed to Do Weird Stuff again musically
column4: which-- with all due respect to his last few albums-- involved getting back to what made him great in the first place
column5: besides the enduring
column6: secretly genius storyteller thing. So he quit his former label
column7: Dead Oceans
column8: because he wanted full control in his endeavor to put himself back together with Dagger Beach
column9: and to write a love letter to his idol with a reinterpretation of David Bowie’s 1974 Orwellian concept album
column10: Diamond Dogs. (Vanderslice funded the project with a Kickstarter campaign that made three times his total funding goal.)

column1: Many of Vanderslice’s most effective songs are clearly fictional
column2: but he commits to them fully. On Dagger Beach
column3: the songs are more clearly personal-- detailing the dissolution of his marriage-- and he executes them with the same specific eye: “In the last known photograph/ Of you and me sprawled on the grass/ You looked off frame/ You were through with this stupid play” (“North Coast Rep”). Unsurprisingly
column4: these songs taste pretty bitter going down
column5: even when they're pretty acoustic numbers like “Song for Dana Lok” and “How the West Was Won”
column6: whose opening riff treads in Fogerty lawsuit territory. “Harlequin Press” is the big exception to this personal vibe
column7: and its clever punchline about a writer who sacrifices personal truth for what the audience wants is a classic of Vanderslice’s fictional storytelling method.

column1: Vanderslice has abandoned the polish of White Wilderness here
column2: though that album’s crucial backing band
column3: Magik*Magik Orchestra
column4: provide woodwind
column5: string
column6: and brass arrangements. Highlight “Song for David Berman”-- an ode to the Silver Jews leader-- leans on strings
column7: inciting a sense of growing eeriness set against a sparse acoustic guitar. It’s one of the only instances on the record where Vanderslice convincingly conveys his pain musically rather than lyrically. It's not a problem of polish vs. lo-fi
column8: but a series of songs rendered so angular that the overall effect feels aimless
column9: an effect that gets old on Dagger Beach. The lack of structure makes these songs feel experimental
column10: but not sufficiently to commit to being out there in a remarkable way.

column1: As far as experimentation goes
column2: Diamond Dogs is a stronger bet. Rather than merely covering the album (which he performed live in full last year)
column3: Vanderslice takes the hits and turns them on their heads
column4: changing lyrics
column5: even titles. “Juvenile Success” (that's “Rebel Rebel”) is a twinkly
column6: soft-spoken affair that feels more like a Belle and Sebastian single than anything Bowie did in his most shamelessly glam moment; the line
column7: “Hot tramp
column8: I love you so” has never sounded so polite. “Would You Possibly Rock and Roll With Me?” (a.k.a. “Rock‘N’Roll With Me”) sounds like a church organist messing around following Sunday services
column9: long after the congregation has filed out. While songs like “We Are the Dead” amplify their original greatness by ramping up the noise
column10: by and large
column11: it’s all sonic effect without much of the attitude and soul that actually drew people to these songs
column12: and the curiosity factor wanes quickly.

column1: For a longtime professional musician who woke up one morning and called off his record deal
column2: Dagger Beach is not as experimental as you'd expect. The Bowie redux
column3: however
column4: is a different story. It seems as though the mere act of bringing new life to one of Bowie’s lesser-canonized albums brought joy to Vanderslice in his difficult days. Even if it's not required listening
column5: if that new lease reflects back on him
column6:
it will have been worth it.

"|18201.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18201-john-vanderslice-dagger-beach-diamond-dogs/|6.2|Jillian Mapes

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19168/homepage_large.7ceea5bc.jpg|Now While it’s Still Warm Let Us Pour in All the Mystery|30320.0|"Oren Ambarchi | Keiji Haino | Jim O'Rourke"|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Black Truffle']|2013-06-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:34.390724|"

At first glance
column2: the collaboration of Keiji Haino
column3: Jim O’Rourke
column4: and Oren Ambarchi looks more like a side-project than a band proper. Their albums are recorded at an annual concert in Tokyo
column5: and billed under the players’ names rather than a group moniker. And their first two
column6: though filled with high-level improvisation
column7: were somewhat amorphous. Lengthy (sometimes half-hour-plus) tracks felt more like one-off experiments-- albeit excellent ones-- than purposeful music.

column1: Things began to shift with 2012’s Imikuzushi
column2: an enthralling set of noise rock journeys that made the trio sound more like an actual band. On their follow-up
column3: Now While it Is Still Warm Let Us Pour in All the Mystery
column4: Haino
column5: O’Rourke
column6: and Ambarchi have landed squarely on the spot they were clearly moving toward. This is now unmistakably a seasoned
column7: fully locked-in experimental rock band-- and
column8: not coincidentally
column9: one of the best around.

column1: The differences emerge both in form and content. For the first time
column2: the trio sticks to shorter pieces-- six in total
column3: with none longer than 11 minutes. And those pieces progress in a distinct arc
column4: one that suggests more craft and forethought than before. Now While it Is Still Warm starts with quieter
column5: more ambient tracks
column6: gradually escalates into louder songs
column7: then ends with a denouement that’s all mood and atmosphere.

column1: More importantly
column2: each track has a distinct shape
column3: often featuring clear beginnings
column4: middles
column5: and ends. Whether with meditative drones
column6: hammering riffs
column7: or heavy rhythms
column8: the trio diligently carves out patterns every step of the way
column9: with at least one eye on where to go and how to get there. This is especially true of three tracks in the middle of the album. Here
column10: Haino churns out guitar pyrotechnics supported by O’Rourke’s bass loops and Ambarchi’s weighty drumming. These are rock jams
column11: though they still retain the group’s essential spontaneity
column12: mostly in Haino’s ability to quickly shift from a memorable riff to an abstract explosion.

column1: Just as compelling are the subdued pieces that bookend Now While it Is Still Warm. Opener “Once Again I Hear the Beautiful Vertigo... Luring Us to 'Do Something
column2: Somehow'” sees Haino moaning hypnotically over the accompaniment of wineglasses (one of which is manned by master minimalist Charlemagne Palestine). Later
column3: Haino’s flute and O’Rourke’s stage-shaking bass create dark lounge-jazz in “Who Would Have Thought This Callous History Would Become My Skin”
column4: and the gentle tension of the closing title track could score an Akira Kurosawa noir thriller like High and Low or The Bad Sleep Well.

column1: Those quieter pieces are so compelling that it’s tempting to hope for a future album made of nothing but. At the same time
column2: it would be fascinating to hear the trio in tight-rock mode for an entire release. That’s the interesting paradox of Now While it Was Still Warm: by honing their music
column3: the trio has actually widened it
column4: showing how much they’re capable of. Haino
column5: O’Rourke
column6: and Ambarchi now sound like a band for whom anything is not just possible
column7:
but probable.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19272/homepage_large.df0ec879.jpg|The Dwell|30427.0|SFV Acid|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['UNO']|2013-06-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:35.059224|"

The original acid house boom produced an abundance of cartoony fare alongside more serious floorfillers. For every euphoric ""Acid Tracks"" there was a nutty ""Activ 8 (Come with Me)""; the sublime ""Voodoo Ray"" could effortlessly segue into the dayglo patchwork of ""Theme from S-Express"". Those larger-than-life acid acts often had an absurd concept attached
column2: or some grandiose scheme in mind. Chris Peat from pop-acid act Altern-8 even stood as a political candidate in the 1992 General Election in Britain
column3: representing his own Hardcore (Altern8-ive) party. Needless to say
column4: he didn’t get far. San Fernando Valley artist Zane Reynolds takes a similarly playful approach to the work he puts out under his SFV Acid alias. On The Dwell
column5: his debut full-length
column6: he's patched together a series of tracks entirely written on equipment set up at his local Starbucks. In 2013
column7: coffee buzz is the new acid rush.

column1: There's a distinction to be made between the conceptual cloaking Reynolds has thrown over this work and the music found inside. Occasionally it's frivolous-- there's a skip in the step to ""PT Sex"" that comes close to pushing it toward novelty status-- but mostly this is a surprisingly inward-looking work. It's reminiscent of the kind of juxtaposition found when encountering the public and creative faces of Richard D. James or Luke Vibert. Outwardly
column2: they're brash
column3: prone to pranks
column4: rarely keeping a straight face. But the music usually has a much deeper value. The Dwell takes a similar tone
column5: working through mournful late night club jams like ""Fresh and Easy"" and ""Dwell on 2"". There's exuberance
column6: too
column7: but even that feels tempered by introspection. ""Mocha"" pulls hard on the feel of Grandmaster Flash's ""The Message""
column8: only to dampen it with a bittersweet whistling keyboard motif.

column1: Reynolds has stated that this material was designed to echo the feel of small town moments
column2: providing a soundtrack to the ""business parks
column3: strip malls
column4: and diner burgers"" he immerses himself in on a regular basis. It adds a loneliness to much of this work
column5: a feeling of someone outside that world looking in. The struggle to connect is key
column6: often throwing up moments of ugliness such as the distorted voice belching through the tinny rhythms of ""Money"". If the original acid movement sought to escape the everyday through a sense of communality
column7: through people with wildly different values coming together under one roof
column8: The Dwell veers in the opposite direction. The coffee shop recording studio positions Reynolds alone amid a small cross-section of society
column9: where he retreats into his own head. It lends a dual sense of inclusion and exclusion
column10: a feeling of being immersed in the world while being utterly removed from it.

column1: That awareness of a creeping sense of isolation while being connected to society en masse isn’t particularly unique
column2: although it is at least intriguing that Reynolds tried to get there via a template that was once all about finding a common bond. He's mostly let down by the execution
column3: which leans too far toward overly familiar 303 acid sounds and house-y keyboard figures. Often the arrangements are too skeletal
column4: or build a little too predictably. Burial did the ""lone raver"" concept a lot more effectively
column5: capturing a sense of seclusion that this record only hints at on occasion. Mostly it feels like Reynolds stirred a few too many colors into the mix
column6: lampooning old acid records
column7: working out of a Starbucks
column8: cooking up the ""small town"" theme
column9: attempting to make something he describes as being ""steeped in blue collar luxury."" The Dwell buckles under the weight of that ambition
column10:
resulting in a work that never really finds a satisfying place of its own to go.

Alexander Spit's A Breathtaking Trip to That Otherside had a lot going for it: a style steeped in modernized psychedelic hip-hop culture
column2: lyrics that deftly mixed the druggy offbeat with the perceptive on-point
column3: and production that made an intriguingly blurry take on a Bay-to-L.A. lineage of influence. The latter stood out the most: While Spit's a good rapper who can catch a ride off mind-altering hedonism and sneak some blacklit profundity into the bargain
column4: his touch with a chopped-up loop is impeccable
column5: sourcing a long bloodline of classic West Coast funk-- g or otherwise-- and putting it to use shining god rays through cloud rap. While his beats have been almost exclusively used in his own work
column6: it's easy to imagine him cranking out enough extra quality work to supply any of the likeminded MCs who parallel that aesthetic. And if for some reason you're not feeling his words
column7: the beats go a long way in justifying them.

column1: Spit's latest beat tape
column2: Mansions 2
column3: is the second in a series of instrumental releases that narrows in on short little flashes of inspiration and strings them along for brief but engrossing moments. And while there's something that feels a little placeholder-ish about it-- his beats don't always feel complete without his liquid Evidence-turned-skate rat voice-- it measures up well in a crowded field filled with Donuts-vibing Cali bedroom beatmakers. If there's a drum loop on a track
column4: best believe it'll get refracted
column5: split
column6: switched up
column7: and scattered in a way that throws it out of joint without knocking it out of its groove. If there's an identifiable canonical sample
column8: it'll be flipped in a way that's restlessly transformative-- slowed to a half-tempo crawl; phased into headswimming oblivion. If there's a vocal drop
column9: it'll mean something more than just a one-liner distraction
column10: as everything from Hustler's Convention's pool-shark verse (""Billiards for Billions"") to a kid's story about a trick-or-treating fatality (""...?"") to a news piece about a $220 million penthouse (""The Sky Is Falling"") builds a sonic travelogue that's like walking through a crumbling Richard Neutra house on a mushroom high.

column1: As journeys go
column2: the scenery changes frequently. One moment
column3: it's all hazy boom-bap tweaks of early 80s R&B for low-lit late-night smokeouts (""Cocaine""; ""Ouija Board Coffee Table""). The next
column4: you might slide into a Southern-inflected cut with 808s that rattle like bill counters under a layer of diamond-shine electric pianos (""Pullover Hoodies""). The impact can gently wash over you with stripped-down codeine strings (""Kubrick Halls"") and jazz-piano minimalism (""Baldwin by the Endless Pool"")
column5: or run up and dummy-smack you until you've got prizefighter snares and Nintendo final-stage basslines rattling through your ears (""Panic Room""). While the mood tends to swing from mellowed-out bliss to mellowed-out dread
column6: there's a dominant sense of unpredictable playfulness that coheres into its own self-contained universe.

column1: Positioning Spit's work against that of his peers isn't the easiest comparative exercise-- it has all the hallmarks of whatever ""psychedelic instrumental hip-hop"" implies without incorporating the heavy-rock vibes of Gaslamp Killer
column2: Madlib's grimy-workshop sludge
column3: or Flying Lotus' art jazz leanings. And while he shares Dilla's affinity for chopped vocal syllables and Tyco Nite-Glow bass
column4:
there are still enough elements from the last five years' worth of post-based airiness and bass-music fusion to duck carbon-copy affectations. It's one of those situations where playing games of spot-the-influence will inevitably end in those influences receding far off into the distance-- an album that sounds less like someone you've heard of than someplace you haven't.

Look at the song title ""I Am a God"" and it seems like easy blasphemy-- Kanye West's update of John Lennon's ""more popular than Jesus"" shocker from 1966. But just as the Beatle's proclamation was fuller and wiser in context-- ""I believe that what people call God is something in all of us
column2: Lennon would later explain-- ""I Am a God"" is not simply the latest self-important blast from one of pop culture's pre-eminent egoists. For starters
column3: the track sounds less triumphant than breathtakingly vexed
column4: crashing in with a gnarled dancehall vocal sample and paranoid sawtooth synths that aim to destroy. Here
column5: Kanye raps about loyalty
column6: respect
column7: threesomes
column8: and
column9: yes
column10: croissants with the urgency of someone being chased by a 30-ton steamroller. The song is pierced by a series of primal screams
column11: pixelated outbursts that are only briefly able to halt the beat's heaving evil. In Kanye's hands
column12: being a god sounds stressful as hell
column13: something we can all relate to
column14: and the song's apparent inspiration is a passage from the book of Psalms: ""I have said
column15: Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High.""

column1: These are the immeasurably lofty stakes Kanye deals in on Yeezus
