column3: but the Chicago native has always been beguiled by the view from above. Take ""Jesus Walks""
column4: where he references another Psalm while gasping from on high: ""I walk through the valley of the Chi where death is/ Top floor
column5: the view alone will leave you breathless."" Then
column6: on ""POWER""
column7: he contemplates leaping out of the penthouse
column8: ""letting everything go."" In a way
column9: Yeezus is the panicked sound of that ensuing free-fall
column10: a rush of angst and despair with absolutely nothing left to lose.

column1: The album is something of a razor-sharpened take on 2008's distressed 808s & Heartbreak and marks a blunt break with the filigreed maximalism Kanye so thoroughly nailed on My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy. In hindsight
column2: the latter record-- with its ingratiating GOOD Fridays buildup
column3: endless guest list
column4: and uncharacteristically apologetic interview sessions-- was his attempt at recapturing a superstar-sized American audience after a slew of entertaining-yet-questionable PR incidents. Except it didn't exactly work: While Twisted Fantasy was universally lauded and went platinum
column5: it still stands as Kanye's worst-selling album to date
column6: failing to produce a top 10 single. But even if it wasn't a chart smash
column7: the intricacy and durability of Twisted Fantasy incubated the Cult of Kanye to an extreme level. ""I’d rather piss a bunch of people off and make myself happy than make everyone else happy and be pissed off inside
column8: he told VIBE around the release of 808s. Yeezus doubles-down on this exclusionary philosophy: ""Soon as they like you
column9: make 'em unlike you/ 'Cause kissing people ass is so unlike you.""

column1: For Kanye
column2: there's purpose in repulsion. And on Yeezus
column3: he trades out smooth soul and anthemic choruses for jarring electro
column4: acid house
column5: and industrial grind while delivering some of his most lewd and heart-crushing tales yet. This is willful provocation that Ice Cube
column6: Madonna
column7: and Trent Reznor could all be proud of. Some of the record has him tackling the same issues he's been rapping about since The College Dropout
column8: albeit with a fire-eyed stare. On his debut's ""Family Business""
column9: he poignantly lamented a jailed cousin's absence at the Thanksgiving dinner table in a manner ""so sweet
column10: like a photo of your granny's picture."" On Yeezus
column11: he's still addressing the plight of incarcerated black men
column12: but now he's incensed. With ""New Slaves""
column13: he confronts us with vulgar stereotypes while exposing the prison-industrial complex for the deeply systemic racist sham that it is.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: XXX creeper ""I'm In It"" sounds like a dancehall orgasm mired in quicksand and makes previous come-ons like ""Slow Jamz"" come off like Disney theme songs. ""The kids and the wife life
column3: but can't wake up from the nightlife
column4: says the new father on that track's knowingly button-pushing final verse. ""I'm so scared of my demons/ I go to sleep with a nightlight."" Kanye told The New York Times he's recently reached a new level of Zen
column5: but this is the opposite of beach-chair music. Perhaps the album's most explicit lines are the blurry fantasies of a confessed porn addict who's described his daughter's mother as a ""superstar all from a home movie."" Without much room for levity
column6: Kanye's complicated and distrustful view of women is unrelenting on Yeezus. And while there's no real excuse for flat oafishness like ""eatin' Asian pussy
column7: all I need was sweet and sour sauce
column8: many of the album's most powerful moments have him broken down
column9: insecure
column10: and bloody
column11: railing against an ineptitude with the opposite sex.

column1: Album pinnacle ""Blood on the Leaves"" tells a nightmarish story of divorce and betrayal
column2: all while samples of Nina Simone's pitched-up ""Strange Fruit"" and TNGHT's demonic ""R U Ready"" horns play yin and yang to the protagonist's alternately sorrowful and furious headspace. ""Hold My Liquor"" and ""Guilt Trip""
column3: meanwhile
column4: find Kanye trying to restate his manhood while his emotions crumble around him; if he's not drunk and swerve-y
column5: trying vainly to reconcile with an ex
column6: he's hoping to brag himself out of being dumped. Caustic humor shows up now and then
column7: buoying certain lines or tracks like ""Send It Up"" and ""Bound 2""
column8: but it's often fleeting. As on ""Runaway""
column9: there's something palpably sad about the men in these songs
column10: which twists them away from misogynistic assertions of power toward feelings that are ultimately more self-destructive. As contemporaries like Jay-Z
column11: Beyoncé
column12: and Justin Timberlake increasingly devote their music to largely winning tales of contentment
column13: Kanye is unwilling or unable to settle for settling down.

column1: This discomfort is essential to his enduring appeal. For instance
column2: instead of working with giant phone companies to guarantee commercial success
column3: a la his big brother
column4: Kanye's now making a point out of rejecting corporate sponsorship. Whether it's a meaningful stance or a blindly contrarian move is up for debate. But after recent tensions between hip-hop and corporate America
column5: visceral and disturbing lines like ""put my fist in her like a civil rights sign"" put Kanye beyond the reach of mainstream brands hoping to siphon his credibility. As he told the Times
column6: he's not disinterested in the idea of big companies or big money-- he compared himself to Steve Jobs
column7: after all-- but he wants control.

column1: The restlessness spreads to his aesthetic and collaborative choices. Rather than relying on known hitmakers to augment his music
column2: Kanye solicited ideas from exciting up-and-comers including Hudson Mohawke
column3: Young Chop
column4: and Arca. And even veteran producers involved in the project
column5: like Rick Rubin and Daft Punk
column6: were seemingly chosen not for their name recognition but their history of rule-breaking. In the mid-1980s
column7: Rubin veered away from the colorful
column8: party-starting tones of early rap music and created bare
column9: hard beats for LL Cool J
column10: Run-D.M.C.
column11: and the Beastie Boys-- a perfect fit for Yeezus' less-is-more snarl. And though Kanye's blaring
column12: digitized assault couldn't be further from Daft Punk's naturalistic
column13: groove-based Random Access Memories
column14: the artists share a basic philosophy. As Daft Punk's Thomas Bangalter recently said of their new record: ""We had the luxury to do things that so many people cannot do
column15: but it doesn't mean that with luxury comes comfort.""

column1: The idea extends to the how Yeezus treats the human voice. Running with the confounding hook from last year's ""Mercy""
column2: dancehall patois is scattered throughout
column3: bringing with it that music's sense of menacing confrontation. And Bon Iver's Justin Vernon shows up on a few tracks
column4: using his voice to give the darkness an angelic tint. Expanding upon the cracked vocal experimentation on Twisted Fantasy's ""Blame Game""
column5: Kanye's own voice is often shadowed by pitched-down ghouls. And though he could've likely chosen any rapper on earth to guest on the riotous ""Send It Up""-- probably the most likely
column6: if not only
column7: chance Yeezus has for a rap-radio hit-- he chose Chicago's relatively unknown King L. His presence
column8: along with that of fellow Chi-town driller Chief Keef
column9: makes the message clear: America may want to ignore these young black men from the gang-strewn South Side
column10: but here
column11: they have a voice.

column1: All of these unlikely choices demonstrate how cohesion and bold intent are at a premium on Yeezus
column2: perhaps more than any other Kanye album. Each fluorescent strike of noise
column3: incongruous tempo flip
column4: and warped vocal is bolted into its right place across the record's fast 40 minutes. The precise approach runs through Yeezus' guerrilla-style promotion
column5: too
column6: which found an army of dark vans lighting projections onto buildings around the world
column7: itself a boots-on-the-ground reaction to today's InstaTweet brand of music dissemination. I went to one of these impromptu happenings last Saturday night
column8: in the middle of Manhattan. At 1:20 a.m.
column9: the words ""NOT FOR SALE"" lit up on the south side of the Louis Vuitton building. A few guys ran across the street with Christmas-morning glee
column10: snapping photos. Then
column11: Kanye's starkly-lit visage appeared to recite ""New Slaves""'s anti-consumerist lines as cabs streaked by the luxury stores below. His was the only black face to be seen across the jumbo ads lining an eerily desolate 5th Ave. The van soon closed its doors and drove away; the culture bomb’s flash was over in an instant
column12:
but the reverberations were just starting to spread.

Back in April
column2: Madlib let slip some info of a test pressing for the forthcoming Quasimoto album Yessir Whatever on his Instagram and Facebook with no further comment. Bloggers and fans went nuts: as prolific as Madlib's traditionally been
column3: the last true Quasimoto album The Further Adventures of Lord Quas was released eight years ago
column4: and something about that pranksterish mushroom-fueled split-personality vibe was still in high demand. Once it became clear that Yessir Whatever was actually going to be a compilation of rare and unreleased Quasimoto material and early experiments
column5: anticipation simmered down a bit
column6: but hey
column7: old Quas is better than no Quas
column8: right?

column1: Right. That said
column2: Yessir Whatever isn't an odds-and-ends consolation prize-- it's an interesting cross-section of Madlib's personal archives
column3: and its scattershot nature is more a stylistic matter than a quality-control issue. The 12 songs on the album were written and recorded over a span of about a dozen years
column4: going back at least as far as being concurrent with the earliest Lootpack releases (at least if the 1997 lyrical datestamp on “Brothers Can't See Me” is any indication). And even the earliest material here has that certain imprint that made the Quasimoto records so offbeat: mood-whiplash sequencing
column5: tape-deck-quality fidelity with Jeep-quality beats
column6: and rhymes that sound like a down-for-whatever stoner verbally sparring with the cartoon devil on his shoulder.

column1: That familiar pitched-up voice starts the record on 2004's thousand-copy single “Broad Factor”
column2: which opens with a declaration that “I know you're tired of dumb shit” and then goes on for a couple of verses about how good he is at getting his bone on. This isn't Madlib at his most esoteric: the beat's sourced from Johnny “Guitar” Watson's endlessly sampled “Superman Lover""
column3: and even if the sex rhymes are fiendishly true to his alter-ego's altered id
column4: they're also more slick than outrageous. Not to knock it
column5: of course; Madlib's nearly as raw in classicist mode as he is when he lets his psychedelic/jazzbo inclinations take over. But the more off-the-path work he did in the early-mid 2000s has a strength that stretches far past pretty-good indie rap into the stuff that cults are made of
column6: and it's that prime material from assorted limited-edition 7” releases and EPs that'll be the draw here.

column1: “Seasons Change” was axed from Further Adventures when a Roy Ayers sample didn't clear in time
column2: and what could've been the best cut on that album was relegated to the B-side of a “Bullysh!t” 7” released on the one-off label Lord Inamel's Wax in 2005. It's brought back here in full
column3: a smooth-fusion lost classic that trades on a good vibes/bad vibes dichotomy and includes one of the better self-descriptions of the Madlib aesthetic going (“Top choice
column4: low rate
column5: no gate
column6: high voice/ It's like we dipped the beat in water now we up on moist”). “The Front” and “Youngblood” were the respective A and B-sides of a 2005 Stones Throw Fan Club 45
column7: and they fill the bill by emphasizing Madlib's own voice muttering restrained stress raps coolly through smooth jazz gone warped from repeated exposure to foundation-rattling low end. And going back a few years to 2002's Astronaut EP unearths a title track that
column8: true to Quasimoto tradition
column9: riffs off some Melvin Van Peebles Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death gems and careens disorientingly between three different voices-- Madlib
column10: Quas and the sampled Van Peebles-- to jarringly conversational effect. There's also one of the best-spit lines you'll ever hear from Madlib's voice
column11: pitched-up or otherwise; the way he rattles off “wouldn't be no more angel to me... anyway” is a surprising salvo of acrobatic flow from a helium voice that usually sounds casually flippant.

column1: A good part of this collection trades a bit on the mythology of those seldom-heard early Quasimoto experiments of the late 90s
column2: when it was just stuff Madlib kept between himself and a few friends who were privy to his beat tapes. And while there's nothing revelatory production-wise if you've heard Lootpack's Soundpieces: Da Antidote
column3: there's a little workshopper's insight in these protoypes for The Unseen-caliber bluntedness. They're a bit more focused (and less attention-grabbing) than ensuing years' choppy
column4: non-sequitur-filled Quasimoto joints
column5: rolling off a sound that aims to synthesize East Coast boom-bap into something a bit more sun-baked. The sleepy guitar loop on “Planned Attack” and the squeaky synthesizer whistle on “Brothers Can't See Me” are
column6: along with his nothing-fancy scratching
column7: the only things really brought in to accompany the breaks. But the drums are heavy enough and smartly assembled to the point that Madlib's foundation was clearly already pretty strong. And even if the spare
column8: downbeat early draft of “Green Power” here doesn't measure up to the intricate
column9: layered bop-bounce of the Unseen version
column10: it still doesn't sound like much that was going on back in the late '90s-- and it was actually enough to start building one of the most voracious cult fanbases in hip-hop
column11: so here we are. This isn't the new Quas album people might've hoped for
column12: but as someone who values the obscure and underheard in other peoples' work
column13: it's good to know Madlib has the same context
column14: respect
column15: and enthusiasm for his own vaults
column16:
too.

column6: though

column8: urgent
column9:
and far more substantive.

After his band Ponytail broke up

column1: The two

column4: like tiny hedgehogs being raked with plastic combs. Over the song's last two minutes
column5: Wong plays tight
column6: pinched little solos high up on the neck
column7: surrounding these little pinging noises with sighing washes of synth. His sound is pearly and fragile
column8: evoking a Renaissance harpsichord more than anything with electricity coursing through it

column3: her voice acts as the titular breeze sighing through Wong's fingerpicking. She often sticks to ""oooh"" and ""la la la
column4: or ""doot-doo
column5: picking out hummingbird melodies that complement Wong's. On ""New Circle Has Begun""
column6: she weaves a charming needlepoint around Wong's guitar

column8: and despite being as lovingly confected as a wedding cake
column9: feels casual
column10: like it was abstractedly hummed into existence. It's a low-stakes affair in the best sense; Wong and Minekawa seem to have made this album as simply as little kids invent a story together. For Wong
column11: it's a way to remind us of his still-developing voice and talent; for Minekawa
column12:
it's a wonderfully low-key way to ease back into the world of music-making after a long hiatus.

column4: destructive Decepticon. From there on out

column3: the release of Emika's self-titled debut album was well-timed. By 2011
column4: dubstep's ascent to global notoriety was well underway: the U.S. was feeling the first ripples of Skrillex fever
column5: while the U.K. had already seen chart success from Katy B and Magnetic Man. By this point Anglo-Czech singer-producer Ema Jolly had been engaged with the genre for some time
column6: having discovered it while living in Bristol as a teenager. Her music showed it: In contrast to the pyrotechnics of mainstream dubstep
column7: hers was a poppier take on the style that drew on the stringent
column8: sub-heavy minimalism of early DMZ for inspiration.

column1: There was more to Jolly's music than dubstep
column2: though. After her spell in Bristol she moved to Berlin
column3: and fell in love with techno. She quickly became embedded in the scene centering around the legendary Berghain club and its label
column4: Ostgut Ton; in 2010
column5: field recordings she had taken in the club formed the basis for the label's landmark Fünf compilation. Jolly's debut album unified these influences-- the yawning negative space of dubstep
column6: Berlin techno's dank hypnotism
column7: and the intricate sound design she had learned at university and put into practice working for Native Instruments-- in the service of a downcast
column8: nocturnal brand of pop. Jolly's sepulchral vocal was a central presence but not an imposing one
column9: preferring to lurk in the shadows cast by her brooding synthetic arrangements.

column1: Come 2013
column2: dubstep has well and truly jumped the shark
column3: and it no longer seems like a useful lens through which to scrutinize Emika's music. Sure
column4: Dva
column5: her second album
column6: tips its fair share of nods to the dance forms that inspired her-- ""Sleep With My Enemies"" sports the razor-edged bass and 140bpm rhythmic chassis of dubstep
column7: and ""Mouth to Mouth""
column8: one of the record's highlights
column9: draws on techno's slow-burn dynamics. But Jolly's vocal is more prominent than ever
column10: and for the most part song-form takes precedent over dancefloor structures. Dva is better viewed simply as an underground pop record-- and as pop records go
column11: it makes a pretty bold entrance. Opening track ""Hush (Interlude)"" sets the electronics to one side
column12: enlisting classical soprano Michaela Šrůmová and a 28-piece string orchestra. The result-- a decent enough pastiche of lachrymal European romanticism-- suggests that Jolly's ambitions have reached grandiose new heights.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: that impression is short-lived. From there
column3: Dva becomes naggingly familiar: jagged
column4: sub-heavy bass lines and metallic percussion give way to slightly plasticky synths and unadventurous drum work
column5: suggesting that Jolly has toned down the sonic experimentation found on her debut
column6: perhaps by way of foregrounding her songs' pop potential. It represents only a mild progression from the themes and sonics of Emika
column7: and while there are occasional hooky pop moments to equal that album's finest
column8: those songs rarely stray beyond the limits set by their predecessors. ""Filters""
column9: with its louche shuffle
column10: and the aqueous piano-led balladry of ""Primary Colours"" leap out. But otherwise
column11: Jolly's limited sonic toolbox and obsession with dirgy minor-key tonalities soon begin to wear dangerously thin.

column1: All of this could be forgiven
column2: perhaps
column3: if Jolly herself was a commanding vocal presence. Unfortunately that's not the case: pushed further into the foreground
column4: the awkwardness and flat melisma of her feather-light delivery become painfully apparent. It's difficult to think of a more apt example of how Jolly fails to inhabit the grandiose architecture she has constructed for herself than on ""Dem Worlds"". Here the string orchestra returns
column5: but Jolly's vocal is dwarfed by its towering
column6: full-bodied chords
column7: her contribution sounding more like an extraneous doodle than the product of the ""rebel diva"" she has claimed to be. In Dva
column8: Emika may be aspiring to a larger scale of pop
column9:
but for the most part this only serves to amplify her flaws.

column2: horns

column5: the effect is more intimidating than the parts on Hidden where they smashed melons to simulate crushing a skull. The spareness and sense of space on Field of Reeds is remarkable

column7: sometimes vicious sense of anxiety; ""There is something there

We still don't know his name
column2: but Gold Panda has made it easy for us to know him. The British producer's debut
column3: 2010's Lucky Shiner
column4: was an emotive tapestry of personal history
column5: with textures that evoked imagery with a distinct personal glow. On his second album and first substantial release in three years
column6: Half of Where You Live
column7: Gold Panda shifts the focus from who he is to where he's been.

column1: This shift makes sense. The success he's enjoyed has sent him far from the suburban Essex enclave he once called home. Lucky Shiner cuts like ""India Lately"" and ""Same Dream China"" swirled the culturally distinctive sounds of plucked strings and tangled sitar detritus into their respective mixes. 2009's Miyamae EP took its name from a ward of the Japanese city of Kawasaki; its bookended cuts were named
column2: respectively
column3: ""Back Home"" and ""Long Vacation"". Clearly
column4: the act of leaving is far more intriguing to him than returning.

column1: A quick scan of Half of Where You Live's tracklist uncovers more name-checked locales-- Brazil
column2: Hong Kong
column3: the Japanese island of Enoshima
column4: the British town of Flinton-- but above all else
column5: Gold Panda's current residence of Berlin looms large. Whereas Lucky Shiner had a bright
column6: nostalgic glow
column7: Half of Where You Live is distinctly darker and
column8: at points
column9: clubbier than its predecessor. The glimmering synths and hazy
column10: chiming techno featured on James Holden's Border Community label are reference points here
column11: alongside shimmering vignettes that call back to the pretty-sounding IDM that German imprint Morr Music was known for in the early 2000s.

column1: Half of Where You Live doesn't mark the first time Gold Panda's flirted with more distinctly dancey fare
column2: but it's he's never been this successful with it. For all its winsome elegance
column3: there were moments on Lucky Shiner that
column4: for better or worse
column5: sounded truly handmade to the point that you could practically hear Gold Panda's fingers mashing hia Akai MPC. The MPC is still present here-- the gurgling ""S950"" takes its name from a specific model of the sampling equipment-- but these tracks sound smoother and more refined
column6: a logical progression from the staticky amniotic techno that made up this year's brief stopgap EP
column7: Trust.

column1: Gold Panda's long been someone who works very well in miniature form; his talent for pushing repetition to the brink of its greatest
column2: most pleasurable effect is documented by the attention-grabbing success of early singles ""Quitter's Raga"" and ""You"". But his ability to expand his vision to fit longer forms is his secret weapon. The nearly psychedelic sprawl of ""India Lately"" already suggested as much
column3: and on Half of Where You Live
column4: Gold Panda delivers his most potent side-stretcher in the form of ""Brazil"". The six-minute track is the closest thing this album comes to in terms of anthems
column5: as a hollow bassline and a male voice repeating the titular city's name build the backbone. A mess of chimes come crashing in
column6: the beat drops
column7: and then picks up again with a tangy
column8: winding synth line that makes for a seismic
column9: satisfying addition.

column1: ""Brazil"" is Half of Where You Live's big highlight
column2: and the subtlety of its charms extend to the record as a whole. The winsome
column3: direct melodies that marked Lucky Shiner's high points are largely absent here
column4: which may cause some to consider the album a slight disappointment. That's understandable
column5: but ultimately the success of Half of Where You Live lies not in Gold Panda repeating old tricks
column6: but in how he's expanded his repertoire to include new sounds
column7:
and his aesthetic proves sturdy enough to accomdate them.

column5: Louisville

column2: Rusty

Drummer Kevin Coultas played in Come and later joined O'Neill in the Sonora Pine. Mueller and Noble eventually got back together in the Shipping News. These movements felt natural
column7: connected.

column3: for instance

column3: and his work as Coma Cinema strongly evokes a sense of the place. While he never references specific geography

column6: detail
column7: or a sense of stakes in the matter. A line like ""cut myself at work"" implies a blue-collar gig where physical injury is a risk
column8: but ""She Keeps it Alive"" leaves too much to the imagination; the same goes for the evocatively titled ""Lee (Columbine High Harmony)""
column9: where Cothran admits
column10: ""My wrists somehow forgot/ That quiet parking lot
column11: and just lets it hang.

column1: The most striking parts of Posthumous Release recall the inventiveness of 2011's Blue Suicide
column2: an album where you sensed a prolific artist straining against limitations of both budget and production know-how. “Satan Made a Mansion” shows Cothran’s knack for snappy alt-rock hooks while the wigged-out flange effects of “Burn a Church” exaggerate the vocal manipulation of “Her Sinking Sun”
column3: thus far his strongest tune. Otherwise
column4: the limitations of Posthumous Release are set into the foundation of its songs
column5: many built upon two chords or revolving around a single
column6: repeated line rather than a chorus. At best
column7: they recall the throwback solo performances that would cut through the orchestral clutter on later Elliott Smith albums
column8: though more often
column9: there’s a perfunctory
column10: boxed-in compositional method that’s more in line with mid-period eels.

column1: Posthumous Release doesn't lack ambition. Rather
column2: it demonstrates the unique challenges inherent in making small music translate to an audience beyond the people immediately surrounding the ones who made it. If Cothran wanted to signify his ambition with bigger drums
column3: string arrangements
column4: or tremulous vocals
column5: I imagine he would have done so. But when you look at the prime examples of small music done right-- Death Cab for Cutie’s We Have The Facts and We’re Voting Yes
column6: Real Estate’s Days and Waxahatchee’s Cerulean Salt-- there’s a generosity within the lyrics and the hooks
column7: a desire to share an experience rather than simply relate it. Cothran’s songs feel both insular and remote
column8: staring off into the distance
column9:
clearly miserable but unwilling to really talk about it.

"|18120.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18120-coma-cinema-posthumous-release/|6.1|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19357/homepage_large.9259004c.jpg|The Wack Album|27233.0|The Lonely Island|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Universal Republic']|2013-06-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:47.632125|"

Since leaving “Saturday Night Live” in 2012
column2: it might appear that things aren't going as planned for the Lonely Island
column3: the New York-by-way-of-California comedy troupe consisting of Andy Samberg
column4: Jorma Taccone
column5: and Akiva Schaffer. Samberg’s jump into full-time movie making hasn’t quite stuck
column6: leading to one film he’s hoping that everyone will forget about and one that seemed like a minor hit at first but turned out to be somewhat lifeless. Schaffer’s turn in the director’s chair for a pair of features-- 2007’s criminally underrated Hot Rod and 2012’s underwhelming The Watch-- suggest he’s not quite ready for the upper tier in that role. Taccone is better known for his “Girls” character than for his own modern cult classic MacGruber
column7: though he’s certainly making a bundle as director for those ubiquitous “It’s Not Complicated” commercials for AT&T. (Taccone technically left his job at “Saturday Night Live” before Schaffer and Samberg but continued to collaborate on Digital Shorts.) In a certain light
column8: another Lonely Island album might seem like a desperate attempt to reinvigorate a fanbase that might have lost interest in the collective’s breed of joyfully silly farce.

column1: Luckily The Wack Album is just as good as their previous collections
column2: 2009’s Incredibad and 2011’s Turtleneck & Chain. Knowing that the tracks would likely be divorced from memorable
column3: NBC-funded visual complements this time around (a song like Incredibad’s “Natalie's Rap” surely got the benefit of the doubt by merit of having a deviant Natalie Portman trashing shit in the “SNL” counterpart)
column4: it feels like the Lonely Island puts a little more oomph into the songs themselves
column5: a little more intelligence into their parodies of overused rap album staples. (The operatic
column6: hilarious leadoff “Dramatic Intro” and the ridiculous “I’m a Hustler (Song?)” are genre sendups as effective as any they’ve ever done
column7: which includes the sublime “Jack Sparrow”.) Sure
column8: a few jokes fall flat
column9: and a few run out of steam really fast-- the song where Andy raps from the perspective of Michael Bloomberg (“I Run NY”)
column10: two separate songs where they swap out “fuck” for “honk” and “hug”
column11: respectively (“Hugs”
column12: “I Don’t Give a Honk”)-- but that’s typical of a Lonely Island or
column13: for that matter
column14: a Weird Al record.

column1: Lonely Island’s jokes
column2: for the most part
column3: invent a ridiculous world and push the silliness to extremes
column4: stretching the same idea in different directions (“YOLO”) or continuing their mastery of sending up bro culture (“We Are a Crowd”
column5: “The Compliments”). Sometimes the song might hint at a deeper meaning or stance; for instance
column6: in a recent Pitchfork interview
column7: the group framed “Spring Break Anthem” as their statement about gay marriage. Others
column8: like “You’ve Got the Look” or the posse introduction riff “Meet the Crew”
column9: are just straight up goofy fun. Andy
column10: adopting rappers’ penchant for spelling words out to fit a rhyme pattern
column11: strings together 69 seconds of rapid-fire alphabet for a lewd roundup of how his life is going. Kiv brags about “Diaper Money”
column12: having enough cashflow to keep his kids in fresh diapers
column13: brags that escalate into “wife pussy”
column14: and Andy’s ownership of a choice grave plot. All three playfully spin-off hashtag rap with the Solange feature “Semicolon”.

column1: I like to think that the group’s output is spiritually influenced by something like Tamra Davis’ Billy Madison-- basically a sea of Tim Herlihy and Adam Sandlers’ inside jokes that you might not get
column2: but a welcoming storm of inanity that you can’t help but enjoy. But what makes the The Wack Album work is the wide range of musical styles the group plants themselves in
column3: from dubstep to “golden era” throwback rap
column4: to auto-tuned R&B to Samberg and Timberlake’s still-potent Color Me Badd riff “3-Way (The Golden Rule)”. The Wack Album is full of smart hat-tips that underscore the fun
column5: allusions to Digital Underground that flex the trio’s rap-loving roots.

column1: The Wack Album’s guests-- a murderer’s row of collaborators featuring the likes of Robyn
column2: Pharrell Williams
column3: Kendrick Lamar
column4: Solange
column5: Hugh Jackman
column6: Lady Gaga
column7: Adam Levine
column8: and more-- all seem to enjoy being there
column9: an aspect that makes the jokes stronger. Though the group works largely without their former ace-in-the whole
column10: Asa Taccone (Jorma’s younger brother
column11: who ably handled the production of the first two Lonely Island albums but has been focusing on his own music lately) The Wack Album's crew of rotating producers deliver a fresh sound palette that punches up the jokes and allows the Lonely Island to do what they do best-- try and make each other laugh. It’s silly
column12: it’s in no shape or form subtle
column13: it’s fun
column14: it works. From “Lazy Sunday” to The Wack Album's closing “Perfect Saturday”
column15:
you could argue that the group has hardly missed.

"|18169.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18169-the-lonely-island-the-wack-album/|7.1|Corban Goble

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19312/homepage_large.c145062e.jpg|Pythons|28248.0|Surfer Blood|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2013-06-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:48.275026|"

""Apologies
column2: meet apologies
column3: Surfer Blood's John Paul Pitts sings on ""Demon Dance""
column4: the lead-off track from his band's second LP
column5: Pythons. Pitts spends most of Pythons pleading
column6: bargaining
column7: rationalizing
column8: trying to make some sense of an increasingly dire situation in any way he can. There's a longstanding tendency in pop music to read too much autobiography into lyrics. In Pythons' case
column9: this kind of conflation's all but unavoidable; just before it was recorded
column10: an altercation with his then-girlfriend lead to Pitts' arrest for domestic battery. Ultimately
column11: no charges were filed
column12: but as Pitts told Pitchfork
column13: that same tumultuous relationship inspired many of Pythons' lyrics. Even before you hear one note
column14: you may feel conflicted about it
column15: and rightfully so. Truth be told
column16: Pythons seem to feel pretty conflicted about itself: hooky
column17: Weezer-ish guitar pop offset by desperate
column18: discomfiting lyrics
column19: fleeting hopes of reconciliation quickly dashed by heavy-hearted resignation.

column1: Produced by Gil Norton (Doolittle
column2: Del Amitri)
column3: Pythons is a sleeker affair than 2010's bedroom-born Astro Coast and 2011's knotty Tarot Classics EP. With 10 lean songs in 32 minutes
column4: there's hardly a second to waste
column5: so Pythons largely dispenses with pageantry and heads straight for the stomp box. Instrumentally
column6: Surfer Blood's reared-on-Pavement looseness proves hard to shake even on these no-nonsense melodies; guitars dive-bomb into choruses
column7: hooks turn into group shout-alongs. This more focused approach occasionally causes slight tunnelvision
column8: songs that seem to rise and fall in essentially the same fashion. There are exceptions
column9: of course: ""I Was Wrong"" dips a toe into grunge
column10: and the waltzy ""Needles & Pins"" harkens back to the Everly Brothers. But there's a satisfying simplicity in all those clean lines and bright-as-can-be hooks
column11: a gleaming surface to bury the dark stuff under.

column1: Pythons' musical confidence is not shared by its narrator. Pitts spends the record sounding one kind of despondent after another: he points fingers
column2: apologizes profusely
column3: hopes something will change
column4: realizes it won't. He sounds stuck in place
column5: his mind constantly reeling
column6: his next move unclear. Pitts certainly seems sorry for something; ""Gravity"" sees him making apologies for ""never stopping when we oughta
column7: a line that both absorbs and assigns some of the blame for the shambolic romance described throughout. Pitts is quick to paint himself in an unflattering light: codependent
column8: unstable
column9: at fault. ""Blair Witch"" finds Pitts pleading
column10: ""I need love
column11: but the more I see love
column12: the more I need love
column13: an unguarded statement that suggests Pitts is at least aware he's got some stuff to work on. ""If I fell apart
column14: would you stay?"" he asks at one point
column15: aware of the awfulness of the situation but still willing to keep going with it
column16: consequences be damned.

column1: It doesn't always work; ""Say Yes to Me"" and ""Blair Witch"" affix themselves to a couple of phrases-- ""true blue"" and ""sour grapes""
column2: respectively-- they can't quite rescue from cliche. Whenever the music gets heavier-- the verses of ""I Was Wrong""
column3: bits of ""Slow Six""-- the lyrical self-flagellation and the muddy guitars congeal into a thick
column4: momentum-halting sludge. The songwriting's fairly sturdy overall
column5: but highlights are a little hard to come by; lead single ""Weird Shapes."" comes close
column6: but there's really nothing here that'll knock the wind out of you quite like Astro Coast's ""Swim"". Pitts proves adept at conjuring the confusion and conflict of the last days of a troubled relationship
column7: and-- probably wisely-- makes himself seem fairly unsympathetic in the process. But he's not always so great at fleshing out the person on the other end of the line
column8: which leaves Pythons feeling trapped in Pitts' head
column9: a spot where plenty of listeners won't want to spend much time.

column1: When I heard about John Paul Pitts' arrest last summer
column2: my first response
column3: like that of many others
column4: was a swift and decisive
column5: ""Fuck you."" Even as more information has come to light
column6: my feelings haven't changed much; Pitts maintains his innocence
column7: and plea-and-pass might be enough for the Florida courts where forgiveness is concerned
column8: but without hearing the other side of the story
column9: I'm still not so sure. Pythons
column10: seething with autobiography
column11: doesn't make it easy to forget the circumstances around its creation
column12: and separating the art from the artists here takes some serious doing; that score at the top of the page is for Pythons
column13: not the people who made it. With Pythons out there
column14: Pitts is going to have to get up there again and again and sing these songs
column15: so full of hurt and confusion
column16: penitence and longing. We'll never know completely what happened that night
column17: but I sincerely hope Pitts never lets himself forget it. As long as he's out there singing ""I Was Wrong""
column18:
he probably never will.

"|18123.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18123-surfer-blood-pythons/|6.7|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19354/homepage_large.336fd16e.jpg|The Incomplete Triangle|2588.0|Lansing-Dreiden|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Mexican Summer']|2013-06-13 00:00:00|2003|2016-06-11 16:56:48.828028|"

When Lansing-Dreiden first rose to indie-world notoriety in 2004
column2: few people would have guessed the group was offering a prescient example of how pop music would come to function nearly a decade later. Fewer would have suggested that this was a good thing.

column1: From the start the Miami-born
column2: New York-based group seemed more interested in provoking their audience than turning them into a traditional fan base. Its members were steadfastly anonymous
column3: they never played live
column4: and they only did press via emails that were either blithely pretentious or explicitly designed to be read as such. Their work extended over several forms of media
column5: including a literary journal called Death Notice
column6: and they insisted on referring to the entire project not as a band or a collective but as a “company
column7: ” which provoked as much suspicion in the indie scene of the time as their frequent use of drum machines.

column1: In the years since
column2: anonymity has gone from a quirk to a fad to an established PR tactic and artists have become increasingly expected to treat their visuals and internet presence as seriously as their music. That
column3: and ambition-- whether aesthetic or careerist-- has ceased to be anathema to the counterculture. The most polarizing act of the mid-aughts would barely raise an eyebrow in 2013.

column1: The intensely conceptual aspects of Lansing-Dreiden’s mission attracted more attention than the music itself
column2: and they’ve come to make up the greater part of the “company”’s legacy. But revisiting the two albums and one EP that were originally released through Kemado
column3: and have now been reissued on vinyl via Mexican Summer-- with new
column4: tastefully minimalist cover art-- it’s apparent that they were ahead of the game on that level as well.

column1: Their debut LP
column2: The Incomplete Triangle
column3: is the most straightforward of the three
column4: in that some of the songs follow simple
column5: conventional pop structures. For all of its potentially off-putting highbrow affectations
column6: L-D was unabashedly influenced by the Beach Boys’ ornate
column7: gently psychedelic spin on standard pop tropes
column8: and by Nuggets-era garage bands that bashed their way through well-worn blues formulas. Their first album opens with the “boom boom-boom crack” that’s been borrowed from the Ronettes’ “Be My Baby” several million times
column9: and offers a substantial amount of harmonized vocals and jangly guitars doused in lo-fi overdrive and reverb. Which basically describes the sound their new label was founded on
column10: and has come to define a large chunk of the underground rock that’s been made since then.

column1: “Straightforward” is a relative term here
column2: though. Even from the start
column3: the group enjoyed surprising listeners with abrupt shifts in tone and style. The manic Turtles impression of “An Uncut Diamond” leads directly into the double-time palm-muted electric guitar that lends the postrock-inflected “Advancing Flags” an unexpectedly metal edge. And after a dozen pop songs the album closes with a suite of five ambient electronic tracks
column4: an over-the-top flourish seemingly designed to goad critics into calling them “pretentious.”

column1: Its follow-up
column2: an EP titled A Sectioned Beam
column3: offers less of a challenge. “Locks in Shadows” and “Spectrum of Vapor” are Pet Sounds-y and about as audience-friendly as L-D gets. “A Sectioned Beam” evokes both new wave and the Madchester sound
column4: which at the time struck some critics as outre but after years of chillwave acts doing a similar thing it seems strange to think of as out of the ordinary. If it wasn’t for the 15-minute closing track or the fact that the record was intended as the soundtrack to a video the group made-- described on this site as “stark
column5: picturesque scenes of plant life digitally mirrored to a vaguely hypnotic
column6: kaleidoscopic effect”-- it would hardly even seem artsy these days.

column1: The most fascinating and currently relevant music L-D wrote is on their 2006 LP
column2: The Dividing Island. The impression that the earlier records gave that the group was bent on replicating the contents of an expansive and tastefully curated record collection becomes even stronger here. Their retro pop sensibilities are infused with the sounds and rhythms of slick 80s radio pop
column3: or melt down into krautrock instrumental interludes. Their interest in beats is pushed up front
column4: and expresses itself in homages to an eclectic range of sounds from the agit-disco that the waning dance punk scene had brought back in style to ungainly electro-funk that has remained resolutely unfashionable since the early 80s. Its closing track
column5: “Dethroning the Optimyth”
column6: is a power metal epic topped with psychedelically droning vocals and twinkling New Age chimes
column7: a combination possibly intended to piss off whatever fraction of their audience was left who hadn’t already been offended by the genre miscegenation that preceded it.

column1: The scale of their stylistic boundary blurring could be seen as a refutation of pop’s taxonomical tendencies
column2: the need to name different sounds and thereby divide them
column3: an urge that was exceptionally strong amongst the indie rockers Lansing-Dreiden was playing to. And in the past seven years it’s gone from the fringiest of ideas to one of pop’s guiding notions. Crossing genre lines used to be seen as artistically suspect
column4: and brought into question the authenticity of the musician crossing them. Now pop radio is dominated by dubstep songs by country artists
column5: country songs with rappers on them
column6: and other combinations that would have seemed freakish a decade ago. Kanye West
column7: arguably the most influential pop artist in the world
column8: is a “rapper” who dabbles in industrial music
column9: prog rock
column10: and singer-songwriter balladeering
column11: not to mention multimedia projects like films and fashion lines. Lansing-Dreiden may have been borrowing sounds from the past
column12:
but the way they borrowed them and what they did with them seems to have perfectly predicted the future.

If it wasn’t for the 15-minute closing track or the fact that the record was intended as the soundtrack to a video the group made-- described on this site as “stark
column5: picturesque scenes of plant life digitally mirrored to a vaguely hypnotic
column6: kaleidoscopic effect”-- it would hardly even seem artsy these days.

column1: The most fascinating and currently relevant music L-D wrote is on their 2006 LP
column2: The Dividing Island. The impression that the earlier records gave that the group was bent on replicating the contents of an expansive and tastefully curated record collection becomes even stronger here. Their retro pop sensibilities are infused with the sounds and rhythms of slick 80s radio pop
column3: or melt down into krautrock instrumental interludes. Their interest in beats is pushed up front
column4: and expresses itself in homages to an eclectic range of sounds from the agit-disco that the waning dance punk scene had brought back in style to ungainly electro-funk that has remained resolutely unfashionable since the early 80s. Its closing track
column5: “Dethroning the Optimyth”
column6: is a power metal epic topped with psychedelically droning vocals and twinkling New Age chimes
column7: a combination possibly intended to piss off whatever fraction of their audience was left who hadn’t already been offended by the genre miscegenation that preceded it.

column1: The scale of their stylistic boundary blurring could be seen as a refutation of pop’s taxonomical tendencies
column2: the need to name different sounds and thereby divide them
column3: an urge that was exceptionally strong amongst the indie rockers Lansing-Dreiden was playing to. And in the past seven years it’s gone from the fringiest of ideas to one of pop’s guiding notions. Crossing genre lines used to be seen as artistically suspect
column4: and brought into question the authenticity of the musician crossing them. Now pop radio is dominated by dubstep songs by country artists
column5: country songs with rappers on them
column6: and other combinations that would have seemed freakish a decade ago. Kanye West
column7: arguably the most influential pop artist in the world
column8: is a “rapper” who dabbles in industrial music
column9: prog rock
column10: and singer-songwriter balladeering
column11: not to mention multimedia projects like films and fashion lines. Lansing-Dreiden may have been borrowing sounds from the past
column12:
but the way they borrowed them and what they did with them seems to have perfectly predicted the future.

"|18167.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18167-lansing-dreiden-the-incomplete-triangle-a-sectioned-beam-the-dividing-island/|8.5|Miles Raymer

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19311/homepage_large.5832a936.jpg|Perfect View|30758.0|Lust for Youth|['Experimental'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-06-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:49.472241|"

This is what Hannes Norrvide does as Lust for Youth: He sets up two simple melody lines on his Casio keyboard. He lets them ram ceaselessly into each other like abandoned go-karts. And then
column3: over a muted thump of a drum machine
column4: he hollers into the void. That's his entire M.O.
column5: and on paper it sounds about as appetizing as sucking stale air from an open freezer. But Norrvide makes surprisingly tactile
column6: even sensual music this way
column7: and on Perfect View
column8: his second full length in only six months
column9: he rides his own modestly cresting wave. He is still making the exact same sound
column10: and it remains narrowly captivating in the exact same way.

column1: The production on Perfect View is marginally cleaner and warmer than last fall's Growing Seeds
column2: making it a lusher and prettier listen. But these are relative terms-- “unnerving” and “lonely” probably suit Lust for Youth better. Growing Seeds’ particular unnerving loneliness came not just from its sonic murk but from the traces of unease the murk failed to cover
column3: and Perfect View
column4: with its richer
column5: mellower synths and deeper sound
column6: brings Norrvide closer into focus. But his thick Swedish accent
column7: muffled by reverb
column8: still keeps us at an arms-length from his message: When he repeatedly chants the title of “I Found Love”
column9: it sounds more like
column10: “I’ve fallen off.”

column1: Norrvide has insisted in interviews that his songs are about love
column2: relationships
column3: and morality. They probably are
column4: but you'll find very little in this music to tell you so. What you'll hear
column5: above all
column6: is a firm belief in the comfort of synthesizers-- the wide
column7: lonely bands of sound they make
column8: the cottony feeling they leave in your mind. The song titles function like blank
column9: terse placards-- ""Another Day""
column10: ""End""
column11: ""Image""-- and the hum of the music acts similarly
column12: as a mild anaesthetic
column13: a small tonic for the times you'd rather erase your feelings for a few minutes than think about them.

column1: Sifting through Perfect View to find highlightable moments proves surprisingly difficult: there's the nearly-funky bongo break on “Another Day”
column2: the little bits of sampled speech that pop up on ""Barcelona"" and elsewhere; “Kirsten” and closer “I Found Love in a Different Place” turn the drum hits way up
column3: and hint at what Lust for Youth might eventually sound like if Norrvide cleared his throat and demanded our undivided attention. But these details melt the minute you stop focusing on them
column4: and I think Norrvide means them to. Listening normally
column5: the songs blur together like fan blades
column6: and it's hard to tell how long you've been listening to Perfect View. His is the ambient music of someone else's party
column7: happening far away from where you are
column8:
and the distance is part of the allure.

"|18122.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18122-lust-for-youth-perfect-view/|6.9|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19284/homepage_large.2f073046.jpg|Desperation|31293.0|Oblivians|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2013-06-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:49.576902|"

For the band's followers
column2: the announcement of a new Oblivians album in 2013 was a big deal. Their last proper full-length
column3: which came out 16 years ago
column4: featured a punk rock band at the height of their power. The Memphis trio made music that was legitimately funny and provocative
column5: and they made it sound dangerous. Between 1995 and 1997
column6: they packed in blown out guitars and snarling
column7: guttural vocals
column8: all of which could have been filtered through a rusted out tin can. Their songs were fast and loud
column9: and when they made their last proper record in 1997 with New Orleans weirdo composer Mr. Quintron
column10: they sounded like the MC5 being backed by an organist. They weren't around for very long
column11: but in their relatively short time together
column12: they cemented themselves as godfathers to today's garage punk landscape.

column1: Since then
column2: all three members of the band have kept pretty busy. Jack Yarber made some solo albums under the name Jack Oblivian
column3: most recently on 2011's solid LP Rat City. Greg Cartwright became the frontman of Reigning Sound. Eric Friedl founded Goner Records. So with some solid achievements under each of their belts
column4: they're back with a reunion album that
column5: in the context of other band reunions
column6: arrives at an ideal time. They've been away for a while
column7: sure
column8: but not long enough to make Desperation remotely analogous to the new Iggy and the Stooges record. (To say nothing of the music from Ready to Die
column9: Oblivians don't have multiple decades seperating their new work and their best work.)

column1: But there's something that needs to be considered when approaching Desperation: This is not the same Oblivians from 1995's Soul Food. This isn't a scrappy
column2: lo-fi punk band brazenly giving songs titles like ""Then I Fucked Her"" or ""Nigger Rich"". (In fact
column3: they've pretty much sworn off writing ""the nihilistic rock anthem"" following the deaths of some close friends
column4: including Jay Reatard. Cartwright has said
column5: ""I don't want a record full of swear words. I don't want to offend people."") The influences sound similar
column6: but Desperation sounds slicker than ever. Their singing is stripped of its former bite
column7: and while they still ramp up the fuzz
column8: it's a much cleaner-sounding album made at Dan Auerbach's Nashville studio. And as a whole
column9: it's very inconsistent. There are songs that quickly reveal themselves as unfortunately repetitive (""Pinball King""
column10: ""Fire Detector"") and others where the melody and tone just aren't that interesting over 2.5 minutes of music (""Oblivion""). Probably the biggest indication that they're no longer the same band: The songs written by Cartwright (like ""EM"" and ""Desperation"") sound more like a fuzzed out Reigning Sound
column11: whose melodies tap more into 1960s pop than archival Oblivians did.

column1: That's not to insult Reigning Sound
column2: a band with great records-- those just aren't the sorts of songs you're conditioned to hear on an Oblivians record. So predictably
column3: the strongest moments on Desperation come when the trio tap into the strengths from their old albums. ""Loving Cup"" is a ripping cover of the Paul Butterfield Blues Band track (in the tradition of their blistering 1995 cover of Lightnin' Hopkins' ""Vietnam War Blues""). ""Call the Police"" once again features Quintron's organ in a solid interpretation of Stephanie McDee's R&B/zydeco track. Two of Yarber's writing contributions are huge highlights: the punk burner ""Run For Cover"" and the doe-eyed ballad ""Little War Child"". But with this album going in so many directions
column4: the inevitable duds
column5: which flank the highlights
column6: make it hard to get excited about it as a whole.

column1: In a recent interview
column2: Friedl joked
column3: ""People will hate [Desperation] when it comes out and in 30 years
column4: when it doesn’t matter anymore
column5: kids will think it’s really great."" Maybe this was Friedl's admission that the Oblivians grew up and inevitably made an album that didn't sound anything like their early work. Maybe he's saying that this album needs to be given its own context and removed from the pressures that come along with being the first Oblivians album in nearly two decades. And that's fair-- history and high expectations can irrevocably mar the way you take in a band's post-reunion album. But down the line
column6: the kids will probably still have access to Soul Food
column7: Popular Favorites
column8: and Play 9 Songs With Mr. Quintron. Ultimately
column9:
those albums are more immediately gratifying and fun than this one.

"|18095.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18095-the-oblivians-desperation/|6.2|Evan Minsker

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19299/homepage_large.2c1c3162.jpg|Soft Will|28000.0|Smith Westerns|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mom & Pop']|2013-06-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:50.211029|"

Like so many child stars before them
column2: Smith Westerns seemed to be headed toward an early burnout. Brothers Cullen and Cameron Omori and their friend Max Kakacek laid down the sandpaper bubblegum of their 2009 self-titled debut when they were still in high school; by the time of 2011’s Dye it Blonde
column3: they were gleefully glomming onto the grandiosity of their classic-rock heroes
column4: in the musical and “extracurricular” senses. Seeing Smith Westerns on the Dye it Blonde tour was like (I imagine) witnessing Faster Pussycat on the Sunset Strip in the late 1980s-- the music was very loud
column5: the band appeared to be a little partied out
column6: and the vibe of youthful decadence verged on self-destructive. As good as the first two Smith Westerns albums were
column7: I questioned whether they could forge a career-- or even make it to the next gig. They were living out their college years in a rock‘n’roll band
column8: a more eye-opening education in some ways
column9: though it doesn’t exactly prepare you for adulthood.

column1: On Smith Westerns’ latest
column2: <i>Soft Will
column3: the band still sounds like a bunch of cocky kids with a preternatural understanding of 1970s glam-rock aesthetics and the physics of power pop songcraft. But the swagger has been tempered along with the tempos; a preference for stately balladry over snotty stompers steers Soft Will away from Electric Warrior and into All Things Must Pass territory.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Soft Will is like the undergraduate version of Vampire Weekend’s recent post-doctoral dissertation on mortality
column3: Modern Vampires of the City-- VW’s cautious “Diane Young” could be an answer record to Dye it Blonde’s celebratory “All Die Young”. Omori is just getting to the point where he can finally see outside of himself
column4: and understand that the world is a big
column5: scary
column6: unknowable place that you might not have licked after all. “I thought I was a loner until I went out on my own
column7: ” he sings on Will’s beatific closing track “Varsity”
column8: as bell-like synths echo back to one of the all-time great “you’re all alone now
column9: bub
column10: ” classics
column11: Naked Eyes’ “Always Something There to Remind Me”. Soft Will culminates with a graduation of sorts-- Smith Westerns have survived their adolescence as a band
column12: learned the right lessons
column13: and (gasp) seem to have grown up.

column1: While the band’s outlook has matured
column2: what hasn’t changed on Soft Will is Smith Westerns’ ability to turn out instantly likeable guitar and synth-based hooks at a prodigious rate. “3am Spiritual” opens Will with a callback to Dye it Blonde
column3: as a simple six-string strum and lilting keyboard figure give way to a heart-tugging “Whoa! Yeah!” chorus. It’s a songwriting trick learned from poring over records that were born around the time the band members were-- Bandwagonesque and I Should Coco and (definitely) Definitely Maybe. Smith Westerns aren’t interested in changing up their formula
column4: they’ve merely found a way to utilize it more thoughtfully.

column1: Just as Dye it Blonde sounded like Smith Westerns with better (or any) production and more sophisticated songwriting
column2: Soft Will elaborates on Dye it Blonde by sharpening the choruses-- the “tell me tell me tell me the answer 'cuz I’m not sure” bit from “Idol” is particularly sticky-- and refining the arrangements. On the instrumental “XXIII”
column3: Soft Will even approaches the elegance of Air’s score for Sofia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides
column4: evoking a similar end-of-childhood dread with its cinematic mix of doomy piano chords and spectral string swooshes. Smith Westerns have given their own coming-of-age an appropriately majestic soundtrack. (The guitar riff on ""Best Friend"" is like a cross between CC Deville's guitar solo from Poison’s “Something to Believe In” and Clarence Clemons’ sax solo from Springsteen’s “Jungleland”.)

column1: In the context of Smith Westerns’ discography
column2: Soft Will is both a fresh start and a conclusion to the first part of the band’s career. In case it needs be pointed out: Smith Westerns have already built an impressive battery of records. Few groups do wistfully melodic trad-rock any better right now. Smith Westerns haven’t only not burned out
column3:
they’re a budding institution.

"|18110.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18110-the-smith-westerns-soft-will/|7.9|Steven Hyden

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19278/homepage_large.96f37d2a.jpg|Avalanche|28590.0|Quadron|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Epic']|2013-06-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:50.895579|"

Quadron are a musician’s band. The Danish duo count Prince
column2: Kendrick Lamar
column3: and Pharrell amongst their many famous fans. It’s not hard to see their appeal: Airtight and carefully virtuosic
column4: they’re perfectly wrapped up in their own hermetically sealed pop world. The attraction largely boils down to singer Coco O’s elastic voice
column5: sometimes chirpy and sometimes soulful. She works in the tradition of the last decade’s neo-soul elite
column6: channeling the jazzy effortlessness of Amy Winehouse circa Frank and the vulnerability of also-ran Duffy
column7: shapeshifting between extremes mid-song. Avalanche is the duo’s second album
column8: and the one that’s poised to earn them wider attention off the back of simple and effective songcraft.

column1: Coco’s partner is Robin Hannibal
column2: also the mastermind behind buzzed-about R&B act Rhye. Avalanche is dominated by his touch
column3: an oh-so-perfect production hand that brings to mind the fastidious fuss of Fleetwood Mac minus the shag carpet thud. This all-consuming perfection is at once Quadron’s most alienating and tantalizing quality-- no alarms and no surprises-- set out in clear tones from the very beginning with “LFT”. Cautious horns
column4: careful guitar
column5: and flamboyant strings offer an impossibly polished surface for Coco’s vocals to glide over
column6: singing a melody that’s just twisty enough not to challenge the listener. “Yes I’m still looking/ Looking for trouble
column7: ” she intones defiantly
column8: as if trying to prove her own edginess in a world of perfectly rounded corners.

column1: The duo have deservedly received plenty of pre-release attention for Avalanche’s first single “Hey Love”. With its throbbing hand percussion and Timbaland-worthy vocal snippets
column2: it has all the precociousness of one of those folky ditties that soundtracked iPod commercials at their ubiquitous peak in the mid 2000s. It’s bolstered with an earworm of a chorus
column3: but it’s a bit of a fake-out: Avalanche prefers intimate ballads over perky pop
column4: offering nothing else as jaunty as “Hey Love”. That’s not a bad thing in itself
column5: but the songs feel a little insincere when saddled with the band’s generic lyrics.

column1: The way Coco borrows mannerisms from country
column2: 60s pop
column3: and other recognizable signifiers brings to mind Camera Obscura stripped of their excess and showmanship. But her lyrics lack that band's depth and detail
column4: meaning her vocal tics have to pick up the slack. On songs like “Crush”
column5: she’s front and centre
column6: exploring every corner of her voice
column7: and moving from raspy and snarky to hurt and forlorn at the flip of a coin. These slower tracks are a catch 22
column8: however
column9: because when she doesn’t have a stellar melody to orient her
column10: like on “Befriend”
column11: it feels like she’s merely stringing together cliches. Other attempts at more upbeat pop (“Neverland”
column12: “It’s Gonna Get You”) are anodyne and patently inoffensive
column13: music made to be quietly piped through coffee shop speakers.

column1: But when they’re on
column2: they’re on. Avalanche ends with a stretch of soft-rock stunners
column3: including the heartfelt title track and the slide guitar daydream of “Sea Salt”. “Better Off”
column4: with its summer afternoon swing and gentle ebb
column5: is arguably the album’s best song-- here Coco’s vocals sound expert and controlled
column6: topped off with an appearance from a sedate Kendrick Lamar. He’s neutered and hushed to fit into their own cultivated world
column7: because above all
column8: Quadron inhabit a very specific universe on Avalanche
column9: one where no note or sound is out of place. If schlocky FM-lite pop is what you’re into
column10: there’s lots to like on Avalanche
column11: but it’s an album that feels hard to love. Avalanche’s obsessive squeaky cleanness keeps its audience at a distance. Coco might insist that she’s still looking for trouble
column12:
but there’s none to be found on Avalanche.

"|18089.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18089-quadron-avalanche/|7.0|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19352/homepage_large.15e62d03.jpg|The Jellyfish Mentality|31414.0|The Jet Age of Tomorrow|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Odd Future']|2013-06-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:51.372841|"

The various artists that make up Odd Future
column2: can
column3: in some ways
column4: be thought of as child stars. They found success and relative fame early
column5: with ferocious records that jump-started the conversation about rap and reignited much of the controversy that lent the genre its vitality. And
column6: thus far
column7: like many who succeed early
column8: they haven't been able to recapture the energy of that first terrific surge.

column1: But there are plenty of ways to distinguish OF from the stereotype of the child star
column2: obvious in the posse’s DIY aesthetic
column3: their self-reliance
column4: and their instinctive drive towards musical exploration. You could see those qualities in Tyler's summer mixes as DJ Stank Daddy
column5: in the interesting failure of the Internet’s Purple Naked Ladies
column6: and in the psychedelic leanings of Domo Genesis’ No Idols
column7: and Hodgy Beats’ Untitled EP. And you can see those qualities at their best on the collective’s newest effort
column8: The Jellyfish Mentality.

column1: The album is officially the work of the Jet Age of Tomorrow
column2: the production duo that consists of Matt Martians and Hal Williams. Martians is also one half of the Internet
column3: and the main producer behind Kilo Kish. His consistent interest in exploring the worlds of funk and acid jazz keeps the collective expanding their borders. The real reason that Odd Future’s music-- rather than rhetoric-- still deserves attention lies in the way that they consistently stoke their melting pot with the next logical set of musical influences.

column1: The Jellyfish Mentality expands on the Soular Groove template that Martians has worked with in the past
column2: adding a hard psychedelic edge to his standard combination of claphappy beats and acid-jazz synth fills. The initial run of tracks here is mesmerizing
column3: extending from the opener “Warping Walls” to the chorus and beat of the transfixing “Juney Jones”. Unfortunately
column4: it’s then that the rappers show up.

column1: The downside of the DIY aesthetic is that it can mean a lack of discipline; a fixation on getting things done often means getting them done quickly. That’s clear on the album’s verses. Mike G does his lackadaisical
column2: post-lyrical thing; Casey Veggies and Earl
column3: two of the most talented rappers here
column4: restrain themselves with one-take verses (Casey bests Earl
column5: which should tell you that something’s off). Mac Miller shows up to piss off the critics. Other than a few hard-charging late verses from Williams on “Squares” and Domo Genesis and Vince Staples on “Wonderful World”
column6: no one sounds like they’re trying too much harder than the jejune Kish.

column1: In contrast
column2: the choruses throughout the record are plenty catchy
column3: a testament to the pocket that Martians and Williams have created in each and every beat. The hook on the aforementioned “Juney Jones” is an earworm
column4: likewise those of “Not So Scary” and the barely-there mutter on “Superfine”
column5: where a simple twist of pronunciation keeps the phrase “you are superfine” in your head for hours after listening. In fact
column6: there’s only one bum hook in the bunch
column7: courtesy of Jesse Boykins III.

column1: There’s a sense of anything-goes exploration that keeps Jellyfish interesting
column2: even as it stretches out over 21 tracks (and 25 if you count the bonus songs that were already released). Not many young producers have this kind of imagination or panache
column3: and the tape abounds with daring
column4: idiosyncratic choices
column5:
creating a psychedelic alternative to the alt-world pop that N.E.R.D. introduced with In Search Of... The downside of succeeding early is the risk of burning out. But the curiosity and work ethic that the Jet Age of Tomorrow show here proves continually impressive.

"|18166.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18166-the-jet-age-of-tomorrow-the-jellyfish-mentality/|6.6|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19273/homepage_large.056222b5.jpg|The Eldritch Dark|31324.0|Blood Ceremony|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rise Above']|2013-06-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:51.865279|"

As Aldous Huxley once wrote
column2: ""The charm of history and its enigmatic lesson consist in the fact that
column3: from age to age
column4: nothing changes and yet everything is completely different."" Though our dystopian visionary surely meant to slyly reference far more sinister puppet masters with his damning and oh-so-quotable bon mot
column5: the unruly hellions pulling rock’n’roll’s nylon strings are less inclined to read between the lines. They prefer to go back to basics but slap a few fresh coats of paint on there to keep things sparkling. The song remains the same
column6: and on The Eldritch Dark
column7: Blood Ceremony follows that axiom with near-religious fervor.

column1: Every chord and whisper harkens back to an earlier Aquarian age
column2: when paisley and peyote ruled supreme and leather fringe wasn’t just for your dad’s musty old biker jacket. Their longtime fixation on 70s rock
column3: Sabbathian riffage
column4: and 60s psych is well-documented and undeniable
column5: and an enduring fascination with dark legend and wild lore charts their pagan’s progress from harvest moon to Midsummer’s night eve. The third album from this Canadian collective is their strongest yet
column6: and clear proof that while yes
column7: everything old is new again
column8: there are a scant few armed with the passion and power to craft something worth revisiting. Blood Ceremony just make it look easy.

column1: “Witchwood” begins with a howling lead and hauls out the Hammond organ
column2: vamping and swaying along beneath Alia O’Brien’s husky croon. This down-to-earth high priestess has got her hands full wielding the microphone
column3: manipulating the vintage organ keys
column4: and trilling away like Jethro Tull with her signature flute whilst conducting the band’s blackest of masses. The Satanic element one has come to expect from the recent glut of “occult rock” bands is absent
column5: and in its stead lie mysteries far more titillating and obscure. The old gods hold court amongst the evils and enchantments that populate Blood Ceremony’s world. Capering fauns
column6: weird sisters
column7: astrological signs
column8: and bewitched souls creep in and out of earshot
column9: imbuing tracks like “Ballad of the Weird Sisters” with a certain otherworldly feel even as they build upon standard 70s hard rock song structures.

column1: Guitarist Sean Kennedy weaves his riffs over and under the flue’s driving force
column2: stealing the spotlight when it suits but generally content to serve as the stage upon which O’Brien’s finery flashes. Michael Carrillo’s drums are understated
column3: slung low in the mix but never far from the action; his militant rat-a-tat in the titular “The Eldritch Dark” serves as a steady anchor for the song’s psychedelic meanderings
column4: and gels perfectly with the burly basslines. “Drawing Down the Moon” is the most vintage-inspired of a host of backward-glancing tracks. Kennedy’s note-perfect Iommi riff wails away while O’Brien channels Marianne Faithfull and Jethro Tull like some heathen love child and pounds that Hammond organ for all of its considerable worth. It’s hip-shaking
column5: head-nodding
column6: sideways-glance-throwing nighttime music. If the Devil were really listening
column7: he’d have booked these guys as his house band long ago.

column1: The hymn-like “Lord Summerisle” is quiet and contemplative
column2: recalling the quietest moments of Black Sabbath’s “Planet Caravan” and guided by a particularly haunting flute melody. It’s the only song to feature a male vocalist
column3: as bassist Lucas Gadke (who wrote the tune in homage to the eerie atmosphere of cult film ‘The Wicker Man’) adds his plaintive voice to O’Brien’s backing harmonies
column4: and also the strangest. Blood Ceremony hit upon their alchemical formula years ago
column5: but it’s still refreshing to see them experiment
column6: just a little. Too much
column7: and their spell would break; just enough
column8: and they prove once again why they are the most vital band of the “occult rock” renaissance. Trends come and go
column9: but a band like Blood Ceremony
column10: with their bewitching tunes and dark secrets
column11: are above such petty mortal trifles. We’re coming with them
column12:
whether we like it or not.
