column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19331/homepage_large.7739baa5.jpg|Chapter II|28028.0|Benga|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sony']|2013-06-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:52.298378|"

In 2002
column2: the then-16 year-old Croydon DJ Benga released his first single
column3: “Skank”
column4: an exploratory 2-step track that took equal parts inspiration from the dark garage experimentalist Wookie
column5: grime
column6: and the beginnings of dubstep. The track wasn’t as brilliant as it was an exciting look into a new wave of UK bass for which Benga would later become a mascot. “Night”
column7: his 2007 collaboration with Digital Mystikz’ Coki
column8: is easily one of the greatest dubstep tracks of all time
column9: wherein melodic
column10: funky
column11: and chomping guttural bass play a game of tug-of-war. When the UK’s basement dance scene slowly began creeping outwards
column12: Benga stayed on track; he became part of dubstep super-group Magnetic Man alongside Skream and Artwork
column13: scored a BBC Radio 1 show
column14: and in 2011 turned his production know-how into pop sheen for Katy B’s breakout single
column15: “Katy on a Mission”
column16: and her next hit “Perfect Stranger” (producing the latter as Magnetic Man). With the release of his newest
column17: third full-length Chapter II
column18: one thing is clear; this is not that Benga.

column1: There’s nothing harder for a fan of Benga than to hear him produce with relevancy in mind. Chapter II is full of festival-leaning ideas: razor-edged Skrillex bass
column2: ambient trance synths
column3: vocalists singing about love and stuntin' on rivals. And it’s no surprise that the producer comes closest to pop-friendly bangers when he uses female vocalists and builds under them. “Smile” features Charli XCX in “Take My Hand”-fashion; half-melodrama and half-defiant punk as bass wubs beneath her and melodic keys sparkle around her. “Higher” fares similarly; its day-glo trance synths build to a frenetic drum and bass beat that leads the singer through love in the club. The pair were no doubt made with radio-play and EDM fandom in mind
column4: but still translate as lesser-than when put in context with the strength of his previous large-scale hits.

column1: And perhaps that’s part of the problem: Chapter II often appears to be catering to tastes when its creator's greatest successes come when he's doing anything but. Benga is one of the DJs that helped made dubstep a pop reference in the first place; before Bieber and will.i.am
column2: there was La Roux and Skream
column3: Britney and Rusko
column4: Katy B and Benga. (Which also forces the questions: Why isn’t Katy B anywhere to be found on this album? And will he be on her forthcoming one?) Instead of pushing forward
column5: all too often the DJ just toes the line of cliched dance pop; “There’s No Soul” unfortunately lives up to its name.

column1: There are some decent ideas to be found here
column2: though
column3: and Benga’s technical production savvy is still something to be admired. “Click and Tap” is a gem where loops of tightly-rolled snares are joined by pulsing
column4: melodic bass lines
column5: and the track ends up serving as an interlude to “Forefather”
column6: which brings out rapper and grime MC Kano to complement Benga’s gritty dubstep pumelling. “To Hell and Back” is a moshpit-ready explosion of abrasive propulsion with menacing kickdrums and wailing horns on the hook. Its chug of battling beats could have followed the producer’s catchy “Baltimore Clap”. The problem with Chapter II is that even the album’s high points are only just good
column7:
when the dubstep world has reasonably come to expect great things from Benga.

"|18146.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18146-benga-chapter-ii/|5.7|Puja Patel

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19249/homepage_large.7e252f9a.jpg|Sunbather|30011.0|Deafheaven|['Metal']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Deathwish']|2013-06-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:52.753079|"

Deafheaven weren't always this good. The San Francisco band's early shows found a scrappy
column2: ambitious bunch of punk kids trying to warp black metal with shoegaze in a way that
column3: for all its advances
column4: felt familiar. In late 2010
column5: they signed to Deathwish
column6: the label run by Converge's Jacob Bannon
column7: and there were expectations in the underground. (Though
column8: at that time
column9: people seemed to focus more on the fact that they didn't look like a metal band than what they were creating.) When vocalist George Clarke and songwriter/guitarist Kerry McCoy released their debut LP
column10: Roads to Judah
column12: they added wrinkles to that live sound
column13: especially on the opening track
column14: ""Violet"". The collection didn't always match those standards. It sometimes felt muddled
column15: like they were trying to squeeze too much into the frame.

column1: But that gorgeous 12-minute set-piece established the template and scope for the band's excellent sophomore album
column2: Sunbather
column3: a record that finds Deafheaven living up to and then surpassing expectations. Basically
column4: they've learned how to take the sounds they've dreamed up out of their heads so we can hear them
column5: too. If you go back and listen to Roads
column6: you'll find the elements that appear on Sunbather with 10 times the intensity. So while the approach here  isn't a surprise
column7: the force with which Deafheaven pulls it off is a revelation.

column1: Sunbather's a seven-song collection that fuses into a massive 60-minute piece. The sequencing
column2: moving from brightness to darkness and back
column3: is brilliant. Throughout
column4: McCoy gives in to his inner Johnny Marr
column5: offering deeper
column6: prettier
column7: more eclectic guitar tones. His lines are smeary with tremolo and delay
column8: and the band seamlessly incorporates melancholic piano
column9: harsh Godflesh-style noise bursts
column10: spoken word
column11: lush acoustic strums
column12: and eerie samples. That
column13: and new drummer Daniel Tracy plays big
column14: adding a wallop they've missed in the past. (Deafheaven have always been Clarke and McCoy with a shifting lineup around them; let's hope this one lasts.)

column1: This is music that inspires the kind of wide-screen feelings people look for in Sigur Rós
column2: Mogwai (who Deafheaven have covered)
column3: or Godspeed You! Black Emperor. Words of anger and frustration collide with the sheer beauty of the music. The power of that blend-- raw black metal and hardcore basking in pastel-colored post-rock guitars-- is something you don't experience in those other groups. There are plaintive moments here
column4: but this is largely music about romantic lust
column5: anger
column6: and disappointment delivered by a band who know their punk and hardcore as well as their metal. They know their Cure and the Smiths
column7: too. Remember the ecstatic closing moments of Fuck Buttons' ""Sweet Love for Planet Earth""? Loop that and ask Explosions in the Sky to play the accompanying music and you're tapping into this sound.

column1: While Deafheaven push this epic music as far as it can go
column2: they retain a central emotional core
column3: and are always in control compositionally. The opening song
column4: ""Dream House""
column5: is over nine minutes long; the closer
column6: ""The Pecan Tree""
column7: which moves from dire black metal to triumphant post-rock without any stitches showing
column8: is closer to 12. The four longer songs don't repeat themselves; each is stunning in its constant motion and variation. ""Sunbather"" is bleaker than ""Dream House""
column9: for instance
column10: and on ""Vertigo""
column11: they downshift from gossamer prettiness to full-on heavy with a warped My Bloody Valentine transition followed by their most power metal guitar soloing to date. At the five-minute mark of that song
column12: blast beats enter and it goes black metal. Two minutes later
column13: though
column14: it's soaring again with hook-laden guitars and floor-punching dynamics.

column1: Even the interstitial parts inspire. ""Dream House""'s delicate closing arpeggios blend with ""Irresistible""
column2: a three-minute swatch of melancholic guitar and piano that works as a gentle pause before the massive ""Sunbather""
column3: but is in of itself a gorgeous composition. The grinding industrial noise at the end of ""Sunbather"" dissolves into ""Please Remember""
column4: a relatively brief piece that features Alcest's Neige speaking lines from Milan Kundera's novel The Unbearable Lightness of Being. (Clarke explained its inclusion in a recent Show No Mercy: ""That passage is really important to me. It just screams insecurity
column5: which I have huge faults with."")

column1: Clarke's voice mixed with the mountains of cascading guitars and drum crescendos is so strong that you don't need to know what he's saying to feel the effect of the music. But if you do decide to read the lyrics
column2: you won't be disappointed: Sunbather was in part inspired by the singer growing up with his mother and brother without any money and wondering what it'd be like to have it. There's also his realization that
column3: like his largely absent father
column4: he's able to be cold emotionally
column5: and not necessary able to love. The album's central image is of a girl sunbathing outside of her upscale house. Clarke spotted her after moving back home for a bit and while stuck in an existential crisis. He wondered what he'd end up doing himself and
column6: more so
column7: what it would be like to have that girl's existence. And
column8: of course
column9: what it would be like to have that girl. ""Dream House"" ends with a dialogue Clarke says he pieced together from drunken texts between him and a woman he was crazy about: ""'I'm dying.'/ 'Is it blissful?'/ 'It's like a dream.'/ 'I want to dream.'""

column1: With Sunbather
column2: Deafheaven have made one of the biggest albums of the year
column3: one that impresses you with its scale
column4: the way Swans' The Seer did last year. Like M. Gira's masterpiece
column5: it has the ability to capture the attention of people who don't normally listen to heavy music. It's also one of the most successful examples of a band using black metal as a starting point and ending up somewhere else entirely. People cite the short-lived San Francisco band Weakling's seminal 2000 album Dead as Dreams as the pinnacle of American black metal; Sunbather is another. Like Weakling
column6: Deafheaven have changed things with this record-- black metal won't be the same now that it's been released. Of course
column7: folks will argue over just how black metal-- or even metal-- Sunbather is
column8: and will discuss the ""un-metal"" pink cover art and the fact that Clarke could probably be a J. Crew model. These kinds of arguments are irrelevant. Instead
column9: try focusing on how much better Sunbather is than any other black metal album released this year
column10: and how it's
column11: by far
column12: one of the best in any genre. Or
column13: maybe
column14:
just talk to your friends about what it feels like to listen to a modern classic.

"|18060.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18060-deafheaven-sunbather/|8.9|Brandon Stosuy

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19287/homepage_large.fcbe9068.jpg|Evil Friends|27983.0|Portugal. The Man|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Atlantic']|2013-06-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:53.340631|"

The latest album by Portland's Portugal. The Man
column2: Evil Friends
column3: is rarely the same from one minute to the next
column4: careening between alt-rock bombast
column5: punk snot
column6: Lumineersy campfire singalongs
column7: pixelated MGMT headbandcore
column8: dawdling George Harrison solos; you name it
column9: Evil Friends has probably stuck it somewhere. All that might sound like more than one album can bear
column10: but funnily enough
column11: Evil Friends is just about the least convoluted Portugal LP so far. With Brian ""Danger Mouse"" Burton behind the boards
column12: Evil Friends finds Portugal sharpening their poppier instincts while still leaving room for the proggy ambitions that got them there.

column1: At least as far back as 2009's The Satanic Satanist
column2: Portugal's hooks sharpened
column3: their restless compositions cut with flyaway choruses. With Burton's help
column4: Portugal continue to clear a path through the fracas; he hasn't done much to tamp down their taste for maximalism
column5: but he's certainly helped them sculpt the melee into something a little less unwieldy
column6: making sure these songs have enough hook to carry the weight of all the instrumental bedlam swirling around them.

column1: It's not a perfect fit; every surface glistens
column2: and Burton certainly helps Portugal keep a lot of balls in the air while staying mindful of information overload
column3: but his mix has that bright-as-the-sun quality of most modern major label rock that leads to fatigue after too long. And he seems to have talked John Gourley into sticking to the upper ranges of his acrobatic pipes
column4: a move that won't likely sit well with every Portugal fan. Still
column5: Burton helps Portugal keep some control of what could easily turn to chaos
column6: taking great care with their elaborate embellishments.

column1: With Burton at their backs
column2: Portugal take a surefooted approach on Evil Friends
column3: confidently blasting through these pan-genre Frankensongs. But
column4: just as the music seems to reposition itself every few seconds
column5: so do John Gourley's lyrics
column6: albeit with a lower success rate. He makes a couple of things clear on Friends: he's anti-apathy (the presumably ironic ""Creep in a T-Shirt"")
column7: pro-ecstasy (""Purple Yellow Red and Blue""
column8: featuring two-thirds of Haim)
column9: and more than a little conflicted about religion. ""We don't need no modern Jesus to roll with us
column10: he notes. ""Who cares if hell awaits
column11: he wonders a bit later
column12: ""we're having drinks at heaven's gate.""

column1: But then there's ""Hip Hop Kids"". What starts out as a stroll with his young daughter takes a sudden turn into bile-spewing rebuke: ""You hip-hop kids think we give a shit when we don't
column2: he spits
column3: apropos of... your guess is as good as mine. Gourley seems like a pleasant enough dude
column4: so this ""get off my lawn"" thing has to be an act; either way
column5: it doesn't work
column6: the song's tart melody spiked with this untoward bitterness. Several songs on Evil Friends sport choruses that seem at odds with their verses
column7: or stabs at profundity that don't hold up under scrutiny. With everything else floating around these songs
column8: they could occasionally use an anchor
column9: a task Gourley's flimsier lyrics aren't always up for.

column1: It took me maybe four or five good listens before Evil Friends stopped setting off my claustrophobia. Even with prolonged exposure
column2: Evil Friends' ever-present busyness can be overwhelming; there's a lot-- and sometimes too much-- going on here. Still
column3: even when their ambitions outpace their execution
column4: Portugal deserve their props for continuing to overshoot the mark. <span>Seven albums in
column5: with a seemingly permanent mid-day slot at almost every decent-sized festival on either side of the pond and a big-name producer on their side
column6: Portugal. The Man could've easily spent Evil Friends shedding complexities and doubling down on catchiness. The frequently overstuffed
column7: occasionally scatterbrained album is far from perfect. But even when going for broke gets them into trouble
column8:
Portugal seem happy to get up there and overshoot the mark.

"|18098.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18098-portugal-the-man-evil-friends/|6.0|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19269/homepage_large.71e7387b.jpg|Yugen EP|28921.0|Koreless|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young Turks']|2013-06-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:54.810108|"

There was once a sense of momentum to the music made by Lewis Roberts
column2: the Glasgow-based producer who records under the name Koreless. ""Up Down Up Down"" from 2009 matched elegant patterns to a skittering beat
column3: delivered via a YouTube clip depicting traffic pouring in and out of a city. Now
column4: some four years later
column5: Roberts is all about suspending figures in time
column6: chopping out the forward thrust altogether. The basic elements were already in place-- cut the beats from ""Up Down Up Down"" and the track wouldn't sound out of place on Yūgen
column7: a five-track EP for Young Turks that forms the most significant Koreless release to date. But this isn't simply a case of Roberts figuring out where he can go by muting the drum tracks on his sequencer. There's a whole world of thought in Yūgen
column8: a creeping sense that its weightlessness was only arrived at after long hours of procrastination.

column1:
Roberts discussed how his music is positioned far from anything that could be described as
""real"" in a recent Rising feature
column2: emphasizing his love of artifice and rigidity. There's no looseness here
column3: no feeling of him trying to overmatch the binary code scrolling down his screen. Instead
column4: there's a sense of parity between man and machine
column5: of Roberts respecting the framing devices his artificial working partner puts around his output. There's a feeling not dissimilar to the one Kraftwerk found on ""Computer Love""
column6: where a tender synthesis of human emotions and mechanics are set in motion. At its best
column7: on a track like the stuttering closer ""Never""
column8: this EP resembles something like dialect between Roberts and his computer
column9: getting close to Isaac Asimov's concept of a study of the personalities of intelligent machines. It makes even more sense when you learn that Roberts is a committed sci-fi fan.

column1: If the goal of Yūgen is to remove the everyday from the equation
column2: it only partly succeeds. But this isn't necessarily a failing of the piece; far from it. In fact
column3: the sense of human emotion that bleeds into each track is what makes it so inviting. It shifts through feelings of loss
column4: hope
column5: and unease
column6: with Roberts often fudging the sound to take it to the brink of malfunction. At times it's reminiscent of a clear-eyed take on the experiments Daniel Lopatin has uploaded to YouTube under his SunsetCorp moniker
column7: especially when he splices the vocal sample on ""Ivana"" across acres of chimerical synths. It's a very visual record
column8: reflecting the way the Haxan Cloak's Excavation conjured up images of a painfully laborious stumble through the afterlife. But Yūgen is more future dystopia than hellish fantasia. ""Sun"" is all glassy skyscrapers crashing into a purple sea
column9: ripped straight from the cover of a pulpy mid-century science fiction novel.

column1: While lost in Yūgen's world
column2: it is useful to think back at how the Koreless sound has evolved; the earlier ""4D"" had traces of a soulful vocal
column3: something Roberts would surely balk at now. His remix work for Foals seems even more incongruous
column4: but presumably the paycheck makes up for it. Still
column5: even in those pieces you can hear him slowly beginning to erase the world from his work. Yūgen is likely to feel similarly transitory to those early releases. This feels like a beginning
column6: a place that Roberts has worked toward that isn't necessarily going to be where he's going to land. In the Rising feature he talks of more rules
column7: more restrictions
column8: getting to a point where ""I don't get any input into it
column9: as he puts it. That thought echoes common considerations about true artificial intelligence
column10: something that feels potentially terrifying and revelatory
column11:
but leaves the future tantalizingly wide open.

"|18080.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18080-koreless-yugen-ep/|7.4|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19325/homepage_large.37a6f1f4.jpg|Walking Field|31151.0|Peals|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2013-06-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:55.408565|"

Side projects are an inevitability for musicians itching to keep their creative juices flowing between tours with their main gigs. But in the case of William Cashion and Bruce Willen’s new joint venture
column2: Peals
column3: it feels less like a time-killing indulgence than a therapeutic necessity. With their respective bands-- glamboyant synth pop fops Future Islands and art punk bruisers Double Dagger-- the two have played active roles in making Baltimore’s Wham City scene one the most vibrant
column4: prolific
column5: and relentlessly excitable music communities to emerge in the past decade. And though they’re situated on opposite ends of the post-punk spectrum
column6: Future Islands and Double Dagger have cross-pollinated before
column7: with the former’s frontman
column8: Sam Herring
column9: lending his outsized
column10: balcony-bound voice to “The Lie/The Truth”
column11: the anthemic standout on the latter’s 2009 release
column12: More. With Peals
column13: however
column14: Cashion and Willen are less interested in exploring any aesthetic overlap between their two bands than distancing themselves from both. Even those living in an inspired
column15: utopian environment like Wham City occasionally need a vacation.

column1: Walking Field thus represents Cashion and Willen’s escape to cottage country
column2: an opportunity to decompress
column3: clear their heads
column4: and experiment with more relaxed
column5: exploratory modes of music-making than their day jobs allow. (True to their mellow-out mission
column6: the duo have taken to performing in a stage set-up that resembles a living room.) The album’s eight tracks are entirely instrumental
column7: and vocals aren’t the only thing missing here-- the record is completely devoid of bass and drums
column8: instead deploying clean acoustic/electric guitar patterns
column9: chimes
column10: percussive mic taps
column11: and third-eye-prying synth lines to establish a blissful sense of weightlessness. But Walking Field isn’t just some random exercise in blurry post-rock atmospherics. Cashion and Willen’s sense of melody is as rich as their textural layering
column12: resulting in pieces that are immediately engaging yet hypnotically serene
column13: and
column14: at times
column15: devastating in their poignancy: Mesmerizing opener “Floating Leaf” is built upon a gorgeous
column16: countrified guitar line that gradually dissolves into an impressionistic smear
column17: its core melody debased into lingering oscillations that resemble the fragmented images of a dream somberly half-remembered the morning after.

column1: Even though they’re operating within deliberately downsized dimensions and a slim instrumental palette
column2: it never feels like Cashion and Willen are limiting themselves-- the songs here range from a graceful
column3: tiki-torch songs (“Blue Elvis”) that could pass for old Galaxie 500 bedtracks
column4: to slow-swelling
column5: deeply affective Stars of the Lid-scaled drones (“Believers”)
column6: to a stirring cello-driven centerpiece (“Pendelles”
column7: featuring guest Kate Barutha) that hearkens back to the brooding beauty of 90s chamber-rock ensemble Rachel’s. (The duo’s adeptness at exploring different shades of melancholy is so impressive that Walking Field’s more playful counterpoints-- “Tiptoes in the Parlour”
column8: “Lonestar”-- can’t help but feel incongruously slight in comparison.) Even when Peals retrace their steps
column9: it serves as a springboard to somewhere new: “Koan 1” closes the album with a distant echo of “Floating Leaf”
column10: the melody slowed down but rendered more dramatic
column11: thanks to the reemergence of Barutha’s cello and a climactic
column12: triumphant explosion of electric-guitar fireworks. It’s the perfect ending to this spiritual retreat-- one that serves as a celebratory capper to a successful sojourn
column13:
while acknowledging that the noise of the big city beckons once again. 

"|18139.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18139-peals-walking-field/|7.6|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19347/homepage_large.432ea46d.jpg|This Is Another Life|29749.0|Case Studies|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-06-11 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:55.887443|"

Jesse Lortz used to record as the Dutchess and the Duke
column2: until he and his collaborator Kimberly Morrison parted ways. Now he records as Case Studies
column3: a studiously manila folder-blank name. The music he makes is similarly understated
column4: and arguing for its muted virtues can be uphill
column5: unsexy work; if you were a fan of the National prior to Alligator
column6: when they were a bleak
column7: Americana-inflected Brooklyn bar band
column8: then Case Studies may hold some appeal-- specifically
column9: the project recalls 2003's Sad Songs for Dirty Lovers.

column1: Lortz is an observant songwriter
column2: however
column3: and both This Is Another Life and his previous Case Studies effort
column4: The World Is Just a Shape to Fill the Night
column5: wear their moroseness handsomely.  This Is Another Life is a writerly album; the sweetly self-effacing
column6: solo-Paul-McCartney-reminiscent ""From Richard Brautigan""
column7: a late-album highlight
column8: finds Lortz repurposing Brautigan's bits of wisdom for his lyrics. His plummy
column9: low voice
column10: the most direct and unavoidable connection to the National
column11: draws your attention to the shape of his words and lines and makes some very unattractive sentiments ring with dark beauty: ""And if you have any decency
column12: then you'll pretend to be asleep so I can write/ I've never made an enemy that didn't fall in love with me for a while
column13: he moans on ""Passage/ Me in the Dark"".

column1: The album's sound is similarly mellow and rounded
column2: warmed by lovely upright piano and strings. The arrangements
column3: which Lortz worked out with guitarist and composer Jon Parker
column4: allow for arcing
column5: slide-guitar leads
column6: small embers of Hammond organs
column7: and
column8: on ""Driving East
column9: and Through Her""
column10: even some Keith Richards-style chop chords slide gracefully to the foreground. ""Driving East""
column11: ""Brautigan""
column12: and the Marissa Nadler duet ""Villain"" prick the album's gray tone
column13: and are the best things on it. ""Driving East""'s modest Southern-boogie steam gives a wry edge to Lortz's doomed-relationship chronicles. ""Those days became some photographs I wish I had not received
column14: he sings
column15: affectionately.

column1: But the darkness is where Lortz repeatedly returns
column2: and when he does
column3: the album swoons into a near-stasis. Nadler's vocals on ""Villain"" are so welcome
column4: in part
column5: because they offer some relief; otherwise
column6: spending the album's duration in the windows-shut
column7: blinds-drawn parlor of Lortz's mind is pretty suffocating. The focus on Lortz's vocals and lyrics also has the tendency to foreground florid stretches like this
column8: from ""You Say to Me
column9: You Never Have to Ask""
column10: where his pen gets away from him
column11: wildly: ""I have known witches/ I have felt so serene in my veins/ And your lips are whispering spells and your fingers are magical wands."" The record bottoms out with the longeurs of ""The Beast With No Name""
column12: where he sings ""If you were a dove in a cloud of ravens/ Swirling as just one animal/ Would you deliver me safely to your nest in the morning light?"" over weeping strings. The moment lays flat
column13: as does the imagery
column14:
and it's where Lortz's project finally crosses the line where ""tasteful"" shades into ""inert.""

"|18161.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18161-case-studies-this-is-another-life/|5.6|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19292/homepage_large.23e67eef.jpg|Tomorrow's Harvest|410.0|Boards of Canada|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2013-06-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:56.426715|"

Sounds like Boards of Canada. In the early years of this century
column2: you heard many electronic music aficionados using that phrase
column3: usually in the context of an endorsement. The Scottish brothers Michael Sandison and Marcus Eoin didn’t invent a new sound
column4: but they did take various strands of music floating around and pull them into one place and essentially perfect them. And their particular fusion was so distinctive that their name became shorthand. The appetite for the BoC was so voracious that the group’s actual output
column5: which was actually fairly prolific in its first decade
column6: wasn’t nearly enough to satisfy it. But that was a long time ago. Since 2006 we’ve heard a lot of music that seems spiritually connected to Boards of Canada
column7: from Burial to chillwave
column8: but we haven’t heard a note of music from the originators until the surprise announcement of Tomorrow’s Harvest.

column1: While BoC have always seemed comfortable inside their core sound
column2: their records are still easy to distinguish. On Music Has the Right to Children
column3: they mixed creepy pre-erased drones with childhood nostalgia and drums that drew from hip-hop; on 2002’s Geogaddi
column4: the beats got harder and the unease grew more intense

column7: intuitive swing may have been less commanding than the brontosaurus whomp of John Bonham

column1: In the end

column11:
but these iron men still walk.

but ""Heretic's Hymn"" is a eulogy that will keep their spirit alive. The fact that it's out there for younger bands to discover is as optimistic a prospect as they could ask for.

Last year

And the band’s very existence as a unit that features close collaboration among musicians from different ethnic backgrounds is its own statement on the conflict in the region; the politics here are at heart a politics of place

The idea of the instrumental virtuoso has fallen out of favor in some underground music circles. This prejudice is usually based around the idea that anyone who has that much invested in the technical aspects of their preferred instrument has gotten so far up their super-muso ass that there's no emotional engagement in the music itself. Bass maestro Stephen Bruner's found a few ways to avoid that fate: cultivating a sessionman's versatility equally suited to gigs with both Erykah Badu and Suicidal Tendencies
column2: aligning himself with the artsy but down-to-earth Brainfeeder community
column3: and
column4: as Thundercat
column5: putting out solo work that
column6: from the outset of 2011's The Golden Age of Apocalypse
column7: used his chops almost exclusively for a feeling of fidgety joy.

column1: But what's really made Thundercat interesting over the last few years
column2: and what gives his new Flying Lotus-co-produced album Apocalypse such a kick
column3: is the sense that he's completely divorced his music from any sort of pretense. He doesn't put up some kind of esoteric barrier between the vision of a serious artiste and an unwitting audience that supposedly needs to be schooled on what true musicianship is. He's more dealing with a simple set of ideas
column4: emotions
column5: sentiments
column6: and experiences
column7: elaborated upon in a surprising way. At his best
column8: Thundercat has reversed the evolutionary process where technology
column9: experimentation
column10: and crossover made music more complicated-- instead taking prog and fusion as a starting point to be whittled down
column11: rather than a destination to be built up to.

column1: Apocalypse gets immediate real quick. Opener “Tenfold” takes off with the sort of astral-jazz keyboards you might hear on a Lonnie Liston Smith interlude filtered through the TONTO synthesizer. But the real pulse is an insistent pounding
column2: chord-blurring 1-2-3-4 hardcore rumble that offsets Bruner's see-saw falsetto
column3: tersely belting out sonic prayers two or three words at a time. It sets the precedent for an album that brings its catchiest tendencies to the forefront and lets the virtuosic stuff in through side channels. What comes up as a whole is this odd but endearing blend of plainspoken nonchalance and almost limitless musical eccentricity.

column1: If that means Thundercat's music feels a little more traditionally song-oriented than before
column2: he's found a way to keep that unpredictable energy of his intact
column3: filtering it through familiar forms of indie R&B (the Mono/Poly coproduced “Heartbreaks + Setbacks”)
column4: electronified soul-folk (“Tron Song”
column5: which feels like Terry Callier gone glitch)
column6: and bristling
column7: burbling old-school boogie funk (the straightforwardly danceable “Oh Sheit it's X”). The moments of ramped-up rhythmic hustle remain a prominent feature; the shivery rollercoaster arpeggios and hand-cranked forward motion of “The Life Aquatic” and “Seven” have the feel of some enterprising knob-tweaker attempting to electronically retrofit the Minutemen's anxious energy for a Detroit dancefloor. But everything falls together in a way that settles into a steady groove that stays easy to follow and sink into.

column1: The catalyst for this is that Thundercat's voice is more prominent and freewheeling now
column2: as much of a driving factor in every song it appears in as the music backing him up. Where he falls short (but not very) in melodic range
column3: he makes up for in stylistic variance: he's longing and frustrated in “Heartbreaks + Setbacks”
column4: velvety and dance-drunk on “Oh Sheit it's X”
column5: sky-gazingly ruminative on “Lotus and the Jondy”
column6: warmly intense and motivational on “Special Stage”. More than ever
column7: it feels like he's writing the instrumentation to fit his voice rather than substitute for or distract from it. And for a series of songs split with a dichotomy of channelling rich
column8: often complex music through an engagingly human voice
column9: the messages are unmistakeable.

column1: The OutRun arcade sunniness of “Special Stage” is a key example: the song's message couldn't be more straightforward but the juxtaposition of simple lyrics and complicated music is the whole point. While there's little that seems quotable on paper
column2: little touches of goofiness and first-thing-that-comes-to-mind spontaneity-- the delivery of his “Your purse is nice
column3: baby
column4: is it leather/ Or could it be suede” pickup line on “Oh Sheit it's X”
column5: or the trip-out “straight up seein' goblins” borderline non-sequitir on “Lotus and the Jondy”-- make him the relatable gravitational center in the midst of a busy intersection of sound.

column1: While much of its musical direction is based on Thundercat's collaborative brainstorming with Flying Lotus
column2: the emotional core of Apocalypse rests either explicitly or implicitly under the shadow of the late Austin Peralta
column3: the Brainfeeder musician and keyboardist/pianist on many of the songs on Golden Age of the Apocalypse. While there are specifically direct nods to his untimely passing-- most prominently on the elegaic closing suite “A Message for Austin/Praise the Lord/Enter the Void”-- the idea that Peralta's influence and memory runs through the entirety of this album's lifeblood makes a lot of sense. In some way or another
column4: everything on Apocalypse is about taking stock
column5: figuring yourself out
column6: and making sure that the people that mean something to you know that they do. That it arrives through the conduit of somebody who has an elaborate means to express this
column7:
but knows when and how to keep things simple? That's how you translate virtuosity into something that hits you right in the heart.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19373/homepage_large.20dad69b.jpg|Desire Lines|662.0|Camera Obscura|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2013-06-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:56:59.488991|"

For more than a decade
column2: the Glaswegian indie-pop band Camera Obscura have made consistency a virtue. Their songs stick to comfortingly familiar forms
column3: and every single one is about love. Not many bands could build a devoted indie following by plowing such a narrow
column4: unflashy vintage row. But not many bands have a singer like Tracyanne Campbell
column5: whose plainly beautiful voice is sluiced through a series of refined lilts
column6: catches
column7: and gulps that have come to trigger a nearly Pavlovian adoration in fans. This constant musical sweetness is balanced by Campbell's eye for the dark clouds reflected in every silvery lake
column8: and even her most starry-eyed love songs tend to be shot through with presentiments of doom.

column1: Camera Obscura's distinctive outlook on generic terrain becomes apparent only via intimate familiarity
column2: like how every forest trail looks the same except the one you've walked a hundred times. A cursory pass over their catalog might make it sound like all one piece
column3: where a baseline loveliness is spiked with absurdly disarming highlights such as ""French Navy"". But a dogged
column4: calculated growth can be traced from record to record. The folksy early-Belle & Sebastian style of Biggest Bluest Hi Fi (produced by Stuart Murdoch) was perfected
column5: and tinged with dreamy 1950s rock
column6: on the classic Underachievers Please Try Harder. The departure of vocalist John Henderson tilted the band away from cuddly duo songs and toward more lonesome
column7: focused showcases for Campbell's vocal performances on Let's Get Out of This Country and My Maudlin Career
column8: which bloomed with stronger electric instrumentation and bolder shades of country
column9: orchestral pop
column10: beach music
column11: and soul.

column1: Desire Lines is the first Camera Obscura album that doesn't seem to bring much new to the table
column2: though it's hard to complain when they have vocal melodies as infectious and thoughtful as those in the verses of standout ""William’s Heart"". Here
column3: Camera Obscura clear out the symphonic pomp that overgrew Maudlin to double down on classic beach music and soul underpinnings. Jeremy Kittel's strings swoop through a 30-second intro and then out of earshot for most of the album
column4: discreetly reappearing to add translucent harmonies to the stirring ballad ""Cri De Coeur"" and the jubilant deep cut ""I Missed Your Party""
column5: where Motown goes to the sock hop courtesy of a horn arrangement by Mark Gonzales. Neko Case and Jim James add unpresumptuous vocal harmonies to several tracks
column6: easing into the low-key setting. The flicker and caress of Kenny McKeeve's tastefully reverbed guitar never gets much rowdier than on the rollicking trifle ""Do It Again""-- sadly not a Beach Boys cover
column7: but with some of that same nostalgic feel. There's not a bad cut here
column8: though it's hard to imagine what a bad Camera Obscura cut would sound like at this point.

column1: It isn't tough to write lyrics about the very beginnings and endings of relationships
column2: when feelings are large and roles are relatively clear-cut. Campbell's gift is to capture the murkier middle regions
column3: especially at transitions or reckonings-- times of acute vulnerability
column4: a quality her voice seems custom-built to transmit. In the first proper song
column5: ""This Is Love (Feels Alright)""
column6: she draws a scenario that is purely flirty and romantic; the kind of helpless
column7: unthinking giving-in that eventually leads to the hard questions posed on the stunning ""Fifth in Line to the Throne"": ""How am I going to tell my king that I don't trust his throne anymore?"" Campbell sings
column8: caught once again
column9: like a moth in a screen door
column10: between staying and going. She's wonderful at lightly sketching the complex dynamics between people who won't say what they both know. ""I've been cool with you
column11: she confides on ""New Year's Resolution"". ""The sooner you admit it
column12: I will
column13: too.""

column1: On the same song
column2: Campbell makes two resolutions: to ""write something of value"" and to ""kiss you like I mean it."" The two are directly related for a songwriter who captures hot feelings in cool songs
column3: and perhaps nod to the relatively long four-year wait for Desire Lines. More deeply satisfying than extraordinary
column4: it seems unlikely to displace anyone's favorite Camera Obscura record
column5:
but neither is it a negligible entry in one of the smartest and most loveable discographies in contemporary indie-pop.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19247/homepage_large.142f9fb5.jpg|The Last Great Challenge in a Dull World|31305.0|Peter Jefferies|[]|0.0|1.0|1.0|['De Stijl'
column3: Last Great Challenge in a Dull World
column4: opened a world for me. It was early 1992
column5: the year after its first reissue by the Chicago label Ajax
column6: who put it out again in 1995. It had originally been released in limited form on casssette by Xpressway
column7: an imprint founded by the Dead C's Bruce Russell that I thought of as Flying Nun's weirder
column8: more depressed cousin. I had a radio show at the college station
column9: and looking through a pile of playlist releases
column10: I came across the first Ajax edition with a thumbs up from our Music Director
column11: and I ended up playing the whole thing on the air that night. It's the kind of record that
column12: if it sucks you in
column13: will do so entirely. Think of it
column14: in that sense
column15: as the gnarlier Five Leaves Left.

column1: Last Great Challenge is a claustrophobic
column2: private-sounding collection that ranges from homegrown
column3: tinny post-punk to melancholic piano ballads to fucked up tape manipulations to the sound of a man singing calmly (and resignedly) while he does the dishes. As far as New Zealand music in the early 1990s goes
column4: there were poppier groups like Tall Dwarfs
column5: 3Ds
column6: the Clean
column7: and the Verlaines. But there was also plenty of noisier material: the Dead C
column8: Wreck Small Speakers on Expensive Stereos
column9: Gate
column10: A Handful of Dust
column11: and other material by Jefferies and his brother Graeme
column12: together as Nocturnal Projections and This Kind of Punishment
column13: and Graeme with his own band as the Cakekitchen. Last Great Challenge found a space between the two camps.

column1: Because it's so personal
column2: my original sense was that it was the work of an individual. Reading the album credits two decades years later
column3: though
column4: I realized many of the people central to that amazing NZ underground scene were on it. Jefferies did record on a 4-track
column5: but in a studio
column6: not his bedroom
column7: and at various points he's joined by the three members of the Dead C as well as Alastair Galbraith
column8: onetime Verlaine Robbie Yeats
column9: David Mitchell of 3Ds
column10: Nigel Taylor
column11: Kathy Bull
column12: and Robbie Muir.

column1: It's a difficult album to describe because it feels so singular. Opener ""Chain Or Reaction"" is a post punk song
column2: with slashing guitar
column3: piano
column4: and drums behind Jefferies' baritone; it's immediately contrasted by ""Domestica""
column5: the song that finds him crooning about ""throwing it all away"" over the sounds of doing dishes (and then revving up some sort of motor). The piano is his signature-- he plays it like he's punching it-- and when he pairs it with noisy guitars
column6: doubled vocals
column7: and backwards tape loops
column8: the sound is all Jefferies'.

column1: While it's a downcast singer-songwriter collection
column2: even the most hushed moments usually include muffled feedback. And there are occasional psychedelic guitar flairs courtesy of the Dead C (they rage
column3: but remain as quiet as whispers). As bleak as it gets
column4: there's also a kind of tenderness. ""On an Unknown Beach""
column5: for instance
column6: was the tear-jerker then and now. The aching
column7: pretty track
column8: featuring Jefferies alone with his piano
column9: sets the scene of a lonesome winter trek to the beach that comes off
column10: like much of his work
column11: like something bigger: ""My back to the water / My feet in the sand/ Finding no recognition/ As each sign of life/ Invades the precision of this/ Aging land."" In it
column12: he paints one of his most beautiful
column13: and lonesome
column14: images: ""There's a man on the shore line/ With a white parakeet/ Trying to make his/ Bird go home."" It's the kind of visual that sticks with you the moment you hear it; Jefferies has a knack for these kinds of things.

column1: Around the time of the original release
column2: he put out a ""The Fate of the Human Carbine"" b/w ""Catapult"" 7""
column3: which De Stijl includes on this new vinyl reissue. Memory works in a weird way
column4: and I always thought of them as part of the same collection anyhow: The subject matter of his material at this time is dark
column5: and those two songs fold into the tracklist seamlessly. Plus
column6: ""Fate"" is the song Cat Power ended up covering on What Would the Community Think in 1996: Her take was Jefferies' biggest ""crossover"" moment until apparent mega fan Amanda Palmer covered ""On an Unknown Beach"" in 2011.

column1: It's understandable why Chan Marshall and Palmer would be drawn to this work: Like them
column2: Jefferies populates his songs with strong characters and real aches. There are protagonists like the wife who gets up at 6 a.m.
column3: has breakfast with her family
column4: then enters an existential void (""Guided Tour of a Well Known Street"") and the character of ""The Fate of the Human Carbine"" who enjoys his time away from his wife before disappearing into his television: ""From six to seven he'll be all alone/ So he turns on television/ Doesn't even notices as is the hours roll by/ Gets lost inside the screen/ Watches the film about the evening sky/ It was someone else's dream.""

column1: Jefferies released four solo albums after this and played in Mecca Normal and 2 Foot Flame with Jean Smith. In New Zealand
column2: he was also a part of Plagal Grind
column3: Cyclops
column4: and collaborations with Shayne Carter
column5: Jono Lonie
column6: and Chris Smith. In 2002
column7: though
column8: he retired from ""professional music."" This makes me think of  a question he asks during ""Domestica"": ""Will anyone be getting old/ Before they throw it all away?"" But it sounds like he's quite content
column9: really: He teaches high school music (drums
column10: composition
column11: recording) in NZ and plays music for special-needs students once a week. It's a fitting move by someone who wrote a record that has the power to change a life
column12:
but still remains relatively unknown. Hopefully this reissue helps shift that.

"|18058.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18058-peter-jefferies-the-last-great-challenge-in-a-dull-world/|8.4|Brandon Stosuy

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19161/homepage_large.3d053d91.jpg|If I Tell U|27922.0|Phaseone|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Williams Street']|2013-06-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:00.705619|"

In 2009
column2: pop mash-ups were so ubiquitous
column3: and so often poorly executed (Super Mash Bros
column4: anyone?) that anyone who showed a degree of subtlety was liable to win approval
column5: or at least a favorable comparison to Girl Talk. The St. Louis producer Andrew Jernigan
column6: better known as Phaseone
column7: took advantage of the situation and dropped a head-turning mix called White Collar Crime
column8: on which he ably mashed-up El-P and Bon Iver
column9: and blended Animal Collective and Burial with equal aplomb. Meanwhile
column10: an album of mostly original material released the same year
column11: <i>Thanks But No Thanks
column12: showed that same range and subtlety in what can now be seen as a clear precursor to the electro-cloud style that’s since become so popular. Jernigan was an early prototype of artists as disparate as Clams Casino
column13: Lapalux
column14: and Teebs
column15: who make hazy
column16: amorphous music structured like instrumental hip-hop and sourced from multiple genres.

column1: Four years doesn’t sound like much
column2: but there are now plenty of producers with the range and subtlety to execute the kind of music that Jernigan was making when he came out. And while the new Phaseone album is a tasteful example of the form
column3: it’s still not quite enough to set Jernigan
column4: who now lives in Brooklyn
column5: apart from the pack in the way that those early records did.

column1: That doesn’t mean there isn’t plenty to like on If I Tell U. Jernigan has moved away from samples
column2: choosing instead to craft similar sounds for himself
column3: and while his hip-hop bona fides are still obvious on an album filled with rap-nerd percussion
column4: there’s not much here that’s particularly upbeat. Instead
column5: we get soothing
column6: zonked out synth-fests like “Hunter” and the flickering “Tangiers”
column7: two of the best tracks on the album. “Hunter” has guest vocals and “Tangiers” has none
column8: but both tracks function as miniature movements
column9: in constant motion even as certain components of the song repeat throughout.

column1: While there’s something soothing about the loops that Jernigan selects
column2: a minimalist repetition that evokes Daniel Lopatin’s more peaceful work
column3: his tracks are too tightly structured and have too much body to function as ambient music. This is where a lack of samples really hurts--without that slice of recognizable melody
column4: that earworm to latch on to
column5: many of the most beautiful tracks here are doomed to first grab
column6: then lose the listener’s attention. Take “Kings”: its lo-fi tonal repetition and breathy vocal are perfectly lovely at first
column7: but the loop isn’t sharp enough to sustain attention through repetition alone
column8: and the entire track ends up being forgettable.

column1: On an album where some compositions are lost to tedium
column2: it might be alarming to see an eight-minute track approaching. But ""Dialogue"" not only validates its running time
column3: but may also hint at a way forward for Jernigan’s music. It's split into four separate sections: a formal
column4: almost classical entrance erupts into a synthetic reinterpretation of a lightshow. Then both vocals and synths are sent through a musical kaleidoscope
column5: waxing and waning before a blurry coda brings things to a halt. Like so many of Jernigan’s pieces
column6: the track is beautiful throughout
column7: but it’s also interesting and unique
column8: a song for listeners to return to and for other producers to take heed of. While much of If I Tell U indicates that the producer might be better off pursuing ambient music with complete conviction or otherwise returning to his polished sample game
column9:
a track like “Dialogue” suggests that Phaseone might have more solid musical frontiers to explore yet.

"|17967.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/17967-phaseone-if-i-tell-u/|6.5|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19316/homepage_large.a45cd798.jpg|Danish & Blue|30206.0|Lilacs & Champagne|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2013-06-07 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:02.004949|"

The second album from Lilacs & Champagne takes the provocation of yesteryear and softens it at the corners
column2: offering a form of easy-on-the-ear radicalism. It's not an overtly political work
column3: although it is one that illustrates how just about anything can retreat into the margins and become a form of background noise. Lilacs & Champagne are the sample-happy duo of Alex Hall and Emil Amos
column4: who craft this stuff away from their main focus in the instrumental rock act Grails. This is a continuation of the work started on their eponymous 2012 debut
column5: with porn and B-movie dialogue mixed up with studied guitar soloing and a blitz of lounge oriented samples. The title is presumably a reference to Danish Blue
column6: a documentary from 1968 that advocated for the legalization of pornography in Denmark. But nothing here seeks to agitate
column7: instead taking outsider art and attempting to expose its soft underbelly.

column1: The references Hall and Amos flip through in their work are an amalgam of the overt and the obscure. ""Alone Again And..."" offers a reduction of the hippy protest dream that makes a titular reference to Arthur Lee's work in Love
column2: while the following ""Police Story"" works through familiar emblems from TV cop show themes. But the cut-and-paste nature of their work means it doesn't just hark back to the original source material-- it does it by way of similarly minded 90s artists such as Tipsy and Sukia
column3: who both had a fondness for piecing tracks together around lounge/exotica samples. The difference here is that this album is a much more passive listening experience
column4: not really inviting the listener to get involved
column5: apparently content to let everything sink into the sidelines. Even an intentional piece of button-pushing dialogue on the title track is barely pushed to the fore. You almost expect someone to leap out and apologise for it being there.

column1: That coy sense of playfulness is a big part of the appeal when Hall and Amos get it right. The expertly disjointed ""Sour/Sweet"" finds beauty in twining peace with chaos
column2: where a scattered drum sample drunkenly lurches into cut-ups of a fresh soul singer. It doesn't belabor the point
column3: getting out in just over two-minutes
column4: offering the perfect distillation of what this band could potentially be. The longer material often gets ponderous
column5: attempting to find a resting ground between psychedelic guitar stokes and something approaching easy listening
column6: but failing to really tap into the power of either. When Stereolab were sourcing artists like Esquivel and Martin Denny
column7: they primarily recognized the striking sounds they were using
column8: culled from strange percussion tools
column9: odd deviations in dynamics
column10: or a great sway of vocal harmonies. Danish & Blue doesn’t get to that spot
column11: instead settling into being that thing you hum while doing other
column12: more important things.

column1: Hall has stated that this record is intended to be a ""direct tribute to the musical outsiders of the past
column2: which makes a strange fit for the reticence and casual air of the album. In a sense it's a logical next step for the dilution of works that could once have been read as insurrectionary
column3: a further blunting of the knife for anyone who might still be incensed that music by the Clash was used in a jeans ad. Taking that fire and pushing it further into the background
column4: turning it into an approximation of what Erik Satie wonderfully dubbed ""furniture music
column5: feels like an endpoint of sorts
column6: if not a particularly interesting one. But Danish & Blue doesn't come close to either making a statement or reaching into the daze that made their debut so pleasingly disorienting. This is the early-hours sound you nod off to
column7:
not the one that has you second guessing what you heard.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19279/homepage_large.40d785e5.jpg|Immunity|27655.0|Jon Hopkins|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-06-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:02.579468|"

Jon Hopkins is a respected keyboardist and sonic technician who instills ambient music and acidic techno with a classical sense of composition
column2: but he tends to work around the edges of things: He got started backing Imogen Heap. He's played keyboards for Brian Eno
column3: a clear influence
column4: on albums such as Small Craft on a Milk Sea. Tagging along with Eno
column5: he wound up co-producing and performing on Coldplay's fourth album. He also created subtle electro-acoustic atmospheres for the Scottish singer/songwriter King Creosote on the exquisite Diamond Mine EP
column6: and crafted an acclaimed string-based score for the British sci-fi film Monsters. It's not a shabby CV
column7: but it's not quite a name-making one
column8: either.

column1: This habit of putting himself on the periphery seeped into his own albums-- until now. Insides from 2009 was impressive but felt faintly impersonal
column2: streaming by like dazzling but disconnected vignettes in a film. But Hopkins' breakthrough fourth album
column3: Immunity
column4: bounds and writhes with its own life force. It's looser and oilier
column5: more limber and dangerous. The aggressive dance tracks darkly obliterate everything else
column6: while the wet and sunny piano-ambient ones wash out into the sounds of wind
column7: waves
column8: and gulls. The latter is impeccably done on ""Sun Harmonics""
column9: where the boundary between electronics and coastal recordings dissolves.

column1: Lots of electronic music creates its own hermetic world
column2: but on Immunity
column3: Hopkins finds ingenious ways to let the world in. He created the album's warm
column4: alive feel by shunning digital perfection in favor of the analog synthesis of original sounds
column5: both electronic and physical. The ambient prelude of the haunting
column6: scrambled glitch-house opener ""We Disappear""-- a key unlocks the door of Hopkins' London studio and his footsteps lead in-- is more than idle window dressing: He is ushering us into the tactile space that suffuses the record. He drums on desks
column7: plays salt shakers
column8: slows down serendipitous recordings of nearby fireworks
column9: boosts the kick-drummed rattle of a window. On ""Form By Firelight""
column10: which sounds like Kanye West's ""Runaway"" remixed by Wolfgang Voigt
column11: Hopkins processes beats and melodies right out of the piano
column12: tapping the pedals and striking the strings. Spacious
column13: with carefully shaped resonance
column14: its delay-flickered counterpoint shows off Hopkins' classical background.

column1: This emphasis on our admission to a physical space naturally makes us feel like we have privileged access to Hopkins' private emotional space as well. Immunity is said to be inspired by the arc of a night out
column2: and whether or not that matters to the listener
column3: it gives the album a holistic pace and flow
column4: from heroically hurtling along on molten bass synthesziers to hovering gorgeously on gathering ambient breezes. Around the monstrous dancefloor anthems ""Open Eye Signal"" and ""Collider""-- the first oozing forward in anticipation
column5: the second climactically crashing down at sharp threshing angles-- there is the lyrical ambient landscape of ""Abandon Window"" and the cunning merger of both styles in ""Breathe This Air"". The title track
column6: with a trickle of legato piano turning a rickety rhythm
column7: brings back King Creosote to add discreet vocal colors for a dreamlike conclusion. It all adds up to a remarkably visceral
column8: sensual
column9: confident electronic record that stays absorbing from beginning to end
column10:
and should finally catapult Hopkins to stardom in his own story.

"|18090.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18090-jon-hopkins-immunity/|8.5|Brian Howe

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19337/homepage_large.102d7b27.jpg|Still Awake EP|30667.0|Ryan Hemsworth|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-06-06 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:03.095458|"

Halifax producer Ryan Hemsworth
column2: he of the narcotized pop instrumentals and nostalgic radio bootlegs
column3: has been prolific and populist for the entirety of his brief career. His new EP
column4: Still Awake (released out of nowhere for free last week) comes on the heels of three major mixes-- one for Diplo and Friends
column5: one for Fader
column6: and one for Rinse FM-- a host of loose singles
column7: and a couple of the finely-tuned pop remixes which got him noticed in the first place. But Still Awake finds Hemsworth eschewing his usual stew of radio-friendly samples for a sound both more intimate and more insular. There’s no lingering question behind the title of this EP: it’s a showcase for an omnivorous producer who stays up after everybody else has gone to bed
column8: tasked only with entertaining himself.

column1: Gone are the Juicy J and Waka hooks
column2: trap drums and associated tomfoolery. Hemsworth’s hip-hop leanings are still present
column3: but they’re put in the service of making elegant miniatures like “(｡◕‿◕｡) (or
column4: I Want to Stare at Your Face Until I Die)”. Dumb name
column5: but it’s a track on which Hemsworth manages to shrink desire down to pocket-size
column6: yearning and plaintive synths all resounding with the same kind of Gameboy fervor.

column1: Still Awake feels more well-blended than anything Hemsworth has done
column2: as if his rap
column3: pop
column4: and indie influences are now completely internalized. The samples are deftly woven-- it's not immediately obvious that there’s a lonesome dude moaning below the surface in the first minute of “Empty Thoughts Over a Shallow Ocean”. If the biggest problem with last year’s Last Words was a lack of cohesion between one track and the next
column5: then consider Still Awake the solution
column6: one on which all songs present are recognizably part of the same project. Even the remix of “Perfectly” that ends the EP-- repurposed as a dyspeptic party jam by the Japanese producer Taquwami-- sounds like Hemsworth giving one of his own tracks his patented remix treatment.

column1: So Hemsworth has found his voice
column2: more evidence of which can be found here in the inclusion of the video game sonics that he loves so much. Earlier this year he contributed a track to a compilation meant to honor the video game composer Yasunori Mitsuda
column3: and he can often be found on Twitter referencing the sounds of ""Pokémon""
column4: ""Zelda"" and ""Street Fighter"". “Perfectly”
column5: the strongest track on the EP

column1: Hemsworth is omnipresent: in the music he releases
column2: his constant touring (he’s on the road with Baauer and R.L. Grime this summer)
column3: and loudmouth social media presence. But his own tracks are often wedged into the middle of mixes populated with more famous faces
column4: and live
column5: he’s prone to crowd-pleasing drops and well-mixed
column6: next-level mash-ups
column7: only airing out his latest bedroom craftwork for a minute or so before quickly switching gears. Still Awake shows the flip side of that coin
column8: revealing an introversion that powers the sinking dolor of “track 5 (crashed)” and the intimacy of the understated “All Our Thoughts Are Physical”.

column1: That reticence speaks to the kinds of personalities that inhabit this purple beat scene. Producers like Hemsworth and his close contemporary Shlohmo didn’t start making music to be stars

column5:
Hemsworth has shown himself to have a developed understanding of what makes pop music tick. But his database of knowledge and constant musical curiosity is better served when he’s refashioning it into delightful little originals like those found on Still Awake.

Over six months after the release of her last mixtape
column3: Mykki Blanco-- the female alter ego of Michael Quattlebaum-- is beginning to prove much more than just a walking talking point. Last year’s Cosmic Angel showed a dextrous rapper with fury to spare

column1: The Initiation starts strong with “Angggry Byrdz”. Like the video game it’s named after
column2: the beat is cartoonish
column3: all plasticky plink-plonk sounds that Blanco pirouettes around with ease. As always
column4: she’s got a bone to pick with
column5: well
column6: everyone
column7: spitting
column8: “Look at them angry birds/ Tryna shit on every word.” If you didn’t already get the feeling that Blanco was automatically defensive about her art
column9: The Initiation makes it pretty damn clear. But in a world where drag queen feistiness is the subject of a popular reality show
column10: Blanco is both caricature and cut-to-the-bone reality. You wouldn't fuck with her.

column1: The rest of the EP is an up-and-down affair that loses the razor focus of its opener. More sprawling than your usual eight-track release
column2: the clumsy experimentalism of Cosmic Angel remains despite Blanco's improved chops. She adopts all kinds of voices
column3: mannerisms
column4: and characteristics
column5: flitting through personalities with the hummingbird hyperactivity of Nicki Minaj
column6: especially on “Crisp Clean”

column8: while Matrixxman’s “Ace Bougie Chick” is a jaunty summer jam with all the winking charm of Lil Wayne’s “Comfortable”. But even this one has a sinister undertone: its playful chorus goes “but you gon’ keep on fucking me/ And nobody has to know
column9: ” reminding us of the grim reality that being a gay black man is still an unspeakable position for so many.

column1: Blanco’s rapping is unmistakably stronger
column2: flowing faster and more naturally than ever before
column3: but when she’s not in full force she has trouble keeping getting from point A to point B. The grumbly “Feeling Special” feels like it’s dragging itself from bar to bar
column4: and the rapped-in-Latin title track
column5: while daring
column6: falls a little flat. In typically unusual form
column7: The Initiation’s most engaging track features no actual rapping at all: “Vienna” is simply spoken word over an electro beat. A hilariously detailed story about a tour stop in Austria starring “this waifish Persian pretty boy named Sammy Nagasaki
column8: ” it oozes with warmth and humour
column9: qualities that her acid-barbed lashings sometimes lack.

column1: The Initiation is a stepping stone for an artist who’s looking increasingly important. Quickly sharpening her stock as a rapper

column6: a spectacle-- and if she keeps up this ascent
column7:
they’re about to be shocked and surprised in exactly the way you begin to sense Quattlebaum wants.

In the 90s noise band Harry Pussy
column4: Bill Orcutt’s electric guitar playing was bracing
column5: brittle
column6: and singularly brutal. When he returned to recording and releasing music in 2009 after about a decade away
column7: his sound was just as distinctive-- but this time it was done with acoustic guitar
column8: making his consistency that much more remarkable. Harry Pussy devotees were suitably stoked by this seamless rebirth
column9: but surely in the back of their minds a question lurked: would Orcutt ever go electric again?

column1: The answer was yes-- Orcutt has played electric guitar intermittently over the past four years
column2: both solo and in various collaborations. But The Raw and the Cooked is the first full-length release in which he plays it exclusively. Recorded live last fall during a tour with drummer Chris Corsano
column3: the album is a storm of high-speed improvisation
column4: with 12 untitled tracks flying by in just 25 minutes.

column1: Orcutt’s old band favored short blasts too
column2: so another question naturally emerges: does The Raw and the Cooked sound like Harry Pussy? The answer again is yes
column3: but with qualifications. Orcutt certainly echoes his work of decades past
column4: dropping the kind of string-bombs that evoke an amplified car crash. And Corsano’s percussion is so rangy that it inevitably overlaps with the blunt pound of Harry Pussy drummer Adris Hoyos.

column1: But he’s generally more precise and pointillist
column2: with rolls and hits that are frequently jazz-like. That in turn inspires Orcutt toward runs that would work as well on an overblown sax as they do on an over-amped guitar. More importantly
column3: the aims of this duo seem decidedly different from that of Orcutt’s former outfit. Where Harry Pussy often dove toward the deepest end of noise rock
column4: Corsano and Orcutt seem just a bit more interested in exchange. They’re more inclined to volley their sounds back and forth than jump together into a noise pit.

column1: Maybe that’s why The Raw and the Cooked turns out to be much more varied than it initially seems. During my first listen
column2: everything seemed as frantic and blaring as the scorching opener. But repeat visits revealed stretches of restraint and reflection. (That’s something Harry Pussy did well
column3: too
column4: a fact that often gets lost in retrospective depictions of them as a relentless noise factory). The best comes in the album’s longest piece
column5: the 5-minute fifth track
column6: which starts serene before escalating into a sprint. Despite the shifts
column7: at no moment does the tension wane or the adrenaline run out.

column1: Ultimately
column2: that’s The Raw and the Cooked’s main strength. It’s so consistently exhilarating that it matters little whether the pair are playing slow or fast
column3: quite or loud
column4: minimal or maximal; all those modes unite into a single rush. Mapping out the changes and patterns in Orcutt and Corsano’s frantic dialogue is fun in retrospect
column5: but when The Raw and the Cooked is playing
column6:
I just want to close my eyes and let it take me wherever it wants to go.

As one half of proggy brother-sister duo the Fiery Furnaces

column3: or maybe Carmen Sandiego: tirelessly globe-trotting
column4: breathlessly complex
column5: and just a little cartoony. In a voice that sounds like a perfect cross between Patti Smith
column6: Stephen Malkmus
column7: and a 19th century diction coach
column8: Friedberger spun elaborate
column9: wildly fictional travelogues (usually written by her brother
column10: Matthew); in one Fiery Furnaces song she was a Michigan boat captain defending her cargo of blueberries against South Asian pirates; in another she sang in Innuit
column11: and a few songs later she was also a high school queen bee caught in a labyrinthine plot involving credit card theft. Then something unexpected happened with the release of her first solo album
column12: 2011's terrific Last Summer. She suddenly began to apply that same keen eye for meticulous detail
column13: propulsive narrative
column14: and ironic humor to the one character it seemed she'd never written about before: herself.

column1: Last Summer was a sharply observed account of Friedberger's first decade or so in New York
column2: where she moved in the early 2000s. At times
column3: its confessional
column4: meticulously detailed lyrics read like ripped-out diary pages
column5: and its brilliance was so sneaky that it was the very definition of a grower. It demonstrated an exciting shift in her songwriting that she continues to explore on her excellent new album

column7: the songs on Personal Record feel like travelogues of the mind
column8: entertaining accounts of adventures closer to home. “The last record I did was so specific and detailed
column9: ” she said in a recent interview. “It’s nice to have a record where you can catch a glimpse of the artist and their world
column10: but this time I wanted something where people could insert themselves into it.” She co-wrote Personal Record with a new collaborator
column11: alt-folk singer and novelist John Wesley Harding
column12: and adding another skilled writer to the mix seems to have gotten her out of her own head a bit.

column1: Occasionally
column2: she nails the one-size-fits-all timeless pop lyric: the opening track’s vivid admission
column3: “I’d rather be two inches from your face
column4: ” the elegantly sighed
column5: “Love is an exquisite kind of pain/ And oh
column6: since I saw you
column7: I’ll never be happy again.” But memory’s a funny thing; it latches onto the sensory details
column8: even when they’re somebody else’s. “When I Knew” so perfectly captures the excitement of a blossoming friendship between music nerds that the line “We both liked weird music
column9: so you played me Soft Machine
column10: ” practically invites you to swap out the specifics for your own favorite band; ditto the scene of the infatuated new lovers reading an e-book in the back of a cab
column11: or the girl curiously dressed as a Dexy’s Midnight Runner for Halloween. Contrary to what she might believe
column12: the more detailed and specific Friedberger’s songs are
column13: the easier it is to insert yourself into them.

column1: Personal Record is so jam-packed with clever wordplay and fleeting
column2: sometimes contradictory emotions (“I’ll Never Be Happy Again” is followed by the calisthenic skip of “Stare at the Sun”
column3: a song about being dizzyingly happy) that it occasionally feels as much like a short story collection as it does an album. But the tight
column4: buoyant pop arrangements keep it from getting bogged down. Despite Friedberger’s singular phrasing and voice
column5: there’s something inviting and comfortingly familiar about Personal Record’s approach to pop melody. The great “She’s a Mirror” sounds at once like Hall & Oates covering “Lust for Life” and the Peanuts shuffling to a Harry Nilsson tune-- but its amiable melody and boingy bassline give an easy entry point to a song that's lyrically devious.

column1: Like the title Personal Record itself
column2: Friedberger’s songs use double meaning to great (and sometimes genuinely funny) effect
column3: but they become suddenly poignant in the moments when those defenses fall away. “Other Boys” is one of the most candid
column4: quietly devastating songs she’s ever written: It’s about the kind of casual
column5: open relationship that
column6: secretly
column7: only one of the parties wants to be casual and open. In her ever-confident voice she pantomimes a shrug
column8: but someone who didn’t care about the competition wouldn’t make a list of her guy’s side chicks as poetic and mythologized as the Iliad’s Catalogue of Ships: “The long-tail pony with the thick
column9: dark mane/ 14 hands
column10: four thousand names
column11: ” “the spider you kissed in the stairwell
column12: ” and the subtly cutting
column13: “that sometime star of stage and screen who had a bit part in a film back in her teens.” “There are other boys
column14: too
column15: ” she insists
column16: her about-face betrayed by the slightest tinge of melancholy. With each repetition
column17: the line becomes a little harder to believe
column18: and a little more heartbreaking.

column1: Ultimately
column2: though
column3: Friedberger’s self-aware enough to be amused by the irony of confessional songwriting. This becomes explicit on “Singing Time”
column4: Personal Record’s bittersweet finale. Over a muted
column5: aqueous guitar
column6: Friedberger finally lets go of a doomed relationship: “You could turn up late and miss the show

column9: my songs
column10: ” she sings
column11: a meta-address that's somehow both playful and self-deprecating. “One day we will know more.” Up until then

column15:

Here’s a guess: if you can’t promise that your blockbuster rap album will outsell the National and Darius Rucker
column3: you don’t have a blockbuster rap album. And
column4: as such
column5: you do not get a blockbuster rap album budget. It’s rare when Billboard statistics can prove anything these days
column6: but in the case of French Montana’s Excuse My French
column7: its meek first-week numbers are an echo of an apathetic reception
column8: the dull thud of a sunk cost. And since Excuse My French does absolutely nothing to make French Montana look interesting
column9: it’s safe to say that the record failed in its one and only goal: to make French Montana look like a star.

column1: This isn’t all that surprising considering that his 2012 mixtape Mac & Cheese 3 achieved the same result as loudly and expensively as its commercially available follow-up. But you can understand what people see in French Montana
column2: as he does give you the raw material of a 2013 rap icon: fluent in regional microtrends and stylistically fluid enough to involve himself in them

column6: fucks
column7: robs
column8: or peddles bricks to is granted any sort of humanity. Which isn’t a huge problem

column2: Montana has no real idea of how to put a song together. As proven by “Stay Schemin’""
column3: “I’m a Coke Boy""
column4: “Pop That""
column5: “Shot Caller” or anything else that’s willed its way into becoming a hit
column6: when surrounded by the right team
column7: Montana can impress himself on a track without stealing it. But left to his own devices
column8: he raps the same way the guy in your freshman dorm played guitar
column9: absent-mindedly moving from one unrelated riff to the next
column10: fixating on familiar phrasings
column11: and just basically annoying the hell out of you. Some decent one-liners are sprinkled throughout
column12: and somehow
column13: hearing him do his trademark “hah?” is about the only thing that never becomes tiresome. Otherwise
column14: any French Montana verse is the sound of time being killed bar by bar.

column1: Nearly a year old
column2: “Pop That” is wisely and somewhat desperately included-- there’s no way Excuse My French will result in anybody’s first-time legal ownership of the song
column3: though you figure its 37 million YouTube views will yield something. Not surprisingly
column4: the noxious lifeblood of “Pop That” courses throughout Excuse My French. Every beat seems to be modeled after it
column5: so whether it’s Young Chop’s domineering synths or Rico Love’s piano-laced and pathos-laden boom bap
column6: it all pounds like Miami bass. Mixed and mastered without nuance or mercy
column7: the relentless blare of Excuse My French becomes a paradoxically ambient experience. Think Music For Airports
column8: except for situations if you’re engulfed in volume: sitting next to a guy on the subway whose headphones function more like a boombox
column9: trying to have a conversation in a restaurant that allows the decibel level of a nightclub
column10: being stuck in a cab blasting Hot 97 during rush hour traffic.

column1: I can’t verify that Montana’s indifference infects the massive roster of Excuse My French any more than I can find concrete scientific proof that yawning is contagious. But the results make the question of correlation or causation a moot point. When the Weeknd’s sexual politics on “Gifted” are somehow less reprehensible than yours
column2: that’s a problem. When “Trap House” finds Rick Ross so disengaged that Birdman manages a more complex rhyme pattern
column3: that’s a problem. When an appearance from ACME-brand rapper Ace Hood feels like the first time in 20 minutes your blockbuster rap album has shown a pulse

column10:
forcing French Montana into that #1 spot and having it come off like a transplant rejection actually lets us know the genre’s in fine health.
