column9: he sings on ""Home I Love""
column10: and that's just the trouble; between the slight remove in Bleeker's reedy everydude voice and these lyrics' indistinct pining
column11: his music is tough to internalize without playing a little emotional Mad Libs with yourself
column12: squeezing your own particular troubles into the big box Bleeker's provided.

column1: Chances are
column2: though
column3: you'll come away from How Far Away feeling pretty alright about things. Even at his weepiest
column4: Bleeker's good company; Buffalo Springfield-nodding highlight ""Step Right Up (Pour Yourself Some Wine)"" draws you right in
column5: asks how you're doing
column6: rummages around for a clean glass. Bleeker doesn't strike me as a wallower; in fact
column7: he seems like the type who gets over a bad breakup by being around people
column8: not avoiding them. And so he did
column9: reconvening his friends in the Freaks and trying to work through the heartbreak. How Far Away holds its juicy details a little too close to the chest to truly prove cathartic to anybody but Bleeker. But as far as guys talking your ear off about their problems
column10:
you could do a lot worse.

Last year
column2: Captured Tracks reissued Cleaners From Venus’ first three albums from the early 1980s
column3: each one an accomplished masterpiece of guitar pop home recordings rivalling the work of R. Stevie Moore and Chris Knox
column4: among others. Now a new vinyl/download set from the label continues the story of the English band
column5: focusing on their work up until the middle of that decade. By this point
column6: the Cleaners were essentially Martin Newell
column7: whose guitar playing
column8: singing
column9: and arrangements balanced a sense of genteel pop-rock as refracted from the late 60s with the rough-and-ready explosion of DIY tape releases. But the real story
column10: already an undercurrent on the earlier releases
column11: was the sense of sadness and unease that pinned down the cheeriest-seeming songs
column12: often reflecting a time of political and social despair as Margaret Thatcher’s government continued in office.

column1: In the Golden Autumn
column2: released in 1983
column3: was the first Cleaners album to be released following the departure of co-founder Lol Elliott. The sensation conjured up in the title carried through songs with titles like “The Autumn Cornfield”
column4: all bird sounds
column5: child’s voices
column6: and piano against a calm beat
column7: and the concluding mock-live-at-the-lounge breeziness of “A Fool Like You”
column8: where even the soaring sax break seems to underscore the refrain
column9: “She’ll never love a fool a like you.” “Ghosts in Doorways” and the accusatory “Krugerrand Gladiators” felt even starker
column10: however hook-laden-- the rich feeling in the guitars on the former contrasting lyrics like “Now you’ll wake alone/ In the golden autumn.” Throughout
column11: the overall feeling of immediacy and using what there was at hand remains key-- liberal echo's featured heavily
column12: but is just as dispensed with entirely.

column1: Under Wartime Conditions followed in 1984
column2: simply subtitled as ""a collection of pop songs."" Newell hadn’t suddenly gone pro by any means-- there were faint degrees of progression in the slightly clearer arrangements and more complicated instrumental passages. If anything
column3: it proved his most enjoyably rollicking record yet
column4: evidenced by the the drum-heavy boogie of “Hand of Stone” and the frenetic instrumental “Fracas on West Street”
column5: a jam where the Cleaners bordered on shredding. If there was more depth and variety to the muffled beats on the opening “Summer in a Small Town”-- as close as the Cleaners got to funk-- the introductory chatter
column6: barbed expressions of contentment
column7: and roughly textured vocals would definitely trace Newell’s increasingly parallel path towards that of future collaborator Andy Partridge of XTC. Meanwhile a tip of the hat to a mutual inspiration (also noting the perils of fandom) with “Song for Syd Barrett” once again showed Newell's propensity for lyrics that intially read as bucolic and pastoral
column8: but revealed themselves to be questioning and uneasy. For instance
column9: from “Johnny the Moondog Is Dead”: “They kill the good guys off in history/ And tomorrow
column10: who will the unicorn be?”

column1: Songs for a Fallow Land
column2: the Cleaners’ 1985 offering
column3: shifts back into murkier mode with the opening “Sun Comes to the Wood”. Newell’s singing on the chorus has a slippery ease to it
column4: a suggestion of another new balance found after a steady five years of work under the name. Sterling musical moments like the simple in-construction guitar breaks on “Julie Profumo” and the quick and just as quickly dispensed-with Beatles nod on “Heroin Clones” abound throughout. Themes of isolation and sudden connection continue to provide a deep anchor at many points-- “Gamma Ray Blue” is one of the sharper critiques of mass media impact on emotion out there
column5: and certainly no less relevant in an Internet generation
column6: while “Stars Are Cold”
column7: is stripped down to piano
column8: bass and beats
column9: and reminiscences about being caught up in ones memories. Meanwhile the echo and space on “Soul Monday” is almost as post-punk as the band ever got
column10: while the bells on “Winter Place 2” accentuate the group’s facility with instrumentals in turn.

column1: After all this
column2: hearing Newell himself introduce A Dawn Chorus: Early Cleaners and Beyond with a quick chat asking us to ""take a break from the normal proceedings of jangly pop for a minute"" is a fun treat. He then plays a snippet of a song recorded in his garage with relatives and friends at the tender age of 12. From there it’s a sampling of otherwise unreleased tracks from 1980 to 1986
column3: ranging from full band efforts to solo recordings. There’s a sense of turning over the years
column4: whether accidentally or by coincidence: the gentle Beatles/power pop swing of songs like “Bon Temps Roulez” leads on to songs with titles like “When Fire Burns Dreams”
column5: addressing the all-too-real nuclear war fears of the time
column6: and beginning with a riff on West Side Story that concludes “Do what we’re told by America.” “Young Jobless” captures that perfect sense of peppiness in the sound
column7: rough recording in the engineering and deeply dark sentiments in the lyrics
column8: a portrayal of post-academic employment failure that rings true 30 years on. Meanwhile
column9: “It’s Been So Long” puts together the same combination with a focus on romantic frustration and yearning. Concluding with a take on the old Jeannette MacDonald chestnut “Beyond the Blue Horizon” that’s both great fun and just as yearning as the many originals
column10:
it’s a fine way to conclude another strong set from this remarkable act.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19340/homepage_large.1196e7c0.jpg|The Child of Lov|30442.0|The Child of Lov|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Double Six']|2013-06-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:07.695663|"

The Child of Lov (the “Lov” stands for “Light-Oxygen-Voltage”) is Cole Williams
column2: a 25-year-old Dutch producer and musician who has neglected to share much else about himself with us. His online presence
column3: however
column4: reveals a bit more; his <a href=""https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&ved=0CDAQFjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fthechildoflov.tumblr.com%2F&ei=Ts-rUc6ZItO04AOi1ICgBQ&usg=AFQjCNFEf8mawBsTic06dpQRhVs7srPZ_A&sig2=cz9RuRQKGn06Zr1LmlRnSA&bvm=bv.47244034
column5: d.dmg"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Tumblr tells us that he counts early-00s American R&B
column6: Woody Allen movies
column7: and pictures of beautiful famous women eating nachos as interests. We also learn that he is a self-styled reclusive perfectionist. He recently posted a note explaining to his fans that he will not be touring live in the near future
column8: despite “pressure” to accept spots at Glastonbury
column9: Bestival
column10: and others. “I’m a perfectionist
column11: and I want to translate my music to a live setting the most perfect way imaginable
column12: because I firmly and religiously believe that is what my music deserves
column13: ” he wrote.

column1: His self-titled debut album also tells us a lot about Williams. Within 30 seconds of opening track “Call Me Up” it’s immediately clear that he has a specific spiritual forebear for his get-it-right-or-not-at-all stance. His vocals are muttering
column2: multi-stacked
column3: and closely harmonized
column4: buried in the cellar of a mix crawling with dirty
column5: brambled
column6: bluesy sounds-- church organ
column7: hard RZA drum loops
column8: electric guitar licks. In short
column9: he sounds in the grip of an all-consuming D’Angelo obsession and The Child of Lov music made by someone who has listened to Voodoo every day for the past decade.

column1: He’s learned some useful things from his deep study. Williams has a wonderful ear for thick sounds
column2: and has manipulated every instrument
column3: whether it’s the dying-fluorescent-bulb synths worming through “Living the Circle” the glumly echoing surf-guitar licks of “One Day”
column4: or nylon acoustic guitar strings underpinning “Owl”. His voice
column5: in the mix
column6: sounds like it is drowning in
column7: or emerging from
column8: a vat of burbling tar. He has worked on some of this music
column9: he has said in interviews
column10: since he was 15 years old
column11: and you can hear it
column12: in a good way: Each track glows with the warmth of William’s smudge marks and eraser scuffs.

column1: The thing about Voodoo
column2: of course
column3: is that that album’s mercurial
column4: flickering spirit is so dim and private that it seems to exist independently of the music itself
column5: and scraping the patina off the album’s surface
column6: as Williams does here
column7: doesn’t leave him with much of his own to work with. The brightest spots are toward the end; he channels Prince on “Warrior” in a surprisingly clean
column8: uncluttered
column9: and devotional ballad.

column1: It should be noted that Williams has gathered some high-profile guests around him: Damon Albarn
column2: who probably also recognized a Gorillaz-sized footprint on Williams’ psyche
column3: shows up to sing some wispy background vocals on “One Day”. And DOOM
column4: not an easy guy to pin down
column5: shows up to spit some of his perfect
column6: gnomic bars over “Owl”. But they don’t do much to change the overall sense that The Child of Lov is a sound-not-the-spirit affair. After a few listens
column7: the novelty wears off and its charms flush from the system. Williams has figured out his sounds
column8:
but he’s still working towards his voice.

"|18155.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18155-the-child-of-lov-the-child-of-lov/|6.1|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19280/homepage_large.e117b531.jpg|Settle|28790.0|Disclosure|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['PMR']|2013-06-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:08.427783|"

In recent years
column2: dance music's growing mainstream prominence has led to a number of excellent debuts: SBTRKT and Holy Ghost!'s self-titled efforts
column3: Classixx's Hanging Gardens
column4: Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs' Trouble
column5: and Katy B's On a Mission
column6: to name a few. These records gained notice for recontextualizing the sounds of dance's various sub-genres-- disco
column7: dubstep
column8: house
column9: and more-- into pop-leaning structures. The latest addition to this list is Settle
column10: the brilliant debut album by Disclosure. The Surrey duo have not only made 2013's best dance record so far-- they've also concocted one of the most assured
column11: confident debuts from any genre in recent memory. That they've done so on a major-label record that's absolutely loaded with guest spots-- these are typically red flags when approaching any dance full-length with crossover potential-- is nothing short of a miracle.

column1: The brothers behind Disclosure
column2: Howard and Guy Lawrence
column3: seem impossibly young considering their talents: Guy is 21
column4: while younger brother Howard just turned 18 a few weeks ago. But they've actually been on the scene for three years
column5: and their artistic growth over that period is impressive. Back in 2010
column6: Disclosure first emerged on the blog circuit's nether regions with ""Street Light Chronicle""
column7: a slice of competent
column8: indistinct bass music that sounded like what you'd expect from a pair that have cited Burial's Untrue and Joy Orbison's ""Hyph Mngo"" as their gateways into club fare. With every succeeding release
column9: however
column10: Disclosure rapidly moved away from ""Street Light Chronicle""'s weatherbeaten greys towards a smoother
column11: brighter sound. Last year's fantastic remix of Jessie Ware's ""Running"" greatly increased both artists' profiles; earlier this year
column12: Disclosure's collaboration with AlunaGeorge singer Aluna Francis
column13: ""White Noise""
column14: rocketed to #2 on the UK Singles chart two weeks after its release. Clearly
column15: they've come a long way in a short time.

column1: A number of tracks from Disclosure's earlier releases would be considered highlights on any debut album. Two of them
column2: ""Boiling"" and ""What's in Your Head""
column3: from the enjoyable 2011 EP The Face
column4: are relegated to bonus track status on Settle's deluxe edition. That such strong material didn't make the album proper speaks to its high quality. Over its hour-long runtime
column5: Settle features an masterful sense of pacing
column6: from the jacking propulsion of ""When a Fire Starts to Burn"" to the album's sweeping closer
column7: ""Help Me Lose My Mind"". Dance music's long had a fickle relationship with the album format
column8: but Settle's impeccable sequencing leads to an album that begs to be heard in its entirety.

column1: Settle's playful
column2: high-energy attitude is sometimes reminiscent of Remedy
column3: Basement Jaxx's star-making 1999 debut. The duos share divisive tendencies: Jaxx's brash and hyper-active production style rubs some the wrong way
column4: and Disclosure have been called out for their clear debt to established UK dance styles. Specifically
column5: Disclosure have been charged with riding the resurgence of the syncopated
column6: R&B-infused gait of late 1990s/early 2000s 2-step and UK Garage touchstones like MJ Cole's ""Sincere"" and Hardrive's ""Deep Inside""; last month
column7: they released an answer-song remix of 2-step kings Artful Dodger's ""Please Don't Turn Me On""-- and this after after UKG veteran El-B offered his own dusty take on ""Boiling"" late last year
column8: making the inspiration explicit.

column1: The skepticism is understandable
column2: to a point. UK dance culture has long prided itself on pushing things forward
column3: and Disclosure's arrival on the scene-- not to mention bass music's current retro-fixated house excursions-- marks the first time in many years that the freshest dance sounds from across the pond sound a little second-hand. Ultimately though
column4: complaining about young artists reviving sounds that they weren't around to experience the first time around is futile. We're a few years into an era where talented musicians are discovering influences new and old not through direct interaction with scenes but through their computers. And when the execution is this accomplished
column5: it's hard to get too hung up on the source material. Some of Settle's giddiest highlights are clear UKG callbacks-- ""Voices"" and ""You & Me""
column6: especially-- but Disclosure refuse to stick to any single genre. They effortlessly spin through romantic house (""Defeated No More""
column7: ""F For You"")
column8: pitch-screwed bass music (""Second Chance"")
column9: and raunchy grime-inflected motifs (""Confess to Me""); nothing is off limits
column10: and Settle is all the better for it.

column1: For all its dance trappings
column2: Settle is a pop record first and foremost
column3: one that feels remarkably inclusive. The handful of male-led vocal cuts range from solid (Friendly Fires vocalist Ed MacFarlane's sultry take on ""Defeated No More""
column4: Jamie Woon's emotive pleading on ""January"") to showstopping (the indelible
column5: effusive ""Latch""
column6: Howard Lawrence's surprisingly effective turn on ""F for You"")
column7: but Settle's array of female voices are the record's nucleus. While a few notable names are used in surprising fashion-- folk-pop singer Lianne La Havas' effusive
column8: bleated samples on ""Stimulation""
column9: Jessie Ware's muted moves on ""Confess to Me""-- the biggest star turns come from up-and-comers like Sasha Keable and London Grammar's Hannah Reid
column10: who shares a co-writing credit on ""Help Me Lose My Mind"". While listening to Settle
column11: James Blake's 2011 quote about U.S. dubstep's ""frat-boy market"" came to mind; in 2013
column12: it could be argued that such aggressively chauvinistic attitudes pervade many areas of big-tent dance culture
column13: and it's hard not to hear Settle's wide-reaching accessibility as a potential antidote to the trend.

column1: Skirting dance's more bass-heavy strands
column2: Disclosure take a spare approach to sampling throughout Settle. They lift a few stray sounds from Kelis and Slum Village and
column3: most curiously
column4: motivational speaker and self-proclaimed ""hip-hop preacher"" Eric Thomas
column5: whose impassioned delivery is featured on the album's intro as well as ""When a Fire Starts to Burn"". The video for the latter brings the sample to life visually and it turns out to be a strange reflection of its source material. As was recently noted
column6: dance music's history contains frequent intersections
column7: ideological and otherwise
column8: with religion. Much like when dance-pop alchemists Hot Chip released their own devotional to the dancefloor in the form of last year's stellar In Our Heads
column9: Settle's appeal ultimately owes something to its spiritual tinge. Disclosure's unabashed pop sensibilities speak to the notion that music
column10: as with a system of beliefs
column11: can bring a diverse array of people-- the dance nerds and the poptimists
column12: the club denizens and the festival obsessives
column13: the perpetually stylish and the utterly clueless-- together as one. Settle is an album-length articulation of this idea
column14:
and it's hard not to believe in that.

"|18091.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18091-disclosure-settle/|9.1|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19275/homepage_large.1ec7221b.jpg|The Devil Put Dinosaurs Here|28049.0|Alice in Chains|['Rock'
column3:
'Capitol']|2013-06-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:09.921134|"

Alice in Chains were one of the most successful grunge acts of the 1990s
column4: but they were also one of the most derided. They started life as a glam-derived metal band
column5: for which they were dismissed by the same people who embraced Seattle’s other big glam-derived metal band
column6: Mother Love Bone. Layne Staley’s drug metaphors and horror-show vocals made hits out of “Man in the Box” and “Would?” but he could often sound self-satisfied regarding his addictions
column7: which ultimately made it difficult for them to tour. If Alice in Chains staked its popularity on the still-vital Dirt in 1992
column8: they maintained it with an MTV Unplugged album. As a band
column9: they never possessed the metal chops of Soundgarden
column10: or the arena-punk populism of Pearl Jam
column11: or the self-torturing sound of Nirvana. As an influence on subsequent bands
column12: they are arguably responsible for mook-metal acts like Puddle of Mudd
column13: codifying self-absorption as a viable rock'n'roll stance.

column1: Even after Staley’s OD in 2002
column2: it’s no real surprise that Alice in Chains are still around-- there’s always cash in nostalgia-- but it is a surprise that the band's latest album actually sounds like they're trying to move forward rather than rest on their dubious laurels. Despite its very 1990s red jewel case and its trollable title
column3: The Devil Put Dinosaurs Here is actually a solid mainstream rock album: more inventive than it needs to be
column4: and less self-congratulatory in its intense introspection. That’s due to new vocalist William DuVall
column5: who approximates Staley's blared sneer but actually has more expressive range. And mostly it’s due to Jerry Cantrell
column6: the guitar player
column7: chief songwriter
column8: and arguably the brains behind the band for 20 years now.

column2: this new line-up made the tortured-but-determined Black Gives Way to Blue
column3: which lacked the desperation of a typical comeback record. In retrospect
column4: that album sounds like a warm-up for Dinosaurs
column5: which sounds more confident and concentrated than its predecessor. The hooks sounds more insistent
column6: the guitars grind harder
column7: and the songwriting sounds almost extroverted at times. The title track is one of Alice in Chains’ most politicized songs to date
column8: a God’s-eye-view of religious extremism in America and a quick glimpse back at the spiritual doubts that infected “Man in the Box”. “The devil put dinosaurs here
column9: ” DuVall sings as the guitars quake and rumble
column10: as though the bottom were falling out of the song. “No problem with faith
column11: just fear.”

column1: That song is six-and-a-half minutes long. It doesn’t need to be. Chop it in half and you could double its impact. But the same could be said of just about any track on Dinosaurs
column2: which typically lumber past the five-minute mark. The result is an album that feels much longer than its bloated 70 minutes
column3: that often buries its best moments
column4: that exhausts its most intriguing ideas either by stretching them out or simply repeating them. On the other hand
column5: Dinosaurs actually does have some intriguing ideas to exhaust
column6: mostly about how you play mainstream rock in 2013. Rather than foreground crunching guitars
column7: “Pretty Done” and “Voices” build their riffs piecemeal out of bent and tortured notes that fit together in jigsaw fashion. The technique approximates melody but conveys mood precisely. That’s what makes first single “Stone” so effective: You’re a full minute or so in before you realize just how smart and menacing its central guitar riff is
column8: or how it slyly establishes an atmosphere of subtle aggression.

column1: In other words
column2: Alice in Chains would rather sneak up on you than attack you with blunt force. That serves a fairly boilerplate anthem like “Scalpel” especially well as it builds quickly from an acoustic intro to an extroverted chorus that in concert likely prompts a few raised lighters. On the other hand
column3: Dinosaurs loses some of its stomp toward the end
column4: with the by-the-numbers “Phantom Limb” and the plodding “Hung on a Hook” sounding more like what you’d expect from Alice in Chains 20 years after their heyday. So it’s as insistent as Dirt
column5: but it’s also not as superfluous as
column6: for example
column7: Soundgarden’s recent reunion record. Instead
column8:
Dinosaurs is a testament to how 90s alt-rock angst can translate meaningfully to middle age. 

"|18086.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18086-alice-in-chains-the-devil-put-dinosaurs-here/|5.9|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19270/homepage_large.3b7e2dd9.jpg|Modern Worship|29058.0|Hyetal|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['True Panther']|2013-06-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:10.569862|"

While Hyetal heralds from Bristol’s once-booming dubstep scene
column2: his sound is hardly about the blow of his bass. David Corney’s production style pulls drum patterns from hip-hop and micro-genres of dance
column3: and grooves along the sort of 1980s synth palette that inspires skipping wanderlust instead of dark-cornered club moves. In interviews the DJ earnestly explains that the exploratory landscapes found in his music are a direct result of specific visions; his 2011 solo debut Broadcast was fashioned around the reverberant sounds of an empty city at night. Modern Worship holds a distanced but telescopic gaze upon the same concreted jungle.

column1: A few aesthetic elements have stayed with Hyetal since he first started making waves in 2009. He has always favored the texturalization of contemporary beats
column2: often accompanied by a glossy sheen with traces of a slowly developed melody. But where Broadcast was more atmospheric and watercolor-like
column3: Modern Worship is a sharper
column4: more clearly drawn picture. Here are purposeful stints of two-step
column5: or footwork
column6: or bursts of the type of sub-bass and skittering tension that his peers Peverelist and Kowton would be proud of
column7: aggressively pushed to the fore. His punches hit harder; on “Lake Rider” a waterfall of chimes drift into a mass of echoes
column8: every new melodic phrase piercing through the last. “Jam the Network” uses stabby
column9: inflated reverb to force the song along. Throwback videogame samples are looped into mocking
column10: futuristic lightshows on “Forefathers” and “1000 Lights”
column11: with a frenzied flair that’s not so different from that of Rustie.

column1: With all of his IDM tricks and dream pop worship
column2: Corney’s sound often feels like it reaches for a broader and more deliberate pop agenda. When trying too hard to get there
column3: he sometimes falls into a trap of synthy sameness; it’s his weirder moments that succeed. Broadcast’s standout track “Phoenix” could have been an under-the-radar hat-tip to ""Miami Vice""’s iconic theme song. As Velour
column4: his dance outfit with fellow Bristol producer Julio Bashmore
column5: he flipped an EP of purple-tinted boogie: “Booty Slammer” sampled the tiniest snippet of Whitney Houston’s “So Emotional”. Neither of those tracks felt as easily suited for a dancefloor as they were roadtrips and headphones. Similarly
column6: the best of Modern Worship comes when collaborative vocalist Gwilym Gold appears (on “Northwest Passage” and “Left”) and the singer’s vague
column7: romantic croons offer the most engaging and emotionally poignant moments on the album.

column1: It’s possible that some of what seems like a confident stride towards the future on Modern Worship is simply a change in Corney’s equilibrium; subtle progressions are less revered than in the past
column2: drums are crisper
column3: synths shine brighter
column4: and vocalists wade through instrumentals instead of singing on top of them. It recalls a certain era of pop ideals: New Order’s early synth pop ambitions and the alt-rock dreaminess of Cocteau Twins are the first to come to mind when met with “Northwest Passage” or “The City Is Ours”
column5: where vocalist Alison Garner serves alongside Gold in an Elizabeth Fraser-style role. Hyetal has a firm grasp on his spin of sweeping
column6: beat-infected sentimentality
column7: and Modern Worship is strong enough to see him lead a crowd
column8:
or keep dancing on his own.

"|18081.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18081-hyetal-modern-worship/|7.0|Puja Patel

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19322/homepage_large.207a8fc9.jpg|Anarchic Breezes|31384.0|Grim Tower|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Outer Battery']|2013-06-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:11.130776|"

From afar
column2: Imaad Wasif and Stephen McBean certainly seem like kindred spirits
column3: two cool-headed psychedelic warriors conjuring expansive sounds for expanded minds. Wasif
column4: still probably best known for his work with the Yeah Yeah Yeahs
column5: and McBean-- of Black Mountain and Pink Mountaintops-- are collaborators at heart. Their new project
column6: so-called ""New Acoustic Death Folk"" ensemble Grim Tower
column7: got its start in McBean's backyard as he and Wasif strummed away an afternoon on a bunch of curiously detuned guitars. Alongside Rob Barbato and Dan Allaire-- rhythm section of L.A. droners Darker My Love-- Wasif and McBean fleshed out those initial back patio tapes into the meditative thrum of Anarchic Breezes.

column1: Where transcendence is concerned
column2: Anarchic Breezes talks a good game; lyrically
column3: you've got your cities in the clouds
column4: your soothsayer-encircled pyramids
column5: pretty standard takeaways from one mystical journey or another. The playing's beautiful
column6: rich and unshowy
column7: as impressive in its technique as its reserve. The title track
column8: a delicate
column9: instinctive duet
column10: might be the best thing here
column11: their playing at once meticulous and moving; McBean's ""Let Death Become Your Comfort""
column12: its guitars wavering in the heat like Tinariwen
column13: is a close second. Produced by McBean and Rob Campanella of the Quarter After and mixed by Mark Nevers in Nashville
column14: it's a gorgeous recording
column15: crisp and spacious
column16: with just the right amount of embellishment. The trouble is in the songs. Most of Anarchic Breezes unfurls slowly
column17: solemnly even
column18: their droning strums and delicate fingerpicking eventually giving way to weighty choruses about the nature of things before retreating into the ether. Between its all-too-deliberate pace and McBean and Wasif's unusually graven delivery
column19: Anarchic Breezes is kind of a slog; The spontaneity that initially sparked these songs is long gone
column20: replaced with a kind of every-note-in-place perfection that doesn't exactly get the blood going.

column1: Still
column2: Breezes' occasionally exacting music is a far easier pill to swallow than its pie-eyed lyrics. Wasif
column3: in particular
column4: seems a bit lost amidst the tangerine trees and marmalade skies: as if the Egyptian time-traveler who spends his days ""talking pyramids and getting stoned"" in ""All the Beautiful Things"" weren't enough
column5: the songs centers around a sorta-chorus of ""get hiiiiigh."" ""Blue""
column6: though less explicitly moony
column7: still manages to grate
column8: imparting a kind of wisdom that confuses more than it clarifies: ""Circle dot
column9: circle dot
column10: goes its unhelpful chorus
column11: ""You can't give what you ain't got."" McBean
column12: for his part
column13: gets in a few ruminations on mortality that at least give you a little more to chew on. Even so
column14: ""Leaving My Old Life Behind"" finds him above the clouds
column15: beyond the sun
column16: using physical highness as a metaphor for
column17: well
column18: you know. Even the less druggy stuff is delivered in something like hushed tones
column19: lending the whole thing a ""this'll blow your mind"" portentousness that doesn't quite sit right with the less-than-mindblowing revelations they've brought back from beyond the bardo.

column1: Anarchic Breezes is in many ways a modest record
column2: charting out a few very specific music ideas in a thoughtful
column3: if not exactly dazzling
column4: fashion. <span>It's beautiful
column5: but rigidly so; hypnotic
column6: but without the kind of intensity that'll hold you rapt
column7: more about gathering energies than letting them loose. On their higher-profile releases
column8: Wasif and McBean have proven themselves to be quite good at making grand gestures in their music seem huge without teetering over into grandiosity. Grim Tower turns that balance upside down
column9: the ponderous nature of its lyrics overpowering the subtleties of its music. Anarchic Breezes does open up a bit after a few listens
column10: but I'm still not entirely sure that's a good thing; with every spin
column11: the music seems to grow more delicate
column12: which just sends all those Castenada-core lyrics into starker relief. Occasionally plodding
column13: and too ruminative by half
column14: Anarchic Breezes is a journey in need of a destination
column15:
stuck between staring at the sun and gazing thoughtfully at its own navel.

"|18136.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18136-grim-tower-anarchic-breezes/|5.3|Paul Thompson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19328/homepage_large.329a0c79.jpg|The Ways We Separate|30627.0|Beacon|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ghostly']|2013-06-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:11.795739|"

There’s no shortage of talented vocalists and songwriters tinkering with the DNA of R&B these days; from the zeitgeisty mainstream and critical appeal of Frank Ocean and Miguel
column2: to the avant-minimalist soul and dance music of AlunaGeorge
column3: How to Dress Well
column4: and Rhye
column5: the thematic standards and compositional tropes of R&B are providing a healthy hotbed for experimentation. Over their short existence
column6: Brooklyn-based duo Beacon-- comprised of vocalist and producer Thomas Mullarney and producer Jacob Gossett-- have staked out their own corner R&B by imbuing pristinely constructed
column7: slow-burning ballads with the murky
column8: bass-blaring darkness of trip-hop and Warp Records' output ca. the early 1990s.

column1: Their first two EPs arrived on Ghostly International in late 2012-- No Body
column2: originally released on Moodgadget in 2011
column3: in August and For Now in October-- and showcased a handful of shimmering
column4: anti-love songs reverberating with cavernous production and Mullarney’s chilly croon
column5: which shapeshifted from sensual to toxically dominant from one line to the next. No Body and For Now also made it apparent that the duo’s vision was diamond-sharp right out of the gate; similar to Abel Tesfaye’s narcotic disillusionment as the Weeknd
column6: they wanted to plumb the searing emotional damage and existential fallout from the desperate need for love through the lens of a genre usually reserved for passionate
column7: sexual yearning. There’s a friction that’s generated from twisting R&B’s usual forms into something considerably more lurid and ambiguous that was evident in the song “No Body”
column8: the first EP’s highlight
column9: when Mullarney coos the casually sinister refrain
column10: “I’ll follow you home
column11: so you won’t be alone.”

column1: And now
column2: with their first full length album <i>The Ways We Separate
column3: Beacon attempt to narrow in tighter on a particular kind of romantic wreckage
column4: using their expansive
column5: ravey R&B to focus on the ways in which we grow together and grow apart
column6: connecting and disconnecting
column7: over and over. It isn’t so much a breakup album as a document of the emotional decay and guilt that arrives when the bonds forged in a relationship become noxious. Sonically
column8: Mullarney and Gosset have pushed their atmospheric
column9: bass-heavy compositions into larger spaces
column10: building off the template they constructed for the quiet disintegration of “Feeling’s Gone”
column11: the lone track from the EPs to make the album. Here
column12: the duo have crafted syncopated webs of keyboards
column13: interspersed with distorted breakbeats
column14: to circle Mullarney’s breathy tenor as he sketches a last ditch grasp at reconciliation that has since soured into cheap sexual dependence: “The feeling’s gone/ You waited for too long/ But if you just stayed tonight/ We could find some more.”

column1: “Feeling’s Gone” is part of the album’s strong opening phalanx
column2: which in turn makes Ways feel a little frontloaded. “Bring You Back” glimmers with cascading synth arpeggios that slowly coalesce into a cacophony of clockwork chimes
column3: even while Mullarney skirts around murky lyrics that never manage to harden for emotional impact. The tar-black trip-hop duet of “Drive” and “Between the Waves” both recall the low
column4: dark rumble of Massive Attack’s Mezzanine with Mullarney’s vocals even hovering around the same register as Horace Andy
column5: the Bristol group’s frequent collaborator. “Between the Waves” in particular slowly brews into a thick storm system of spiraling bass whomps
column6: skittering drum hits
column7: and trancey
column8: seasick synths
column9: as Mullarney digs through the resignation of a coupling that has slowly faded into oblivion
column10: struggling against the numb inertia of indifference as if it’s a rip tide: “Of all the ways we separate/ Where we start to fade at different frequencies/ I could compensate
column11: try to fill the space/ Only to suffocate between the waves.”

column1: The album’s second half suffers slightly simply because it seems like Mullarney and Gosset run out of fuel for their intense slow burn
column2: with the production
column3: melodies
column4: and lyrics not quite matching the inventiveness
column5: and emotional wallop
column6: of Ways’ opening salvo. The disjointed malaise and lyrical opacity of “Studio Audience” along with the undeniably pretty but slight “Headlights” (which ends up sounding like a wilted xx cover) both seem dormant compared to the quiet
column7: devastating ruptures of “Between the Waves” and “Feeling’s Gone”. Regardless of the inconsistencies
column8: The Ways We Separate still leaves its mark. With three releases in the past eight months alone
column9: it’s exciting to watch as Thomas Mullarney and Jacob Gosset continue to sharpen their vision
column10: using their dark
column11:
slickly composed R&B to explore the treacherous rifts and chasms that gradually form in human relationships.

"|18142.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18142-beacon-the-ways-we-separate/|6.8|Patrick Bowman

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19276/homepage_large.d452370d.jpg|Like Clockwork|3494.0|Queens of the Stone Age|['Rock'
column2:
'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2013-06-03 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:12.287196|"

Deep into the new Queens of the Stone Age album
column3: Josh Homme blithely declares
column4: “I blow my load over the status quo.” Missions statements don’t come cockier than that. But Homme can get away with it because the status quo he’s referring to could easily be his own band. Since launching Queens of the Stone Age from the ashes of the almighty Kyuss in 1998
column5: Homme has treated hard rock and metal as soluble materials; his band’s music is mercurial
column6: its membership highly fluid.

column1: By QOTSA's unconventional standards
column2: a six-year layoff between albums doesn’t even feel like an unusually long hiatus
column3: but more like the natural amount of time it takes for a new incarnation of this ever-shifting band to settle into place. Of course
column4: Homme was never far from the headlines in the interim: He’s done everything from form a new band with a member of Led Zeppelin to produce an underrated Arctic Monkeys record
column5: serif;""> to survive a near-death experience. Along the way
column6: the Queens have shed long-time members (Joey Castillo
column7: whose departure was announced partway through the ...Like Clockwork sessions; he appears on four tracks) and reacquainted themselves with some old friends: Songs For the Deaf-era sticksman Dave Grohl
column8: go-to growler Mark Lanegan
column9: and
column10: most surprisingly
column11: Nick Oliveri
column12: who was ousted from the band in 2004 (and in the ensuing years
column13: narrowly avoided jail time for domestic violence
column14: drugs
column15: and firearm-related offences). All the while
column16: Homme lined up a guest list for ...Like Clockwork-- including Scissor Sisters' Jake Shears
column17: Arctic Monkeys’ Alex Turner
column18: U.N.K.L.E.'s James Lavelle
column19: and even Sir Elton John-- that threatened to make the band’s previous revolving-door records seem grossly under-populated.

column1: But if all that suggests a return to the scatterbrained lunacy of the band’s early-2000s releases-- and the band’s exodus from Interscope to Matador would seemingly encourage a left-field foray-- ...Like Clockwork presents another curveball. Queens of the Stone Age’s first album for an indie since their debut is actually more polished and melodically focused than anything they ever released on a major; you’d be hard pressed to classify 80 per cent of it as hard rock. But ...Like Clockwork simply foregrounds an aspect that’s been lingering in the Queens’ music since the beginning: beneath all that volcanic riffage
column2: Homme has always been a sucker for a pretty pop song.

column1: Queens have flashed their softer side before-- see: Rated R’s “In the Fade”
column2: or Era Vulgaris’ “Make It Witchu”-- but there’s always been a self-consciousness about their slow jams
column3: like someone not unsubtly dimming the lights and pretending to stretch their arm to sidle up closer to their date. ...Like Clockwork
column4: however

column10: “I’ve got bruises and hickeys

column8:
it kicks like a mule even when it dresses like a queen.

Whatever you think about Centipede Hz
column3: it definitely sounded like the work of a band that was on its own path. Since raising their profile considerably after the breakthrough album Merriweather Post Pavilion and maintaining that amount of accessibility on the subsequent Fall Be Kind EP
column4: the material Animal Collective have released since-- from the “visual album” ODDSAC to the live box Animal Crack Box to the solo efforts from Panda Bear and Avey Tare-- has not pandered. And Centipede Hz continued the trend
column5: taking the band’s most distinctive elements-- yelping vocals
column6: busy production-- and amplifying them.

column1: Every Animal Collective full-length since Sung Tongs has been followed by a companion EP. A couple of these
column2: like Fall Be Kind and Prospect Hummer
column3: rank among the highlights in Animal Collective’s catalogue. Others
column4: like the People EP and this one

column6: Monkey Been to Burn Town is a collection of four remixes
column7: three of Centipede’s “Monkey Riches” and a version of “New Town Burnout” by Shabazz Palaces.

column1: One of the challenges of Centipede was the dense
column2: midrange-heavy production
column3: so a couple of tracks on Monkey give you a chance to hear the song with a different backdrop. The Teengirl Fantasy remix of “Monkey Riches” isn’t exactly minimal
column4: but there is a certain amount of space and clarity in their bright electronic mix
column5: and it leans toward bass. So the hook of the song’s central refrain seems just a little catchier
column6: and lately when I imagine the song this is the version that sticks into my head. Brian DeGraw of Gang Gang Dance applies his band’s feel for industrial funk to the song. It’s even leaner and more stripped down
column7: with a lopping slide guitar riff and a stop-start 2-step beat
column8: but he seems to be listening to what the song is doing and finds appropriate tweaks to its verse/chorus dynamics. Finally
column9: Chicago-based footwork producer Traxman offers the most radical interpretation of the three
column10: upping the tempo and adding a 4/4 thump and turning a few of the song’s original elements into a ghostly swirl that serves mostly as a tint for the beats.

column1: Once in a while a remix comes along that changes how you hear a song or makes you want to reach for it rather than the original; none of these get there. But the Shabazz Palaces version of “New Town Burnout” has the advantage of being basically a cover/extension rather than a remix. So Shabazz Palaces’ Ishmael Butler voices Panda Bear’s words and turns them into a downcast gothic chant as snippets from the song are re-arranged
column2: and then he takes the song much further out
column3: with new lyrics and a new refrain. The Shabazz Palaces cut is easily the most interesting song here
column4: and seems to be the one you might still be pulling out once in a while in another six months. Considering that the EP
column5: with three versions of the same song in a row
column6: isn’t really meant to be heard as a whole
column7:
getting one truly intriguing track out of it isn’t such a bad deal.

Laura Marling has spent the first few years of her career in a state of perpetual arrival. Alas I Cannot Swim-- her 2008 debut
column2: made when she was 18-- was a bright
column3: brooding collection that set her up as the darling of the latest British folk revival and saw her nominated for the Mercury Music Prize; a feat she repeated with 2010's more polished I Speak Because I Can. On 2011's sprawling A Creature I Don’t Know

column5: sharpening vision. With each release

column7: deft melodysmith
column8: butterfly wing-fingered guitarist-- continued to reveal themselves so steadily as to have a lulling effect
column9: like waves hitting some shoreline where it’s always high tide. But now here comes Once I Was An Eagle

column11: hard-won achievement. It’s expansive and ambitious
column12: and divorced of all the tweedy preening and aw-shucks raggediness the idea of “folk” has accumulated in recent years. It's dark
column13: it’s angry
column14: it’s even sexy
column15: in a sly

column1: Once I Was An Eagle marks another
column2: more literal departure: Making the record in producer Ethan John’s countryside studio was one of Marling's last acts as a full-time Brit. Whether she had plotted her move from London to Los Angeles before she wrote the album isn’t clear

column7: examines every scrap and trinket

column9: she took barely any of her possessions to LA.)

column5: carried out under the ever-present pall of mortality
column6: ” maybe closer. As a lyricist

column9: and executed so supremely that sussing out the “real” from the “unreal” has always seemed beside the point. But this one feels personal in ways the others haven’t; the “I” of the songs is not always clear

column11: but seems closer than ever to being Marling’s own self.

column1: Eagle was made over 10 days
column2: with just a cellist and Johns (on carefully-placed drums
column3: piano
column4: organ) providing accompaniment; Marling recorded her vocal and guitar parts in a single take each
column5: and in one day
column6: though it somehow sounds even more immediate. Present in both her singing and her playing is a ferocity that now seems to have been lurking there all along; at times
column7: too
column8: she’s possessed by a newly emergent serenity
column9: and an astonishing ability to shift between the two modes. This is especially evident on Eagle’s opening tracks
column10: four songs written as a proper suite and a fifth that feels equally of a piece. Together they seamlessly
column11: almost imperceptibly
column12: build from somnambulant finger-picked acoustic to a wild fury of howling cello and frantic tabla-style percussion
column13: “Take the Night Off” leading it off the way a rainshower usually precedes a hurricane; by “Master Hunter”
column14: the suite's cap

column2: out of which creatures and names and scraps of ideas turn up over and over: birds and beasts
column3: the devil
column4: water-- and
column5: most prominently

column8: the same man: her “freewheeling troubadour
column9: ” the dove to her eagle. Some amount of drama has transpired offstage

column12: indicts him

column14: always stopping short of apology
column15: not even allowing herself to playact the rites of guilt.

column1: Later
column2: after the sparse chill of “Interlude”

column5: a figure perhaps understandable as some fragment of who Marling might have been before all this began. On “Little Bird”

Rogue Wave’s past decade has been defined by two reputations that seem unrelated on the surface. The first is that they excel at a kind of jangly
column3: chiming
column4: and softly anthemic iteration of indie rock that made a lot of television music supervisors’ jobs easier in the mid-2000s. The other is that the Oakland band has incredibly shitty luck. Rogue Wave does everything earnestly
column5: and in the last couple of years
column6: they’ve tried in earnest to shed these reputations. And they’ve not found much success. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column7: serif;"">On ""Chicago x 12
column8: a single from 2007's Asleep at Heaven's Gate
column9: Zach Rogue expressed the dissonance between his band's critical acclaim and their demoralizing tours with one heartbreaking line: ""it don't matter/cause no one comes out to see us."" More pointedly
column10: 2010’s Permalight was a slick dance-pop rebranding
column11: an admirable strategy that unfortunately played to none of the band's strengths and created no new ones. Newly signed to Vagrant Records
column12: Nightingale Floors arrives with Rogue Wave bearing acceptance of who they are: they’ve made a good record of jangly
column13: chiming
column14: and softly anthemic indie rock. And in 2013
column15: that makes it a record with exceptionally poor timing.

column1: Opener “No Magnatone” serves as a mission statement for Nightingale Floors even if doesn’t actually say very much. It’s a wisp of a song
column2: little more than a ringing guitar figure and Zach Rogue’s soft
column3: strangely enunciated vocals moving together in shuffle time. It lets you know Rogue Wave have readjusted their mechanics and
column4: immediately after
column5: “College” proves to be the first time they’ve truly connected in years. It bears all the characteristics of Rogue Wave’s slightly cracked and wholly tuneful past highlights: snappy
column6: major key melodies disguising depressive lyrics
column7: enthusiastic strummed acoustic guitars backing singing electric leads
column8: verse-chorus structures nudged by off-kilter time signatures. Nightingale Floors positions itself as the logical next step for Rogue Wave had the ill-fated Permalight been replaced by Come Back to Us
column9: the solo album Rogue put out in 2011 as Release the Sunbird. The gorgeous
column10: kinda mushy “The Closer I Get” hearkens back to Come Back’s emotionally and instrumentally naked folk pop and serves as a retroactive advertisement for an album that mostly went overlooked.

column1: John Congleton’s typically holistic and crisp production forces Rogue Wave to ensure the underlying song structures of “Siren’s Song” and “Used to It” can support their ambitions of multi-tiered builds and swelling crescendos. They succeed in those instances
column2: but elsewhere
column3: you’re reminded that Asleep at Heaven's Gate's weaknesses weren’t just a result of puffy production or unmet arena-rock aspirations. As Rogue continually dials down the tempos or broadens song length
column4: he hasn't compensated for them with melody; even the quieter
column5: acoustic moments on Rogue Wave’s first two records were briskly performed
column6: so even if they didn’t pop
column7: they at least fizzed. Eight-minute closer “Everyone Wants to Be You” aside
column8: Nightingale Floors is compact and centered enough to avoid drift; it just goes through enough unmemorable
column9: mid-tempo patches to remind you why so many listeners and artists sought out more rhythmically exciting sounds at a time when post-Shins indie rock loomed large.

column1: It’d be unfair to judge Nightingale Floors within the context of prevailing trends that are out of Rogue Wave’s control if they it didn’t appear to be such a pervasive concern for Zach Rogue himself. How could they not be? “The gravity of career ambition/ Never meant that much to me
column2: ” Rogue shrugs on “Figured it Out”
column3: though it would appear there’s an implication of denial. The occasional hints at familial disappointments on “Used to It”
column4: unfulfilled ambitions on “College”
column5: and resigned acceptance elsewhere suggest Rogue hasn’t lost his self-awareness
column6: that being themselves probably won’t make Rogue Wave any bigger than they were when they wrote “Chicago x12”. But maybe the rooms will be smaller and the crowds more appreciative. Nightingale Floors isn’t a confessional
column7: nor is it a cry for help
column8:
but an attempt to be the acceptance Rogue wants to see in the world-- a modest record of modest aims from a songwriter coming to terms with his current station.

If you’ve listened much at all to Norway’s Shining
column3: you’ve likely learned not to be surprised by their ceaseless surprises. For more than a decade
column4: the band has often functioned as a pinball ricocheting between musical enthusiasms with delightful unpredictability. Initially a jazz band
column5: they’ve since shot between psychedelic and progressive rock
column6: spasmodic noise and iron-fisted metal
column7: ostensibly directed by little more than mercury and whimsy.

column1: After four albums
column2: though
column3: 2010’s radical Blackjazz­-- their public and aesthetic breakthrough
column4: all at once-- showed that their path had been
column5: if not deliberate
column6: then not without its instructive moments. That previous decade
column7: Blackjazz proclaimed
column8: had been one of stepwise accretion
column9: where all the heavy metal and free jazz
column10: long-form experiments and stylistic adventures had gathered around the core of charismatic producer and frontman Jørgen Munkeby and pliable drummer Torstein Lofthus. Suddenly
column11: they were able to mine all of those past sounds for an album that could not sit still. In 57 minutes
column12: they jerked from Naked City-speed eruptions to Ministry-sized beatings
column13: from Meshuggah-bordering technicality to Melvins-dumb lumber. Hell
column14: they ended with a King Crimson cover. If you didn’t come to expect surprises
column15: you’d come to deal with whiplash
column16: vertigo
column17: or nausea soon enough.

column1: But any record as adventurous and idea-saturated as Blackjazz creates a de facto albatross for the band that’s made it: Hit repeat
column2: and you’ve made yourself obsolete. Push the hybridization to the limits again
column3: and you run the risk of becoming merely tedious. (See Shining’s collaborators in Enslaved for a case in point.) So on One One One
column4: their first studio LP since Blackjazz
column5: Shining has smartly pulled back and inward
column6: delivering nine incredibly understandable but willfully baroque modern rock singles in about 36 minutes. Rather than find several dozen new ways to surprise
column7: Shining landed upon just one-- trim the excess
column8: forego the over-involved lyrical complications
column9: and make a rock’n’roll record. One One One likely won’t rearrange anyone’s imaginations regarding how much motion a band can fit into one album
column10: but it does lift the veil of obtusity from Shining
column11: a band that’s suddenly as good at songs as they have been at suites.

column1: One One One opens with a short squall of guitar noise and an immediate drum groove
column2: funneling into a verse that runs with the same italicized spirit as most any rock number you’ll find along the FM dial. Roaring keyboards and chugging riffs swell beneath Munkeby’s hook
column3: pushing the signal outward. It’s just one of several instantly memorable numbers here: “Walk Away” is little more than a series of refrains
column4: with Munkeby repeating the title over a tech-metal riff by way of mere introduction. By the song’s end

column8: making music best analyzed from some safe distance. They are making visceral
column9: economical anthems
column10: meant to be felt first and fussed over later.

column1: To that last point
column2: though
column3: these songs do brim with the sort of compositional depth that’s now expected from Shining
column4: even if they take a while to tease out. “The One Inside”
column5: for instance
column6: seems to get stuck on a drum roll at one point

column8: the bass steps on top of and away from the groove

column11: just in delightfully compact form. Speaking of saxophone

These complications make the song no less direct; they simply make it something you’ll want to listen to again and again.

column3: for a decade

column5: Shining soon shifted toward its complicated machinations. “I started rediscovering metal
column6: ” he listened. “I listened to my old stuff

column8: and then I started discovering newer stuff like Marilyn Manson and Nine Inch Nails.” That sort of joyous newness defines both Blackjazz and One One One

the surprises likely aren’t over.

When it arrived in 2007
column2: Italians Do It Better's After Dark compilation provided a way forward. ""Italo survived electroclash
column3: wrote Marc Hogan; indie rock had too. Six years later
column4: dance music has pervaded that genre to the point where discussing specific movements no longer feels relevant; it's just there

column1: There's always been a factory feel to Italians Do It Better

column2: reminding us that while some strains of classic dance music were meticulous and expert
column3: many were cheap and quick. Jewel's ability to pump out quality tracks with a host of collaborators connects him to the faceless electro/disco producers of the 1980s; presenting the tracks as glammy punk-noir fantasies contemporizes him. Jewel is an expert stylist
column4: able to project fashionable cool without exclusivity or mightiness. Never more so than on After Dark 2; the songs here are big and warm
column5: tighter

column5: but ""The Possessed"" and ""Beautiful Object"" deliver pleasantly sighing choruses. Chromatics sound at home on the wistful ""Cherry""

column1: It's in this context that contributions from Farah-- severe and menacing-- and Desire-- easy and sweet-- can be lovely diversions
column2: and that instrumentals from Mike Simonetti and Jewel (as Symmetry) can feel like luxe interludes. The vocoder funk of Mirage's ""Let's Kiss"" and Twisted Wire's husky piano house offer crucial variety. Lesser lights are afforded the opportunity to be lesser

which remains a hugely attractive mode.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19253/homepage_large.c8d86cf0.jpg|False Idols|4285.0|Tricky|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['K7']|2013-05-31 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:15.814988|"

I wouldn't blame Tricky if he was sick of hearing about the 1990s. It's the decade where he set up his presence
column2: released his defining works
column3: and then noisily tried to escape. That he spent the last dozen years of his career stumbling into the kind of modern rock/indie pop territory that didn't mesh well with his early aesthetic says something about how definitive (and potentially imprisoning) his fame-making sound was. Whether or not his genre-hopping would've worked out on its own terms-- and for the most part
column4: it hasn't-- it'd have a hard time maintaining the moody
column5: seductive yet stressed pull of his first few albums. But Tricky wasn't wrong to try shaking his trip-hop rep and attempt new things
column6: he just sounded so adrift that it was hard to figure out where he'd find his way back to once he finally refocused. By the time he released Mixed Race in 2010
column7: it became clear that the best-case scenario where Tricky was concerned was to either wait for some new thing to finally click
column8: or hope that he looks back just long enough to be reinvigorated by memories of where he started.

column1: False Idols tries to split the difference
column2: and weirdly enough
column3: it nearly succeeds. Calling it Maxinquaye for the middle-aged seems a bit too glib
column4: but this album really does return to the ethereal
column5: almost fragile intensity that marked his well-loved 1995 debut with the more solemn perspective of a grown man who's felt like he's lost his way. And for a while
column6: everything seems right. The production's appropriately spare
column7: moody
column8: and elegant
column9: streamlined and engineered to sound uniquely his while still throwing alternate jabs and nods to contemporary R&B's underacknowledged debt to his sound. But it's still far from monochromatic; the subdued yet rich minimal house thump of “Bonnie & Clyde” and the dirgy guitar squall of Antlers collaboration/cover/semi-rewrite “Parenthesis” are integrated variations on the stylistic theme
column10: not whiplash detours. That sustained mood benefits greatly from his harmonizing and interjections with singer Francesca Belmonte
column11: filling Martina Topley-Bird's role as the quietly assured yet emotionally driven foil to Tricky's clenched
column12: whispery murmur
column13: like two introverts trapped in close quarters. Going into a Tricky album hoping for that pull between beauty and tension is going to leave you at least somewhat happy with this record.­

column1: But the catch-22 of “return to form” albums is that without the dregs that precede them
column2: they need to stand up as something deeper
column3: something without ghosts following it around. And even if False Idols is approaching a more coherent idea of what a Tricky album could sound like in 2013
column4: a lot of the record comes off more like a tentative first step. There's no overthinking here
column5: which is a relief after all the tryhard high-concept ideas-- poppy hip-house
column6: French Touch knockoffs
column7: leering cock-rock-- that didn't really take off on his last couple of records. But with that simplified approach comes simplified songs: Only the gel-submerged minimalist funk of “Tribal Drums” barely scrapes past the three-and-a-half-minute mark
column8: and even the more immediately catchy tracks start to sound like sketches on further investigation. It's most evident in the songwriting: Opener “Somebody's Sins” is simply a cover of Patti Smith's opening verses to her cover of “Gloria”; “Nothing's Changed” features a generous interpolation of Pre-Millennium Tension highlight “Makes Me Wanna Die”
column9: and too many songs lean on simplistic metaphors and imagery that merely hint at deeper things they leave frustratingly concealed: the vague romantic overtones of “Valentine”; disjointed debauchery on “Is That Your Life”
column10: the evasive “Passion of the Christ”.

column1: And yet in the end it does show promise: the songs aren't bad by any stretch
column2: and when the first negative that comes to mind is that the ideas need to be fleshed out a bit
column3: it's a long way from wishing they'd've been discarded in the first place. Even with 15 tracks all averaging around the three-minute mark
column4: there's little time on False Idols devoted to offbeat goofs or weird failed experiments
column5: just a handful of songs that bottom out at “not bad but a bit forgettable.” A front-to-back listen won't dredge up any obvious duds or collar-grabbing highlights
column6: but it might get this album's focused vision planted a bit deeper in your head. Tricky might not have succeeded in bringing his old sound 100% back to life
column7: but as an effort to hit the reset button and rediscover himself
column8:
this record's a better-than-expected surprise.

"|18064.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18064-tricky-false-idols/|6.7|Nate Patrin

column5: head-cleaning dance. Classixx remixes frequently possess the slick expansiveness of disco
column6: with a touch of nocturnal mood-shading to boot. By contrast

column9: and breezy

column1: Classixx excel at creating a textured push-and-pull within the framework of their own productions

column6: propulsive Balearic structure. Album highlight ""Holding On""
column7: meanwhile
column8: elicits comparisons to Discovery-era Daft Punk
column9: uncannily combining ""One More Time""'s repetitive pulse with the bright-eyed
column10: bushy-tailed purity of ""Digital Love"".

column1: Classixx are very good producers-- their sonic excursions are placid and stylistically considered
column2: with plenty of surface beauty
column3: if not a ton of depth-- but the biggest surprise of Hanging Gardens is that they're great songwriters
column4: too. It's astonishing how many of the guest appearances simply work
column5: and in such a satisfying way
column6: too: Take the all-caps kiss-off anthem ""All You're Waiting For""
column7: featuring a typically tart vocal from ex-LCD Soundsystem member and DFA fixture Nancy Whang
column8: and Sarah Chernoff's dizzying ""A Stranger Love""

column3: an ethereal R&B-leaning tune that's a silkier
column4: less pathos-heavy version of what AC did on 2011's just-okay You Are All I See. The record's most potent punch
column5: ironically
column6: is more than three years old: ""I'll Get You""
column7: which saw release as a single in 2009 on the waning tastemaker imprint Kitsuné
column8: wields Jeppe's brash vocal beams as an effective weapon
column9: as the former Junior Senior vocalist asks repeatedly and somewhat ridiculously
column10: ""Do you like bass?"" It shouldn't work
column11: but it does
column12: and pretty well.

column1: More than anything else
column2: the pure pop cuts on Hanging Gardens leave the listener wanting more
column3: which is exactly the record's paradoxical flaw: although it runs to nearly an hour long
column4: a good deal of space is relegated to the more instrumental cuts
column5: which aren't quite distinctive enough to push the five-and-six-minute mark as they frequently do. The less impressive material loses its effectiveness when isolated from the sequencing of the album

column7:
a deceptively simple record that has the potential for great longevity.

Montreal's DIY-driven Arbutus Records is experiencing A Moment
column2: boasting a roster led by now-bona fide superstar Grimes and fleshed out by the likes of Doldrums
column3: Braids
column4: and Blue Hawaii. Their sounds may be disparate
column5: but they're united by their desire to tackle questions of identity from unique and exciting perspectives
column6: which makes Arbutus' latest release (from one of its earliest signings) a strong fit. Edmonton transplant Sean Nicholas Savage put together three full-lengths in 2011
column7: suffered through the end of a relationship
column8: and decamped to Berlin
column9: where he wrote and recorded Other Life
column10: an album largely shaped by that romantic turmoil. The final product is an unvarnished
column11: honest collection of avant-pop meditations on love and the individual.

column1: The major musical antecedent hanging over Other Life is Dan Bejar's band Destroyer
column2: a group that has spent several full-length albums embarking on sonic reclamation projects like Your Blues (tiny MIDI symphonies) and Kaputt (chintzy
column3: cheesy soft rock and jazz fusion). Savage deploys smooth
column4: adult-contemporary instrumentation whose sound verges on tinny and toy-like
column5: in a marriage of the principles guiding those two Destroyer records. It's not an innovative maneuver
column6: but the juxtaposition of that sound with Savage's voice-- high
column7: reedy; cracking and bending with emotion-- and the hefty lyrical content is jarring and effective.

column1: Savage's own exploration of identity manifests in ideas of impersonation: ""These days I feel like I'm somebody else/ Who looks just like me/ But he's not me
column2: he sings on opener ""She Looks Like You""
column3: a relationship ballad that frames the way people change over time and slowly become unrecognizable to each other. The best songs on Other Life tuck similarly weighty concepts into romantic narratives
column4: whether it's fantasizing about living another life to escape the mistakes made in this one (on the title track) or coping with a love that cripples as it endures (""More Than I Love Myself""). The icky come-ons and dismissals of ""Lonely Woman"" recall the way Arbutus alumnus Majical Cloudz delights in making his audience uncomfortable. It takes a good deal of bravery to write and record songs that are so naked and unflinching
column5: and it pays off: Savage's courage and palpable investment in the material makes it easy to connect and empathize with his subject matter.

column1: After trekking through dangerous
column2: taxing emotional terrain for the great majority of its runtime
column3: Other Life ends with the sweet
column4: bubbling ""Chin Chin""
column5: an ode to gentle kisses on the chin delivered in the morning light. These lovers aren't posturing
column6: fantasizing
column7: or racked with anxiety; they're happy
column8: unadorned
column9: revelling in each other's goofy love. And while Savage has cobbled together a very good
column10: honest album from a dark place
column11:
placing ""Chin Chin"" at the record's close is a bright glimmer of hope for what could come next.

On “Mephisto in the Water”
column2: a standout off her second solo album for Rune Grammofon
column3: the Norwegian singer/songwriter/novelist/critic/academic/provocateur Jenny Hval bends her voice into unusual and unexpected shapes. Over a disquieting Möbius strip keyboard line
column4: she performs a wordless fanfare
column5: sing-chants the verses
column6: and splits into a choir of singers on the vocal hook. “Hey
column7: what do you hear?” she asks coyly. On the protracted bridge
column8: her voice warps and mutates and turns the syllables into pure sounds. Hval goes deliberately flat
column9: savoring the pulsating dissonance
column10: until all that is left is a high
column11: tensile note that wavers in either distress or desire. Rather than alienating
column12: it’s actually inviting: a strange and powerful performance. Innocence Is Kinky thrives on such moments
column13: when Hval’s primary instrument sounds like it’s disentangling itself from her body and swooping around the ether of the song.

column1: First under the stage name Rockettothesky and later under her real name
column2: Hval has been a mainstay in the Oslo scene for several years now
column3: but little in her catalog-- which includes a handful of albums as well as two novels
column4: several sound installations
column5: and a master’s thesis on Kate Bush-- signaled the breakthrough she makes on Innocence Is Kinky. In the past her music has tended toward subdued art-pop
column6: full of plaintive beats and hushed vocals; at her best such subtlety was commanding
column7: even if it occasionally threatened to settle for decorous passivity. The new album
column8: as that title suggests
column9: is more direct
column10: more brazen
column11: more aggressive
column12: more provocative
column13: both conceptually and musically. Recording with producer John Parish
column14: Hval explores some enormous
column15: unwieldy concepts that tend to pop up more often in textbooks than on turntables.

column1: Opening with Hval watching internet porn and closing with her discovering a new way to inhabit her body
column2: Innocence Is Kinky examines thorny issues of gender identity and commodified sexuality. She gives her songs titles like “Death of the Author” and “Amphibious
column3: Androgynous”. Mythological figures wander in and out of these songs: Mephisto does his best Ophelia
column4: Oedipus blindly wanders the streets of Oslo
column5: and Pinnochio takes communion. By far the most significant figure among these songs is also the most human: Renée Falconetti
column6: the silent-film star whose close-up in 1928’s The Passion of Joan of Arc is one of the most indelible images in the history of cinema. “The camera is a mirror
column7: but mine
column8: not yours
column9: ” Hval sings as an organ thrums in the background and a low bass note pulses on the downbeat.

column1: She’s obviously having a blast throwing these figures and narratives against one another
column2: and her irreverence suggests a playfulness that dispels any hint of pretension. Yet
column3: she keeps the focus squarely on her commanding vocals
column4: which means you don’t need to know Carl Theodor Dreyer from Laura Mulvey to appreciate this album. In fact
column5: the most fascinating ideas on Innocence Is Kinky are the musical ones. While rooted in the same art-pop as Laurie Anderson
column6: Yoko Ono
column7: and pre-“Sledgehammer” Peter Gabriel
column8: Hval paints with a broad palette
column9: not only deploying an array of sounds and styles but setting them against each other to create jarring juxtapositions. As “Mephisto in the Water” fades to its close
column10: a few raw guitar chords introduce the stomping psych-pop of “I Called”. “Oslo Oedipus” opens with a Middle Eastern chorale
column11: layered moans swaddled in reverb
column12: before transitioning into a poetry recitation set to a clangorous beat. Based on a sound installation called “A Continuous Echo of Splitting Hymens”
column13: “Give Me That Sound” is composed of belches of frazzled distortion and bent vocals that make for an arresting interlude before Hval launches into “I Got No Strings”
column14: the album’s truest rock song. The seams between the songs speak as loudly as the songs themselves
column15: giving the album the shape of a journey. It’s less a critical essay than a picaresque: a woman leaving the dirty white glare of her computer and wandering around Oslo.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the album’s heady diversity originates in Hval’s malleable voice
column3: which alters style
column4: approach
column5: timber
column6: and tone from one measure to the next. One moment she addresses the listener in a slyly conspiratorial whisper
column7: as if to draw you into her curious world. The next
column8: she lets loose a full-throated wail that shakes that world apart. Not content to merely test the limitations of musical genre
column9: of sound
column10: of her own voice (and
column11: by virtue
column12: her body)
column13: Hval knowingly transgresses those limitations as she explores what’s just beyond her range. That bold tack gives Innocence Is Kinky its unique aesthetic
column14: but it is also
column15: oddly enough
column16:
what keeps the music so grounded in the physical and the human.

Kylesa have always been a moving target. Since their inception
column2: the Savannah

column1: After a string of LPs that have consistently found Kylesa fortifying these wayward genre aggregations

column6: feel like a non-navigable maze with no steady vectors or outlined intentions: Opener “Exhale” shortchanges a great hook from Laura Pleasants with verses that don’t support the same weight and an instrumental breakdown that simply stalls the song. “Unspoken” hides behind an unnecessary 80-second introduction and subsequently plunges into an unremarkable and overly long solo

column8: Cope drowns many of his own vocals in effects
column9: hiding them behind the wallop like coded messages. Likewise
column10: Pleasants harmonizes the chorus with herself

column13: Ultraviolet pauses to concede to such extraneous effects and rockpiled elements
column14: as if Kylesa have finally made the mistake of brandishing their eccentricity rather than simply thriving on it. Ultraviolet rarely feels singular or confident; it’s the sound of a band attempting to underline its claims to distinction.

column2: they are unstoppable: “We’re Taking This”

column14: ” the album’s best surprise

column16: magnetic ballad; overactive bass
column17: distant harmonies
column18: and streaks of soft guitar noise create an impressionistic web for its starry-eyed hook. In all three instances
column19: Kylesa’s disparate strains work together to create the same inexorable sense of euphoria that unites most of the band’s influences

with some seams still showing.
