There’s a 99% possibility that some 10th-grade boy out there is currently relying on Pinkerton to guide him through the indignities of adolescence
column2: and how’s this for some perspective: He wasn’t even born when Weezer released that album. And it’s been that long since any form of denial played a role in Rivers Cuomo’s music. From “Pork and Beans” to “Can’t Stop Partying”; from the Raditude cover art to the Hurley cover art; from the Weezer Cruise to the Pinkerton reunion tour
column3: Cuomo has pretty much done everything over the past 17 years except take “no” for an answer. So when you consider his longstanding predilection for Asian culture (to put it mildly)
column4: the only thing surprising about him making a Japanese-language album is that it took him until 2013 to do so. And yet
column5: Scott & Rivers is one of the few unequivocally good ideas he’s had in a very
column6: very long time: name a 21st century Weezer album that wouldn’t be immediately improved if you didn’t understand English.

column1: Cuomo linked up with a suitable travel buddy in Scott Murphy
column2: frontman for Allister
column3: a Drive Thru pop-punk band you might be familiar with if you keep tabs on the Warped Tour
column4: but have likely only heard if you’ve been to the Warped Tour. They're very much “big in Japan.” So what can be expected of Scott & Rivers? Are Murphy and Cuomo going to fully concede to the stylistic tenets of J-pop? Is it simply going to split the difference between Girlfriends and Dead Ends with lyrics like “goddamn you half-Japanese girls” sung in full Japanese? Is it going to appeal to the 18-year old girl who lives in small city in Japan or the 35-year-old she grew up to be since Pinkerton? Holy shit
column5: there’s a song called “Butterfly” on here; is Rivers really going there?

column1: Some of these questions are answered definitively
column2: all are answered rather uninterestingly. No matter what language you speak or how familiar you are with either artist's work
column3: there isn't much culture shock to be had listening to Scott & Rivers. In short
column4: it’s a hell of a lot like an off-brand recent Weezer album
column5: in that the style isn’t guitar rock taking cues from factory pop
column6: but factory pop interpreted through clinical guitars that sound like they’re sourced from test tubes rather than tube amps. It would sound overproduced for 1998 yet seems curiously rinky-dink compared to the current pop maximalism of any continent; Scott & Rivers splits most of its time between ruthlessly utilitarian power pop and midtempo
column7: jangly acoustic alt-rock that reimagines the break between Pinkerton and the Green Album as one where Cuomo ditched Harvard for higher education in the form of Stroke 9 or Eve 6 CDs. Or
column8: in the case of the pure synth-pop numbers and the cover of Kimura Kaela's ""Butterfly"" (sorry)
column9: those of Vitamin C or any other sub-Spice I can’t immediately recall.

column1: This isn’t some Kickstarter lark-- it’s being released on Universal’s Japanese imprint. But the few hooks that are sung in English make it abundantly clear that neither Cuomo nor Murphy's songwriting has been altered in the slightest: “I love
column2: love
column3: love my homely girl!/ She just knocks me to the ground!” “I freakin’ love my life!/ It’s turning out just right!/ It’s a party every night!” Those two songs are “Homely Girl” and “Freakin’ Love My Life”
column4: naturally. Otherwise
column5: the frictionless production and rounded
column6: vowel-heavy Japanese phonetics gives Scott & Rivers a sonic viscosity where consuming one song or all 12 feels roughly equal. It sticks with you
column7: but the sweetness has a sickly chemical feel.

column1: Cuomo told us from the beginning that his favorite rock group was Kiss
column2: so we shouldn’t be surprised about him using his artistic goodwill as quarters in a perpetual game of whack-a-mole
column3: going after whatever monetization opportunity presents itself. In some ways
column4: it’s weirdly admirable. Scott & Rivers just seems more savvy than anything-- you sense that he and Murphy know something us Yankees don’t
column5: or maybe Scott & Rivers is just prelude to Weezer’s inevitable Live at Budokan. There’s a heartening belief in how Cuomo still sticks to writing the kind of songs that need mass exposure for them to mean anything to anybody
column6: and assumes rock radio still has the juice to provide it. There’s no doubt he believes it
column7:
so there’s no way a song called “Freakin’ Love My Life” could be ironic; Cuomo’s fantasy world is the realest thing he knows.

Ambient music has plenty of stargazers
column4: but not many stars. There are so many people working in subtly different but broadly similar styles
column5: and so much of their music is less keen to develop the individual persona than to dissolve it in a universalist hum. One exception is Matthew Cooper
column6: who has spent the past decade becoming a touchstone for contemporary indie ambient music. As Eluvium
column7: Cooper has staked out an ambient brand that blends piano-playing in the styles of classical minimalism and French Impressionism with dreamy electronics and guitar drones derived from IDM and shoegaze. It should not diminish his talent as an arranger to hazard that his centralizing influence probably rests on his impulse for accessibility above intricacy. Cooper's music can be light or dark
column8: vehement or mild
column9: romantic or hopeless
column10: but it is always shaped into emotionally lucid
column11: easily habitable spaces.

column1: Still
column2: Cooper's stature is surprising when you consider that he hasn't released a great record since 2007. Copia was the highlight because it combined modes that were isolated on his prior releases-- from the Satie-like piano jingles of An Accidental Memory in the Case of Death to the grainy
column3: radiant drones of Talk Amongst the Trees-- with expanded acoustic instrumentation
column4: resulting in a majestic statement that sounded like the work of an artistic thinker rather than a fine technician of incidental sound. Copia at last meets its match in Nightmare Ending
column5: Eluvium’s commanding new double LP. That it was supposed to be Copia's immediate successor might make you slap your forehead over Cooper's five years of mixed successes: the low-impact ambient techno of his Martin Eden alias
column6: the tepid vocal-centric pop of Similes
column7: and the dark
column8: noisy Static Nocturne (the best of the bunch). But perhaps Cooper couldn't finish Nightmare Ending until he repeated the process that produced Copia
column9: gathering new fuel for this bonfire of an album. The bided time pays off in what feels like a career-spanning best-of that happens to contain all new music.

column1: Alternately delicate and deluging
column2: the 80-plus minutes of music that compose Nightmare Ending are wrought together with a heft and thrust that banish the aftertaste of Cooper's most recent EPs
column3: which collected leftover dregs from Similes. This tremendous collection holds electronics-encased piano themes (e.g. the breathtaking dawn of ""Don’t Get Any Closer"" and the Harold Budd-like ""Covered in Writing"")
column4: rich orchestral fogs that recall Copia (""Warm""and ""Unknown Variation"")
column5: and rhythmically roiling dark clouds resembling Static Nocturne (""By the Rails""
column6: ""Envenom Mettle""). Elegant little solo piano compositions
column7: insistent with nostalgic repetitions
column8: periodically surface through the heavy drapings of texture and harmony
column9: proving refreshing for it. Cooper even redeems the ambient pop that derailed him on Similes by roping in a ringer
column10: Yo La Tengo's Ira Kaplan
column11: to sing on the tender closer ""Happiness"".

column1: Cooper reportedly first conceived of Nightmare Ending as ""a way of helping loosen his self-imposed ideals of perfection
column2: which provides a clue as to why the record makes such an impact. Cooper has never made anything terrible
column3: but the greatest danger to which his music succumbs is to be too perfect
column4: too placid and undisturbed
column5: too perfunctorily lovely and sad. Nightmare Ending
column6: on the other hand
column7: is always bursting out through its own imperfections and impulsive gestures
column8: with a wide emotional spectrum pumped full of fresh life from when Cooper returned to finish it years later. It's a long glorious exhalation of energies not actually dissipated
column9: as it seemed for a while
column10:
but only multiplying in force under suppression.

While the bands populating Southern Lord’s mercurial roster continue to veer between ferocious and tepid

column8: Martyrdöd
column9: Miasmal

column1: Rites of Separation is the band’s first LP since 2010’s Host of the Winged and third overall release. As good as its predecessors were

column6: but ultimately
column7: there’s more of an epic
column8: dark crust hardcore vibe. Think Morne
column9: Fall of Efrafa
column10: Downfall of Gaia
column11: or even Tragedy
column12: who all embrace the same original crust punk foundations
column13: but have been willing to branch out in search of more.

column1: Agrimonia do this so well
column2: it’s almost unfair. “While Life Lies” is a muted
column3: somber affair
column4: starting slow and quiet before picking up the pace from a shuddering sludgy crawl into a spate of sharply melodic death metal and bleak hardcore. Once more
column5: Christina’s forceful
column6: throat-scraping growls and admonitions are a massive help
column7: used sparsely but wisely. Her approach is fairly one-dimensional
column8: but allows her to fade comfortably into the shadows to function as an instrument rather than a focal point. Music like this needs space
column9: and time
column10: and Agrimonia know how to use both. “The Battle Fought” rushes out of the gate with a driving beat and a flurry of distorted riffs and doesn’t let up for a moment; even the peppy rock’n’roll part swinging on the tail end keeps its grip tight. Its smart
column11: midtempo pace is typical of the songs on this album
column12: but feels like a gallop compared to the more staid instrumental and atmospheric passages. There is an emotional element to the songs
column13: of course
column14: but the primary focus is on the music itself; indecipherable lyrics and cryptic song titles take a back seat to the wondrous scope of sonic expression that’s happening around them. Show
column15: don’t tell.

column1: Agrimonia take the “epic” tag seriously

column3: especially for a punk/hardcore band
column4: but each note and chord feels absolutely necessary. The final and most ambitious track

column6: starts off with a woozy
column7: industrialized drone (courtesy of Miasmal/Martyrdöd guitarist Pontus’ ominous keyboard work) and dares the listener to navigate its treacherous terrain
column8: wandering through fiery hardcore and icy black metal while accompanied by heavy nods towards pure metallic crust and circling a gloomy
column9: doomy central passage. The song fades out on another strong

column12:
and will hopefully receive the recognition it deserves as one of 2013’s great triumphs.

column4: Timmy Vulgar has recorded some of his most boisterously awesome work to date. Last year
column5: he put out the Timmy's Organism album Raw Sewage Roq-- a solid collection of songs with scumbag lyrics slurred over blown-out hard rock guitars. But while the most recent Timmy's album is marked by its devotion to Johnny Thunders and the Freeze
column6: his other band Human Eye is more defined by their sci-fi psychedelia. Their stage show usually involves Timmy throwing on a big monster mask
column7: and their thematic territory tends to sound like something from the yellowed pages of a sci-fi paperback. Their 2011 album They Came From the Sky paired punk rock muscle with buzzing sci-fi sonics. Into Unknown

column1: Instead
column2: Timmy and the gang aim for a sound that's more paced than raucous. The percussion of ""Immortal Soldier"" moves quickly
column3: but it simmers beneath the surface. Timmy is yowling
column4: but the vocals are muffled. The guitar solo sounds smothered. With a slightly different arrangement and slightly faster tempos
column5: it could be a soaring rock'n'roll anthem. Instead
column6: the more muted tone folds into the album's loose narrative. And sometimes
column7: the quieter elements are used to complement Timmy's noisier inclinations. ""Surface of Pluto"" starts out spare-- a quiet piano and acoustic guitar
column8: some desolate 2001: A Space Odyssey synths. Then
column9: right as things get a bit sleepy
column10: boom: big screeching guitar solo. At the end of the LP sits the title track: a six-minute
column11: all-instrumental odyssey. There's a krautrock bassline
column12: a simple melody being plunked out on a xylophone
column13: and a warm guitar solo that switches from a warm Eastern tone to a scuzzy Detroit attack. With an occasional tinge of UFO feedback
column14: it evokes exactly what it's meant to: a journey into the unknown.

column1: Human Eye go in for more straightforward rock'n'roll
column2: too
column3: but aside from the barking track ""Juicy Jaw""
column4: those are some of the album's weakest moments. ""Alligator Dance"" has the barroom piano
column5: guitar sound
column6: and howling vocals that sounded so great on Raw Sewage Roq. Here
column7: however
column8: they're implemented on a song with worse lyrics
column9: an unnecessarily lethargic tempo
column10: and a completely lazy guitar solo. ""Buzzin' Flies"" somehow feels too repetitive after just two-and-a-half minutes. Then there are the other questionable sonic decisions; throughout the record
column11: there's a keyboard sound that's most easily described as ""circus organ."" Maybe that's what they're going for-- Timmy's stage presence and deranged howls
column12: after all
column13: aren't too dissimilar from Tim Curry in It.

column1: The easy highlight is ""Outlaw Lone Wolf""
column2: a story with the basic revenge-fueled beats of a Tarantino movie. It's the kind of song that provides every single piece of context in the most transparently stated lyrics possible
column3: like Lefty Frizzell's <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JI_xCH6wkO8"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Saginaw

column5: Timmy embarks on the tale of the son of a blacksmith
column6: who was abandoned as an orphan
column7: rescued by Apaches
column8: and became a great warrior. One day
column9: while he was out hunting
column10: somebody burned the entire village. As the warrior's charred wife dies in his arms
column11: she manages these last words: ""It was the blacksmith/ Avenge our deaths."" (Again
column12: nothing vague about this story at all.) And then there's an instrumental breakdown that sounds like Human Eye doing Ennio Morricone. It's a ridiculous
column13: campy
column14: awesome six minutes.

column1: The pacing and sequencing of Into Unknown is stellar

column3: ""Alligator Dance"" is anything but. It's an album that seems to have a sense of humor

“I know they ain’t gon’ play this on top 40 radio
column3: ” begins “Slow It Down""
column4: IV Play’s confrontational first single. An indignant backlash against the wave of EDM-R&B that’s been sweeping the airwaves of the past few years
column5: it’s a ballsy
column6: against-the-grain move that highlights the identity crisis that Terius Nash seems to be undergoing. But in truth
column7: the song's dilemma applies to his entire career. While The-Dream has written some of the biggest hits of the past decade-- ”Umbrella
column8: ” “Single Ladies”
column9: lots more-- his solo work has failed to take off. Instead
column10: he's developed a cult and has become a fixation of R&B nerds everywhere. Packed with guest stars
column11: IV Play feels like it’s finally vying for that elusive spotlight. And
column12: while he’s still not making those “motherfucking dance songs
column13: ” for the first time it feels like he’s trying to keep up with everyone else.

column1: IV Play starts off shaky with “High Art”
column2: an awkward attempt at a club anthem. Nash has never done this sort of machismo well; his charm lies in his ability to string sweetly sung hooks together
column3: but he forgoes his established style repeatedly in IV Play’s first half. Always a fan of references
column4: he takes a thesaurus to Ginuwine’s “Pony” for the bizarre and plodding “Equestrian”
column5: while the less said about the tepid mess of “Turnt” (with Beyoncé and 2 Chainz
column6: no less) the better. The only decent guest appearance is Pusha T's on ""Pussy""
column7: which is ruined by Big Sean's embarrassing appearance two minutes later. It’s the first time Nash has disappointed like this; he’s had a bum track or two
column8: sure
column9: but the early string of clunkers is discouraging.

column1: Not that there aren’t gleams of brilliance. The title track is intriguingly out of character-- “I could give a fuck about the foreplay/ I’m talking straight sex
column2: ” this coming from the man who once described messing up his girl's hair like it was an elaborate courting ritual. But it falls into a despondent outro that edges on self-doubt. There’s been a string of self-loathing running through Nash’s music since his very public divorce (immortalized on 2011’s self-released 1977)
column3: which he can’t quite seem to shake. It’s there in the defensive “Slow It Down”
column4: it’s there in the outro to “IV Play” (“I don’t deserve you”)
column5: and it’s there in another one of the LP’s most plaintive tracks
column6: “New Orleans”. Like an outtake from 1977
column7: the song’s subject (“this bitch”) is repeated at the end of every line
column8: and while it’s undeniably affecting
column9: the misogyny becomes grating.

column1: Thankfully there’s at least one classic The-Dream track on IV Play-- the effortlessly airy “Michael”. And
column2: though more questionable lyrics abound (“He say he love you/ I just wanna fuck you/ Over the weekend”)
column3: it has all the lilt and masterful vocalisms of his best work. But this song is an exception. For an artist that’s modeled himself so closely after Prince
column4: it’s striking how IV Play resembles the Purple One’s late 80s transition phase when the Minneapolis artist tried to re-engage his black fans by self-consciously urbanizing his music (see The Black Album). IV Play has many of the same restless impulses
column5: from the surprisingly excellent blues slow-burner “Too Early” to the two-songs-stuck-together shambles of “Loving You/ Crazy.” The brilliant auteur we fell in love with is still in here somewhere. He’s just buried under layers of pretense.

column1: IV Play winds down with the epic “Holy Love
column2: ” which references his “Umbrella” height of 2007 and hints at emptiness in the wake of success. Where exactly his ire is directed is unclear
column3: but it makes explicit a frustration obvious to anyone who’s been watching his solo career since it started
column4: through record label ordeals
column5: delayed release dates and scrapped albums. “Always with you baby/I’ll never sell out
column6: ” he sings in a verse to “Slow It Down
column7: ” which begins to feel like a coded message to his longtime fans. Sticking with him through the machinations of the music industry has never been more difficult than it is now
column8: but IV Play still has its rewards. When the world finally heeds the plea of “Slow It Down”
column9: he might achieve immortality all over again. For now
column10: though
column11:
he’s merely human.

CocoRosie have impressive staying power for a band that has frequently incorporated repellence into its style
column3: tempering their perversity with enough weird beauty to keep us on the hook. On 2004 debut La maison de mon rêve
column4: sisters Bianca and Sierra Casady meowed warped endearments over freak folk guitars and hip-hop beats. It's their sparest and loveliest album
column5: but it still raised eyebrows with ""Jesus Loves Me""
column6: a seemingly heartfelt but inescapably patronizing burlesque of negro spirituals that repeatedly used an even more taboo word than ""negro."" How were we to take this coming from two white women
column7: wedged in amid all those demented operatic stylings and feline French chansons? Were they sincerely culturally tone-deaf or were we being provoked
column8: and if so
column9: to feel what precisely? ""I like CocoRosie…"" you might say
column10: on a pre-emptive defensive.

column1: Things only got murkier over three more albums
column2: as the Casadys expanded their junk drawer of guitar
column3: piano
column4: harp
column5: toys
column6: and percussion with electronics
column7: bass
column8: keyboards
column9: and beatboxing. They had a phase of styling their faces like Guy Fawkes masks; a phase of wearing Sean John velour and cornrows. Noah's Ark featured unicorn sodomy on its cover
column10: lyrics about turning aborted babies into Bambies
column11: and criticism inoculations via Antony Hegarty and Devendra Banhart features. On The Adventures of Ghosthorse and Stillborn
column12: nursery rhymes crept toward raps
column13: and CocoRosie's scab-picking at African-American otherness started to feel more like a particular fixation than just exotica among exotica. The record included some of the band's most flagrantly off-putting music (""Japan""
column14: incompatible with any conceivable taste) and some of its most deceptively ingratiating. ""Rainbowarriors"" was an electro-pop earworm where preposterously vapid lyrics masked a subtler angle on CocoRosie's more obvious race-baiting: They were based on Longfellow's Native American fantasia ""The Song of Hiawatha""
column15: a sacred text of fraught cross-cultural appropriation.

column1: Following Grey Oceans
column2: their meekest and least memorable album (except for its impressively unappealing cover)
column3: CocoRosie wipe the slate clean on Tales of a Grass Widow. With two Antony spots and sleek Valgeir Sigurðsson production
column4: it returns to the more extroverted styles of Noah's Ark and Ghosthorse. But while those albums were full of tangents
column5: Grass Widow highlights CocoRosie's most practical songwriting
column6: with vocals that are often refreshingly natural and fluent. First single ""Gravediggress""
column7: while thin for its length
column8: gives an accurate impression of the rest of the record: The juiced-up piano and synth bounce of ""After the Afterlife"" leads without a hitch into ""Tears for Animals""
column9: a sweeping duet with Antony
column10: who sings sweetly about love for humankind. Beyond electronic pop
column11: there are restorations of CocoRosie's folksy side; the cracked brightness of ""Roots of My Hair"" recalls faded Joanna Newsom comparisons. The cobwebs that overgrew Grey Oceans are swept back to corners such as ""Broken Chariot""
column12: a quite reasonable four minutes of velvety Mesoamerican flutes.

column1: It's all remarkably pleasant for a CocoRosie album-- you leave it not with the feeling of having weathered an intriguing
column2: baffling ordeal
column3: but of having listened to something recognizable as an album. There are half-hearted jabs at provocation
column4: with perspectives of endangered children linking songs such as ""Child Bride"" (""Whose little girl am I? / The man with the black hat will take me home tonight"") and ""Harmless Monster""
column5: but it's all more soapy and sentimental than disturbing. Nor is there anything very loaded now about the generically misanthropic singsong raps over the lush whistles and tuned percussion of ""End of Time"". It feels like a long-held transgressive impulse spending its last momentum
column6: beneficially redirecting energy into more direct emotional appeals.

column1: It's hard to fathom that Grass Widow is the work of a band that has inspired so many sour fights
column2: think-pieces
column3: and passionate apologias from prominent musicians. The question of whether CocoRosie were cynical shock-jocks or fearless artists proved permanently unanswerable to everyone
column4: probably including the Casadys themselves. It was always too simple to say they were just charlatans
column5: but it was also too simple to protest they were not. The point was that your position said something about who you were and what you believed in. But it's mooted on this open-hearted
column6: revitalizing album
column7: the boldest gesture left to a band that had been so determined to repulse. Grass Widow makes it easier to say
column8: ""I like CocoRosie
column9:
period.

Kyle Thomas is King Tuff. He's been using that name on-and-off for a long time
column2: but pre-2007
column3: he was Kyle
column4: one-eighth of the freak folk band Feathers
column5: who made gentle
column6: Eastern-tinged acoustic tracks. With J Mascis
column7: he was in Witch

column9: stoner rock leanings. But Thomas needed another outlet
column10: one that was truer to his own rock'n'roll tastes: He had been writing songs since he was about 10

column1: It's a tight
column2: consistent
column3: and unbelievably catchy rock album that quickly and effectively defined who and what ""King Tuff"" was
column4: stuffed with killer guitar solos
column5: infectiously sunny hooks
column6: and lyrics that come off like personality-defining mantras. If you were at all familiar with Thomas' other work

column8: but I’ve pretty much always had a rock'n'roll heart.""

column1: The LP certainly made the rounds with garage heads
column2: and eventually grabbed the attention of the Sub Pop offices. But by the time King Tuff was released last year
column3: Was Dead was already out-of-print and had become a collector's item. After an initial run of CD-Rs in 2007
column4: it came out on Colonel Records in 2008
column5: was pressed four times
column6: and eventually showed up on eBay for exorbitant costs. Even if it was just a couple of years old
column7: owning a copy of Was Dead became something tangibly special. It initiated you into a club with a bunch of other weirdos
column8: and the one thing you all had in common was one weird
column9: great power pop album.

column1: Its greatness definitely felt like a secret. While the garage focus at the time was on King Khan
column2: the Black Lips
column3: and Jay Reatard
column4: Was Dead didn't exactly make a splash in the larger critical conversation. Thomas
column5: of course
column6: doesn't care about maintaining any sort of cult status he might have accidentally developed; he just wants people to hear it: ""It’s really flattering to be thought of as so ‘collectible
column7: ’ but you’d much rather that just everyone could have it.”

column1: A new reissue on Burger Records proves that
column2: as power pop-leaning rock'n'roll albums go
column3: Was Dead is a front-to-back masterwork. While a lot of these kinds of records work under the ""peaks and valleys"" principle (because even the Ramones had songs like ""Here Today Gone Tomorrow"" and ""I Wanna Be Your Boyfriend"")

It's legitimately tough to peg ""best songs"" on this album: ""A Pretty Dress"" and ""Just Strut"" are easy contenders with their saccharine melodies and fiery electric guitars
column7: but about half a dozen others could easily be tapped as favorites.

column1: The album's pace slows down exactly once during ""Stone Fox""
column2: but even that track is fueled by a steady electric guitar churn
column3: and ultimately
column4: it's a much-needed cool-down to springboard into the choogle of killer closer ""So Desperate"". The album's final stretch offers some of its best moments. Thomas delivers a simple
column5: triumphant melody
column6: which seems to trigger an instant dopamine release. He caps the song's chorus with a set of ""woooooooooo WOO WOO!"" vocals and rounds the track out with a brief but point-perfect guitar solo. It's a very satisfying cap to an impressive album.

column1: As a whole
column2: Was Dead paints a portrait of the man behind King Tuff. ""Freak When I'm Dead"" is all about wanting to be buried in all his rings and favorite clothes. (""Everything with patches and everything with holes."") ""Sun Medallion"" paints a portrait of a man who drinks black coffee

“Dream-pop” should have an unlimited number of definitions. But it almost always describes records like Still Corners’ second album Strange Pleasures-- records filled with swooning harmonies
column4: lush reverb
column5: and vaporous melodies that are fleeting if you don’t make a concerted effort to hold onto them.

column1: If not terribly distinctive
column2: Strange Pleasures nonetheless represents progress for Still Corners. Their 2011 Sub Pop debut Creatures of an Hour was rightfully likened to a post-chillwave Broadcast
column3: who themselves drew heavily from the psychedelia of previous decades. Two years later
column4: the London duo are more of a modernist kind of nostalgia act
column5: taking the night drive alongside contemporary breakthroughs such as <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15881-hurry-up-were-dreaming/"" target=""_blank"">Hurry Up
column6: We’re Dreaming
column7: Teen Dream and especially Kill for Love-- records with self-explanatory titles that infused dream-pop with either an overwhelming sense of the moment
column8: sex appeal
column9: or danger. It’s a welcome shift
column10: though Still Corners are establishing a presence more than a personality. Including a song called “I Can’t Sleep” amidst all this downy pillow talk is sort of asking for it
column11: yet the duo do about enough to evoke what might be keeping them up: neon city lights
column12: cars roaring in the distance
column13: their own desire for escape.

column1: Still Corners present Strange Pleasures as something of a driving record
column2: though the implication throughout is that it’s better if someone else is at the wheel. Opener “The Trip” is a six-minute pacesetter that savors the transit more than whatever impending arrival awaits
column3: as its steady acoustic strums and cruise-controlled rhythm progress at a safe speed. Meanwhile
column4: the miniature motoriks of “Beatcity” and “Berlin Lovers” obsess over German synth engineering
column5: and “Midnight Drive” is even less covert about its influences
column6: a four-minute audition for After Dark 3 that’s still a little too on-the-nose.

column1: Otherwise
column2: the rest of Strange Pleasures approaches the edge of palpable sadness rather than wallowing in its depths
column3: demonstrating how “Beginning to Blue” makes a color into a verb: the near-constant harmonies are guided by an instinct for high thread-count layering rather than harmonic composition
column4: and every synth line sounds like a pricier version of the “quasar” or “space” preset on toy Casios. It’s often quite pretty
column5: but there’s still something of a void within this nebular atmosphere.

column1: The two predominant textures of Strange Pleasures-- ethereal gauze and smooth alabaster-- don’t make much of an impression
column2: nor offer much to grip onto. While Tessa Murray’s vocals remain breathy and mysterious throughout
column3: that doesn’t mean they draw you in. The closer you get
column4: the more you realize how beholden she is to stock images of oceans
column5: doves
column6: and deep breaths. And yet
column7: ""Fireflies"" becomes the true standout of Strange Pleasures by unapologetically embracing these tropes rather than cloaking them. At the center of such an image-conscious LP
column8: it’s a surprising indulgence
column9: its romantic ideals unabashedly gooey and awestruck. It doesn’t just share a title with the Owl City song; try to guess which lyric belongs to which band: “Awake when I’m asleep/ Because my dreams are bursting at the seams;” “The night is long as we like/ All the innocents of youth and the fire light.”

column1: Listening to Strange Pleasures
column2: you’re reminded of why we invest so heavily in dreams to begin with: we want these passing fancies to have meaning
column3: to be symbolic
column4: to tell us something about ourselves. M83 or Beach House are able to create musical frameworks bigger than our own minds
column5: something you can lose yourself in
column6: to inspire waking dreams. Strange Pleasures works on a much more modest scale
column7: content to subliminally scoot its way in
column8: to serve as connective tissue between the Cocteau Twins and Chromatics on a mixtape
column9: but not as the main attraction. It's a pleasant listen of selfless
column10: opaque indie-pop that still feels indulgent
column11: proof that captivating made-up dreams are the work of compelling dreamers
column12: or have some basis in reality. After all
column13:
no one wants to hear what you dreamt about unless you dreamt about them.

column12: eventually

column1: On Cold Spring Fault Less Youth

column6: and with unexpected collaborator King Krule. The duo

column4: to Oval

column6: syncopation

column8: no dubby decay or wistfulness
column9: locked up in Cold Spring. This alone is refreshing.

column2: kempt state. The most noticeable example of which is the addition of King Krule

Will Wiesenfeld wanted his second album as Baths to be nothing short of an out-of-body experience. While creating
column3: producing
column4: and performing Cerulean by himself may have been a declaration of independence at one point
column5: he soon felt trapped and limited behind his MPDs
column6: unable to fully connect with crowds
column7: and mislabeled as a ""DJ."" More crucially
column8: his physical frame was failing him. Last year
column9: a debilitating bout with E. coli rendered him incapable of eating or getting out of bed
column10: let alone creating new music. After slowly convalescing
column11: he channeled all of these pent-up frustrations and desires-- for escape
column12: for artistic growth
column13: for transformation
column14: for death
column15: for self-actualization-- into Obsidian. And by doing so
column16: he didn’t just create his second album. He made an evil twin.

column1: While Obsidian maintains some aspects of Cerulean
column2: namely
column3: its lap-pop intimacy and Wiesenfeld's unsteady
column4: quavering vocals
column5: the shock is in hearing him make a complete heel turn
column6: fearlessly operating like someone absolved of personal repercussion or culpability: He pursues every gnarly musical idea
column7: every perverted lyric. Cerulean gave no indication as to how much range Wiesenfeld could cover working exclusively in purple and pitch black. Over the sickly
column8: chain-gang lurch of “Worsening”

column10: morbid poetry
column11: and Obsidian’s thesis statement-- “Birth was like a fat black tongue/ Dripping tar and dung and dye/ Slowly into my shivering eyes."" As to be expected from someone whose body was recently powerless over the most basic functions

column13: an advance single that gave the impression that Baths’ idea of pop was a suicidal version of what the Postal Service do. He can’t prevent himself from being sucked into the ground as the molten
column14: heavy metal banger “Earth Death” creates its own gravitational pull.

column1: Throughout
column2: the songs on Obsidian are physical in a literal sense
column3: mimicking the human motion of the characters described therein. The collation of disparate layers on “Worsening” is simply astonishing
column4: so many parts going in gawky
column5: arrhythmic directions to form a fearsome
column6: fluid whole. The illicit love affair on “Ironworks” moves to a limpid Satie-like piano figure of incapacitating beauty
column7: containing all the sadness
column8: longing
column9: and tenderness the two feel for each other. Meanwhile
column10: the stunning breadth of Obsidian becomes apparent as “Incompatible” skulks forward
column11: non-quantized rhythms emphasizing the fumbled communication and resentments of an ice-cold relationship.

column1: The physicality and darkness aren’t just borne out of a 24-year-old’s first brush with death. Obsidian is in some aspect a “grown up” record in that the characters find themselves in adult situations. But they aren’t mature by any means. In fact
column2: the sexual conduct is fueled by as much nihilism as the apocalyptic conjuring. This is really where Obsidian feels less like a typical artistic “leap” than a bold leap of faith. Vocally
column3: Wisenfeld was a bit player on Cerulean
column4: and often would whisper sweet little love notes: “Please tell me you need me
column5: ” “I still smell you
column6: distance aside.” On “Ironworks
column7: ” he likens himself to “Sweet swine/ In Victorian doorways/ In tempestuous foreplay
column8: ” and that’s as cute as things get.

column1: Otherwise
column2: it’s brutal stuff: anonymous sex is pursued and consummated in a manner as merciless and cold as the mechanical animal beat of “No Eyes”: “It is not a matter of if you mean it/ But it is only a matter of come and fuck me.” Even more unsettling is “Incompatible”
column3: which is of a piece with “No Eyes”
column4: the same poisonous self-seeking and carnal misconduct brought much closer to home. Wiesenfeld deftly sets the scene by utilizing the connotations embedded in the unflattering aspects of cohabitation-- a shared toilet seat
column5: an unmade bed with “covers in divisive heaps.” From there on out
column6: he plays a manipulative
column7: abusive
column8: loveless lover where the sexual demands (“Nights you roll over and introduce yourself/ Nurse this erection back to full health”) are somehow less cruel than the gutwrenching asides you might hear at the dinner table: “You don’t do anything with your life /I could prod your hurt all night.” While the narrator admits

column1: These wouldn’t be shocking lyrics within the catalogs of Xiu Xiu or Perfume Genius

column3: if not peers

” what sticks is how he makes you wonder if you have “it” in you as well.

They compare themselves to small piles of rocks behind neglected railroad tracks

column3: jazzy music influenced by 1960s artists like Burt Bacharach or the Free Design-- music whose pleasant immediacy is actually the product of sophisticated planning. Each wayward handclap and casual jangle of guitar is matched with tight

column12: carefree backbeat of ""Night Time Made Us""
column13: he confesses
column14: ""I wanted to steal something that was already mine."" In case the idea wasn't clear

column4: equality

Few producers have made the recent transition from underground bass music enigma to pop-adjacent craftsman as seamlessly and effectively as Kingdom. It shouldn't be much of a surprise
column3: even if 2010's bracingly pounding That Mystic EP and its fun-through-overload atmosphere provided a strong first impression. His 2011 EP Dreama proved as much: here's a man who could use all that stomping bass of his to boost up some genuinely romantic-sounding R&B crossover that didn't just drop in nods to “Like a Prayer” ironically. He didn't lose force or energy in the process-- he just turned up the contrast and opened the blinds. Now he's closer than ever to perfectly balancing the two things in his music that've always stood out: heavy pulses and airy spaces.

column1: Vertical XL is even more soulful and warm than his Dreama material
column2: the kind of beats that would work wonders under a Chance the Rapper verse or a Katy B performance. Not to fantasy-book collaborators or anything
column3: but it really does fit the moment
column4: and leadoff cut “Bank Head” rises to the occasion. Its appearance as an instrumental on Night Slugs Allstars Volume 2 was a red herring: there were plenty of icily glowing synthpop homages to carry it
column5: but it feels more like a complete piece now that the final version adds vocals that complement its tense austerity. Singer Kelela
column6: an Angeleno with an upcoming mixtape on Kingdom's Night Slugs sister label Fade to Mind
column7: pulls off a name-making performance as the initially delicate
column8: increasingly impassioned voice that draws out
column9: complements
column10: and then drastically expands on the longing frustration of the track.

column1: Maybe it's the strong impression that “Bank Head” makes
column2: but from there on out the rest of the EP's alt-pop
column3: hip-hop and R&B tendencies jump to the forefront. The pull between deep percussive bass and the beats he doesn't drop continue to give his work a simultaneously heavy and aerodynamic sparseness
column4: a groove too clean to be chaotic but too forceful to really be minimal. And that approach-- intricacy in the service of simplicity-- is a good environment for his hookier tendencies to emerge. Even when things get moody
column5: they don't need a lot of coaxing to get danceable: the chain-clanking
column6: plinking-water darkness that sets off “Corpse” is overwhelmed by machine-gun kicks and synths that toe the line between foreboding and intimate
column7: and the minor-chord moan of “Viper Lash” has enough hopped-up percussive interplay piercing the surface to make it more thrilling than gloomy.

column1: When it's at its most explicitly future-pop stylized
column2: the music takes on some of Kingdom's best tendencies. The sparse
column3: heavy-foot loping “OG Master” isn't exactly a good-mood pool-party soundtrack on its own
column4: but the speaker-rattling resemblance to some of the more iconoclastic space-rap beats to emerge from grime-savvy Southern and West Coast underground producers works in its favor. And even through all the characteristically dense drum programming and intense forward motion
column5: the heart of “Viper XL” is a juxtaposition of synthpop and old-school house that lets him construct some of his most euphoric melodies yet. Kingdom's still a relatively low-profile entity-- for now
column6: at least-- but he does what pop musicians should do: build
column7: reinterpret
column8: transform
column9:
and revel in the possibilities of a long lineage of dance music. That he does so with only one vocal track makes it clear that his own voice is just getting stronger.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19244/homepage_large.d45b3bce.jpg|Infinity Pool|29483.0|When Saints Go Machine|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['K7']|2013-05-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:28.858260|"

From the Yeah Yeah Yeahs’ anti-cellphone signage to Savages’ humanist manifestos
column2: the 2013 musical landscape is starting to resemble a Terminator-style revolt against our machine masters. Even the robot rockers in Daft Punk are using their rare press appearances to extol the virtues of using real
column3: live sentient beings to perform on their new record. But don’t expect When Saints Go Machine to join the uprising; the Danish quartet don’t just embrace electronics
column4: they surrender to them. The band’s previous two releases inspired no lack of synth-pop descriptors
column5: but for them
column6: the synthesizer is a literal concept-- an interface that allows them to truly fuse the human and the artificial
column7: and translate emotions into digital frequencies and vice versa. Their band name may have started out as an awkward pun
column8: but at its core lies a certain modernness-is-next-to-godliness ideology.

column1: On Infinity Pool
column2: When Saints Go Machine treat their songs very much as machines-- i.e.
column3: mechanical objects that are constantly rewired and reassembled into new forms and functions. But as with any science-lab experiment
column4: the process is as arduous as it is illuminating. Both in terms of the internal song components and the tracklist as a whole
column5: Infinity Pool comes off as disjointed
column6: as if we’re hearing the band piece the tracks together in real time without a manual and hope the final product holds together. In Nikolaj Vonsild’s processed voice
column7: there's a palpable sense of wonder at his ability to transform his new-romantic croon into a sad-robot warble. But that curious quality ultimately proves to be the album’s undoing-- in that the band seem so enamored with the sounds they’re emitting
column8: they often lose sight of the songs.

column1: Ironically
column2: the odd-couple pairing with Killer Mike on lead single “Love & Respect” results in Infinity Pool’s most fully realized moment
column3: its gothic strings and gritty boom-bap beat effectively bridging the gap between the Atlanta rapper’s streetwise swagger and Vonsild’s trembling murmur. (Plus
column4: it’s a lot more fun and catchy than 2013’s other fey/gangsta hybrid.) However
column5: the fact it’s featured here as the opener only magnifies its complete disconnect from the rest of the album
column6: which deemphasizes rhythm and concision in favor of ominous bass drones
column7: doodling synths
column8: and perpetually rearranging melodies that often feel at odds with the music trying to support them.

column1: Compared to the relatively streamlined electro-pop of 2011’s Konkylie
column2: Infinity Pool is decidedly darker and a more demanding a listen. When their vision comes into focus
column3: When Saints Go Machine are capable of some arresting moments-- the beaming chorus of “System of Unlimited Love” and the clattering climax of “Slave to Your Take in Heaven
column4: ” in particular-- but they take a fair amount of trudging through moody
column5: meandering passages to get there. And the album’s sense of gravitas is continually undermined by the undue emphasis on Vonsild’s fragile voice
column6: which is over-modulated to the point of sounding cartoonish
column7: like Antony Hegarty karate-chopping his own throat to produce a faux underwater effect. There’s much to admire about When Saints Go Machine’s effort to move their synth-powered pop music away from the dancefloor into more cerebral realms. But like the band name itself

their attempts at cleverness can come off sounding clunky.

Sometimes it seems like NYC-via-Detroit drummer Gerald Cleaver turns up on half of all the interesting albums in forward-thinking jazz
column2: and it's been that way for more than a decade. Track the activities of scene pillars like Matthew Shipp and William Parker
column3: and younger luminaries such as Craig Taborn and Jeremy Pelt
column4: and Cleaver
column5: now 50
column6: will never be far behind. He's well documented as a bandleader too
column7: with three fine full-lengths stretching back to 2001
column8: all issued by connoisseur-friendly Barcelona label Fresh Sound New Talent.

column1: But jazz is only one facet of Cleaver's aesthetic. In the past
column2: he's engaged with the genre's time-tested traditions-- his second album
column3: 2008's Detroit
column4: was both deeply conventional and highly satisfying-- but as early as his 2001 debut
column5: Adjust
column6: he'd marked himself as a bandleader who values free-form textural exploration as much as an orderly progression of solos. For his new
column7: fourth record
column8: Life in the Sugar Candle Mines
column9: released under the group name Black Host
column10: he partners with a label that shares his broad vision. The Northern Spy roster includes avant-jazz heavyweights such as Charles Gayle (a longtime Cleaver associate)
column11: as well as Zs
column12: Rhys Chatham
column13: Hubble and other conceptually minded artists who have carved out personal niches that transcend genre. The album's engineer and mixer
column14: Bryce Goggin
column15: whose credits include Pavement
column16: Antony and the Johnsons
column17: and Phish
column18: fits neatly into this expansive company.

column1: The supporting cast is another tip-off that Cleaver is broadening his scope. The drummer's earlier bandleading sessions drew mostly from his peer group
column2: but in Black Host
column3: he's assembled an intergenerational all-star quintet
column4: featuring three of NYC's most volatile
column5: expressive improvisers. Saxist Darius Jones and guitarist Brandon Seabrook come equipped with heavy-duty punk-fusion credentials-- Jones plays in the harrowing collective quartet Little Women
column6: and Seabrook leads his own raw
column7: frenetic trio
column8: Seabrook Power Plant-- while pianist Cooper-Moore (a.k.a. Gene Ashton
column9: a longtime collaborator of the late saxophone force David S. Ware) has established himself over three-plus decades as an alternately tender and terrifying player.

column1: It's telling that Cleaver's name isn't on the marquee. Life in the Sugar Candle Mines features some outstanding drumming
column2: but the leader's core concept here is to let his formidable cast loose and see how the players combust
column3: both with each other and with a wide array of compositional tactics
column4: from crunchy
column5: choppy jazz rock to hazy psychedelic ambiance. The results are sprawling and sometimes draining
column6: but overall
column7: Cleaver's gamble succeeds. The record exudes a raw
column8: otherworldly beauty that you won't find anywhere else in contemporary music
column9: jazz or otherwise. (The Tony Williams Lifetime's Emergency! and other gritty late-60s/early-70s fusion statements are a definite touchstone
column10: but the record doesn't invest seriously in retro allusion.) Black Host's music is a well-tended hot-house: feverish and bracingly weird
column11: yet also purposeful and shrewdly strategic.

column1: Opener ""Hover"" is a brilliant collision of form and chaos. The piece starts with a nod to ecstatic 60s free jazz
column2: the instruments roiling and mingling
column3: but soon Cleaver segues into a driving
column4: waltz-time backbeat; like elements of a blurry photo slowly coming into focus
column5: the players unite in a gnarled yet triumphant theme
column6: with Seabrook's amp-frying tone heightening the punk-gone-gospel mood. The track crossfades ingeniously between blaring and pastoral modes.

column1: ""Citizen Rose""
column2: one of several ballad-like pieces on the record
column3: functions as an effective counterweight to the likes of ""Hover""
column4: and ""Ayler Children""
column5: which builds to a climax that's closer in feel to U.S. Maple's heady mid-90s avant-rock than the expressionist praise music of the piece's namesake. Jones
column6: Seabrook
column7: and Cooper-Moore (on synth) float through the ""Citizen Rose"" theme in a group trance
column8: urged on by Cleaver's exquisitely patient brushwork. The improvisational section that follows is the opposite of traditional jazz solo practice
column9: where each player takes a turn out front; instead it's an ambient psych soup
column10: with Seabrook's disembodied twang and Pascal Niggenkemper's moaning arco bass bubbling up from the murk.

column1: There's no getting around the fact that Life in the Sugar Candle Mines is a demanding record
column2: full of lengthy
column3: exploratory performances. (Of the eight tracks here
column4: four crack the 10-minute mark and none are significantly shorter than six.) Most of the time
column5: that's a good thing; the stretching feels urgent
column6: a key component of the weird spell Cleaver and co. are casting. ""Gromek"" is an exception. The woolly psych-jazz meditation
column7: which builds from a rustle to a roar over the course of nearly 13 minutes
column8: lacks a coherent narrative thrust.

column1: The album ends on a quietly stunning note
column2: with the slow-blooming ballad ""May Be Home"". In an ingenious arrangement move
column3: Cleaver effectively splits the quintet into two overlapping sub-groups. The track begins with a ghostly Jones/Seabrook duet
column4: which recalls the spectral seances that saxist Joe Lovano and guitarist Bill Frisell conducted in their long-running trio with late drumming master Paul Motian. The focus then shifts to the piano-bass-drums trio. Cooper-Moore eases into a balletic
column5: free-floating reverie
column6: virtuosic but not the slightest bit showy
column7: that might be the record's single most arresting passage. Cleaver rustles tastefully in the background
column8: demonstrating again what an unconventionally effective bandleader he is.

column1: For an open-minded listener not attuned to present-day jazz
column2: Life in the Sugar Candle Mines is an excellent entry point. It's too idiosyncratic to typify any broader movement
column3: but it transmits the untamed energy of the contemporary New York scene. The album never panders with obvious genre cues; Cleaver simply gathers the sounds and textures he needs from various sources and blends them without fuss. More importantly
column4: he does right by the essential tenets of jazz bandleading: Give your bandmates a clear
column5: compelling blueprint and embrace their spontaneous revisions. The result is an exemplary study in fantastical form
column6:
and the humanistic detonation thereof.

The year 2003 was a heady one for listening. On computers in the post-Napster landscape
column2: guitar-rock intermingled with avant-garde classical music as well as “clicks’n’cuts
column3: ” which in turn could mix with twee indie rock and the thumps of backpack rap. After <i>Kid A
column4: analog components could fuck with guitars and laptops and soon a slew of new artists were pushing beyond these genre distinctions: DFA’s discopunk was already afoot
column5: Jim O’Rourke had morphed from resplendent indie-pop fingerpicker to laptop noisenik
column6: a producer from Florida named Diplo was mashing together heavy psychedelic rock breaks into something for rap heads
column7: while underground hip-hop was getting strange and musty thanks to Madlib’s myriad personas.

column1: The Class of 2003 also offered up three upcoming producers who embraced every sound on their hard drives and within one month that year
column2: they all released their breakthrough efforts. There was Prefuse 73’s One Word Extinguisher
column3: the soon-to-be-renamed-Caribou’s Up in Flames
column4: and Four Tet's Rounds. The first melded IDM’s glitches to backpacker breaks while the second mashed it to psychedelic sunshine pop; Rounds
column5: the third album for Kieran Hebden's project
column6: grabbed at all of the above while also including jazz and folk. For the listeners out there who knew Hebden from his days in instrumental post-rock outfit Fridge and who might have considered his early recordings under the name of Four Tet as more of a side attraction than main gig
column7: Rounds announced the arrival of one of electronic music’s vanguard producers.

column1: The album opened with a recording of a dog’s heartbeat before Hebden lets it bloom into free meter drum rolls that evoked the amoebic pulses that defined late 60s experimental jazz before tightening it all up with a beat that headnodded at hip-hop without quite being beholden to it. That three distinct rhythms (cardiac
column2: jazz
column3: hip-hop) could effortlessly convene on “Hands” augured Hebden’s formidable beat skills
column4: which even in the present tense pull from house
column5: 2-step
column6: Afrobeat
column7: and dubstep while remaining singular.

column1: It makes sense that Hebden so easily drew from multiple genres. As he revealed in a recent interview
column2: Rounds was comprised entirely of samples. But that he draws from the most arcane source material available speaks to Hebden’s touch; on Rounds
column3: his obscure sources serve the overall poignancy of the music. So while “She Moves She” retains the crisp snare and hi-hat work that underpinned millennial R&B productions
column4: it’s the twinkling glockenspiel line that gives the track its emotional heft. Same for the harp line that intermingles with the iron lung beat of “My Angel Rocks Back and Forth.” Sampledelic or not
column5: Four Tet’s music feels personal rather than patchwork.

column1: The media catchphrase for mixing the pastoral airs of folk music with electronic music’s low-end became “folktronica
column2: ” a term Hebden detested and kicked against with each subsequent release. He embraced the fiery
column3: brassy tones of spiritual jazz for his follow-up Everything Ecstatic and soon after began collaborating in earnest with free jazz drummer Steve Reid (while also producing for folk-jazz-noise-nonsense freewheelers Sunburned Hand of the Man). And when that generation-gap crossing collaboration ended with Reid’s passing in 2010
column4: Hebden dove headfirst into modern dance music
column5: taking in two-step
column6: jungle
column7: dubstep
column8: techno and house
column9: reconfiguring these heavier rhythms into something suiting his own manner. And as Pink recently showed
column10: Four Tet’s knack for instantly-identifiable melody remains undiluted
column11: no matter how strong and dancefloor-filling his new tracks are.

column1: While touring for Rounds
column2: Hebden began to slough off the “folk” tag of his live shows
column3: pushing at the parameters of what a laptop could do onstage. The bonus disc on this 10th anniversary edition of Rounds reveals him at the height of his powers. Recorded live in Copenhagen
column4: it finds Hebden taking the melodies and beanie-nodding rhythms of Rounds further and further out into the cosmos. “She Moves She” dilates from four to 10 minutes
column5: with Hebden finding new pockets of space amid the string twangs and kick to add skittering samples and blurs of noise. A metallophone sample similarly gets rubberbanded-- at times resounding like a Balinese gamelan orchestra
column6: other times flickering in even patterns like Steve Reich’s Music for 18 Musicians-- before turning into “Spirit Fingers”.

column1: The most astounding transformation occurs on “As Serious As Your Life”. The track’s taut drum break suddenly has Tibetan chimes
column2: ghost notes
column3: scraped strings
column4: and electroacoustic gurgles mingle with its snare and hi-hat before the recognizable part of the song drops. But soon Hebden mutates it into a 15-minute monster that gobbles up every single genre tag in the process
column5: until it’s a dervish of noise. As the original album proved and this reissue reinforces
column6: Four Tet showed a new generation of listeners that much like 60s jazz before him-- which could embody soul
column7: gospel
column8: blues and primal howls while still sounding like “The New Thing”-- 21st century laptop music could be as serious as your life
column9:
too.

This time last year was a trying time for Pure X: Nate Grace busted his knee skateboarding but didn't have insurance
column2: multi-instrumentalist Jesse Jenkins was going through a breakup
column3: and drummer Austin Youngblood moved to be with his girlfriend in Los Angeles. While all that was going on
column4: they were also working on Crawling Up the Stairs
column5: the follow-up to their splendidly hazy debut LP

column8: as they call it
column9: sparing no attention to detail.

column1: Where Pleasure unfurls like a drop of ink in a glass of water
column2: Crawling Up the Stairs has a plan. ""There's kind of a hard descent
column3: Jenkins explained
column4: ""and the rest of the record is a slow ascent back up to reality."" Pure X also made a studied departure from the feedback and reverb that occasionally muffled Pleasure's finer textures. On Crawling Up the Stairs
column5: they looked for guitar sounds <a href=""http://www.thelineofbestfit.com/features/interviews/pure-x-one-night-i-had-a-true-battle-with-what-jung-called-the-shadow-self-and-what-i-would-call-a-demon-123800"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""like glass knives slicing through your eardrums
column6: influenced by Nashville's golden era of high-polish production

column8: Electric Larryland. The diamond-cut dulcimer that opens ""Thousand Year Old Child"" sounds more at home on a sunlit Brooklyn rooftop than the dark
column9: dusty Texas basements in which it originated
column10: and the bowed piano splintering the end of ""Never Alone"" feels almost three-dimensional. When the guitars do squall
column11: they radiantly explode into being instead of burning low and dirty
column12: as they did on Pure X's earlier releases.

column1: Sometimes this clarity comes at the expense of the smoldering noise that made their last album so sensual
column2: but Pure X make up for lost immediacy by giving a lot more attention to Crawling's vocals. Rustling whispers and conspiratorial voices on ""Shadows and Lies"" are the perfect companions to Grace's rangy
column3: paranoid wails. In fact
column4: it's almost a relief to hear him totally lose it for once
column5: howling himself ragged on ""How Did You Find Me"" instead of keeping his voice at a safely reverbed distance from the listener. After Grace rips his throat apart
column6: Jenkins-- who
column7: for the first time
column8: shares singing duties-- is there to pick up the pieces with his sweet and haunting falsetto. Despite Grace's injuries
column9: it's Jenkins who sings
column10: ""The pain in my body is so great"" on ""I Fear What I Feel""
column11: reaching high octaves of pain repeated across several lines like a dull
column12: throbbing ache.

column1: Jenkins has said Pure X won't make their next record the same way they made Crawling Up the Stairs
column2: which makes sense-- how many times can a band have a collective nervous breakdown?-- but hopefully they'll find a few takeaways from the creative process behind their second album. It may not be as instantly gratifying as Pleasure
column3:
but it's more sophisticated and self-aware.

It's been five-and-a-half long years since Saturday Looks Good to Me
column2: Eastern Michigan's premier temp agency for indie-poppers
column3: gave us Fill Up the Room. Not that Saturday bossman Fred Thomas hasn't kept himself busy
column4: forming the dreamy City Center and issuing a couple Neil Young-ish LPs under his own name. Thomas
column5: ever the compartmentalizer
column6: largely abandoned the sweeping romance of Saturday's Motown-and-Northern Soul-inflected indie-pop
column7: letting his most famous project fall by the wayside in order to pursue these noisier
column8: rootsier stylings. But
column9: though many
column10: him included
column11: thought Fill Up the Room would remain the last Saturday LP
column12: the songs that wound up on One Kiss Ends It All would sound awfully strange from any other Thomas project. Despite their fluid personnel-- Thomas frequently recruits new singers for each Saturday LP-- the idea of what a Saturday song is and isn't hasn't changed: great big hooks
column13: peculiar little emotions.

column1: That said
column2: One Kiss Ends It All doesn't exactly pick up where Fill Up the Room left off. With the benefit of hindsight
column3: Fill Up seems something of an outlier in the Saturday catalog
column4: having straightened out some of the blurrier edges that marked the band's earlier work. One Kiss
column5: on the other hand
column6: nudges the frame
column7: casting everything at a slightly odd angle. Little scratches and pops abound deep in the mix
column8: vocals get warped halfway through verses
column9: saxophones collide headlong into strings. The whole thing's just silly with melody. The warm
column10: wistful One Kiss plays like a dodgy mixtape of lonesome teenage classics dubbed over so many times that ""Where Did Our Love Go?"" is starting to bleed through ""The Stars of Track and Field"".

column1: Amidst all these instrumental crinkles
column2: One Kiss is best at its most direct. The jaunty ""New City"" takes a rather a slash-and-burn stance on public policy: ""The city's falling apart
column3: new recruit Carol Catherine sings
column4: ""It's time to build a new city
column5: a hard-to-miss allusion to the ailing Detroit some of Saturday call home. ""Are You Kissing Anyone?"" is pure vaseline-on-lens
column6: achey last-dance-at-prom stuff.

column1: When that directness falters
column2: so does everything else. Thomas' occasional overreliance on metaphor muddies the sentiments at the heart of some of these tracks
column3: and a couple songs find him mixing the vocals low enough as to render their words virtually incomprehensible; one wonders why he'd invite somebody over to sing only to bury the take in reverb. Vocally
column4: Thomas is in fine company throughout One Kiss
column5: but between the constant turnover behind the microphone and all that instrumental foofaraw
column6: One Kiss sometimes feels a little overstuffed. ""Negative Space""
column7: ironically enough
column8: gets the worst of it; after a stirring verse
column9: the song dips into spacey ambience
column10: essentially killing time before its rousing climax. The good songs on One Kiss are constantly reshuffling themselves
column11: shifting fidelities
column12: rearranging instruments; the couple of really great ones (""New City""
column13: ""Sunglasses"") seem to dispose with all the fuss and get right to the point.

column1: Still
column2: when words fail Thomas and company
column3: their music rarely does. Despite the rough patches
column4: One Kiss is largely rich and rousing
column5: quick to grab your ear even when it fails to snag your emotions. It's not always easy to put names to the in-between feelings Thomas explores with Saturday Looks Good to Me: not just love
column6: but yearning; not just missing someone
column7: but the way that someone you're missing can start to feel like a specter
column8: an ""Invisible Friend"". Thomas occasionally puts too many layers between himself and the listener
column9: and it's not always easy to tell what he means to say
column10: particular when most of it's being said by someone else. But throughout One Kiss
column11: it's obvious how much Thomas missed writing these stirring
column12: expansive
column13: romantic pop songs for Saturday Looks Good to Me. Even as they sputter through certain emotions
column14:
that longing comes through loud and clear.

Dean Blunt is heartbroken
column3: possibly. The Redeemer is his break-up album
column4: a relatively straightforward affair after numerous releases that seemed to reveal as little about him as possible-- or maybe they revealed everything. His prior work
column5: both on his own and with sometime partner Inga Copeland
column6: varied wildly in quality
column7: finally reaching a dead end with last year's The Narcissist II
column8: a half-assed tribute to half-assedness. Where do you go from there? For Blunt
column9: the answer is to lose the dopey feel of his prior records
column10: strip away the layers of fuzz
column11: and etch out a set of short ballads that form something resembling a relationship crisis album. There are occasional diversions-- distraught voicemail messages
column12: clocks chiming ominously-- but much of The Redeemer assimilates the feel of someone slumped over a bar
column13: reading the last rites on a romance.

column1: The most interesting thing this album does is pose a few questions about substance and how it's ascribed. Does Dean Blunt now come with added ""weight"" due to sad horn solos
column2: sweeping strings
column3: and the sound of hands running up and down harp strings? No
column4: not really. Often it sounds like someone keenly aware of the trappings of music that reads as ""heartbroken
column5: and how to manipulate them. At least it occasionally seems like there's genuine hurt there
column6: sometimes from a twist in Blunt's voice
column7: or a passage of particularly weepy piano playing. But most of the songs are half-formed and barely able to gain any momentum
column8: strangled by track lengths that clock in around the one- or two-minute mark. There's a strong sense of something as transient as the Narcissist material
column9: just dressed up in different clothing.

column1: Fortunately
column2: The Redeemer isn't just an elongated comment on how heavily certain devices have been leaned on throughout music history. On a song like ""Demon""
column3: tellingly one of the longest here
column4: Blunt ties together vocal manipulations
column5: sound collage
column6: pounding drums
column7: and even a softly tooting trumpet solo. It finds room to bridge between Blunt's prior inclinations for haze and the roomier ones he works in here. His work as an arranger is often skilled
column8: even if the end result either can't or won't get beyond feeling like a simple exercise. ""All Dogs Go to Heaven"" is his attempt at a Histoire de Melody Nelson cut; ""Make It Official"" briefly dips into woozy David Sylvian territory. Even Inga Copeland
column9: possibly the person cast as Blunt's subject matter
column10: surfaces on the title track
column11: although her appearance lacks any dramatic élan. The Redeemer is too cynical an enterprise for that
column12: always stopping short of actually feeling very much.

column1: There is some worth in giving common musical tropes a kicking
column2: although Blunt's approach-- essentially swilling the dregs of balladry around in his mouth and spewing them out-- too often ends up more flaccid than the style he's referencing. The Redeemer ends up somewhere between sarcasm and sensitivity
column3: but can't dig deep enough in either direction to provide something that's worth returning to. The fragmented nature of the tracks
column4: where ideas are set in motion and just trail off into insubstantial thought
column5: can't get to the genesis of what makes material like this work. Pop that comments on pop needs to have a thorough understanding of the form in order to function. As a consequence
column6: it doesn't really matter whether this is Blunt making a genuine attempt at recording a break-up album or using it as a framework to illustrate how vacuous such a gesture can be. Whatever he was looking for
column7:
he hasn't found it here.

Throughout “Whirlwind”

column1: There are four primary parts to Rubinos’ busy sound: her electric

column6: and she yells with frustration
column7: knowing that her memory of this guy is already fading. By “Let’s Go Out”
column8: the drums slump with dejection: She's given up trying to remember. After the tropical wilds that precede it
column9: the synthetic
column10: silvery keyboards here sound effectively bleak.

column1: Although Rubinos’ heart is aching
column2: she's not completely giving up on life in color; “I Like Being Alone” is a chirruping ode to solitude: “Because it means I don’t have to be something I’m not.../ Because it means I don’t have to consider you/ I can just be awful like I am/ I can be as lazy as I am.” It’s that comfort with her own ideas and company that makes Magic Trix so life-affirming

then Magic Trix is the glitter in the dark.

Alex Zhang Hungtai of Dirty Beaches isn't shy about his influences. A year after 2011's breakthrough Badlands elicited comparisons to retro-damaged ancestors Suicide
column3: he released a recording of an improv-heavy performance in Norway that featured a ""loose adaptation"" of Suicide's ""Ghost Rider"". Earlier this year
column4: Hungtai shared the title track to the second disc of his new double-album
column5: Drifters/Love Is the Devil
column6: accompanied with a quote attributed to wastrel poet and professed inspiration Charles Bukowski: ""Love is a fog that burns with the first daylight of reality."" And the YouTube account used to host the song was an abused portmanteau of Chinese director Wong Kar-wai's name.

column1: Hungtai told Pitchfork around the time of Badlands' release that his media-saturated theatricality spoke to his own experience as a perpetually displaced stranger in strange lands-- he was born in Taiwan
column2: but raised in Montreal: ""Nostalgia can be a sickness or melancholia
column3: like how immigrants that came to North America feel homesick. I don't really have a place where I can say I was born and raised. Home is a collage of all these different
column4: fractured landscapes that I try to piece together.""

column1: Badlands was an impressive work
column2: but it was also sonically limited
column3: switching almost exclusively between howling open-road antagonism and evocative
column4: soft-focus balladry. On Drifters/Love Is the Devil
column5: all previous limitations are off the table. The double album
column6: recorded in Montreal and Brian Jonestown Massacre frontman Anton Newcombe's Berlin studio over a period of six months
column7: is both sprawling and detailed
column8: a sonic travelogue that takes the textural aspects of his work to impressionistic heights. Though few have heard his earlier material
column9: Dirty Beaches' catalog is more diverse than the two-headed focus of Badlands suggested. But Drifters/Love Is the Devil is more robust and eccentric than anything he's ever released before.

column1: This pair of albums also represents some of Hungtai's most experimental work yet
column2: a hard left-turn from Badlands' song-oriented approach. There are a few excellent echoes of that previous record's sound on Drifters-- the junkyard roll of ""Night Walk""
column3: ""I Dream in Neon""'s bad-vibes glow
column4: the raw blast of ""Casino Lisboa""-- but song structure is less of a concern here. This music isn't impenetrable
column5: but for those who listen more for song structure
column6: it might take a few listens to lock into what Hungtai's doing. Much of the material collected on both discs-- each is about 37 minutes long and has its own title
column7: though they are sold together-- comprises vignettes of varying length that exist in their own space. But a front-to-back listen starting with Drifters is the best way to take in the rich
column8: haunting soundscapes on display.

column1: Drifters
column2: focusing more on songs
column3: is the more accessible record
column4: but it's also a confrontational work. The sole instrumental
column5: ""Belgrade""
column6: featuring synthetic oscillations matched with a perpetually doubled-over bass line
column7: is chilling. Its electronic textures are submerged in pools of echo
column8: bringing to mind vast
column9: empty spaces that create an uneasy atmosphere; ""ELLI"" is a gothic
column10: coldwave-leaning song about aspirational love (""In my dreams I'm always with you"")
column11: while ""Aurevoir Mon Visage"" finds Hungtai shouting in French over tumbling drums and a low jet-engine roar: ""Goodbye my face/ It is nothing"".

column1: And then there's ""Mirage Hall""
column2: which towers over Drifters and proves its most satisfying surprise. Hungtai has flirted with electronic music before
column3: on 2010's Night People-released cassette Night City
column4: but he's never operated with this kind of scope. Over nine harrowing minutes
column5: he and collaborators Shub Roy and Bernardino Femminielli build a thick monolith of clattering techno
column6: broken up by ethereal moans that eventually dissolve into high-pitched howling noise. Five minutes in
column7: Hungtai enters screaming in Spanish
column8: his vocal performance turning from muscular to absolutely blood-curdling.

column1: The weatherbeaten horns and underwater ambience of Drifters' closing track
column2: ""Landscapes in the Mist""
column3: act as something of a portal to Love Is the Devil's drastic shift in sound. Hungtai has hinted that Love is a breakup album
column4: but you don't need any context to hear this music as impossibly sad and lonely.

column1: By design
column2: Love Is the Devil is much more abstract than its counterpart; ""Woman"" is four minutes of synth and distant
column3: irregularly plinked piano
column4: while the second section of ""Like the Ocean We Part"" is a minute-and-a-half of what sounds like railroad field recordings. Give it time
column5: though
column6: and the album reveals itself as the more impressive of the two
column7: a dense and cinematic exploration of grief and loss that is as pretty (the title track's swelling strings) as it is desolate (""Like the Ocean We Part (I)""'s dolorous vocals and radiant
column8: solitary guitar). The highlight of the record-- and
column9: possibly
column10: the collection as a whole-- is the centerpiece ""Alone at the Danube River""
column11: a seven-minute that features a guitar solo eventully overcome<span> by waves of shimmering synths. In sound and spirit
column12: it brings to mind Neil Young's masterful soundtrack for Jim Jarmusch's gloriously empty 1995 Western Dead Man.

column1: For me
column2: ""Alone at the Danube River"" has an uncanny ability to lodge itself in my mind. After months of listening to Drifters/Love Is the Devil
column3: its central guitar figure loops endlessly in my head
column4: something I want to hum or whistle. And I think fits with Hungtai's overall artistic intention and shows why he's such an interesting artist. These records
column5: steeped in reference and atmosphere
column6: draw on memory but
column7: being so textured and tactile
column8:
they bring the focus back to the present moment.

A Complete History of Popular Music was the cheeky subtitle of a 2007 label compilation by Sweden's Labrador. Now eight albums deep
column2: Labrador mainstay Club 8's unassumingly rewarding discography tells its own version of indie pop's history over the past 15-plus years. The duo of composer-instrumentalist Johan Angergård and wispy-voiced singer Karolina Komstedt has cycled through aspects of bedsit pop
column3: hi-NRG chic
column4: trip-hop noir
column5: and quiet-is-the-new-loud bossa nova
column6: eventually encompassing many of those within a tender
column7: nuanced take on acoustic pop-- and that's not mentioning the pair's prior work with the twee-leaning Poprace
column8: or Angergård's ongoing roles in the noisier Legends and lushly orchestrated Acid House Kings.

column1: Above the City
column2: while as stylistically diverse as Club 8's back catalog
column3: is once again strikingly of the moment. After turning to producer Jari Haapalainen (Camera Obscura
column4: the Concretes) for 2010's The People's Record
column5: which delved into African-inspired polyrhythms
column6: Angergård returns to the boards-- or
column7: the old-school Cubase VST audio software-- this time around. Centered around icy synth pop and vibrant disco
column8: the band's latest should be readily embraced among audiences primed by the Drive soundtrack
column9: Daft Punk's ""Get Lucky""
column10: and the diaspora of groups influenced by the Knife's ""Heartbeats."" That said
column11: the record largely maintains Club 8's familiar low-key reserve

column1: Even after so many little sonic shifts over the years
column2: Above the City still impresses with how adeptly Club 8 conquer new terrain. Opener ""Kill Kill Kill"" bears the late-night post-disco skulk of Johnny Jewel's Italians Do It Better groups. Fellow preview track ""Stop Taking My Time""
column3: with its creepy sampled chatter
column4: finds Komstedt raising her voice to inhabit gothy 80s synths convincingly-- think Robyn's ""Dancing on My Own"" if she wanted to be on her own
column5: goddammnit. ""Hot Sun"" just as convincingly rolls out the beach blanket for a dubwise meditation. And the album's closing two songs are glossy stompers so uncharacteristically outsized that Angergård has said he considered sampling Queen's ""We Will Rock You"".

column2: and a sure bet to become someone's favorite. The minimal techno-inspired strut of ""You Could Be Anybody"" or the gauzy electro-pop grandeur of ""Run"" could make for equally easy entry points. It's fair to say the various instrumentals are skippable

column4: over the ebullient neo-disco of ""I'm Not Gonna Grow Old""
column5: that ""I want to stay somewhat like me
column6:
it's clear Club 8 hope to remain constantly open to new perspectives while still staying true to themselves.
