Glenn Jones turns a trick with the title of his fifth album for solo acoustic guitar and banjo
column4: My Garden State. Jones is known best as a Boston musician
column5: having led the city’s art-rock updaters Cul de Sac through the 1990s and having alluded to his adopted hometown with the names and anecdotes of several cuts on previous records. But Jones grew up in northern New Jersey. During the last several years
column6: he’s often returned to his childhood home for extended periods to take care of his mother
column7: who has Alzheimer’s disease. The bulk of My Garden State was written during these eldercare furloughs
column8: prompting Jones to take the thematically logical step of recording the tunes in New Jersey
column9: too
column10: 60 miles or so south at the farmhouse of friend and collaborator Laura Baird.

column1: But this wistful 10-tune set is called My Garden State
column2: not The Garden State
column3: a clever way for Jones to sidestep songs about New Jersey so as to offer his experience with discovery
column4: love
column5: and loss within the state itself. Sure
column6: the names of several numbers reference specific area locales-- the Tappan Zee Bridge that spans the Hudson River
column7: the teeming county where Jones grew up
column8: the nursing home where his mother now lives-- but these are places that have meant something to Jones. There is no ode to the Boardwalk
column9: no observations on the state’s industrial cornucopia
column10: and no interpolation of “Where Eagles Dare”. Instead
column11: these songs are intensely personal reflections on the cycle of life as he’s seen it here. “The Vernal Pool”
column12: for instance
column13: is an improvisation Jones played shortly after Baird showed him the farm habitat of spadefoot toads
column14: which use the “spades” of their feet to dig into their subterranean lairs for a season’s rest. When it rains in the spring
column15: they dig their way out and become “explosive breeders.” Jones saw the toads in the fall
column16: when they still lurked underground. This piece starts with listless hibernation
column17: his slow notes languishing inside their own decay. Across its five minutes
column18: though
column19: it builds into a bustle
column20: with a thumbed bass line muscling its way through a raga-like flurry of sound. Even at its most vibrant and vivid
column21: “The Vernal Pool” reveals a constant vein of anxiety
column22: as if to acknowledge at once the world’s forever-chained wonder and worry while celebrating it

column1: Indeed
column2: My Garden State is defined by its sincerely bittersweet sense
column3: where Jones never seems too mournful of or sentimental for the past nor overly naïve for some idealized future. Jones’ work isn’t emotionally conflicted; it’s simply emotionally honest
column4: with his fingers doling out lessons as he’s learned them. These instrumentals seem to acknowledge Jones’ feelings as they are-- mixed and confusing and sometimes overwhelming
column5: with the sweetness of childhood memories tempered by the exigencies of the present and the uncertainty of what’s ahead. “Bergen County Farewell”
column6: written after Jones and his sisters had finally sold the family home
column7: sublimates nostalgia into optimism and back again. Its darting melody is bright and cheery
column8: but there’s sadness tucked between the notes
column9: too
column10: like a worried mind behind a well-intentioned smile. “Blues for Tom Carter”
column11: ostensibly written for Jones’ fellow guitar traveler after the Charalambides co-founder fell seriously ill while on tour last year
column12: doesn’t dip into full-lament mode as its title might suggest; rather
column13: it feels like an affable Sunday afternoon phone call to an old friend
column14: as though Jones is simply checking in to make sure everything is OK. You can imagine Carter making a wisecrack on the other end of the line.

column1: Both of the album’s guitar extended guitar marvels-- the eight-minute duet with Meg Baird
column2: “Going Back to East Montgomery”
column3: and the slightly shorter “Like a Sick Eagle Looking at the Sky”-- thrive on such emotional imbalance. They’re both relatively warm and welcoming tunes; in fact
column4: when Baird’s guitar joins Jones’ for the refrain
column5: it’s possible to picture day breaking to the sound of the strings’ bright harmonies. For most of the piece
column6: though
column7: Jones simply winds back and forth through one lithe melody
column8: a reminder that any “sweet shot of joy
column9: ” as he calls Baird’s playing in the liner notes
column10: matters most because of the humdrum toil it interrupts. “Sick Eagle” is more dimly lit
column11: but Jones lifts the melody at just the right moments
column12: offering a sudden horizon of hopefulness.

column1: Perhaps it’s strange to call any instrumentalist a master storyteller
column2: but five albums into his solo career
column3: that’s starting to seem like the most apt summation of Jones’ talents. The liner notes of My Garden State include the tuning systems of each of these songs
column4: as well as technical notes about capo placement and a brief narrative about each tune’s inspiration. Aspiring guitarists might need the alternate tuning suggestions
column5: but listeners won’t really need the anecdotes. Rather
column6: Jones puts it all right there in the pieces
column7: speaking volume about the challenges and triumphs of growing up and older without singing a word of the blues. My Garden State is your Garden State
column8: too
column9:
a collection of magnetic ruminations that applies to anyone who’s ever struggled to go back home or leave it in the first place.

Following 2010's The Heart of the Nightlife
column3: which celebrated the inherent ""I Love Us"" factor of a couple making music together
column4: Kisses' now-engaged Jesse Kivel and Zinzi Edmundson are taking a more thoughtful turn on their second album. Inspired in part by Bret Easton Ellis' Less Than Zero
column5: Kids in L.A. follows a group of rich Bel Air teenagers suffering from Los Angeles' mid-winter ennui. ""I've been unbalanced over my time at the pool
column6: Kivel sings in one of the album's many ""The O.C.""-worthy moments. Like cloud cover on what moments ago was a sunny day
column7: the honeymoon froth and bounce of Kisses' debut have been subsumed by moody bass lines and the angst of privileged teens. While it's admirable that Kisses turned their puppy dog-eyes outward

column1: Part of the problem is due to location

column3: Kivel said in an interview a few years ago. On Kids in L.A.
column4: Kisses seem to have internalized this off-the-cuff remark; instead of engaging with the abuse of privilege they claim as an influence in a meaningful way

column4: which ripples like disturbed water. The luxurious urgency that Larcombe brought to his work with Lana Del Rey is tempered here by crisply gated snares reminiscent of Lisa Lisa and Debbie Deb

column6: but ""Having Friends Over"" is the most effective combination of them. Pumping with dancefloor bends and snaps

column1: The best song on Kids in L.A. is ""Funny Heartbeat""

Though it’s known as the devil’s music
column2: rock'n'roll has always adopted the language of religion: New bands are often propped up as “saviors”; artists with especially fervent fans are labelled “cult” acts; and pretty much every transcendence-seeking rock band has
column3: at some point in their careers
column4: recorded a song called “Shine a Light”. So that the Source Family functioned as both a religious sect and an interconnected network of rock groups is not totally surprising; what’s most remarkable about this early-70s hippie enclave was their industriousness. Unlike another Californian “family” of radicals led by an aspiring musician
column5: the Source Family applied their anti-establishment ideologies-- as espoused by their 50-something
column6: fearsomely bearded leader Father Yod-- to mostly benevolent ends: They operated a popular
column7: celeb-studded vegetarian restaurant on the Sunset Strip (a precursor to the lucrative health-food industry) and issued their music as a series of small-run
column8: self-produced albums (making them unlikely harbingers of punk’s DIY
column9: handmade ethos)
column10: all while avoiding the mass suicide-- if not the skeezy polyamory-- that typically defines such rogue religions.

column1: It’s these records that have rescued the Source Family from a 70s-footnote fate. Since 2006
column2: Drag City has been overseeing an extensive reissue series to complement a label roster that has long served as a safe haven for modern-day psychedelic eccentrics. But the latest part of the campaign could push the Source Family story beyond record-collector realms to mainstream movie-goers in the form of a documentary
column3: The Source Family
column4: that recounts the group’s history through the mostly fond remembrances of its ex-members. And with it comes a soundtrack that should provide a convenient entry point into the Family’s deep discography. But unlike
column5: say
column6: the recent Searching For Sugarman soundtrack
column7: The Source Family has no ambition to serve as a greatest-hits retrospective of an obscure artist. It’s more like a K-Tel commercial for one
column8: presenting a fleeting series of snippets that provide but a surface-level overview of its subject.

column1: Much like the Source Family’s history
column2: the soundtrack begins innocently enough-- with the acoustic lullaby-cum-recruitment theme “Home”-- before drifting into more chaotic terrain. (Driven out of L.A. after frequent hassles with the cops
column3: the Family relocated to Hawaii
column4: where
column5: in suitably Icarusian fashion
column6: Yod met his demise in a hang-gliding accident in 1975.) A clip of a speech delivered by Yod to a Beverly Hills high school (!) in 1974 espouses the virtues of free improvisation
column7: however the Family’s musical principles were actually quite organized
column8: with Yod centering different group aggregates around specific sounds: Father Yod and the Spirit of 76 specialized in spiritual psych-folk and drone; Children of the Sixth Root Race proffered rousing
column9: gospel-infused pop; YoHoWa 13 explored the outer limits of Hendrixian acid-rock; while Father and the Original Source Family issued recordings of chants inspired by traditional Jewish prayer. Stripped of the sensational backstory
column10: the Source Family’s most accomplished songs can easily hold their own against the popular classic rock of the era: It’s not hard to imagine the sassy soul strut “How Long in Time” flowing out of Carole King’s “I Feel the Earth Move” on your local AM-radio station in 1972
column11: and if some misinformed torrenter were to accidentally mislabel the righteously indignant “Godmen” as an unearthed Jefferson Airplane jam from Woodstock
column12: no one would question it.

column1: But the Family’s more outré excursions are ill-served by the compact format of this soundtrack
column2: whose second half is given over to a random assortment of frustratingly brief excerpts of more substantial recordings. The uncannily Can-like “To the Principles for the Children” and proto-doom-metal lurch of “Penetration” suggest there’s a case to be made for the Source Family as vanguard-pushing visionaries rather than some bygone freakshow curio
column3: but in this abbreviated context these experiments come off as scatterbrained whims. Ultimately
column4: this soundtrack functions best as an invitation for the curious to delve deeper into the Drag City reissues. Rather than deliver an all-consuming religious experience
column5:
The Source Family feels more like a brochure handed to you by some robed devotee at the airport. 

"|18052.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18052-the-source-family-the-source-family/|6.6|Stuart Berman

Imagine someone at your otherwise-mundane party has dropped ecstasy; he's the only one there who has done so. Flushed
column2: sweaty
column3: intense
column4: he stares everyone directly in the eyes and says things like ""I see this light coming from behind and growing to enormous size. This is magic."" Ignoring everyone's obvious discomfort
column5: he presses on mercilessly: ""Hey mister
column6: he asks
column7: locking eyes with you. ""Don't you want to be right here?""

column1: Devon Welsh sings these lines on Impersonator
column2: his second album with synth programmer Matthew Otto under the name Majical Cloudz. And this role-- the Jehovah's Witness ringing your doorbell at 7 a.m. to save your life
column3: the AA member interrupting your lunch hour to explain how his fear of being loved led him to key your Volkswagen last April-- is the role that Welsh plays on Impersonator. In his searingly direct live shows
column4: which have often ended with Welsh standing in the crowd

column6: and on record
column7: Welsh burns through surrounding obstacles in order make you feel what he is feeling. Impersonator is a gorgeous record-- extraordinarily sung

column1: The foundation of the music is synth pop
column2: though Welsh and Otto use it to construct glacially paced
column3: small pieces of music with almost no harmonic motion. Most songs are made of three or fewer elements: ""Childhood's End"" has a four-note keyboard melody
column4: two bare notes of synth string
column5: one droning ""ahhh"" note
column6: and a heartbeat-pulse click track. The air around each element is as palpable-- and as important to the track-- as the elements themselves. On the title track
column7: some voices
column8: looped and babbling
column9: are the only sounds accompanying Welsh
column10: apart from a hushed burst of church organ. There is a natural
column11: inexorable feel to the repetition of these sounds; like clear water quarreling over smooth stones
column12: they're an impersonal constant that situates Welsh's painfully personal performance somewhere larger than himself.

column1: The simplicity of the sound also mirrors the purity and directness of Welsh's language. Here's his idea of an icebreaker: ""Hey man
column2: sooner or later you'll be dead."" ""I wanna feel like somebody's darling
column3: he sings on ""Impersonator"". Welsh's are the carefully chosen words of someone whose life depends on getting his point across
column4: and his lyrics often read
column5: on paper
column6: like self-help: ""I feel the mood to love myself and I know I'm trying
column7: he says on ""Mister"". But to someone dangling by a thread
column8: self-help clichés take on a terrible significance
column9: and Welsh's voice conveys the desperation of someone who has been tasked with believing in the simplest things again.

column1: Welsh has said that
column2: although he gravitated naturally towards the frontman role of whatever band he was in
column3: he was never trained to sing. Listening to his expertly modulated phrasing
column4: his long-breathed lines
column5: and his rich
column6: even tone on Impersonator
column7: it's kind of hard to believe. (For his part
column8: Welsh attributes his natural vocal command to the fact that his father is actor Kenneth Welsh
column9: best known for playing ""Twin Peaks""' Windom Earle.) There is a hint of Depeche Mode's David Gahan in the plummy edges of his voice
column10: but Gahan's camp and hauteur are burned away; Gahan used those tools to establish distance
column11: and Welsh's aim is to close it. He is startlingly flexible
column12: capable of dipping to Calvin Johnson-basso profundo lows
column13: but without Johnson's training-wheels wobbles. He can ascend effortlessly into a bell-clear head-voice that recalls the George Michael of ""One More Try"". His velvety
column14: heated vocal take on ""Turns Turns Turns""
column15: while not a pyrotechnic performance
column16: remains one of the most nakedly beautiful pieces of singing I've heard this year
column17: in any genre.

column1: You can hear the idiosyncrasies of Welsh's self-training poke out of some of the album's odder edges. On ""Childhood's End""
column2: the word ""come
column3: sung in an ascending melody
column4: separates out so that it sounds like ""come home."" On the same song
column5: he turns the word ""me"" into three words
column6: each with a different vowel. These quirks work as part of Welsh's larger forceful disarmament strategy: “People that have written reviews of our shows have commented that
column7: ‘Oh
column8: he seemed nervous or he seemed uncomfortable on stage' … I tend to take that as a compliment
column9: he said. ""I never want to be the kind of performer that seems completely calm and collected on stage; I would rather … [be real] about the idea that when you get on stage it always feels new.” On ""I Do Sing for You""
column10: Welsh reaches out to soothe a member of his own embarrassed audience: ""You would laugh
column11: but I'm on stage for you/ I do sing for you/ Of course I do
column12: and I love to."" There is very little you can do in the face of such an onslaught of loving kindness
column13: so you surrender. Impersonator gently twists your arm like this
column14: song-by-song and note-by-note
column15:
and it is as discomfiting as it is transcendent.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19329/homepage_large.209a8290.jpg|Hecla & Griper EP|26175.0|Songs: Ohia|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2013-05-22 00:00:00|1997|2016-06-11 16:57:37.681950|"

When Songs: Ohia signed with Secretly Canadian in 1996
column2: the label was barely even a label. It was just a couple of college kids who had heard and fallen in love with the single Jason Molina had recorded for Palace Records earlier that year. But both the singer-songwriter and the label hit the ground running: In 1997
column3: they released Songs: Ohia's self-titled debut album as well as its first LP
column4: Hecla & Griper. Molina released at least one-- and very often two or three-- albums every year until 2003
column5: when Songs: Ohia morphed into Magnolia Electric Co. It was largely on the strength of Molina’s keening and affecting vocals as well as his poignant and probing songwriting that both the band and the label flourished throughout the late 1990s and into the 21st century.

column1: At the time of his death this past March
column2: Molina and Secretly Canadian were planning to reissue releases from the darker corners of his catalog
column3: and the first to see the light is the Hecla & Griper EP
column4: which appears on vinyl for the first time. Molina
column5: a Ohio native
column6: took a short break from touring to stop off in Bloomington
column7: Indiana
column8: and cut a few tracks with Daniel Burton. The result is a set of songs that are disarmingly raw and unbounded
column9: less polished than even Songs: Ohia from that same year. Burton’s production is spartan to match the arrangements
column10: which feature Molina’s signature tenor guitar and only occasional contributions from a handful of musicians.

column1: Hecla & Griper sounds suitably lonely and beleaguered
column2: two moods Molina conveyed with innate conviction. Especially compared to his later work with Magnolia Electric Co.
column3: his voice pierces through these songs almost violently
column4: high-pitched as usual but with a sharper nasal quality that suggests an unassuming
column5: untrained performer: a regular guy who simply stepped up to the mic and started speaking his mind. Except there were some dark thoughts in that mind. At times Hecla plays like a statement of purpose
column6: a prologue to his career: “If I decide to smile and fake it
column7: the lord would ne’er forgive that sin
column8: ” Molina sings on the opener “Pass”
column9: a slip of a song-- barely a minute long. “I take the words the angels tell me
column10: and I’m singing it from my conscience.”

column1: And yet
column2: there is some humor on here. Molina was hardly one to crack a joke mid-song
column3: but you can get a sense of his casual humor just by reading a few interviews. “I first chose you for my all-star team
column4: ” he claims on “Easts Last Heart”
column5: which uses a baseball metaphor to decry the wealth divide: “Rich kid
column6: I’m talking to you!” he concludes
column7: as if you might have missed his target. Molina ends Hecla with a Conway Twitty cover
column8: “Darling…” (popularly known as “Hello Darling”)
column9: and seems to relish the opportunity to sing someone else’s words. Considering that this EP was recorded just after the height of the 90s alt-country movement-- when upstart acts often played the part of rough-and-tumble hayseeds-- Molina doesn’t condescend to the song or its source material
column10: which is not to say he doesn’t have a little fun with it. He speaks the vocal hook with resignation
column11: suggesting the song is only an imaginary conversation-- what he wishes he had the guts to say to his darlin’.

column1: This 15th anniversary edition includes two unreleased tracks
column2: as well as early versions of songs that would show up on Impala in 1998. “Debts” and “Pilot & Friend” show just how deep Molina’s catalog goes; especially the former
column3: with its curious organ lines
column4: could have been the centerpiece of this or another EP
column5: although “Pilot & Friend” sounds too halting
column6: as Molina’s howl turns into a caterwaul that tests the limits of the microphone. The two Impala tracks are the fullest numbers here: “Hearts Newly Arrived” sounds more frayed and jittery here than it does on Impala
column7: as Molina navigates the tempo changes with a frantic energy and galloping guitars. Insistent drums drive “One of Those Uncertain Heads”
column8: which features a more pointed vocal from Molina that hard-sells the songs’ apocalyptic visions.

column1: Overall
column2: there’s a scratchy
column3: isolated feel to Hecla & Griper that’s similar to Autumn Bird Songs
column4: the final release of new material in Molina’s lifetime. Without suggesting too perfect a circle or too tidy a conclusion to his working life
column5: that comparison does reveal a certain aesthetic that carried through his entire 16-year career. Molina believed in the song at its most primal and most austere
column6: understanding that he could get his point across better with minimal adornment. For him
column7: the power of these songs comes through in the spaces between syllables and notes
column8: where Molina can catch a breath and simply let the silence say its peace. Hecla & Griper is a minor release in his sprawling catalog
column9:
yet that does not mean it’s insignificant: This is the sound of a man who was only just getting started.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19319/homepage_large.cde3c379.jpg|Sunday School II: When Church Lets Out|31352.0|Tree|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Creative Control']|2013-05-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:38.111611|"

Chicago hip-hop’s always had something of a split personality
column2: and the recent global attention on the scene has only served to heighten the contrast between Chief Keef and the giddily sociopathic drill scene on one end of the spectrum
column3: and on the other
column4: Chance the Rapper and a new generation of artists looking to reinvigorate a conscious rap scene that was last at its peak back when Kanye was still a backpacker. And almost exactly halfway between the two ends of the spectrum sits an MC named Tremaine “Tree” Johnson.

column1: Last year Tree released a mixtape called Sunday School. It was a rough record released in an unmastered
column2: unpolished state
column3: but it managed to establish him as something like the David Banner of the Midwest: a rapper/producer with a carefully considered aesthetic that’s organic and insightful
column4: but who doesn’t consider himself above writing songs aimed at the street
column5: the club
column6: or the bedroom. Sunday School II improves on its predecessor in almost every aspect. The songs are stronger
column7: his performance is more assured
column8: and the production-- with assistance from Chicago hip-hop recording kingpin Michael Kolar-- is deeper and denser. He doesn’t feel like an artist sitting between two scenes
column9: skimming off ideas
column10: but one strong enough to stack them atop one another and climb on top.

column1: Tree calls his artistic philosophy “soul trap
column2: ” and it’s as honest a name as it is catchy. On a basic musical level
column3: it accurately describes Tree’s preferred blend of soul music elements-- warm
column4: churchy organ lines and vocal samples pitched up
column5: Kanye-as-chipmunk style-- with beats built around the kind of booming 808 kicks and snappy
column6: precisely machined hi-hats that have been a feature of Southern rap mixtapes for years
column7: and which have recently taken hold in the Midwest.

column1: Taking a deeper view
column2: “soul trap” can also describe the emotional and intellectual heart of Tree’s music. A native of the city’s notorious (and now demolished) Cabrini-Green projects
column3: his roots are deep in the street-- in his lyrics Chicago gangs like the Black P. Stone Nation are features of the neighborhood just the same way brick high rises are
column4: and he makes multiple references to a brief stint selling crack at age 13. He sees the nihilism that pervades the gangster lifestyle he opted out of
column5: and wants to stay as far away from it as possible. In Tree’s capable hands these two elements
column6: which on the surface seem so contradictory
column7: combine into a raw but subtly layered portrait of life in black Chicago
column8: one that’s miles away from Keef’s in tone but just as bracing and honest.

column1: Tree delivers this portrait with a ragged melodic howl that recalls Chicago bluesmen as frequently as it does other rappers. Despite the sometimes weighty nature of the material he tackles lyrically
column2: he’s a pop artist at heart (on “King” he gives the chipmunk-soul treatment to a snippet of Elvis’ “Can’t Help Falling in Love With You”)
column3: which helps set him apart from many MCs who get tagged as “conscious” and makes Sunday School II a pleasurable repeat listen.

column1: And even when he’s being conscious he’s not a drag about it. On “So Bad” he describes a dream woman who’s independent
column2: intelligent
column3: and self-actualized
column4: but also stacks paper
column5: flashes diamonds
column6: and projects the kind of intensely confident not-giving-a-fuck that’s more common to rappers than the women they write about. The song describes a combination of virtues that also fit Tree’s music: flashy enough to grab your attention and smart enough to know what to do with it
column7: brainy but sensual
column8:
and easy to get hooked on.

Before MS MR had written a song
column2: the band already knew how they would initially release their music
column3: conceiving a Tumblr rollout strategy complex enough that Wired first reported it. The project was originally the idea of Lizzy Plapinger
column4: co-founder of boutique NYC pop label Neon Gold
column5: and it was consummated when she started working with producer Max Hershenow. After putting out a few singles under the guise of anonymity
column6: they made music to fit the Tumblr plan in the form of 2012’s Candy Bar Creep Show EP. They put out one song a week
column7: alongside “obsessively curated” images and remix stems.

column1: In his review of Charli XCX’s debut
column2: True Romance
column3: Marc Hogan called for a moratorium on treating internet platforms as musical genres
column4: and rightly so. But even as MS MR break their umbilical connection to Tumblr to release their full-length debut album
column5: they’ve supplemented Secondhand Rapture with what they’re calling “Secondhand Captures”-- a different visual treatment for every song available online; made up of videos of eerie
column6: wretched glamor and corruptible
column7: all-American innocence. MS MR’s desire to give their music a visual analog is interesting
column8: but you wonder about their ability to create a record that can be listened to on its own.

column1: “We both get off on wild weather and write our best music when there’s something crazy happening in the air
column2: ” MS MR have said; fittingly
column3: much of Secondhand Rapture revolves around deep
column4: thunderous rumblings
column5: celestial twinkling
column6: foggy shrouds
column7: and the sweet clarity of a pastel dawn. There are brooding
column8: rhythmically strong pop songs that fall halfway between the poutiness of Lana Del Rey and the hyperactive fizz of HAIM. The parts where it deviates from that template
column9: however
column10: are baffling: most notably ""Salty Sweet""
column11: which has an airy
column12: pumping Middle Eastern-sounding riff
column13: and “Head Is Not My Home”
column14: which revolves around what sounds like a programmed banjo sample. They fit awkwardly amidst the rest of the record.

column1: Plapinger has spoken about not feeling confident about her ability as a lyricist
column2: which works for and against them. At her best
column3: as on the wounded trip-hop-leaning “Hurricane”
column4: she conveys the air of a girl in her mid-to-late teens feeling disillusionment for the first time
column5: mistrustful of herself and others. Songs like “Dark Doo Wop” and “Think of You” make triumphant hooks out of single lines (""Baby
column6: you should stick around” and “I still think of you and all the shit you put me through” respectively
column7: and conversely)
column8: the latter in a hi-NRG springy chorus that sticks out like a showgirl in a convent among its plain verses. But elsewhere
column9: as on<span> the rumbling
column10: pastel synth-swathed “Bones”
column11: the words come over as thin and contrived.

column1: The “secondhand” part of the title
column2: the band say
column3: is a reference to how many of our experiences are mediated through the internet rather than direct contact. It’s a concern shared by many of the current class; Drake is terrified of Tumblr
column4: Savages want to smash through mediating devices to live in a present
column5: burning now. MS MR
column6: however
column7: make no attempt to engage with or bristle against the idea
column8: merely representing it. Just as their early release strategy predated the existence of the music itself
column9: these songs play like the moodboard for an actual album
column10: a pitch for the idea of a pop band
column11: rather than one you’d set up a fuckyeah… Tumblr for. MS MR do have one
column12: but it hasn’t been updated in 10 months. It’s all well and good having a pristine launch strategy
column13:
but it means nothing if you can’t follow it with something that invites genuine engagement.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19318/homepage_large.2a4d197e.jpg|Between Two Selves|29942.0|Octo Octa|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['100% Silk']|2013-05-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:39.212007|"

Brooklyn producer Michael Bouldry-Morrison has always stood out among the 100% Silk roster. As Octo Octa he was making crisp
column2: hi-definition dancefloor music when much of the L.A. label’s output felt like an extension of the dubby psychedelia of parent label Not Not Fun
column3: or else pursued an overtly retro
column4: lo-fi house aesthetic. And in contrast to his peers’ allegiances to the US underground
column5: Bouldry-Morrison’s emergent style seemed to mirror the U.K.’s adoption of house forms-- particularly in its use of bold chord progressions and re-pitched R&B a capellas (see the ""1 Thing""-sampling ""I’m Trying""). But Bouldry-Morrison’s use of these techniques has always been inventive and
column6: above all
column7: distinctive-- the sugary synthetic surface and lambent reverb haze of his tracks is often unmistakable. And as 100% Silk has continued to churn out records of variable quality over the past couple of years
column8: Bouldry-Morrison is one of its few signings who
column9: you sense
column10: may have a future beyond that corner of the underground.

column1: Between Two Selves is Bouldry-Morrison’s debut LP
column2: and it represents the next step in a steady refinement of the Octo Octa formula. The arrangements have become a little more measured perhaps
column3: the deployment of a capellas less brazen. Structures undulate smoothly
column4: acting out a series of mini-dramas of tension and release
column5: and the handling of frequencies is pleasingly full-spectrum
column6: displaying a renewed emphasis on thunderous basslines and kickdrums. A recurrent feature of Bouldry-Morrison’s sound is his unusually extreme use of compression
column7: meaning that sonic elements don’t sit alongside one another so much as pump fluidly in and out of focus. It’s an effect that may detract from these tracks’ dancefloor effectiveness-- clarity can be lost in denser moments
column8: and important percussive parts might become temporarily obscured in the fog-- but it also lends them a mirage-like quality that is hugely appealing.

column1: Bouldry-Morrison uses this sound as a vehicle for a newly committed exploration of the limits of his expressive range in a record which
column2: in the producer’s own words
column3: delves into themes of “happiness
column4: anxiety
column5: queerness
column6: and relationships.” An undercurrent of darkness surfaces at points
column7: one not really heard in previous Octo Octa releases. ""Fear"" is sluggish
column8: warehouse-ready techno of a sort
column9: brooding at the opening and
column10: when its chords take on a serrated edge at midpoint
column11: almost aggressive. ""Come Closer"" is more driving
column12: but its looped central refrain of “I want you
column13: ” shrouded in a frost of reverb
column14: takes on a sinister urgency. Meanwhile
column15: at the opposite end of the expressive spectrum
column16: ""His Kiss"" is a joyous
column17: U.K. hardcore-indebted affirmation of desire
column18: all delectable chord-spume and rickety breakbeats.

column1: These moments are all excellent in their way
column2: and it’s gratifying to see Bouldry-Morrison broaden his emotional palette. But
column3: going on the evidence of Between Two Selves
column4: the producer’s strongest mode is a form of dreamlike
column5: sensuous fulfillment. It’s present in languid deep house opener ""Who Will I Become""
column6: with its aqueous synth figures
column7: or the lucid ""Bad Blood""
column8: whose down-pitched R&B vocal manages to evade cliche through the the subtle sweetness of its backing. ""Please Don’t Leave""
column9: meanwhile
column10: is a little more forlorn
column11: but trades in the sort of deluxe melancholy that demands to be wallowed in. These tracks are confections
column12: light on the palette and tremendously moreish
column13: and they’re among Bouldry-Morrison’s finest work.

column1: Granted
column2: there are a few weaker moments too-- particularly ""Work Me""
column3: whose alternation between the robust thud of New York house and a syncopated bass hook feels a little too derivative of the U.K. house new school. And in spite of its variations in tone
column4:
Between Two Selves is sonically rather homogenous-- Bouldry-Morrison’s taste for candyfloss synths can can start to grate after 50 minutes. But for the most part it’s clear that the producer’s style has reached new heights of subtlety and richness on this record. Octo Octa has long been one of the stronger cards in the 100% Silk deck; after hearing Between Two Selves it's tempting to declare him the strongest.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19219/homepage_large.91787d75.jpg|Trouble Will Find Me|3006.0|The National|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2013-05-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:39.917543|"

Most people attribute the National’s escalating popularity to their reliability: They write songs about existential dread and the real pressures that result when others are depending on you to have your shit together. And while that steadiness is certainly important
column2: it gives short shrift to how the Brooklyn-via-Cincinnati band’s career fulfills a fantasy. Though their self-titled 2001 debut is all but written out of their history
column3: every National album since has been more ambitious
column4: accomplished
column5: and successful than the one that came before it. They are strivers
column6: and their place in the indie rock world suggests that life can be a series of upward promotions and self-improvement. <span>But hard work is often a cover for repressed frustration
column7: as was clear on 2010’s High Violet
column8: an album whose wrought arrangements and violent lyrics underscored every story about what a tremendous pain in the ass it was to make. The question they ask on Trouble Will Find Me is both relatable and fantastical: When do we get a break from shooting up the ladder?

column1: The National may find it impossible ever to relax
column2: but they have learned to stop struggling on <i>Trouble Will Find Me
column3: their leanest and most aerodynamic record yet. Most descriptors of the National’s musicianship-- the exacting performances
column4: Matt Berninger’s oaken baritone
column5: the allegiances with the equally finicky St. Vincent and Sufjan Stevens-- can double as evidence for self-serving arguments about how they’re “boring.” The only term that’s dogged the National more than that one is “grower
column6: ” a slightly backhanded remark implying that enjoying them requires an inordinate investment
column7: or that it’s more cerebral than physical. While the National never lacked confidence or craft
column8: Trouble is an easily accessible and self-assured work
column9: largely because it focuses on the visceral power of Berninger’s vocals and Bryan Devendorf’s inventive drumming. It's a sign of trust that they can convey all of their ornate and rich melancholy without every sad note being underlined by a bassoon.

column1: It’s been eight years since Berninger screamed on record
column2: and now that act appears to have served as some kind of exfoliant. (He also quit smoking in 2011.) His vocals are deeper and richer than ever
column3: as well as more tuneful and elegant. The National's dirty secret is that for all of the Dessner brothers’ orchestral ambitions
column4: these songs are simple things: Instantly memorable melodies and minimal chord progressions become familiar after one listen
column5: and then there’s a pivot
column6: usually undetectable the first time around
column7: that takes the National towards one of their proprietary grand finales. The greatness lies in when the listener connects the two and realizes they're part of the same song.

column1: “Graceless” perfects the kind of fist-pumping victory lap featured on “Abel” or “Bloodbuzz Ohio”
column2: and subsequent spins reveal how expertly the build is structured. Ditto for “Sea of Love”
column3: which incrementally wells up to a cathartic call and response that extends a hand to a slipping friend with both empathy (“tell me how to reach you”) and dark humor (“what did Harvard teach you?”). There are plenty of great little moments as well; the fractious time signatures of “I Should Live In Salt” and “Demons” pushing against Berninger’s burly vocals
column4: a tiny
column5: chromatic guitar figure setting “Humiliation” on a new trajectory
column6: “I Need My Girl” expressing its nervy claustrophobia through frilly filigrees. You never lose sight of Trouble Will Find Me being the result of a meticulous process conducted by professionals
column7: though like surgeons
column8: chefs
column9: or interior decorators
column10: they trust themselves to know when to put the tools down.

column1: That’s mostly true of Berninger’s lyrics as well. Trouble Will Find Me doesn't contain his sharpest writing-- in particular
column2: “Fireproof” and “Slipped” cross over to being a bit pro forma-- but in ditching the obtuse metaphors and playing with and against type
column3: it’s his funniest. “I am secretly in love with everyone I grew up with
column4: ” he gravely intones on “Demons”
column5: hinting at the dominant theme of how the self-image and relationships formed during his younger
column6: angsty years figure in to his present reality. He brings the stakes down to a tangible level
column7: where he’s invited to nice dinners
column8: punk parties
column9: and meet-and-greets
column10: only to wind up calling his wife
column11: feeling like his presence there is all somehow a giant mistake. “When I walk into a room
column12: I do not light it up... FUCK
column13: ” Berninger stresses in an exasperated tone as a minor chord inversion takes away the mock scare quotes during the final chorus of “Demons”
column14: revealing the deep-set despair at the source of all this self-deprecation.

column1: As usual
column2: he’s not alone on Trouble Will Find Me. Within this elemental music
column3: compulsions towards substances
column4: sex
column5: and depression are likened to swamps
column6: oceans
column7: and agricultural decay-- natural events tentatively contained by human will. The characters are medicated
column8: missing
column9: and incapable of justifying their hangovers
column10: let alone glorifying them. On Alligator
column11: Berninger’s sociopathic tendencies felt defiant
column12: and some may miss that; during “All The Wine”
column13: he drank from bottomless goblets
column14: claiming “God is on my side.” Conversely
column15: the narrators of Trouble Will Find Me are creatures of habit attending to dull aches; a perfunctory anti-romance is consecrated with “Tylenol and beer”
column16: and by the next song
column17: Berninger mutters
column18: “God loves everybody
column19: don’t remind me.” Where he once fancied himself a cold-blooded heat-seeker and a “birthday candle in a circle of black girls
column20: ” the isolation he now feels renders him as unique as “a white girl in a crowd of white girls in a park.”

column1: Considering the National can no longer be compared to anyone besides themselves
column2: it’s fitting Trouble Will Find Me is their most self-referential album. Sometimes
column3: they’re alluding to their image as the definitive yuppie band: Berninger calls himself “a 45 percenter
column4: ” “a television version of a person with a broken heart.” They’re also putting their own work up against the canon because they’re big enough to do it: Let It Be and Nevermind serve as paragons of stability on “Don’t Swallow the Cap”
column5: Elliott Smith’s despondent “Needle in the Hay” contrasts with the pokerfaced “Fireproof”. Bona Drag plays during the luxurious piano mope of “Pink Rabbits”
column6: LA Woman and Guns N' Roses are given malaprop name-checks on “Humiliation”.

column1: Of all the references
column2: the most powerful serves as the final line on Trouble Will Find Me: “they can all just kiss off into the air.” On a song which bemoans the futility of living in the past
column3: here’s a band often mocked for aging with their music quoting a band often mocked for music that’s stuck in a permanent state of teenhood. It could be the funniest or the most heartbreaking moment on a record full of instances of both
column4: a reminder that when Berninger sings “I was trying not to crack up” on the previous song
column5: there’s two ways of reading it. On a similar topic
column6: Ezra Koenig recently opined
column7: “wisdom’s a gift but you’d trade it for youth
column8: ” and “Hard to Find” is a similar thought taken from a different angle. People stay down with their demons wishing for that trade to be a realistic possibility
column9: and in the clearest terms his medium-sized American heart can muster
column10: Berninger expresses his means of finding serenity when trouble tries to find him-- “there's a lot that I've not forgotten/but I let go of other things."" As a culmination and refinement of everything the National have done over the past decade
column11:
Trouble Will Find Me couldn’t be granted a more fitting mission statement.

It's less than a year since Laurel Halo released her debut full-length album for Hyperdub
column3: the brittle
column4: beautiful Quarantine. This four-track EP for the same label makes that record feel light-years away. The vocals are gone
column5: the sense of space has all but vanished. If Quarantine resembled a Cronenbergian amalgam of flesh and machine
column6: here Halo goes one step closer to erasing humanity from the frame. Those swooping vocal takes feel absent at first. It's hard not to mourn their removal
column7: and worry about the premature halting of an idea that had long life in it yet. On further plays
column8: though
column9: Behind the Green Door casts a different shadow over Quarantine
column10: just as that album did with her prior work. It makes Quarantine a stronger
column11: bolder piece
column12: gaining a little extra weight due to the sense of isolation
column13: even among Halo's own work
column14: that surrounds it.

column1: The sense of forward momentum merges into the music on Behind the Green Door in a quite literal sense; these aren't exactly club bangers
column2: but the feeling of propulsion is aided by the beats that underpin all four tracks. Those rhythms guide Halo down a purposefully tangled path
column3: picking up elements of house music and minimal techno along the way
column4: but cloaking them in a sense of agitation that's barely kept below surface level. This isn't exactly angry music
column5: but there is a feeling of itchy unease that runs as a theme throughout. ""NOYFB"" is the best embodiment of this
column6: with each new layer feeling slightly out of step with everything that came immediately prior. It's disorienting
column7: which is
column8: it seems
column9: Halo's favorite place to be
column10: allowing her to construct worlds that immediately get pulled down and discarded on the cutting room floor. She never appears fully satisfied in the present moment
column11: always eager to move on somewhere else.

column1: Halo has commented on the ""sexual energy"" of these tracks
column2: setting up a fascinating disparity between the title of the EP (taken from a well-known porn film from the 1970s
column3: which was among the first hardcore pictures to gain wide distribution) and the tender pound that thumps through a track like ""Sex Mission"". If there is a sexual energy
column4: it's wide-ranging
column5: bridging from moments of quiet joy and reflection to feelings of loneliness and alienation. But the sense of distance being gained while human aspects recede
column6: at least compared to what came before on Quarantine
column7: adds a further twist. The bass drum beats and bursts of stiff electronics that rise in ""UHFFO"" suggest a darker sensuality
column8: something more akin to the dystopian sci-fi dreams of Demon Seed
column9: the 70s horror feature in which Julie Christie is impregnated by a supercomputer. The underlying themes of that film-- of technology being abused
column10: breaking down
column11: fudging the lines between what's real and artificial-- serve as a useful parallel to the feel of Behind the Green Door.

column1: It's interesting to listen back to Hour Logic
column2: Halo's 2011 EP for Hippos in Tanks
column3: in light of the moves she's made here. In many ways the two releases feel like the flipside of a utopian dream
column4: with the earlier work all brash outward moves
column5: caught up in a moment of cautious optimism. ""Throw"" from this EP is noticeably harder
column6: more pessimistic in outlook
column7: with the warped
column8: house-y piano stabs the perfect dysfunctional hook to signal a sense of restlessness. There's a feeling of moving away from something
column9: not to a space necessarily much darker than some of Quarantine
column10: but certainly one where chaos and decline are taking a stronger hold. The title of the EP makes more sense in that context
column11: if you take the enormous popularity of Behind the Green Door as a sort of ground zero for the subsequent wave of seedy profiteering that the adult film industry would be built upon. This work feels more in tune with decay and exploitation in sexual portrayal
column12: the numbness accrued from a constant barrage of imagery
column13:
than anything that’s notionally ""sexy.""

Survival is the latest dispatch from the imagination of Hunter Hunt-Hendrix
column2: better known for fronting the black metal band Liturgy. He's the kind of acutely intelligent musician who can’t resist articulating the grand conceits behind his work even if he knows they will irritate people
column3: which they often do. But when drummer Greg Fox departed Liturgy in late 2011
column4: it took the heartbeat out of Hunt-Hendrix's theories. On Survival
column5: he's in a comfort zone of sorts
column6: playing with older friends: Greg Smith and Jeff Bobula once backed Hunt-Hendrix in a screamo band called Birthday Boyz
column7: while Krallice guitarist Colin Marston worked with Liturgy on 2009's Renihilation. It's a nice update for Hunt-Hendrix's vision
column8: but it's not quite vivid enough to dispel the nagging reminder that the mighty vessel who delivered “Sun of Light” and “Generation” has temporarily run aground.

column1: Survival is a much more straightforward and grounded project than Liturgy. Some of the guitar parts and melodies start out foursquare; “Tragedy of the Mind”’s hiccuping pentatonic riff
column2: for instance
column3: stomps somewhere just north of Soundgarden’s “Rhinosaur”. The vocals are chanted low instead of screamed high
column4: but they're as much a textural background element as they were with Liturgy. The band has cited Black Sabbath
column5: Smashing Pumpkins
column6: and Creedence Clearwater as influences
column7: and there are some classic rock wisps to pick out-- the Sabbath-thick power chords on the breakdown to “Original Pain”
column8: for one.

column1: But this being a Hunt-Hendrix project
column2: there's always a moment when the threads begin twisting-- a drum fill sprouts an extra beat and the song club-foots into a new time signature
column3: or guitar lines stumble over themselves and then start rewinding in place
column4: like they’re trying to back off of a treadmill. There is very little simple forward motion in Hunt-Hendrix’s music; his compositions tend to steer themselves into corner walls and bump repeatedly against them. It produces a calming
column5: repetitive sort of madness
column6: if you're the sort of person who finds banging their head against a wall soothing.

column1: The lyrics scramble our sense of chronology in similar ways: ""Ending begins all the time
column2: goes the repeated chant to ""Tragedy of the Mind"". “Original Pain” takes the word ""pain"" and flogs it until it becomes a mantra. The song titles reinforce the implicit threads of tragedy and freedom linking each of the album’s nine droning
column3: pounding compositions. This is one Ur-Riff
column4: divided up into small
column5: manageable transmissions.

column1: Survival's music is a little better-suited to head-banging/fist-pumping than that of Liturgy. “Freedom 1” pairs its titanium-grade riff with a heavy blacksmith forge clink
column2: and “Freedom 3” works up a thrumming
column3: migraine tension with its jittery cymbal work and thrumming hand percussion. But Survival isn’t as interesting or as rich as or any of the other projects the various band members are involved in. The lone quiet moment on the record
column4: the acoustic “Since Sun”
column5: is an intriguing glimpse into a spot where Hunt-Hendrix’s vision shades into the world Phil Elverum explores in Mount Eerie. But the rest of the record veers too often
column6: and too readily
column7:
into gray.

Oakland trio Shannon and the Clams have a broad musical vocabulary that belies their simple
column2: trad setup. Their sound contains lo-fi's distorted treble
column3: the gruff tumble of rockabilly
column4: the soaring heights of R&B balladry
column5: and the weirdness of mid-60s psychedelia. Their albums have the feel of a freeform AM station whose DJs and programmers get their jollies from being gleefully unpredictable
column6: the kind that wouldn’t think twice about following up a tender oldie like “Oh Louie” with a punkabilly romp called “Cat Party”.

column1: Songwriters Shannon Shaw and Cody Blanchard frequently switch duties as lead singer
column2: sometimes within the same song
column3: which is testament to both their differences and the clarity of their shared vision. They’re singers whose range and timbre often makes it difficult to tell which of them is singing lead (which is more interesting than it is negative)
column4: but they're sharp lyricists with very different writing styles. On Dreams in the Rat House
column5: Shaw’s “Ozma” is a touching eulogy about her dearly departed dog
column6: while Blanchard’s “Heads or Tails” is a fictional narrative about a vagabond with a coin in his pocket that he flips whenever he needs to make a critical life decision.

column1: Dreams in the Rat House combines elements of their debut
column2: I Wanna Go Home (particularly the off-the-cuff hijinks and threadbare fidelity)
column3: with the songwriting focus of their great second effort
column4: Sleep Talk. Songs like “If I Could Count” and “The Rabbit’s Nose” toy with complex melody and song structure while exhibiting the fine art of making it all look easy. “Rip Van Winkle” takes a generations-old fable and turns it into a monologue from a heart-struck woman waiting for a lover to return to her
column5: and has a glittery lead guitar part and a soaring chorus that combine to far more than the sum of its parts. In the number of years they’ve played together
column6: Shaw and Blanchard have learned how to disassemble the parts and rebuild them in a way that sounds both classic and wild at the same time.

column1: But their chief attribute is how fun their songs sound. They can do sinister
column2: ghastly garage-punk like the Mummies (“Bed Rock”) or throw faux-ghoulish noises that suggest parody but never cross that line (“Rat House”) without coming across as a novelty act. Blanchard and Shaw are dedicated enough to songcraft to the extent that it’s evident they’re not just fucking around.

column1: One common misconception about certain corners of garage rock is that there's a lack of serious-mindedness among its proponents. But there’s a broad line between having a good time and making a joke out of something. When Shannon and the Clams pull out a ballad as affecting as “Unlearn”
column2: it becomes apparent that they’re just as good at tugging heartstrings as cackling after tracking those googly noises in “Rat House”. When they craft a goodbye as poignant in its simplicity as “I Know”
column3:
it’s like Shaw and Blanchard know you’re going to realize you’ve underestimated the emotional resonance of their songwriting. And that’s when they know they’ve got you hooked.

Study the erratic career arc of Eddie Ruscha Jr.
column2: the Los Angeles resident who records under the name Secret Circuit

column4: some of which were gathered on the excellent Tropical Psychedelics compilation in 2012. It wasn't always this way; Ruscha played in notable shoegazers Medicine for a time in the early 1990s
column5: and in the Virgin-signed
column6: John Cale-produced psychedelic rock act Maids of Gravity. Those failed glimpses of the limelight appeared to send him scurrying deep underground
column7: only to surface for air again in recent times.

column1: Tactile Galactics has the air of an album with something riding on it
column2: not just for Ruscha
column3: but also for Tim Sweeney
column4: the WNYU DJ who is putting it out as the first full-length LP on his Beats in Space label. Both even admitted to feeling nervous about its release in a recent joint interview about the project. That fear doesn't translate to the music
column5: which flashes past with a similar stylistic blur to the Tropical Psychedelics collection
column6: gleefully pulling a wide range of influences into the mix. Sometimes the tools are different-- there's nothing here that infuses the Martin Denny lilt that lit up ""Foggy Twilights"" from Tropical-- but mostly it's airy
column7: relaxed electronic work
column8: rarely raising a sweat
column9: often constructed from trancey vintage synth patterns that circle around one another.

column1: It's a graceful and highly intricate record
column2: sometimes taking a baffling amount of twists and turns. The arpeggiated swirl of ""Exalter"" shifts through so many changes it sometimes resembles a fully electronic take on an old Gong record. Ruscha can play it loose or tight whenever either mood takes him
column3: ending the album with the endearingly sloppy keyboard work of ""Milk"" and dropping the tighter mood piece ""Escargot"" earlier in the tracklisting. Earnest vocal tracks occasionally surface-- a new addition to the Secret Circuit sound-- sometimes resembling the clash of earthy and synthetic impulses that Hot Chip like to play around with. That's the place where much of Tactile Galactics lands-- gentle electronic work touched by palpable human emotions
column4: a mix that's often hard to get right
column5: but which seems to come naturally to Ruscha (admittedly after many years of practice).

column1: Those years spent toiling in the studio have also led to a natural cohesion that helps bridge Ruscha's fondness for moving from
column2: say
column3: wild cut-up synth lines that resemble Death in Vegas' ""Dirt"" (""Parascopic Rope"") to the New Age stew of pan pipes and bongo fury that partly make up ""Mountains"". In lesser hands
column4: Tactile Galactics would sound disjointed
column5: maybe even rashly uneven. But Ruscha is clearly a big picture thinker with a careful ear for making connections. The deliberate choice to keep everything ticking over at 120 BPM throughout acts as the glue that holds it all together
column6:
giving this material a meditative feel that's as easy to lie back and get lost in as it is to dance to. It's understandable why Ruscha is so apprehensive about letting this work out in the open after getting burnt by the industry and then spending so long in the dark. Tactile Galactics shows why he's got no reason to hide anymore.

column1: Random Access Memories

column3: continues the trend. But the differences between their first three albums and this one are vast. RAM finds them leaving behind the highly influential

column1: Another way is to work with artists young and old who have inspired them. Rodgers pops up again on “Lose Yourself to Dance” and “Get Lucky”

column6: despite being the biggest contemporary star on the album
column7: sounds anonymous-- his vocals are pretty much just functional. But even that is arguably in line with Daft Punk’s reverence. Disco
column8: after all
column9: was often a producer’s medium
column10: and lead singers weren’t necessarily meant to be the the focus of attention. So it comes back to songwriting and production: How strong is the groove
column11: how memorable are the hooks? “Get Lucky”
column12: a deserved hit
column13: works on both counts. “Lose Yourself to Dance”
column14: on the other hand
column15: is OK

column2: “Within”

column4: slightly jazzy robotic soul
column5: delivered in the kind of gorgeous vocoder that Daft Punk have perfected. Musically

column1: “Giorgio” is a stunning piece of pop-prog that seems partly drawn from the groundbreaking producer’s experiments in long-form

column3: like his side-long version of “Knights in White Satin”. Moroder’s only contribution to the song is an interview that offers a thumbnail history of his life as a musician
column4: one that recounts how how he heard the sequenced Moog as the future of music (see “I Feel Love”). The construction of “Giorgio by Moroder” is masterful

column3: the record’s literal centerpiece
column4: is where things start to get interesting. It’s telling that the songs featuring the two oldest and deepest influences on the record-- Moroder and Paul Williams-- are the most over-the-top.  (Williams' role in the 1974 cult film Phantom of the Paradise became an early obsession for Daft Punk.) These pocket symphonies allows the duo to take their concerns to the furthest reaches of ambition-- and good taste. “Touch” packs in a Cluster-fied spacey intro
column5: some showtune balladry

column7: and a sky-scraping choir

column3: Jackson Browne

column1: The continual churn of the internet
column2: experience tells us

column4: conveniences
column5: ephemeral pleasures. But there are areas of culture popping up that seek to slow down
column6: focus on details
column7: and wallow in the kinds of media that it still takes money to create. This is the space that Daft Punk seek to occupy
column8: which in and of itself can be seen as problematic. For those who embrace the more egalitarian approach to music production created by access to cheap tools and cheap distribution
column9: Daft Punk’s mind-bogglingly lush record scans as elitist
column10: possibly even dismissive of the creativity that is happening on a smaller scale.

column1: To really understand where they’re coming from here
column2: you have to go back to the height of the album era
column3: which was really just a blip in pop music history. Three things made it different: 1) it was the time just before MTV; 2) it was the time just before the CD; 3) it was the time just before the Walkman. All three hit around the dawn of the 80s and had a profound influence on how recorded music was experienced. MTV
column4: in addition to foregrounding the visual presentation of artists
column5: returned music to a singles-focused realm. The CD did its part too
column6: making skipping ahead so easy and allowing for the listener to jump around at will. (It also made artwork less important and introduced the idea of records as “data”.) And the Walkman's convenience opened up new spaces for listening while decreasing sound quality
column7: a trade-off that has driven the technology behind popular music consumption ever since.

column1: So RAM is best appreciated as a counter to these trends. It’s not that “all music should be this” but that “some music could be this.” By the time you make it to the album’s astonishing final stretch

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19010/homepage_large.d08f8310.jpg|Sing to the Moon|30879.0|Laura Mvula|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['RCA']|2013-05-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:44.139750|"

Birmingham singer Laura Mvula has been garnering plenty of adoring reviews across the pond. Even before her debut album Sing to the Moon was released in Britain
column2: she was shortlisted for the prestigious Critics Choice Award at the 2013 BRIT awards. Since the album was released
column3: Mvula’s bright-hued retro-soul has been praised to the heavens for originality while simultaneously being compared to the luminary likes of Nina Simone and David Axelrod. Much of the praise is richly deserved. <i>Sing to the Moon
column4: which was just released here in the States
column5: is a triumph of arrangement and melody: Songs like opener “Like the Morning Dew”
column6: or the gorgeous title track
column7: combine earworm hooks with beautiful
column8: uniquely shaped verses
column9: and showcase the open-hearted faith in the world that is clearly Mvula’s calling card. Even when her lyrics communicate melancholy
column10: it seems the singer has no choice but to sound defiantly anti-blue.

column1: The formal complexity of Mvula’s best songs is testament to an education at the esteemed Birmingham Conservatoire
column2: whose graduates often stray towards jazz
column3: opera
column4: and classical composition. You can hear that training in the stately processional entrance of “Make Me Lovely”

column6: powerful chorus

column8: Mvula’s voice is also a winning draw. There’s a hitch in her dusky alto that recalls a mix of Jill Scott and a demure version of Amy Winehouse. Her voice is classically beautiful but there’s enough oddity-- a sort of gravelly undertone-- in her pronunciation to keep it interesting throughout the album.

column1: A lot of anonymity is built into Mvula’s topics of choice: beauty
column2: love
column3: faith
column4: heartbreak
column5: and hardship are all discussed on the album with the same generalized air. This can be a strength when it comes to pop songwriting-- the stories here are universal enough to be broadly relatable. But Mvula shines when she gets a bit more personal: She shows a snappy attitude on the show tune-like “That’s Alright”
column6: an affirmation of her faith in who she is
column7: which doubles as one of the most exciting tracks here. Mvula sounds best on her more upbeat songs
column8: so it's a shame there are so few of them.

column1: It’s an odd choice
column2: given the success of singles ""Green Garden"" and ""Like the Morning Dew""
column3: to fill the album with so many slow-burning
column4: hopeful anthems. Though they show off Mvula’s vocal talents as well as anything else here
column5: over the full record they can become mundane and somewhat repetitious. “Is There Anybody Out There?” and “Father Father” might work as one-offs for someone encountering Mvula’s voice and compositional abilities for the first time. But they sink in comparison to the songs they follow
column6: leaving the album with almost 10 minutes of under-utilized space.

column1: Mvula's music hearkens back to an earlier era than that of her many British contemporaries: She hovers on the edge of pop
column2: but the majority of her songs are too reserved to fully break through. Mvula's debut is filled with visceral and musical beauty--that is its strong spot. Once she rids her work of thematic repetition and lyrical mundanity
column3:
she'll be on to something truly special.

Scout Niblett's latest album opens with a murder ballad
column2: ""Gun""
column3: which reveals its call-to-vengeance line-by-line. It begins uninnocently enough
column4: arming up
column5: then moving to intent
column6: and finally motive: ""Maybe you'll be holding her hand/ Or watching her shitty band
column7: she snarls
column8: drawing out ""band"" in a way that displays the full plumage of her disgust. She strums slowly
column9: unfancily
column10: as she recounts a lover's bed-hopping betrayal. Then there's the shot-- ""HA!"" and a grunge-glorious bridge with the big reveal
column11: ""She took your love away from me/ And I am thankful."" She wants him back as much as she wants him gone.

column1: It's Up to Emma
column2: Scout Niblett's seventh
column3: is her best album since her debut
column4: full of raw power as it follows the aftermath of a toxic relationship through the various Kübler-Ross stages
column5: alternately restless and rutting
column6: psychotic and clear
column7: murderous and devoted. Niblett fashions a compelling arc for the kind of character we know colloquially in popular culture as ""the psycho ex-girlfriend."" Niblett inhabits the story
column8: first person: ""I fooled myself for too long."" ""I wish that you could find what you need."" ""I still remain by your side."" ""I don't need to hear her name."" ""What can I do?"" She gives it breadth and depth that expands the character
column9: humanizing the caricature of the done-wrong
column10: bunny-boiling bitch that just can't get over getting dumped.

column1: Not unlike Lungfish
column2: Niblett has worked her particular brand of blues to a science. Record to record
column3: there's a reliable similarity that is either finessed or stripped back. It's Up to Emma is her first without Steve Albini producing
column4: and is markedly fancier for it; a bit of an about-face from her last two that were so fitful and so raw. Even as harrowing and discomfiting an experience as Emma is
column5: it's the most listenable record Niblett has made since her debut; caustic in a totally different way than usual.

column1: The real work of this album is just how far she lures us into the this character's dark cocoon. She initially presents us with this vicious fantasy of a woman seeking to disrupt her misery by any means necessary
column2: but it's also a fantasy about wresting control. The character is finding power where she can; in this gun
column3: in this dream of offing her two-timer
column4: in being glad he is gone
column5: she gets to have the last word. She's not necessarily the sort of protagonist you'd want to relate to. Maybe not even the sort of character you'd want to hear define the hard edges of her confusion and agony for the better part of an hour. But Niblett does a masterful and most uncanny thing-- she turns us. She splays the guts of the matter
column6: nuancing the petulant need and baby-why'd-you-go as it reconciles into something softer. By the end it's hard not to find resonance with it
column7: even if you've never been a Heathcliff mewling on the moors.

column1: As the album moves us through the aftermath
column2: the mood doesn't particularly let up. Coming on the heels of ""Gun""
column3: ""Can't Fool Me Now"" is about as much air as we get until the nearly seven-minute closer
column4: ""What Can I Do?"" The song is a sort of secondary reckoning
column5: a diagnosis
column6: and is the album's real moment of ceremony: soaring strings and rolling kettle drums give some dynamic to Niblett's familiar guitar interval. There are fits of strings and percussion throughout that force things forward
column7: but Emma mostly stays in the same place
column8: these tense few chords repeating
column9: with a spindly little note run or lead here
column10: a little e-bow there. There's this drag to it
column11: though; the down-tuned rumble of her unadorned guitar tone anchors the feeling that there is no escape
column12: its stasis mirroring the album's relentless obsession.

column1: Emma does offer redemption
column2: though that implies that something has been transformed. Over the course of the record's story
column3: the sense of who our heroine is-- or even that she is someone outside of the context of this man
column4: this pain-- becomes evident. She goes from martyr (""I wish I could take the weight for both of us/ Sure did try to"")
column5: calling ""My man... my man..."" to the confusion of ""Second Chance Dreams"" where she confesses ""I'm still getting wet"" at the thought of reuniting with the man that's rejected her. On the penultimate ""Could This Possibly Be?"" she owns up to who she is
column6: tied to this love
column7:
setting up ""What Can I Do?"" where both the singer and the listener see the ""truth"" of the situation: She has not been broken by this.

Daniel Menche does not create albums in as much as he creates atmospheres. For the last two decades
column4: the Portland
column5: OR
column6: musician has built dozens of massive
column7: teeming spans of sound
column8: deliberately sculpting a cacophony of static
column9: hum
column10: and rhythm into objects of inescapable gravity. In the past
column11: his best work-- 2002’s subwoofer rattling Face of Vehemence
column12: for instance
column13: or 2006’s seasick induction Creatures of Cadence-- has tended to be impenetrable from both sides: That is
column14: his strident layers of noise and concussion make hard
column15: instant demands of the listener’s durability. Once you’re in
column16: however
column17: Menche’s work tends to keep you there
column18: waiting for the next subtle shifts within his generally overwhelming musical framework. Menche is a wizard of tone and a master of pacing
column19: toggling expertly between tedium and restlessness
column20: a linked pair that’s something of a holy grail in such long-tone experimental fare.

column1: Another key aspect of Menche’s output is its prolific pace. Indeed
column2: keeping track of his catalogue has often felt like a task best suited for librarians or
column3: better yet
column4: hoarders. To wit
column5: his Bandcamp page offers 49 separate volumes
column6: and that’s only a partial discography. Menche has been working at that frantic pace for the majority of his career
column7: too
column8: issuing several albums
column9: collaborations and contributions with each new calendar. Between 2005 and 2009
column10: he seemed unstoppable
column11: releasing a feverish amount of material that felt ever significant and never tossed-off. During that period
column12: I collected everything he released. Recently
column13: though
column14: Menche’s aesthetic had started to feel a bit tired
column15: at least to me. I’m still not sure if the problem was with Menche or me-- perhaps I’d heard too much too quickly and grown too obsessive
column16: or perhaps he’d actually stalled out. After all
column17: he’d gone deep with visceral bass and high with wrenching noise
column18: fast with industrial wash cycles of percussion and slow with drones that blossomed like orchids. What was left? Last year’s aggressive Guts was good
column19: sure
column20: but it also felt like stylistic mannerism
column21: an irascible body blow from a guy trying to fight his way outside of the cloister of his own construction.

column1: But already in 2013
column2: Menche has released two remarkable records that not only stand alone as magnificent marathon trips but stand apart within his own canon
column3: too. Previously
column4: Menche’s oeuvre might only be described as beautiful from the inside looking in; spend enough time learning his vocabulary and becoming accustomed to the customary din
column5: and the harshness begins to glow. But Marriage of Metals
column6: his first for Editions Mego since Guts
column7: is his most identifiably pretty music to date and one of the best albums of his career.

column1: For recording
column2: Menche entered the studio of the Venerable Showers of Beauty
column3: a Gamelan ensemble that “foster artistic exchanges between Java and the Portland community.” He captured the range of available gongs and metallophones and then routed the recordings through his electronics
column4: shaping the sounds into two tracks. Pieces of liminal wonder
column5: the dual protracted pieces test the boundaries between attack and decay
column6: between consonance and dissonance
column7: between motion and stillness
column8: between disasters and dreams. Tiny melodies bubble from beneath cloaks of distortion and disappear
column9: leaving you to wonder if they were ever there at all. Rhythms pepper the space like fireflies in the dark. Everything about these pieces is intentional
column10: but Menche somehow makes it all feel incidental and instinctive
column11: as if you’ve simply stumbled into the sound of another world-- part Gamelan and part electronic
column12: sure
column13: but mostly alien. Menche’s music has long tended to pull listeners away from reality
column14: suspending time and expectations for vast stretches. Marriage of Metals
column15: however
column16: creates its own reality.

column1: Vilké dovetails more with Menche’s past. On a series of four 19 or 20 minute tracks
column2: he uses tumbles of warped digital percussion and swelling-and-subsiding drones to create harrowing environments where something sinister always seems to lurk just ahead. These are gauntlets of abrasion and anxiety. Taking its name from the Lithuanian vocative noun for female wolf
column3: Menche hints at wildlife mimesis within these 80 minutes
column4: the drums occasionally galloping like lupine paws and the distended tones howling like the wind or the animal itself. Still
column5: Vilké feels soft around the edges
column6: as though the animalistic wrath of similarly structured Menche records has now been augmented by a more balanced and honest view of the world around him. Vilké tempers Menche’s usual approach without dulling it. Perhaps the joys of dog ownership have finally started to moderate Menche’s work
column7: or perhaps he’s finally learning how to let more people in the front door of his atmospheres
column8:
even as he’s smartly sealing the exits.
