Director Jim Jarmusch has been increasingly hung up on music since shooting his last feature The Limits of Control
column2: a beautiful slow-crawl through the mind of an assassin. He's produced two albums with lutist Jozef Van Wissem
column3: worked as a curator at the New York incarnation of ATP
column4: and recorded a series of EPs with his new band
column5: a trio named SQÜRL. This project began life under the name Bad Rabbit
column6: assembled by Jarmusch
column7: drummer Carter Logan
column8: and Vampire Weekend/Sleigh Bells engineer Shane Stoneback. The initial aim was to flesh out the Limits soundtrack with thoughtful
column9: instrumental rock passages. This EP
column10: apparently the first in a series
column11: is an advance on that music. The setting is firmly fixed to ""desert
column12: with each of the four tracks touching on Josh Homme's approach to psychedelic rock.

column1: It's not hard to imagine an alternate universe where Jarmusch pursued music harder than film. At a recent show at the Mercury Lounge in New York
column2: staged to showcase SQÜRL and his work with Van Wissem
column3: he cut an imposing figure on stage. Whether stepping up to the mic or stooping down by his amp to pull out a wail of feedback
column4: it felt like these were the predominant moments Jarmusch played out in his teenage dreams. Of course
column5: he's played on stage many times before
column6: notably with no wave outfit the Del-Byzanteens
column7: but at this stage in his career
column8: where he's comfortably established in a different medium
column9: the show at the Mercury was pleasing for the full-blooded commitment it showed. It's indicative of the way Jarmusch works
column10: finding weight in moments both big and small
column11: never ascribing more importance to one over the other.

column1: That wilfull artistic blindness is fundamental to Jarmusch's stradling of the avant garde and the mainstream. It's what allows him to put Butthole Surfers frontman Gibby Haynes in a movie with Robert Mitchum and Johnny Depp. Similarly
column2: SQÜRL draws from a number of different disciplines. One track on this EP is simply drawn from layers of feedback. Another matches crunchy
column3: distorted guitar lines to Jarmusch singing about being surrounded by piles of dead hippies. Yes
column4: he's singing here
column5: on two out of four tracks
column6: only one of which deviates into the forlorn rock & roll crooner trap you might expect him to fall into. That track-- a cover of Elvis Presley's ""Little Sister"" forcibly shoved through a meat grinder-- is the weakest work here
column7: the only song that feels like an afterthought
column8: and currently outpaced in the gutter-neon stakes by Jarmusch acolyte Dirty Beaches.

column1: Where SQÜRL works best
column2: perhaps unsurprisingly
column3: is through the planes of repetitive sound that make up ""Pink Dust"". It’s the most soundtrack-y thing here
column4: the closest this EP gets to forming a link to the material this band specifically composed for film under their Bad Rabbit guise. The guitar tone isn’t far from Boris's ""Farewell""-- itself a part of the Limits of Control soundtrack-- but with a far nastier undercurrent crudely stamped all the way through it. It's a decent approximation of the kind of stuff Jarmusch has clearly been listening to in recent times
column5: judging from his soundtrack work and handpicked ATP lineup. It's part drone-rock
column6: part metal
column7: part blissful stoner fatigue. There's a power to it that the rest of the material can't get back to
column8: a sense of magic unfolding in those gigantic riffs. For now
column9: SQÜRL describe themselves as ""enthusiastically marginal
column10:
but there's enough going on here to suggest that's a placeholder rather than an epitaph.

The concept behind the soundtrack to Baz Luhrmann's cinematic adaptation of The Great Gastby was born when excessive rain halted filming in Sydney
column2: which gave the director the chance to connect with Jay-Z. The latter saw Gatsby as a tale of aspiration (check the novel's Rap Genius entry)
column3: and persuaded Luhrmann-- whose 3D production of the film was designed to draw audiences into the wild party scenes-- that a hip-hop-inspired soundtrack was the perfect way to convey the excitement and novelty of the Fitzgerald-coined ""jazz age"" to modern viewers.

column1: But Jay-Z and music supervisor Anton Monsted didn't exactly commit to the theme; Jay's opening track
column3: and the inclusion of his and Kanye West’s undeniable ""No Church in the Wild"" are the only full-on rap tracks here
column4: with a few other
column5: poppier songs hanging from the genre's coattails. Perhaps it shows Jay-Z’s knack for Gatsby-like social one-upmanship
column6: allowing everyone to participate in his vision while remaining very much at the center of it
column7: reveling in his influence. Either way

column9: folded just for the thrill/ Go numb until I can’t feel
column10: or might pop this pill
column11: ” Jay raps in cavalier fashion over a woozy
column12: stuttering beat. The ecstasy side of the party platter remains resolutely untouched throughout the rest of the soundtrack
column13: which grinds ahead with numbed
column14: blithe bombast.

column5: maddening on Emeli Sandé and the Bryan Ferry Orchestra’s dull-but-tasteful
column6: jazz-lite cover of “Crazy in Love”
column7: a sickness on Will.I.Am’s torturous EDM jazz-hands scat
column8: “Bang Bang”
column9: and narcotic on Ferry’s reinterpretation of Roxy Music’s “Love Is the Drug”. It’s telling of how ill conceived this defiantly modernity-inclined collection is that a 67-year-old crooning a nearly 40-year-old song is the sexiest thing here
column10: the high point of a perfunctory
column11: blockbuster bacchanal that displays a stunning lack of imagination among what's meant to be the cream of pop's crop.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: Fergie

column1: The xx and Gotye bring the only touches of anything approaching humanity to the soundtrack; the former on the slightly tedious attempt at high-stakes emoting “Together”

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19063/homepage_large.a818de96.jpg|Black Pudding|31166.0|Mark Lanegan & Duke Garwood|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ipecac']|2013-05-17 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:46.802827|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".26838d0pvk0.1.6:0.1.0.$17869/=1$17869.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div id=""_dyhb23rg4374"">
In the 1980s and 90s
column2: Mark Lanegan never seemed like he was going to be an old man. In the 21st century
column3: however
column4: it’s become nearly impossible to remember that Lanegan was ever young. In his review of Lanegan’s characteristically growly 2012 solo record Blues Funeral
column5: Ian Cohen likened Lanegan to weathered classic-rockers like Tom Waits
column6: Bob Dylan
column7: and Leonard Cohen
column8: and speculated that he “will be all but grandfathered into that Hall of Fame in 20 years.” But why wait another two decades when Lanegan already affects a spooky “chain-smoking walking corpse” persona as well as anybody? The first time Lanegan emerges on <i>Black Pudding
column9: his new collaboration with English multi-instrumentalist Duke Garwood (who most recently guested at the end of Savages' Silence Yourself)
column10: he’s addressing his frequent sparring partner Jesus C. in the bluesy prayer “Pentacostal”. On the next track
column11: “War Memorial”
column12: Lanegan points to “a pack of feral dogs” nipping at his heels
column13: as he’s not one to choose sides between God and the Devil. “Don’t tell me the ending of the play/ Don’t make me look/ In the mirror
column14: ” he sings. We all know which undead creature generally avoids mirrors.

column1: Blues Funeral was Lanegan’s first solo record in eight years; for Black Pudding
column2: he’s back to working with a musical co-pilot
column3: which has been his preferred mode of working for the past decade. Like his partnerships with Isobel Campbell and Greg Dulli
column4: Lanegan’s coupling with Garwood is somewhat vampiric in nature. While Garwood makes his presence felt throughout <i>Black Pudding
column5: most notably on the evocative bookending instrumentals “Black Pudding” and “Manchester Special” (which sound like a film score for an imaginary post-apocalyptic spaghetti western)
column6: he’s ultimately subsumed by Lanegan’s outsized personality. To his credit
column7: Garwood seems to understand that this was probably inevitable and acts accordingly: His accompaniment on Black Pudding tends to be spare and unobtrusive
column8: which keeps the spotlight on Lanegan
column9: that monstrous croon
column10: and his ongoing communion with the great beyond.

column1: While Black Pudding is more limited and monochromatic than Lanegan’s other pairings-- the beauty-and-the-beast lustiness of the Isobel Campbell records is obviously missing
column2: as is the mile-deep veneer of filth and depravity from the Dulli-assisted Gutter Twins records-- it doesn’t necessarily suffer from it. Lanegan is a brand name that promises scarifying dirges and tough-guy sensitivity
column3: and Black Pudding delivers on both accounts with workmanlike consistency. You can guess precisely what songs like “Death Rides a White Horse” or “Sphinx” sound like before playing them. If that makes Black Pudding a wheelhouse record
column4: so be it; the Sly Stone-like downer funk of “Cold Molly” demonstrates that Lanegan falters whenever he ventures outside of his self-made pine box.

column1: Predictability isn’t the most exciting or virtuous artistic attribute
column2: but at least Black Pudding is a luminous and finely crafted example of a well-established formula. Lanegan is a year-and-a-half away from his 50th birthday
column3: but he already has the gravitas of 70s-era Clint Eastwood; Black Pudding might not be High Plains Drifter
column4: but it’s a suitably entertaining bad-ass diversion a la The Gauntlet.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19207/homepage_large.f5136458.jpg|No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers|30406.0|Vår|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-05-17 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:47.455801|"

The young Danish punk group Iceage makes claustrophobic songs so short and dense they make you breathe in a shallow fashion to preserve their limited oxygen. The band has also gained what may feel like a claustrophobic reputation. The swift militaristic efficiency of their musical maneuvers
column2: the transgressive influence of dead French surrealists
column3: and the heavily reported flirtations with nationalist and fascist imagery have added up to a distinctly aggressive image
column4: even though the members look more like One Direction-gone-to-seed than bellicose reactionaries. That’s what makes Vår
column5: the new band of Iceage's Elias Bender Rønnenfelt
column6: sound like a refutation rather than a mere tangent-- or at least
column7: a balancing of scales.

column1: Vår is something of an unusual supergroup within the boundaries of Copenhagen's thriving D.I.Y. hardcore scene. Joining Rønnenfelt are Loke Rahbek of Sexdrome and Kristian Emdal of Lower
column2: along with Lukas Højland. Their similarities to Iceage end with the purported influence of Georges Bataille-- which might account for the absurdist poetry moaning over the doomy electronic pulses of their song ""Hair Like Feathers""-- and the use of rolling field snares
column3: suggesting the forced marches of valiantly defeated armies. But Rønnenfelt's downcast voice and mournful
column4: dystopian lyrics are laid bare by the krautrock
column5: industrial
column6: goth- and synth-pop styles that replace guitar thrash on No One Dances Quite Like My Brothers. Though crusted with rough textures
column7: the music is as open and vulnerable as the Copenhagen punk bands are clenched and impervious
column8: bending the same apocalyptic impulse in a serene
column9: interior
column10: even sensuous direction.

column1: For being recorded in a cramped home studio in Bushwick last summer
column2: Vår's Sacred Bones debut feels surprisingly spacious and cool
column3: roaming a wide swath between the softest borders of Joy Division
column4: Kraftwerk
column5: and the Foley-effected
column6: electro-acoustic war folk of These New Puritans. Throughout the album
column7: samples of broken glass and metal
column8: acoustic and electric guitars
column9: analog electronics
column10: bleary trumpets
column11: and processed percussion line up in soft curves with scoured edges. Bright Eyes may have beat Vår to the mirrored album cover by 13 years
column12: but Vår's choice of artwork makes a sound contextual point: This is reflective music
column13: making the listener complicit.

column1: At their poppiest
column2: as on ""The World Fell"" and ""Pictures of Today/Victorial""
column3: Vår set raggedly reaching multi-tracked vocals (apparently canned in Germany in the 1970s) over thumping beats and chiming guitars that think they're synthesizers. The velvety
column4: sparkling miasma of the latter represents this collaboration at its most realized
column5: the low heat gradually igniting the snarled images of iron and fire at the end. Not everything is that considered: ""Motionless Duties"" breaks the dreamy mood with its darkness and abrasion
column6: though woozy trumpet peals eventually open it up a bit
column7: and the drums-and-drones piece ""Boy"" is a long interstitial at four minutes.

column1: But ventures outside of Teutonic synth-pop pay off in the title track
column2: where Pharmakon's Margaret Chardiet gives a remarkably tender recitation atop a pillow of distorted symphonic ambiance. A stirring piece of music in its own right
column3: it also feels like another deliberate attempt
column4: following the video for “In Your Arms (Final Fantasy)”
column5: by the punks of Vår to soften a brittle public perception of themselves as right-wing hawks. Although the sensitive side it reveals is less developed than their established one
column6:
it's just as intriguing.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19208/homepage_large.1d3762cf.jpg|The Last Spire|31266.0|Cathedral|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rise Above']|2013-05-17 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:47.999069|"

After nearly a quarter century
column2: 10 albums
column3: a major-label stint
column4: and a deserved reputation as an act that helped pull doom metal from its stylistic exile
column5: exactly how will Cathedral end its final album? That’s the question that hovers above The Last Spire
column6: the excellent eight-track LP that will mark the end of the long-running
column7: ever-restless English quartet. Early last year
column8: Cathedral played their final show in Australia before returning to England to chart their own demise. For the last two decades
column9: the band has pushed far beyond the slow-growing and wide-set roots of its foundational debut
column10: 1991’s Forest of Equilibrium
column11: to incorporate thrash blitzes
column12: psychedelic tangents and 70s rock bombast. Talking through each entry in the band’s catalogue with Terrorizer earlier this year
column13: frontman Lee Dorian acknowledged the deliberate nature of his band’s non-linear development. Sometimes they wanted to retreat from doom
column14: and sometimes they wanted to retreat into it. “I hate complacency
column15: ” he said. “It’s not something you should ever feel
column16: especially in terms of art.”

column1: That perspective has kept Cathedral interesting for the long haul
column2: even if it hasn’t resulted in necessarily great records. For instance
column3: the band’s most recent LP
column4: 2010’s The Guessing Game
column5: spent 85 minutes dipping and diving into prog rock aberrations that sometimes felt excessive and often unnecessary. Cathedral kept twisting free from its traditionally lugubrious mid-tempo maul with an assortment of influences
column6: from Uriah Heep to Genesis. Mostly
column7: it made you wish Cathedral would just settle back in to doom again.

column1: And for a moment at the close of The Last Spire
column2: it seems that Cathedral will indeed exit with a sentimental reminder than that they’ve generally been more than a simply gloomy squadron. “This Body
column3: Thy Tomb”
column4: the final song
column5: opens with a low-strung
column6: generously distorted riff
column7: which Dorian pairs with appropriately funereal imagery: “I exist in this coffin
column8: ” he opens from a backlit pulpit. “Murdered trust and misfortune has evolved into strife.” Just past the three-minute mark
column9: though
column10: Dorian and the strangling tone of Garry Jennings go quiet
column11: fading into a series of somber instrumentals-- a twinkling acoustic guitar
column12: a glass-eyed electric solo
column13: a music box melody played on mellotron. Cathedral
column14: it seems
column15: will fade into their own apoptosis.

column1: But the mighty band enters one last time
column2: pounding at Jennings’ lead harder than it has for the entire record. Brian Dixon locks into distended drum rolls and swings hard coming out of them
column3: while keyboardist David Moore and bassist Scott Carlson build steep walls around the riff
column4: conjuring claustrophobia even while heading for the exit. No treacle here: Cathedral ends exactly as it started-- heads down in heavy doom. Swansong attachment aside
column5: that return-to-basics approach is one defining characteristic of The Last Spire
column6: an album that reconnects with Cathedral’s beginnings without simply repeating them.

column1: Another is restraint: In an interview with Ghost Cult Magazine published the week after The Last Spire was released
column2: Jennings admitted that the band left a lot of recorded material on the cutting room floor for this album. Of those five omitted tracks
column3: he said
column4: at least one of them was a 30-minute Cathedral farewell that was never finished. At 56 minutes
column5: however
column6: The Last Spire is very much the right length for a band whose most consistent handicap has been not knowing when to say when
column7: or how to move toward the next track or album. No
column8: efficiency has never been Cathedral’s bailiwick
column9: but on The Last Spire
column10: they operate with surprising and newfound economy. They surround lengthy tracks with much shorter ones and generally just get out of their own way. The first half of the record
column11: for instance
column12: moves as swiftly as anything Cathedral has ever done. A terrifying introduction of swelling field recordings
column13: tolling church bells and grating noise passes quickly into “Pallbearer”
column14: a 12-minute anthem that pauses just enough for an acoustic interlude before sprinting headlong into a burst of thrash. It’s an extended number
column15: but Cathedral anchors shifting momentum to a grim mantra00 “War
column16: famine
column17: drought
column18: disease!”-- and a center of doom gravity. You almost want it to keep going
column19: a rare quality for this band. “Cathedral of the Damned”
column20: meanwhile
column23: while “Tower of Silence” adds a dose of punk ire to its unfettered seven-minute march. By not pausing to take stock of its progress
column24: Cathedral testifies to its true purpose and power.

column1: The Last Spire is so close to the spirit of Cathedral’s earliest works that Dorian has said it’s the record he’s hoped to make since their debut
column2: Forest of Equilibrium. Importantly
column3: though
column4: it does not feel like a microwaved visitation with the past or some self-obsessed tribute. Rather
column5: these pieces sound like the work of a band hoping to fortify their legacy at the end of their career rather than simply prolong it. The last two decades of exploration reappear here
column6: certainly-- listen for the sidewinding second guitar in the distance during “Tower of Silence”
column7: or
column8: more obviously
column9: the playful and possibly avoidable keyboard-and-bass fantasy that sits at the center of the otherwise morose “An Observation”. But these are simply the positive after-effects of years of auditory experimentation
column10: not the driving force for the record itself. They’ve got too much to fit into an hour for self-involved excess.

column1: If The Last Spire is the end of Cathedral
column2: it’s a lofty exit for a band that’s often tripped over its own artistic ambition and unease. These eight tracks serve as a swift
column3: sinister reminder of why Cathedral mattered at the start and why they intrigued for so many years in the middle. When it mattered the most
column4: they had the sense to recognize that their work was done and to experience the end with dignity-- and
column5: thankfully
column6:
doom.      

"|18020.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18020-cathedral-the-last-spire/|7.5|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19314/homepage_large.12715d05.jpg|Tectonic Plates Vol. 4|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tectonic']|2013-05-17 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:48.462123|"

If there was a time when Bristol was deserving of the title “second city of dubstep
column2: ” then Rob Ellis<b>
column3: better known as Pinch
column4: and his label
column5: Tectonic
column6: were central to its claim. From 2004 Ellis’ Subloaded clubnights were the first to bring the great and good of London’s nascent scene to the city. Tectonic
column7: launched the following year
column8: served as a home for productions from some of dubstep’s future stars
column9: including Skream and Loefah. By 2007 the label was at the forefront of Bristol’s own spin on the genre
column10: splicing its 140 bpm rhythmic framework with the metallic sonics and hypnotic arrangements of Berlin techno.

column1: But as the noughties wore on and UK dance music began its migration to slower
column2: house- and techno-friendly tempos
column3: Ellis dragged his heels. He would cling to dubstep for far longer than the majority of his contemporaries
column4: and when he finally (partially) let go it was
column5: it seems
column6: with a heavy heart. (He released a 2011 mix titled Oh No Not Another DJ Playing House Music.) Ellis’ A&R-ing followed a similar contour. In recent years Tectonic’s output has constituted a slightly awkward mixture of backwards-looking dubstep and house- and techno-oriented signings. And while it has remained admirably independent-minded in style (who else in the UK would have taken a gamble on the abstract beat-sketches of Pursuit Grooves?) it feels like Ellis’ previously strong aesthetic vision has frayed a little
column7: and at this point the label’s influence is at something of a low ebb.

column1: The Tectonic Plates compilations have long functioned as a sort of state-of-the-nation for the label
column2: and last year’s Vol. 3 seemed firmly entrenched in dubstep. By contrast
column3: while Vol. 4 has by no means abandoned that approach
column4: it feels far less wedded to the past. That’s partly down to the recent renaissance in dark
column5: grime- and dubstep-derived forms clustered around Blackdown’s Keysound label: Two proponents of that scene are featured here. Beneath
column6: whose music typically transplants 2005 dubstep’s baleful sonics onto a UK funky framework
column7: contributes ""Flight""-- an oddity in his discography
column8: bumping along at a sluggish 116 bpm
column9: but compelling nonetheless. Mumdance and Logos
column10: meanwhile
column11: play fast and loose with the sonic hallmarks of grime in ""Drum Boss""
column12: distributing a heavily reverbed percussive palette across cold
column13: weightless space.

column1: There are welcome injections of fresh blood elsewhere
column2: too. ""Talk""
column3: by recent Tectonic signing DECiBEL
column4: is an unexpected highlight-- essentially quickstepping dubstep
column5: all throbbing sub and flickering hi-end
column6: but leavened by brash sampled chords and vocals. And U.S. producers Sinistarr and Texel turn in an intriguing (if confusingly titled) triplet-swung techno number in ""Decibell"". Elsewhere
column7: a few label stalwarts offer pleasant surprises. Jakes’ ""Rounds"" is a welcome detour from his usual high-octane
column8: low-IQ fare
column9: avoiding blindingly obvious drop-structures in favour of an unusual multi-tiered structure. Guido-- always the more imaginative of Bristol’s so-called “Purple” crew-- explores pleasingly off-kilter digital soul in ""State Of Joy""
column10: while Pursuit Grooves’ ""Hard Beginnings""
column11: with its rumbling sub and discordant sample work
column12: is a characteristically bizarre offering.

column1: Granted
column2: there are moments here that feel a little stale
column3: or just plain ineffectual. The syncopations that animate Kryptic Minds’ ""Convoluted"" are smart but
column4: as with much of his work
column5: their execution is so varnished as to pass by without incident. Armour-- an alias of Roly Porter
column6: one half of fabled industrial-dubstep duo Vex’d-- doesn’t shine on ""Skylark""
column7: whose stuttering bass and muted mentasm stabs aren’t nearly as punishing as they ought to be. And it’s difficult to see why the also-ran halftime of Steve Digital’s ""Larry Shite"" merited inclusion. But taken as a whole
column8: Tectonic Plates Volume 4 is a considerable improvement on its predecessor
column9:
cleaving closely to the aesthetic co-ordinates of Tectonic’s past without reading like a misty-eyed love letter to a lost time. It also suggests a number of new directions for Ellis to pursue. 2013 may yet be a good year for the label.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19233/homepage_large.c38365a2.jpg|Re-Mit|1445.0|The Fall|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Cherry Red']|2013-05-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:48.984406|"

Mark E. Smith was already a cranky old man when he started the Fall at the age of 19; now that he’s 56
column2: he’s eager to act like a child. The first words we hear Mark E. Smith utter on Re-Mit are: “Geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh-geh/ Gus-gus/ Wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-wah-blah-blah-la-la-la-la-la-la-la-la-la-la-la”-- and in the weird and frightening world of the Fall
column3: this is what happiness sounds like. Because 36 years after forming the band
column4: Smith seems to have finally found a group of people he genuinely enjoys playing with: Not only has his current keyboardist and wife
column5: Eleni Poulou
column6: now been at his side for twice as long (11 years) as his most famous musical/matrimonial partner
column7: Brix Smith
column8: the line-up that appears on Re-Mit is the same one that featured on the Fall’s preceding three albums. By the standards of a band whose list of former members warrants its own Wikipedia page
column9: bassist Dave Spurr
column10: guitarist Pete Greenway
column11: and drummer Keiron Melling have been playing in the Fall long enough to be eligible for commemorative gold watches. But there are no such prizes to be handed out in the Fall. The reward for such dedicated service is: You get to make another Fall album.

column1: Not that stability breeds consistency
column2: mind you. This version of the Fall has produced their best album of the past decade (2010’s Your Future Our Clutter) and the worst (2011’s Ersatz G.B.). Re-Mit fortunately leans more toward the former
column3: proffering a dense
column4: unwieldy tangle of rockabilly rhythms
column5: 60s proto-punk petulance
column6: krautrock thrust
column7: musique-concrete spoken-word splatter
column8: and sci-fi synth-tones salvaged from 70s bargain-bin prog. It’s messy and menacing in equal measure
column9: a bar fight that ends in broken glass and slippery floors
column10: but not before landing a few killer strikes. (In particular
column11: the soccer-riot melee of “Sir William Wray”
column12: the morse-code motorik drive of “Victrola Time”
column13: and the wobbly-kneed boogie of “Loadstones” are the ones you’ll be dragging onto your ongoing post-millennial Fall playlist.) And if Smith now sings like a man who’s had all his teeth knocked out
column14: at least he’s still smiling-- whether emitting Beefheartian grunts on “Kinder of Spine”
column15: squealing like a frightened granny on “Victrola Time”
column16: or punctuating the predatory groove of “Hittite Man” with 20 seconds of phlegm-gurgling coughs
column17: he seems to be reveling in the opportunity to showcase the least flattering extremes of his wizened voice
column18: and present a more grotesque caricature of Mark E. Smith than his haters could possibly imagine.

column1: For all its seeming disarray
column2: Re-Mit makes does make some concessions to structure
column3: opening with an instrumental garage-rockin' rave-up (“No Respects”) that’s later reprised in expanded
column4: vocal form
column5: while positioning its fragmented
column6: formless rambles (“Noise”
column7: “Pre-MDMA Years”) as brief interstitials between the more realized tracks. (That said
column8: “Jam Song” is every bit the meandering slog its title suggests.) And as he is wont to do
column9: Smith offsets his cryptic spiels on Anatolian subcultures
column10: vacationing Italian nationals
column11: and 19th century British politicians with contemporary pop-cultural concerns: in lieu of Ersatz GB’s Gossip Girl episode recaps
column12: we have a shout-out to LCD Soundsystem leader/unofficial Fall fanclub president James Murphy on the roly-poly rumble of “Irish” (“James Murphy is their chief/ They show their bollocks when they eat”)
column13: which
column14: given Smith’s notorious refusal to equate imitation with flattery
column15: is probably not meant as a compliment. However
column16: compared to the vitriol he once spewed upon progeny like Pavement and Sonic Youth
column17: Murphy gets off relatively easy. If you need more proof that Mark E. Smith is in a good mood these days
column18:
there you have it.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19197/homepage_large.c9e0cfba.jpg|Abandon|31210.0|Pharmakon|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-05-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:50.124601|"

It starts with a scream. Not just any scream
column2: but one that sounds like it's shredding all the muscle tissue in the vocal cords of Margaret Chardiet
column3: the 22-year-old New Yorker who records as Pharmakon. It's more a warning than an introduction
column4: a line drawn in the sand that forces you to either cross and face the consequences or turn away and go about your pleasant day. Chardiet outlined her backstory in a recent Rising feature; the daughter of punk parents
column5: highly active on the DIY scene in New York
column6: uninterested in cultivating any kind of online presence. She says Abandon is about ""fiercely holding on to what's true and unapologetically abandoning what's not."" Getting to the heart of Chardiet's truth is an ugly process
column7: full of pain and suffering and confrontation spilling outward
column8: forming an unwavering commitment to her art that's both commendable and distressing at the same time.

column1: This release for Sacred Bones is the most high-profile Pharmakon output to date
column2: following a series of hard-to-find CD-Rs and cassettes. The music hovers around the noise and power electronics genres
column3: taking cues from Throbbing Gristle
column4: various phases of Swans
column5: and Whitehouse among others. Like those bands
column6: Chardiet isn't interested in music as a passive listening experience. Instead
column7: Abandon is a brick hurtling through the windshield of a moving car
column8: a purposefully antagonistic act that forces you to fully focus on the moment. Pharmakon's most frightening moments rarely involve a complete noise blackout. This is a carefully worked set of lethargically paced songs
column9: sometimes passing from a chilly machine hum to dull thuds of metallic percussion (""Ache"")
column10: sometimes taking pitch-shifted vocal passages and layering them over drones that sound like bombs tumbling out of the sky (""Crawling on Bruised Knees"").

column1: There’s a thread of body horror loosely strung through Chardiet's work. A prior release included a track named ""Mound of Flesh
column2: Cavern of Fluids""; this record depicts Chardiet covered in maggots on the cover and includes ""Crawling on Bruised Knees""; one of her older tracks
column3: ""Xia Xinfeng""
column4: is named after a woman who literally kissed her lover to death by passing him a capsule of rat poison when their lips met. Similarly
column5: the music carries a strong sense of disease and decay
column6: of things nearing a point of total breakdown. The fascination with bodily atrophy makes sense here
column7: anchored to work so physically draining for both listener and performer. Abandon isn't at all about creating distance or putting up boundaries. Chardiet often forces audience members to look her directly in the eyes during live shows
column8: sucking participants down into her despair in an unnervingly direct manner.

column1: The arc Abandon takes feels deliberately mapped out
column2: heading from an overpowering form of aggression at the start and gradually sinking into more studied material later on. ""Pitted"" borrows some of the clarity Swans found circa Children of God
column3: where noise started to feel like a dead end and tracks like ""New Mind"" represented a solemn trudge out of the mire. Chardiet's vocal bears a similar authoritarian tone to the one Michael Gira possesses; when she sings
column4: you shut up and listen. It's helped by the fact that her multi-octave voice can rise and plummet so effectively
column5: something driven home by ""Pitted""
column6: where no amount of harsh electronics can compete with the full-tilt power of her vocal. It's the one slip of the mask here
column7: the one moment where a form of deathlike beauty is stirred into the swill
column8: momentarily hinting at a place somewhere outside of Pharmakon's defiant battle mode.

column1: In a recent Wire interview with Wolf Eyes
column2: the band's John Olson discussed the gradual cessation of musicians working in all-out noise
column3: resulting in more meditative electronic artists such as Oneohtrix Point Never and Emeralds. Olson likened the move to a shift from external to internal impulses
column4: a retreat from the outright purge of Wolf Eyes into something more inward-looking. Chardiet's work as Pharmakon spills all its guts out onto the floor and leaves them hanging for close inspection
column5: but this isn't entirely a return to external outpouring. As noted in the aforementioned interview
column6: there are times in the Pharmakon live show where she's ""disappearing into her own head."" Those moments are apparent here
column7: too
column8: making it feel like Chardiet oscillates between being lost to the world and thoroughly bruised by it. Getting forcibly pinned down in her personal cycle of attack and retreat is a dark
column9: visceral
column10:
utterly compelling thrill.

"|18009.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18009-pharmakon-abandon/|8.0|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19191/homepage_large.9b71ec8d.jpg|Dungeonesse|30919.0|Dungeonesse|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2013-05-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:50.557794|"

""Something that Jon and I talk about a lot is the idea of reclaiming pop music
column2: Wye Oak singer/guitarist Jenn Wasner said as an introduction to their new electro-pop duo Dungeonesse. “Placing it squarely in the hands of
column3: I dunno
column4: say
column5: a couple of regular nerds from Baltimore.” (Jon Ehrens is of the Baltimore band White Life.) Wasner’s quote was a pretty soft sell. With very few exceptions
column6: the best kind of pop music is superhumanly suave and wilts at the first sign of even quasi-academic jargon
column7: so there are a couple of red flags in that sentence: “regular”
column8: “nerds”
column9: “reclaiming.” But luckily
column10: none of these words have anything to do with the way Dungeonesse’s light
column11: infectious
column12: effortlessly cool debut actually sounds. Dungeonesse has none of the awkwardness you might expect from an artist like Wasner (who’s stepping more out of her comfort zone here than Ehrens is) making a self-conscious foray into a totally different genre; surprisingly
column13: she sounds completely at home in the album’s crush-struck vibrancy and retro-90s shimmer. You’d be hard pressed to find the slightest trace of that self-proclaimed nerdiness-- except for the fact that one of the best songs is called “Shucks”.

column1: Wasner and Ehrens wrote the album like a post-dial-up Postal Service-- he sent her tracks
column2: she filled in the lyrics and melodies-- and as a team
column3: they bring out the best in each other. White Life’s neo-new-wave self-titled 2011 debut was solidly catchy if a little faceless
column4: but here Wasner’s husky
column5: charismatic vocals bring his tracks to life. And as for Wasner herself
column6: she’s had a busy and stylistically varied couple of years: since Wye Oak’s excellently brooding 2011 album Civilian
column7: she’s released a few singles with her art-pop side project Flock of Dimes and made cameos on albums from Future Islands and Titus Andronicus
column8: basically becoming the go-to name in indie rock's “elegantly forlorn female voice"" Rolodex entry. Which is why it’s refreshing to hear her sound like she’s having so much damn fun on Dungeonesse. Ehrens’ bright and bouyant tracks bring out a lighter side of Wasner: Overtop a cascade of glimmering synths
column9: she’s never sounded as playful as she does on the great lead-off single “Drive You Crazy”
column10: while the Dev Hynes-like beat on the swooning “This Could Be Home” is punctuated with samples of her sighs and laughter.

column1: Dungeonesse’s sound is poised somewhere between the past and present. Their take on the poppier side of modern R&B would sound at home on a playlist with Jessie Ware and Solange
column2: but they’re also trying to reanimate a very specific mid-90s vibe-- think Jock Jams for a private party rather than a whole bleacher-rocking stadium. They embrace their influences wholeheartedly
column3: enough to bring the past vividly into the present moment. It’s pretty amazing how well they get the vibe down: If you played “Cadillac” for someone and told them it was a long-lost would-be dance hit from 1994
column4: they wouldn’t bat an eyelash. But like a few other tracks
column5: “Cadillac” almost sinks under the weight of the album’s most glaring problem: They’ve yet to make a convincing case for why there should ever be a rap verse in a Dungeonesse song. TT the Artist lends a couple of hip-hop Mad Libs lines (“Get-get on up/ Feel the groove”) to the otherwise excellent “This Could Be Home”
column6: and Baltimore emcee DDm’s cliche-ridden verse on “Cadillac” isn’t much more imaginative. Maybe this is just the one place where Dungeonesse studied the 90s dance hit songbook a little too hard; after all
column7: the dude from Real McCoy wasn’t exactly Andre 3000.

column1: It’s funny what a difference a couple years makes. Five years ago
column2: it would have been a lot rarer to hear a singer firmly rooted in indie-folk territory gushing about 90s dance pop and her <a href=""http://www.usatoday.com/story/popcandy/2012/12/11/dungeonesse-baltimore-band/1761977/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“youthful fantasies growing up
column3: listening to Mariah Carey and trying to recreate [the] vocals.” But in 2013
column4: that sentiment feels commonplace enough for Wasner’s comment about “reclaiming pop” to almost feel dated. After all
column5: the boundaries that used to separate “pop” from “indie” are corroding from both sides. One example of many? Jenn Wasner has made a very good pop record... and the new Mariah Carey song opens with a warm
column6:
fuzzy riff that sounds like something lifted out of a Wye Oak song.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19110/homepage_large.7b3433f0.jpg|Raw Solutions|29397.0|Slava|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Software']|2013-05-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:51.043949|"

For years
column2: dance music was gripped by a compulsion to sort its constituent material into ever more finely grained categories
column3: so that a style like drum n' bass could spawn dozens upon dozens of sub-subgenres
column4: each with its own precise aesthetic definition. Thankfully the easy digital exchange of music and the influx of new participants in the culture who aren’t bound by received orthodoxies has helped to break this taxonomical fever
column5: and the dance music artists most worth paying attention to right now are the ones paying the least attention to the lines drawn between styles.; ones like Moscow-born
column6: Chicago-raised
column7: Brooklyn-based producer Slava Balasanov
column8: for instance.

column1: Balasanov (who records using just his first name) has in the past been associated with the seapunk and witch house movements
column2: but that’s more a side-effect of putting out music on labels like Coral Records and Tri Angle than because of any particular stylistic affinity. He identifies simply as a house musician
column3: which is much closer to the truth
column4: although still inexact. On his debut full-length
column5: Raw Solutions
column6: Balasanov gives the impression of someone taking all of house's splintered
column7: baffling stylistic descendants
column8: and attempting to fuse them back into one unified whole.

column1: While Raw Solutions takes a holistic view towards house
column2: with an apparent goal of touching on every possible variation of the form
column3: Balasanov obviously has some favorites. He gets the most mileage out of a Chicago-specific stylistic continuum that starts in first-wave house and moves on through ghetto house
column4: juke
column5: and footwork
column6: folding an entire evolutionary branch back in on itself in an atemporal collage of stuttering high-speed beats
column7: raunchy vocal loops
column8: and retro-ravey synths.

column1: As interesting as Balasanov’s attempt to create an ur-house may be-- as well as his excursions further afield into R&B
column2: moombahton
column3: and beyond-- his emulations of those sounds wouldn’t be proper tributes unless they bumped. Which they do
column4: it turns out. Raw Solutions can offer the armchair musicologist hours of entertainment dissecting it
column5: but stepping away from the analytical perspective reveals it to be a very solid collection of viscerally compelling dance music.

column1: Balasanov has a deeply intuitive understanding of house’s build-and-release dynamic
column2: as well as its give and take with its audience
column3: which he applies in interesting ways. The return from the breakdown on the opening track
column4: “Werk”
column5: which nods at salsa and 90s club music
column6: is a piece of subtle
column7: nuanced craftsmanship that’s the polar opposite of the walloping EDM drop. The triptych of “Girls on Dick”
column8: “Wait”
column9: and “On It” comprise a two-part exploration of ghetto house’s hypnotic salaciousness
column10: split up by a brief
column11: juxtapositional trip into chillwave-inflected ambience.

column1: Raw Solutions is more ambitious than the average dance album
column2: both in terms of the span of sonic territory that it covers and its attempts to synthesize all of it into one cohesive work. And it’s more successful than most. Track-by-track
column3: the music’s potent
column4: but like Balasanov’s approach to making it
column5:
it’s much more than simply the sum of its parts.

On the percolating title track that opens John Grant's second solo album
column3: he sings of ""pale green ghosts""-- trees that line the Colorado byways by which he oriented himself
column4: ""Helping me to know my place."" The line packs a double meaning
column5: as the entire album is Grant mapping exactly where he's at after the fiery dissolution of a relationship with a man who a mere album ago was the one. Grant's route is not complicated-- really just a rough ride to downtown Fuck You and back
column6: his hatred for his ex occasionally outpaced by his own self-loathing.

column1: In his previous life
column2: Grant helmed the Czars
column3: giving Denver bragging rights to a decent band in the late 1990s. After the band fell apart
column4: Grant cleaned up and came out
column5: and collaborated with Midlake for his 2010 solo debut Queen of Denmark. In the intervening years Grant contracted HIV and went public about his status on stage during a performance with Hercules and Love Affair last summer. Pale Green Ghost's themes and energy dovetail out of all of this-- it's an intense
column6: angry record of inconsolable heartbreak
column7: crooned with authority over luscious electro. Though not strictly for the disco
column8: perhaps for the post-disco comedown and hungover dejection
column9: producer Birgir Þórarinsson (of Iceland's GusGus) bouys the record and keeps it from capsizing under the weight of its own emotional baggage.

column1: Pale Green Ghosts is defined by Grant's willingness to broadcast directly from his hell; he's a bit of a serial confessor
column2: and the confessions are marked by blitheness that belies just how much he did care
column3: how far from love he has fallen. He sings the songs of a man with little else to lose. There is not much the way of self-preservation
column4: which can be a touch brutal
column5: as when he addresses his diagnosis on ""Ernest Borgnine"": ""Doc ain't lookin’ at me
column6: says I got the disease/ Now what did you expect
column7: you spent your life on your knees."" At times his anguish is refined: ""There are days when I think about you/ And on those days I really feel like a fool
column8: because/ You don’t deserve to have somebody think about you
column9: as he sings on ""You Don't Have To"". Other times the lyrics are visceral
column10: like day-after break-up texts
column11: clamoring to inflict the hurt right back ""You don’t have to say things that you don’t mean/ It just embarrasses me/ because you think you’re so fucking cool.""

column1: Grant's regal baritone makes his sadness and his anger sound that much more serious-- but throughout the album there's some delight mixed in with all the spite
column2: a sadistic little smirk lodged in the flesh-ripping sarcasm. On ""GMF""
column3: he flips between braggadocio (""But I am the greatest motherfucker that you’re ever going to meet"") and backhands (""You think I hate myself but it’s you I hate""). ""Remember how we used to fuck all night long?"" he asks on ""You Don't Have To""
column4: only to answer
column5: ""Neither do I."" It's eviscerating and almost funny
column6: but maybe not ha-ha funny. On the chorus of ""Vietnam"" he extends the metaphor of just how his ex has laid his life to waste
column7: but the real decimation comes with the outro: ""And the only thing that brings me any comfort/ Is the knowledge that no matter who you’re with/ You’ll always be alone."" Grant is plummeting to the depths
column8: and exacting payback through incisive emotional terror as he goes down.

column1: Grant's ease of disclosure can be unnerving
column2: but it's this sense that nothing is (seemingly) too private for him to share in a song that makes Pale Green Ghosts so potent and
column3: ultimately
column4: accessible. If you have ever felt splayed by life
column5: made powerless by circumstance
column6:
you can find yourself seething right along.

Before they could legally drink
column3: the Deal twins
column4: armed with one guitar and two mics
column5: were fixtures in the scuzziest bars of Dayton
column6: Ohio
column7: where legend has it their salty-sweet harmonies could make even the motorcycle dudes cry. The year was 1978
column8: maybe 79. Like the bikers
column9: Kim and Kelley listened to Hank Williams and the Everly Brothers; when Kelley was 16 she watched The Song Remains the Same on acid and the souvenir she kept from her trip was this dead-serious conviction that she wanted to be Jimmy Page. Other people's songs were too hard to figure out
column10: so they made up their own. Nobody else would play with them (Kim: ""This is Dayton
column11: Ohio. You know the NGA kids: No Girls Allowed. Motherfuckers."")
column12: so they played with themselves. The angel-voiced twins kept booking scuzzy bar gigs and kept writing songs with no greater ambition than staving off boredom. ""There was no scene
column13: Kelley recalled years later
column14: ""You made up your own fun.""

column1: Kim considered herself a guitarist first and foremost. She'd been playing since she was 11
column2: but shortly after she moved to Boston in her mid-20s
column3: she tried out for a band called Pixies whose two current members suggested she learn bass. All the better that she'd never played one before; the Boston Phoenix classified ad she'd answered had said
column4: ""Please
column5: no chops."" They asked Kelley to be the drummer but she didn't feel like leaving Dayton
column6: so she said no. For the next seven years
column7: Kim sang backup and played bass in the Pixies
column8: but mostly she was cool for a living. The kind of cool that people mythologize in songs years later. The kind of cool that dominoes immeasurably: in the same way that we'll never know exactly how many babies are on this earth because of Sade
column9: we will never know how many girls picked up bass guitars and started bands because of Kim Deal's grinning
column10: invitingly normal
column11: yes-even-you-can-do-this-too charm. It was the kind of cool that irrevocably scrambles people's ideas of what cool actually is. ""Kim would come straight from work
column12: so she had skirt-suits and office pumps on a lot
column13: recalled Tanya Donelly
column14: then of Throwing Muses
column15: who accompanied Pixies on their first European tour. ""So many people in [the Boston scene were] trying to look cool
column16: and meanwhile the coolest person there is dressed like a secretary. I have to say
column17: in a day it changed my perception of what was cool.""

column1: As the Pixies' cult fanbase grew throughout late 80s and early 90s
column2: Kim's artistic contributions diminished with each record. Depending on who you ask
column3: she was either almost kicked out of or almost quit the famously tumultuous band a few different times before Frank Black sent out indie rock's most notorious fax in the summer of 1992
column4: letting everyone know that the Pixies were through. In the liner notes to the 20th anniversary reissue of Last Splash
column5: the phenomenal second album from her other band the Breeders
column6: Kim sums up the Pixies' explosive seven-year run in a single
column7: tellingly faceless sentence: ""[W]e started by driving ourselves in a van with no record contract
column8: went on to appear on front covers of the English music press (while still largely unknown in the States) and ended when the lead singer quit the band to pursue a solo career.""

column1: The Breeders began in earnest when Pixies and Throwing Muses came off that first European tour
column2: at some point during which Kim and Donelly decided they wanted to make a record together. They recruited a British bassist they'd met on the road
column3: Josephine Wiggs
column4: and their Boston friend Carrie Bradley would play violin. In 1990
column5: they released the great
column6: eerily primal Pod
column7: which Kurt Cobain loved
column8: cited as an inspiration on Nirvana
column9: and later dubbed
column10: ""an epic that will never let you forget your ex-girlfriend."" After that
column11: Donelly left to form Belly
column12: Dayton's Jim Macpherson became their permanent drummer
column13: and the Breeders found themselves in search of a new guitarist so they could go back into the studio with the bouncy
column14: grungy demos they'd been writing in 1992. Kim knew somebody back in Dayton. Could she play well? Well
column15: the thing was that she couldn't play at all. But she figured she could teach her pretty quickly
column16: because she was her twin.

column1: That's some of the psychic energy fueling one of alternative rock's most unlikely platinum records and most enduring masterpieces
column2: the Breeders' Last Splash: an indie-famous frontwoman who'd spent the last couple of years feeling increasingly fed up and creatively muzzled at her high-profile day job; an untrained lead guitarist joyriding up and down the fretboard and riding high on the freedom of please
column3: no chops; and maybe above all else a decade-delayed bar band family reunion. It's no wonder that 20 years later
column4: Last Splash still sounds as sloppy and beguiling and warm as the day it was pressed. Although the songs were meticulously crafted and revised
column5: and although the post-Nevermind boom had made the audience for a record this singularly weird suddenly visible
column6: in the end the Breeders sound like a couple of kids from Dayton (and one like-minded Brit) making up their own fun.

column1: Last Splash is a noise-pop record in the fullest sense of both of those words: It is a symphony of feedback but the melodies holding it all together are sweet enough to rot your teeth. From the squalling
column2: rhythmic dissonance of ""Roi"" to the melodic Lynchian lullaby ""Mad Lucas""
column3: the record is full of warm
column4: damaged beauty. Fresh off a tour with Nirvana
column5: the Breeders drove to San Francisco in a blizzard to record Last Splash with veteran producer Mark Freegard in the winter of 1993
column6: and the reissue’s liner notes describe the process as a series of sonic experiments. What's that corrosive whir that opens ""S.O.S.""? It's Kelley's sewing machine fed directly through a Marshall amp
column7: because why not. The distorted vocal on ""Cannonball"" happened because Kim (who shares a producer’s credit with Freegard) wondered what it'd sound like to sing through a harmonica mic and when they play the song live
column8: they still get that particular tone of the iconic opening vocal (""Ahhhhhoooo-oooh/Ahhhhhoooo-oooh"") not through some custom pedal
column9: but by putting a styrofoam cup over the mic. At times they resorted to measures even more DIY than that. The best take of Bradley's warbling strings on ""Mad Lucas"" was the one where
column10: by her account
column11: ""Kim and Kelley grabbed me on each side and shook me and quaked me while I played.""

column1: All of which might make Last Splash sound like a haphazard and amateurish affair
column2: but the collection of demos and the 1992 live show included in the extensive LSXX reissue tell a more complex story. Unlike their Dayton buddies Guided by Voices (the Breeders' own cover of ""Shocker in Gloomtown"" made the reissue
column3: along with the rest of 1994’s excellent Head to Toe EP)
column4: the Breeders crafted
column5: road tested
column6: and revised their tunes. Check
column7: for one example
column8: the completely reworked demo of ""No Aloha"" against the one that made the album. As all the extras on the reissue attest
column9: the genius of the Breeders lies in the balance between being tirelessly tinkering perfectionists who still understand how to embrace creative serendipity. So Last Splash is a tight record that's also alive with happy accidents. Perhaps the most famous example: the bassline's hesitant entrance on ""Cannonball""-- and we're talking about one of the most iconic basslines of the 90s-- was actually the product of a fortunate mistake. In a rehearsal
column10: Wiggs played the last note of the riff flat (twice in a row) but everybody thought it sounded cool
column11: so it became a part of the song.

column1: Wiggs and Macpherson are the unsung heroes of Last Splash; a driving-but-just-loose-enough rhythm section
column2: they gave the sprawl a backbone. But the Deals are the record’s charismatic center. It’s hard to imagine a frontwoman more perfect for a record so fixated on the tension between distressed textures and gleefully hooky melody. From her mirror-fogging enunciation of “No bye/No/A-lo-ha” to the way she delivers the title syllable of “Hag” like a cutting sidelong glance
column3: each note comes out of her mouth affixed with a halo of cartoon dirt
column4: like the one that hovers over Pigpen. Expressive yet enigmatic enough to cover a whole range of emotions
column5: Kim’s voice embodies that dirty-prettiness that makes Last Splash’s appeal so complex and hard to pin down. In a 1995 issue of Spin
column6: Charles Aaron called Last Splash ""the rare album that had all the I-need-you and you-gross-me-out emotions seamlessly bound together."" It can be mean one second (""You’re a nuisance
column7: and I don't like dirt"") and then deliver something as vulnerable and classically tender as ""Do You Love Me Now?"" the next. That it doesn’t always want to admit that it’s a romantic record only makes it more of a romantic record. The point is that it's sweet and gross and guarded and needy and cutting and gleeful because love can be all of those things too.

column1: The reissue is available either as a three-CD package or a vivid
column2: electric-brite vinyl box set
column3: though either prompts a fair question: “Why should I spring for a special edition of an album I can probably still find in the dollar bin?” For any Breeders fan
column4: though
column5: the extras make a convincing case. The live album (recorded in Stockholm in 1994) and disc of rarities and demos put the finished product in context
column6: while the array of EPs show off the wide stylistic range of everything the Breeders could do well. They’re all worth a listen
column7: though the wooly pop of Safari (Donnelly’s last recording with the band) and the later
column8: comparatively aggro Head to Toe (featuring the great
column9: Wiggs-penned title track-- a fan favorite) are the best of the bunch. The less essential Divine Hammer EP is notable for featuring “Do You Love Me Now Jr”-- a fittingly titled duet that features J Mascis
column10: who recalls his amusingly ill-fated attempt to produce some Breeders tracks in the liner notes. “I was not the best producer. I only wanted to work until 7 p.m. Kim got up about 3 p.m.
column11: so that didn’t leave much time before I would bail.” And as the duet proves
column12: their voices are about as compatible as their working hours.

column1: Still
column2: it was Mascis who once succinctly summed up the irony of Deal’s two great bands: “The Breeders seemed bigger than the Pixies
column3: and now the Pixies are way bigger than the Breeders.” In both instances
column4: it was a matter of being at the right place at the right time. With Last Splash
column5: the Breeders were poised to ride the cresting alt-rock wave that the Pixies had inspired but just missed out on
column6: and when the Pixies reunited in 2004
column7: the mounting nostalgia for late 80s/early 90s indie rock made it the perfect time for a long-delayed victory lap. But now it’s the Breeders’ turn to bask in a little bit of that nostalgic glory. LSXX is proof of an enduring benefit of sounding like nobody else: 20 years later
column8: these songs still sound fresh. The undeniable “Cannonball” may have made Last Splash an unlikely mainstream hit
column9: but as Kim reminds us in the liner notes
column10: “This is an indie record. Put out by 4AD.” She says “indie” proudly-- like it means something personal. And Last Splash proves it still can. As big as it made the Breeders
column11: it has a scrappy intimacy that captures what those early
column12: unrecorded
column13: make-your-own-fun Deal sister bar gigs must have sounded like. A million alt rock fans and all the bikers in Dayton
column14:
Ohio can't be wrong.

There’s a new Boards of Canada album coming out in a few weeks and Stephen Wilkinson is likely as excited as you are; after all
column3: he's never turned down the chance to express his intense fandom of the band. Even better news for him is that his seventh album as Bibio
column4: Silver Wilkinson
column5: will not be rendered redundant by Tomorrow’s Harvest. That wasn’t the case last time BoC released new material; the two would namedrop each other in interviews
column6: and when The Campfire Headphase finally allowed six-strings into the mix
column7: they were modeled after the kind of gelatinous
column8: wobbly guitars that defined Bibio’s early work on Mush. The presumptive show of mutual respect was the biggest thing Wilkinson had going for him at the time
column9: but now
column10: he shares not only a label with his heroes
column11: but a similar quandary: after creating such a definitive document of his sound
column12: he faces the redundancy that comes with competing with his own work.

column1: He actively courts this problem on Silver Wilkinson
column2: which junks the plasticine electro-pop that marred Mind Bokeh and returns to the warm splendor of 2009’s Ambivalence Avenue
column3: the record which began his second
column4: more rewarding phase. It was only then that he fully explored what it meant to be a producer with vision; he dabbled in songwriting
column5: beatmaking
column6: crate-digging and acoustic strumming
column7: sometimes all at once
column8: unifying it with an aesthetic that established an equilibrium between the pastoral and the digital (and proved perfect for selling Kindles). It’s a an all-inclusive
column9: welcoming sound that puts a wide range of potential conflicts of interests-- wafting British folk
column10: Dilla-fied hip-hop instrumentals
column11: psychedelic light funk-- into the same frame
column12: consistently providing pleasant surprises and never making a huge deal about how diverse it was.

column1: In short
column2: Bibio relies on an accumulative effect more than the strength of any individual songs. But when the ratios get thrown off even in the slightest
column3: the results come off as alternately distracted or monotonous. The first four songs on Silver Wilkinson contain no sound you haven’t already heard from him: aqueous atmosphere
column4: washed-out acoustics
column5: Wilkinson’s haunted vocals. They’re just allotted in less satisfying proportions; instrumentals “The First Daffodils” and “Wulf” are too short to offer immersion
column6: too long to qualify as interludes while “Dye the Water Green” and “Mirroring All” are humble folk songs burdened with too much found sound and drift to justify their five-minute lengths. Immediately after
column7: ""À tout à l'heure"" establishes some kind of momentum with a nimble acoustic riff and a spirited
column8: stomping rhythm
column9: but by the time you get there
column10: Silver Wilkinson has exhausted nearly one third of its run time.

column1: And that gets to the mundane issue at the center of Silver Wilkinson
column2: which is that it’s a layering of holding patterns. It either idles too long in genial background
column3: or gets to relatively exciting productions which specifically recall his previous work. The combination of light
column4: bumping funk and analog nerd synths on “Look At Orion!” is a canny move on Bibio’s part
column5: establishing himself as the missing link between labelmates Boards of Canada and Flying Lotus
column6: but it barely builds on that idea. “You” is sequenced as the literal centerpiece of Silver Wilkinson and the figurative one-- the hiccupping samples and percussive jump cuts remind you that his whole aesthetic is more hip-hop than anything. There’s something underhanded about it
column7: though; it’s meant to be a gaudy display of Wilkinson’s range surrounded by the overt naturalism of “Sycamore Silhouetting” and “Raincoat”
column8: when really it’s just a minor variation on Ambivalence Avenue’s “Fire Ant”.

column1: None of the above makes Silver Wilkinson a bad album
column2: far from it. It just questions what Bibio’s true strengths are; the melodies and arrangements are nice
column3: but does he have a go-to skill besides curation? If it’s your first experience with Bibio
column4: there’s a lot to like here and thankfully
column5: Silver Wilkinson renders Mind Bokeh’s “Take Off Your Shirt” as distant and out of character as an embarrassing Spring Break memory. And yet
column6: it can make someone who’s followed Bibio since the beginning nostalgic for the willingness to take that kind of risk. The problem is that while Ambivalence Avenue was a pleasant surprise in all forms
column7: an astounding leap from an unexpected source that constantly offered new sounds
column8:
Silver Wilkinson provides the same thing without the surprises. And all that’s left is the pleasant part.

It’s tempting to play what-if with Love’s lost labor
column2: Black Beauty
column3: which was recorded in 1973 but shelved for nearly four decades. What if Buffalo Records hadn’t gone out of business just prior to the album’s release? What if Black Beauty had actually hit stores? What if it hadn’t languished in limbo until years after Arthur Lee’s death? Would it have stopped Love’s slide into obscurity? Would it have signaled a comeback for the man who masterminded Forever Changes
column4: still one of the most complex and compelling artifacts of 1960s Los Angeles? Would his life and career have played out any differently? Would we think of him today as something other than a cult artist
column5: inspired as well as damned by his era?

column1: It’s difficult to imagine any answers to those questions
column2: but it says a lot about Lee that the album even raises these what-ifs and coulda-beens. The very qualities that made him such a fascinating voice-- restlessness
column3: excitability
column4: paranoia
column5: perfectionism
column6: single-mindedness-- may have doomed any commercial prospects more than his notorious fear of travel ever did. After recording Forever Changes
column7: he fired the band and hired new musicians to take their places. Every subsequent album featured a different line-up

column6: and performing music. ""If 'the realm of freedom is established progressively by the development of human powers as an end in itself' and I am freedom rocker

column3: stretching to darker

column5: slowcore pace. It's a more serious and multi-dimensional record
column6: its poised weariness the sound of experience and devotion

column1: On Gemini and Golden Haze

Tatum will be the first to admit he doesn’t put too much stock in his lyrics and his chosen genres can tolerate plenty of nonsense. But it's a little hard to take when Tatum’s stonefaced sincerity doesn’t break on a line like
column4: “I’ll be your monkey/ Every night/ If it makes you love me.”

column2: what he has done is composed a couple of bum instrumentals. You can’t just toss out “On Guyot” and “Hachiko” if you value Empty Estate as a full experience; credit where it’s due

column6: regardless of the outcome
column7:
a gradually evolving songwriter like Tatum benefits from not waiting two years between releases.

Eight years into a career that had started at a reclaimed church in Athens
column2: Georgia

column4: the members of R.E.M. were getting restless. They’d been touring almost nonstop throughout the 1980s and were understandably growing tired of their assigned instruments and their assumed roles in the band. So in 1988
column5: when they holed up in a local studio to demo new songs

column1: The immediate result of this intraband game of musical chairs was “You Are the Everything”

column1: This alone would have been sufficient to establish Green as pivotal in R.E.M.’s catalog. Released on November 8

Against the military stomp of “Orange Crush” he sings through a megaphone that lends his vocals a corroded quality appropriate to the subject matter (namely

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19185/homepage_large.5e798442.jpg|The Way Things Fall|25.0|ADULT.|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ghostly']|2013-05-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:57:56.232819|"

ADULT. never quite fit in with the electroclash outfits they were grouped in with during their rise to sorta-fame in the early 2000s. Detroit's Adam Lee Miller and Nicola Kuperus had the same mix of dance music sounds and punk aesthetics that their largely New York-based peers did
column2: but none of the downtown glitz and coked-up post-9/11 escapism. Instead they projected something more intense and unsettling
column3: a faceless anxiety that pitched French existentialist horror through a bleak Midwestern Rust Belt worldview.

column1: Over a decade after the release of their first album
column2: most of ADULT.’s electroclash-affiliated contemporaries have fallen off the map
column3: and the post-millennial tension that made them seem so timely back then has evolved into something different. But that sense of deep alienation still pervades The Way Things Fall
column4: the duo’s fifth  album
column5: although like the music it’s embedded in
column6: it’s become subtler and more intriguing.

column1: The pair’s approach to making music has previously relied heavily on discomfort: synthesizers and drum machines EQ’d to remove whatever hints of warmth they might once have had
column2: Kuperus’ monotone delivery a microtone off key
column3: an aura of harsh
column4: treble-heavy distortion surrounding pretty much everything. On The Way Things Fall
column5: though
column6: they’ve dialed down the more outright aggression
column7: and aimed more directly for pop appeal than ever before. Everything’s cleaner
column8: smoother
column9: and considerably less prickly.

column1: The apotheosis of this new approach is “Tonight
column2: We Fall”
column3: an easily accessible piece of sleek new wave engineering
column4: with a straightforward rock drum beat
column5: burbling bass
column6: and a recurring synth lead that sticks mainly to a major scale and only barely veers into the kind of woozy pitch bends that are one of the pair’s favorite discomfiting compositional techniques. Kuperus backs up the broadly hooky vocal melody with an emotional performance verging on the melodramatic
column7: and far removed from her usual angry-cyborg style.

column1: Kuperus and Miller haven’t exactly transformed into affable pop artists
column2: though. This newfound emphasis on catchiness is just another vehicle for delivering the same kind of unease that ADULT.’s always specialized in. It’s just sneakier now. On its surface “Tonight
column3: We Fall” reads like a straightforward swooning love song. Kuperus opens the song by asking
column4: “Will we
column5: will we live like this/ Forever
column6: ” which is the kind of vaguely philosophical inquiry that we expect a bittersweet new wave love song to ask. But when Kuperus answers her own question things get complicated. “This feeling came over me
column7: ” she sings
column8: “It sticks to you
column9: sticks to me/ Forever.” If it’s love she’s talking about
column10: like the song’s tone sets us up to expect
column11: it doesn’t sound like something you’d want to touch. It sounds more like a curse.

column1: Using well-worn pop tropes to establish a set of expectations in the listener only to subvert them as thoroughly as possible is a pattern that repeats itself throughout The Way Things Fall. The stacked arpeggios on “Love Lies” sets up an unhurried Gary Numan groove that Kuperus uses as a platform to declaim on the falseness of human emotion. “Heartbreak” comes on like a 70s space disco jam then drops a creepily dissonant chromatic bridge that can make the hairs on the back of your neck stand up. Of course this kind of anxiety is exactly what ADULT.’s fans want from them. For whatever perverse reasons we want to be unsettled by their music
column2: and made psychically uncomfortable. They’ve always delivered
column3:
but never before with this sense of style.
